text: I am a skeptic by nature, a physicist by training, and an oenophile by pleasure.The idea of catalyzing the removal of CO2 from wine didn't seem too far fetched. But then I received this item. It has a stopper that goes in the bottle, but that would seem to defeat the idea of removing CO2 from the wine. Why seal the bottle and cause a build up of pressure, which inhibits outgassing? And then include a pump to remove the CO2, which would naturally leave the bottle if it wasn't stopped?I saw no sign of any removal of CO2, buildup of pressure, or effect of using the pump when trying this item on several bottles of wine. Nor did I notice any improvement in taste.If this thing does anything I suspect it involves the long, rough grooves in the ceramic having a lot of surface area which would hold air against them and, when plunged in the wine, allow the oxygen in the air to slightly aerate the wine.Mostly, I suspect, this device relies on the placebo effect. If that works for some people, it may be worth the cost ...

I got a Netgear Zing, and can't get more than one bar with it. So I tried this antenna. Attached it, put it in the window, still one bar. Moved it around, articulated it, still one bar. Might work for some people, but didn't help me.

I bought an SSD to speed up my old laptop, and needed a USB adapter to clone the old drive. This adapter is bare bones, but was cheap and did the job. Couldn't ask for anything more. (Just be sure it's the right adapter for your drive.)

I have an old Fujitsu laptop I liked, except for its speed. Especially the time it took to boot. I'd check into the hotel, start it up, then unpack while I waited for it to boot.I thought an SSD might help, and this one was pretty much the choice. I didn't pay a lot of attention when I ordered it, and didn't realize it would ship from China. And on the slow boat from China, at that. (No fault of the product, of course.)When it finally arrived I set it to the side, and didn't get back to it until a few days ago. Well, the old gray mare is moving faster than she has in years. No, she's no modern race horse. But for use on a trip now and then (I'm on one as I write this) the experience is no longer painful.A new laptop is still on my horizon. But this drive is a cheap way to get some more months out of the one I have.By the way, if you get it as a replacement drive you'll probably want to get a USB adapter so you can clone your current drive. I used: Micro SATA Cables - USB to 50 Pin IDE/ZIF HDD Adapter with USB Cable.

I was curious how Gray was going to move from elements to molecules. The elements are a fixed and defined set, so the book organized itself. But molecules are a huge and complex set, beyond the ability of any book to discuss them all.Gray's solution is effective. He groups molecules into groups that will be meaningful to the reader. Thus he has sections on, for example, salts, soaps, and artificial sweeteners. Salts have a strong meaning to chemists, as well as to lay readers. Soaps are less clearly a clean chemical concept, but still meaningful to readers. Artificial sweeteners represent a desired end to industrial chemists more than a group of similar molecules, but are still of interest to readers. Thus he bridges the gap between the science of molecules and keeping a reader's interest.The format is superficially similar to The Elements, with lavish illustrations, discussions of applications, and technical information about each category. Definitely a beguiling volume.What the book lacks, in comparison to The Elements, is the irrefutable logic and sense of completeness of the earlier volume. Which it could never have. At first I leaned toward four stars because The Molecules didn't quite meet the standard set by The Elements. But, then, it couldn't, so that is an unfair standard. Judged on its own merits, this is a five star book.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

Note: my Acura TSX takes one 26" and one 16".My first impression was that they look pretty good, at least for wiper blades. (I'm not that into wiper blades, really.)The instructions are minimalist: two steps, "Identify wiper arm" and "Install new wiper blade". There are three sets of pictures for three different installations. The pictures are small--Bosch couldn't afford to print them on a full size piece of paper so they'd be easy to see?--but a quick squint and I had the general idea. My installation required squeezing tabs to lift a cover. Not that easy with bare fingers, but I used needle nose pliers for one, which made it much easier.Slipping them on was easy, as was lowing the cover. They hug the windshield well enough, and pick up the windshield washer fluid cleanly and effectively. Plenty good blades for a non-connoisseur.

For some reason not everyone enjoys the smell of a sweaty bear. But you can't always hop in the shower when the need arises. When traveling, for example.These wipes worked better than I expected them to. Although about the size of one of those hand wipes that come with the BBQ, these are plusher and have a lot more, and much gentler, cleaning fluid. A quick wipe of the offending areas and the offensive smell is replaced by a subtle, powder smell. These are going in my bag for use on those long trips when I need a freshness reset.

I'll start with the chocolate, of which there are four varieties:Milk: I'm not a big milk chocolate fan, but this one is a bit richer and darker than the norm.Semisweet: Again fairly rich, but somewhat light and sweet for my taste.Bittersweet: At 70% cacao it is close to the 72% Ghirardelli I often buy, but it tastes lighter and sweeter.Extra Dark: This was my favorite. For an 82% cacao chocolate it is quite rich and smooth. It actually is closer in taste to the 72% Ghirardelli than is the bittersweet.Overall these are good chocolates, but I wouldn't rate them as being all that special.The gimmick is the idea of pairing them with wines. (Which is not novel, other manufacturers have long packaged chocolates for wine pairing.) To this end two small booklets are included in the package. One is about half about how great John Scharffenberger is, and about half a brief introduction to the history and production of chocolate. The other is about the pairing. This second booklet was obviously written for a different product, because it only refers to three of the four varieties (the milk is not included). The pairing information is minimal, and specific wines, down to the vintage, are recommended. More recent vintages of those wines are currently being marketed, again suggesting the booklet is leftover from another product.Also, the hinged lid on the box is cheap and hard to open and to keep on the box.Not a bad product, but not a great one or a great deal.

I ordered this, and then the closing spring on a door started squeaking. Next a cooling fan in a small appliance started rattling. So I had uses for this oil upon arrival.It fixed the door squeak just fine. But the snout was too blunt to get oil into the fan bearing. WD40 helped that one, although I ended up replacing the fan.As for this oil being dry, it isn't really. It feels less oily than regular 3-IN-ONE, and it doesn't leave a very oily feel on surfaces. But it is still an oil, and doesn't have the dry feel of, say, a Teflon lubricant.This seems to be a good lube when you don't want to leave a typically oily feel or sheen on a surface.
This product cleans well, and leaves a nice shine. It won't work miracles and make a worn surface glow, but it shines as well as any competing product I've tried. The smell is soft and pleasant.

From a purely functional viewpoint, this soap dispenser efficiently dispenses soap. And the big plunger on the top makes the dispensing easy.From an aesthetic standpoint, tastes will vary. Some will see the design as modern, others as industrial. What I hadn't thought through was that the stainless steel part spots very easily. So keeping it looking nice means wiping it off a lot. And that leans more industrial than modern.Overall, it does the job, in a basic kind of way.

Having just read another children's book that places a penguin in the arctic, I understand the little puffin's anger. Penguins are very in, but they only live in the southern hemisphere.* This little puffin gets tired of being mistaken for a penguin, and goes on a little rant. Sure, he's a bit unfair to penguins. But he has a point, and rants don't tend to be fair.Cute and informative, this is a fun little book.Not to spoil the story, but it ends on a puffin-friendly note.* While the book refers to penguins living in the antarctic, there are also penguins in the Galapagos Islands. But that is still in the southern hemisphere. Definitely no penguins in the arctic.I was provided a copy for review by the publisher.

A young Inuit and his dog take off on an adventure, led by a star, ultimately to the northern lights. So far, so good.But, almost immediately, they pick up a penguin to take along for the ride. A penguin. In the arctic.There are no penguins in the northern hemisphere. Puffins, yes. Penguins, no. And I'm pretty sure there are no penguins in Inuit legends.Sure, penguins are in, and penguins are cute. But they don't belong in the arctic, and they don't belong in a retelling of an Inuit legend.Sorry, but for my taste an author can't take this kind of liberty with a story and claim is it based on a native legend.I was provided a copy for review by the publisher.As the paper and Kindle versions of this book are not linked, I've posted this review to both.

This knife is probably hurt by Amazon's description saying "this utility knife is a perfect choice for cutting meats, slicing vegetables, or tackling a loaf of bread". Oxo's own packaging more modestly says it slices "soft fruits and tomatoes".This knife it too short to use as a bread knife. (It might slice a small roll.) As for meat, think the over-sized steak knife some steak houses give you as they try to convince you that everything they offer is big.So here's where my niche problem comes in. I have a Messermeister tomato knife that is nearly as long as this knife, but with a narrower blade and smaller serrations. It's perfect for tomatoes. As I go beyond it's limits, I have high quality, non-serrated, knives that I keep sharp. So this knife doesn't really fill a need in my kitchen.That said, this is a very inexpensive knife for its quality. For someone who doesn't have good quality knives, or doesn't want to keep sharpening them, this knife may fill a niche.Finally, there is the question of the handle. It is rather bulbous. I have small hands, and I don't like the feel of this knife. For someone with larger hands, or trouble gripping things, maybe due to arthritis, it could be a much better fit.

Having received this product, I no longer had an excuse not to clean my car. So I did.It worked fine on all my internal materials. It warned that too much fluid would lead to streaking, and it did. But that was the only real negative I encountered, and it was stated upfront, and was not out of class for this type of product.I did like that it didn't have a strong chemical smell. I finally decided that it smelled a bit of yeast, but think whiff of brewery, not fresh bread.Overall, a good product.

My first thought on opening this is that it's something of a brick. Not really that large or heavy but, as something to pack, kind of a brick.It paired with my phone, and the sound is pretty good for its size. It's mono, but the instructions helpfully explain how to pair two of them to get stereo. That, of course, means carrying two bricks.It also serves as a USB charger. But you can get that in a much smaller package.I see this as fitting a small niche. It's a little big to travel with. At home you don't need something compact, you can accept larger solutions. For me, small, wired, USB speakers are a better choice for travel. But if you need a small Bluetooth speaker, this unit delivers

I noticed that some reviewers were concerned about speed on this card, so I stressed it as much as I care about. I put it in its adapter, put it in my Canon 70D, and shot about a minute of full res video. That's an application that doesn't require a smaller form factor, but it's the most stressful test readily available to me. Passed without a hiccup.This chip formats at just under 64 billion bytes. It comes in at 59.4 GB by normal standards, which is usual. Some could quibble about the labeling, but as someone who remembers floppies, I just see lots of memory.It does everything I want, so I'm completely happy with it.

The Walter Pons Trio recorded soft jazz versions of some popular tunes about fifty years ago. Knowing these recordings only from a handed-down vinyl album, I wondered if they would ever be professionally digitized.I've found a few tracks on other albums, but the transfers were poor. These transfers are excellent. They sound about as good as a fifty year old record is ever going to sound.The original album has a blurb from "Der Bingle" (Bing Crosby) saying how much he enjoyed hearing the trio. These are clean, simple, and innocent arrangements performed by a very talented trio. The very fact that after half a century there is still an interest in this album is testimony to it being worthy of notice. If you are looking for edge you won't find it here. If you are looking for music Der Bingle might have relaxed to at the end of the day, you've found it.

This book obviously isn't aimed at someone wanting an in-depth understanding of our solar system. It contains basic information presented graphically. The astronomical history is simplistic, and the presentation of the Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram is skeletal. But there aren't glaring errors, and someone knowing little about the solar system going in will know a little more coming out.Probably more for a child just being introduced to the solar system than one who's already shown an interest and wants to learn more than this book is prepared to offer.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

I'm something of a sucker for bear books. (Go figure.) And this is a cute one. A little bear prepares for hibernation with his mother. He says goodnight to the animals of the forest first.In reality, of course, some of those animals wouldn't go near a bear. But it's a kiddy's book, and it's all in fun.The illustrations are nice, but not exceptional. The goodbyes are a little repetitions.Amazon lists this as ages 4-8, but I'm thinking more 2-4. This is a read-to book for the little ones who will like the animal pictures as much as the simple prose.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

I have some qualms with this book. Some are questions of presentation, others are errors of fact. I consider these issues to be of particular significance because this book is intended to draw a child's attention to errors of science past.For example, the author says the planets move in oval paths. While I accept the concern with expecting a child to understand the concept of an ellipse, the problem is that a child may have a sense of the word "oval" that is inaccurate for the case of planetary orbits, which are very close to circular. Perhaps something like "the orbits of the planets are not quite circles, being stretched slightly into ovals" would have been better.The author uses the term "optical illusion" to describe the apparent motion of planets. But their apparent motion is not an optical illusion, it is exactly as seen. And it is easily understood in a heliocentric, but not in a geocentric, solar system.This book asserts that "First, people sent spacecraft to orbit Mars." The first Mars probes were flybys, which sent back the first pictures showing Mars as a cratered planet.It is noted that "wobble" (which I consider a poor choice of term) of another planet's orbit led to the discovery of Pluto. While having some historical truth, the book fails to note that the calculations that inspired the discovery of Pluto were in error. Instead, it leaves the issue open.The author mentions the legend of Galileo dropping objects off of the Tower of Pisa. It didn't happen, but the author could have devoted a paragraph or two to the experiments Galileo actually did.While many of these are nits, taken together this isn't as good a book as the concept would have allowed for.I was provided a copy for review by the publisher.Note: At the time of posting this review Amazon has separate and unlinked listings for the paperback and library bindings of this book. I have, therefore, posted this review to both.

I have, therefore, posted this review to both.

To begin, I have a very tough beard, and have trouble getting a good shave even with a blade. But my face doesn't like being scraped with blades every day, so when I need to shave on a weekend I tend to go electric.The best electrics I've ever found are by Panasonic, and the ES8243 I currently use is the best electric I've ever found. But it's not perfect, so I'm open to trying other options.This Remington is interesting because the instructions are written for four different models that don't actually have the same instructions. You are told to charge it for 24 hr before use, but the nominal instructions don't describe its behavior, so you have to piece it together. It turned out that the shaver came fully charged. While I understand the need to condition rechargeable batteries, I'm a bit at a loss as to why they want you to charge fully charged batteries for 24 hr.Most current electrics have a head that pivots on the theory that it will better conform to the shape of your face that way. What I have found is that, with a beard as tough as mine, I need to control the angle of the shaver to get a good result. The Panasonics, and some other shavers, allow you to lock the head; this shaver doesn't. I wasn't able to get a good shave with it.For someone with a light beard this shaver might work well. For me, it didn't.

This is advertised as being usable as a tie, as well as a scarf, rack. It is for that purpose I use it. While it easily holds a lot of ties, I can see where it might disappoint as a scarf rack due to its size.Although the welds are not very neat, they look like that should hold well, and this item isn't really intended for show. The chrome finish is shiny and has only a few, small, blemishes. More importantly, it is smooth with no flaws that will snag silk.Nothing special, but it's fine as a tie rack for the closet.

OK, a publisher is willing to give you a free copy of a book about sex for a review. Of course you agree.Well, maybe not of course. A key point here is that this is a book by serious authors who want to get the facts out. Yes, they have a sense of humor. They are even willing to titillate a bit. But this book is not raunchy, nor does it pander. If that's what you are looking for, this isn't the book for you.The structure of the book is a series of "myths" that some people hold about sex. (I'd say some are far more widely held than others.) They are grouped into sections about men, women, sex, disease, and pregnancy. In each case the authors discuss the best science or surveys available to determine the likely truth. When there is no sound basis to decide, they admit as much.So you can learn, among many other things, how men really measure up. (And how researchers really measure men!) What really is safe. How you really get infected. And how pregnancy really happens. And what won't prevent it.On that last point, I'm amazed that there is enough ignorance out there to support myths like a woman can't get pregnant if she has sex in the water. People really believe that? And there are more like it!The myths are treated as self-contained discussions (although there is an occasional reference to another myth). This is likely good if you read a chapter here and there. But reading the book straight through it leads to some repetition of material. In fact, there are two discussions of premature ejaculation in two different sections, with a lot of common material between them.Written with a solid but light touch, and seemingly well researched, this is an interesting book for someone interested in sex (i.e., most people) and also interested in understanding the facts thereabout (perhaps fewer people).The publisher provided me a copy for review. In case you didn't pick that up. (The authors, by the way, discuss the myth that two condoms are better than one. I won't spoil the surprise.)

The combination of the reduced size of the popular APS-C sensors with advances in optical glasses and fabrication of aspheric lenses has allowed the creation of compact lenses with remarkable zoom ranges. This lens spans 16-300 mm, a zoom ratio of 18.75. (With the Canon APS-C factor of 1.6, this is a 35 mm equivalent of about 26-480. At the long end that's quite a telephoto!) All this in a package slightly smaller than my Sigma 18-200 from a few years ago.It is, however, a little bigger than its less ambitious competitors, the earlier Tamron AF 18-270 and the Sigma 18-250. Mounted on my 70D it has a nice balance. On a smaller body it might seem a bit big for a "compact" zoom.Overall it feels well made, a bit better than the 18-270.To be clear, my rating is for its class, not against a set of prime lenses or a pair of smaller range zooms. This is a lens for when you want to travel light. By its nature it's pretty slow at the long end (f/6.3), which is unavoidable without increasing the lens diameter. It's sharp, but not razor sharp. I see only a little pincusion at the long end, but some clear barrel at the wide end. All typical of this kind of lens, but overall fairly well controlled.This is a lens for carrying around, taking on a hike or a trip, or to an event. It's not a lens for studio work, serious architectural photography (although it will do OK in its mid zoom range), or where you are worried about parallel lines.In other words, it is good at what it claims to be, a fairly compact lens with a huge zoom and without excessive compromises.

I'm a long time user of CorelDraw, and sill prefer it for vector graphics. (I'm forced to do graphics in PowerPoint at work, and when you've used a program like CorelDraw you understand that PowerPoint is not a graphics program!)For someone serious about computer drawing it's hard to go wrong with Corel. You can do just about anything with it, and if you check out some of the art users have generated with it, people have done just about everything with it. (That, of course, also requires a level of artistic talent I don't have.)PhotoPaint is decent photo/bitmap image editor that has improved over the years. The convenience of being able to edit bitmaps "within" CorelDraw is certainly a plus. But I'm a long time Photoshop user, and still prefer it for photo editing. With Adobe having moved to a monthly payment model, however, PhotoPaint looks more appealing in comparison, and the price for the two programs bundled is hard to beat.The value of upgrading from a recent version is less clear. Corel lists a bunch of new features, but they are mostly minor. There are some new options for customization of the interface and workflow, for example, but nothing that really makes the new version more valuable to me.Do note that with X7 Windows XP is no longer supported.

When my Ergo Lounger disintegrated after a few years of use I decided to try something different. After reading some of the negative reviews of Ostrich products, I decided to try this one. Turns out it's an Ostrich, even though the description avoids mentioning that.Some reviewers have complained that it is flimsy, but it's designed to be easily portable, and that implies lightweight construction. It's easy to carry and not overly fragile, at least so far as I have experienced.On the other hand, it's not really a lounge, it's a chair with a footrest. I assume the model in the pictures is quite short, as my legs extend well beyond the end of the footrest, and I'm not very tall. It lies flat, but only sort of. There is a concave region and gap right at your lower back when you flatten it out. (I use a cushion from the old Ergo Lounger to cover and flatten that region.) The handles jut up at an awkward angle when the chair is flat, which inhibits ingress and egress.I do like the flap to cover the reading hole when you aren't using it. On the other hand, the cushions around the reading hole are small and not really up to the job; I supplement them with another cushion salvaged from the Ergo Lounger.So it's adequate, but no more than that.

Sandra is very, very smart. Sandra can be very insightful, and very amusing. But Sandra is a prima donna (she's a performance artist, after all--not exactly the realm of those of normal ego).As Sandra relates her life during her period of change--apparently, if I interpret the acknowledgements correctly, in somewhat fictionalized form--she is often insightful and very often funny. But there are times when her self-absorption and sense of entitlement cause a bit of cringing. Many women go through the symptoms she went through, but most won't view themselves as being as special as she views herself.Fortunately, the worst of the self-indulgence is in the first half of the book, and it's easier to laugh and enjoy the ride later on.For all the humor of this book, I walked away from it thinking I would not want to actually be someone close to Sandra. She seems to suck the life out of her sphere of influence to feed her performance art. From a distance, however, it's possible to laugh.Overall the humor and insight carry the day, but there were some intensely self-centered stretches that were cringe-inducing to read.

"God Bless America" and "This Land is Your Land" are two seminal songs about America. Their paths to composition, however, were very different, and actually linked.This book brings together three threads. The first is about American musical traditions, from minstrelsy to hillbilly, that provide the background for the two songs. Second are the alternating biographies of two composers who had many things in common, yet were very different in outlook. Finally, there are the details of how each song came to be written.Berlin and Guthrie both rose from aching poverty to success. Both were strong advocates for civil rights and integration. Berlin was a Jew who married a Gentile over her father's objection. Guthrie was a Christian who married a Jew over her father's objection. But they had very different worldviews.When Berlin was a child his family came to America to escape the pogroms in Russia. They were very poor, but there were no pogroms in America, and it was a time of opportunity. Berlin became successful at a young age, and was wealthy and famous by the time of the Depression. He felt a deep love and gratitude toward America.Guthrie, a generation younger, grew up poor in Oklahoma, and experienced both the Depression and the Dust Bowl as a young man. He saw a nation with both wealth and poverty, one that failed to take care of the poor and needy. He became a leftist and communist sympathizer.Shaw looks at the history of anthems, and particularly American anthems, and discusses how they arise from their times, and sometimes fall out of favor. (He frequently mentions "Yankee Doodle".) One, "America the Beautiful", was an influence for both Berlin and Guthrie. Shaw also discusses how different American musical traditions influenced the two songwriters. Tin Pan Alley, from whence Berlin arose, had strong roots in minstrelsy. I was surprised to learn that Berlin, who insisted on an integrated cast when he produced "This is the Army" during World War II (the real Army was not integrated) also included a blackface number! Guthrie's musical roots were different, more aligned with what might now be considered country.When, in 1938, Kate Smith wanted a patriotic song from Berlin he, being both sincerely patriotic and also very fearful of the Nazis (recall he was a Jew whose family fled pogroms in Russia) reworked a song he had cut from a WW I production into "God Bless America", which was an immediate hit, filling a need the American public had for such an anthem at that time.Guthrie and his crowd had different feelings. In fact, Guthrie started "This Land is Your Land" as a response, and included leftest and communist verses in the early versions. He reworked it many times over many years, but what we know today is far from his original version.But America is a great assimilator, if not always a melting plot. Both songs have become embraced and loved as part of our heritage.Ultimately, life is not fair. Berlin lived to be 101, and lived well for most of those years. Guthrie died at 55 of Huntington's disease, following fifteen years of very poor health.This book is fascinating, well researched, and well written. One criticism is that the author knows almost too much about America's musical history, and sometimes wanders away from the central story for too long in displaying his knowledge. A bit more editing would have resulted in a tighter book.This is a niche book, but if you find the premise interesting you should enjoy it.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

To be honest up front, I was not able to test any of the proposed uses for a dinosaur. Not only do I not have a dinosaur at home, it turns out no one I know has one, either. I thought I might pick one up on Amazon but, while searching on "dinosaur" yielded 94,015 items, not one was a real dinosaur! So I suppose the uses must remain more theoretical than practical.But that, of course, is the point. This is a book to amuse a little one who loves dinosaurs. The pictures are colorful and well drawn. The prose is fun, if not sparkling. It is written in a way that allows the little one to imagine his or her scale compared to dinosaurs of different sizes. And it offers helpful hints about how not to use a dinosaur. (You might want to keep it away from your lunch!)I was provided a copy for review by the publisher. But I may order a copy for my niece. Then finding a dinosaur to test the uses with will be my brother's problem ...

Greg Bellow, oldest son of Saul, has written a memoir of his life with (and, often, without) his father, and with the extended family and world his father created. For anyone familiar with the Bellow story, it will come as no shock that there is a lot of heartache in the story. Saul Bellow was married five times, carried his disputes with his wives and others around him into his books, and was known as a curmudgeon in his later life.(Tolstoy's comment that "every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way" comes to mind reading the story of the Bellow family.)It is difficult to evaluate a book like this one. You read it because it is about Saul, but it is the memoir of Greg. It is Greg's story, but he knows that what the reader wants to hear about is Saul. But he can't tell his story without drifting away from Saul at times.While seemingly not a great premise for a book, the topic of Saul Bellow is important enough that the book adds to our understanding of one of the great writers of the twentieth century. While hardly objective, the son's memoir allows a viewpoint on Saul's pains and the pains he inflicted on others that it would be hard for an objective biographer to achieve. A reader should, of course, read it with a grain of salt. But a Bellow lover should read it.Greg Bellow is a (retired) psychotherapist, and his training and experience both adds to and subtracts from the story. Sometimes his training provides insight into Saul's behavior, but at other times the analysis gets a bit in the way of the flow of the story.Of particular interest is the author's evaluation of the evolution of the "Young Saul" into the "Old Saul". In his youth Bellow was a very progressive voice. Late in life he became very conservative, and often not in a constructive way. Greg provides a lot of discussion of the transition, but mostly from a personal viewpoint of how it led to differences with his father. (Importantly, he discusses the influence Allan Bloom had on Bellow.)My takeaway from the discussion is that Bellow was disillusioned when his progressive ideas failed to lead to a greatly improved society, which he likely also saw as undermining his chance to be seen as a prophet. His son takes it more personally, as a betrayal of earlier, commonly-held beliefs. I think this is an example of where the author's closeness to the subject gets in the way of the story.Nonetheless, warts and all, this is a good book to have. And it's hard to see how we could have a book with this valuable viewpoint without some warts.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

My prior experience with Undset was reading the epic Kristin Lavransdatter set in medieval Norway.* This work is very different.Marta Oulie is an introspective (but not autobiographical) novel. Like many young authors in early works, Undset is exploring how she differs from those around her. Her perspective on the world is big, and her surrounding seem to constrain her. The conventional and expected life doesn't fit her.Marta has the additional burden of being a woman in a world that hasn't yet accepted women working after marriage, much less being full participants in intellectual life. (Although early twentieth-century Norway was hardly as oppressive as many societies.)While Marta is self-centered--hardly a rarity among author-surrogate characters, as authors tend to need to be self-centered to endure the obstacles to success--she is also acutely aware of how she hurts those around her, something not always found in this type of early, introspective, novel.Marta tries at, fails at, yet again tries at love with her husband. But the pieces never completely fit together, because her inner life never completely fits with her outer life. She can dissect the problems with herself and her life analytically, but she can't impose solutions on herself emotionally.This is a short but remarkable book. It provides an insight into Undset the person that a reader could never deduce from reading a work like Kristin Lavransdatter. Highly recommended.I was provided a copy for review by the publisher.* A more recent translation, which I have not read, is available: Kristin Lavransdatter.

This book excels where you would expect National Geographic to excel. The descriptions of the place, the history, and the people is excellent.For example, although I thought I knew a lot about Brazil, I hadn't known that the Atlantic Forest was "[o]nce a rival to the Amazon in size". Wow! It's hard to imagine someone reading through this book and not wanting to visit Brazil.But, then, there are the practicalities. This is a book of about three hundred pages about a country of about three million square miles. So the coverage of accommodations is thin, as it must be in any short guidebook to any large place. Sure, the internet lets you fill in the details nowadays. But understand the limitations of this, generally very well done, book before you rely on it.

Yes, it will clean your dishes. But what caught my eye was the "Crystal Clean Shine!" claim. Maybe this product would really end the mineral buildup on my glasses.Alas, no. Using this Oxy-clean product actually left my dishes with a bit more of a film than the Cascade Gel I was using. So OK, but not the best.

These towels are very white, have a nice pattern, and take up water nicely. They do what I want a kitchen towel to do.At the next level, the finish is so-so. The hems are narrow and there are lots of thread ends showing. This doesn't matter for functionality, but these are not towels for show.So abuse them for everyday needs, but don't look too closely at them.

This book has several sections that consist of a word (like "star" or "sun"), a black and white shape related to the word, and a following page with the shape repeated several times in a colorful image.While visually fine, I think an adult sharing this book with an infant will use it with an expanded narration. Curiously, the back cover praises "its high contrast, black and white illustrations", while I found the color illustrations far more eye-catching.Overall OK, but nothing special.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

For context, I am a physicist by training, and well versed in relativity theory. And I've been faced with the challenge of explaining relativity, and therefore know it's not as easy as it may sound.Overall, I will say that Bennett has done a good job. He walks through many simple examples, slowly building up the story of what Einstein realized and codified from his student days through the final papers on the general theory. It's a cute but non-obtrusive choice to have many examples place the reader in a scenario with his or her friend "Al" as the second party.While I don't know of a better choice for the beginning relativist, this book is not quite perfect. I think Bennett draws out some of his scenarios a bit long; most readers will either have gotten the idea or aren't going to. He opens with the idea of someone traveling to a distant star and aging slower, but defers the "twin paradox" this raises until much later in the book, when he is into the general theory and ready to explain it. (This is fine if you believe that your readers won't figure out that there is a "relativity" problem with the story and spend chapters wondering what is going on.)My biggest issue with the book centers on a personal peeve, and maybe most people won't care about it. Bennett employs the rubber bedsheet model, and while he admits it has limitations, to me it misses the point of the general theory. The rubber bedsheet model invokes a mythical gravitational force at the bottom of the page that has nothing to do with relativity. The curvature of spacetime is intrinsic to spacetime, and I find this model to be a distraction.This book also fails to highlight what I consider the most profound aspect of relativity. Einstein began by realizing that light is seen to travel at the same speed in every reference frame. But the special theory teaches us that what we think of as the speed of light is merely a conversion constant between space and time units, which are really the same. Bennett introduces the idea of setting the speed of light as 1, but doesn't really talk about how fundamental a geometric principle that has become in physics. In the general theory we learn that light travels on a null geodesic, which ultimately separates the casual from the noncasual. I realize this may be a little deep for a popular book, but it is, to me, at the heart of relativity theory.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

Rassoul is sent to Leningrad to study by his communist father. He loves Dostoevsky, but not Russia nor communism, and he returns to Kabul, a city chaotic, anarchistic, and dangerous.Having few prospects and a fiancee and her family to support, he decides to murder a woman of questionable morals and steal her money. In mid blow he begins to think of Raskolnikov and sees himself recreating Crime and Punishment. He ends up killing the woman, but can't take the money. He moves to the side, and sees a woman in a "sky-blue chador" appear to complete the crime. This is not a hugely useful piece of information, because there are many women in sky-blue chadors in Kabul.He begins to inhabit the story of Raskolnikov, and imagines he is being sought for the murder. But late twentieth century Kabul in not mid nineteenth century Saint Petersburg.* There is no functioning civil authority, and death is commonplace. No one seems to notice that the woman was murdered, much less care. Her family thinks she may have gone away. The body and the blood disappear.Where Raskolnikov played a psychological game against the investigator in his head, Rassoul plays a psychological game against confusing stimuli and an invented moral force in his head. When he finally seeks authorities to confess to and be punished by, he finds that they either don't care, or actually believe he was justified in the killing.The comparison to Kafka is slightly unfair, as in Kafka the protagonists faced a labyrinth of incomprehensible bureaucracy, while here the labyrinth is more sprawling and encompasses the lawlessness of the whole society. But I invoke Kafka because where Raskolnikov faced the certainty that an investigator was pursuing him, Rassoul suffers similar moral and psychological doubts while also confronting uncertainty about what is really happening around him. Where Dostoevsky was very focused on what went on in Raskolnikov's head, Rahimi's story is more divided between the story in Rassoul's head and the chaos of the Afghanistan he interacts with.This book is not as deep and gripping as Crime and Punishment, but it pulls you along and is intense at times. Without wanting to give away anything, I found the ending to have a little of bit melodrama that broke the intensity of the story.I very much enjoyed this book, and recommend it to lovers of Dostoevsky and those interested in Afghanistan.* Saint Petersburg was known as Leningrad in Soviet times.I read the UK edition.

What most attracted me to this album was the premier recording of the Leroy Anderson concerto. As is to be expected of his music, it is light and tuneful, although none of the tunes stuck in my head. Interesting to hear, but not a significant addition to the repertoire.If Gershwin's Second Rhapsody is heard far less often than his more famous pieces for piano and orchestra, it is for a reason. While pleasant enough, it is not Gershwin at his best.Gottschalk's Grand Tarantelle is the best piece on the album. It's jaunty and tuneful, as is typical of the composer. But it is also available on recordings of albums dedicated to Gottschalk, which might be a better way to experience it.The orchestrations of the rags, while understandable for a pops concert, doesn't really enhance their original, piano-only versions.Finally, the Gould Interplay is again pleasant, but not exceptional.Reasonably well played and recorded, this is more of a curiosity album than a discovery.

The idea is that an aging Galapagos tortoise relates stories of lost animals to the newest mammal discovered, he of the title. The book is well illustrated and has the text in both English and Spanish.Given his age, the tortoise sufferers memory lapses. Fair enough, and it adds some flavor to the story. But it is overdone, and too frequently interrupts the flow of the story. Had the author tread more lightly the book would have been better.Note that this book has a clear message of environmental protection. Few children will object to this, but some adults might.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

Having read about the abuse of First Nation's children in residential schools, I was interested in reading this book. I suppose if I'd read the description more carefully I would have realized that this was an academic monograph about the commission itself, not a work more specifically about the history of the schools. No fault of the author there.Niezen is fair upfront about what the commission was and what it wasn't. It wasn't an attempt to learn historical truth. It offered people who had been hurt an opportunity to tell their stories and, possibly, achieve some catharsis. But he also discusses how some people suffered from remembering long-suppressed injuries, and how some witnesses were really more aggrieved by events that happened to them later in their lives.While the commission was was titled "Truth and Reconciliation", Niezen titles this work "Truth and Indignation". That is appropriate, because the commission didn't try to "reconcile" the two sides. It was a relocating forum for victims to testify to their molestation. But while there is no question that many native children where harmed, that in and of itself doesn't tell a complete story. What fraction were harmed? While any child abused is one too many, a system that abuses 1% of children is not the same as one that abuses 99% of them. Were the people--mostly from religious orders--who ran the schools mostly monsters, or mostly good people with a few monsters among them?Niezen also interviews people--primarily priests and nuns--who worked at the schools. They present a very different version of history, and also express their hurt that the commission seemed focused on publicizing the bad while burying the good that happened in the residential schools. Hearing the other side greatly complicates the moral certainty of the story.While some of these people acknowledge knowing that there was abuse taking place, many come across as sincere, caring people. They note that they tried to run schools for the nation without being provided adequate resources. Some learned and tried to preserve native languages, while the commission portrayed them as dedicated to extinguishing native culture.So the commission provided a forum for people hurt by the system to express their pain, but did not serve to generate a fair assessment of the larger impact of the residential schools. And that ultimate assessment is beyond the scope of this book.Where this book does come up short is in its overly academic and convoluted language. While I understand the need for academic works to be precisely written, that doesn't generally preclude simple English expression. In the early pages alone there are phrases like "[t]he methodological paradigm of ideography ..." and "... in contrast to the the crowded heterogeneity and simultaneity of the multiple-venue regional and national events ...". The author reverts to simpler discourse in his final summation, but the damage is done by that point. I think a harsh but loving editor would have made this a much better book.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

I ran across the "Healthy Grain" style in a supermarket, and decided to give them a try. Liking them, I decided to give these a try. With only 90 calories (25 from fat) and 9 g of fiber, using one of these to make a wrap rather than two slices of bread to make a sandwich is a great way to add some fiber while cutting a few calories and simple carbohydrates.With that much fiber and that little fat, they are inevitably on the dry side. The flavor is mild, but pleasant. Put something tasty in them and they will add a hint of bread flavor and texture.The "Healthy Grain" style have 100 calories (still 25 from fat), and a little less fiber, 8 g. (They also have some flax and Omega 3 fat.) I find them to be a little moister and more flavorful than the "Light Original", and I prefer them.

I ran across these in a supermarket, and decided to give them a try. With only 100 calories (25 from fat) and 8 g of fiber, using one of these to make a wrap rather than two slices of bread to make a sandwich is a great way to add some fiber while cutting a few calories and simple carbohydrates. They also have flax in them to add a little Omega 3 fat.With that much fiber and that little fat, they are inevitably slightly on the dry side. The flavor is mild, but pleasant. Put something tasty in them and they will add a hint of bread flavor and texture.Having liked these, I also tried the "Light Original" style. They are 100% whole wheat, and have only 90 calories (still 25 from fat), and even more fiber, 9 g! They do not have the flax and Omega 3 fat. While not bad, they are even dryer and less tasty than the "Healthy Grain" style. I prefer these.

Perhaps unfairly, I expected this book to delve more generally into how math has influenced art. In fact, the author presents various mathematical symmetries and theorems, and the artist creates artwork based on them. Each mathematical topic is a chapter, with a few page explanation of the math, a plate of artwork, and often additional drawings.Although presented clearly and at an introductory level, the math is serious. If you have no interest in math you probably won't enjoy this book, and if you have no basic understanding of math, at least through introductory algebra and geometry, you may have trouble following it.Likewise, if you don't enjoy art, and specifically art based on symmetrical patterns, the artsy part of the book may not interest you.This is a case where the Amazon "Look Inside" feature can be used to good value. You can read a chapter or two, and look at some of the pictures. If you want to read more, this is a good book for you. If you aren't engaged you don't want this book.This book is definitely a niche book, aimed at the math/science lover who also likes art. You know who you are ...I was provided a copy for review by the publisher.

It wasn't too hard to figure out why my garage door opener didn't open my garage door anymore. It wasn't even that hard to figure out that, although this is the part that commonly fails, no one locally has it available.So I had to order it. Installation, in principle, is easy. The old part slips off the track and the new part slips on. Because of the placement of my door hardware, however, it wasn't that simple. To create room to get parts off and on the track I had to remove four additional bolts so I could rotate as well as translate the track. With that I was just able to make the swap. What might have been a 15 minute job became a 45 minute job.And this part is just the basic part. You need to reuse the connector and cotter pin, the disconnect pull, and the warning label from the old part. None are included with the new part.But it's cheaper and easier than replacing the whole opener.

Like many others, I love my Sonicare for how it cleans my teeth, but I don't like how the air vents encourage muck to grow between the handle and brush assembly, which is much closer to my mouth than I want muck growing.This little plastic thing creates an air-tight seal between handle and brush, and prevents the muck.The downside is that it takes some effort to pull it into place, in part because it does create an air-tight seal. The upside is that three months later, when it is time to replace the brush, everything is clean and muck-free.This simple product fills such a clear need that I have to give it five stars.

The subtitle of this book is "the Science of Champagne", and this is a book of science. It starts with an historical introduction to sparkling wine (the real history, not the myths). But then it get into science. Real science.As you go through this book you'll encounter Henry's law and Van der Waals forces. You'll learn the difference between the fluid sphere limit and the rigid sphere limit. On one page you'll encounter wake instabilities and hydrodynamic instability. You'll learn about nucleation and laser tomography.None of which is bad. I'm a physicist by training, and I eat this stuff up. If you are interested in both science and bubbly, you should enjoy this book. But if the preceding paragraph put you off, this probably isn't the book for you.This is a fairly technical book with figures, photos, and references. As technical works go, it's a quick read. But if technical stuff turns you off, you won't enjoy it.As a warning, there is a section on what global warming might do to the Champagne region. If you refuse to accept that warming is occurring, this might annoy you.Overall, I enjoyed this book. But it's not for everyone.

To be honest, when I first saw the title of this book my thought was, "Yes, but not as smart as they think they are!".But a key to this book is the subtitle, "The Mammal Behind the Myth". Because a lot of what we think about dolphins is based on the Einstein of the Sea view that John Lilly promulgated for years, based first on questionable research, and later on speculation and fantasy. Gregg, a dolphin researcher, first extricates the question from Lilly's grip, then begins to present the evidence.He starts by explaining that there is no definition of general intelligence that allows clear comparisons across species. Science can define (and sometimes test) specific cognitive skills, but can't really define a basket of cognitive skills that can be used to rank species in intelligence.Some birds do extremely well on certain tests of cognitive skills, better than animals generally considered to be "smarter". This is not a surprise, as species evolve to thrive in a particular environment, and so a species can evolve a particular cognitive skill without evolving a broader "intelligence". In fact, some insects have behaviors that might seem intelligent, but clearly aren't due to highly capable brains, which they lack.As Gregg reviews dolphin performance on various tests, he shows that they do well on some, and not so well on others. They certainly don't seem to reach human levels.He then takes on the idea of a "Dolphinese" language. In the Lilly mythology, if we could only figure out the Dolphinese-English (or Spanish or Swahili, the particular human language doesn't matter) dictionary, we could share with dolphins profound insights and witty aphorisms. But the evidence doesn't support dolphins having a human-like language. Yes, they communicate, and in ways similar to other pretty smart animals. (And pretty dumb insects can manage pretty sophisticated communication.) But Dolphinese as a human-level language just doesn't exist.Next, Gregg takes on the idea that dolphins are gentle, caring animals. Yes, they often play with or help each other, and sometimes with dolphins of other species, and sometimes with humans. But they also commit infanticide and attack (and kill) dolphins of other species. And they are carnivores; Gregg notes that there are no vegetarian dolphins.One issue that concerned me throughout the book, and which Gregg addresses near the very end, is that "dolphin" encompasses a lot of disparate species. While most of the research has been done with bottlenose dolphins, he relates information from other species, as well. There is no reason to suppose that all dolphins are of similar intelligence.Consider, for a moment, a book called "Are Apes Really Smart?". We know that apes differ widely in intelligence. Humans are very closely related to chimps and bonobos, yet we are generally considered much smarter. Gorillas are often viewed as extra-large chimps (partly because they both knuckle-walk). But gorillas don't seem to be as smart as chimps. And the so-called lesser apes aren't as smart as the great apes.So, while Gregg touches on the issue of different dolphin species at the end of the book, it is such an important issue that I think it would have been better for him to discuss it early on.So how smart are dolphins? They certainly aren't as smart as the myths Lilly created suggest. They don't seem to approach human intelligence. But where they rank compared to other animals isn't clear based on the evidence available. We know they're pretty smart, but we don't know just how smart.

A little girl makes eloquent statements that subdue the mighty and make them do right. It's cute and well done, but a touch saccharin. Definitely fairy tale material, but all lightness and goodness, unlike most traditional fairy tales.The illustrations are attractive but don't do much to enhance the story.All in all, a cute enough story for a little one.I was provided a copy for review by the publisher.

This book tells an old Indian tale of a flood. As such, the story is what it is, and it's not a bad one.A man follows the advice of the spotted frog, and builds a raft that saves him from the flood. Rather magically, he ends up with a wife also survived after the flood recedes. Those who followed the arrogant pronouncements of an arrogant leader didn't come out as well.The illustrations aren't bad, but they strike me as a mishmash of Indian styles, and not always evocative of the story.Overall, a nice enough book to offer some cultural diversity to a little one.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

Patrick has a rather dream-like experience in the family kitchen as he learns where different foods come from. This brings a slight sense of what a farm boy would know intimately to the city boy experience. The illustrations are slightly crude, but effective. Useful for a little one to learn about where his or her food comes from. It ends with hints about bacon the next day. That's a little more intense than the sources of eggs and milk.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

I can almost picture the author thinking "how do I do the next Rudolph?". While cute, this book isn't very original nor imaginative. The illustrations are nice enough, but nothing special. Something different to read a little one, but this book will be soon forgotten.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

I'm a fan of Northwest Coast Indian art, and I enjoyed this book focused on the collection at the Burke Museum. The introductory essays are well done, although a series of essays by different authors never quite adds up to a comprehensive treatment.*That said, if you are a fan of the genre both the essays and the nicely presented plates of items in the collection make this book a welcome addition on the subject.* Classics include Looking at Indian Art of the Northwest Coast and Northwest Coast Indian Art: An Analysis of Form.

I like color. Really. While I can admire black and white photos, I prefer color. I'm fascinated by color spaces, color perception, and color in general.So, naturally, I wanted to read about the "science, nature, history, culture, [and] beauty" thereof.And, mostly, I liked what I read.The book opens with the physics and chemistry of color. That's mostly well done, but I would have liked more depth. (As a physicist I might not be the average reader ...)Later parts of the book alternate between sections about different colors and how color is related to things like the universe or animals. Here it get a little bit choppy.Sections on each color seem a bit like grab bags of things that color. Color in nature seems to lose focus. For example, one section discusses the color of animals, but from the standpoint of how we see them in their environment. Another section discusses how different animals see color differently. I would have liked to have seen a discussion of how animals are seen by other animals they want or don't want to see them.There are some things that are a bit off. Pictures of the planets seem arbitrarily sized, so you might think Venus was the largest planet, and Mars bigger than either Earth or Jupiter. The discussion of the color of gemstones is oversimplified. They say a cardinal stores berries in its feather when they surely mean the pigments from berries. But these are nits, albeit likely related to the authors' desire to race through vast amounts of material quickly.Overall a good, but not great, survey of color.The publisher provided me a copy for review.

I've been tasting--and drinking!--wine for decades. My friends tend to think of me as something of a connoisseur. But when I read descriptions like "undertones of rose petals beneath burnt shoe leather" I roll my eyes.This book, on the other hand, oversimplifies, decomposing wine into a handful of aromas. I think that's a good starting point, and I applaud the author for cutting through the crap of wine puffery. But there is another level or two of subtlety beyond this book, and it won't make you an "expert".In format it's a 22 page board book, much like you'd give a small child. But the text, as well as the subject, is grown up. It walks you through the basic categories of wine smells--the biggest components of taste--and lets you "scratch & sniff". As such, it's a great starting point for understanding wine.What's peculiar is that while the author does noble service in cutting through the pretense that surrounds--and inflicts--wine tasting and wine descriptions, he feels the need to posture his brief, otherwise excellent, introduction as a guide that will make readers experts. In that, he's actually pretentious in attacking pretension.If you are a beginner trying to understand what wine people are talking about, this book is a good starting point, as well as a good corrective to snobbery. But it's not an expert guide.

This book tells the tale of a boy finding a polar bear cub and taming her into a renowned dancing bear. In this telling Brett focuses on the encounter with trolls on Christmas Eve while on their way to Oslo. The boy arrives with the bear at the house where the girl Kyri is preparing the food the trolls will steal; her father has gone off to try to stop the troll from reaching the house. The bear ends up driving off the trolls.There is another telling of this story available: Sister Bear: A Norse Tale by Jane Yolen. Yolan reinterprets the tale into a tale of a girl finding the bear. She has the owner of the house present, but only as he and his family leave, wanting to be gone before the trolls arrive. That eliminates the (chaste) boy-girl angle of this version. "Sister Bear" ends up taking care of the trolls, then moving on to success with the King of Denmark. The bear, again, is the hero, driving off the trolls.Comparing the books is challenging. They are both well written, but take the tale from different perspectives. The illustrations in "Sister Bear" are a bit more opulent, while those in "Who's That Knocking ..." are more rustic, and have a more period feel.Forced to choose, I'd take "Who's That Knocking ..." by a bear's whisker. But I could see getting both as a lesson on how tales can be told more than one way.

This book reinterprets an old tale about a boy finding a polar bear cub and taming her into a renowned dancing bear into a tale of a girl doing the same. Yolen has the girl taking her bear to see the King of Denmark when she stops for shelter on Christmas Eve. The owner of the house where she stops offers shelter, but only as he and his family leave, because trolls always invaded their house on Christmas Eve and ate their meal. "Sister Bear" ends up taking care of the trolls, then moving on to success with the King of Denmark.There is another telling of this story available: Who's That Knocking on Christmas Eve? by Jan Brett. Brett focuses on the encounter with the trolls on Christmas Eve. The boy arrives with the bear at the house where the girl Kyri is preparing the food the trolls will steal; her father has gone off to try to stop the trolls from reaching the house. When the boy and bear show up there is a little boy-girl subtext, but it's chaste. The bear, again, is the hero, driving off the trolls.Comparing the books is challenging. They are both well written, but take the tale from different perspectives. The illustrations in "Sister Bear" are a bit more opulent, while those in "Who's That Knocking ..." are more rustic, and have a more period feel.Forced to choose, I'd take "Who's That Knocking ..." by a bear's whisker. But I could see getting both as a lesson in how tales can be told more than one way.

Yukon is the only girl in her husky litter. But she shows the skills a musher looks for in a lead dog. Roberta trains her for that role.This book gives a nice flavor of what sled dogs do, and is inspirational. Both the text and illustrations are good, but not at the very top of the form. A child who likes dogs should like this book. (Ironically, the author has three cats.)(As a side note, "Yukon King" was the name of Sergeant Preston's lead dog. Cue the Reznicek. "On, King! On, you huskies!")

I have two cats living at home. One doesn't care much for treats, but the other one is a feline garbage disposal who will eat any treat, anywhere, anytime. I can get my cats to chase and catch these treats like a piece of string, but they're no more interested in eating it than eating a real piece of string. This had the potential to be the ultimate cat treat, but if my garbage disposal cat won't touch it, I think it's time to take this product back to the drawing board and figure out how to make it taste like a cat treat.As one reviewer said, there is no zip-lock. These are pliable treats, so you will probably want to store them in a zip-lock bag after you open the package.

I always wanted a dash cam, but I'm particular about features and quality. I researched for days before deciding on this one for my minivan.POSITIVES:* I am impressed by the video this tiny thing can capture! The picture is nothing less than crystal clear HD. Need to read that license plate? No problem!* The dash cam is so unobtrusive, if you mount it so that the lens is just below your windshield's tint strip, no one will notice you have a dash cam unless they specifically look closely for it.* Continuous-loop recording means you'll never have to swap out memory cards.* After six months of continuous, daily use, my dash cam is still going strong.NEGATIVES:* The camera records continuously, but saves the video to the memory card in five-minute segments. So, for example, if you want to review a two-hour trip, you'll have to open and view 24 independent files. Fortunately, the video segments overlap slightly, so you'll never lose a second of video.  But that also means if you want to use editing software to create a long, seamless video of your trip, you'll need to do a LOT of tiresome video stitching.* The menu and the five black buttons are not very intuitive. It will take patience to navigate the menu to find what you need and get the camera to do what you want.* The video is slightly choppy (it jerks about once a second), however, that may not have anything to do with the camera. I've read up on the problem, and it could be the memory card or even my computer.Summary: This dash cam does exactly what I want it to do -- it gives me peace of mind. I am a cautious driver, but I drive often and therefore witness a lot of crazy people on the road. Some day one of those crazy drivers is going to get too close to me, and when they do, my dash cam going to make my insurance agent very happy! If you're looking for a nice-quality, reliable dash cam in a tiny, unobtrusive package, I highly recommend this one.

What this book does so well is explain how polka music came about, flourished, and how it exists today in its various styles. A lot of history is covered, yet the book is not too wordy or lengthy. The book concentrates on the more influential bands over the decades, and discusses a few of the other bands that have come after and them and still play to this day. It probably would have been easy to overload the book with band and musician data, but in my opinion, Rick March did a perfect job of condensing all of his research into a superb read.The average person on the street doesn't know polka music comes in very specific, different styles. They think it's all tubas and accordions, and it's either Polish or German depending on who you talk to. Nothing could be farther from the truth. Therefore, I highly recommend this book to anyone who wants to broaden their knowledge of polka music.Dick Blau's professional photography is second to none. His photos don't just compliment the reading; they invoke emotion.The main reading of the book is interspersed with interludes that focus on specific people, places, and things that are uniquely relevant to Midwest polka music.Whether they were Iowa farmers or Chicago foundry workers, your parents, grandparents, and great-grandparents kicked up their heels to polka music. Though the polka's heyday is long gone, the music is likely still in your blood, waiting to be tapped and enjoyed. Reading this book will take you all around the heartland of America and teach you about the music of your ancestors, and share with you the joy it brought to them and still brings to so many people today.

As someone who works in music production, I never cease to be thoroughly impressed by Seth's performances and McNeely's arrangements. I'm not surprised to say they knocked it out of the park again. The music is stunningly warm, the arrangements are rich, the vocals are soothing, and the mood is inescapable. Like his first CD, Seth reached for every nostalgic nuance to give this recording a sentimentality that is particularly moving. If you are a fan of Sinatra's early recordings because of how they make you feel, you need to add this recording to your music library.

I've played with several different racquets over the years, but this is my first made of graphene.Right off the bat, I didn't care for it. I wasn't getting a nice-sounding "ping" and I was having trouble adjusting to the racquet's sweet spot. But after using the racquet several times over the last couple weeks, I've adjusted to it rather quickly. Now I love it, and have raised my review to five stars. I especially like the weight distribution and swing action. It's a fantastic racquet to swing hard with, and also deliver quick-spinning drop shots. Hard hits on the sweet spot will zero in on their target.In my opinion, at the recreational level, graphene doesn't seem to provide any kind of noticeable advantage over your typical carbon/titanium/graphite composites. If you're a 3.0 or a modest 3.5 player, graphene is probably not going to improve your game. It could even hurt it a little bit if you're used to racquets with a larger sweet spot. But if you're a hard baseline hitter or like to play the net in competitive doubles, I think you'll enjoy the weight and balance of this racquet.In general, while I am impressed by the scientific breakthrough of graphene, I haven't yet experienced the material to be a significant advancement in technology as it pertains to tennis racquets. I give this racquet five stars for simply being a really good racquet.

I bought this low-profile heater to custom-mount underneath a music stand. Overall, I'm very pleased with it. It's a just a basic heater with three settings: fan, low, and high. No thermostat. It's kicks out as much heat as you would expect for a heater this size. No more, no less. It's a little on the noisy side, but for under twenty dollars, I think it's a good bargain.

I recently purchased and installed a $225 Rigid Industries 50481 D-Series SAE Fog Light Set on my minivan. They're top-of-the-line LED lights. I quickly discovered a problem with those lights, though. When mounted low and properly aimed, the wash of light they lay onto the road directly in front of your car is so bright, it causes your pupils to constrict and reflects a hazy glare onto your windshield, making it literally harder to see into the darkness with the lights on.I once owned a sport wagon that had PIAA Plasma Ion bulbs in the fog light housings, and they worked beautifully, so I decided to go back to halogen lighting and try out these PIAA 2011 fog lights on my minivan. Would they give me the same results?Yep! These lights work great! The Rigid LED lights did a great job of pouring intense, white light onto the road, but that light seemed to die when it hit the darker foliage along the sides, and it didn't help much to illuminate distant objects except for reflective road signs. The light from the halogen PIAAs, however, scatters and diffuses naturally to illuminate everything much more uniformly, from the lighter pavement and shoulders to the darker foliage. And the light carries well, meaning it will help me to spot more important things, like deer. I created and attached an oversimplified graphic to show the visible difference between the Rigid Industries LED lights and the PIAA 2011 lights when driving.When it comes to quality construction, nothing beats Rigid Industries' LED light housings, mounting brackets, connectors, and hardware. They are the most durable auxiliary vehicle lights I've ever come across. The PIAA 2011 light housings are lightweight plastic with glass lenses. They're good enough, and I don't anticipate any problems, but they're not in the same league as the Rigid lights.I have to admit, though, I don't understand why these PIAA fog lights, which run about $185 for a pair, are so much more expensive than other halogen fog lights. I don't know why the price difference is so exorbitant. I'm led to believe most of the money we're paying out for these lights is just for the PIAA name. But I'm not here to rate their price. I'm just here to rate how well they work, and for that, I have to give them an uncontested five stars. If you're simply looking for the best lighting regardless of price, you won't go wrong with these PIAA fog lights.A few things to note:1. This is just one light. If you need a two-light kit with a switch and wiring, order a PIAA 2091 2000i Yellow Plasma Ion Fog Lamp Kit2. Each light comes with about 6" of wiring that terminates in a plastic PIAA connector. Unless you have existing PIAA wiring, you're going to need to snip off the plastic connector and then either hard-wire or crimp the light to your own, supplied wiring. So make sure you first test the lights before you begin installing them.3. The beam is wide and relatively flat, and the color of the beam is white in the middle and yellow toward the outer edges.4. When the lights are off, they don't look the slightest bit yellow as the product photos show. Up close, you can tell they have yellow bulbs in them, but otherwise they look like regular, white driving lights.

The first thing I'd like to say about these fog lights is that they are extremely well-built. The housing is tough, and the wire boots/gaskets show that nothing was left to chance in the construction of these lights. The ingeniously-designed mounting brackets allow for both flexible light placement and beam adjustment. I've owned a lot of universal fog/driving lights over the years, and these are, by far, the most durable of them all.The only practical place I could mount these lights on my minivan was in the lower section of the front bumper, inside the air dam. I mounted them upside-down to the bottom of the bumper's metal frame. This put them at the same height as the factory fog/driving lights that come on most cars and minivans. But then I discovered a problem...When the lights are mounted low on a vehicle and properly aimed, they dispense a very intense wash of light onto the road right in front of the vehicle. The wash is so bright that it has two negative effects: 1. It reflects a glare onto your entire windshield, which is amplified by the slightest haze or dirt on the windshield. 2. If you're driving on a completely dark roadway such as a rural interstate, the wash of light on the road is so bright that it constricts your pupils enough to make it more difficult to see out into the darkness and spot potential dangers, such as deer.The light wash is so overwhelming that it's literally easier to see, and therefore safer to drive, with the fog lights off rather than on. Being able to see better without auxiliary lighting sounds counter-intuitive, but the reasoning is no different than why you don't go star-gazing during a full moon.In order for these lights to be effective, they'd no doubt need to be mounted higher on a vehicle so that the beam of light contacts the road further in front of vehicle. This is not a problem for vehicles like trucks or jeeps, but it's not an option for the average car or minivan.Unfortunately, after less than a half-hour of use, I ended up uninstalling the fog lights and selling them on eBay.I give these lights the highest marks for brightness, durability, and craftsmanship, but an average rating of three stars overall due to their limited vehicle applicability.Sidenote: I ended up buying a couple of PIAA 2011 2000i Yellow Plasma Ion Fog Lamps. The difference was remarkable. Even though the PIAAs have a flat, wide beam like the Rigid LED's, there's something about the way halogen light spreads and scatters, uniformly lighting up everything from light pavement to dark foliage. LED lighting just doesn't have that property. I don't have a degree in physics to know why. All I know is that reverting to halogen fog lights was the right choice for me.

I had been using Westone UM Pro10s, but they kept failing under warranty. For that reason, I was given special permission to return them to the retailer in exchange for another brand, and I chose the Shure SE215s.It was not one of my better decisions.The first thing I noticed is that the default earpads were unusually big. It took some wrangling, but I eventually got them off and replaced them with smaller ones. That helped quite a bit, but the monitors themselves aren't nearly as ergonomic as the Westones. The Westones felt as if they were molded to the curvatures of my ears, and could be popped in and out in a second. The Shures, on the other hand, seem bulkier and don't sit well. I really have to cram them into my ears to get them to stay, and even then they occasionally twist themselves out of a tight seal. I never once had that problem with the Westones.The wires coming from the Westones are light and flexible, allowing you to quickly rest them behind your ears. But the wires coming from the Shures are rigid, and therefore not friendly to people who wear glasses. Even though they can be bent somewhat like a coat hanger, I can't inconspicuously tuck them behind my ears.I have no complaints as far as the clarity of the audio is concerned, but the Shures sounded significantly brighter than the Westones... almost bordering on unpleasant. But they also put out more low end than the Westones. Personally, I prefer the flatter response of the Westones.In hindsight, even though my Westones were dying under warranty after about every 15-20 hours of use, I would have been happier if I had purchased a second set of Westones as a backup pair, and took turns sending them back for warranty repair as needed. But now that I'm stuck with the Shures, I've decided to re-purchase a pair of Westone UM Pro10s, and will be using the Shures only as a backup when my Westones are away for repair.POSITIVES:* Cost $50 less* Slightly longer cord* Brighter and deeper response (if that's what you prefer)NEGATIVES:* Don't fit as well* Wiring too rigid to make inconspicuous* Too bright for my taste

I'm going to come right out and describe what these light shakes taste like: Let's say you just ate a bowl of Frosted Flakes or some other sugary cereal. Now take the little bit of milk left over in the bowl, add a few packets of Splenda, and add a few drops of paint thinner.  Yeah, it's kind of like that.So why four stars?  Because there is a significant dietary benefit to drinking this shake: The artificial sweetener is sweet enough to curb any further craving for sweets or chocolate. So instead of drinking a 190-calorie, sugary protein shake like Special K or Slim Fast, you can gulp this down, save 120 calories, and feel exactly the same a few minutes afterward. Drinking it is not a pleasant experience, but you'll feel good about yourself for making the low-calorie choice.

My only complaint is that it seems like On Stage designed and built this product without testing it first.  If they had attempted, for example, to mount a couple of Shure SM-81s in an X/Y position, they would have discovered that they needed to make the bar at least an inch wider.  The bar is so short that you have to push the heads of the SM-81s partially into the clips.It might not be easy to gauge by the product photo alone, but picture two mic clips mounted on the bar at a 90-degree angle.  There's plenty of room for the clips, but as soon as you mount the microphones, you realize there's not enough room between the clips (uness you're using mics with very small heads.)Other than that, you get what you pay for, which is a mic bar that's prone to swiveling loose upon contact.
