If you're willing to tinker and fidget with it, the MY500 will get the job done, but my recommendation would be to save yourself a small headache by spending a little more money for a better mic bar.

The stability and versatility of this mic stand just can't be compared to a regular boom stand.  My Studio Projects C-1 large diaphragm condenser mic and metal pop filter are now standing rock solid on my studio's heavily carpeted floor.  Within the first thirty seconds after setting up this stand in my recording studio, I decided to buy a second one.In the isolation booth, the counterweight on this stand allows me to position the stand off to the side, raise the mic high and extend the mic down and over to the singer via the long boom.  This frees up all the space in front of the performer beneath the mic, leaving plenty of room for a music stand.  It also reduces the risk of a performer accidentally knocking the mic stand over.  That's an expected occurrence when you use regular boom stands, but these stands offer significant resistance to tipping.The construction of the stand is very solid.  Its sturdiness meets all my expectations.  My second stand will be arriving in a few days, and I can't wait.  I wish I had these stands in my studio a long time ago!UPDATE: I ordered both of my stands from Amazon, and each time, they arrived in a box that was literally torn open in several places.  Aside from a tiny scrape here and there, the stands were not damaged.  If you order your stand from Amazon, you may want to inspect it when it arrives.

If you Google for images of this patch bay, you'll never see a photo of its underside.  Well, that's because it literally doesn't have one.  Nor does it have any sides.  This patch bay is not a solid box.  It's basically an L-shaped, open metal frame to which 24 1/4" modules attach.  The modules' circuit boards are completely exposed.Each of the 24 4-jack modules is secured to the patch bay frame with only a single plastic nut that screws onto plastic threading.  (Um, are you kidding me?!?)I installed this patch bay in my studio today, and even though it's functioning, I've already begun shopping for its future replacement because I can't imagine this patch bay will last more than a year before the jacks crack or strip, or the modules are permeated by dust.  I also racked my patch bay upside down so that the labeling strips were on top, and to give each module a little firmer seating in case its single, plastic mounting nut ever loosened.  Then I used a black Sharpie marker to draw division lines through the label strips between the modules.Removing a module to flip (de-normalize) it requires unscrewing its threaded nut.  Unfortunately the modules are too close together to seat a metric socket onto the nut, so you either have to fumble with a half-seated socket or try to grasp it with a needle-nose pliers.  It took me over a half-hour to de-normalize all 24 modules.In summary, for a hundred bucks, I'd at least like my patch bay to have... you know... all six sides.  And I'd like to have more than one screw holding in the modules.  And those screws should be... you know... metal.  Given it's lackluster design and the most corner-cutting construction I've ever seen in a piece of studio gear, in no way would I value this product anywhere near $100.  But, because it is working for the time being, I am obligated to at least give this product an "OK" rating of three stars.

I don't claim to know much about Hawaiian culture, nor am I familiar with any Hawaiian musicians or entertainers.  But one I thing I do know, having worked in the music industry for over 25 years as an audio engineer and producer, is quality.  And this CD is top-notch.  By professional standards, the arrangements, musicianship, and vocals are of the highest caliber.  If you are looking to add Hawaiian music to your next Christmas celebration, this CD will not disappoint even the most discerning ears.  I highly recommend it.

Unfortunately I can't rate this product any better than average for a couple reasons. The first reason is that its hottest setting is not quite hot enough for my taste.  (It's roughly equivalent to the medium setting on my previous heating pad.) And the second reason is that "feel the heat in 30 seconds" on the packaging implies "hot", when, in actuality, what you feel in thirty seconds is a tinge of warm as the heating elements just start to kick in. None of these qualities are necessarily bad for a heating pad, but I wouldn't consider them to be above average. Based on my experience with heating pads, Sunbeam ought to re-label this product's packaging and drop the MSRP to $19.99.

I'm not exactly sure how to rate this toy.  When I gave it to my two cats, they went overboard bonkers as if the toy must have contained some sort of "special Jamaican blend" of catnip, if you know what I mean.  They started clawing and biting at it like mad.  The toy survived the first playtime with loads of tooth punctures, but by the end of the second playtime, the cats had the pumpkin stemless and ripped apart at the seams, with catnip everywhere.I'm rating this toy an average of three stars -- one star for durability, and five stars for giving my cats the best night of their lives.

I operate a recording studio and purchased this drive for one purpose only: to back up clients' projects in case my computer's hard drive ever fails.  I don't leave the Seagate Expansion drive plugged in, though.  Once I back up data to the drive, I disconnect it from both the computer and the power supply because I want the data to be protected from lightning or other power surges.Using the drive is as easy as using a flash drive.  The only reason I give the drive four stars instead of five is because nothing happens when you plug it into an AC outlet.  No noise, no light... nothing.  I thought I must have had a bad outlet or received a bad AC adapter.  As it turns out, its only when you connect the USB cable that the LED power light comes on.

Long before I started using a Grace 101, I had been relying on consumer-grade preamps, such as the kind built into my Mackie 8-Bus mixer.  They're good preamps, but it wasn't until I started using the Grace 101 that I heard the difference between a consumer-grade preamp and a pro-grade preamp.  With the 101, instruments and vocals started sparkling with a clarity they've never had before.  Higher-frequency sounds like vocal sibilants and drum cymbals began to shimmer.  Microphones started shining with their true colors.  (It is absolutely amazing what a hundred-dollar Shure SM58 sounds like through a Grace 101.)The Grace 101 gives you exceptionally clear, uncolored sound.  In some recording situations, you want colored sound, but when you want your recorded source to be as true as possible to what the human ear hears, the Grace preamp can't be beat.  In my opinion, this is probably the consummate preamp for Foley artists and people who sample acoustic instruments to make virtual instruments, which is something I do.  I like the 101 so much, I bought a second one for stereo miking applications.

The A-grade of Taiyo Yuden CD-Rs is exclusively what I use at my studio due to their proven reliability.  Since I started using them a couple years ago, I've literally not had one single coaster.  That's an impressive statistic for any CD-R!  None of the typical CD-R brands sold in stores (HP, Memorex, Verbatim, etc.) can compete with A-grade Taiyo Yuden.The overprint is actually a handsome, lightly-textured, glossy, steel-blue coating that adds a pleasing aesthetic to the disc.  You can write on it or label it without any problems.Although this review is for the product itself, hence the five stars, I do want to alert you that the careless packaging might leave you a few CD-Rs short.  Mine were shipped in a cello/shrinkwrap-like covering that had busted open on the bottom, and the CD-Rs were beginning to slide out into the mailer.  The CD-R on the very bottom was visibly damaged so I simply threw it out.  A couple others on the bottom look iffy -- we'll just have to wait and see.

In the past couple years, I've worn Barricade Team 2's and Barricade 7's.  From my experience, I knew that Adidas made Barricades on the small side, so I always ordered a full size larger and got a perfect fit.  (Please note that a "perfect fit" for tennis is a shoe that is a touch roomy to help avoid "turf toe" and other problems.) So this year, I ordered Barricade 8's one full size larger as usual, but now the 8's are actually too large, especially in the heel area.The shoes' durability and grip is right in line with previous versions of Barricades, and I give them kudos for being a little bit lighter as well (the 7's were heavy.)  But if you're going to order these shoes, do not order them a full size larger as I've always suggested for Barricades in the past.  Order the 8's a half-size larger at most.  Better yet, try them on at a local sporting goods store first, if you have that opportunity.  There's nothing more aggravating than buying shoes online from a manufacturer that tinkers with sizing.

When the Harmony-M that I ordered arrived in the mail, I set it up in my home studio to try it out and hear how it sounds.As far as quality goes, the harmony voices and effects are excellent. I also like the flexibility of being able to save your own presets.  It has a rugged chassis and seems to be well-built.But I found two negative issues that have me returning the unit and looking for something better.The first issue is that the volume of the third harmony voice is too low in volume.  The second harmony voice completely overpowers it.  In fact, if I set the third harmony higher in pitch than the second harmony, I literally can't hear the third harmony (and I am a veteran studio engineer by trade.)  Unfortunately, there's no way to adjust the volume of the individual harmony voices relative to each other.The other negative issue I discovered is that the unit's sensitivity is automatically set all the way open.  I kept hearing this annoying swirling/swishing noise coming through, and it turned out to be the Harmony-M trying to generate harmony voices from the faint hum of my furnace on the other side of the wall.  There's no reason for a harmony voice generator to be THAT sensitive.I suppose it's possible the Harmony-M I received may have been defective, but regardless, I'm going to have to send it back.  It would make a great second harmony generator for studio use, but it's definitely not going to work for my live applications.

Sometimes with adapters like these, after you insert your 1/4" speaker cable, you then have to gingerly back it out a fraction of an inch at a time until you get a connection -- a rather unstable connection.  Fortunately, that's not the case with these Hosa speaker adapters.  My 1/4" speaker cables plug in all the way and give me solid, reliable connections.  Hosa is not exactly known as being the Cadillac of cable manufacturers, but this is one product of theirs that seems to be as well-built as any speaker adapter could be.  I took one of these completely apart and was 100% satisfied with the quality of construction.

Some people show up to the courts ready to play with nothing but a racquet in one hand and a water bottle in the other.  That is definitely not me!  Besides having a primary racquet and a spare, I bring two large water bottles, two Tennis Saver ball storage cylinders, a couple cans of new balls, two mobile phones, keys & wallet, three sets of sports goggles, lens cleaner, sun screen, a towel, headbands and wristbands, mosquito repellent, band-aids.... well, you get the picture.In past years, I've always used a duffel bag to tote all my gear.  It's worked okay, but a fully-loaded duffel bag is awkward and cumbersome to carry around, plus it really digs into and wears down your shoulder on the walk from the parking lot to the courts.  And there's no practical way to carry a racquet in a duffel bag.  I've always wanted a backpack for hands-free, easier toting of my tennis racquets and gear, but it had to be one that was not only large enough, but also have extra pockets to give me some ability to organize my gear.This Wilson backpack fits the bill.  It's large enough to carry everything you could possibly need to take to the tennis courts, and it has many pockets for organizing.  The backpack even has a thoughtful divider that separates the top-accessible main compartment from a bottom-accessible clothing/shoe compartment.There are two downsides to the backpack:1. Only one of the four side pockets (the one that was designed to carry a water bottle) is the only pocket large enough to carry anything of significance, because the inside wall of the pocket extends into the interior of the backpack.  The other three pockets are little more than just shallow exterior pouches, and can't hold much more than a slim mobile phone.  Because gear sitting in the bottom of the backpack naturally pushes outward against the interior lining, it would have been more practical for Wilson to give the added depth to the upper pockets instead of a bottom pocket.2. A significant portion of the silver finish on my black/silver backpack has mysteriously faded after only a few months of tennis.  I don't know what may have caused that to happen.  I tried rubbing the silver off, but it doesn't rub off, so I'm left to believe that the silver finish fades in sunlight.In summary, though this is not the most practically-designed backpack, it does the job.  I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who lugs a lot of gear to the tennis courts.  It's large enough and versatile enough for just about anything you could think of bringing.

My Protege's driver's side seat belt receptacle had been problematic for years, and one day it finally fell apart.  I tried to rebuild it, but some of the plastic was too worn, so I had to replace it with a new one.Although you're supposed to take out the front seat to replace the seat belt receptacle, my Protege is no longer in the best cosmetic shape, so I installed it (albeit a little more "destructively") with the seat in place.  To do that, I notched out the top of the plastic guard that covers the bolt, and then removed the bolt with a plain ol' wrench.The installation went fine, and the seat belt receptacle is working good as new.

When the wimpy, stock horn in my compact hatchback stopped working, I decided to replace it with something a little more ballsy. The Superior Bass Horn by PIAA is a good horn, and definitely an upgrade to what I had, but it's nothing to write home about. There's really nothing "superior" or "bassy" about it. It's a typical car horn, but just a little lower in pitch. It reminds me of some of the cars I owned back in the 1980's.Realistically, I'd value the product at around $30-$35. But, since there doesn't seem to be any competition in the 300-400Hz car horn marketplace, PIAA can charge whatever they want.In summary, if your main concern is apparent loudness, almost any universal, aftermarket replacement horn will work just as well as this one. But if you want to make your Chevy Cavalier sound more like a Ford F-150, and you're willing to spend over $50 to do it, this product will do the job well.

I bought this Mobitron stand because I have a 12.1" Asus Eee Slate B121 tablet PC, and just about every tablet holder on the market is designed for smaller tablets, like iPads.The first thing I noticed is the heavy weight of the product. When I saw the big locking teeth on the solid metal joints, it gave me peace of mind that I didn't spend over a hundred dollars on something cheap.  This is a durable product.The installation of the stand went rather smoothly.  At first, I installed it using the included extender plate that connects the stand's mounting lug to the seat bolt, but noticed a fair amount of wiggle, in fact, a little more than what I would consider acceptable for a $100+ stand.  It seemed that the use of the extender plate might have been the cause, so I took the plate off and attached the hollow mounting lug directly onto the seat rail via the seat bolt, which is the number one installation option they suggest.  Voila!  That cut down the wiggling so much, it's literally not even an issue anymore.  (I would highly recommend that if you were thinking about buying a support arm brace, BEFORE YOU DO, first check to see if you can attach the stand's mounting lug directly to the seat bolt without the use of the extender plate.  That alone may reduce the wiggling by more than 50%.)The cradle was very accommodating.  With all the height, width, and depth adjustments it has, I knew I'd have no problem getting it to hold my large tablet securely, which it does very well.  I did, however, have to make one modification to one of the four adjustable stops: the upper left corner of my tablet is where the power supply plugs in and where the volume controls are.  The stop in that corner blocked those things, so I used a bench vise to flatten out the 90 angle and make a new 90 degree angle about an inch further down.  Problem solved.The stand mounted to my car just fine, and my tablet mounted to the cradle just fine, but I ran into a problem adjusting my tablet for the best viewing angle.  Even though the Mobitron has a LOT of positioning and tilt adjustment flexibility, the cradle cannot be rotated (picture grabbing the cradle with both hands and trying to turn it like a steering wheel) and it really needs this capability.  The more I adjust my tablet into position for an optimum viewing angle, the more the screen tilts to the left, and there is no way to correct for that.A slip of paper inside the box offered me a free USB LED light if I left a five-star review, but my integrity won't allow me to leave a five-star review for a product that is very good, but not perfect.  It's an excellent product in almost every way, but I seriously did consider returning it due to not being able to rotate the cradle.  I am able to adjust my tablet to an angle that is acceptable, but to put it where I really want it would leave it more slanted to the left than a keynote speaker at an Obamacare rally.  If the cradle had a rotation adjustment, I'd easily give this product a full five stars.By the way, since the product description does not specifically say, I would like to point out that this stand DOES have a quick-release lever.  You can remove it from your car in seconds.

This is now the fourth cat-sitting DVD I've purchased.  Overall, this video is very well done.  Both the videography and resolution are excellent.  The scenes change a little more quickly than in other cat sitting DVDs, which your cats may enjoy.The product description states it was shot in "full HD" which may be true, but there's something funky about the videography, noticeable during action scenes, that leads me to believe either they didn't use a very expensive camera, or the video was downgraded during the editing or mastering processes.  But that's a minor detail that will not be an issue with your cats.  My only real complaint is about the dubbed background sounds -- as with the Cat Sitter DVD, they don't fit with the video.  Seeing birds frolicking in a birdbath without hearing water splashing is annoying.  And if you own their original Cat Sitter DVD, that horribly incessant, infamous bird chirping is back.  Fortunately, they didn't use it nearly as much in this video.In summary, this is one of the better cat sitting videos, and my cat (I have two, but only one responds to videos) is absolutely enthralled by it.

If this were a video for human entertainment, I'd give it no more than two stars. The footage looks like it was shot with a VHS camcorder set to "Auto-Adjust." The coloration is dull, the lighting is washed out, and the original resolution seems to be 480. It's about as "hi-def" as the video of your middle school band concert from 1985. The "mastered in hi-def" description can be misleading, because you can start with 480 resolution video and master it in 1080 or even 1920, but it's still going to look like 480.But the video isn't for me. It's for my cats. Only one of my cats responds to video, and he does respond to this one... especially the bird segments which he loves. He doesn't care for the fish or anything that is too large because the camera zoomed in too far, though. If he could rate this video, I think he'd give it three stars.One thing they did right, though, is that they didn't dub over the entire DVD with canned sounds, like annoying bird chirps. In segments where they showed birds and squirrels feeding, you can hear the action as it takes place. I don't know why the other cat sitting DVDs don't do that.Summary: It will entertain your cats, but there are better alternatives out there.A side note about cat-sitting DVDs: Some people will leave a one-star review for a cat-sitting video because their cat ignores the video. The fact is that some cats are wired to respond to videos, and others are not. If your cat responds to one cat-sitting video, he'll respond to all cat-sitting videos. Likewise, if your cat totally ignores a cat-sitting video, he'll ignore them all. If your cat ignores a video, please don't punish the video manufacturer by leaving a one-star review. It's not a fault of the product. Here's an analogy: if you were a broccoli grower, would you want your broccoli reviewed on Amazon by five-year-old kids, or adults who like broccoli? :)

If you don't care for longer reviews, I've summed everything up in this first paragraph:I work with many high-end software programs, such as Steinberg Cubase and Adobe Photoshop, and I can say without a doubt that MS Street & Trips is the most needlessly counter-intuitive software program I've ever used.  It's not hard to use -- rather it just doesn't function the way anyone would want or expect a GPS software program to function.  If you use it every day, you can get used to the backwards interface, but for someone like me who uses the software every now and then, it's so frustrating it would drive a person mad.The details:I want to point out right away that I don't use GPS for planning long trips with rest stops, calculating mileage, points of interest, etc. My only purpose for MS Streets & Trips is to simply know where I am at all times, and to occasionally plan routes to gigs and back since I am a weekend warrior musician. Once you tell the software to start tracking, it does a great job of it. (I use a GlobalSat BU-353 receiver.) You always know where you are. The additional map configurations (political, terrain, and especially nighttime) are very handy, the speedometer is dead-on accurate, and installation onto my ASUS tablet running Win 7 Pro was a breeze.But that's pretty much where the accolades end.The automatic route planner has major issues. It can choose some pretty weird paths.  If the software chooses a funky route and you want to change it, you can't fix it just by moving or dragging it. (Why, that would make too much sense!) Instead, you have to set up "stops" so that the software follows along the path of the stops. Editing your route this way is a pain in the butt, because the software can be stubborn and want to send you on unnecessary 'round-the-block goose chases.  (And to set up stops, you have to exit the mode that you had to enable for the software to plan a route in the first place.  What???)  So, anytime you use this program to create a route, even though it will get you from A to B, plan on spending time going over the entire route and manually inserting stops to correct all of the route's "mistakes". Otherwise you'll be listening to an incessant, mechanical voice blaring "Off route!".The maps themselves are not great, but they're acceptable. There's no font smoothing to speak of, which is sorely needed, but at least you can enlarge the text for easier reading. Microsoft seems to have adopted Google's senseless "white streets on an off-white background" color scheme, but the product offers optional maps: terrain, political, and nighttime map. In my opinion, the terrain map is perfect for daytime driving, and the nighttime map is great for night driving.The construction update information seems useless. MS Streets and Trips kept insisting on connecting me to the freeway via a ramp that had been closed for construction for almost a year.But it's the counter-intuitiveness of this software that is most annoying. For example, I entered a destination and wanted the software to tell me how to get there, but the "Plan Route" button was disabled. I had to exit the route planning sidebar and call up another sidebar which had a button for creating a route from my current location, or "press F3". And when the route was created, I was unable to move the map around to preview the route it gave me! And when I wanted to fix the routes mistakes by setting up stops, I had to exit the mode the software used to plan the route in the first place.  Arrrrgh! This is one annoying program!In summary, this program does a great job of tracking your whereabouts, and it's loaded with features. The map quality could be improved, but it's acceptable. Unfortunately, MS Streets and Trips' reliability as a route planner is questionable, and its interface is outdated and unintuitive. This product is years overdue for a complete redesign from the ground up.  I get the feeling Microsoft made a decision years ago that it was not going to bother competing with Garmin or any other GPS services, so their investment of resources into this program was minimal at best, and it shows.

I use this receiver on my Asus 12.1" tablet running Windows 7 Pro and MS Streets and Trips 2013.  I installed the drivers, fired it up, and it worked right away.  I plan to mount it on the roof of my car and do a custom USB cable installation, so I have yet to see how this receiver will hold up over time in the elements.  But so far, just sitting on my dashboard, it holds a signal perfectly.I noticed that the driver is actually a parallel-to-usb converter, which is really strange since USB has been the standard for a long time.  But regardless, this receiver works great once you install the driver.At no more than two inches in diameter, the receiver is actually quite small, which may help you mount it rather inconspicuously on your dashboard.

I was very glad to have found this product.  It's darn near impossible to find accessories for the Asus Eee Slate B121, probably because not many people buy tablets that big.  This was the only 12V charger I found that was advertised to work with my tablet.  Fortunately, it works great!  It has a bright status LED.  It also seems to be well-built to last a long time.I feel I should clarify, though, that the bonus 10-1 USB charging cable does not plug into the charger.  I assumed the charger had a USB port so that you could use the 10-1 cable to charge things like iPods, cell phones, etc.  But the 10-1 cable is not related to the charger in any way.  It's just a free gift from iTekiro that you can use with your computer.  It's nice of them to include the 10-1 cable, but they should specify in their product description that you can't power it with the charger.

Some people say the poles are a bit wobbly.  I've noticed the same problem.  On a windy day, I wouldn't be surprised to see my speakers swaying a bit.  It's my experience, though, that the looseness is a universal trait of almost all subwoofer pole mounts.  Everyone I know who uses subwoofer mounts puts tape on their speaker poles for tightness.  If these speaker poles were any wider, or if subwoofer mounts were any smaller, any direct heat source (the sun, stage lighting, propane stage heater, etc.) could expand the metal of the poles and make them impossible to remove.The first thing I noticed is that one of these poles is just as heavy, if not heavier, than an entire Ultimate Support tripod speaker stand.  I was hoping to save weight, but it's actually no big deal, because the trade-off is that these poles are obviously constructed very well.In fact here's proof of just how well they are constructed:A couple weekends ago, right before my gig was about to start, I looked over to one of my mains (original JBL EON 15's) and saw that it was leaning forward 45 degrees.  The 40-pound EON, a front-heavy speaker by design, had tipped forward, literally ripping the pole mount almost all the way out of the top of the subwoofer cabinet.  The On Stage speaker pole, however, didn't bend the tiniest bit.  It held the speaker firmly... at 45 degrees!  (It turns out that the pole mount was cheaply secured to the subwoofer cabinet with 3/8" wood screws.  I've since replaced the screws with nuts and bolts.)These are excellent-quality speaker poles and I fully expect them to last a lifetime.

Since I play 150+ gigs a year, weight and portability have always been major factors in determining what stage gear I purchase. I play multiple instruments, but as a bassist, I've been using Walter Woods amps over the years. I happened to stumble upon this bass amp, and was intrigued by the specifications. I was worried that using Walter Woods over the years may have spoiled me and that nothing smaller and lighter could compare, but decided to give the MB200 a try.Wow! What a great amp! I plugged my bass guitar into it to try it out, and the amp really boomed. It's very impressive for something that is literally the size and weight of a few sticks of butter. The tone controls sound great, and the knobs even have a pleasing, upscale feeling of resistance to them.The contour switch does exactly what I hoped it would: it mellows out the "boxy" midrange and boosts the bass and treble, much like running everything through a smiley-faced graphic EQ. When you engage the contour switch, you can then continue to use the EQ controls for additional tonal adjustment.An interesting thing to note is that the MB200 is not just limited to bass. I was recently hired to play keys on a gig, and brought this amp along just to see how it would fare as a keyboard amp. I predicted it would probably sound frequency-deficient or gritty on the higher frequencies like my Walter Woods bass amps, but it didn't at all. It sounded great! Out of curiosity, I contacted GK to ask them about the frequency response of the amp, since the documentation only gives the frequencies of the EQ controls. Their answer was 20Hz-20kHz. Interesting! So I did a side-by-side comparison with a PA amplifier and found that if you leave the contour off and set the treble and bass EQ knobs to approximately nine o' clock, you get nice, flat, full-range amplification. Bass... keyboard... PA... the MB200 works great on everything. I ended up buying four of these amps.Drawbacks: I contacted GK to ask if they make rack ears for their MB200 bass amplifiers, and they do not, so I ended up making my own out of sheet metal. GK claims this amp is only intended to be carried around in gig bags, but I think they're selling their product short. An amp this good is worth rack ears, because one way or another, a lot of these amps are going to end up in musicians' racks for the sake of convenience. I'm certain of it. I also would have preferred to see a 1/4" speaker output, but a speakon connector is nothing much to complain about.Summary: Walter Woods pioneered ultra-light, portable bass amplification back in the 70's, and now the other major manufacturers are catching on like never before. I think the MB200 is a solid performer and a testament to the evolution of compact amps.

On the tennis court, I play hard. On the hottest days I'll sweat out six to seven pounds. I also wear prescription glasses/sports goggles. The insides of my lenses can fog up terribly, especially on cool nights. What I've found is that with Jaws Quick Spit, instead of water vapor condensing into microscopic droplets (fog) as normal, it builds up by coalescing into a single clear, runny layer of condensation. Basically it's trading one problem for another. Instead of playing tennis in a cloud bank, I'm playing tennis underwater. Either way, the goggles are rendered completely useless.This product does work, but only to a limited degree.  I would not recommend it for anyone who plays competitive sports at a high aerobic intensity level (i.e. sweats a lot and produces a lot of heat).

I used this cabinet for the first time yesterday, on a gig at a rather large, historic banquet hall. I was skeptical at first, but this little beast filled the hall with bass. I could have pushed it louder, but didn't need to since the hall is rather echoey. I normally use a 15" cabinet for this venue, but from now on I'm taking the Ashdown MI-10 because it literally sounded no smaller than the 15".I bought this cabinet to replace my Ampeg PB110H Portabass 10" cabinet which quit working earlier this year. The Ashdown cabinet is a big improvement over the Ampeg. It sounds larger and louder, again very similar to my 15" cabinet.The only reason for four stars instead of five is for the corner-mounted carrying handle, which makes toting and setting the cabinet down needlessly awkward. A couple times I inadvertently set the cabinet down on its front instead of its bottom.  A balanced, top-mounted handle would have been preferred.  But as far as sound is concerned... five stars.UPDATE August 2014: The more I use this cabinet, the more I like it.

Originally, I wrote a two-star review for this amp, because when I did a side-by-side subwoofer listening test between the iNuke 6000 (1,500w/side into 8 ohms) and my Alesis Matica 900 (270w/side into 8 ohms) I heard no difference in volume.  Both amps clipped at the same apparent loudness.  I was disappointed.But the disappointment didn't last very long...The other day, I used the iNuke 6000 as a subwoofer amp at an Oktoberfest gig, and it sounded like an entirely different amp than what I had tested against the Matica.  It was loud.  Really loud.  It pushed my 21" downward-firing subs like they've never been pushed before.  The kick drum was producing a solid, deep "whump!" while only the first signal indicator light on the iNuke was lighting up.  I didn't have my Matica along to do a comparison, but I KNOW my Matica could not have reached that volume.  At half that volume, my Matica's clip light would have been sputtering like a fluorescent hospital light in a low-budget horror movie.So why did I get all that volume with the iNuke on the gig and no difference in volume when comparing it with the Matica amp at home? I honestly have no idea.  I'm guessing there might have been a difference in line voltage between my house the Oktoberfest venue, and maybe Class D amplification requires clean voltage?  I just don't know.  All I can tell you is that I was impressed with how well the iNuke worked on the gig.  My subwoofers filled the tent much better than I had expected.  I am not a fan of Behringer in general, but I believe in giving credit where it is due, and Behringer really came through on this amp.Originally I was going to dump my iNuke after testing it against the Matica, but after hearing how it performed on the Oktoberfest gig, I've decided to keep it.  I'm going to try it next year to see how it performs at various other venues.  Even if it doesn't give me full volume in all venues, I'll still keep the iNuke as a spare amp, especially because it's literally one-fourth the weight of my back-breaking Matica.In conclusion, the iNuke 6000 is definitely worth looking into.  Based on my experience so far, I think it's an excellent deal at $400.  So why four stars instead of five?  Because my experiment has shown that it may not give me 100% volume in all venues for some inexplicable reason, and because it's literally the ugliest amplifier I've ever seen.  (Screw the warranty, I'm painting mine black!)UPDATE 2014: I've used the iNuke 6000 at a couple of venues this summer, and it's been consistently and reliably cranking out at full volume.  Therefore I've changed my review from four stars to five.  This amp is definitely a keeper.

The only thing I don't like about this tuner is that it could use a few more independent buttons rather than rely on partially-labeled multi-function buttons.  For example, to start and stop the metronome, you have to press the button labeled "Input Select".  To set the BPM rate, you have to press and hold the Sound/Metronome button for two seconds.  I'm sorry, but one should not have to consult an owners manual to operate a tuner!  Since I don't have a lot of tolerance for pro audio product designs which needlessly hinder workflow, I cannot give this rack tuner five stars.  Despite the design drawback, it does the job.  It tunes instruments well and has some handy, flexible options for tuning, such as a reference tone generator and a built-in mic.

The first thing I noticed is that one of these poles is just as heavy, if not heavier, than an entire Ultimate Support tripod speaker stand.  I was hoping to save weight, but it's actually no big deal, because the trade-off is that these poles are obviously constructed very well.  In fact here's proof of just how well they are constructed:A couple weekends ago, right before my gig was about to start, I looked over to one of my mains (original JBL EON 15's) and saw that it was leaning forward 45 degrees.  The 40-pound EON, a front-heavy speaker by design, had tipped forward, literally ripping the pole mount almost all the way out of the top of the subwoofer cabinet.  The On Stage speaker pole, however, didn't bend the tiniest bit.  (It turns out that the pole mount was cheaply secured to the subwoofer cabinet with 3/8" wood screws.  I've since replaced the screws with nuts and bolts.)Some people said the poles are a bit wobbly.  I noticed the same problem.  On a windy day, I wouldn't be surprised to see my speakers swaying a bit.  Applying some tape to the poles seems to tighten everything up.  However, I believe that the wobbliness is not due to a shortcoming in the pole design, but rather it's a universal trait of most subwoofer pole mounts.In summary, these are excellent-quality speaker poles and I fully expect them to last a lifetime.

These replacement knobs and nuts fit and work perfectly.  It's very fortunate that these parts are readily available, because the threads tend to strip after about three years.  I bought several because I know I'll eventually need to replace all of them.  The shipping from PlanetDJ was significantly faster than expected, too.

Many of the jobs I play as a musician are with a two-piece or three-piece band.  The main reason I bought this mixer (I bought two, actually, in case one breaks) is because I needed a very compact mixer to mount into a custom-built, half-rack PA system, yet the mixer could not skimp on features.I needed six channels, and all six needed to have three-band EQ and a monitor send.  Too many compact mixers today focus on features for two or four channels, and pretty much disregard the rest of the inputs.  And some mixers use volume faders instead of knobs, which requires making the mixer needlessly larger.  The Alesis MultiMix is uniquely compact because of how it uses every square inch of space.I wouldn't call the effects top-grade, but in a live setting they do the job just fine.I have used this mixer on a weekly basis for about seven or eight years now, and it's still working great.

If you can't afford a high-end orchestra VST library, and you can get this one for around $100 or less, go for it.  Like most less-expensive VST instrument libraries, you get what you pay for, which usually means a balance of good and bad.  But Miroslav Philharmonik Orchestra has more good than bad, which means you'll be able to go quite far with its sounds.The graphical user interface is simple and intuitive, yet allows you to get in-depth where needed.  My only complaint about the interface is that it must have been designed for antiquated 800x600 monitors, because the miniscule controls and the tiny arrows used to expand and collapse the sounds menu are very hard to see on high-resolution monitors.  I hope IK Multimedia will consider updating their interface for monitors built in this century.Some of the sounds, with their cringe-worthy sample split points, sound like they were ripped from 25-year-old sound modules.  But overall, this product sounds very nice and even possesses some real gems.  One of my favorites is Orchestra Performance 6 under Dynamic Performance Elements.  The ensemble libraries, in particular, are absolute ear candy.  The string ensembles are incredibly lush, just like you'd expect to hear in a film score, and have a definite edge over the strings in the Garritan libraries.The staccato patches have completely different sounds than the other patch libraries, which is great for authenticity, except some of the staccato sounds are so beautiful, THEY should be offered in the full range of patches and articulations.  The staccato tuba, for example, is the very best sampled tuba sound I have ever worked with.  If only I could sustain THAT sound!  The same goes for the other brass.  They attack with a crisp, brassy BLAT! but they are staccato-only sounds which means, of course, they can't be sustained. If only!  But then I must remind myself that this is an orchestra, not a concert band.  This product's sound libraries definitely make no mistake about that.Negative issues to point out: The strings have annoying release noises that are most noticeable when moving from chord to chord.  It's not all that noticeable when you fully release chords before playing new ones -- it's only when you move legato between chords that they stand out, almost like singers catching quick breaths.  It drives my ears nuts.  It will severely limit how and where I can use the string patches on my recordings.  Also, there is a robotic-sounding glitch with some notes in the Female Choir Ah Stch patch that somehow made it past quality control.  A few other sustained patches have annoyingly audible sample loop points.  Then again, this is a rather inexpensive product, so flaws such as these are not all that unexpected.I'm satisfied with my purchase of the Miroslav Philharmonik Orchestra, especially since I got it as part of sweet deal on a bundle at a reduced price.  Would I pay $200 for it?  I personally would not unless I needed to score a B-movie quickly on a limited budget.  My recommendation would be to buy this product at a lower price and enjoy the treasures it has, and then save up more money and go for a higher-end, glitch-free product for when you're recording music for discerning listeners.  Either way, you will certainly find plenty of uses for this product in your composing and recording.  Miroslav Philharmonik probably won't cover 100% of the bases to your liking, but if you can get it for a hundred bucks or get it in a bundle, its usefulness will make a very welcome addition to your VSTi arsenal.

And patience it takes, because this is not a very intuitive program. You'll be playing a guitar sound on your keyboard, and suddenly every note changes to a muted sound.  Well, you just accidentally hit one of the non-momentary key switches, and it can take a while to figure out how to get back to where you were.  Because of the way Electri6ity works, you need skills as a both musician and as a MIDI composer to get the most out of it.I needed to replicate the approximate sound of AC/DC's "You Shook Me All Night Long" and used a Strat run through the included effects.  I got the sound I needed, but it wasn't easy because of the way Electri6ity uses velocities to morph palm mutes into sustains.  I had to go into some custom mode and click something (I don't even know what it was) just to be able to play sustained notes at a lower volume.  And then I still couldn't help from hitting key switches and getting utterly lost in the maze of articulations.  Like I said, this is not the most intuitive or user-friendly program.  The graphical user interface seems more convoluted than it needs to be, and could use some redesigning to appeal more toward musicians rather than VSTi engineers.The libraries of sounds, noises, and articulations are extensive. Electri6ity also gives you deep editing controls that allow you to adjust every possible parameter of playing style and sound.  Some of the controls are so obscure, I can't hear any difference when I adjust them, but perhaps a professional guitarist could.  Given all of this, the sky is the limit with what you can achieve.Electri6ity sounds great right out of the box, but to get the most out of this VSTi, you will want to study it like a college course, and you will want to be quite proficient at MIDI composing (sequencing, editing controller information, etc.)  So if you have the patience and are as much of a programming musician as a performing musician, this product will deliver stunning results.  (Although, for half the cost, you could hire a guitarist who could cut the tracks you need in a fraction of the time it would take you to get them with Electri6ity.)One sound I could not get from this VSTi, even after experimenting for a couple hours using Guitar Rig 5, were chunky, Metallica-like palm mutes.  All I could get were staccato mutes/notes without any sustain.  But I'm not a guitarist, so I can't say whether it was Electri6ity's capability or my knowledge that fell short.I rate the product at an average of four stars... three stars for not being as intuitive as it could be, and five stars for having the best sampled guitars you'll ever find.

When the second of my Motorola 2210 modems (known for their limited lifespans) finally kicked the bucket, I ran out to my local Milwaukee PC store and picked up this Actiontec modem because I had to get back on the internet that very day and couldn't wait for AT&T to mail me a new modem.  I paid fifty bucks for it.  I remember how much of a hassle it was to get my 2210's to work with my wireless router, but this modem installed quickly and had me back on the internet literally within two minutes.The modem has been working flawlessly since I installed it.  My service provider is AT&T.  I think AT&T ought to ditch Motorola and start using these Actiontec modems for their DSL service.

You would think every filter would be manufactured exactly the same, but that doesn't seem to be the case.  Sometimes I can put in a new filter and it will last for a few weeks, doing its job perfectly.  But other times I will put in a new filter, and within a day or two, water will be flowing over the top of it instead of through it.  The water doesn't get dirty or slimy, nor does the filter.  It's as if the charcoal itself somehow blocks the water flow.  The filters all look and feel the same to me, so I am baffled as to why this happens.  I don't have an exact number, but I estimate that about four out of every ten filters fail within one or two days and have to be replaced.UPDATE NOV. 19th: I changed my two-star review to four stars.  Of my most recent order of filters, all of the filters worked fine.  Based on this experience and the general consensus of other reviews, it seems my previous experience must have been a rare manufacturing anomaly.

My first modem would drop the internet connection once a month, then once a week, then once a day, then eventually up to twenty times a day.  I would have to turn off power and reboot the modem every time.  AT&T claimed it was from a "bad batch" of modems and sent me a new one.It wasn't long after that the second one began to fail.  It had a difficult time booting up.  It would keep shutting down during the boot process, and sometimes I'd have to boot it fifty times or more before I got an internet connection.  Just recently, it decided it wasn't going to boot up at all.The Motorola 2210 modem doesn't suddenly quit working -- it seems to get worse over time.  It gets really hot, indicating that the electronics inside must be slowly frying.  I agree with the reviewer who stated this modem was probably designed to last 18-24 months, because that has been my experience.This modem is literally one of the worst electronic products I've ever been unfortunate enough to own.  I didn't throw mine out, though.  I flipped it over and now I use it to fry eggs.

I recently bought a Presonus Faderport, but had to return it because the recording punch-in mode didn't work with Cubase 7 64-bit.  Since having punching capability was vital to my recording process, I bit the bullet and bought the Steinberg CC121 to ensure I wouldn't run into similar incompatibility problems, even though the CC121 was more advanced of a controller than what I needed.  But then I started working with the CC121, and realized it was not too advanced at all.  In fact, it was exactly what I needed.To have instant rotary control over a channel strip's EQ section is a real boon to the mixing process in Cubase.  In the mixer window, as you turn the knobs, you'll see your adjustments represented graphically in real time across all four bands.  Very nice.  (Please note that in order for the EQ knobs to function on the CC121, don't bother installing the Tools from the enclosed CD-ROM. Download the latest Tools from Steinberg's website instead.)Nearly all of the functions of the CC121 work perfectly, including punching with a foot pedal, which was my main concern.  The only problem I encounter is that the fader can be fussy at times.  I'll select a track, and instead of the fader instantly controlling that track's volume, it offers resistance and must be "worked loose" for a couple seconds before it starts working properly.  The fader also feels rather flimsy.So what's the design flaw to which I alluded in the subject?  You can probably figure it out for yourself just by looking at the photo.  The center of the CC121 is painted black.  It may look cool from a design perspective, but it makes the EQ knobs and transport buttons nearly impossible to see at arm's length under typical control room lighting conditions.  The channel strip buttons on the left (mute, solo, effects, etc) are easy to see, but the transport controls are dark buttons with black icons on a black background.  Who's the genius that came up with that design?  Louis Braille?  Of the eight transport buttons, only three of them have backlighting, and are lit only when in use.  The other five buttons remain dark.  C'mon Steinberg, what were you thinking?!?  This blunder is such a senseless hindrance to workflow, I cannot rate the CC121 five stars until Steinberg redesigns it with some common sense.

This tabletop mount is roughly the same price as the one Radio Shack carries, but that's where the similarities end.  The first thing I noticed when I took the mount out of the packaging is how heavy it is.  It's one heck of a solid piece of hardware.  It didn't come with mounting screws, but I happened to find three black screws laying around, and they made for a very sleek-looking installation.

I bought this product mainly because I need a way to do punch-ins with a foot switch.  As it turns out, when you're working with Cubase 7 64-bit, everything on the Faderport seems to work EXCEPT for the punch-in capability.The documentation that came with the Faderport was outdated by several years.  I installed the Faderport per the directions, but it didn't work.  I Googled my problem to find out from another Faderport user that I had to use the Faderport in Mackie HUI mode.  I did get it working after a few more installation hiccups, and the features that worked did work well, but again, no punching capability.I contacted Presonus support, and they said to make sure I had the right type of pedal.  I checked, and even tried two different pedal types, and neither worked.  I replied with a request to let me know whether or not the punch-in feature will work with my software, because if it didn't, I'd have to buy another brand of DAW controller, and that the window to return the Faderport was closing soon.Presonus replied a few days later and said they didn't know if the punching worked in Mackie HUI mode, would check into it, and get back to me.  For crying out loud, how can they not already know this?  They manufacture a product to work with the world's leading software recording programs, but don't test it with those programs to identify and publish specific incompatibilities?  Who do they think they are... Microsoft?I could not afford the time to wait for their reply as I have recording sessions coming up, so I returned the Faderport and bought a Steinberg CC121.  I will still rate the product at three stars, however, because tech support was very understanding, and also because my Faderport problems were apparently specific to my recording software.I also want to add that Presonus got it right when it came to the design of the product, using white, backlit buttons with black icons.  The Steinberg CC121's transport buttons are dark with black icons on a black background, and only three of the eight buttons light up.  They are nearly impossible to see under typical control room lighting conditions.  So kudos to Presonus for getting it right.If you're thinking about buying this product, BEFORE YOU DO, I strongly suggest you go to Presonus' website.  Select Products > Faderport > Tech Specs, and check to see if your recording software is approved to work with the Faderport.  If it is and you buy the Faderport, set aside the installation documentation that comes with it (or donate it to the Smithsonian) and instead go to Support > Knowledge Base > Faderport > and select the "How do set up my Faderport in..." for your particular recording software.

The most appropriate word I can think of to describe RealGuitar V3 is "fun" because it blow you away as you start playing it for the first time, and you don't have to be a Jeff Abbott.  Unlike some VST instruments that practically require a college course to learn, RealGuitar is intuitive enough that a musician can tinker with it for a while and figure most of it out.  MusicLab has made it easy to get an authentic acoustic guitar from a keyboard controller, and that's what a musician like me (who prefers performing over programming) needs.Play a chord on your keyboard, and RealGuitar not only strums the chord, but knows how a guitarist would finger the chord on the fret board, and automatically plays it that way.  You can set RealGuitar so that as you play higher on the keyboard, the "guitarist" follows by playing higher on the fretboard.  RealGuitar V3 also knows where to automatically add in fret noise and string squeaks.  In my opinion, RealGuitar V3 has found a nearly perfect marriage of authenticity of sound and ease of playability.RealGuitar V3 is not a library of instruments where you can choose from a particular Martin or Taylor.  You get ONE acoustic guitar, your choice of steel or nylon strings, and your choice of fingered or picked.  You also get ONE acoustic twelve-string guitar.  That's it.  So don't buy this product if you're looking for a specific guitar model.  I have no idea what acoustic guitars were sampled for RealGuitar V3, but the samples are beautiful and can be used universally across many styles of music.  You can use RealGuitar V3 for everything from Funk to Rock, but I'll be using it mainly for Country and, believe it or not, Oberkrainer.RealGuitar V3 comes loaded to the rafters with a huge library of rhythm pattern presets for all types of music.  The pattern library doesn't cover everything, but it comes close.  Unfortunately, the one type of pattern I need most, it doesn't have, which is a slow, very basic, classic country waltz.RealGuitar V3 allows you to flexibility with many parameters, such as noises, strum timing, slides, equalization, etc. and there are many articulations available that you can assign to controllers or key switches.  You can choose if you want to play single notes or chords, and there are other playing modes that I have not yet needed to use.No VST can compare to having a professional guitar player in your studio, but when it comes to an acoustic guitar, this product is absolutely phenomenal.  There is no comparison between using this product and trying to play an acoustic guitar out of a standalone sound module.  Depending on how you use it, everyone will believe your tracks were recorded with a real acoustic guitar (except, of course, for the professional guitar players who are losing more and more studio gigs!)RealGuitar V3 is awesome, but there are two things I'd like to point out:  It's a two-hundred-dollar "one size fits all" VST instrument, and may not have enough tonal variation where you wish you had it.  I'd like to see MusicLab broaden RealGuitar's palette by adding two or three different guitar makes and models, and maybe two different mic distances, even though it would mean increasing the price tag.  Also, I feel as though the softest velocity sample of the guitars is still a bit too loud.  You know that little shimmer of sound you get when the string is lightly grazed?  You won't find it here, and that will limit how intimate you can make your guitar tracks.Vir2 just came out with a new acoustic guitar VST instrument called Acou6tics.  If you need the cat's meow of sonic dimension that RealGuitar can't give you, Acou6tics would probably be the route to go (although at twice the cost.)  But RealGuitar V3 can hold its own as a virtual instrument.  I own Vir2's Electri6ity software, and it is incredible, but it's also just plain too complex and convoluted to fully enjoy.  For that reason, I'm sticking with MusicLab for my acoustic guitar tracks.

The metal panel is probably even a little thicker than the metal face plates of most rack gear.  After I installed it in my rack, I rapped my knuckles in the center of it, and except for the metallic-sounding clang, you wouldn't even know it was a blank rack panel.  It's a solidly-built product, and a good bargain for the $12 price I paid.

They are stylish and comfortable to wear, but have serious design flaws.The first and most obvious flaw is that there is no ventilation. None. Nada. As a result, these glasses can fog up very, very badly.  I play tennis, and on a cool night, even after applying an expensive anti-fog treatment, condensation can build up every five to ten minutes of playing, rendering my prescription Rec-Specs completely useless.  I paid about $400 for my prescription Rec-Specs, but some nights they fog up so badly I simply have to play without them.The next design flaw is that the glasses fit so closely your eyes, your eyelashes can make contact with the lenses, smudging any condensation on them.The final design flaw is that the frames block too much peripheral vision.  (Shouldn't eyewear designed for playing sports, you know, NOT hinder vision?)If Liberty simply offered an alternative nose bridge piece with a deeper offset, I think that would solve most of these problems.  I wrote to them last year and inquired about it, but they never bothered to reply.I would not recommend Rec-Specs to anyone.

I've been using the same cat-sitter video for quite some time now, and my cat always seemed to be most entertained by the video segments featuring birds.  So I found this Mewvie DVD on Amazon and decided to give it a try.This no-frills video is nothing but footage of various birds at various bird feeders, with various bird chip-filled audio backgrounds.  In other words, it's perfect!  It's as close as any cat-sitting video has yet gotten to being like an open window.  It's exactly what a cat-sitting video of birds should be like, and my cat LOVES it!  He absolutely loves it!The DVD loops by itself, so you can leave it run for hours while you're gone.

First, let me explain what this device does NOT do.  It does not keep a tennis ball as fully pressurized as a brand new ball, nor does it restore lost pressure to an older ball.  The only thing this device does, and does well, is slow the rate at which pressure escapes from the tennis ball, thereby extending the ball's playable life.League players will still want to use new cans of balls since nothing plays like a new ball, but avid recreational players may be able to keep balls in playable condition for up to two or three additional weeks when storing them in the Saver between matches.  For this reason, it's a good idea to use extra-duty balls for hard court play, because balls stored in the saver can literally lose too much felt before losing too much pressure.As both a league and recreational player, I use new balls for league play, and then store them in the Saver to use recreationally between league matches.  I play tennis four to five days a week from Spring to Fall, and estimate that the Tennis Ball Saver saves me at least forty dollars a year in tennis balls.  I like the product so much, I recently bought a second one.

What I like most about this mirror is its rock-solid stability, even in high winds and over bumps.  Month after month, it stays put.  The mirror also doesn't experience any vibration problems which can hamper viewing.  Also on the plus side is the mirror's adjustability, which allows you to mount it in any position and still achieve the viewing angle you need.What I dislike about this mirror is that its small size and convex surface can be a safety compromise in street riding situations. Everything on the road appears to be so small.  When you glance at the mirror, moving cars are indistinguishable from parked cars, houses, mailboxes, yard signs, etc. A moving car can be one of many specks in the mirror one second, and passing you the next. To make this product safer for street riding, I literally bonded a flat mirror over the convex one.  Due to my bike's bar end grips, my mirror has to extend downward below the bars. Add that to the fact that I am over six feet tall, the mirror is quite far from my face. If you're shorter or have the luxury of being able to mount the mirror upright, that will be an advantage.Summary: This mirror is top quality, yet, I would like to see it offered in a slightly larger, less-convex version.

Papermate pens write darkly, but are too prone to drying up.  Bic pens don't dry up like Papermates, but the ink is too light.  So one day, I picked up a Pilot gel pen.  The first time I tried it, I was hooked.  There may be other pens out there that work just as good, but I'm not going to bother looking.  I found a pen that works great.The inks in this 8-pack of pens are very rich in color, yet all of the ink colors are dark enough to use anywhere a regular pen is needed.  It literally looks as if you've written with an ultra-fine point Sharpie marker.  Ink output is very consistent, too.

If you've been wondering how such a highly-rated product like this can also have one-star reviews stating these earbuds have "absolutely no bass whatsoever" and sound "horribly tinny", I'd like to offer an explanation.These Panasonics are not designed to be placed in the ears and worn like standard earbuds.  If that's how you wear them,  you'll get nothing but tinny sound at relatively low volume (think 1960's pocket transistor radio.) These earbuds are specifically designed to fit snugly into the ear, forming an airtight seal.  If you choose too small of an earpad and/or don't push them in far enough, you won't hear any low-end frequencies.  It's only when you get an airtight seal that the earbuds will instantly come alive with full-range sound and volume.Here's a quick analogy: Tightly plug both ears with your fingers, close your mouth, and hum the lowest note you can.  Now take your fingers away, and notice how almost all of the low end and volume drops out.  That's the difference between a proper fit and an improper fit with these earbuds.  Although the acoustic principles are different, these earbuds must literally plug your ears in order to give you the full frequency spectrum.  Otherwise they'll sound absolutely horrendous.Unfortunately, Panasonic wasn't very forthcoming on their product's packaging about how to wear the earbuds, and I'm quite certain some unwitting consumers are throwing away perfectly good pairs.As an audio engineer, I can assure you these earbuds, when properly fitted, sound great.  They're not audiophile-quality earbuds with the sonic transparency of a $200 pair of studio-reference headphones, but for the price, they are an exceptionally fantastic bargain -- arguably one of the best product bargains I've ever run across on Amazon.  Do they have a lot of bass?  They're not deficient in any of the low frequencies, but they're not bass-enhanced earbuds, either, which some of you may be used to.  They have a relatively nice, flat bass response as is, but if you want extra bottom end on your music, you'll want to boost the low end of your MP3 player's EQ.  Fortunately, boosted lows, even the deepest of lows, are handled very well by these Panasonics.As a result of how these earbuds are designed to be worn, they could be uncomfortable for some people to wear for extended periods of time.  The earpads are very soft and pliable, though, and I personally don't experience any discomfort wearing them.  Since these earbuds are designed to be wedged into your ear, there are two unique, negative issues to point out:1. Be very careful not to drop your MP3 player, because having earbuds ripped out of your ear canal is not a pleasant experience.2. These earbuds will amplify the sound of your heartbeat when it's racing during an intense workout.  The incessant "tick tick tick" is loud enough that it becomes extremely annoying during quiet passages in the music you're listening to.In summary, the audio quality of these earbuds, when properly fitted, will satisfy 99.9% of the general population.  I would not recommend them for bike riding or street running since they block out ambient noise, or for intense workouts due to the amplified heartbeat problem, but if you need some quality earbuds to tune out the world for a while, these Panasonics are an excellent choice and a phenomenal value.

The enclosed plastic pry bar literally broke within the first five seconds of using it; the iPod seam clamped back down and snipped off the edge of the tool.  Fortunately, I had a small flat-head screwdriver nearby, and that got the iPod open quite easily.  The other tools worked fine.  The battery works fine, too.  I cannot believe $3.53 WITH shipping revived my iPod, but it did, and that's why this product easily gets five stars.  I've literally never found a better value anywhere on Amazon.The kit came without instructions, so you'll need to refer to YouTube or another online source for step-by-step directions.  The YouTube videos make the task look easier than it actually is, although it's still not that difficult to do.  There are a few things to note when taking apart your 4th-generation iPod:1. The enclosed pry bar is worthless. Have a small, flat-head screwdriver handy.2. When I opened my iPod, I noticed that one edge of the battery was taped down to the inside of the iPod, so you may need a razor blade or X-Acto knife in order to remove your battery.3. The two halves of the iPod are connected by a thin headphone ribbon cable.  Be VERY, VERY, VERY careful not to pull it out of the headphone jack assembly.  I learned this the hard way.  If it does come out, you'll need a small needle-nose pliers (better yet, a surgical clamp) to insert the ribbon back into the tiny slot from where it came.

As someone who rides almost exclusively at night on deserted bike paths and parkways, I decided to go with the brightest light on the market -- the NiteRider Pro 3000.For the past twenty years, I had been using my trusty four-cell halogen bike light.  For the longest time, that light was always as bright as any other incandescent, halogen, or 1st generation LED light out there.  Before I turned on the Pro 3000 for the first time, I turned on my halogen.  Then I turned on the Pro 3000, and stood there in disbelief while my jaw hit the floor.  The light from the Pro 3000 completely swallowed the light from my halogen a thousand times over.  There is absolutely no comparison to be made.  It's like shining a helicopter's search light at a candle.This led to the realization that I would have been completely satisfied going with a less-bright light.  In hindsight, I would have bought the 1500 instead of the 3000 to save money.  1,500 lumens is plenty bright for a bike light on the darkest of trails.  The extra 1,500 lumens the Pro 3000 has will make you go "wow", but they are of little practical use.There are two negatives that need to be addressed... one minor and one rather significant:The minor thing I wish NiteRider did was provide a better system of attaching the battery pack to the bike -- they rely on Velcro strapping.  Velcro is functional and will easily mount the battery pack to any size tubing, but it's not completely stable.  The battery pack will shift around on your ride.  Some sort of a clamping system would have been nice.The more significant problem with the light is that there is no beam cut-off horizon to prevent blinding oncoming traffic.  Having a uniform beam spread is a big plus when you're riding on deserted, wooded trails and need to see overhanging branches and moths before they whack you in the face, but on the road, it does nothing but blind oncoming traffic.  Even with the light at it's lowest power setting and pointed downward onto the road, oncoming cars WILL flash their brights at you.  I am surprised NiteRider never addressed this problem.  I modified my Pro 3000 by designing and installing a flip-down light dimming filter.  For the rest of you, expect to partially cover your light with your hand EVERY SINGLE TIME you pass an oncoming car, bicyclist, or pedestrian.  It's a major inconvenience, and for this reason alone, I cannot give the Pro 3000 five stars.If you want the brightest light available, you found it!  Just be sure that before you go for a night ride, you call your local airport to inform them that you are not a low-flying aircraft.

I am a tennis player who wears prescription Rec-Specs sport goggles.  Rec-Specs offer no ventilation, so fogging and condensation are often a problem.When the temperature is hot or when the air is dry, these wipes will help prevent general fogging.  But when the temperature drops into the 60's or 50's on a humid night, these wipes are useless.  Within minutes of playing tennis, my Rec-Specs will go from clear to foggy and dripping with condensation.  I partially blame the Rec-Specs for not having any ventilation, but I've run into the same, exact problem using these wipes on my regular prescription glasses on the tennis court.I give this product two stars because it works only under limited conditions, doesn't last long, and is far too expensive to be practical.  The wipes dry up and lose their effectiveness once they're out of their sealed packets.  To help me get through the fall tennis season, what I really need is a stockpile of these wipes, but there's no way I could afford that at $4/wipe.  Clarity should offer this product in an economy size, as well as package it in resealable, air-tight container for longevity.

This printer has been working flawlessly for me for at least seven or eight years now.  Yes, it's a bit noisy, but the noise is not excessive for a printer of its size.  The output is extremely consistent, and that's a big plus.The major drawback to the printer is that it will disable itself when it feels the toner is too low.  At first, like a dummy, I would replace the toner cartridges.  But then I found out you can put the printer in a diagnostic mode which allows the printer to keep printing even when it's telling you to replace the cartridge.  Then I found out you can go into the printer's setup menu and completely override the printer's settings, allowing you to print until a toner cartridge literally runs out.  Do this, and you will be blown away by how much more printing you can get out of your toner cartridges!  I'd estimate that I get at least another 33% out of my cartridges.

I have written hundreds of reviews, and I have never been as impressed by a product!I was very very skeptical that a small package like this could ever start a car, especially a high compression V8. Some of my much larger heaver jumper boxes have trouble with most high compression engines.When I received it I was even more skeptical, small and very light weight. Fits in a glove box.So to test it, I gave it the worst scenario. I disconnected the lead acid battery from my high compression small block Chevy V8, and clipped this jump-starter to the disconnected cables.Much to my surprise, not only did it crank over the engine, but it cranked it at a higher RPM than my $120 dollar 800 CCA lead acid battery!Very impressive!There is a down side though that you must be aware of. This and similar boxes are designed for convenience. They do not have large gauge cables, and as such the cables will overheat if you crank the motor excessively, or if you start multiple dead cars back to back without letting the cables cool down. But for normal use to start your car with a dead/low battery, it is stellar.Very highly recommended

I unfortunately have a treatment resistant form of sleep apnea. I have a difficult time with CPAP, and am not a candidate for surgery. My snoring has been described as horrendous with frequent non-breathing episodes nightly.The concept of anti-snore oral appliances is to pull the bottom jaw out slightly to make the throat opening larger for better air flow and breathing. With better air flow and less breathing disruption, snoring and apnea are reduced or eliminated. Dental appliances are usually designed by a dental professional at a high cost, and work for some, not for others. So I was leery to spend the big money for a 50/50 proposition.This Night Guard Mouthpiece was a much less expensive way to try one out and see if the concept worked for me. This model is adjustable, as different people tolerate there bottom jaw being moved out different lengths.I followed the easy to follow molding instructions and it was ready to wear in 10 minutes. I had read many reviews about how big it was, so I figured I needed to get used to it. I set the adjustment to zero (no jaw adjustment), then wore it around the house on a Saturday morning. Obviously at first it felt very unnatural, but over the course of he morning I forgot I was wearing it. Then I started to adjust the device for more and more lower jaw extension. This to was slightly uncomfortable, but the more I wore it, the less I noticed. I kept adjusting until I got to the point that it was uncomfortable continuously, then I backed off one setting. At this point I decided to not use the device Saturday night, but to let my jaw relax one night. My jaw was a little sore the next morning, but it was fine by noon.So Sunday night was the test. I placed my cell phone app on record and attempted to sleep. I was a little uncomfortable for a few minutes, but then fell asleep. I woke up at 4am with a slightly sore mouth/teeth/jaw and checked the recording. No Snoring!! This was a time to celebrate for me after years of failed treatments.With this good result I continued to use the mouthpiece. The first couple nights were a little uncomfortable, but now I don't even notice it, and my sleep quality and general feeling has improved tremendously.Because of the moldable nature of this mouthpiece, the plastic is soft. At the present rate I think it may last about 6 months before needing to be replaced. But now that I know this treatment works on me, I have made an appointment to have my dentist custom design a smaller lighter version using my mouthpiece settings as a guide. Now the expensive custom dentist created model is money well spent.RecommendedNote: The first mouthpiece I received must have been exposed to high temperatures because the moldable plastic was melted on one side. I returned it and got a perfect replacement in a couple days.

This wireless router is top rated by several review sites and is priced right. It actually rates higher than the newer C8 model in most aspects.Installation was a snap, I just set my SSID and WPA passcode.Range on the 2.4Ghz band is much better than my old N router. The 2.4GHz antenna is internal.The external 5GHz antennas are great and angle adjustable for maximum range. I experimented with several aftermarket longer antennas and some directional antennas. None had more range than the stock antennas. (Note that the 5GHz band doesn't penetrate walls as well as 2.4GHz, but it has faster specs.)Overall very satisfied.Highly Recommended

This is a decent NON-atomic manual set wall clock with 2" time digits.The temp gauge is accurate and a nice feature.It was easy to set and looks good sitting on my desk at work with its included stand.Price was reasonable and it seems to keep good time.

I have TW cable and was tired of the monthly rental fees for my modem.I wanted a modem that is more future proof. This one is approved by all the major carriers, and has the latest standards capable of 686Mbps. Not that I have that fast of service now, but who knows what I will have/want in the future?It set up easily. I just hooked it up and called TW for activation. An added bonus is my download speeds tripled for free (the TW rep mentioned this, and it was true).Couldn't be happier.Highly recommended.Note: This modem does not have a router or wireless. I have several different brand atomic clocks around my house and workshop, and I really like this one because the time digits are 3" tall verses 2" on my other clocks. It also has a slick mounting clip that either allows wall mounting, or doubles as a stand to set on a flat surface.Temp readings are within 1 degree of my mercury temp gauge.RecommendedNote: remember to keep the outdoor temp sender out of the rain and sun. I placed mine under the eaves of the house.

These bits worked great to remove the screws in several power tool battery packs that I rebuilt.And the whole set costs about the same as two or three security bits from the brand names.Probably not near as heavy duty, but worked great for my application.People that complain about the T5 and T6 not having a security hole: Do a web search.
