Awesome scrim! The weave of this scrim isn't too tight or too loose. The holes really add some freaky, fun dimension. There is enough in this package to drape, wrap, pile, or hang - however, it's probably smart to order two unless your display is pretty small. Why? Once you put this up, you'll start finding all sorts of places that can benefit from it's spookiness. This is very pliable and easy to form to your needs. I had never used this before, so I ordered three different brands. This was the only gray, and I love it! It isn't a "bright" gray - more of a dusty black. It goes well with the black ones I got. I'm going to buy at least one more of these for next year. This tied as my favorite - it's a great deal!

Hard, rubber spiders. Mine didn't glow in the dark very well, although the substance they use that's supposed to glow does help them stand out in pictures when it's dark. There is a some variance in the spiders you receive. They are ok - I don't know that they added much to my display, but they were fun.

Duracell batteries are known for great performance and for lasting a long time. This is a phenomenal price and the (heavy) box of batteries arrived quickly. We go through a lot of batteries in my house (I don't even know where they go - I believe my children are trained battery bandits) so this was much more cost effective than buying the small packages of batteries at the store. It will also keep me from having to run to the store (late at night or in the middle of a blizzard is when we usually realize we need more) - which I love. We are about 30 batteries into the 100, and I haven't encountered one single problem with these. All have worked well, without fail - none have leaked or caused any sort of corrosive damage.These all have expiration dates that are pretty far in the future - 2020. Mine have English writing on them - no Chinese. I don't know how anyone could complain about this deal...and with free shipping on this weighty bundle? SCHWING!! I found this to be an excellent deal that I will definitely take advantage of  again, as soon as we go through this lot.

This is just what I was looking for to wrap around a fat 6" candle. The candle is ivory and looks pretty plain. I bought it to go in the largest of a three lantern set I bought. The candle is nice in the lantern, but I want beautiful. Especially since I'm thinking about/starting to decorate for the holidays. I purchased this ivory vanilla pip berry garland, and I purchased the burgundy version as well. I am going to intertwine them and then wrap them around the base of the candle. I am also going to add a few rusted jingle bells (in different sizes) to some thin wire, then wrap that around the ivory/burgundy pip berry bunch. It should create a beautiful holiday piece for the steps of my front porch - and with the LED (remote controlled!) candle I was able to find here on Amazon, I can set it each night - and forget it. (Just the kind of thing I like!)The pip berries on this garland are the perfect size for a project like this - and they are close enough together that there won't be gaping spaces of wrapped wire (that kind of resembles grapevine from a foot away) that is "berry naked". (That just totally cracked me up!) This arrives in a neat bundle, which definitely makes it easier to work with. One of my favorite things about this garland is the double berry design. Having two pips placed close together (instead of just one) makes an enormous difference in the perceived fullness of the garland. It is pretty lightweight - I can't imagine it would weigh anything down. The wire is thin enough to easily work with your fingers - no tools necessary. At the same time, it's thick enough to stay in the shape you bend it, and it has some depth to it. Please note that I doubt this will hold some intricate unsupported shape...but it's excellent for draping over a shelf, a curtain rod, wreath, around bottles or candles, as part of a centerpiece, etc. This could also be used as a regular home decoration (not just for holidays), and I am sure I will use it for my spring/Easter table. 18' is a good amount to work with, also. I'm very pleased with this garland!

Very cute idea...not very good pens. I used to purchase pens like this, with the marbled ink, from Zebra. They weren't 100% perfect - occasionally the ink would skip and the pens required that you hold them in a specific way - but they were more than decent. They were good enough for me to purchase by the box, which I did on multiple occasions. When I saw these, I was stoked - finding the marbled ink again was like running into an old friend, I loved the diamond-shaped tip, and the faux diamond gem on the cap was cute. They arrived in great time and were in a fantastic package - the way I wish more pens were shipped. Not only was the plastic container great for shipping, but it would also work as a stand to store the pens. (I don't use things like that. As a pen freak, I store all my pens horizontally after checking to make sure they write upon arrival.) The first pen I tried was great from the first mark - the ink flowed well and the pen was easy to write with. It is vital to note that these pens aren't juicy at all - it has something to do with the ink. I've never had a juicy marbled-ink pen...unless it was bubbling out and leaking. Yuck! (Very rare.)These pens - and the ones from Zebra I used to purchase - have a significant drag. They are not very smooth to write with. They aren't really intended to be daily use pens - these are geared more for decorative writing, scrapbooking, art, etc. The ink is not very dark, but does show on light and dark paper. I've always gotten better results on dark paper - the yellow doesn't show well at all on white paper, and some colors appear gray at times. (It's the way the ink mixes - there is no gray ink in the pens.) The amount of muddy, or gray, ink you get in your writing really depends on the pen...it's kind of a "luck of the draw" thing. (Or "UNluck of the draw", depending on the results you're trying to achieve.)The cap fits these pens well - on the writing end of the pen and when you place the cap on the other end (to "store" it while you write). The gems seem to be secured well - I don't anticipate losing them. Wouldn't that be embarrassing..."Oh, excuse me - I think my diamond just fell off in my _____." Best to avoid that - and I believe you will with these pens.I believe the rest of my review is best handled by the photos I've added. Please don't hesitate to ask if you have questions...as my life revolves around pens (not really, but I wish it did!), I'm happy to provide any comparisons or further information. It probably won't be useful...but that doesn't mean I won't still provide it. ;)Photo 1: Pens full length  Photo 2: Pens as they arrive in container  Photo 3: Gem tops of pens  Photo 4: Pen tip  Photo 5: My written review - shows you the colors of the inks, plus my opinion  Photo 6: Gem top of purple pen, close up of container, neon green free bracelet included with purchase

Duracell batteries are known for great performance and for lasting a long time. This is a phenomenal price and the (heavy) box of batteries arrived quickly. We go through a lot of batteries in my house (I don't even know why - you'll have to ask my kids) so this was much more cost effective than buying the small packages of batteries. It will also keep me from having to run to the store (late at night or in the middle of a blizzard is when we usually realize we need more) - which I love. We are about 18 batteries into the 100, and I haven't encountered any of the issues other reviewers have described. If those issues begin, you can bet I will be back to update this review.These all have expiration dates that are pretty far in the future - even the closest date is like a year away. I don't know how anyone could complain about this deal...and with free shipping on this weighty bundle? SCHWING!! I found this to be an excellent deal!

I've had several different squeegees for my showers over the years. While having my master bathroom remodeled recently, I chose clear glass doors for the shower. In an effort to cut down on the look of water drops and soap scum - and trying to increase the amount of time I can get away with between shower cleanings - I wanted a new squeegee for this shower. I wanted a small squeegee without compromising quality - and I wanted to be able to hang it in the shower. (Leaving it on the floor = gross!) After considering several different models, I came across this one. I liked how short the handle is, but that the actual squeegee part is the normal size. This also came with a large suction cup to hang the squeegee on - it isn't a suction cup with a hook to hang it on, the squeegee actually fits into the suction cup. I have horrible luck with getting suction cups to stick for very long, so this seemed like a good option. Having the squeegee actually on the suction cup seems like it puts less stress on the suction cup than hanging the squeegee from an attached hook does. I also like the black and stainless steel look - it's more attractive than the white plastic one I used to have. I believe the stainless steel is better quality than plastic - it will hold up better over time. Since it's stainless steel, I don't have to worry about it rusting or doing other funky things that metal can do when it is often exposed to water.I'm really glad I got this - I love it! It met all the criteria I was searching for, the rubber squeegee part does an amazing job of wiping down the water drops (or whatever) and keeping my shower sparkling clean. I use it every time I finish showering and it takes less than a minute - but saves me a lot of scrubbing work when I actually scrub the shower. It also makes the doors much nicer to look at on a daily basis - the whole bathroom just looks cleaner when the doors don't have dried water droplets on them.

I had heard all sorts of commotion about UD eye primer so I was anxious to try it. The first tube I ordered arrived without the sponge doe foot applicator, so I didn't get to try it. The seller was out of the anti-aging eye primer (so politely refunded my money) and I decided to order this from a different seller. (At my age, you just don't buy stuff unless it's "anti-aging", "anti-wrinkle", or "dear-God, just-please-turn-back-the-clock"!) The price was very close to the cost of the first tube I bought (within $2), so I grabbed this and checked out, then anxiously awaited the arrival of my new eye primer, sure it was going to be just the life-altering product I've always wanted.WRONG.I probably should have started this review by saying that although I've very into skincare, I'm not a big makeup person. I have to go to my teenage daughter to ask about the latest trends (winged eyeliner) and products. She almost fell over when I began asking about UD eye primer - although she was decidedly less excited about the anti-aging properties than I was. (Who knows why.) She was so excited about acquiring Urban Decay anything, she immediately went and cleaned her room (an herculean task!) before returning and promising to love me "forever" if I would buy this eye primer. (Maybe that was my out?? Ha) Anyway, I ordered it. Again. Based on the honkin' photo the seller has chosen to represent the primer in this listing, I thought I was buying the exact same thing I had just purchased...with a working applicator. I was pretty bummed when a tube 2.5 times SMALLER showed up. (Yeah, now I see this is advertised as the 0.13 oz Mini Travel Size, instead of the 0.33 full size I had purchased the first time.) In my defense, the large photo is of the 0.33 size. Since I'm not familiar with this product, I was kind of dependent on the photo depicting what I would receive. (And 0.13 is pretty similar to 0.33 when you are comparing between pages.)I was taken aback with the silver pointy top - I was expecting the pretty prismatic top that had adorned the first tube I purchased. You know, like the lid this seller shows in their large product photo above. I was in a rush to get ready that day, so I unscrewed the lid to apply the primer...and was really shocked that there was no spongy doe foot applicator on this one, either. After noting the differences between the item I held in my hand versus the photo staring back at me from the picture, it dawned on me that I was holding an entirely different size.I'm a big one for reading descriptions and knowing what you are buying - and this item was no exception. However, based on the advertised photo I can understand how the size difference could be confusing to a new user. There is no applicator with the size I received, although there is one in the picture. Well, I take that back - your finger is the applicator. It was a big bummer.UD Primer Eyeshadow Primer Potion Anti-Aging alleges it will instantly wake up tired eyes, minimizes crepiness and red, ruddy issues and imperfections. It contains special optical-blurring (light diffusing) pigments that are supposed to create a subtle, soft-focus effect around your eyes by obscuring flaws - and it asserts "new, advanced ingredients" will prevent future age-related damage. If I remember correctly, Bare Minerals purports similar facial results by using their Mineral Veil.This primer claims it has "high-tech wrinkle fighting ingredients", "improves tone and texture", and "measurably improves the signs of aging over time". The active ingredients are Dermaxyl (helps with wrinkles) and Kalpariane (hydrates, firms, and plumps). Kalpariane is also supposed to help with skin suppleness. I'm not familiar with those ingredients, but their results sounded pretty good! ;) I like the primer, although I can't tell any effect from the anti-aging properties. I don't wear this everyday, though. In fact, I probably wear it once-a-week or once every ten days. That's about how frequently I wear eye makeup - but I know my daughter has used it almost daily since it arrived. We both agree we love how it feels - it makes your eyelids kind of velvety...and how it looks, or rather, doesn't look - eye shadow stays in place much better, for much longer, and doesn't get sucked into the lid crease halfway through the day. I don't wear heavy, dark makeup - mostly browns and creams, neutral tones - but I feel like it's hard to see any of my makeup by lunch. I'm not real sure where it slides off to, but when I figure it out I'll be looking at one massive mound of eye shadow! This primer kept the eye makeup on longer, as well as keeping the appearance fresh. My make up doesn't move when I apply a base layer of this primer before doing my eye makeup - and my daughter reports similar results.Even though this little tube isn't going to last very long, I think I'm hooked enough to order more when this is gone. I'm glad we decided to try it. I wish the picture would have been more representative of the product we were actually getting, but I learned a lesson. I will be much more careful comparing listings when I am unfamiliar with the product I'm considering. This is super expensive...however, using it feels more like a pampering splurge than it does just another makeup product to slap on.

Mmmmmk...not the best product, and I'm an office product freak! I got these to go inside the hardcover book I am using as my new planner/art journal. I got these as small holders for little notes, memorabilia, business cards, etc. I chose the medium size because the small doesn't seem like it would hold much. (Not that I'm planning on loading these babies down, but I'd like to be able to get a couple of pieces of paper in them before they are full!) I really had to really think about whether to get these - they are a little costly and there are much prettier/cuter/different options in the scrapbooking realm. After deciding I wanted something clear, I got these. I am apparently blind because I didn't see the white dotted pattern on the body of these. They are still somewhat see-through, I just don't know how I missed that.I ended up having to add my own adhesive to these in order to secure them to the inside of my book. The front of the packaging says "sticks securely" - which I was not blind enough to miss. However, whoever put that on the packaging isn't the sharpest tool in the shed, either. The adhesive on these is awful! The adhesive isn't very big and "strong" is about the last adjective I'd choose to describe it. It sticks to the inside cover, true...but a sudden breeze would dislodge the whole envelope. There is no way they would stick to any surface while you tried to open the flap and put something inside. I wound up using double stick tape all around the perimeter of the back, which has made a world of difference. I can still remove the envelopes if I want, but they are much more secure now than they were with 3Ms version of adhesive. I'm surprised by that, since 3M manufactures so many great adhesives. They missed the boat on this one - especially for the price of these.On the positive side, the Velcro closure that holds the flap closed works really well. These also seem to be sturdy and well made. The perfect size for holding all sorts of little pieces of awesome! They'll fit in a wide assortment of books. Getting three in a package does make them seem a little more reasonable price-wise...but they really need to improve the adhesive, in my opinion.

Who wouldn't love these? Really fun and festive drumstick headband that is comfortable and doesn't squeeze your head. The headband is slightly padded, which also helps. The drumsticks are stuffed material that stand up surprisingly well. Even if they only last this one year, for under $5 I would still consider these a great investment!I got these to dress up the cow statue we have out front, who suffers through (no, celebrates!) being dressed up for each holiday. Don't feel bad for her - the lion is wearing a wonderfully hysterical turkey hat, just so the cow isn't lonely. They actually had a fight over who got to wear these - somehow the cow came out the winner. Which is good, I suppose, because she looks beautiful in her drumstick headband. She really knows how to pull it off! (I'm sure she wishes she really did know how to pull the headband off!) She can wear it until Thanksgiving, when my daughter and I are going to wear the Thanksgiving headwear to our very formal family Thanksgiving dinner. I'm betting these drumsticks are more popular than the two that will be on the table!

This hat is hysterical - it fits my lion statue perfectly. Oh - that isn't the reason you are considering buying it? Well, in that case, it's a little snug on my head, but fits my teenage daughter's head perfectly. The way the legs flop around keeps cracking me up. It's really hard to have a serious conversation with someone wearing this - especially when the wearer keeps bobbing up and down, saying "Gobble! Gobble!". If they bend over, so the turkey beak looks like it's pecking at imaginary food, it's over. There is no redemption - you just can't come back from that! I can't wait to wear this to our formal Thanksgiving family dinner. Until then, it will keep the lion's head warm...and will keep the cow statue - that is wearing a drumstick headband - from feeling lonely.It isn't the best made hat...but it's definitely worth the price! Gobble! Gobble!

Wonderful Halloween decorations! The bat feels very...spooky! It's a gross texture, perfect for Halloween. The spider moves nicely - it kind of wobbles - when hung by the clear plastic loop that it's attached to. (It's more of a price tag loop than a hanging loop so it's a little short, but it worked for my purposes!) The rat is hard plastic and it squeaks when squeezed, like a dog toy. The bird was fantastic attached to the zombie Styrofoam head we made. We draped some of the fake spider web on the wig of the head, then buried the feet of the bird in her hair - it was awesome! The owl...well, the owl is why I deducted a star. That's a piece of junk! I don't mind if decorations like this arrive and I need to do some bending/altering to make them fit my purposes, especially for $2 each. There was nothing I could do to fix that poor lil guy. He was kind of an egg shape with some black feathers stuck to him. His nose wouldn't stay on so I finally glued it to his face. Owls usually have incredible eyesight - unfortunately, my guy is legally blind. I'm not even sure if both eyes are there - the feathers are so sloppily glued on that it's impossible to tell this is supposed to be an owl - which is why I left a star off.If not for the owl I would say this is a pretty great set of decorations at a fantastic price. I would buy them again - with the understanding that the owl won't be usable. That way, if your package arrives differently, you'll be pleasantly surprised. (The owl was really bad.)

Terrific leash! I have three small dogs - a 4 lb Chihuahua/Italian Greyhound puppy, a 6 lb Chihuahua, and a 12 lb Chorgi (Chihuahua/Corgi mix) - and use this leash for all 3 of them. (Well, not the same leash - I bought 3.)*The ribbon-type lead is wonderful:~ It doesn't cut or burn you like the thin string type can~ Multiple leads are easy to untangle when the dogs get all wound together (infinitely easier than the thin string type!)~ I don't worry the lead will burn or cut the pup's skin if it somehow gets wrapped around them~ The ribbon is fantastically bright, very easy to see (even in the dark)~ The leash itself doesn't weigh much - it's very light~ The lock is easy to operate and the locking mechanism is sturdy~ The retraction apparatus is smooth, strong, and doesn't get tangled while winding/unwinding~ The handle is large enough to comfortably fit an adult hand~ There is enough room at the bottom of the handle to clip on a bag dispenser (or tie on three bags with no problem) and a used poop bag holder~ Very confident the lead won't break (like the thin string type can) or suddenly snap away from the handleWhile looking at leashes, I found one that is extremely similar in features and aesthetics, but costs a few dollars more. I originally purchased one of those and one of these - so I could compare. The only difference I noted is that other brand has a light blue, textured "panel" on the sides. The only purpose for the panels is decorative, and definitely not worth the extra money.Bottom Line: Attractive, no frills leash for female or male dogs. If this leash can properly contain a totally spastic puppy just learning to walk on a leash, who pulls constantly while trying to chase rabbits and squirrels, changes direction at full force, and oddly seems to enjoy the bouncing jerk she experiences when, running as fast possible, she suddenly reaches the end of the lead...this leash will work for your dog(s). Awesome price for a reliable leash!* I had different leashes for them, but was recently notified there is a 10 ft leash law in my city. Although my dogs had always been on leashes very similar to this one, the lead was 16 ft. According to Animal Control, "one cannot properly control their dog from a distance of more than 10 feet". Yep, I know I've always struggled to control my mini dogs when they were 16 ft away. Anyway, if your location has a similar ridiculous law - which, by the way, carries the exact same ticket (and fine) as not using a leash at all, or allowing your dog to "run at large" - this leash fits the 10 ft distance perfectly.

Beautiful blue, heavy, thick glass. I was hesitant to purchase a glass spray bottle, after having always used plastic bottles and knowing how clumsy I am, I was worried I would drop and break this soon after delivery. Nope! The sprayer works really well - with two OFF spots, a MISTER spot, and a STREAM spot - your needs are covered. The stream is pretty powerful, much better than the plastic bottle I bought this to replace. My favorite part? It doesn't drip. At all! Dripping dispensers are one of my biggest pet peeves - so I'm thrilled to report that isn't an issue with this beautiful spray bottle. And at 16 oz, it doesn't require frequent filling.  ~ Schwing!! ~A couple of days ago, I grabbed the bottle with wet hands. (I use the bottle as a bark deterrent to train our new puppy - a Chihuahua/Italian Greyhound mix. Chihuahuas have a hard time understanding that barking is not the way to make friends and influence people...so it's getting quite a bit of use.) I went to spray it and it slid out of my hand, falling about four feet to the carpeted floor. It didn't break, chip, or crack. I also accidentally kicked it down the wood stairs - not a single problem. Even the plastic sprayer is sturdy - it's heavier duty than my old sprayer. Neither fall damaged the sprayer at all. (I told you I'm clumsy!) I love this spray bottle - and if it can survive here, it will do a great job at your place!

Tired of finding cotton buds at the bottom of the alcohol bottles, I decided to try this. For probably twenty years I've had my nail polish remover in a similar dispenser - and have loved how easy it is to use. That was my thought about this - no more yucky cotton buds hanging out at the bottom of the bottle, a couple of pumps and you've got just the right amount for your cotton ball or "swab on a stick", and not likely to spill. This has easy, one-hand operation. During research I was doing regarding the best ways to store household chemicals so they don't lose their effectiveness, many "experts" (professionals) assert that amber glass keeps most oils, vitamins, chemicals, etc, more effective, longer. The amber glass helps to maintain the potency of many products. This bottle is made of nice, thick glass - it's unlikely to break if accidentally knocked over. The white ALCOHOL is very easy to read and distinguish from other products. It is also easy to see through the bottle to determine when it needs to be refilled.Although I like this dispenser, I did deduct a star because I don't feel like the pumps deliver enough alcohol. I was hoping a few extra pumps would saturate my cotton ball more fully - but that doesn't happen. Whether I pump the top three times, or eight times, the cotton ball winds up with the same amount of alcohol on it. That's fine - for the most part...however, when I want my cotton ball to be pretty saturated with alcohol so I can use it as an astringent on my face, the small amount (that doesn't even closely saturate even the smallest cotton ball) is frustrating. It's a small annoyance in the scheme of life, but an annoyance nonetheless. Other than that issue I really like this dispenser - it looks nice and is convenient.

The queen of the Gelatos Fan Club is here to leave another review for these fascinating, versatile pigments. This box contains twelve different pastel colors that are, frankly, DELICIOUS! The colors in this line are modeled after French macaroons and include Coconut, Buttercream, Aqua Dolce, Watermelon, Guava, Peach, Earl Grey, Caramel, Kiwi, Fig, Elderberry, Strawberry. Just like with the other sets, I find it impossible to choose one favorite. I have several I use more often - some, MUCH more often - but I wouldn't want to give up any of these precious pastels. Design Memory Craft just keeps outdoing themselves with these amazing magical sticks!The consistency is like a velvety lipstick - you control whether they saturate the substrate, leaving a slick, smooth, powerfully colorful surface...or more of a light hint that produces a washed out/faded look...or anything in between! It doesn't take much to create a piece that really rocks - especially when water is added. Using the included paintbrush with some water will allow you to move these yummy creams around your project with incredible ease. Adding a little water will just turn these into succulent watercolors - adding more water will allow you to achieve the "washed out" look that is so popular right now. (See the photo of the house I made with the Brights set. This is the same unfinished project I keep adding to my reviews, but I can't seem to remember to take pictures of other projects. Thanks, aging! Grrr)I absolutely love the paintbrush Faber Castell has chosen to include with the 15 piece sets. I think it's perfect - which is oddly fantastic, since I usually find the free brushes included with art supplies to be total junk. Surprisingly, this is my VERY favorite brush and I'm using it for everything - not just Gelatos. The clear handle looks cool, fits in my hand like it was custom made, is shorter than the gajillion brushes I already own (easier to control), and the white bristles are...ohhh, those white bristles! They pick up the perfect amount of water for Gelatos. They lay down the Gelatos with amazing awesomeness. (That's my official technical term.) Since the Gelatos are creamy, it would be easy to understand if the medium got all gunked up at the top of the brush (by the ferrule), but miraculously it doesn't. The hairs don't fall out...the bristles aren't too soft or too hard, and it doesn't pick up too much - or too little - water. Goldilocks would definitely approve...This. Brush. Rocks!Wood, canvas, paper...Gelatos will work on many substrates. Metal and glass are the only two things I can think of that wouldn't work - yet, even excluding those two things, do you have any idea how many substrate choices that leaves you with?!? You also have tons of options when it comes to putting them on the substrate...slice off just a little, put it and some water in a spray bottle, and mist it on your project. Apply directly from the applicator. Use a paintbrush. Use a wet paintbrush. Use a cotton bud. A tissue. Your finger. A palette knife. Dauber. Sponge. I'm sure you get the idea. Oh - and these also come with two sponge wedges (like make up applicators) - one soft and one hard. I am so in love!Workable fixative seems to hold these in place, although I have to say that I haven't noticed any color change when adding another wet medium AFTER these have THOROUGHLY DRIED. I also like to use a combination of clear gesso and clear varnish (in a thin coat) to make sure everything stays the same on a prior layer, while adding some tooth for a new layer.Did I mention Gelatos are also acid-free? Portable? Wonderful to mix or overlay? Ohh, yeah! They are my new favorite supply - which says a lot. (My house is like a mix of Hobby Lobby, Michael's, and Dick Blick combined....but only because I would need the square footage of all three of those stores to properly store all my supplies!) Whether you are new to arts and crafts, or you've been around long enough to see all sorts of products come and go, you will easily find a use for these. The effects you can create are truly endless, especially when you begin to bring water into the equation. Easy to control, deposits rich color on the paper, wood, canvas, etc you're using (the house is on a birch wood panel), countless ways to apply...ooh! Gives me goosebumps just thinking about all the creamy, colorful fun crammed into this box of velvety sticks!Gelatos are available in a wide range of combinations - a couple of colors are available in sets of 2, there are many different color combinations available in four packs (each comes with a brush), sets of 15 that have a theme (Pastel, Metallics, Brights, etc), a collection of 23 Double Scoops (Double Scoops are about twice the size of these regular sticks), and a few additional gift sets. You can get a good idea of their awesomeness in the 4 packs - they are more than enough to play with (quantity-wise), and fairly priced at around $10. Plus, you'll get a "free" paintbrush - although the brushes vary, many of the newer 4 packs contain one of the magnificent brushes I spoke about earlier. Wahoo! Try 'em...I think you'll like 'em!

The queen of the Gelatos Fan Club is here to leave another review for these fascinating, versatile pigments. This box contains fifteen different, amazingly shimmering colors...including Silver Ice, Gold Champagne, Iced Coffee, Metallic Mint, Metallic Grape, Metallic Icing, Iced Rose, Iced Pear, Iced Chai, Metallic Melon, Metallic Blueberry, and Iced Currant. Just like with the other sets, I find it impossible to choose one favorite. I have several I use more often - some, MUCH more often - but I wouldn't want to give up any of these precious metallics. Design Memory Craft just keeps outdoing themselves with these amazing magical sticks!The consistency is like a velvety lipstick - you control whether they saturate the substrate, leaving a slick, smooth, powerfully colorful surface...or more of a light hint that produces a washed out/faded look...or anything in between! It doesn't take much to create a piece that really rocks - especially when water is added. Using the included paintbrush with some water will allow you to move these yummy creams around your project with incredible ease. Adding a little water will just turn these into succulent watercolors - adding more water will allow you to achieve the "washed out" look that is so popular right now. (See the photo of the house I made with the Brights set. This is the same unfinished project I keep adding to my reviews, but I can't seem to remember to take pictures of other projects. Thanks, aging! Grrr)I absolutely love the paintbrush Faber Castell has chosen to include with the 15 piece sets. I think it's perfect - which is strange, since I usually despise the free brushes included with art supplies. (They are usually junk!) This one is my favorite brush and I'm using it for everything - not just Gelatos. The clear handle looks cool, fits in my hand like it was custom made, is shorter than the gajillion brushes I already own, and the white bristles are...ohhh, those white bristles! They pick up the perfect amount of water for Gelatos. They lay down the Gelatos with amazing awesomeness. (That's my official technical term.) Since the Gelatos are creamy it would be easy to understand if the medium got all gunked up at the top of the brush (by the ferrule), but miraculously it doesn't. The hairs don't fall out...the bristles aren't too soft or too hard, and it doesn't pick up too much - or too little - water. Goldilocks would definitely approve...This. Brush. Rocks!Wood, canvas, paper...Gelatos will work on many substrates. Metal and glass are the only two things I can think of that wouldn't work - yet, ven excluding those two things, do you have any idea how many substrate choices that leaves you with?!? You also have tons of options when it comes to putting them on the substrate...slice off just a little, put it and some water in a spray bottle and mist it on your project. Apply directly from the tube. Use a paintbrush. Use a wet paintbrush. Use a cotton bud. A tissue. Your finger. A palette knife. Dauber. Sponge. I'm sure you get the idea. Oh - and these also come with two sponge wedges (like make up applicators) - one soft and one hard. I am so in love!Workable fixative seems to hold these in place, although I have to say that I haven't noticed any color change when adding another wet medium AFTER these have THOROUGHLY DRIED. I also like to use a combination of clear gesso and clear varnish (in a thin coat) to make sure everything stays the same on a prior layer, while adding some tooth for a new layer.Did I mention they are also acid-free? Portable? Wonderful to mix or overlay? Ohh, yeah! They are my new favorite supply - which says a lot. (My house is like a mix of Hobby Lobby, Michael's, and Dick Blick combined....but only because I would need the square footage of all three of those stores to properly store all my supplies!) Whether you are new to arts and crafts, or you've been around long enough to see all sorts of products come and go, you will easily find a use for these. The effects you can create are truly endless, especially when you begin to bring water into the equation. Easy to control, deposits rich color on the paper, wood, canvas, etc you're using (the house is on a birch wood panel), countless ways to apply...ooh! Gives me goosebumps just thinking about all the creamy, colorful fun crammed into this box of velvety sticks!Gelatos are available in a wide range of combinations - a couple of colors are available in sets of 2, there are many different color combinations available in four packs (each comes with a brush), sets of 15 that have a theme (Pastel, Metallics, Brights, etc), a collection of 23 Double Scoops (Double Scoops are about twice the size of these regular sticks), and a few additional gift sets. You can get a good idea of their awesomeness in the 4 packs - they are more than enough to play with (quantity-wise), but fairly priced at around $10. Try 'em...I think you'll like 'em!

As I've commented in my other reviews of other Gelatos (I'm a little obsessed with these), THESE ARE PERFECTION! I love the wide range of colors Faber Castell provides in this pack. It's like some color fairy went on a mission to find all the colors you could possibly need, then threw in a few more you'll use time and time again, but didn't realize it. I create a lot with these and I can always find the color I need in this 33 piece set. (28 Gelatos, 3 stamps, 1 palette knife, 1 paintbrush.) From the bright colors you want to get lost in, to the regular colors everyone uses frequently, and even a couple of metallics - this is one set they absolutely nailed. It's kind of expensive, but if you think about it, you get a lot for your money. For just over $2/Gelato - plus a few tools - you get a wide range of delicious creamy pigments that will last forever. Even though I reach for these constantly, they barely look used. The pigments are so rich and deep that it doesn't take much to create something as bright - or subdued - as you want.The photo I've included was one I added to my review of the Bright set which has 12 colors. (That's my favorite set!) Although the house was created with the Brights, it provides an idea of what Gelatos can look like when you work to knock down the colors a bit and want a more subdued look. It's easy to make something brilliantly bold - or to get the washed out look that's so popular. That's one of the things I adore about these creamy sticks of magic - you decide the effect you get by the method you use. There are quite a few YouTube videos that can give you some ideas and I encourage you to check them out if this is a supply you are interested in, but haven't worked with before (or don't know what to do with). I included a few of my favorite tips in my review of the Brights - and always struggle with whether to point people to another review or just repeat the information in my current review. In this case, I'll leave those tips under that other review, but I will say that these work equally well on light or dark surfaces. You choose whether the effect is opaque, full coverage, slick, solid, and appears to lay on the surface of your substrate - or - the color appears to be a part of your substrate, like it's integrated into the paper weave.Whether you are new to arts and crafts, or you've been around long enough to see all sorts of products come and go, you will easily find a use for these. Did I mention they are also acid-free? Portable? Wonderful to mix or overlay? Oh, yeah! The effects you can create are truly endless, especially when you begin to bring water into the equation. Easy to control, deposits rich color on paper, wood, canvas, etc you're using (the house is on a birch wood panel), countless ways to apply...ooh! Gives me goosebumps just thinking about all fun crammed into this box of velvety sticks!Gelatos are available in a wide range of combinations - a couple of colors are available in sets of 2, there are many different color combinations available in four packs (each comes with a brush), sets of 15 that have a theme (Pastel, Metallics, Brights, etc), a collection of 23 Double Scoops (Double Scoops are about twice the size of these regular sticks), and a few additional gift sets. You can get a good idea of their awesomeness in the 4 packs - they are more than enough to play with (quantity-wise), but fairly priced at around $10. Try 'em...I think you'll like 'em!

Let's just get it out of the way...My name is Katherine and I am OBSESSED with Original Pink Box tools. It started with their hammer and quickly moved on to power tools. Before I knew it, I was clamoring for their metal toolbox - just having the pink tool bag isn't sufficient, am I right?! I've had my eye on this saw for awhile now, but kept talking myself out of it. I went back and forth between this reciprocating saw and the circular saw. I spent months telling myself I could just live with the old, ugly, NOT PINK handsaw that I've had for years. I tried to convince myself that saw was enough - I really did. In the end, I chucked that awful idea...and grabbed this OPB beauty. I'm so glad I did!This is one energetic power tool! My handyman made fun of me for getting a pink reciprocating saw (he should have learned when he made fun of my drill...and it totally annihilated his piece of junk) - before we go any further, why do I have a handyman if I'm such a pink tool girl? There are some things that are just too heavy for a girl to carry...and like any of you are going to fault me for employing a younger guy to flex his muscles while he sweats...ANYWAY...(Haha I totally kid). (Or do I?) ;)I've never understood why someone would purchase a corded saw, but thankfully that wasn't anything I had to think about too deeply since OPB's reciprocating saw only comes in the sporty cordless version. This saw does NOT come with the necessary 18 volt lithium ion battery, so you'll want to grab one of those when you're purchasing the saw. I also got an extra charger while I was throwing things in my Amazon cart. (If you already have the drill then you have a battery that will work...but where's the fun in that? Don't you want to have a fully charged battery for your power toys? A lady needs to be ready to "git down" at a moment's notice - so get the extra charger. You'll thank me later, when you're finishing up the work your man's saw just couldn't handle.) You may also want to grab a pair of OPB's fashionable PINK safety glasses, too. One tends to lose a bit of their sexy power when having to wear a Dixie cup taped to their eye because they didn't wear safety glasses, and therefore had to spend an afternoon in the ER with a nurse fishing small shards out of their eye. Just sayin'.The battery takes about 4-5 hours to fully charge the first time. You'll know the battery is charging when the red light comes on...and you'll know it's fully charged when both the green and red lights are lit. Putting the battery in/taking the battery out of the saw is self-explanatory and easy. I should mention that this does comes with two saw blades - a coarse tooth blade (I use these for wood and plastic) and a fine tooth blade (I use these for cutting metal). It also arrives with an average size hex key (or Allen wrench) to tighten/loosen saw blades. (It's really easy to see where the hex key fits - it's at the top end of the saw in the area of the blade shoe.) I love that it's an average/popular size - if it's misplaced (which mine most likely will be soon), it's super easy to replace it. Oh - and about the blades...it's really important to buy the correct length and type. A blade designed for cutting wood works much better when you cut wood with it - and surprisingly, a blade intended for metal use seems to excel at cutting metal. The blades need to be at least 3.5" for this saw, and depending on your project, possibly longer. It's also good to know one thing about TPI (teeth per inch), too - the lower the number, the faster and rougher it is designed to cut. Higher numbers are better for slower, smoother cuts. So 6 TPI is great for ripping through some wood that doesn't need to be cut smooth & precise...while 20 TPI indicate you should go much slower and your result will be a smoother, "prettier" cut. (If I could just make myself follow this now...)One other quick note - depending on how you plan on storing your reciprocating saw, you may want to hold onto the little bags that the original blades come in. At least while you are still using the blades. Saw blades are covered in oil and can make a big ol' mess - and there is definitely a "smell" to them. When I keep my saw in my tool bag I take the blades out and put them in a little hard plastic sleeve thingy I have. If it's just going in my toolbox, I don't bother removing the blade - it won't be bouncing around in a bag, so the oil won't come off on everything around it.I also want to mention the other thing I love about this saw - the handle. It's softer than other saws I've used - and it's the perfect size for my hand. I don't think it's any smaller than other saw handles, I just like how it's made. It fits my hand well and it's easy to control. And like the other fine machinery made by OPB, this has a 12 month warranty. Amazon also lists this saw for about $12 less than you can get it on OPB's site. So...WHY are you STILL reading this? I can't believe you haven't gotten one yet. The warranty, the company reputation, the price, the variable speed, the comfortable fit in your hand, and hello - it's PINK!! You won't find a better saw - especially that will make the boys jealous. It's such a great reciprocating saw that I doubt the bright pink color would even both most men. You may have to drag out the Bedazzler if you really want to make sure they keep their hands off. ;)(Wow. Power tools - in general - must just make one act like a chauvinist!)

This is exactly as described - it arrived quickly and it charges the extra battery I purchased for my saw. The drill comes with a battery, but the saw doesn't. Now that I have two batteries, it's only a matter of time before I lose the charger...right?!...so I went ahead and purchased this charger when buying the reciprocal saw and additional battery through Amazon. I love the quality of everything I've purchased from Original Pink Box and this charger is no exception. It's nice having a charger in my pink metal toolbox (in the garage) - and one in my pink tool bag (more portable). These are so small they don't take up much room. I can't get enough of these pink tools and should become their tool model soon. ;) Nah - I would put Rose Riveter in some pink overalls (or maybe give her a pink bandanna?) and make HER the OPB spokeswoman!Having multiple batteries and chargers means I always have a full battery ready to go. My plan of world domination is coming along nicely - it won't be much longer until I have every single tool Original Pink Box makes, and then there will be no stopping me!

Another cute-as-can-be little detail that added some spooky fun to the Halloween decorations in my fairy garden! This is sitting on a little leaf table in one of the corners - next to a dripping taper candle...the table is kind of covered by trees and sits across from the main table the fairies like to gather around. That table has a little Spell Book I got this year - so it appears the resident fairies are up to all kinds of mischief this time of year! This is the perfect size at just under an inch. Superior Dollhouse Miniatures always has darling miniatures - the quality is reflected in their prices, but I know the little treasures I purchase will last for years. (Probably long after my children are successful at putting me in a home!)

Perfect little book to put in my (ever-growing) fairy garden. I purchased it when I got some miniature jack-o-lanterns and I just love how this adorable book adds so much festive detail to the main table the fairies like to gather around. I placed a few of the jack-o-lanterns on the ground by the bottom of the table - like they may have been knocked over, and placed a small camping lantern next to this book on the table. It looks like the mischievous little fairies were busy looking up spells before something scared them off. It's about an inch long - and makes a spooky sweet addition to any fairy garden or dollhouse. Great purchase!

The hat arrived quickly in a plastic retail bag. Every time I look at it I crack up - it is perfect for the cow statue we keep out front and dress up every holiday. I love the braids! The hat is big enough to fit an adult head, with the braids hanging down below the shoulders. The braids are very soft and bright white - but they are made out of some sort of wool, so it tends to snag when touching anything (even dry skin) and the fibers break, leaving portions of braid "fuzzy". (That's why I deducted a star.) I'm going to replace the little red ribbons on the ends of the braids with some ribbon of cows singing Christmas carols. It's going to be lovely with her oversized ornament necklace. This hat is so fun, I can't promise my kids won't be trying to steal it so they can wear it to school during the holiday season!

I already own several self-healing cutting mats. One is so big it nearly covers my entire desk - I think it's 24" x 36". I love being able to create on it without having to worry about cutting the table, or accidentally getting paint/ink/glue/etc on my desk - and I love the smooth writing surface a good self-healing mat creates. The only problem? The ugly green one I have (which is black on the other side) doesn't cover my whole desk, so I'm constantly either writing off the edge or getting some supply on my table. (Tangent: Does that mean I've actually gone over the edge? More than once?!) I have been looking for another self-healing cutting mat for awhile, in order to fill the rest of the desk, but I didn't want another green/black one. Since I adore anything pink, this was like winning twice!The perfect pink hue, this mat takes cuts easily and immediately self-heals. It also provides that comfortingly familiar writing surface excelencia! The white grid lines really stand out, which makes measuring things and drawing straight lines incredibly easy. (I am awful at drawing straight lines - even with a ruler.) This arrives with a sticker attached to the top that folds over and also attaches to the other side. It is pretty easy to remove the adhesive, but you will probably find a minimal amount of Goo Gone or Sticky Stuff Remover to be helpful in removing the slightly sticky film that remains. It's hard to describe - I didn't have any trouble removing the large tag, it removed cleanly, but it left behind an oddly tacky film. Not problematic enough to ruin your day (or even prompt second thoughts about purchasing this mat), just something to be aware of.Working on a self-healing mat just makes everything so much easier. Your handwriting will improve dramatically when you write on this - pens you didn't care for (or refused to work) previously, will suddenly become your favorites. The very best thing about this self-healing mat - well, besides the fact that it's pink? Is that the material heals well and you have two sides to work on. So you can make one side the side you use when doing messy activities (painting, gluing, etc) - then flip it over when you are going to use it as desk protector, so that stays clean and pretty. I've used self-healing mats for so long that I can't remember life without them! I am also very fond of Vyco, which is an amazingly smooth and cool self-healing mat/protector you can apply to your work surface. I actually prefer Vyco, but it's kind of permanent - and one thing I love about these mats is their portability. Vyco just attaches to the surface with a special double-stick adhesive, and can easily be cut with scissors or an Xacto to perfectly fit the contours of your table or desk. There is nothing like that flat, smooth surface - the expense is greater, though. Then again, the Vyco lasts a really long time before you replace it. It comes in gray/cream and green/cream - your choice which color to have face up. If you're interested, you can find it here: Alvin Home Indoor Office Craft Art Draft VYCO Green/Cream Board Cover, 31 x 42 Inches Sheet (VBC44-5). Whether I decide to install Vyco on my table or desk again remains to be seen...but everybody better keep their hands off my pink mat! :)

Gobble gobble! These are absolutely adorable! Yes, they arrive a bit...wonky. However, it isn't difficult to bend them a bit - using only your fingers - to make them stand a little straighter. If your fingers don't work, a small pair of needle nose pliers does a great job! If you choose to use a tool to perform a little surgery on your gaggle of waddles, be very careful. The teeth on the pliers can mar the paint, and too much pressure can detach the less-than-optimal welding. I also used my fingers and the pliers to lightly bend the feathers, so each one has a little additional character. Doing that isn't necessary at all, but I think it made them even cuter than they were when they arrived.There are two each of three different turkeys. All have yellow, orange, brown, and green paint, but the placement varies on the three pairs. A small tea light fits perfectly in them, although a couple required a bit of a struggle before the turkeys would cooperate. When I adjusted their wings and legs, I also used my fingers to bow out their heads and turn their beaks up just a little (that appears to be what a few of them in the photo have had done). The heads arrived pretty flat, so they appeared to be looking down. A very simple thing to fix - had I chosen not to adjust anything on them, they truly would have been fine...and very cute. I put remote controlled tea lights in them. The ones I had on hand change colors randomly, which adds even more fun to these little guys. I mention that because I don't know if the heat from an actual candle will make these metal turkeys hot - so if you use a regular tea light candle you may want to keep an eye on their warmth. (Between a meat thermometer for your edible turkey, and feeling for the heat level of these turkeys...I never knew I could be so concerned about turkey temperatures!)These should last for years, but the paint feels like it will scratch easily. I am going to place mine on our front porch on a piece of natural wood. Using Glue Dots to keep them grounded in the wind, I'm going to place raffia, small pine cones, Putka pods (mini pumpkins), silk leaves, and acorns around the feet of my little gobblers. Before I put them in the elements, however, I am going to give them a quick spray of acrylic shellac. I would be more concerned about their flammability if I wasn't using LED candles. The spray acrylic will increase the durability of the paint, but can *potentially* make them more attractive to flame - which is important to keep in mind. (I've switched almost all the regular candles in my home over to LED candles.)These would be adorable in a table centerpiece or other display around your home. There are enough of them to spread out, or you could give a few as gifts - and their colors make them perfect for any sort of fall decorating. If you are careful and have the tiniest bit of talent with pliers, it would be so cute to bend their legs and change their positions - maybe bend one knee so one of their little leaf feet can rest on a miniature bale of hay? (Just a suggestion.) As another reviewer pointed out, some of these turkeys experience difficulty standing when they first arrive - jet lag? - however, I don't find it to be as big of an issue as the other reviewer found it to be. And with the popularity of LED candles, there is absolutely no safety concern. Based on my experience, you will most likely have to spend less than five minutes barely bending their legs - it seems like their weight distribution is easily thrown out of whack...but what a small issue in order to have the cutest little rafter of turkeys around!

So...I really like these! I needed a way to create light up eyes in the Styrofoam heads I was making for Halloween. I couldn't find any sort of eyes that would either light up, or glow-in-the-dark, around the size I needed. (And I was very flexible on sizing options.) These popped up as one of the options under "Customers Who Bought This Item Also Bought" list. As soon as I saw them I knew they would be perfect!I only received nine of the ten pair I was supposed to receive, but it wasn't that big of a deal since I only needed eight pairs. (The reason for the star deduction.) The fact they are different colors is just awesome! I wedged the earrings into a small hole I made in each Styrofoam head, where the eyes should be. These were bright enough they could be seen from the street - at least 50 yards! They really added character to the spooky faces. AND they lasted without any issues - 16 nights at 3-4 hours/night. That's excellent - and way more than I expected! They also arrived very quickly.Now that Halloween is over, I put them on my art desk. I wasn't sure what I was going to do with them at this point - since you can replace the batteries I thought about just hanging onto them until next Halloween. When my daughter and her friends saw them sitting on my desk, that was it. She asked if those were the earrings I had used as the head eyes, and when I replied yes, they all squealed. She asked (begged?) to have some of them for her and her friends...when I said yes they all squealed again. Apparently they've been wearing them at school and they've been a big hit. From what I heard, the bowling alley almost CLOSED DOWN because they were so cool. lol ;)A few of the earrings have stopped working, a few are pretty dim, but several are still going strong - which is hard to believe. The girls have asked if I can find replacement batteries, so I'm off to do that as soon as I post this review. The batteries are really, really small, so we'll see how many actually make it into the earrings...and how many wind up lost on the floor. I will also be ordering another set of these for next Halloween - and probably another set for New Year's. These are fun and unique, seem to last forever, and the price is terrific. Had I gotten all ten pairs then this would have easily been a resounding five star purchase!I've attached two photos of how they looked the way I used them. I apologize for the amount of reflection around the green eyes - they didn't look like that in person.

I purchased a "Set of 3 Indoor or Outdoor Metal and Glass Lanterns" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00G2SKCJS?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage) without realizing how large the largest lantern really is. All of the candles I already owned looked ridiculously sad in this lantern - even placing a couple of the candles in that lantern didn't work. I began the hunt for a 6" candle. When I came across this I knew I'd hit pay dirt - I have purchased Gerson LED candles previously and knew they are beautiful, high quality, flameless candles. The one I purchased arrived quickly and in perfect condition. There is no way you could find a traditional candle of this size for the same price, so I feel I got a great deal.This requires 3 "C" batteries to operate, which the seller includes! <gasp> This looks exactly like a traditional candle - due to the real wax they use, it's impossible to tell the difference...in the daytime. The story changes at night - the candle is still beautiful, but the "triple wick flame" sits about halfway down the candle. I don't care for LED candles made like that - most of the light drowns in the space before it ever reaches the top. The thickness of the sides - which is good for every reason except lighting - suffocates a good portion of the light, too. Placing the flame much closer to the top would allow more of the light to spill over the edges. The flame would be quite a bit brighter and it would look more natural. There isn't anything particularly "wrong" with this style, I just prefer the other one. I normally have candles around to produce a flickering, ambient light in low light conditions (or power outages) - having the "flame" so far inside the candle kind of defeats my purpose.The fact remains that this candle fits my lantern very well and it is a beautiful, large candle. It doesn't seem to drain the batteries very fast - I have used this for three hours a night, for twelve nights - and it's still going. It is easily operated by the On/Off switch on the bottom. Although I haven't had to do it yet, the batteries appear easy to change. The bisque color matches every decor. I am going to wrap a pip berry garland around the bottom of the candle to create a little more interest, although adding anything really isn't necessary. This was a fantastic purchase that I am genuinely happy with. If you are looking for a large candle that doesn't pose all the dangers of a "real" candle, your search is over...you won't find a better deal on such a sizable, high quality LED candle. What are you waiting for? Order one already!

Pretty pods that will be great with the Thanksgiving centerpiece I'm making. Although I like the pods, I am really disappointed with the seller. I thought the pods would arrive in a bag similar to the photo. Or some sort of bag, as stated in the description:  Features 4 cups in one Bag. There was no bag. They were simply thrown in a small box and mailed. What a MESS when I opened them! I had tiny pieces of Putka pods e-v-e-r-y-w-h-e-r-e!! It was like mini pumpkin confetti...that I didn't expect. Or want.The second problem is that I received a little over 2 cups - not the 4 cups advertised. I am highly annoyed with Vintage Designs Store and will never purchase from them again. Most of the pods arrived broken, many in tiny pieces. Had I known this is what I would end up with, I would have gone with another seller. ANY other seller. If you are going to purchase these, please be aware you will not receive anything like the photo - you will get a small box of about half the amount you pay for. I would send these back, but probably a third of them are now in my vacuum. When I said I received a little over two cups, that estimate includes the dust/pieces that "exploded" when I opened the box. The amount I can measure is just over 1.5 cups. With a natural dried product like this, it's understandable - even expected - that some will arrive broken. However, I believe that should be the minority - not the majority.(Please Note: The last photo belongs to the seller - it is NOT my picture. I am including it with my photos so you can compare what is advertised vs what I received. The photo of the pods in the box is how they arrived - the other two photos are of the pods in a glass dish, so they are easier to see.)

These are great tombstones to write on for Halloween, an old milestone birthday, etc. I bought one to put in my yard, along with some zombie hands that I strung spider webbing on, then placed the hands about two feet from the tombstone. It was AWESOME! I had written "Here Lies Myra Mains" and "April 15, 2014 - October 31, 2014" on the black space with chalk markers. I can't tell you how fabulous it looked! It looked like the chalk writing was glowing at night. The space to write on is nice and big - you can see the writing from a good distance - and it just begs to have spooky names written on it. My kids and I kept changing the names - but I decided we needed a few more to properly express the temporary cemetery, so I returned and bought five more. "Bea A Fraid", "Ira Gret", "Yule B Sorree", "Gladys Nottmie", "Upton O'Good", "Lon Gawn", and "Pastor Prime", were just a few of the names we had in our cemetery during the Halloween season this year. For an Over the Hill party it would be great to put the "old" person's name on the tombstone.It can be difficult to write on these - the chalkboard coating is VERY thin and it's super easy to accidentally push too deep and kind of poke a hole when you write. A damp cloth removes the chalk marker, but even being really gentle and careful, some of the chalkboard coating comes off. The more you erase/change the writing, the more evident it is. The tombstone itself is sturdy enough to last for several years - so I plan to quickly re-paint the chalkboard part with new chalkboard paint next year. Only the black part of the tombstone is meant to have writing on it - there is no chalkboard coating on the gray parts. The paint and details on the gray perimeter of the tombstones makes them more realistic than I expected.One star was deducted for the flimsy chalkboard surface - at about $17 each, I don't think it's asking too much to have a chalkboard surface that lasts more than one time - erasing on the current chalk surface leaves muddied areas where the chalkboard surface has come off, so no matter how gentle you are, using a damp cloth to remove some writing (even a mistake) will leave a marred, matte, unattractive spot. This doesn't happen all over, but just in (some) large spots. I only took one star for that because with chalkboard paint so readily available, this is easy to fix myself. (You could even use black acrylic paint and write on it with paint pens, repainting it when you want to change the wording.) The other star was taken due to the very poor quality of the plastic "stakes" included with the tombstone. They are a total joke. It's a waste of money on the company's part to even both having these included with the item. I wound up breaking bamboo skewers in half and using those instead. The skewers worked MUCH better. I wouldn't even waste time trying to get the included "plastic cocktail straws" to work...unless, you know, you dig fiddling with frustratingly impossible, ridiculously unusable, total time wasters.The little complaints aside, I would (and did!) buy these again. The price is a little steep, but they'll last for several years - especially if you don't mind repainting them a bit. Really fun decorations!

I purchased two of these soap dispensers in the same order, but from different sellers. This one is nice and heavy - it doesn't slide around when your wet hand is pressing the pump. The glass is clear, without any bubbles or flaws. The sturdy thickness helps to prevent chips and cracks - and means the glass is not likely to break easily if it's knocked over or dropped. (Obviously the results will probably vary with a 10 ft drop versus, say, a 2 ft drop. I'm guessing.) At 16 oz, it holds quite a bit of soap. I bought two of these dispensers - one from Sally's Organics that is blue glass and has the "modern" pump Refillable Liquid Soap Dispenser - Designer Cobalt Blue Bottle / Mirror Polished Silver Hand Pump with Stainless Steel Spring Mechanism - Decorative in the Kitchen or Bathroom , and this one from Industrial Rewind that is clear glass and has the "traditional" metal pump - and I am SO much happier with this pump.I use both of these dispensers with the generic version of Dial hand soap, not dish soap. I noticed a pretty bad dripping issue with the other dispenser by the end of the first day, but was kind of trapped by that point. (You have to fill the dispenser in order to check the drippiness factor...however, filling it means it's gonna be a LOT of work to return it!) This dispenser, on the other hand, hasn't dripped once. Not even a little dribble. It's been wonderful! The amount of soap it dispenses is perfect for hand washing, too. The bronze metal pump matches my kitchen perfectly. As a whole, the dispenser is a classy, beautiful addition to have near my kitchen sink. In fact, I'm ordering three more of these (for shampoo, conditioner, and body wash), and I already ordered another one of these pumps as a replacement pump for the drippy (defective) dispenser. This style matches many different decors, but I love how it enhances my antique farmhouse/shabby chic theme.Soap dispensers take quite a bit of abuse in my house because they get a lot of use. This one has held up perfectly for the short time we've been using it, and I have confidence it will continue to perform flawlessly. If there is some sort of change - the pump begins to drip or stops working, the glass suddenly develops a crack - I will definitely update this review. If there is no update then it's safe to believe the dispenser is still successfully pumping out handfuls of soap...left and right.

Beautiful handmade journal full of flower-infused paper. The pink colored cover is lovely and the tooling appears professional. As these are all handmade by different artists, the actual tooling design varies, although the overall design is classic and will appeal to women who like a variety of styles - this would appeal to a wide variety of different tastes and would be an excellent gift. I can't imagine someone not liking this!Due to the handmade nature, no two are exactly alike. For example, the one I received has a completely different design on it than the one in the photo. It is still a beautiful, bright pink journal, but the front has flowers all over it, with a sort of basket weave, or lattice border. The back has the same border, but the tooled design inside the border is completely different - still highly attractive. The sides of the journal are smooth and plain, with only the boarder pattern at the top and bottom. The left spine has black strings binding it in an X pattern. (Double needle binding?) There are a few errant holes from the awl used to pierce the leather, which I'm afraid will cause the thread to tear through over time. That isn't a big enough issue for me to dislike the journal, just an observation. The leather is very stiff - obviously not the highest quality leather - I'm confident it will soften up with use. (A question/thought...doesn't the Indian culture revere bovines? Does working with leather conflict with those deeply held beliefs? I don't know, just wondering. An Indian artist working with leather would seem to cause some inner strife. Maybe I'm wrong?)The closure is fantastically awesome! I can easily imagine it on a vintage box of some sort - but used as a closure on this book? Brilliant! I love the way it slides closed, securely locking itself. I don't believe there is any way to attach an actual lock to this journal or closure. If you are searching for a journal that locks to avoid prying eyes, this probably isn't the one you want.There are five signatures bound in this book. The description states there are "80 pages", but there looks to be more. I haven't counted all the pages (I don't want to take all the fun!), however there are 20 pages in the first signature. (Ten sheets folded/bound in half.) The paper has a very organic feel - there are little yellow flowers and green grasses made into the paper. This does add a slight additional texture to the (already) somewhat naturally textured paper. The paper has a nice feel to it. It accepts ink very well - ball point, roller ball, and pencil have been fantastic. Felt and fountain pens tend to bleed unless you're quick. My guess is that this is internally slack-sized paper. I definitely would not create my finest work on this paper! It is good for sketching and writing, but like most handmade paper, is too absorbent to hold crisp or fine details. As a mixed media artist, I strongly believe this paper would successfully accept adhesives, dry painting techniques, pastels, Gelatos, and graphite - and possibly watercolor, as long as it's on the drier side. I wouldn't attempt anything real wet with this paper - it's going to tear and degrade too quickly. As an art journal this is terrific as long as you keep those constraints in mind. If you are looking for paper to handle a larger range of media, try one of the journals available specifically for that purpose. (I have this Strathmore Mixed Media Art Journal, 5.5 by 8.5-Inch, 64 Pages and absolutely love it, along with this one Strathmore Visual Journal Spiral Bound 5.5"X8"-Mixed Media Vellum. Both are great depending on the type of binding, and overall look, you prefer.) Keep in mind the limitations of handmade paper - it has certain strengths, but it also tears and disintegrates relatively easy.I am very pleased with this journal and am looking forward to using it a lot. I will mainly use this for my thoughts, quotes and phrases I want to remember, sketching...kind of an overall "Book of Me". ;) There are much better journals on the market for art processes - as an overall catch-all to jot down everything from appointments to notes, and memories to pictures/sketches made with relatively dry media, this is perfect! (I don't want to discourage anyone from using "wetter" or "heavier" media in this journal - by all means, use whatever you want! You could probably get some beautifully dramatic backgrounds if you used alcohol inks, Hydrus Inks, etc. Using really wet supplies like that, combined with the flowers and leaves already buried in the paper, would create some truly magnificent background pages!)I would totally buy more of these for gifts, whether the recipient is creative or not. A wonderful size that's large enough to give you the space you need to actually write (or draw) something - the signatures are easily laid flat, giving you the option of writing (creating) all the way to the inner "hinge". (Probably the wrong term.) Unlike books like Moleskin journals, where you never can really get to the spot where the pages meet (that "hinge" part), this binding makes this easy. You can create a double-page spread without any difficulty. The size is also perfect for taking with you - whether you carry it or stick it in your bag. (If your purse or bag is like mine, it's a bottomless pit of who-knows-what...so putting a book of this size in it is no big deal.) You will feel somewhat elegant and pampered when you use this beautiful journal.If you have questions about anything I haven't covered, please ask. I am happy to provide any additional information you need. :)

Ummmmm NO. These are NOT glow-in-the-dark. AT ALL. (I just noticed the headline states they are - which is completely false. I had totally forgotten they were supposed to glow-in-the-dark! They aren't...not even a little. I wrote the following review based on my experience BEFORE I saw they supposedly phosphoresce. I can't believe I forgot they were supposed to do that - if they glowed at all, I wouldn't have suggested adding glow-in-the-dark spray paint!)  ~  (I had originally given these four stars, but after seeing the false advertising, I'm changing my rating to three stars. These are not for you if it's important they glow-in-the-dark out of the package - I can't stress this enough.) Would I buy these again? Yes - but I'm truly annoyed at the misleading information. Such a blatant misrepresentation would normally produce a 0 star rating from me. Anyway, onto the review...I looked all over for skeletons like this, but couldn't find them locally. The price of these thin-plastic little guys seems a bit high to me for what you get. That said, these are so versatile and gravely cute, my regret was not purchasing more. They are made out of that thin, bendable plastic that is full of air (sorry - I forget what it's called, but it's the opposite of hard, extruded plastic) so they are easy to change or manipulate with minimal effort. It would be really fun to hang a bunch from the ceiling...and even more fun to remove the gauze and lightly spray the only the skeletons (or just the gauze) with glow-in-the-dark spray paint. These will definitely last for many seasons. Whether you choose to hang several, or just one, these skeletons will add tons of spooky flair to your Halloween decor.I changed mine quite a bit, removing the gauze wrap and cutting off the thin plastic loop (used for hanging) on top of the heads. With a few art supplies I had around, I "dirtied" up the gauze (mummified skeletons can't have clean gauze!), added a little hair, painted the nails black, and made tiny nooses for their necks. (The idea was to make them look like some people I know, but only a slight resemblance.) I re-wrapped each one in their gauze and hung them outside. Even though they got stuck in a pretty good rain, they stood up very well to the elements. I look forward to pulling them out again next year, but will have to purchase a few more to make the family complete. ;)

Adorable miniature pumpkins! All the jack-o-lanterns in my bunch are painted just as well as they are in the product photo - it's clear they are good quality. These are the perfect size for a fairy garden, but also have many uses as Halloween/fall home decor. The perfect addition to so many of my little scenes - next to tiny houses, on infinitesimal hay bales, sitting around the base of a tree, in the cemetery...the list goes on and on. My only problem - I should have ordered a second set! When purchasing online, it's always a crapshoot whether miniature items will actually match the photos provided, so as a sort of trial I only order one item/set at first. (I've spent too much hard-earned money on horribly painted, poor quality miniatures in the past.) These jack-o-lanterns are made of resin, so they'll last - and are truly just as cute as can be. Get some and see - BUT save yourself some shipping costs. If you think you may need more than six for your purposes, order multiple sets. You won't regret it!Tip: I can't remember being disappointed by anything I've ever purchased from Dollhouses and More LLC, although I try to wait and purchase a couple of things at once so the shipping charges don't seem so excessive. They offer an incredible selection of cute items so the problem isn't finding something you "have" to have - the difficulty is narrowing your order enough that delivery won't require multiple mail trucks showing up in front of your house!

I have to admit, I bought this more of a curiosity than anything else. I was looking at adhesives and it showed up in my search results. I was intrigued so I ordered it...along with the normal adhesive I use. (I didn't want to be left with some novel idea that didn't work and no adhesive!)The package arrived quickly, packed well for shipping - and included everything in the photo. When I first opened the little tin that holds the adhesive-filled little pen and light combo, I was truly surprised how flexible the pen-like part is. It makes sense, as squeezing the adhesive medium out of a slightly soft tube is much easier than a rigid cylinder - this adhesive is compromised of a kind of runny, gelatinous formula. It isn't overly liquidy (nice word!), but rather staying where I placed it. I love that a strong bond is achieved with small amounts of Bondic. I was worried when I tried to adhere objects I couldn't see through - after all, how is the little UV light supposed to penetrate solidly opaque surfaces and cure the adhesive? I finally came to the conclusion that I don't need to know HOW...as much as I need to know it WORKS. And it definitely works!I had used a glue gun to adhere a couple of Neodymium magnets to the backs of wood clothes pins. That method worked for about six months, but then I found the clothes pins laying on the kitchen floor after they'd fallen off the magnets. After scraping most of the glue gun residue off the clothes pins, I squeezed out two small dollops onto the clothes pins, placed the little round magnets over the dollops of wet Bondic. I began to apply the light, sure this wasn't going to work because the light couldn't really filter into the necessary spots. WRONG! After just a couple of seconds, I removed the light and carefully (gently!) tried moving one of the magnets. I was shocked when it didn't move at all!!I don't know the specifics of how this stuff works and frankly, I don't really care. My focus is how well the product works...and work it does!
