Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for a fair and honest reviewThis is an ultra beefy charger with a large bank and fast charge times.It's actually pretty lightweight and about the same size as a cell phone except a bit thicker.The charger itself can actually be charged about twice as fast as a comparbly sized power bank, and it actually adjusts to the requirements of the devices you are charging to ensure a fast charge every time. Plus, that 10k bank means you can charge a lot of devices before needing to refill the powerbank, making it perfect for travelling or extended time away from a convenient charging station/computer/etc....It has a power button as well, which is actually a pretty nice feature and has 4 LED indicators for charge levels (each represents 25% of the charge bank).All told, this is actually the single best charger I own. I have a couple others that are almost on par with this, but this one still stands a bit apart due to its speed and efficency. sadly, I rarely get to carry it as my wife has claimed it as her own, lol.

Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for an honest reviewWe were pretty stoked to be able to test this out as my wife and I were actually in the market for one at the time iHome made this review request to us, so fortuitous timing.As far as this diffuser goes, it's more in the subtle realm of diffusers. It works, and works well, but it will take a while for the scent to reach all the corners of your home. That isnt a negative at all in my opinion. Rather than be overwhelming, it provides a nice background scent, which I personally really appreciate.We didnt have any issues opening the diffuser, which I have read is one of the larger compalints about this one. We thought it was pretty easy to manage. We did find it to be a little resistant or stiff however.It is worth noting that this doesnt really hold 160ml. It does hold 110ml safely, and that is more than adequate, but the basin size was a bit misrepresented. You can probably get 160 ml in it, but I wouldnt recommend it.As far as cleaning it goes, we've really just used warm water, which has been sufficient. You dont add enough essential oil to the water for it to really retain the scent after a simple rinse (at least, we dont).It seems to run for a good 3 or 4 hours before needing to be replenished.Also, the lighting looks really cool. We often turn this on at night, and it definitely is pleasing to the eye. It's also fairly unobtrusive and can be placed almost anywhere easily.All told, a very nice product. I'd like to see the pieces come apart a bit mroe easily and also would like to see the specs clarified a bit better, but all told, it's definitely a worth owning item.

This was an interesting book that goes through the history of sugar and the impact it has had on the world. I found it engaging and I liked the fact that many old photos and pictures of paintings and sketches were included. They really helped get a sense for the various periods of time represented/detailed in this book. Obviously, sugar has been the source of a lot of violence in the world and the authors dont...ummm....sugar coat....this fact. They try to be honest and fair in their approach to this title. While I thought it wasnt perfect as a historical or contextual work, it was still very good and I enjoyed reading it quite a bit.

So, I saw these dudes opening for Mastodon and Gojira a year or so ago, and I'm not even sure where to begin. The singer came out with a stuffed owl being worn as a headdress, which I cant say I've ever even contemplated before, much like seen. They then proceeded to rock the house. Clearly I had been missing out on some awesome rock, so I immediately went out and bought this album from a local CD shop. It exceeded my expectations. sometimes, thinking back on a show, you can romanticize somethign so it becomes greater in memory than it is in reality. Not so with this band. This album is raucous, non stop in your face rock. Sometimes it teeters on being metal, sometimes it pulls from older rock and metal influences, and sometimes it is almost stoner rock. It is always however unrelenting and incredibly fun. Gets me pumped up everytime I listen to it. I really cant recommend this album enough.

This is the second album I have heard from Graveyard as I journey through their releases one at a time. This is absolutely another great album by a band that has quickly become one of my favorites. This one goes in a distinctly more Clapton-ish direction with a lot more bluesy, soulful songs, but still retains that Sabbath-y edge. The music and the vocals are spot on once again, and this is another album I can listen to any day of the week and be stoked.

So, the first I really heard of these guys was seeing them open for Mastodon and Clutch recently, and I was pretty blown away by their catchy old school riffs and the fact that their singer can flat out wail, so I went out and bought this album from a local CD store (GrayWhale). It has exceeded my expectations. I have since read a lot of comparisons to Sabbath, and those are apt, but they dont really tell the whole tale. You really gotta throw in a heavy dose of Clapton/Cream and sprinkle in some Donovan (yes Donovan) to get the whole picture I think. However, these guys arent just regurgitating old riffs. They are bringing it with a fresh look at an older genre of music and recapturing the awe and almost mystical nature that music held back in the day. I can listen to this album any day of the week and be stoked. I recommend you give it a listen.

Disclaimer: I received this in exchange for a fair and honest reviewThis dehumidifier works great! We have a swamp cooler in our house, and so this has become a tool of necessity. One clear indication that it is working (outside of the fact that the air feels notably dryer) is that the little water basin fills up in a day or two at most. A cool side effect is that this water is apparently potable (I havent tested this out, lol, but I imagine it could come handy in a pinch). Speaking of....their is a little indicator on it that lets you know when the tank is full and it auto shuts off as well so you dont overflow the basin.It's also completely unobtrusive. It will pretty much fit anywhere, is lightweight, and has a long enough cord to give you options for placement.For us, this has been a stellar product that is actually in use every day. If you live in an area with high humidity, or if you have a swamp cooler like we do, this is almost a must own IMO.

Received as part of a Kickstarter reward for backing the game.So....this game was everything I hoped for and more. Obsidian really set the bar for CRPG's. Beyond that, I think Avellone and company really elevated their game further as far as their story writing goes as well. Just flat out superb, seamless, and fairly well flawless IMO.There has been a lot written about this game already, obviously, but I will say that with all the hype and all the funding that went into this, the potential for a let down was great, so to have the game not only deliver, but deliver in such grand fashion was amazing.The character development was deep and fulfilling and the quests actually made sense....rather than just simple fetch and escort quests with no rhyme or reason, everything had an actual reason in this game, and even where they didnt serve to advance the main story, they still had a very real role in filling out the depth of the world itself.The actual story line itself was pretty gripping. The end of Act 1 gave you the sense of a journey really just beginning, the end of Act 2 was a "holy !" moment, and the end of Act 3 let you know there was no turning back and that everything was about to get all too real as you approached the end of the game. That doesnt even factor in some of the other, non main quests story lines that develop throughout the game, which are also stellar.The journey itself was filled with pretty much any emotion you can imagine. The moral choices were often difficult due to the realistic consequences that come with every decision.Speaking of decisions, quite a few of them factor into the ending...and speaking of endings, I cant remember another game that had such a well thought out one. There also seems to be potential for a lot of variations to the ending depending on what choices you made at pivotal moments throughout. My ending was a fair mix of incredibly good and depressingly bad consequences to what I had done during my extensive playthrough. I loved that fact.I am thoroughly impressed with this game, and I have to give it the edge over Baldurs Gate 2 as maybe the best CRPG of all time, and a top 5 all time great game from any genre.I have a lot more to say, but so vast was the story and so deep the experience, that I think maybe it's better if I leave the rest unsaid and let you form your own opinion instead.Play this.Can there be a 15 out of 10? Because seriously, I think that is how I am going to rate this game.

Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.This little swivel stand is in my estimation perfect for a bedroom television that, in my case, sits atop a dresser. It's really quite convenient with space to store our Roku, Ouya, Wii, and PS3 along with the attendant controllers and a few games. This obviously helps us to reduce the dresser top clutter, which has been quite nice. It also looks nice and is unobtrusive, making this a win as far as items go. I haven't had cause to test its durability, but it certainly holds up to the minor stress of holding our 32 inch TV just fine, and as mentioned before, has enough space with the shelves to keep clutter to a minimum. I am quite pleased with this item.

This is a great album. While it has influences as varied as NIN and Motorhead, this album still manages to have a very clear vision and manages to convey that perfectly. The song structure throughout is impeccable, and the mix of musicianship and songwriting is simply great. A rocking album that is eminently listenable and something you can hear over and over without it ever getting old. There are also quite a few guest appearances on this album such as Jonathon Davis from Korn for example.I recommend checking this out for sure. I have really enjoyed it.

Looks exactly like the product page image.It is definitely durable as my toddlers abuse stands testament to lol.Really, it is well crafted, looks great, is soft, and in my estimation is a perfect toy for the kiddos....especially if they have already been asking you where Perry is. :)

I didnt love this keyboard at all. For one, it is tiny...much smaller than you really get a sense for. However, and more importantly, the keys not only arent responsive, but when they do register, they often stick, and you truly have to peck hard to get it to respond to begin with. Also, that little touch mouse on the side....picks up indirect motion....meaning you dont have to touch it for it to respond, which is kind of funny in a way since it is hyper sensitive while the keys are the complete opposite. It is possible that I got a defective unit, but I would lean in a different direction if I was looking for a smaller keyboard.

I have really been loving this keyboard. I wasnt certain going in, what with the hilarious typos in the product description due to a shaky grasp of the English language, lol, but actually, it's truly been great. The backlighting is nice as is the ability to change colors. I generally stick with blue, but none of the three are obtrusive and all help out under low light circumstances.The key layout I especially appreciate. It is set up exactly the way I would expect (and having tried out a number of keyboards, I can tell you that a lot of companies dont stick with this tried and true format for some reason). Additionally, while the keys are firm, they never stick and are completely responsive. The keyboard is also the perfect size. None of the keys are too large or too small. This was definitely made with everybody in mind. I have large hands, but my wife has small hands, and both of us use this keyboard without any issues and in fact, it is completely comfortable.I use it for a pretty fair mix of general typing and k/m gaming, so I can definitively affirm its usefulness/comfort/efficiency under both circumstancesIt is also quite durable. It's been knocked around, dropped, stepped on, and generally abused, and is no worse for wear.The only thing I would like to see done differently is the addition of a longer power cord OR a wireless option. Other than that, this keyboard is flawless in my opinion.

Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.This lemon squeezer is really the perfect device for juicing a few lemons. Much like a garlic press, this takes the brunt of the work making it easy on you the user. It is actually surprisingly easy to place a half lemon in the squeezer, squeeze, and actually get basically all the juice you possibly can from it. So, minimal effort and maximum payout equals a great device.As far as the durability, I havent had any issues. It isnt as heavy as I would have thought, and it is set up essentially the same as a pair of tongs with a similar spring mechanism at the end. I would expect the life of the squeezer to be about the same as a good pair of tongs based on this.Cleaning it is as simple as rinsing it off, and I have had no issues with washing it in a dishwasher either,.One final note: I have played around with squeezing other citrus with similar results. Limes work fine as do smaller oranges, tangerines, etc...All told, over the month and a half or so that I have been testing this out, it has been a stellar item, and I have no problem recommending it. In fact, I would say it is almost a must own if you cook or make drinks often with fresh squeezed citrus as we do.

Purchased on Steam, and mention of pricing/cards reflects its life on Steam.Not terrible. This is basically a physics based puzzle game where rats take out their vengeance on cats in varied and unique ways. The music for the game sounds cool, the animation is good, the contraptions have cool and varied ways of accomplishing your goals, and in general, the game is actually not bad at all. Especially since you probably will own this regardless, either via gag gifts or because it often costs like 19 cents and offers trading cards. Whatever the reason you end up with this game (and you will, lol), you can at least get a little bit of fun out of it while farming for those cards.You already own this (or will), so there isnt really a reason to rate this, but I think I will still give this six shaved cats with a variety of scars and missing limbs from explosions, axes, baseballs, and so on out of ten possible.

So far, this game is far superior to it's 2014 predecessor in every way. The graphics are better, the animations are better, but most importantly in my opinion, the online play is 100% improved. I cant even begin to tell you how often we had our online league games disrupted by server crashes and freezes. It was highly aggravating, and I know everybody in my league came into this years game with a bit of trepidation. It still does feature the occasional lag, but so far, several games into our season, nobody has experienced any game killing crashes or freezes, whereas last year, it happened almost every week.The other features remain essentially unchanged except that you earn playing cards and in game currency as you play (and in fact you earn a card every time you log on it seems). I havent actually used any of these yet, but it seems like a nice feature nonetheless.Aside from the vastly improved online play, the most notable change is in the realism of pitches. They really look just about the same as real life pitches, with breaking balls actually breaking at the appropriate times, rising fastballs actually rising, and so on. Very cool.The packaging for this is also very nice. The steelbook looks like part of a baseball bat and the free gamepad decal that came with preorders is cool.All told, very pleased with this installment of the game.

Purchased on NuuvemThis game was intense. The Redux looks amazing and plays basically exactly like Last Light, which was one of my all time favorite shooter/survival horror games ever. Everything is pretty seamless, and while it still has stout requirements to play on Ultra settings, you can definitely play on High without any real issues with a middling CPU as long as your GCU is good.Anyway, the story was engaging, the pacing was spectacular, and the tension....OMG the tension. Truly top notch. I loved this game from beginning to ending. I easily recommend playing this. A truly memorable experience and one of the best out there.9.5 slaughtered mutants out of 10

Interesting little experiment is this game. A literal fishbowl (or pond as it were) and a self contained ecosystem that you tweak by spawning various critters (some fish, some shellfish, an otter) and by adjusting the oxygen content, which adjusts the toxicity of the water and from what I can tell, the lifespans of the fishies.It's a free title, and an interesting way to spend ten or twenty minutes. After that, the charm sort of wears out and you are left wondering why the otter never needs to come up for air, lol.Interesting enough to be worth your time, but not enough here to hold your interest for long. I'd give it a 6 out of 10 (mostly because it was free, otherwise I would rate this more like 4 out of 10), and hope that the developer explores this genre a bit more and possibly creates something a bit more detailed. It has the potential to be a very cool simulation game with the proper time and dedication. As it is, you will find it relaxing but probably wont ever play it again.

So, there has been a lot of mixed feelings towards this game, and the  reviews reflect this fact.Personally, I thought this game was excellent. It did have its share of problems, mostly centered around the wildly variable specs depending on your system of choice and the lack of effort as it pertained to syncing the audio with the video during the cutscenes (an embarrassing oversight in my opinion).That said, the game was really very interesting, dark and at times sardonic, and just flat out fun. The stealth aspects really shined through, but as can be seen by my achievements, playing a more aggressive Garrett is possible as well. The upgrade system makes sense and really makes you decide how you want to play your Thief. There are numerous side quests to help you learn the game mechanics and earn cash to purchase equipment upgrades. You do have an equipment stash in your hideout, but I never got around to stocking it (however, I recommend you do....you will need as much gear as possible going into the last two chapters).At first, there is a bit of mysticism involved, and in fact, your first mission ends up with you witnessing some crazy ritual which shapes the rest of the story. There are betrayals and such along the way, and the tension just continues to increase as move through the main story. By the time you get to chapter 5, you have already gotten the sense that there is a whole lot going on that you would never have guessed at before, and the story itself turns from being pretty dark and forlorn to being more horror-centric and at some points, even scary. The first 4 chapters were fun, but the last 4 were amazing in my opinion.There was one endgame issue that I thought was pretty cheap and can potentially ruin your experience if you don't plan properly, which I will explain below (however, if you don't want spoilers, just make sure you have enough health packs available to where you can have at least one set aside for the very end of the last battle)....SPOILERSo, the last battle has you trying to gather the three crystals while Erin tries to kill you (and she is able to have several avatars hunting you simultaneously). Each time you grab a crystal, she explodes, burning off her avatars and you in the process (unless you stay in a dark area when that is happening). Plus, her main attack is an explosion as well. So, it is almost inevitable that you will take some damage...and the long road to get to that final encounter almost guarantees you will be low on health and health packs (well, it doesn't guarantee it, but I find it unlikely that most people will arrive at the last encounter unscathed). Anyway, when you grab the final crystal, it goes to a cut scene where she does her power burst one last time, and if you are low on health, you die even though you have technically finished the battle. So, in order to prevent this and be able to see the endgame cutscenes, you need to heal before you grab that last crystal...if you have no health packs (food) and have taken any damage, you will be unable to finish the game and will have to go back several saves most likely to do it over. I had two food left when I started that final encounter, and after trial and error, I was able to figure out a pattern that allowed me to save one food for just before I grabbed the last crystal (I died AFTER grabbing the 3rd crystal several times before figuring it out).Anyway, that could potentially damage our experience, but really, I thought the game was excellent overall and would give i a solid 8 out of 10 (I would have given it 9 were it not for the issues I mentioned).

Lol. Decisions need to be made here: was this an intentionally or unintentionally bad game? I am leaning in the intentionally bad direction with this one. It's essentially a walking simulator with ridiculous attempts at jump scares (creepy mannequins moving around, random camera jumps to basically mundane items like a piano or a bookshelf, shadowy creatures, and so on). The story itself was 100% predictable, lol. The graphics themselves are fairly typical of Unity engine games. Nothing of note good or bad.You dont actually click on anything. Events are unlocked mostly by question marks that you walk into., which then trigger whatever may or may not happen next lol. The dialogue is obviously ridiculous.The music however was pretty cool such as it is.Also, there are trading cards, and at the time of this review, they are shockingly selling for 20+ cents a piece.hmmm...do I rate this as a positive or a negative.I'm going with a real rating of 2 out of 10, but an intentionally bad rating of 6.5 out of 10. That averages out to what, 4.25? That settles it. Thumbs down. However, for a buck, I'd still recommend buying it just for  and giggles. So, thumbs up?btw...this game has multiplayer. LMAO!btw, the confusion in this review fairly well sums up the game also. :)

Well, Finding Teddy was a cute little game that was included in a bundle I bought a while back and finally got around to trying out. The story itself is cute/quaint, and the sort of tale you could expect to come from the mind of somebody's little daughter (or having been written for somebody's little daughter). That said, the strength of this game was definitely the puzzles, which incorporate music into riddle form fairly brilliantly. Once you realize what is happening, you wont have any real issues solving them, but learning them initially will take most people a bit of time, and you will need to pay attention in order for the final puzzle to become obvious. Outside of that, there are also objects you find that you will need to progress, much like every point and click game, which this is (albeit, done in a refreshingly different fashion).All told, this game probably took me about an hour and a half to finish, and there is replay value for the completonist. In fact, I get the sense that other things are unlocked in NG+ (unconfirmed by me personally).Anyway, I found this game to be a pleasant surprise and can easily recommend it.

Well, this is basically Surgeon Simulator, but instead of killing patients, you are killing it making some nice hot tea, sometimes with sugar, sometimes with milk, sometimes with both, sometimes with neither, lol.You lost your arm in battle and so you were given a robotic arm with which you must try to make your aforementioned tea in hopes of calming down after the stress of losing your arm.Physics based all the way. It's pretty challenging, but the learning curve isn't as steep as with Surgeon Simulator.All in all, it's a charming, sometimes frustrating little game that will make you want to do everything. Took me about an hour to get all the achievements except the play 500 times one, but there are scripts available to handle that one in the community hub.Anyway, pretty fun. I give it 7 broken tea cups out of 10 possible. The spilled milk and hot water abounds.

This game is a ton of fun. It doesnt necessarily look the best (Unreal 3 engine I believe), but it more than makes up for it with solid gameplay, ballsy attitude, and well populated servers (32 player matches). It's multi player only, although you can set up private servers and populate with bots if you prefer. Matches are your typical Deathmatch, Objectives (which are basically one team defending and the other attacking with objectives as you go along such as burning down or crashing gates, smashing towers, and so on on route to eventually trying to kill the King), Free For All (everybody vs everybody), etc..., but they are all quite fun. I've played through four different maps so far. I'm not sure how many more there are, but it's a little consequence. The gameplay is more important than the locations with this game.The learning curve can be steep depending on the type of warrior you select as well as their loadout, (which is initially limited, but unlocks more stuff as you keep getting experience), but it is also pretty easy to get into the flow of the game. You WILL die a lot, and often in hilarious ways, such as getting set on fire just before having your head and an arm hacked off. You can also shout battlecries to your hearts content, lol.You do get penalized for hitting your own teammates, which takes the form of longer respawn times, and if you are a repeat offender, everybody on your team gets to vote on whether or not to kick you. You can also switch sides if you like, mid game, and in fact, the game will sometimes rebalance and shift you automatically to even out the teams. Speaking of respawns, while you are waiting, you basically are the ghost of your now dead warrior and can float around and/or above the battlefields checking out the battles while you wait.All told, the game is a ton of fun to play, and I think it is pretty hilarious as well, with the graphic deaths, copious battle cries, and people running around like madmen.Initially, I thought this was about 8/10, but the more I play, the more I lean closer to a full 10/10.

Played through Papa & Yo today.Not a bad game. I remember the press on this being highly favorable. The gameplay wasnt really very challenging, but it was engaging enough to convey the story, which was obvious very quickly, so no worries about spoilers really...you (but really the guy who wrote the story) had an abusive alcoholic dad, and the torment of that upbringing haunted him throughout his life until he was finally able to let go of the fear and torment and move on with his life....that is pretty much the story in a nutshell. It is put forward in a very sensitive manner, and serves to explain the writers feelings without necessarily forcing them on you the gamer. So, I can see why people liked the game based on that. I think the gameplay was probably a 6 out of 10, but the story was more like a 7 out of 10, and the presentation was a 9 out of 10.

Super cheesy but actually pretty solid Indiana Jones style adventure that doesnt take itself seriously at all but yet still provides a solid adventure regardless.The story itself is decent and the dialogue is intentionally cheeseball and pokes fun at itself often. The gunplay is solid. The backdrops are gorgeous. This is a very nice looking game. The puzzles were mostly easy, but there were a couple challenging ones mixed in.If you are looking for a game similar to Indian Jones movies, or in the same style of a Tomb Raider or Uncharted (but without the production values), but with more humor, this is a game you should definitely try out.

Super cheesy but actually pretty solid Indiana Jones style adventure that doesnt take itself seriously at all but yet still provides a solid adventure regardless.The story itself is decent and the dialogue is intentionally cheeseball and pokes fun at itself often. The gunplay is solid. The backdrops are gorgeous. This is a very nice looking game. The puzzles were mostly easy, but there were a couple challenging ones mixed in.If you are looking for a game similar to Indian Jones movies, or in the same style of a Tomb Raider or Uncharted (but without the production values), but with more humor, this is a game you should definitely try out.Far more enjoyable than you would think just by looking at the product page. Well worth the 10 or 12 hours it takes to finish.7.5 out of 10

DLC Quest is a cute and fun game that pokes fun at the gaming industry and the ridiculous state of things as it concerns needing to purchase DLC just to get features for games that should have been included with the base game release. Still, it doesnt take itself too seriously and really does a great job of integrating that statement with humor and solid gameplay. A worthy addition to any collection in my estimation.

I bought this for my brother who had a weak WiFi single issue in his living room of his two-story house.Once I got past the small print of the instruction manual (is there an ESL school that actually teaches "All your bases are belong to us" syntax?), it was a breeze to set up, pair and forget about it.I liked the materials used and the quality if the manufacturing employed. I particularly liked the discreet function-indicators.A good product that delivers what it promises at a reasonable price.

Let me make something very clear: this is NOT an Apple iWatch - and (appearances notwithstanding) it does not pretend to be. It is a budget alternative that will help cure the urge to slap down 550$ to buy the overpriced Cupertino product. Yet, quite surprisingly, it delivers what it does promise in spades.As the watch functions go, it will display the time as well as function as a stopwatch and timer. How accurate is it? Frankly, I do not know - but we are not timing the 100m race at the Olympics with it, are we? The only downside of this aspect is that I could not see how to install different watch faces, a major omission for any smartwatch.Controlling your phone music player with this smartwatch is easy and practical, the screen being both responsive and clear.Now, pair it with your phone and you will both receive notifications and be able to read as well as answer to SMS. It can go completely silent with only the vibration on and this works so well, you will never be in doubt if you received anything or not. On top of that, ask your carrier for a second -SIM card and (whenever your phone battery runs out) this little smartwatch can function as your emergency messaging device, even without being paired to a phone. w, THAT is a function even the Apple iWatch cannot do!What I did not appreciate was the (quality? richness? certainly feel) of the materials, especially of the strap and the push-button.At this price, the StarryBay SmartWatch a fair deal, provided one is fully aware what he is purchasing.And a great stocking-stuffer idea for Christmas.

This is great budget tablet that is small enough to carry around all day, fast enough to handle everything thrown at it and has the capacity to contain most of the files one would need to have on a tablet.The 7 inch screen is phenomenally bright and sharp. It can accept up to five-point touch and, being of moderate size, it does not drain the battery. The manufacturer claims to have a 5 hour autonomy and my experience confirms the real-life number to be very close to that with reasonable usage. Of course, "reasonable use" means surfing the Web and watching videos on WiFi, listening to music or an audio-book and checking your Social Media accounts - it does not mean 5 straight hours of ...Fallout Shelter or Clash of Clans! Playing a graphically demanding game will drain the battery in between 2 to 3 hours. Nevertheless, since it is very light-weight and easy to carry around, it will save your smartphone battery while offering far better visual experience for such tasks.The front-facing camera works fine for Skype; however, even if most people will not use their tablet to take pictures, I would rather have a rear camera with a sensor larger than 2MP, just in case.This is the 16GB model and it can accept Memory Cards which more or less take care of any storage issues, persistent in any Android device. I found 16GB to be more than enough but I made sure to also insert a 64GB. On the same page, I would strongly advise rooting your device to truly make it yours. Ubuntu for tablets works like a charm!At this price range one should not expect the razor-edge manufacturing fitting of Apple products, mind you. Then again, those come at a 5,000%(!) markup since a comparable 16GB iPad Mini retails around $250. No, the iRULU eXpro Mini is a budget product at a price that would be very hard to find another 7 inch tablet that offers so much.A fair product at a very reasonable price.

This is a backpack of excellent quality I received for reviewing purposes. Because of the colors, I did not use it myself but gifted it to my sister-in-law who could not be happier with it as she uses it as a carryall for their three toddlers' stuff.The backpack has ample of room, with numerous external pockets and internal compartments, including one for a laptop (up to 15-16" in size). It has sturdy zippers (easy to operate even with gloves on) and it also has very comfortable (padded) back-straps which, in my case, also sported the front decorative pattern. The material is water-resisting canvas, which, unless drenched, will keep everything dry. The covered zipper-drivers also see to this.The one I received was light blue which will not withstand dirt (or little fingers with chocolate on them) for long. Nevertheless, there are plenty of colors to choose from.Like most canvas backpacks, it may not be the best idea to use this to carry a heavy book-load everyday but, other than that, it is perfect for everyone: from iStudents and light-travelers to overworked mother and preschoolers.Recommended.

When things get bad, we tend to look to the past. And the bleaker the future looks, the further back we search for comfort. As the new millennium keeps disappointing us, TV shows set on the 50's and the 60's (once a rarity) keep growing in numbers. Many have tried and failed. MAD MEN tried and closed the deal. And have been doing so until the very end of of 7 seasons.Meet Don Draper (Jon Ham), a Madison Avenue water-walker (and based on real life ad-man, George Lois). He is an enigma wrapped in a mystery. He is brilliant and secretive. He wants to keep walking the tight rope with no safety net. And definitely no contract. He is a chain-smoking, hard liqueur guzzling, womanizing alpha male. He was a loving father of three, married to a picture-perfect ex model. He had it all. And yet he can never peace. Because he learned early on that the world is always yawning at your heels, eager to yank everything you love away. And more often than not, it succeeds.From bursting with joie-de-vivre Roger Sterling (hilarious John Slattery) and ever scheming Pete Cambell (baby-faced Vincent Kartheiser) to the gorgeous women (such as barbie January Jones and refined Jessica Par as his first and second wife, respectively), the cast is one perfect pick after another. And the writing is brilliant, reproducing the tastes and smells and nuisances of the era around Camelot, while drawing you in to the personal stories of characters polished yet inevitably flawed.The 50's and the 60's were before my time so it is not nostalgia that makes me love the show. Yes, I find the era mesmerizing and (probably undeservingly) less complicated. If nothing else, though, back then they knew how to dress. Women looked feminine and men looked manly. You see January Jones on the red carpet, for example, all dressed up and groomed for a Hollywood function - and that modern image cannot hold a candle to herself dressed for everyday(!) life in the early 60's. When did we loose it? When did we decide men should stop wearing suits and hats and women should start wearing sweat-suits outside the house? I, for one, blame the hippies!This is one of the best TV shows ever and this box-set includes all seasons. As I have said again before, good TV is best watched on DVD. Make weekends out of it. It is much more enjoyable to watch an entire season in a couple of days than having to wait week(s) between episodes. And (quite ironically, in this case), you will not have to suffer the...commercials.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

I have tried wireless mice in the past (the unparalleled MS Natural Wireless Laser 6000) and even if convenient in some ways, they are a hassle to keep on battery power, a handicap in gaming and add to the already too many radio-wave sources in our houses. So, when I was offered this for reviewing purposes, I accepted it as someone who appreciates wired mice.This baby has everything! Great DPI (adjustable from 1,000 to 8,000); a reinforced breaded cord, which appear to be as durable as Timberland laces; adjustable weights, insertable under the base in a way that allows to alter the Left-to-Right balance (my advise: if right handed, keep the weights to the right); numerous lighting modes (red, blue, green, yellow and purple) that will match most modded PC cases, even if I prefer to keep my mouse dark. It glides like a dream on my wooden desk (no mouse pad) and I found it to be as precise as comfortable to use.The materials the VicTsing 8000 is made from feel solid and do not seem prone to accumulate grease and dirt, a constant problem with my past MS mice. The only thing I did not like was the quality of the plastic the side red buttons are made from. Other than that, this is a great gaming mouse at a great price.Recommended.

This is a well-made Security Cable for Laptops and Notebooks I accepted for reviewing purposes. And I am glad I did.It is easy to attach, using the built-in standard T-locking bar, reset the combination (to something other than the preset 0-0-0-0), tether the other end to a secure point and that is all. Technology these days has shorter and shorter cycles yet this does not make our hardware any cheaper. And even if many files can be saved in cloud services, loosing a laptop or a notebook is always a hard blow.This RUBAN Universal Security Cable is made from good materials that both look and feel of high quality and the 6.2ft (~1.90m) of steel cable allows for both a peace of mind and convenience.This something traveling professionals and students of all ages should consider for the safety of their laptop or notebook.Overall, a nicely designed and well made product at a fair price.

I have tried wireless mice in the past (the unparalleled MS Natural Wireless Laser 6000) and even if convenient in some ways, they are a hassle to keep on battery power, a handicap in gaming and add to the already too many radio-wave sources in our houses. So, when I was offered this for reviewing purposes, I accepted it as someone who appreciates wired mice.This baby has everything! Great DPI (adjustable from 1,000 to 8,000); a reinforced breaded cord, which appear to be as durable as Timberland laces; adjustable weights, insertable under the base in a way that allows to alter the Left-to-Right balance (my advise: if right handed, keep the weights to the right); numerous lighting modes (red, blue, green, yellow and purple) that will match most modded PC cases, even if I prefer to keep my mouse dark. It glides like a dream on my wooden desk (no mouse pad) and I found it to be as precise as comfortable to use.The materials the VicTsing 8000 is made from feel solid and do not seem prone to accumulate grease and dirt, a constant problem with my past MS mice. The only thing I did not like was the quality of the plastic the side red buttons are made from. Other than that, this is a great gaming mouse at a great price.Recommended.

It was only last year that I was forced to abandon my trusted WinXP and upgrade to Win7. And I say forced because Microsoft made sure that key features of my OS was not working anymore, including its security. So, Win7 was a brief yet not a bad altogether experience - if one disregards numerous lack of customization options and the palpable effort of Microsoft to make us abandon them yet again, that is. Such as stopping our desktop widgets from working in order to promote the "brilliant" Win8 tiles! Nevertheless, what I want to make clear is that I am comparing Win10 to an extensive background on WinXP and an adequate experience with Win7.ALL YOUR BASES ARE BELONG TO USTwo words: forced updates. I was lucky enough to have opted for the Professional edition of the Win7, so when I got to switch to Win10, I received the Professional edition as well - which comes with the option to defer (yet still not pick between or even cancel) the installation of the latest updates. Currently, I am trying to ignore the Action Center notification for an nVidia update, that keeps pestering me to install it since las week. The Home edition, however, does not give the user any such option and all updates are forced onto him. Remember how after numerous "essential" updates in the past, our PCs encountered a myriad or mysterious problems that were never solved before the next update, months later? Yeah, there is no more avoiding these problems anymore.A PRIVACY NIGHTMAREFrom the initial Logging in only with a Microsoft-confirmed eMail account to the Groove Music and the Movies & TV Players amassing info on your files and personal habits, including the content of our eMails which MS "reserves the right" to pass on (read: sell) to unnamed third parties(!). There is no avoiding it: Win10 are a private person's worst nightmare. In a sense, Win10 are the basis of the most intrusive and abusive DRM ever to be slipped in in our computers, coupled with the most blatant disregard for a person's privacy at home. There had been an uproar even since the pre-release builds and some deactivation options are now available - but they are far from thorough and very prone to turning back on by themselves after a while. And it now begs the question: how much can one trust a company that silently downloaded Win10 to every WinVISTA, Win7 and Win8 PC without the consent of their owners?NO, IT IS NOT FASTER BY ANY MEANS!Microsoft did not allow us to perform a clean install when upgrading from a previous Microsoft OS; however, using one's product Serial Number, it was possible to download the official image and burn it onto a disk (or transfer it to an empty USB). In preparation for the upgrade, I increased my system's RAM to 12GM and a few days after the initial update, I formated and did a clean install. Then I went on installing only software that was Win10 compatible. Keep this information in mind when I tell you that Win10 are SLOW. Slower than Win7 and much, much slower than WinXP! It takes forever to transfer files to and from a USB flash drive (a problem that started with Win7, supposedly to prevent data loss when removing drives insecurely, yet still with no option to toggle it on and off). What is more aggravating, it takes forever to explore folders, especially those on my second HDD, even if they were opened just a few moments ago.So, why is it not faster? Is it because of an increase in cosmetic additions and aesthetic customizations? No. Absolutely no. Kindly read on.ESSENTIAL CUSTOMIZATION OPTIONS ARE MISSINGThe Windows interface and Menu options look worse than Win7. Aero Glass, for some unfathomable reason, is not available. The Windows borders are not customizable (for the first time since Win95!). Quick Launch can be made to appear with some Registry editing (I would advise Googling it - carefully!) yet the icons in this DIY Quick Launch now cannot be centered in the Toolbar and they stay misaligned to the Task View button; the option of which icons and how to appear in the Taskbar is missing; whereas, this latest shinny OS refuses to learn that I do not like every shortcut to have a "Shortcut to" prefix to every shortcut I create - something Win98 had no problem learning after the third time I removed it on a new one.There is a semi-official piece of software (no, I am not calling them Apps!) called Windows Ultimate Tweaker 4: I would recommend it as it does offer a number of options, some of which are very useful. However, one of the most important ones (specifically: which new file-templates and options to appear when right-clicking on the desktop) -you guessed it!- is missing.And do not get me started on the Start Menu!WHY MESS WITH SOMETHING THAT WORKED FINE?Win8 were a complete failure mainly because of their Start menu. We all loved the WinXP Start Menu, easy to use, a breeze to customize and backup when needed. Win7 improved on it, even if, quite counter-intuitively, one had to use libraries in order to add personal folders in the Start Menu. Yet, everything was at the right place. Well, not so much with Win10.The Power button now looks like any other and is to be found between(!) All-Apps and Settings - and when pressed (remember that this will also be needed to be done at 2:00AM after 12 hours of working on a screen) one has to read and carefully select between the Shut Down or Restart options that appear. Every single time. With no confirmation dialog.The installed software (All-Apps) are alphabetized easy to navigate - yet its folders do not respond to Right-clicking them. They are just dead.The Tiles Panel, however, this is where they screwed up again: none of the tiles are customizable in other aspects than total size (resulting in beautiful icons looking ridiculous in all that empty background). Why can we not readjust the sizes of the contained icons? And yet they even failed to adjust the tile sizes correctly!The Tiles Panel allows resizing but only in huge pre-set steps. We can also move and group the tiles. Some (but not all) tiles come in 4 sizes, others in 3 yet most in only 2 sizes. The step-wise increments of the Tile Panel create space for 6 small tiles in each group. (if you are asking why, I shall tell you why: because 5' screen Windows Phones can show 6-tiles, that's why!). Have less than 6 tiles in a group and the empty space is an ugly waste. Moreover, no tile under them can grow to fill the space under 6 small tiles, so, once again, more ugly wasted space.Oh, and for some another mysterious reason, not all installed software can be pinned to the Tile Panel, even if they do appear in the All-Apps list! You have to hunt for them in your Program Files and find the executable.COMPATIBILITY MODE IS STILL A JOKEDrakensang: The Dark Eye is not an old game, barely 5-6 years old and it is supposed to be Win10 compatible. At least its expansion is, and that run fine. The original game, however, refused to run under any "compatibility mode". Does this thing finally do anything besides reducing the resolution, Microsoft? You know, like trying running a few years old software under DirectX 9.0c or something?ALL KNOWN BUGS ARE STILL THEREThe Recycle Bin still refuses to use its customized icons, just like with Win7. The Explorer folders are still unable to retain my Viewing preferences. And the Desktop still ...looses files (especially saved web-pages) one then has to hunt down with the Explorer (even if they are still in the Desktop folder).Overall, not a failure of WinVISTA or Win8 proportions but nowhere near as good as WinXP - or even Win7 for that matter.I am willing to accept this as a work in progress and give them 6 months to get their act together and patch things up.Yet they should not think that they will get a free ride just because they claim to be giving it away for "free". Because it was not.We had to exchange our perfectly working OS for it.This goes to prove that, once more, there is no free lunch in this Universe.

It was only last year that I was forced to abandon my trusted WinXP and upgrade to Win7. And I say forced because Microsoft made sure that key features of my OS was not working anymore, including its security. So, Win7 was a brief yet not a bad altogether experience - if one disregards numerous lack of customization options and the palpable effort of Microsoft to make us abandon them yet again, that is. Such as stopping our desktop widgets from working in order to promote the "brilliant" Win8 tiles! Nevertheless, what I want to make clear is that I am comparing Win10 to an extensive background on WinXP and an adequate experience with Win7.ALL YOUR BASES ARE BELONG TO USTwo words: forced updates. I was lucky enough to have opted for the Professional edition of the Win7, so when I got to switch to Win10, I received the Professional edition as well - which comes with the option to defer (yet still not pick between or even cancel) the installation of the latest updates. Currently, I am trying to ignore the Action Center notification for an nVidia update, that keeps pestering me to install it since las week. The Home edition, however, does not give the user any such option and all updates are forced onto him. Remember how after numerous "essential" updates in the past, our PCs encountered a myriad or mysterious problems that were never solved before the next update, months later? Yeah, there is no more avoiding these problems anymore.A PRIVACY NIGHTMAREFrom the initial Logging in only with a Microsoft-confirmed eMail account to the Groove Music and the Movies & TV Players amassing info on your files and personal habits, including the content of our eMails which MS "reserves the right" to pass on (read: sell) to unnamed third parties(!). There is no avoiding it: Win10 are a private person's worst nightmare. In a sense, Win10 are the basis of the most intrusive and abusive DRM ever to be slipped in in our computers, coupled with the most blatant disregard for a person's privacy at home. There had been an uproar even since the pre-release builds and some deactivation options are now available - but they are far from thorough and very prone to turning back on by themselves after a while. And it now begs the question: how much can one trust a company that silently downloaded Win10 to every WinVISTA, Win7 and Win8 PC without the consent of their owners?NO, IT IS NOT FASTER BY ANY MEANS!Microsoft did not allow us to perform a clean install when upgrading from a previous Microsoft OS; however, using one's product Serial Number, it was possible to download the official image and burn it onto a disk (or transfer it to an empty USB). I received these Compression Calf Sleeves for reviewing purposes and I have to admit that they are working beautifully.I try to make the time to power-walk 5-6 ml (8-10 Km) every weekday afternoon and even with the proper walking shoes, I had to miss a day almost every week for my calves to recover. Wearing these not only allows me to complete my walks faster (lactic acid, the cause of fatigue, gets dispersed more efficiently with the proper compression)  but also allow for faster recovery afterwards.Yet their uses are not limited to power-walking. I have used them while sitting for hours at my office chair as well as while traveling by plane and I realized that there was significant less position fatigue, as the gradual compression of the calves helps the blood circulation up the legs.Not only are they made from very durable material but it will not shrink and it refuses to fray. Just make sure to use the calf-circumference guide to find the proper size because the correct fit is going to make a difference. My only complaint is the arrow-patters coloring: I prefer my athletic gear, if not in total black then, monochromatic. Other that this, an excellent product. If they did such a great job for my calves, I can only imagine how effective their Plantar Fasciitis foot sleeves will be!Recommended.

When I bought my WP NOKIA 800 I also bought the original NOKIA CoLoud headphones to be able to listen to music while taking my daily walks. Because they were flat they would not tangle but they did keep falling off my ears. And, contrary to the promise made in their name, they were far from loud. NOKIA sure knew how to make phones; earphones, not so much.So, when I was offered these sport Bluetooth headphones to review, they were something I needed but I tried to keep my expectations low. Did they surpass them though!FIT : it takes some finagling to understand how they are to be inserted and secured in your ears (and make sure to try all the supplied sizes for both ear-canal seal and antihelix-stabilizer); but once you do they stay there! No wind or jogging manages to knock them off. And the safety neck-cable will let you remove them and they will stay around your neck.SOUND : the true test of any headphones and one these MPow SHIFTs pass with flying colors! Crystal clear and crisp sound with volume to spare. The latter was especially appreciated since the NOKIA 800s have a known low volume issue after the later WP 7.8 update. An issue that gets corrected by adjusting the volume of these brilliant headphones up.CONNECTIVITY : turn on the headphones, turn on Bluetooth on my phone and they get immediately recognized and paired in a second. Every single time.PHONE COMPATIBILITY : an incoming phone call can be easily answered without taking my phone out of my pocket as the built-in microphone works exceptionally well, even on windy days.CHARGE : the headphones come with a regular/micro USB cable that will deliver a full charge in less than 20 minutes. It says 2 hours in the boxed instructions but the light turns from red to blue in far less than that.DURATION : for such short a charging time, I manage to get a full week of 1-hour walks, probably 5-6 hours in total.All in all, a great pair of earphones (compatible not only with my Android phone but with NOKIA Lumias as well). Faultless sound, secure fit and no-hassles technology that works.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

In 2007 a small Eastern European game developer (CD PROJEKT)...teaches BIOWARE how to use their own Aurora engine. The original Witcher was the game that Neverwinter Nights had promised to be. Two years later BIOWARE picks up the glove and comes back with a strong response, the masterpiece Dragon Age: Origins. Unfortunately, its 2011 sequel does not live up to expectations. And this is all the opening the perfect sequel needed to come in and, once more, steal the show.THIS IS HOW TO MAKE A cRPG SEQUEL!Although there may be Xbox and PS3 versions of this game later on, this is a game designed from start to finish for the PC. In an age when 5-6 years old consoles set the standard this is very important. From the brand new engine to the very last script line, everything that could be worked on was and everything that could be improved shows improvement.  The story is now even deeper; the graphics are several notches higher; character development has been both streamlined and more balanced; equipping Geralt is now more detailed whereas loot is abundant.It is possible (although not necessary) to import your character from the first WITCHER. If, like me, you liked the original game, you will simply love the sequel.LOOK AT THE SKY: IT IS THE WITCHING HOUR - EVERY HOUR!The graphics are simply A-MA-ZING! I like the way the rock formations catch the moving shadows and how the wind stirs up dust. I like the subtle movement of the grass and the exploding colors of the wild flowers. I like the textures of the clothes, the shine of the armor and the glint of the swords. I like the way the sun gets in your eyes and the way rays of light play with the tree foliage.What is also important, these graphics and dynamic lighting are achieved even on medium-built systems (Minimum specs: Intel Core 2 Duo 2.2GHz/AMD 2.5GHz, nVidia 8800/ATI 3850, 1GB of RAM for WinXP/ 2GB for WinVISTA&7).Even more impressively, the game is set in a day/night cycle, and this is reflected not only on the levels of ambient light but also on the activities of the surrounding world.THE WORLD AROUND YOU COMES TRULY ALIVERemember how in most RolePlaying games approaching a Non-Playing Character (NPC) usually means he or she would utter any one of a small number of preset phrases? After a while, you have heard them all and it got very predictable. Well, prepare to be surprised. Again and again.This is a world you will truly be immersed into. A world that wakes up, goes to work, gossips, bickers and barters, and unwinds in the tavern. Walk the same streets at night and they are eerily empty. And that is without taking into account the ever changing weather!The immersion is so total for yet two other reasons: not only is the world fully open from the very beginning (no blocked areas or closed bridges!) but there are no loading delays between areas (only between chapters).THE LIFE OF A WITCHER IS NEVER BORINGGeralt is a real warlock, combining a mix of sword fighting with potions and spells. These are the three main character developing trees, Swordmaster, Alchemist or Mage. Sword moves, potion ingredients and spells can be combined - and all choices are meticulously balanced.With the original WITCHER it took me a while to master the timed sword-strokes - but it was really satisfying after that. In the sequel, sword-fighting has been simplified to the classic mod - and that is one of the gripes I have with this game. The other is the short dialogue options. I like my cRPGs wordy.Now, the story is far from being linear. Choices matter and choosing a path will bifurcate the story, most of the times irrevocably. And the story in WITCHER 2 is as important as the fighting.What I also appreciated was the return of consequences. Those of you who have played BALDUR's GATE Saga know that bashing or picking the lock of a chest was a punishable offense if anyone saw you. In contrast, in DA-O you could rob the town blind and (quite unrealistically) the NPCs could not care less. Well, in this game, your character better behave or face the ever vigilant guards.ADJUST TO YOUR ACCEPTABLE LEVEL OF BINDINGMost retail versions of the game come with a simple disc-check, implemented by SecuROM. If you own FALLOUT 3, for example, you have experienced the same thing. Compared to the customer-abusing schemes out there (UBISOFT's and 2K GAMES' ears should be burning at this point) this was already benign.However, because there had been problems with the activation of the game, CD PROJEKT patched out the DRM and now the game is (wait for it...) DRM FREE! And it gets even better:  if you rather have a digital rather than a retail version of the game, the developers made sure to also release a GOG version of the game which is also DRM-free. Only the STEAM version has DRM.Just for listening to its customers and doing this CD PROJEKT earned a permanent place of honor in gaming history.A FINAL SPELLI have only praises for this magnificent sequel to a great game. It was one of the rare cases when I pre-ordered a game before I knew anything about it and was rewarded with a game that exceeded my highest expectations.  I do have some advice for the game developers though.First, keep showing the same respect to your customers and you will see that gamers know how to repay this with equal respect and loyalty. And finally, when the mega-publishers show up at your door with their mesmerizing bags of money, try to remember what happened to so many great game developing groups in the past that did not resist to temptation.The game will get a complete overhaul in April when the Enhanced edition will be released. However, because CD PROJEKT is a gamer's company (and not some greedy multinational), as owners of the original edition we will be able to download the Enhanced edition Patch from the official website - for free. As are all the DLCs by the way!WITH MY HIGHEST RECOMMENDATIONS!

The original Witcher was a great game, whereas the sequel was even better, bigger and more beautiful in every aspect. Following on this trend of building upon and improving their achievements, CD PROJEKT RED, the small Polish developer that has been humbling gaming behemoths for years, released their best game yet. And what a game this is!THE BEST VIRTUAL WORLD I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCEDYes, the world of THE WITCHER III is huge, far larger than SKYRIM. Far more importantly though, it feels more real and it is full of life.The game throws you in a world of unparalleled beauty with details that keep unfolding the closer you observe it. Every spade of grass and every pebble looks real and obeys the laws of physics as set by the new REDengine. From the night and day and weather cycles to gear that gets damaged and needs to be repaired by blacksmiths and from growing facial hair to NPCs with real lives, the world of The Witcher absorbs you in and never, ever lets you go. The flames of Igni feel absolutely real as do bodies of water. Beasts and humans will do the unexpected whereas the skies sheltering your travels are absolutely mesmerizing. One can easily spend hours in the game simply observing the gorgeous world around him.There are some concessions to absolute realism one can take advantage off (quick traveling and in-battle repairs for example); however, purists can ignore them and sink in the extra hours to go old school.Now, all these come at a price. A couple of weeks ago, I made sure to upgrade to a nVidia 960 (pouring with a brand new 352.86 driver) and 12GB of RAM just for this game (at some point, CD PROJEKT has to ask ASUS for dividends!) and the game runs smoothly at Ultra.(Also, no save-files crashes this time around. So far).AN EPIC SCORE FOR AN EPIC STORYOnce more, the music is an essential part of both the atmosphere and the gaming experience. The composers are different than those of the previous games and this translates into a novel approach to the world of Geralt of Rivia. You will recognize a number of variations on themes from the previous games and it feels like meeting old friends, matured yet still dear to you; however, I found the music more subtle and effective and not less powerful.CHOOSE YOUR WEAPONS OF DESTRUCTIONRemember the days form the very first Witcher when you basically finished the game with the same sword and kept saving every last oren to buy the 5,000O leather jacket? Well, Geralt not only yields an extra crossbow but he also enjoys an ever growing choice of armor and weapons. Combine this with a huge library of books and an endless supply of potion and bombs ingredients and you will soon find your hero to be overburdened. And then you realize that there is no storage chest! Not to worry, the game now employes Roach's saddlebag (buy it as soon as possible and enlarged it). This way your storage is always close by. And, take my advice, do NOT sell anything! From ingredients to older swords, you will need them for crafting. And even find loot is abundant, it always feel great to gather all the ingredients to finally forge a sword or a piece of armor whose schematics you had been carrying for some time.IT'S ALL ABOUT CONTROLLING THE WORLD AROUND YOUSome people have been complaining about the PC controls and, up to a point, I can understand why. As with all games, I remap almost everything so that I am able to use only the right end of the keyboard (arrows for movement are default here but I use the Num-keys 1-5 to select my Sign, Num-0 to use it, / for the steel sword, * for the silver one, and so on). The game is enjoyable when set at the highest difficulty one can survive at so having quickly accessible controls are essential. That is why I hope to see a key-rebinding option Menu soon and not have to dive in the input.settings file.The Expansion Pass will cover the Expansion (as per CD PROJEKT RED's practices, all DLCs are to be free). And if they are known for anything is offering a more than fair value for the released products.WITH MY HIGHEST RECOMMENDATIONS!
