alive at the press conference at which he just announced her death."A Night to Raise the Dead" -- A mudslide unearths a cemetery whose corpses are infected with typhoid, threatening a massive epidemic."A Question of Death" -- After Quince declares a patient dead and the body is harvested for organs, an ambulance-chasing shyster convinces the family he acted too hastily and brings a suit against him."The Depth of Beauty" -- Quince wages all-out war against an incompetent, assembly-line plastic surgeon whose bungling has lead to mutilations and suicides."Physician, Heal Thyself" -- When a young woman bleeds out in a doctor's waiting room, it's discovered her "routine" abortion was handled by a drunken surgeon."Semper Fidelis" -- The mysterious death of a Marine recruit pits Quincy against the U.S.M.C."An Ounce of Prevention" -- Investigating a construction worker's death, Quincy discovers toxins leaking from an illegal waste dump are the cause, and takes on the company responsible."The Death Challenge" -- Quincy's investigation of the death of a magician puts him at odds with an old friend determined to pull off the dangerous trick or die trying."Eye of the Needle" -- Quincy struggles to determine whether holistic healing techniques cost the life of a patient, and on his investigation hangs the reputation and career of a dedicated doctor.In addition to these, the moving two-parter "Walk Softly Through the Night" is a gutty examination of doctors who dispense drugs like Pez dispensers, irregardless of the consequences, which features three excellent and frequently-used character actors on the show: A Martinez, Charles Aidman, and Spencer Milligan (of "Land of the Lost" fame). And the touching episode "Promises to Keep" finally reveals much-awaited backstory about Quincy, which explains why such a gifted surgeon decided to become a forensic pathologist.QUINCY was and remains a unique series in the annals of television. It was neither a medical program nor a mystery show, but combined both elements and also introduced audiences to the world of forensic pathology -- twenty years before CSI hit the airwaves. At the same time its structure was equally unique, in that two-thirds of the storylines were about causes which the producers, and Jack Klugman, felt needed a champion, or evils which needed to be exposed to the viewing public: autism, the "code of silence" in medicine, toxic waste dumping, plastic surgery malpractice, dangerous airline regulations, affirmative action and organ donation are all subjected to the ill-tempered Quincy treatment. It's true that by modern standards the show is sappy and heavy-handed, that the technology is laughably outdated, and so on, but it's also true that nearly every "cause" tackled by QUINCY has yet to be resolved today. Some shows date badly, and others remain timely while having a wonderful sense of nostalgia. QUINCY is the latter. So the next time you're in L.A., give him a ring. You may be murdered during the visit, but I guarantee he will find out who did it.

A number of SHADOW episodes dealt with "spiritualism" and the occult. This is not the flashiest of the bunch by any means, but it is a pretty effective mystery-suspense story with the sort of late-episode twist that distinguishes a good episode from a very good one.We begin with the brutal murder of a wealthy man named Sanders who is caught in mid-snitch to the police while on his telephone. Cut to the murderers: a gang whose racket is a using fake seances to wring cash out of the bereaved rich. Since Sanders' daughter Consuela is still under the thrall of the gang, they aren't too worried, but maybe they should be, since Commissioner Weston has tipped Lamont Cranston to their activities in the hopes the amateur criminologist will be able to do what the police department can't. No sooner has Cranston taken the case, however, than he's target by the most dangerous type of assassin -- one who seemingly does not know they are an assassin. Soon bullets are flying, double crosses are no short supply, and it will take all of the invisible avenger's wits to avoid ending up on the wrong end of a seance himself."Seance" is a tightly written episode that explores a very familiar theme -- con-men with itchy trigger fingers -- and takes it in some unexpected directions, not only providing us with a first-class plot twist toward the end, but also exploring in some detail how this particular con-job was run. The 30s and 40s were perhaps the last hurrah of the high-society seance con artist, and the gang of Doc, Robbie the Gunman and Swami the Fake Swami are quite a villainous trio, who, it turns out, have more to worry about than just The Shadow."Seance with Death" was originally broadcast on May 25, 1947.and stars Bret Morrison as The Shadow.

I get annoyed when there is no product description for an item sold on Amazon, but I get really annoyed when the item in question is a radio compilation. How are you supposed to make an intelligent decision as to whether to buy a compilation if you don't know what the hell is in it? To rectify this omission I went to the Radio Spirits website and got a product description, and while I don't own THE SHADOW: SILENT AVENGER, I have heard everything on it. So here is a list of episodes along with a very brief description of each:The League of Terror 1-09-38 (Orson Welles): To save innocent shopkeepers from extortion, the Shadow takes on a mysterious crime lord known as The Big Boss.The Plot Murder 02-27-38 (Orson Welles): A  foreign spy with the power of hypnosis plots to assassinate the President of the United States using radical military technology and an unwilling confederate in the U.S. Army.The Silent Avenger 03-13-38 (Orson Welles): A shell-shocked former sniper is convinced by his murderous brother, now on death row, to avenge his coming execution by slaughtering the jury which convicted him.The Fire Bug 04-10-38 (Orson Welles): The Shadow goes after a gang of arsonists.Night Without End 10-16-38 (Bill Johnstone): The city is held for ransom by a gang in possession of a military device which shrouds the city in perpetual darkness.Shyster Payoff 11-06-38: (Bill Johnstone): The Shadow takes on the unholy trio of a crooked lawyer, an equally bent politician and a ruthless gangster.The Oracle of Death 10-20-40 (Bill Johnstone): Lamont and Margo are bewildered by a man who can seemingly predict the future of crime.The House of Horror 11-17-40 (Bill Johnstone): The Shadow must rescue Margo from the clutches of a mad scientist with a breathtakingly villainous agenda.The Chess Club Murders 02-23-41 (Bill Johnstone): Lamont's chess club is the scene of a series of murders, each of which has a plethora of suspects.The Unburied Dead 04-14-46 (Bret Morrison): The Shadow tangles with a vicious gang running a grisly corpse-swapping scheme.The Cat and the Killer 01-12-47 (Bret Morrison): A visit to a pet store uncovers a murderous mystery whose solution seems to lie with a cat with a diamond collar.Death Rides High 05-18-47 (Bret Morrison): The Shadow travels south of the Border to take on a ruthless alien smuggling ring.Sance With Death 05-25-47 (Bret Morrison): The occult is the backdrop for this tale where trying to communicate with the dead leads to many more of them.The Phantom of the Lighthouse 09-07-47 (Bret Morrison): Lamont and Margo investigate brutal murders taking place at a remote lighthouse, murders seemingly committed by the ghost of a long-dead pirate.Death Takes the Wheel 09-28-47 (Bret Morrison): The Shadow tangles with a gang of car insurance fraudsters.Death and the Black Fedora 01-18-48 (Bret Morrison): A missing hat is the key to a tale of blackmail, murder and memory loss that only The Shadow can solve.The Beast of Darrow House 03-07-48 (Bret Morrison): A paranormal investigator, the heiress to a supposedly haunted mansion, and The Shadow cross paths in this violent tale of a (maybe) supernatural hound.Revenge Is Murder 09-19-48 (Bret Morrison): When a gangster is left for dead by his partners in crime, he embarks on a bloodthirsty quest for vengeance.This is a pretty broad compilation of SHADOW stories, covering more than half of the show's seventeen years on the air and including tales from the three actors to definitively play the role: Welles, Johnstone and Morrison. The reason I gave it four rather than five stars is that it contains no newly discovered episodes (in recent years about fifteen supposedly "lost" tales have been discovered and released by Radio Spirits, who own the rights to The Shadow), and because there are a few dud episodes in the lineup ("Firebug", "Night Without End"). On the other hand, all the rest of the stories range from sold to spectacular, and demonstrate a pretty wide cross-section of plot types favored by the show -- meaning mystery, suspense and good old-fashioned horror. People who have been collecting THE SHADOW for years will find nothing new here, but new hands to the OTR game will definitely enjoy.

"Carnival of Death" is a solid B-/C+ episode of THE SHADOW. A highly innovate and extremely macabre idea that is fairly well-executed, it lacks that ineffable quality which elevates a middle-of-the-road installment of this series from the truly outstanding, yet remains an enjoyable listen.Lamont and Margo are headed to Joy Island, an amusement park with a tragic past. On the park's opening day, a terrible subway accident killed 40 would be carnival-goers headed to the park, causing the city to shut down and seal off the line. Arriving at the Island, Lamont and Margo enter a wax museum and discover, to their horror, that is populated not by wax figures but human corpses. When they are unable to convince the carnival's owner, Mr. Norcross, of their claims, Lamont dons the Shadow's cloak and investigates, but it turns out the mystery goes way beyond -- and way deeper -- than the mysterious owner. There's a conspiracy of silence at work at this carnival, protecting a killer whose motives and modus operandi are horribly linked, and The Shadow must get to the bottom of it before Margo becomes his next victim.This story is quite original and features a killer who has been terribly wronged, yet who, in the tradition of SHADOW villains, executes a revenge scheme which sweeps up the innocent rather than the guilty in its clutches. There are  elements reminiscent of such stories as THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA and WAXWORK, and an added air of mystery since the killer is seemingly being enabled by those who run and work at the carnival. Yet for some reason the episode is not scary; all the pieces are in place but the puzzle doesn't quite come together; what should be a grisly tale of insanity and revenge ends up being a modestly entertaining story and nothing more. The best thing I can say about it is that it's worth a listen."Carnival of Death" was originally broadcast on November 10, 1940, and stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow and Marjorie Anderson as Margo Lane.

For my 700th review on Amazon -- yes, I have no life -- I wanted to do something special. Not just some run of the mill book or movie or product but something different, something special.LIBERATION definitely qualifies.I've seen a crap-ton of WW2 movies and mini-series over the years -- American, Canadian, British, Italian, German, Japanese, and even one Russian one (THE HOT SNOW). I wasn't prepared, however, for either the scope or the sweep of this Soviet-era epic, which chronicles the entire Eastern war from early '43 to the fall of Berlin in mid-'45, as seen both from the very top (Stalin, Zhukov, et al) to the very bottom (junior infantry officers, enlisted tank crewmen, a female medic, fighter pilots, etc.). Forget everything you think you know about "big budget" war films; even THE LONGEST DAY and A BRIDGE TOO FAR look a bit sickly when compared with this historical epic, which features not only a cast of thousands, but enough period military equipment to actually fight a minor war.LIBERATION is divided up into six parts, which cover not only the Soviet point of view but also the German, and to a lesser extent the American, British, Italian, Polish, and Yugoslavian as well. Though there is not much room for personal moments, a few minor characters in the army and air force round out the parade of important historical figures. The episodes are:The Fire Bulge - This is an utterly awe-inspiring look at the Battle of Kursk, i.e. the greatest tank duel of all time, from inception at German HQ to the burning fields of Prokarovka, where it came to a climax. The combat sequences are incredible, featuring brilliant cinematography and using hundreds of real tanks. There is a single take which goes on for some minutes featuring savage point-blank battles that resolve into vicious hand to hand fighting, occurring against a backdrop of tracer fire and explosions, that the viewer will never forget. But equally interesting is the high-level strategizing on the German and Russian sides.Breakthrough - Another staggering episode shows the heavy price the Soviets had to pay to push the Germans back to the Dnepr River in late '43, and some of the ruthless tactics they employed, including diversionary attacks which condemned whole units to annihilation. This story also covers the progression of the war in other theaters and the rise of guerrilla movements.Direction of the Main Blow Parts I & II -- An episode steeped in intrigue, this one takes place in the summer of '44. Stalin wants to drive the Germans from Soviet soil once and for all, but there is a great deal of argument among the Russians on how to do it, and among the Germans on how to stop it. Meanwhile, the plot of the generals against Hitler is hatched.The Battle for Berlin -- A slightly deceptive title, this is actually about the Soviet push in late '44 - early '45, which brought the Red Army to the gates of Hitler's capital; also about Hitler's decline from a self-confident warlord to a jittery, paranoid, delusional dead man walking. Also about intrigue among the "frenemies" -- America, Britain and the USSR.The Last Assault - A lavish episode, featuring a whole army of extras, shows in brutal (and occasionally humorous) detail the vicious fight for Berlin, which lasted only a week but cost the Soviets 300,000 casualties. A great deal of time is spent showing the fight for the Reichstag, and some of the street-fighting sequences are as spectacular as they are vicious.LIBERATION was directed by Yuri Ozerov, and it must have sorely tested his skills as an organizer, because the scale of this series is massive. In "The Fire Bulge" we see battles waged with entire battalions of real tanks. In "Breakthrough" a massive-scale river crossing (under fire) is shot, as is the deployment of what looks to be a whole army of Germans in full regalia with Tigerpanzers and heavy guns. And in "The Last Battle" what seems like the entire Red Army brawls with the last, most fanatical remnants of the German in the cathedral-like Reichstag. Aside from big battle sequences, however, there are some really good depictions of Churchill -- quite rightly shown as a cold-blooded imperialist with a hidden agenda; Mussolini (when he is deposed in '43 by his own army, he snaps, "This is the only successful operation of the General Staff!"), and Roosevelt (shown as an idealistic dreamer), as well as interesting depictions of guerrilla warfare against the Germans, and various strategy sessions and political intrigues. The acting is quite good, and I was particularly impressed by the performances of Mikhail Ulyanov as Marshal Zhukov, Horst Geise as Joseph Goebbels, Peter Sturm as Walther Model, and Nikolay Olyalin as the tough Russian soldier Tsvetaev. Writers Yuri Bondarev and Oscar Kurganov could have chosen to depict all Soviets as heroic archetypes and all Germans as Nazi sadist-murderers, but in the end they chose to be pretty fair in their depictions, and the series benefits as a result.The reason I gave LIBERATION four rather than five stars is due to a certain amount of historical whitewash. All nations fib and distort history to make themselves look better, and the actual amount of outright lying in this film is very small -- perhaps even less than in an American war film. For example, the subject of the Russian National Liberation Army, a nationalist army organized by the Germans from Soviet POWs and defectors to fight communism, is tackled with surprising honesty -- I wouldn't have blamed the Sovs for omitting this embarrassing story completely. However, the depiction of Stalin (Bukhuti Zaqariadze) is oddly wise and all-knowing (odd because the cult of Stalin had long since been debunked when this series was shot), the portrayal of Hitler (though ably performed by East German actor Franz Deiz) is cliched and somewhat "slanderous" (the bunker sequences are flat-out wishful thinking on the Soviet's part), and there is a scene with Zhukov, where he orders his army to make use of searchlights to blind the German defenders, that is not only inaccurate but actually a flat-out inversion of history (Ozerov depicts the Germans as completely flabbergasted by this technique, running around with their hands over their eyes and fleeing in terror; in fact this tactic failed miserably, and merely provided the German gunners with big, sparkly targets.) Most egregiously, there is no mention whatever of Soviet atrocities in Germany. The Reds behave like Merry Men in a "Robin Hood" film when they reach the Fatherland, flirting with willing German girls and sparing the lives of wretched German boy soldiers. In fact, the Soviets behaved more like Mongols, slaughtering and raping on a scale that is difficult for an American to even conceive, and while I understand they wouldn't want to linger on this subject, it deserved at least a passing mention. Finally, on a technical note, though the English-speaking and German-speaking sequences are filmed in their own language, they are translated by a narrator who is overdubbed in Russian -- so we get two languages going at once while subtitles play out below. And the translations from Russian into English leave a great deal to be desired.Having said that, I can't recommend this series highly enough. Americans and Brits love WW2 movies because they depict us in a heroic, world-saving light, while seldom or never mentioning the fact that the center of gravity in the European war was in Russia and not in the West. In fact, of Hitler's 200 divisions, 150 were deployed in Russia, along with 2/3 of his air force, and while there is little or nothing to choose morally between the Nazis and the Soviets of the same era, there is no denying that Hitler's dream of European mastery was choked by Soviet blood: 27 million Soviet citizens died between 1941 and 1945, and they inflicted 75% of the casualties suffered by the German Wehrmacht during WW2. LIBERATION, while not pretending the USSR won the war alone, gives a much-needed "Eastern" perspective on the world's most destructive war.

It's logical to expect that a bad idea will produce a bad story, and a good idea a good one. Nothing is more frustrating, however, when a good idea is badly executed. This was only rarely the case with THE SHADOW, but it sadly applies to "The Comic Strip Killer," a fine and innovative idea on a vain quest for proper execution.The story begins with a rash of inexplicable, fatal poisonings throughout the city. Chief Weston is, as usual, baffled in the face of the crime wave -- he can't even figure out how the poison is being delivered to the victims -- but Lamont Cranston has a crazy idea. A popular cartoonist has recently created a character named Hypo, who offs his victims by using a special hypodermic needle that doesn't even break the skin. Is the killer a simple copycat, or could it be the cartoonist himself? It's up to the Shadow to discover before Hypo strikes again.The idea for this episode is fiendishly clever. The idea of a murderer imitating a psychopathic cartoon character is a great one, and the story opens strongly. Also, the identity of the killer is well-disguised through until the very end through red herrings and misdirection. Unfortunately, the episode bogs down at the exact point it ought to speed up, with the investigation becoming talky and tedious rather than exciting, and by the time it gets out of neutral and into drive once more, the interest of the listener is elsewhere. This script definitely needed, and never got, a second draft."The Comic Strip Killer" was originally broadcast on November 23, 1947 and stars Bret Morrison as The Shadow.

I think everyone would agree that THE SHADOW was a dark and often brutal show, one which showed the full range of human villainy and didn't shy away from Old Testament-style punishments for its bad guys. In its 220+ surviving episodes, evildoers were stabbed, shot, strangled, beaten to death, ripped apart by dogs and wolves, crushed by gorillas and robots, plunged into baths of acid, irradiated, gassed, flung from aircraft or into volcanoes, blown to pieces, drowned, poisoned, bitten by venomous spiders, and dispatched by death rays. Sometimes they survived, only to be scheduled for electrocution or hanging. A small number simply did prison time, but none escaped scot-free. Once a year, however, the show put down its Old Testament lightning bolt and dispensed hefty doses of sentimental Christmas schmaltz: Hence, "The Stockings Were Hung."The story opens with Lamont and Margo going to tip a paperboy on Christmas Eve. When they can't find him, they do a little investigating and discover that his father, Mr. Grover, has been forced out of his job by his crooked business partner Mr. Jordan, and that the whole Grover family is now destitute. Unable to prove that Jordan is guilty of a crime, Lamont must devise a strategy which will save Christmas for the Grovers, and he hasn't much time -- in a few hours it will be Christmas day.There are only two surviving Christmas episodes of THE SHADOW, and this is definitely the superior of the two ("Joey's Christmas Story" is just awful). That is not to say that it is actually good, of course. The gushing sentimentality of the 30s - 40s, all sap and saccharine, is a bit difficult to swallow, especially from a show where happy endings often consisted of innocent people merely being avenged rather than saved. Essentially this is THE SHADOW's take on A CHRISTMAS CAROL, with the Grovers as the Cratchit family, Jordan as Scrooge, and The Shadow as the Ghost of Christmas Yet To Come, but the tale was better told by Dickens, and the heavy-handed moralizing about the self-defeating nature of individual greed ignores many of the built-in social problems caused by a greed-based economic system."The Stockings Were Hung" was originally broadcast on December 24, 1939 as stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow and Grace Matthews as Margo Lane.

Vampire. Knight. Pilot. Wizard. Sith Lord. Dad. Assassin. Inquisitor. Soldier. Heavy metal musician. Is there anyone Christopher Lee hasn't been been, either on screen or in real life? Let me answer my own question: no. There isn't. This is a guy who is descended from Charlemagne through his mother and Robert E. Lee through his father, and is a cousin by marriage to Ian Fleming. That alone would qualify him for my interest, and he had all that at birth. It's the 90 years that have followed which make things REALLY interesting,LORD OF MISRULE is the autobiography of one of the most prolific and accomplished actors of the last century, Sir Christopher Frank Carimandi Lee. Lee, of course, is best known as the man who played Dracula in about 17 Hammer horror films during the 50s, 60s and 70s, often pairing up with the legendary Peter Cushing in the process; as the formidable Bond villain Scaramanga in THE MAN WITH THE GOLDEN GUN, the evil wizard Saruman in the LORD OF THE RINGS trilogy, and as Count Dooku in the STAR WARS prequels. In other words, every generation from the end of WW2 has known what it means when this enormously tall, basso-voiced guy with the terrifying smile enters the room: something bad is about to happen. The book, however, is about considerably more than Lee's long film career. It covers his entire life, and brother, what a life it's been.Lee was born in 1922, during the "interwar period," but his childhood was really an echo of the Edwardian age: he grew up in a privileged environment and attended a classically English boarding school. Indeed, if not for the fact that his mother, a Countess by marriage, hadn't had very poor taste in husbands he might have led a much interesting life. As it was, the outbreak of WW2 found him a clerk working in London. He joined the RAF but was disqualified from flying just after he became a pilot due to an issue with his vision, so he "fell" into intelligence work, which carried him from North Africa through Sicily and into Italy and finally, Austria. After the war he entered acting and struggled on the fringes for years before landing a role as Frankenstein's monster in a Hammer horror film, the move which was to define him as one of celluloid's most intimidating baddies. In the decades that followed he appeared in nearly 300 movies, worked with most of the major actors and directors who came along -- it's a damned Who's Who of Hollywood -- and set a record, which he still holds, for having participated in the most swordfights cinema history. His celebrity gave him a chance to indulge in other passions, such as travel, music, fencing and golf with some of the greats of that sport, and just when it appeared that age would render him irrelevant, he enjoyed a massive career renaissance by landing, in short order, important roles in the films of Tim Burton, Peter Jackson and George Lucas. All in all a life of breath-taking scope, and Lee relates it very well, often utilizing a wry and extremely English sense of humor, even when conveying the darkest parts of his life: near-starvation as an unknown actor, near death in WW2, near tragedy when his daughter was born with a serious ailment. I've read a lot of autobiographies and memoirs in my life, but Lee's shows us a little more than names, places, dates and anecdotes: it gives us (I think) a real look at the man behind the fangs, and while he may be a little intimidating and imperious, he also strikes me as a good human being. Assuming, of course, that Lee really IS human...which I tend to doubt.Now, I didnt say the book is perfect and it isnt. Lee has many interests and not all of them will thrill the reader. If youre not interested in golf, Lees obsession with the sport will tend to bore you. Likewise, anyone who has lived as long as Lee is going to have to be very selective about what he puts in a book versus what he leaves out, and if there is a major sin in these pages it is definitely one of omission. For example, while he speaks extensively about his military service during WW2, he almost entirely avoids discussion of his service in the SAS and the SOE, which is sort of like being an astronaut and leaving out the fact you actually went into space! Likewise, he barely mentions is friendships with such people as Peter Cushing and Vincent Price, except in retrospect. Chapters involving his role in the Star Wars prequels are similarly scanty. This is a guy that did so much fascinating stuff that even to touch lightly on all of it would have filled a volume twice as long, but despite the book's length I often found myself wishing he'd been more rather than less verbose. He is a walking testament to what can be done when a human lives life to his fullest potential.At the time of this writing Lee is 92 years old, and still acting. Doubtlessly he will have to retire sometime, and I don't suppose he will live very much longer regardless...but I'd bet that Death is more afraid of meeting Christopher Lee than the other way around. After all, this is the guy that famously said:  "I've seen many men die right in front of me - so many in fact that I've become almost hardened to it. Having seen the worst that human beings can do to each other, the results of torture, mutilation and seeing someone blown to pieces by a bomb, you develop a kind of shell."

The average life expectancy of a combat infantry officer in the U.S. Army during WW2 was ninety days. By that time lieutenants and captains could expect to be W.I.A. (wounded in action) K.I.A. (killed in action) or an N.B.C. (non-battle casualty). In essence, pinning the gold or silver bars to ones' collar was a deferred sentence: you knew you'd be clobbered eventually, the question was merely when and how badly. This grim knowledge hung over George Wilson, the author if IF YOU SURVIVE, from the moment he landed in Normandy in July of 1944, and it followed him until the end of the war. It would be a mistake, however, to assume that Wilson beat the odds just because he lived to tell his tale: this is a man who paid full homage to the grim logic of war.Wilson was a more or less apple-pie American from Michigan who was selected, after completion of basic training, for O.C.S., the so-called "shake 'n bake" school which turned enlisted men into second lieutenants after a 90-day course of instruction. He shipped into Normandy after D-Day during the horrific hedgerow fighting that followed, during which the U.S. Army alone, independent of the others, lost 20,838 killed, 94 881 wounded, 10,128 missing (a total of 125 847 casualties) in just three months. Wilson, of course, didn't know how bloody the campaign would prove to be when he arrived, he was simply told by his commanding officer, "If you survive your first day, I'll promote you." Some welcome, huh?IF YOU SURVIVE is, despite its grim subject matter, a highly enjoyable and fast-paced book, the journey of an American everyman from a green-as-grass private soldier to a battle-hardened captain who became a past master at infantry tactics.Wilson takes us from the brutal slog through the hedgerows, in which gains were measured in yards per day, to the sudden triumphant steeplechase across France that led to the liberation of Paris, to the green hell that was the Battle of the Huertgen Forest. Having emerged from that slaughterhouse intact, he found himself thrust into the Battle of the Bulge, and finally a long, punishing march eastward to the Rhine and beyond. The fact that he survived all of this -- the man had a positive knack for being in the wrong place at the wrong time -- is a medium-sized miracle in and of itself, and Wilson is keenly aware of it. This book is not the work of a braggart or a glory-hound, but a totally ordinary guy thrust into horrific circumstances that showed just now extraordinary he truly was. I was constantly reminded of the fictional Captain Miller in SAVING PRIVATE RYAN: a hero who is all the more heroic because he is so totally undistinguished.IF YOU SURVIVE is a narrative written in a plain but entertaining style, and there are numerous images which stand out in my mind: the night in Normandy his position was bombed by the Luftwaffe, his disgusted reaction to the mounds of German corpses he saw rotting in the Falaise Pocket, the time he was almost refused entry to a snobby officer's restaurant in Paris because he was still wearing combat fatigues (no infantrymen welcome!), the massacre of an American battalion he witnessed in the Huertgen when an attack went wrong, the rage he felt when the Germans were allowed to occupy a position unmolested because he couldn't convince headquarters what he was seeing was real. These and a hundred other incidents -- funny, tragic, horrifying, disgusting, thrilling -- come together and give us a picture of an infantry officer's life, a life in which friendships were created in seconds and measured in weeks, where goodbyes to dead comrades were a constant refrain, where sanity was constantly tested and sometimes found wanting, and where hunger, cold, exhaustion, brutality and terror were everyday occurrences. And Wilson, to his credit, doesn't fall into the trap of glamorizing or romanticizing his experiences, even when they are nakedly heroic, as some vets are prone to do when time has dulled their emotional memories. You know that this is a guy who remembers everything perfectly -- stench, discomfort, fear, grief -- and never wants himself or anyone else to have to go through war again.I've read a hell of a lot of war memoirs, and I've certainly read ones that were better written or struck more profound notes of observation or wisdom, but IF YOU SURVIVE nevertheless became an instant favorite of mine. It's simply the unembellished story of one man who managed to do just that....against the heaviest possible odds.

LONA MASON: Turn on the light, Hugh. Put us to the test. Let us see your face.HUGH WINDHAM: All right, I'll do it -- but remember, I warned you. I warned you all..."The Face" stands out as one of the most sinister and brutal episodes in the canon of THE SHADOW -- and given the show's taste for exploring the dark corners of the human heart, that is saying something. Far from being gratuitous, however, this story stands as a fascinating exploration, not only of the vanity and narcissism of its villain, but of the shallowness implicit in all its characters -- and in all human beings -- for placing so much emphasis on the collection of features we call a face.Hugh Windham was one of the most successful -- and the handsomest -- actors of stage and screen. When a horrible accident disfigured his face, however, he retreated into seclusion. When his former co-star Lona Mason convinces him to reveal himself, however, she isn't prepared for the horror she sees, and neither are Lamont Cranston and Margo Lane. Not long after this incident, the landlady who first saw his horrid new visage, and screamed in revulsion, is found strangled with her own face beaten beyond recognition. This is the beginning of a series of grisly ritual murders, at first seemingly unconnected; only The Shadow comes to suspect that all the victims have one thing in common: each is a woman who saw the new and terrible new face of Hugh Windham. And if that is the connection, then Margo may be the next to turn up in the morgue...As I said before, this is a very dark episode, in which the villain has a motive which, though twisted and springing from a perversion of his own enormous vanity, is entirely understandable. Worshiped for his looks, he is now reviled for them; driven into isolation by his shame, he is coaxed out into the public eye by well-meaning people only to be regarded with disgust and horror. His quest for vengeance is single-minded and cruel -- the killing of the nurse is extremely "graphic" -- but one can't but feel as if he's right when he screams "I gave you a chance, and you failed, failed miserably!" As for his final confrontation with the Shadow, it is at once macabre in the extreme and strangely pathetic. This is one serial killer who is less a monster than a reflection of the ugliness of a society that places so much emphasis on looks and so little on talent or character. Unfortunately I don't know the name of the actor who played Windham, but he certainly deserves honorable mention for a blistering vocal performance."The Face" was originally broadcast on September 21, 1947 and stars Bret Morrison as The Shadow and Grace Matthews as Margo Lane.

INFESTISSUMAM is one of those albums that gets better with time. This is a good thing, because my initial reaction to it was a bit underwhelming. I felt as if it were missing some ineffable quality possessed by its predecessor, OPUS EPONYMOUS, something I couldn't quite name but could definitely hear. It turns out that what I was hearing wasn't disappointing, it was merely different. I guess in our secret musical hearts we always want bands to make the same sort of music over and over again and never branch out; but I'm glad Ghost did, because like a slow-acting poison, this album packs quite a wallop if you give it a chance.The show starts with the title track, a slam-banger right out of the soundtrack one of the OMEN films. This transitions into "Per Aspera Ad Inferi," which reunites the audience with the surprisingly non-metal sounding voice of lead singer Papa Emeritus, coupled with a militaristic beat that summons images of zombies marching along to Satanic drummers. After that we get "Jogolo Har Meggido," a mildly catchy song that shows some very interesting guitar and keyboard work. Next up is the intended showpiece of the album, "Secular Haze," which on the Deluxe version comes in two versions, the second with a video. This song took me quite a long time to appreciate: at first I was off-put by its weird, carnival-like melody and out-of-the-box lyrics, but I have to admit it grew on me with time (although I still feel as if it's a bit out of character for Ghost). Likewise "Guleh (Zombie Queen)" which starts very slowly and rather drearily, with some disgusting lyrics, before putting the pedal to the metal and turning abruptly into a rocker.By this time, during my initial hearing of the album, I was kind of confused and disappointed. The production felt a little flat and the songs were all over their place in tone, as opposed to the extremely hand-in-glove approach used in the previous album, where every track felt like a chapter one great book. Then, suddenly, I fell into the fiery, foot-stomping "Year Zero," a Satanic anthem that pretty much epitomizes everything that Ghost stands for and does well: beautiful vocals full of diabolical lyrics, driving drum beats, and rousing guitar work. The next four tracks ("Body and Blood", "Monstrance Clock", "Depths of Satan's Eyes" and "Idolatrine") are much more in the vein of OPUS EPONYMOUS, which came as a great relief. "La Mantra Mori" is pretty much just filler, but evidently it was just a breath-pause before the next-best song on the album,  the decidedly Megadeth-esque "Marionette." This song, with its brilliantly bitter lyrics and reeling refrains (so unlike the detached, coolly observational tracks on OPUS EPONYMOUS) is perhaps not quite in-character for Ghost, but it's so emotionally authentic and resonant-- the lamentations of a court jester, laughed at and despised by all, powerless over his own fate -- that it deserves special mention. As I said before, the band places a lot of emphasis on "Secular Haze" and in fact closes the album with a second version (8 seconds difference) which includes a video which will play on your mobile device as you listen.Ghost is definitely one of the most unique bands I've ever heard. They have taken quite a beating in metal circles recently because they are not genuine Satanists and so are viewed by some as poseurs and exploiters, but personally I couldn't care less whether they are Satanists, Christians, atheists or freaking Jewish Nazis. Some of the best novels on war were written by men who never came within 1000 miles of a battlefield, and I'm pretty sure Tolkien never met a Hobbit. What matters to me is the end product and not the resume. Papa Emeritus and the Nameless Ghouls make darkly beautiful, highly evocative music which takes its share of musical risks and combines lavish atmosphere with extremely clever lyrics; not to mention that P.E.'s vocals are light-years away from the tuneless screaming which is the signature of this genre. INFESTISSUMAM isn't as neatly composed as OPUS EPONYMOUS, it takes more risks and therefore makes more missteps, but it's got guts, and as Sgt. Hartman says in FULL METAL JACKET, "Guts is enough."

"The Wailing Corpse" is a strange but enjoyable episode of THE SHADOW that blends the more prosaic motives of greed and revenge with spiritualism and macabre intrigue.When Ellsworth Van Dyke asks an undertaker for a coffin, it's business as usual at the funeral home, until the rich old gent specifies that that the coffin must be twice the normal size and made of glass. Then things get really weird. When Van Dyke is asked who the coffin is for, he answers simply, "Myself." Van Dyke promptly dies and is buried in his telephone-equipped casket. The funeral director takes this bizarre news to Lamont Cranston, whose love of all that is odd is well known and ties in neatly with his secret life as The Shadow. But as the invisible avenger begins his investigation, he soon discovers that Ellsworth's bizarre request was hardly the weirdest thing about the Van Dyke clan. The house is full of scheming relations with motives for wanting the old man dead, a daughter who may or may not be insane...and a pesky voice that may or may not be Van Dyke himself, communicating from the beyond.As I stated before, this episode has a lot of intrigue which is spiced by a possibly supernatural element -- the ghost (or is it?) of Ellsworth Van Dyke. The show's half-hour format -- less when you factor commercials -- is a tough one when you want to develop a complex storyline with multiple suspects -- in this case no less than four! -- but THE SHADOW's writers were usually up to the task, and they more than earned there paychecks here."The Wailing Corpse" was originally broadcast on November 8, 1942 and stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow.

"Death Stalks The Shadow" pits the invisible detective not against a psychopath, foreign saboteur, or mad scientist, but an even lower form of criminal...the crooked lawyer. THE SHADOW wasn't awfully shy in depicting that breed of lawyer known as the shyster, the mob mouthpiece or the Cop-Out Louie, but in this episode we examine an even baser aspect of legal criminality: the lawyer as head of a gang.The story begins with crooked lawyer Peter Murdoch visiting one of his clients on death row. Dan Malley is about to be executed for a murder he committed on Murdoch's orders, but Murdoch isn't shedding any tears for the man he threw to the prosecutorial wolves. After all, dead men tell no tales. Unfortunately for Murdoch, while the governor declines to pardon Malley, The Shadow hears his last testament as to Murdoch's guilt and decides to take the shyster down. But Murdoch is no dummy: knowing the invisible vigilante is after him, he devises a fiendish trap using the latest technology: a death chamber triggered by a photo-electric beam. Facing a situation where his hypnotic powers are useless, The Shadow will have to dig deep simply to survive the night, much less take down Peter Murdoch.This episode has many of the qualities which endeared me to THE SHADOW. There's plenty of crackly gangster dialogue, an absolutely vicious criminal who is a worthy match for Cranston, and a diabolical concept centered around technology which in 1938 was practically science-fiction, the photo-electric beam.This last bit is not only unintentionally funny to modern listeners, but gives a wonderful snapshot of the world of that time, which was teetering on the edge of a technological revolution. The earliest seasons of THE SHADOW suffered somewhat from the omnipotence of the character, but soon after Bill Johnstone took over the role, the writers increased the cunning of The Shadow's enemies and as a result, tended to produce better drama and suspense. This episode is a fine example of that evolution."Death Stalks The Shadow" was originally broadcast October 9, 1938 and stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow.

"The Creeper" is one weird episode of THE SHADOW, but its weirdness doesn't detract, and in fact adds to, the twisted appeal of the story. Macabre is a term rarely used nowadays, but I think it applies to this tale where murder is only a side-effect of one man's twisted obsession.The story opens with a rash of mysterious disappearances in the exclusive Mayfair District. Private security guards and sophisticated burglary alarms are of no use: people are simply vanishing out of their homes with no evidence of foul play. When Margo's dear friend Edith Day joins the list of the missing, however, she begs for Lamont Cranston to get involved, and get involved he does, using forgotten blueprints from the end of the 19th century to discover a hidden tunnel system running through the district. This discovery, however, only tells him HOW the unfortunates may have been whisked away, not why, or who is doing it. That answer lies within the tunnels, where a mysterious lunatic who calls himself The Creeper keeps his lair...as well as his victims, which, much to The Shadow's horror, may now include Margo Lane."The Creeper" is a classic showdown between The Shadow and a crazed but diabolically clever nemesis. It wasn't unusual, even in a show as morally heavy-handed as this one, to make the bad guy as pathetic as he was evil, and Everett Sloane, a staple of the early years of THE SHADOW, delivers one of his trademark "sad monster" performances. Orson Welles is also near the top of his considerable game here, trying to deal with a nut whose motive isn't money or revenge but simply...well, to find out you'll just have to meet The Creeper yourself.In closing, I'd like to note that the title "The Creeper" was used for two different episodes of THE SHADOW. This one is not to be confused with the story of the same name, with a completely different plot, broadcast in 1940 during the Bill Johnstone era. ,"The Creeper" was originally broadcast on May 29, 1938 and stars Orson Welles as The Shadow and Agnes Moorehead as Margo Lane..

An unusual idea inside a fairly typical storyline, "Scent of Death" is a strong and brutal episode that once again showcases how versatile the writers of THE SHADOW were. Having only a half-hour (minus commercials) to work with, they managed to pack this one with enough violence, double-dealing, and snappy-gangster dialogue for a Humphrey Bogart movie.The story opens with a man giving his wife a bottle of perfume as an anniversary gift. One inhalation of what's inside, however, and the lady drops dead, prompting the grief-stricken husband to look up the underworld's least favorite amateur detective, Lamont Cranston. But the occasionally invisible detective is immediately stumped by one stark fact: there was nothing IN the bottle at all. No perfume, and, evidently, no poison either. His investigation soon turns up a counterfeit perfume racket whose members include a befuddled, former Prohibition-era chemist and a trigger-happy gunsel named Jackie. But who's running this murderous show, and how did knockoff perfume end up taking lives? The Shadow will have to move fast, because the bodies are piling up even faster."Scent of Death" is one of those SHADOW episodes that downplays the invisible-detective angle in favor of classic gangster themes: extortion, double crosses, brutal murders, and most importantly, absolutely crackling dialogue right out of THE MALTESE FALCON. The homicidal and sadistic wise-cracker Jackie is as nasty a piece of work as you'll encounter, his gun-moll is even better, and The Shadow has his hands full just trying to negotiate through the corpses, much less solve the mystery. The writers of this show loved to point out that there was no honor among thieves, and these thieves work very hard to show their creators right."Scent of Death" was originally broadcast on February 2, 1947 and stars Bret Morrison as The Shadow.

SHERSTON'S PROGRESS is one of those books that makes me wish the rating process on Amazon had a little more flexibility: it's somewhat better than the three-star rating I gave it but not quite good enough to merit four. The final act of the "Sherston Trilogy" which began with MEMOIRS OF A FOX-HUNTING MAN and continued with MEMOIRS OF AN INFANTRY OFFICER, it is a book of an entirely different mettle -- as terse as the other books were loquacious, and as humorous and rich in self-depreciation as they were in callowness and self-involvement.The Sherston Trilogy are semi-autobiographical novels by Siegfried Sassoon, the English poet and war hero who famously threw his Military Cross into the river Mersey and wrote an eloquent denunciation of British war policy while WW1 was still raging. The first book dealt with "George Sherston's" formative years in late Victorian/early Edwardian England: a sedately beautiful portrait of a bygone era of horse races, trophy cups, claret, flannel bags, pipe smoke, riding boots, boarding schools and snobbery, snobbery, snobbery, which was abruptly and brutally ended by the First World War. The second explored the painful growing-up Sherston experienced as an infantry officer at the front, which saw his boundless thirst for glory evaporate into a sullen resentment at those who he felt were prolonging the war for purely imperialist ends; a resentment which led him to being locked up in a mental institution to spare the government embarrassment. SHERSTON'S PROGRESS picks up where this book left off, with Sherston leaving the institution having resolved to see the war through, despite maintaining it had outlived its original aims. It is a novel which reflects the deep and profound changes that occur when one lives not only through a brutal and stupidly-fought war, but through the end of a great era.As I mentioned, PROGRESS is much shorter than its predecessors, taking place over a single year which begins with his admission to Slateford War Hospital for "war neurosis" in 1917. There Sherston meets the man who will guide and shape the rest of his life: W.H. Rivers, the famous neurologist/psychologist/anthropologist whose job was to get Sherston to abandon his antiwar stance and return to the front. Once Sherston agrees, however, he finds himself not back in France but in mutinous Ireland, engaged in sophomoric shenanigans with other former patients of Rivers' which harken back to the more innocent first novel. The shadow of the war is long, however, and following a colorful and beautifully-written sojourn to Palestine, Sherston ends up in heavy combat once more in his old Gaullic stomping-grounds, is wounded once more under the most ironic circumstances imaginable, and returns to England, a man who has perhaps finally come to terms with everything in his life, including, it seems, the fact that the England he fought to preserve is now as dead as many of his former comrades in arms.I definitely enjoyed SHERSTON'S PROGRESS -- especially the Palestinian passages, which feature some of his finest descriptive prose -- but I did think the novel, like the others, suffered from Sassoon's overly powerful sense of self-control. He writes everything, from battle to travelogue, in the same sedate, measured style, with the result that the entire novel never leaves its initial gear. Though it is as occasionally evocative as FOX-HUNTING MAN, which was an amazing if slow-paced reconstruction of Edwardian England at the height of its lovely, decadent silliness, it is also a description of a world which is palpably less attractive: a world of mental hospitals, backwater garrisons full of recuperating men, crowded troop ships, snobbish staff officers and muddy trenches. War is of course an interesting subject in and of itself, but oddly enough, it is perhaps not the best subject for Sassoon, because of his oddly cool-blooded perspective of the world. We read about his anger at the waste, stupidity and insanity of his surroundings, yet there is no sense of passion in these paragraphs. Sherston's anger is intellectual, not emotional, and I began to wonder in this third volume if perhaps he hadn't gone to war to experience that emotion for himself after an incredibly shallow youth centered around nothing but horse races and fox hunts. The English, particularly in Sassoon's day, were notorious for their stiff upper lips and calm demeanor in the face of adversity, but as George Orwell once pointed out, a mask can twist the face that wears it, and it may be that the mask of haughty indolence worn by the young man could not be removed. A reviewer of this novel claimed that it was nothing more than an Englishman trying to rise above his own Englishness -- and failing -- and that seems rather accurate.It's interesting to note that just a year after the war began, Sassoon -- not Sherston but the actual Sassoon -- famously wrote, "I want a genuine taste of the horrors, and then  peace. I dont want to go back to the old inane life which always seemed like a prison. I want freedom, not comfort. I have seen beauty in life, in men and things ... The last fifteen months have unsealed my eyes. I have lived well and truly since the war began; now I ask that the price be required of me." In MEMOIRS OF AN INFANTRY OFFICER he paid that price and then some, but I'm not sure that he sentiment about not wanting to go back was true. I think both Siegfried Sassoon and his alter-ago George Sherston were fighting for just that -- for "Atlas buses, of the hansom cab, of sulphurous fogs, of the lazy country-house life, of the long, lovely decade of the Edwardian age" Indeed, a better epitaph for his experiences might be summed up in his own comment from MEMOIRS OF A FOX-HUNTING MAN: "I wanted the past to survive and begin again."

One of the interesting things about radio is that there are some stories which couldn't be told in any other medium. "Death Shows The Way" is arguably such a story, but that doesn't detract, and in fact probably adds to, the luster of this amusing and brutal tale of deception, thievery and murder.Lamont Cranston and Margo Lane are spending the weekend at their good and very wealthy friends the Bartons; present as well is the equally rich Count Santo, whom they met while traveling in the Mediterranean. Henry Barton has just purchased the Great Harvey Diamond, which has a reputation of bringing misfortune on its owner, but he is unperturbed when a representative of Taylor & Co. shows up to deliver the priceless stone. His mood of insouciance doesn't last long: before you can say "Is the curse on this necklace real?", the representative is dead and the annoying adopted son of the Bartons, Skippy, has been kidnapped. Cranston doesn't believe in curses, however, and donning the Shadow's cloak begins an investigation which shows him the way to truth...but only by way of death.This episode is a great deal of fun from its humorous beginning, which shows Cranston losing a round to his implacable butlerAlan, to its decidedly brutal ending, which involves a criminal who should have been nicer to the Barton's Great Dane when he had the chance.There are not one but two, maybe even three, major plot twists I can't even hint about, and some delightfully sarcastic dialogue involving Cranston and the Barton's obnoxious child Skippy. All the SHADOW episodes that dealt with priceless jewels or objects -- "Death and the Crown of Odalph," "The Giant of Madras," "The Ruby of Karvahl," "Collectors of Death" etc. -- were excellent, and this one is no exception."Death Shows The Way" was originally broadcast on December 3, 1939 and features Bill Johnstone as The Shadow.

"Bride of Death" is an excellent episode from the Orson Welles era of THE SHADOW. It is also one of the more brutally told stories in the whole canon, and exposes the rather tired lie that entertainment back in the 1930s was less violent than it is today. This is one bloody half-hour."Bride" is the story of a cult leader who calls himself "The Prophet of the Ancient One" who has ensconced himself in a small seaside town in New England, using the money of one of his rich followers to support his nefarious doings. The mysterious Prophet, who hails from "some Asiatic sinkhole of the godless", travels with several vicious bodyguards and even a pack of trained panthers and has the entire village living in fear. However, when the local reverend's daughter falls under his sway, the reverend speaks out against the Prophet in church - whereupon the whole place goes up in one huge explosion, killing the entire congregation. This massacre draws the do-gooding pair of Lamont Crantson (Orson Welles) and Margo Lane (Agnes Moorehead) to the town; but when the Prophet learns they are investigating him, he kidnaps Margo, and it's up to The Shadow to save her and foil the Prophet before she becomes the latest sacrifice to the mysterious god known as "The Ancient One."Orson Welles' tenure as The Shadow was very much a hit-or-miss affair. Many of the storylines he was given were superb and even brilliant pieces of entertainment, while others were boring and silly. This one is firmly the former category. Although the plot is straightforward and there is no real mystery element (except for the true motives of the Prophet), it is a very well-written and well-acted episode, with lots of atmosphere and some great dialogue ("I stood fifty year afore the mast," one old salt tells Cranston. "And I ain't afeared of man, devil or the sea.") But even for a show as violent as THE SHADOW, this one stands out as unusually brutal. Just goes to show you that, blow up churches or unleash panthers as you will, when Mr. S is around...crime don't pay."Bride of Death" was originally broadcast on March 6, 1938.

DETECTIVE MONTALBANO is like pasta. No matter how much you eat, you always want more. Luckily, this TV show is not only delicious...it's good for you, offering nutrition not only for the mind and the wit, but for the eyes and the soul.For those unfamiliar with this superb mystery-comedy-drama series produced over many years by Rai Television, DETECTIVE MONTALBANO follows the life of Salvo Montalbano (Luca Zingaretti) a wily, quirky, quarrelsome, food-addicted Sicilian cop who is police chief in the small but far from sleepy seaside Sicilian village of Vigata. Backing up Salvo, and quite frequently fighting with him (this is Sicily, after all) are his long-suffering, long-distance girlfriend Livia, sultry and (mostly) platonic friend Ingrid, hot-tempered and perpetually amorous second-in-command/best friend Mimi Augello, bumbling but loveable aide Catarella, gentlemanly sleuth Fazio, trigger-happy Galuzzo, indolent CSI tech Jacomuzzi, and of course the irritable pathologist Dr. Pasquale. Together they are half-family, half-colleague, and all entertaining. This DVD set includes three episodes: "The Mystery of the Terracotta Dog", "The Artist's Touch" and "A Trip to Tindari."MYSTERY - Montalbano has his hands full, and then some, juggling a Mafia don who wants to defect and a 50 year-old double murder committed during the final days of Italy's involvement in WW2.  But while digging up the past is touchy stuff, playing the Mafia is dangerous business, and a mistake by Mimi Augello turn Montalbano from hunter into hunted, with tragic consequences.ARTIST - A wealthy but crippled goldsmith commits an almost ritualistic suicide in his wheelchair, but when his will is determined to be a forgery, his estranged brother becomes the prime suspect in his murder. Montalbano's investigation unearths a love triangle, an old family quarrel, and an elaborate plot centering on that oldest of Sicilian motivations: revenge.TINDARI - A notorious womanizer is shot dead on his own doorstep. An elderly couple disappears on an excursion to the resort town of Tindari. Is there a connection between these two seemingly unrelated incidents? Before you can say "mingia!" Montalbano is dealing with an aging Mafia boss speaking in riddles, a young Mafia hood on the run from the law, and a lot of home-made pornography which may be the clue to solving it all.I hesitated whether to give this package 4 or 5 stars because I didn't feel "The Artist's Touch" was quite in the league with the other two. However, "Terracotta" is so damned good it is almost painful -- a mingling of Sicilian history with a Romeo & Juliet style love story, slippery Mafia intrigue, and some brutally violent action. As for "Tindari", it is the most nakedly sexual and at the same time, most diabolical of all the MONTALBANO storylines, showing both the grisly depths of barbarism to which the Mafia sinks as well as one of the funniest sequences in the history of the show, when Montalbano tries to kick down a door that proves to be somewhat tougher than he is. As always, the episodes spend much time exploring Montalbano's complex sense of honor as well as his relationships with such people as Mimi and Ingrid, but the best thing about MONTALBANO is not the plotting -- which can at times be convoluted and sluggish by American standards -- but the superb writing (adapted for TV from the novels of Andrea Camilleri), the wonderful chemistry between the actors, and the exploration of Sicilian life and culture -- a life of food, family, argument, corruption, humor, violence, sensuality and intrigue. That, and Luca Zingaretti, who is just a joy to watch, and brings to the screen the same mix of genius, idiosyncratic irascibility and off-kilter sex appeal that Jeremy Brett did to the amazing Granada TV SHERLOCK HOLMES series of the 1980s/90s. Montalbano loves a mystery, but what he really hates is the idea that someone can play him, and as a general rule, it's not wise to try. Though it is fun to see!These episodes (in Italian with English subtitles) are presented in 16:9 anamorphic, and total up at 312 minutes, or about an hour and three quarters each. So sit back, open a bottle of wine, and get ready to feast your brain on some of the finest TV around...from Sicily, with love.Arrivederla!

If you're like me -- poor -- you probably still drive a car that uses audio cassettes. And if you're a fan of old time radio -- like me -- you probably love THE SHADOW, arguably the best and certainly one of the most successful programs to air during the Golden Age of Radio. Of course, THE SHADOW is generally associated with the most famous actors to play the role: Orson Welles, Bill Johnstone and Bret Morrison; the name John Archer doesn't necessarily ring any bells, and that is perhaps understandable. Archer only played the part for one year (1945), and as of this date, only two episodes from his brief run survive. This cassette includes both. They are:"The Destroyer" - Foster Merrill is a kindly-looking old man, a respectable member of society, and a friendly acquaintance of Lamont Cranston. He's also a lunatic. Merrill gets it in his head that only those who destroy go down in history, and one day embarks on a rampage of arson simply to prove his point. The police are baffled, and so too is Cranston, especially when arson escalates to bombing and mass murder. And just as Cranston narrows the list of suspects to Merrill and two others, Merrill decides that the nosy amateur investigator must die, to clear the way for one final, massive act of destruction."The Little Man Who Wasn't There" - A seemingly invisible thief is robbing jewelry and other priceless valuables from city luminaries in broad daylight. Chief Weston suspects The Shadow has turned to crime, and only Lamont Cranston and Margo Lane know otherwise. But how does an invisible detective track down and invisible criminal, especially one who seems to have greater powers than The Shadow himself?Both of these episodes are highly enjoyable, and I would argue that "The Destroyer" is about as good as anything THE SHADOW produced in its 17 years on the air. I don't know if John Archer's brief tenure was this good all the way through, but these two episodes provide some evidence in that direction. Archer, who died in 1999, was hardly an actor of the standing of, say, Orson Welles, and he isn't as important to the legacy of THE SHADOW as Morrison or Johnstone, and I always thought his delivery was a little too nasal to be really effective: but he was a competent, effective Shadow who played the role with enthusiasm. If you give him a little of your time, he won't disappoint you.

"I don't know if it's art, but I like it." So says the Jack Nicholson version of the Joker in Tim Burton's BATMAN. Well, I don't know if OPUS EPONYMOUS is art, either, but I love it. This is one devilish metal album that demonstrates once and for all that this genre of music doesn't have to consist of sweaty mustachioed men in too-tight leather pants screaming unintelligible nonsense into spittle-dripping microphones. It can be melodic, lyrically beautiful, technically precise and grandiose without being gaudy, all the while rocking its freaking brains out -- and yours, too.Other reviewers have gone at length into the history of the band Ghost, so I'm going to approach OPUS EPONYMOUS from the point of view of somebody who just likes good music and doesn't give a damn what genre label has been slapped upon it, or whether or not the guys in the band are really Satanists or just playing the role, or any of that. My only criteria is: does this album rock? And my short answer: HELL yes.Now, when I say it rocks, I don't mean you'll be banging your head off listening to it, or emerging from a mosh pit covered in blood, or left with a desire to start fights or smash things. OPUS isn't quite that type of album. In fact, the bookend songs -- the organ into "Deus culpa" and the driving, cosmic-sounding instrumental "Genesis" -- don't sound like Metal at all. They are merely demonstrations of Ghost's musical versatility -- not only technically but in terms of style. "Con clavi con Dio", the first full track on the album, hits pretty hard with relentless bass, drums and guitar rhythms, but it also showcases singer Papa Emeritus' surprisingly clear and restrained yet passionate vocals, which are not in any way typically "Metal." Next up comes "Ritual," which opens softly before shifting to more traditional crunchy guitar chords, over which Emeritus busts out some superb rhymes -- half clever wordplay, half Black Mass, which continue the Hammer horror-film atmosphere established by the opening track.After that is "Elisabeth," my personal favorite on the album, dedicated to history's most prolific and sadistic serial murderer, the Countess Elisabeth Bathory, "whose acts of cruelty and lust for blood make her one of us." The song is excellent, but what it really does is put the last nail in the album's coffin: there's no doubt, listening to this oddly romantic and poignant track, that you are in the midst of a musical horror movie. This theme is extended by "Sand by Him," an ode to a witch who hasn't renounced Satan despite being burned at the stake, and by "Satan Prayer" (do I really need to explain this one?) and the extremely catchy "Death Knell."The album's penultimate track is "Prime Mover," which is almost hypnotic in its sinister, bass-heavy intro, before telling a story which, if it had been a script, would certainly have been made into a film starring Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee. And make no mistake about it: this is a band that is striving -- and succeeding -- at establishing an atmosphere of fog-shrouded, full-moon-'n-the-werewolf-is-hungry-style horror. The album cover, showing the miter-clad Papa presiding over a spooky Dracula-style castle, says it all. These are songs for Halloween...or for people who want to summon up the feeling of Halloween any time they press "play."It's not my purpose here to talk about the band itself, or what their actual agenda may be, or even how they are perceived by their fans from an aesthetic standpoint. I don't know if this is art or just superb musical craftsmanship, and I don't really care. I just know that I like it -- and so, I think, will you.

Every now and again, a pop music album comes along that transcends the temporary nature of the genre, and has a lasting impact on the listener. Eddie Money's CAN'T HOLD BACK is such an album. On an intellectual level I can pick it apart; emotionally it remains irresistible to me - the moreso because the songs for which it is known by the general public are only the tip of its creative iceberg. This is just a very enjoyable album, and more importantly, one that hasn't dated - which is more than I can say about most 80s pop.The album starts with the song that made it famous, "Take Me Home Tonight", a bellowing, extremely catchy and sexually charged duet with Ronnie "The Original Bad Girl of Rock `n Roll" Spector that dominated the airwaves for what seemed like aeons when I was a teen. It's a terrific song, but those who buy the album on the strength of this duet will be surprised at the depth and enjoyability of what comes after it.It's said that any decent singer can make you feel nostalgic, but only a great singer can make you feel nostalgic for things you haven't done. I don't know if Eddie Money qualifies as great, but on "I Wanna Go Back" he made me long for my high school years...when I was 14 years old and still had plenty of them left ahead of me. That's pretty impressive. Likewise, he transcended the obvious message of "One Love" with a stucatto delivery and that half-sleepy, half-passionate delivery which made him famous. On "Endless Nights" and "One More Chance", he elevated what could have been clich-ridden songs about the anguish of failed romances with some clever lyrics and, as before, a delivery that seems so perfectly syncopated with the music that you just have to tip your hat to the album's engineers and mixer Richie Zito.The album's second side (yes, I still refer to it that way, having originally bought it on tape) switches up the gears a bit, opening with the powerful and underrated "We Should Be Sleeping", which makes the excellent point that a couple's energy is better spent making love than fighting.After that comes "Bring on the Rain", a tune about being a transplanted Easterner in Southern California, which easily could have been released as a single, and which appeals to me greatly...being a transplanted Easterner in Southern California. The song's title track is fairly ordinary, and "Stranger in a Strange Land" is so totally 80s - with its somewhat hollow background vocals and coldly mechanical drum-machine beat - that it feels dated. Likewise, "Calm Before the Storm" is forgettable and ends the album on a ho-hum note, but by this time it scarcely matters.As I said at the beginning of this review, there are some albums that are more than the sum of their parts. CAN'T HOLD BACK is a gushingly sentimental, occasionally trite pop album that relentlessly beats the pinata that is love in the hopes of producing some lyrical candy. Ordinarily this would annoy me to no end, but thanks to Money's great, somehow distinctly blue-collar delivery, and to some very pleasing harmonies and background vocals, it works. Big time.

It's either amusing or disturbing -- or both -- just how many institutions of today sprang from the scheming brain of Nazi Germany. The Autobahn... modern highways...the Volkswagen...INTERPOL...U.S. military doctrine...the jet engine...the guided missile. Among this cornucopia can be numbered the musical request show. As strange as it may seem today, the idea of ringing up a radio station and asking for a specific song did not originate with radio itself. That medium was around for nearly a generation before a wealthy German told a popular station he'd donate to the cause of their choice if they played a favorite tune of his. Cut to a few years later; WW2 has broken out and the German people are in need of distraction: the Wunschkonzert fr die Wehrmacht is born. This was a popular weekly broadcast which allowed civilians and soldiers to request and dedicate songs to loved ones, military units, or whoever they seemed worthy. It featured appearances by all the greatest stars of the day as well as jobbing amateurs and was enormously popular. So it's little wonder Goebbels decided it could feature as the backdrop and inspiration of its own feature film.WUNSCHKONZERT, in the tradition of other German films of this period such as UBER ALLES IN DER WELT, is actually a number of stories which interweave around a single unifying idea, theme or incident. It begins at the Olympic games in Berlin in 1936, where the lovely Ilse Werner (Inge Wagner) meets and falls in love with Luftwaffe Lieutenant Herbert Koch (Carl Raddatz). After a whirlwind courtship they plan engagement, but he soon receives orders to go to Spain, where the civil war is raging, as a military adviser to the Fascists. The mission is top secret, and thus Koch is forced to abandon his flame without explanation. Eventually she becomes close to another Luftwaffe pilot, Helmut Wilker (Joachim Brennecke), who befriends Koch without realizing they are in love with the same woman. As war breaks out the pilots fly together in combat, neither knowing the other is in love with Ilse. At the same time, there is an extensive sub-plot about a unit of German infantrymen going into battle in France, which involves not only their various loved ones (especially their mothers) but two bumbling soldiers who are sent to Berlin to perform a ditty of their own composition for the Wunschkonzert. As the story goes on, each character's destiny is affected and to some degree decided by their decision to request songs.As the title implies, WUNSCHKONZERT is not so much about the individual characters in the film per se as the way their lives are tied into, and ultimately effected by, the popular request show. The fate of the two star-crossed lovers, Herbert and Ilse, actually turns on the Olympic fanfare he requests of the program; and in another sequence, the fate of a German infantry squad is decided by one soldier's rendition of a Beethoven song on an organ he finds in a burning French church. There are also performances by real-life celebrities of the day, including the Berlin Philharmonic and Marika Rkk, arguably THE pin-up girl/singer of the Nazi era next to Lale Anderson. The film is also strong on the theme of men performing their duties in wartime while their women (moms, wives, sweethearts, sisters) wait anxiously at home, and how the music unites them. If all this seems a bit corny, one must remember that this film was released in 1940, and is not measurably sappier or more contrived than British or American romantic war movies of the same era. In fact, I would unhesitatingly say that WUNSCHKONZERT is one of the best WW2-era movies I've yet seen, featuring a skillful balance of romance, propaganda, music, history, and war-movie action, which give the modern viewer a fascinating, if idealized, view of popular culture in Nazi Germany. The acting is good, there are an unusual number of obstacles for the young lovers to face in their quest to be together, a splash of intrigue with the Spanish Civil War angle, a certain amount of pathos, and some entertaining Laurel & Hardy-style moments involving two bumbling soldiers and a captured pig. Like all movies of this type, it tends to blur its focus on the main element of the story towards the end in favor of a grand, all-inclusive climax, but aside from that I had no major complaints.Believe it or not, though hundreds of feature films were released in Germany during WW2, only twenty or so actually dealt with the war which was taking place at the time, following Goebbels' undoubtedly wise decision that what the people of Germany needed was distraction from the war and not reminders of it. This stands in fascinating contrast to Britain and America, who cranked out war movies nonstop and kept them going long after the war itself had ended. And because of this, WUNSCHKONZERT is just as valuable as historical evidence as it is an entertaining flick in its own right. Like all Americans I grew up on a steady diet of WW2 movies which seldom, if ever, gave even the slightest thought of what the enemy was like -- what he wanted, what he was feeling, why he was fighting, and what was waiting for him when he put away his rifle and went home. WUNSCHKONZERT puts faces and names and hopes and dreams on the dreaded, faceless Nazi soldiers, and it's perhaps no big surprise that these things weren't a helluva lot different for guys named Gotthard, Eberhard and Johannes than they were for the Joes, Mikes and Bobs of the war.  As a German song of the pre-war period refrained: "All I want is music! I don't need anything else!"

When I mention the name Ernie Pyle to people today, their usual reaction is "Who?" This is unfortunate, and a commentary on the ephemerality of fame, because there was a time when Ernie Pyle was as famous as any of the big-name American reporters you care to name today, and probably more deservedly so. Though he is best remembered (if he's remembered at all!) as a war correspondent, one who "brought the war home" to millions of Americans through the almost daily dispatches he sent from North Africa, Sicily, Italy, France and later the Pacific, Pyle actually won initial renown as a syndicated travel reporter, and ERNIE'S AMERICA is a best-of collection of his domestic reportage during the Great Depression and the very first days of WW2.The format is quite simple. Ernie simply drove from town to town, state to state (and territory to territory), crisscrossing the whole of the country, filing stories what he saw, who he spoke to, and the strange, funny, interesting and tragic things which happened to him on the way. Nothing and nobody were neglected: he drove through huge cities and ghost towns; he traveled to the wilds of Alaska and the tip of the pre-bridge Florida Keys; he talked to people of all races and all ages, all professions and trades, and all economic levels from the super-rich to the dirt-poor. Once in a while he'd encounter someone genuinely famous -- Booker T. Washington, for example -- but more commonly an unknown person with an absolutely fascinating life-story: a sea captain, a prospector, a prohibitionist, a cowboy, a fur-trapper, a barnstormer, a moonshine-maker, a former slave, and get it out of them. Over the years, and over thousands of columns, he unearthed a million fascinating details and the best of these have been sifted out and placed here for your reading pleasure. Together they form a kind of patchwork quilt image of the America of 80-odd years ago, and make for fascinating, amusing and often touching reading.It's worth noting that Pyle's writing style is very much like he comes off in his reports: apple-pie American, which is to say plain and simple but also honest and enjoyable. He isn't corny or naive or sham-patriotic, and his isn't the most gifted prose-writer who ever picked up a pen, but when he tells a story, you tend to remember it. Indeed, I retained more memories of this book -- more clear and vivid mental imagery -- than I have from many others. Ernest Hemingway, a man known for carrying grudges legitimate and made-up, often referred to himself as "the Poor Man's Pyle" -- implying that Pyle was some kind of literary snob. Nothing could be further from the truth. Pyle was not only not a snob, he was exactly the opposite of one. The image left to me after reading this book is of a balding redheaded sunburned Hoosier in a Chevy with a cigarette in the corner of his mouth, a crumpled road map on his lap, and a half-eaten hamburger on the front seat. In other words, of a plain old American, jamming down Route 66.Now, it's worth noting that America of 1935 - 1941 was obviously very different than that of today. The Civil War was still a living memory for the very old, Alaska and Hawaii were still territories, Arizona had only been a state for 20-odd years, and some West Coast towns were mere shadows of what they later became. Vast stretches of the country were scarcely inhabited. Drought had turned huge sections of the Middle West into a Dust Bowl, Jim Crow ruled the South, and most of the inventions and conveniences we take for granted today weren't even in the realm of science fiction back then. Yet what struck me was how little the essence of America has changed.
