Pyle's comments and observations on the politics of Washington, the thickness of government bureaucracy, anxiety over foreign wars, issues of poverty, inequality, immigration, racism and the economy don't seem dated, but rather timely. And on top of this, Pyle manages to convey through his reports something of the immensity and diversity of this huge country -- old mining camps in the Rockies, white shantytowns in the Deep South, trapper's cabins in Alaska, tomato stands in Hawaii, trim little Cape Cods in New England, and the enormous clamor of big cities everywhere. One can't help but feel, having read the book, that one has not only accompanied Ernie on his road trip across America, but actually traveled back in time to an era which is shockingly different and yet hauntingly the same.

In George Orwell's superb but conveniently half-forgotten essay on Salvador Dali, he made the extremely unusual case that it was possible to produce great art which should should nevertheless be suppressed as an outrage against morality. Orwell posed the question using this comparison: "The first thing I ask of a wall is that it be sturdy and not fall down. That is the purpose of a wall, which is separate question entirely from how the wall is used. But the best-constructed wall in the world deserves to be torn down if it surrounds a concentration camp. It ought to be possible to argue that such-and-such is a great artist, and his work out to be burned in the town square by the public hangman."One could argue that ICH KLAGE AN is great art, and one could argue that it "ought to be burned by the public hangman" despite this, given that the film's ultimate legacy was as a softening-up bombardment in the Nazi campaign to desensitize its population to the idea of euthanasia preparatory to initiating their hideous "T-4" mass euthanasia program, which saw 100,000 mentally ill Germans gassed or poisoned as an act of racial hygieneThe story begins with the effervescent and life-loving Hanna Heyt celebrating the appointment of her research-scientist husband Thomas to a professorship in Munich. When Hanna injures her arm slightly during their dinner celebration, however, the injuries don't heal, so Thomas calls in a former romantic rival of his, Dr. Bernhard Lang, to perform an examination. To everyone's horror, Lang, who is still in love with Hanna, diagnoses her with multiple sclerosis. Thomas immediately throws himself into researching a treatment for the progressive and fatal disease, which is steadily robbing Hanna of all the quality of life; but when his efforts come to nothing he begins to seriously contemplate granting her wish for euthanasia, even though the law forbids it, and Lang is militantly opposed. Thomas' decision ultimately lands him before a court of inquiry, where his actions and motives are scrutinized and some evidence is presented that may exonerate him without a clear decision as to the morality of assisted suicide. But Lang isn't having it: refusing to grant anyone an easy way out, he demands to be tried solely on the basis of whether his actions were right or wrong, and its upon this verdict that his fate rests.IMDB's review of this movie calls it "morbid melodrama," but I no longer trust any official reviews of Nazi-era films, since the reviewers inevitably confuse enjoying a film produced by the Nazi government to mean the viewer is in sympathy with its ideology and methods.I myself found the film deeply moving and extremely dramatic. The direction, by Wolfgang Liebeneiner, is crisp and assured, the performances are absolutely first-rate and the script is tight and beautifully written. The lovely Heidemarie Hatheyer delivers an award-worthy performance full of charm and pathos. Hartmann and Weiman are also superb as the rival doctors. Margarete Haagen is also excellent as Hanna's housekeeper/surrogate mother, the loving Berta, as is the always-reliable Christian Kayssler as the judge. This film won the prestigious (at the time, anyway) Biennale Cup, and I believe deservedly so. It's at least as good, and probably considerably more gutsy in its subject matter, than most American and British films shot at the same time.ICH KLAGE AN translates from German to English as "I Accuse" and it is an appropriate title for the film. On trial for his life, Thomas Heyt ultimately accuses his accusers of cowardice and hypocrisy for being willing to condemn a suffering human being to indefinite physical suffering merely to spare themselves moral anguish, and he asks the audience to render its own judgement on his actions. In other words, this film was designed to open a dialogue as to its subject, and I believe it does just precisely that. What surprised me was the even-handedness with which the movie explores the idea of euthanasia itself. Religious, moral and ethical arguments against it are all brought to bear and given, I believe, at least the pretense of a fair hearing. There's little doubt where the movie itself lands, but it does not subject the anti-euthanasia crowd to ridicule. For a Nazi-sanctioned film, it's surprisingly fair.I quoted Orwell above because I know there are many who wonder why Nazi-era cinema has a modern audience or is even allowed to be sold. Many would argue that whatever the artistic or technical merits of movies like STUKAS, SA-MANN BRAND, UBER ALLES IN DER WELT, etc., etc.  they were ultimately fruits of the poisonous tree that was Nazi Germany, and should be suppressed or destroyed, as so much Nazi literature has been suppressed and destroyed. Orwell himself may have argued this, but I can't agree, and I'm grateful to live in a country where -- unlike most of "liberal" Europe, in which these films are banned -- art is not burned in the town square by the public hangman. After all, who appoints the hangman? And who is to say what else he might choose to burn?

It is very interesting to note that THE HELLBOUND HEART is as economical a novel as its predecessor, THE DAMNATION GAME, was overwritten. In fact, it is not a novel at all but a novella, a sort of gory-fied short story that is all the more disturbingly effective because it later gave birth, in movie form, to the HELLRAISER franchise -- in other words, to Pinhead and his ghastly latex-demon pals, the Cenobites.THE HELLBOUND HEART opens with the hedonistic sociopath Frank Cotton playing with a mystical puzzle box known as the Lament Configuration. He soon discovers that the rumors about the box are true: it has the power to summon a group of demonic entities known as the Order of the Gash, who offer Frank -- who feels as if he has exhausted all known forms of pleasure and debauchery -- an experience he has never had before. It soon turns out that Frank has bitten off more than he can chew, but there is no going back from a bargain with the Order. Cut to a few months later: Frank's tame brother Rory and his faithless wife Julia have moved into the Cotton family home. The wife carries a dark secret: she once bedded, and has ever after lusted, after Frank. So when she discovers, after a bloody accident, that the presumed-missing Frank is still in the house, she readily agrees to help him escape the Cenobites so they can ditch Rory and run off together. Of course there is a little business which must be taken care of first: the demons have reduced Frank to a disgusting parody of a human being, little more than an animated skeleton. To regain his humanity, he needs blood...lots of blood...which Julia must supply to him via a series of hapless horny businessmen she picks up in airport bars...and after that, he needs skin to walk around in...which perhaps his brother can supply. And here comes the small hitch in the plan: Rory's wife may be a two-timing narcissistic psycho, but his friend Kirsty thinks he's the greatest guy on earth and is (pardon the pun) hell-bent to protect him. Suspecting Julia of an affair, she soon discovers wifey is up to much worse, and ends up making a twisted bargain of her own with the Cenobites to save the day. The trouble is, she may not be able to hold up her end of it; and even if she does, who's to say they will keep their word? In the grisly world author Clive Barker has created, the only certainty is that come what may, there will be blood. Lots and lots of blood.THE HELLBOUND HEART was Clive Barker's second novel, and it is written in a very different style than his debut, THE DAMNATION GAME. The latter book was interesting and even occasionally brilliant, but so heavily overwritten as to become a bit tedious. This novel has almost the opposite problem: Barker has written such a terse, economical story that I began to wish, halfway through, that he'd fleshed it out some more. And that is really the only criticism I can level at the book. It reminded me strongly of the film Noir movies of the 40s and 50s, albeit with a demonic twist. It is a highly imaginative and deeply disturbing story, in which each character has a clear and understandable, if not necessarily sympathetic, motive. Frank, suffering from his own bad decisions, wants out of his living hell. Julia, suffering from anomie and boredom, wants out of the dull confines of middle-class marriage. Kirsty wants to protect her secret love, Rory. And Rory? The poor guy just wants his wife to love him again. Amidst all this simmering human motivation the Cenobites add an unholy spice to the broth: they want what is owed to them, and they are damned well (pun intended) gonna get it.To be sure, if you have already seen the movie HELLRAISER this book will not surprise you: Barker's script stuck very closely to his novel, and there are few,  if any, significant departures from the story. But even having seen the movie a number of times I found myself page-turning almost frantically as the novel stamps along to its gory, barbaric and apocalyptic conclusion. This is a very dark tale, full of twisted motives, shattering betrayals and brutal murders, and while it can be said that vice is punished, it can't necessarily said that virtue is rewarded. In the world Barker has created, once you make a deal with the devil, there's no such thing as a bargain.

The definition of "strange" is "something which is different from what is usual, normal or expected." The definition of "macabre" is "involving death or violence in a way that is strange, frightening, or unpleasant; having death as a subject : comprising or including a personalized representation of death."Both these words apply to THE WICKER MAN.I'd heard rumors and whispers about this movie for years; I'd even read Christopher Lee's warm words for it in his autobiography, but I didn't watch it until this year, and I admit that about halfway through I was ready to press STOP and give up. The movie was slow, eccentric, bizarre and at times, borderline ridiculous; then, all of the sudden, the eccentricity began to ravel into a feeling of increasing unease and menace, a sort of "everyone is in on the joke except the hero, and it's a very black joke indeed." By the climax I was watching mainly to see what the hell would happen, and once it did...well, not since the original PLANET OF THE APES have I been so jarred by a movie's ending.THE WICKER MAN is the story of a British policeman named Sergeant Howie (Edward Woodward) who flies out to the remote, clannish, half-forgotten Scottish island of Summerisle, to investigate the disappearance of a young girl named Rowan Morrison. Almost immediately upon landing he begins to suspect the tight-lipped islanders aren't telling him everything, but his frustrated investigation rapidly yields one piece of very disconcerting information: on Summerisle, Christianity is dead and Celtic Paganism is the one true faith. Howie, a devout and somewhat self-righteous Christian, is revolted by this, and by the wanton sexuality of the island's female population, most noticeably the gorgeous Willow MacGregor (Brit Ecklund). Encountering the island's de facto ruler, Lord Summerisle (Christopher Lee), Howie gradually begins to suspect that Rowan Morrison may not have been murdered as he first suspected, but may in fact have been kidnapped preparatory to some Celtic ritual of human sacrifice. Determined to save Rowan's life, he searches the island from one end to the other without success, before deciding on an even more radical plan of action: he will infiltrate the "cult" by masquerading as one of them. Only then will he discover the answer to the question that brought him to Summerisle and has now placed his life in jeopardy: what the devil happened to Rowan Morrison?As I said, I found the first half of this movie to be heavy going. There is a lot of bizarre dialogue and a lot -- I mean a LOT -- of singing. A lot of what I saw seemed weird for the sake of being weird and I didn't understand what the hell the point of all of this discomfort was. Only my loyalty to Edward Woodward and Christopher Lee kept me going, but once I crested Mount Weird, I began to see that like Rowan Morrison, I was being led somewhere...somewhere very freaking nasty, and all the nastier because the bad guys in this film don't see themselves as bad at all. Quite the contrary....Obviously I am not giving you hard details here, because I can't describe the movie very accurately without giving away the store. What I can say is that Edward Woodward delivers a possibly career-best performance as a devoutly Christian cop whose entire sense of right and wrong, sane and insane, and hell, even up and down, are attacked from the moment he lands his seaplane by the quiet little island -- at first subtly, then more and more blatantly until the audience wonders just how much power the law has on an island which seems to be a law unto itself. This is a film that crumbles the self-assurance of its hero by degrees, inflicting a slow nonviolent torture on both him and the viewer, until exploding into a climax so jarring, so disturbing, and so outright horrifying that it took me hours to recover.And isn't that exactly what you want from a horror movie?

I watched GERMANIN: THE STORY OF A COLONIAL DEED out of sheer curiosity. I've been exploring Nazi-era cinema at some length this year, and have generally found it to be much more subtle thematically, better written and better acted than I would have expected. Shot at the height of WW2, this movie can be excused for its propagandistic and anti-British themes, and represents a solid of unspectacular UFA studios release which perhaps belies George Orwell's assertion that no art of any value can be produced under a dictatorship.GERMANIN begins in 1914 in a German colony in Africa. A resolute German physician (Peter Petersen) and his lovely assistant (Lotte Koch) are working on a cure to the dreaded, fly-borne disease of sleeping sickness, which is decimating the population. When war breaks out, the British attack his isolated research outpost, forcing a friendly trapper (Luis Trenker) to flee to Germany with the doctor's research. After Germany's collapse, the three reunite in Berlin to continue the fight against the disease, only to face bureaucratic obstacles set in their path by the British and by the Bayer corporation. After an act of heroism by the trapper, which proves the doctor's formula is effective, Bayer gets on board and the British reluctantly allow the trio to return to their former colony to bring the "Germanin" formula to the masses: it's only then that the true extend of British perfidy is revealed, and our three heroes must fight both a scheming British officer (Albert Lippert) and the disease itself in order to see that justice is done for the people of Africa.GERMANIN is a film somewhat typical of the period in which it was shot and to some extent, the government which authorized its production. The idea of European colonization of Africa is accepted on its face as a beneficent enterprise: the Germans bringing modern medicine and technology to well-meaning savages (whose customs are depicted in great detail, with a huge cast of black people which includes the German-speaking black actor Louis Brody). At the same time, the loss of the colonies after Versailles is depicted as a national humiliation, doubly so because the rationale for stripping them from Germany was Germany's "moral unworthiness" to guide the local populace to civilization: yet the morally "superior" England is shown deliberately interfering with the distribution of "Germanin" in favor of an inferior American medicine, to the detriment of the natives. And the Germans themselves are depicted as ethical, manly and heroic (if they are men) and sexy and stalwart (if they are Lotte Koch). By today's standards the film is clumsy, obvious and deeply racist (in a strangely well-meaning way) but American and British films of the same era are no different, and as far as the British characters are depicted, the script actually allows for more character development from the British antagonist than would have been granted to a German in an "Allied" film of the same time.As entertainment, GERMANIN does the job without exceeding expectations.The acting is quite good, and there are a few interesting twists to the story and some first-class villainy on the part of Col. Crosby, the bad-guy Englishman, such as when he destroys all the Germanin out of spite. (Lotte Koch is really a sight, too.) Technically the film is pretty sophisticated, and director Max Kimmich (Goebbels' brother-in-law) does his job with professionalism and some obvious gusto.  I'm not sure where the exteriors were actually shot, but the locations look African to me and I suppose it's not impossible some of it was filmed there during the period when the Axis had a large foothold on "the black continent." The camerawork is more mobile than many films of its time period (1943) and the use of stock footage of  chimpanzees, snakes, cheetahs, waterfalls, jungles, swamps, etc. is less obtrusive than you might imagine. The weaknesses are a lack of character development (everyone is pretty much fully formed at the beginning of the movie and stays the same all film through, except for Col. Crosby), uneven pacing, and a somewhat anticlimactic ending. We are continuously told that curing the sickness is only half the battle, that exterminating the tsetse fly is the real answer, and that the British stand in the way, but there is never an explanation as to how this might be done even if the Brits don't interfere -- especially by a band of 3 Germans with some native helpers.All in all I'd say this is a decent but not a great film, entertaining without being riveting and enjoyable without being truly resonant. I'd recommend it for fans of 40s-era movies, adventure cinema, and those curious about what going to a movie in Nazi Germany would have been like.

I ordered this thing because I recently purchased an old Atari 800XL on eBay, and after trolling Frye's and Radio Shack,  discovered that the old RF switch-box adapters which hooked the game cord to the TV are not easily available anymore. You can get them, but it takes work, not the least of which because the employees of modern electronics stores, who are usually young, often don't know what the hell they are. What's more, modern televisions don't properly interact with the old RF boxes anyway. So it's nice to know that if you have an elderly video game system, you can invest in one of these bad boys. About 1" long, it fits into the game system's computer cord, and allows it to mate with your modern television. Presto! You're playing the games of your youth again.That's pretty much it. These are neat, cheap, easy solutions to the problem of how to play 80s and 90s-era video games on flat-screens, HDs and plasmas of today. Now if you'll excuse me I have to get back to playing "Frogger."

The Circle of Death" was one of the very first, if not the first, episodes of THE SHADOW to deal with a mass-murdering lunatic. Not coincidentally, it features the actor Alan Devitt as the bad guy, in what would become his signature type of role on that show: a crazy man with a penchant for murder. Few people did it as well as Devitt, which explains why "Circle of Death" is a such solid and enjoyable episode.The story opens with a mysterious bombing in the "City Arcade" (presumably Times Square), which kills many innocent people. The bombings continue, seemingly at random and without motive, and the angry business owners are soon demanding Commissioner Weston resign if he can't catch the person(s) responsible. The Shadow decides to take a hand in the matter and publicly challenges the anonymous killer to bomb the Arcade again. It's a risky gamble, but in order for The Shadow to stop the bomber, he must get him to expose the diabolical method he uses for delivering his bombs."Circle" is not a perfect episode. It has a few plot holes, the ending is a bit anticlimactic, and the reliance on the Shadow's ability to read minds (a device quickly abandoned after about one season) weakens the suspense. Balancing that are a slam-bang (no pun intended) opening, some great verbal jousting between Weston and The Shadow, and a great performance by Devitt as the lunatic. It's not a classic tale, but it delivers many of the elements which made the show itself a classic: jarring violence, high stakes, and a bad guy who puts the "c" in "crazy." As a bonus, this ep was produced during the era when Weston hated The Shadow, which made for some great humor."The Circle of Death" was originally broadcast on November 28, 1937, and stars Orson Welles as The Shadow/Lamont Crantson, Agnes Moorehead as Margo Lane, Ray Collins and Commissioner Weston, and Alan Devitt as Anton Spivak.

"The Death Triangle" is a dark tale from the height of the Orson Welles era of THE SHADOW -- a tale of twisted motives, madness, and revenge."Triangle" begins on Devil's Island in 1913. Inmate Pierre Martan is being whipped for attempting to escape; as he is flogged he swears revenge on three of his fellow inmates who got away and whom he believes left him behind as a patsy: Dr. James Evans, Raymond DuBrille, and Jacques Covet. Cut to twenty years later; Evans, DuBrille and Covet all have successful lives in America, and have forgotten Martan...until he finally manages to escape, and embarks on a quest for revenge. Evans, who saved The Shadow's life by removing a bullet near his spine years before, pleads with the invisible avenger to intercede and stop Martan before he can exact his revenge. Can The Shadow stop a man that even Devil's Island could not contain? All is not what it seems in this story of twisted motives and debts that can only be paid in blood."Triangle" is a strong if unspectacular story; its only real flaw is a certain muddiness caused by the large number of characters and the central plot twist (a case of addition by subtraction). It is nevertheless a very good example of the type of tale which relies mainly on understandable human feelings and motivations (like guilt and revenge), rather than a flashy gimmick like a death-ray or a mad scientist. (THE SHADOW was often at its strongest when rooted in the real world -- or rather the real underworld.) And as always, the vocal acting is excellent all around."The Death Triangle" was originally broadcast on December 12, 1937 and stars Orson Welles as The Shadow/Lamont Cranston, Agnes Moorehead as Margo Lane, Bennett Kilpack as Pierre Martan, Alan Devitt as Raymond DuBrille, Ned Wever as Dr. James Evans, and Everett Sloane as Jacques Covet.

THE SHADOW was nothing if not inventive when it came to storylines, and "The Phantom Fingerprints" is as good an example as you could find of a show which never let its own formula detract from spinning a great yarn.Our story begins with Chief Weston debating whether or not to retire a beloved but aged police surgeon. The old man demurs, saying that retirement would kill him: so when he's found brutally murdered in Weston's office, there's a heavy dose of irony as well as outrage that sweeps the Police Department. Confusion is added when the fingerprints of the murderer come back as belonging to Killer Norvelli, a vicious hoodlum who Weston sent to the electric chair years before. Ridiculing the notion that a dead man wielded the fatal knife, the principal suspect becomes a cop with a gambling problem who owed the surgeon money...but the Shadow isn't convinced. To get to the truth, however, he has to track down Norvelli's widow, and discover whether the cop is guilty, the murderer really has returned from the grave...or a third suspect is out there and waiting to strike again.There is nothing specifically spectacular about this episode. The basic themes are familiar to any veteran listener of the show, and it could be argued that the ultimate identity of the killer becomes obvious sooner than the writer would have liked, but these are minor points. Sometimes even the less complex SHADOW tales managed to strike precisely the right notes of mystery, suspense, terror and the macabre, and "The Phantom Fingerprints" is one of those. Throw in a killer both evil and ridiculously cunning, and you have a sure-fire recipe for entertainment."The Phantom Fingerprints" was originally broadcast October 29, 1939 and stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow.

"Death Speaks Twice" is an entertaining and original episode of THE SHADOW which hovers somewhere between three and four stars in my estimation, Three because there is nothing really spectacular about it, four because what it does, it does quite effectively.Paul Bartow is in prison, but if you believe him, he's been framed -- framed by his corrupt, bullying judge of an uncle, who just happens to be the same judge who sentenced him to prison. Paul doesn't have much time left on his sentence, but his lifer cell mate, Marty LaGort, another victim of the hanging judge, convinces him to escape and get even. Why? Because Paul's ex-flame is about to marry his shifty  step-brother. News of the breakout alarms everyone in the prosperous but troubled Bartow family, and when Judge Bartow is brutally murdered, Commissioner Weston is determined to bring Paul to justice, but Lamont Cranston and Margo Lane have their doubts as to Paul's guilt. The trouble is, Weston has the most damning of evidence: a recording of the murder itself! With everything stacked against Paul, it's up to The Shadow to discover just who has committed the real crime here...and who must pay.I probably overuse the word "straightforward" when reviewing episodes of THE SHADOW so I'll just say that this one is direct without being overly obvious. The opening, set in prison, is very strong, and there is a remarkably clever device by which Paul may or may not have been framed. Throw in the opaque motives of the escaped murderer Marty LaGort, and a lot of twisted, inter-family scheming, coupled with Chief Weston's tendency to shoot first and ask questions never, and you have a fun, swiftly-paced half-hour which just goes to show that crime does not pay, but it does entertain."Death Speaks Twice" was originally broadcast on February 15, 1942 and stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow.

There are episodes of THE SHADOW that rely very heavily on the fact that the show's hero, Lamont Cranston, has the power of invisibility. "The Temple Bells of Neban," for example, or "The Shadow Challenged" or "The White Witchman of Lawaiki." just to name a few.. On the other hand, there are quite a few stories in which this dramatic gimmick plays little part, and the plot is simply straight gangster - Noir. "Until Death Do Us Part" is one of them.The story begins with a brutal murder: a hit-man named Roxy offs the supposedly two-timing wife of a big-shot gambling kingpin named Lou. Cut to two years later: Lou has remarried, but his new spouse Fey is just as unhappy as her predecessor -- so unhappy she tries vainly to seek comfort in the arms of Lou's chief lieutenant, the handsome Vince. Vince, however, isn't having it, even when Fey reveals that she has evidence Lou killed his first wife and that he's planning on doing her the same way. Enter Lamont Crantson, who steps in to try to protect Fey while simultaneously dealing with the murderous Roxy and a kingpin who doesn't seem to be deterred by the army of cops sent against him. But where cops fail, the Shadow is determined to succeed -- if only he can get to the bottom of a nasty tangle of greed, jealousy, betrayal and murder.This is a fine story full of plot twists, double-crosses, violent ambushes, and brutal murders. The dialogue is straight gangster pulp, with the actors who play Roxy, Vince and Fey doing exceptional jobs at portraying people for whom lawbreaking, scheming and hustling are second nature, yet have their own weird charisma all the same. As with most stories of this type, not everyone who is guilty gets punished to the full extent of the law and not everyone who is innocent lives to see the end of the episode, yet the moral at the end is harshly decisive. Or, as the Shadow puts it apropos of a killer: "He'll get what's coming to him -- every volt.""Until Death Do Us Part..." was originally broadcast on March 6, 1949 and stars Bret Morrison as The Shadow.

Hans Zberlein was one of the lucky ones.Or was he?Born in 1895 in Imperial Germany, he was of precisely the right age group to be sucked into the maelstrom of World War One. That was unlucky. And no sooner had he finished his military training than he was shipped off to the massacre masquerading as a battle known as Verdun. That was unluckier still. So it's no coincidence then that the first volume of"Faith in Germany" (Glaube an Deutschland) his (when all volumes are counted) 900 page account of his wartime experiences, begins with an account of that massacre -- and reading through it, one wonders how the hell he survived.Maybe he was lucky after all?Purely by accident, Zberlein became a "guide" almost as soon as he arrived at the front. His job was to lead fresh troops to the trenches and worn-out ones back from it. It sounds like a simple-enough task, but Verdun in 1916 had ceased to be a town, a fortress or even a geographical location, and devolved into a massive, shell-cratered sea of mud and corpses, whose landscape was pounded into fresh new shapes every day by French heavy artillery. At night, with poison gas lingering over everything, with shell holes deep as three-story houses and full of stagnant water everywhere, with one's boots sinking ankle deep in slime, with machine-gun bullets shrieking overhead and shrapnel and high-explosive detonating all around....well, the task of being a guide had its own peculiar difficulties.What struck me about Verdun, from the German perspective, especially when the author contrasts it to the idyllic, full-bellied time he spent on the Eastern Front, sunbathing and drinking "grog" and waiting for action that never came, was that Verdun was not so much a battle itself as a kind of natural disaster which  consumed human lives by the hundreds and even the thousands every day. For the first 2/3 of the book, the Germans seldom ever even glimpse the French, except as rotting corpses. Their reality is mud, lice, rats, stench, more mud, still more mud, and constant fear of death. The idea was not to win, to attack or even to defend, but simply to endure, and to survive. As an American soldier once quipped when asked by a journalist what he wanted most in the world: "Gimme tomorrow."VERDUN isn't what I'd call a page-turner until the book's final act. Like a lot of amateur writers, Zberlein's clumsy prose style becomes more surefooted as he gets deeper into his subject, and his word-pictures become clearer and more concise. What's more, the war itself changes character, with more direct action, including a fascinating accidental attack conducted by the Germans, and a brutal yet black-comic sub-plot about a French sniper who utters a horse laugh every time he picks off a German soldier (it's Zberlein's task to teach this fellow some humility). The climax of the book, which shows how Zberlein's outfit is treated in the rear after their arduous and selfless duty, is a real gut-wrencher, right out of THE FORGOTTEN SOLDIER or IF THIS BE GLORY, and seems to represent a turning point in his attitude. Naivete  and obedience to authority begins to ferment into bile and gall, as well as the hard self-assurance of a battle-tested front line soldier, who tells his superiors, in essence, to go F themselves, you can keep your Iron Cross. It's not hard that the Nazi in Zberlein was conceived out of sheer bitterness.If the short first volume (only 115 pages) is emotionally honest -- Zberlein freely admits to fear, horror and confusion at all times -- technically, the book is all over the place. The author writes in a typically German vein, meaning he uses the present tense and begins the memoir in media res, without any biographical information other than what is occasionally revealed by idiom, reminiscences, or conversation. This is effective for dramatic purposes but doesn't give us too much to work with in regards to getting to know Zberlein. The book's translation is from German into British English, and it is often unwieldy. As for the editing , it is just plain atrocious. Words are repeated, mis-spelled or just plain omitted, many quotes aren't closed, punctuation is occasionally missing, and despite the handsome illustration on the cover, the whole book has an atmosphere of something which was rushed into print by a small-press publisher with no time, no money and no editor. I'd have dearly loved just one day to proof-read this sucker before it went to press, as it would have dearly helped the readability. I don't want to seem ungrateful, and I'd rather have this version of "Faith in Germany" than none at all, but I hope, if only for the sake of book sales, subsequent volumes of Zberlein's book produce cleaner copy. I will, however, be buying "Volume II" when it comes out, regardless.Now, it's worth noting that "Faith in Germany" was, until the end of WW2, considered, alongside "All Quiet On The Western Front" and "In The Storm Of Steel"  to be perhaps THE account of the Great War as written from the German perspective. The book was an international best-seller, became the basis for an equally successful film called "Shock Troop 1917," and was evidently read and admired by Adolf Hitler, who later wrote a forward for it in which he called it "the legacy of the front." But therein lies the rub. Because Hitler saw in  Zberlein a kindred spirit, one who had taken the "right" attitude toward the war and drawn the "right" lessons from it, and because Zberlein, unlike, say, Ernst Jnger, joined the Nazi Party and may have even been involved in the postwar "Werewolf" movement, he has suffered the fate Orwell might have called "Going down the memory hole." Since 1945 his works have been banned in Germany, and the movie is only permitted to be shown after heavy editing, lest it rouse in its viewers some resentment at the victorious Allies or some spark of Teutonic martial spirit. Indeed, it's only just now that both the film and his multi-volume memoirs are available to even the English reader, and for that I am grateful to the publisher, notwithstanding my comments as to the editing. I am a firm believer in freedom of speech and freedom of thought, and I believe that suppressing "dangerous" literature in the name of freedom is far more dangerous than any literature could ever be. Hans Zberlein's experiences in the war -- which in this volume, anyway, aren't to be distinguished from Remarque's, though his conclusions certainly were -- speak for themselves. It should be, and thanks to TRB, it is, up to the reader to pass judgement on them. The reader, and not the government.

I've had my Fitbit One for about two years now and for better or worse, can't imagine life without it. I had to order a replacement charger when I lost the original, so I thought I'd write a fast review of this device for the newcomer.THE PROS: The charging cable is small enough to pocket and forget about. It travels easily. It's a USB plug, so you can charge the Fitbit from pretty much any computer of any size, whether the FB software is installed or not. It also charges the unit with remarkable speed.THE CONS: Because it's a USB, wall outlets won't help you, and this is annoying. If the Fitbit's battery is totally dead, it will take several minutes to register a signal. This can confuse the owner into thinking the charger is broken. It's also grossly overpriced, which sucks because it's very small and correspondingly easy to misplace.That's pretty much it. If you own a Fitbit One you must have a charger, so you don't have much of a choice, but given the lack of same, this isn't a bad only option.

I've seen a helluva lot of war movies, but THE HOT SNOW definitely gave me something different to chew on, presenting both a broad and extremely narrow view of history's most destructive conflict, and employing a literal "cast of thousands" to tell a tale of heroism, grim determination, and the importance of the individual in the face of huge historical events.In terms of plot, THE HOT SNOW is about as straightforward as a bullet. It's December of 1942, and a Soviet anti-tank outfit has been charged with holding the line against a German attack intended to relieve their trapped army at Stalingrad. Because the fate of the war may hinge on repulsing the relief attack, the Soviet general in charge orders each of his soldiers to fight to the death where he stand -- there is to be no retreat. Correspondingly, after a series of tough fights against waves of oncoming German tanks, only one gun and its seven-man crew (actually six men and and one woman) survive. Freezing, cut off, surrounded by dead men, each member of the crew struggles to master their nerve and do their duty while staring, quite literally, down the barrels of German guns.Although I've very little experience with Russian films (ALEXANDR NEVSKY and NINTH COMPANY are the only other two I've seen), in some ways I found this movie familiar, in that it's the classic story of a small unit thrown into the crucial sector of a huge battle -- a story told in movies as disparate as BATAAN, THE ALAMO, THE LOST BATTALION, and 300, just to name a few. On the other hand, I was fascinated by the differences between Russian/Soviet culture and, for example, that of Americans or other Westerners. Everybody knows the Russians have a reputation for toughness, stubbornness and ruthlessness, but even so, the cold-blooded behavior of General Bessanov made quite an impression on me. Early in the movie his HQ is strafed by German fighters; he tells the flying-control officer that the punishment for this ought to be death. A short while later he orders the summary execution of a drunken tanker who has retreated instead of fighting to the death. Later yet he waits to order a counterattack even though he knows it may mean the annihilation of an entire division, because the time is not yet right. One gets the idea that the Russians are at once primitive and almost savage folk, with their guitars and vodka and barbaric discipline and casual regard for life, yet at the same time deeply and fatalistically soulful, understanding that life is a rental and not a purchase, and that the cause they fight for is infinitely larger than themselves.Technically the film is sound. The acting is very good, I enjoyed the script -- the translation seems very spot-on, with a lot of idioms -- and the cinematography was respectable and sometimes quite inspired. The sequences of the gun-crews clanking shells into the smoking breeches and firing round after round at the elephantine German panzers were superb. And being filmed in 1972, the producers couldn't fake battle sequences with CGI, they actually had to employ vast groups of extras and surprisingly large numbers of vehicles to get the job done. There is some model-work typical of the period, but for the most part if you see a tank, it's just that, not a blob of pixels. Of course the viewer already knows the ultimate outcome of the Stalingrad battle, so the tension lies in the fate of the individual characters. And here, to some extent, is the film's main weakness. Although several of the characters do get killed over the course of the movie, I felt that to some extent, the writer was not quite ruthless enough in doling out the scythe as the film went on. What's more, there is no precise point of climax in the story; just a lot of fighting which tapers off to a long, miserable night in a bunker followed by the battle's aftermath. An American writer would have structured the story more predictably, but also with a greater eye to tension and pacing.I can't say THE HOT SNOW is a great war movie. There are a lot of characters to follow, probably too many stereotypes, and having been shot in the Soviet era, there is no mention of the tension which probably existed between the general and his chief commissar -- the two men come off more like brothers-in-law. Yet I can't say the movie didn't effect me or that I didn't enjoy it, and I will almost certainly watch it again. That's a pretty strong recommendation.

For an Orson Welles episode of THE SHADOW, "The White God" falls pretty squarely in the middle of the pack. It's not anywhere near in the league of such classics as "Death From The Deep" or "Sabotage"; nor is it as bad as clunkers like "Hounds in the Hills" or "Voice Of The Trumpet." It's a fairly fast-paced, respectably entertaining, e'er so slightly ridiculous story that will hold your interest but probably not resonate in your mind."The White God" opens with a rash of inexplicable ship disappearances and sinkings in the South Pacific. Volunteering his services to the U.S. Navy, The Shadow, with Margo at his side, is flown to a remote island chain to investigate. However, no sooner have they approached the chain than their plane crashes, evidently affected by some mysterious force. Washing up on the island, they discover the natives worship a mysterious, homicidal white man who claims to be responsible for wrecking the ships. The boast seems preposterous, but if it isn't supernatural power behind the reign of the White God, what is it -- and how will the Shadow put a stop to it?As I said, this episode is not one of Welles' best. The premise is rather busy for a half-hour show; plus it is bizarre and a little silly, which makes the vicious brutality of the White God seem jarring. The best SHADOW episodes knew when to play a story absolutely straight and when to place tongue firmly in cheek; this one lacks that balance. On the other hand, it is pretty bold in its scope, solidly entertaining, and surprisingly well-written for all its silliness. The 30s were a time when mankind was beginning to actively fear the products of its own science, and "The White God" is a good reflection of this growing unease."The White God" was originally broadcast on July 10, 1938 and stars Orson Welles as The Shadow and Agnes Moorehead as Margo Lane.

For a show that depended heavily on formula, THE SHADOW was nothing if not diverse in its array of storylines. Few lawmen or vigilantes in history had to deal with such infinite varieties of villainy as did poor Lamont Cranston and his trusty sidekick Margo Lane: from ruthless foreign spies to home-grown gangsters, from psychopathic murderers to mad scientists, the invisible detective tackled 'em all, and in "The Leopard Strikes" our heroes are tested once more by crooks that think -- and kill -- outside the box.The story begins with two beat cops patrolling a park near the city zoo. When one of them is killed by what appears to be a huge animal, suspicion naturally falls on Rebu, a huge leopard maintained by the zoo. One of the keepers agrees with Commissioner Weston's conclusion that the big cat must be responsible, but Rebu's keeper violently denies this. The disagreement, and several subsequent murders, make Crantson wonder if there isn't more to this case than an escape-prone leopard, and as The Shadow he begins an investigation which takes him from the zoo into the midst of a bizarre animal cult that may...or may not...be responsible for the grisly killings.This episode is a good if not riveting listen, and I hesitated as to whether I should give it three or four stars, because it's fast-paced and entertaining. I settled for three because despite an interesting premise, the story itself is a bit too linear to be really gripping, there are several glaring plot holes, and I found the Shadow's attitude toward the feelings of the keeper whose favorite animal dies during the story to be rather callous. On the other hand, it's noteworthy that in this story, The Shadow actually kills someone deliberately, an event I think unique in all 220+ surviving episodes, and for that reason alone it's probably worth a listen."The Leopard Strikes" was originally broadcast on January 5, 1941 and stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow.

Before I go any further let me start by saying that the meager three stars I've bestowed on QUINCY, M.E. is based on a sliding scale. In other words, I only rate the first two seasons as "okay" because I know just how good the show became when it finally hit full stride in its third. This two-season package is well worth owning, and is in fact a must-have for fans (or aspiring fans) of the series.Having gotten that out of the way...welcome to QUINCY, M.E., one of the most enjoyable and influential television shows in the history of the boob tube. This is the story of Dr. Quincy -- no first name ever given! -- a crusty, hot-tempered, do-gooding Los Angeles County medical examiner (Jack Klugman) who uses forensic science to unravel mysteries which leave his cop friends Lieutenant Monohan (Garry Walberg) and Sergeant Brill (Joe Roman), and his paper-pushing fop of a boss, Dr. Asten (John S. Ragin) scratching their respective heads. Of course when Quincy is not solving murder mysteries he is taking up a lance for every public-spirited cause you can possibly think of, from child abuse to teenage drug use to illegal immigration to punk rock music and beyond. Can't fight City Hall? Quincy treats City Hall like a rock-'em-sock-'em robot!Of course, in so doing, he aggravates absolutely everyone, from murderers, who try to kill him, to big corporations, who try to muzzle him, to his girlfriends (he has thousands), who try to leave him, to his long-suffering assistant Sam Fujiyama (Robert Ito) and best friend Danny Tovo (Val Bisoglio) who just try to put up with him. Half the fun of QUINCY is seeing the enraged or baffled expressions of everyone who crosses his path. Imagine a fiery liberal muckraker with a medical degree and a nose (a BIG nose) for mysteries and a taste for the ladies, and you've got this show in a nutshell.Now, it must be said that the first "season" of QUINCY is not a "season" in the understood sense of the word. When the show originally debuted in 1976 it was intended to be a "movie of the week", not a regular series, and in fact the first seven episodes in this 17 episode package are just that -- TV movies of about 75 minutes. Beginning with episode 8, the format changes drastically: the show goes to an normal hour length, and most of the episodes are shot on sets or back lots rather than expensive locations. Quincy's steady girlfriend is given the soap opera "unperson" treatment and a revolving door of suspiciously young, hot women take her place. Finally, the "strictly mystery" approach is replaced by alternation between regular mystery stories (in which Quincy uses forensics to solve a crime) and "causes" -- battles in the public interest which Quincy (and presumably the writers and producers of the show) felt were worth fighting. Each element, in 1977, was unique to television; nobody had ever done a show about forensic pathology and nobody had ever done a prime-time network drama with a social conscience. Combining the two made TV history...and I guarantee will make your day.Some of the better episodes include "Hot Ice, Cold Hearts", "Snake Eyes", "The Thighbone's Connected to the Kneebone", "Let Me Light The Way" and "Visitors In Paradise." However, it must be reiterated here that Seasons 1 & 2 of QUINCY are primitive in several ways. First...this show was shot before DNA, before computer simulations, before the Internet, cell phones, and just about every other damn invention except fire. So a lot of what seems revolutionary to our protagonist will seem like ancient history to the viewer, especially the younger viewer ("DUDE...nice station wagon!") Second, the show, particularly when "causes" get embraced, is cheesy and heavy-handed, albeit in a charming way: there is more than a hint of "ABC After School Special" morality being dispensed here, and some will find it too much to swallow. But when you balance this with the superb performance of Jack Klugman, who plays every scene with lusty relish, the engaging storylines chock-a-block with famous character actors from shows like M*A*S*H, BATTLESTAR GALACTICA and STAR TREK, and the wonderful nostalgia element of 1970s fashions, it's hard not to give a thumbs up. I still maintain that the show didn't really reach a gallop until Season Three, when the budget increased, the background characters like Sam and Asten got more play, and everything just generally came together: but every story has to start somewhere, and for a modest price you can ride along with the ill-tempered angel on his very first missions. It's not a bad deal, believe me.

"Oracle of Death" is an overlooked episode of THE SHADOW. While not classic or even great, it's an entertaining and enjoyable story with several very clever plot gimmicks and is well worth a listen.The story begins with a car accident; submoronic cab driver Shreevie has accidentally run down a pedestrian while carrying Lamont and Margo home after a dinner date with Chief Weston. The couple obligingly takes the pedestrian, who calls himself Spud, into Lamont's apartment, and when he recovers, Spud claims that he is twenty-four hours "ahead" of everyone else. As proof, he points out that in his yesterday (which is their today), the Continental Bank was robbed. Lamont, erring on the side of caution, phones Weston and tells him to send some cops to protect the bank; Weston replies that it's too late -- the bank was robbed only minutes before. This is the first of several eerily accurate predictions Spud makes, the last two of which are that a series of bombs will rock the city's East Side "tomorrow"...and that Lamont Cranston will be murdered..."today." Now Lamont, or rather The Shadow, has only hours to determine how to foil the prophecies and determine just how -- and more importantly, why -- Spud is able to predict the future.I realize that this story sounds somewhat ridiculous, but it actually works surprisingly well. From the opening banter between Lamont, Margo and Weston to the addition of Cranston's ex-convict butler Roland to the storyline, "Oracle of Death" makes a sustained effort to rise above convention and provide a fresh angle for the invisible detective and his audience. It's not a nail-biter, but it shows a little more of Lamont Crantson than we usually get to see (pardon the pun) -- including one who is unusually ruffled by his impending doom."Oracle of Death" was originally broadcast on October 20, 1940 and stars Bill Johnstone as The Shadow.

I got a jar of this for free through the Amazon Vine program and thought I'd check it out. Why? Because, damn it, the hair on the back of my head is thinning and who the hell wants to walk into the grocery store and see a big reflective spot on one's dome as he walks beneath the security camera? No this decaying middle-aged specimen. In fact, when I got this I was already using Fixplant, which I'd found more than adequate if not spectacular. So, here is my verdict on the experience I had with this product, which I think may be semi-valuable as I have something to compare it to:This stuff is not bad. It does the job in question, which is to thicken the hair you have. It differs from Fixplant in that the filler is very fine and less clingy, so that you lose more during application to the scalp. Probably because of this it requires more to achieve the same effect, which is why the bottle didn't last nearly as long as one of Fixplant. I found it slightly more resilient, however, i.e. it seemed to last longer before a new application was needed. And lIke Fixplant it washes out immediately when you shower. I had some issue with the coloring not matching the description -- "dark brown/black" actually looked a lot like medium brown to me.All in all I can't say I think this product is better that Fixplant, though whether it is worse is a matter of opinion. (I don't think quality control on FP is all that good). However if you use it in tandem it actually achieves a better effect than either would alone. I would definitely use it again if the price was right.

I've said it before and I'll say it again: 1948 was an excellent year for THE SHADOW -- maybe the best the show had in its 17 year run on the air -- and the fact that "The House That Death Built" is not the best produced that year serves as proof of that fact. It's an outstanding half-hour that blends mystery, suspense and terror into a near-perfect formula.The story begins at night during a snowstorm, with a gang of hoodlums digging up the grave of old Ben Falkenberg, a former prison guard who took a fortune in bribes to help a death row inmate escape years ago. Cut to Lamont Crantson and Margo Lane, who are seeking refuge from the storm in Falkenberg's decaying old house, conveniently located deep in the middle of nowhere. There they encounter both the gang, which is ripping the place apart in hopes of finding Falkenberg's stash of illicit cash, and a mysterious woman with a hidden agenda. Unfortunately for all parties, the dear departed Falkenberg (evidently both a miser and a homicidal maniac) has turned the house into a death trap, rigging the rooms and hallways with enough pitfalls, ambushes and lethal devices to fill an Egyptian tomb. Between the trigger-happy gangsters, the mystery woman and the traps, The Shadow will have his hands full just keeping alive, much less proving to all involved that "crime does not pay."This episode has a lot going for it: it moves swiftly, throws out dense layers of characters and numerous plot-twists -- on top of everything else, one of the gangsters is not what he appears to be -- and continually attacks the audience by attacking the characters with double-crossings and fatal and near-fatal ambushes. What's more, it's remarkably prescient: 60-odd years before the SAW films made a horror sub-genre out of sticking gangs of characters into houses loaded with murderous traps, the writers of THE SHADOW delivered the same kind of creepy premise -- without all the gore and bad acting."The House That Death Built" was originally broadcast on January 25, 1948 and stars Bret Morrison as The Shadow.

I'm going to write a proper review of this movie when I have the cast information etc. in front of me. For now let me just say this: based on what the other reviewers have written it seems clear to me that everyone has been fooled into believing this is some kind of Nazi-themed "Chained Heat" lesbo-style prison flick. Nothing could be further from the truth. This is a serious film -- albeit with an idiotic title -- about the Lebensborn program initiated by Heinrich Himmler during the Second World War. Himmler, head of the SS, grew worried that the war was killing off large numbers of healthy young German men before they could have children. To combat this problem he created a program by which racially pedigreed German soldiers with no kids (serving at the front) would be taken out of the line and mated with women judged to have equal racial value. This program provides the basis for the plot of the movie, which in brief is this:A Luftwaffe pilot who voiced strong anti-Nazi views in a moment of drunken rage is sent to the rear to be court-martialed. With him is the man who denounced him, a fellow pilot and staunch Nazi. En route their car is ambushed by partisans. The Nazi is killed, and our hero, realizing that the Nazi was headed for Lebensborn to "mate" with some blue-eyed Aryan princess, decides to switch identities. He arrives at the love-nest compound but immediately falls under the suspicion of the beautiful but ice-cold "house mother," who seems to be a committed Nazi herself. In the mean time, conflicts arise when the law of natural physical attraction imposes itself over the desires of the SS scientists, who seek to mate the men and women based on "racial compatibility" and not whether they actually want each other. (As Jeff Goldblum says in JURASSIC PARK: "Nature will find a way.")I don't want to repeat myself, but this is not -- repeat NOT -- some kind of soft-porn flick in a Nazi uniform. It's a serious film, starring serious actors (I grant you the female actors are smoking hot) that highlights at once the absurdity of Nazi racial ideology and the fanatic and dangerous seriousness with which they pursed it. Although it's not a great movie, and the subtitles will turn off some people, it is of interest for fans of foreign films, WW2 buffs and anyone with a taste for (very) unconventional love stories.

Decent range, nice sound, good bass, lightweight.Pairs instantly with my mobile phone.Not the most adjustable headset. Just fits my big head.The quality of the construction is like that of a toy. Too bad it's not foldable.Doesn't pair with my PC. Needs drivers. My PC is unable to find them. Not available anywhere I check either. Don't know if it's my PC or not. The deptch, clarity and maturity of her voice are well-matched to the emotional, introspective tunes that support it. She's really something special.

One size *doesn't* fit all. These things seem tailor-made for a very specific ear & they're not too forgiving of others. Hurts to wear them. As for sound, even after adjusting for price, they are not so good. The earbuds that come with the most basic of mobile phones are superior to this device. Rubber-budded earbuds create a seal that improves base. This little contraption is bassless. However, if I can endure the pain, they do stay on my ear whilst running. They seem to resist water and sweat just fine as well.Even at $13, these might be overpriced. Two stars is generous.

The attention to detail in the packaging is impressive - from the leather-smelling, fluted box top, to the inside packaging. Nice presentation. Invicta paid close attention to the small details.The watch has some heft to it; it's quite large and solid. Feels very well-made. There's little point in my repeating the features that are mentioned on this page, but the directions provided are simple and thorough, so set-up was forthright, simple and quick. I'm so accustomed to doing research to operate everything these days, so the simple procedure was a pleasure.The contrasting colors make it easy to read at a glance in sun light on in dim light. The stainless steel material makes this watch a good fit for casual or more dressed occasions.What more can I say? I always try to give discerning reviews, but I've no cons as of yet. If I do so, I will amend my review. Until then, I am enjoying this beautiful, well-made, easy to operate timepiece from Invicta. I'm very pleased with it. At only $100 or so, you'd be a fool to pass it up.

Handsome watch & comfortable to wear. However, it's not the most functional watch in that it's simply too difficult to read. In sunlight, too much glimmer. In dim light, simply hard to make out what's what.The clasp on the watch is a bit of a science project. I'm an Android user, so I know a bit about science projects, but I really don't want to have to take a class to put on my watch.The hard-to-read, but stylized watch and the fancy clasp make this more of a decorative than functional time piece. It's a real looker and a bit on a conversation piece. So, it's not a day-to-day watch, but definitely something I wear when I'm dressed up a bit.

Much better than Brita. The filter fits securely so you are sure no water is seeping through. Definitely makes a difference in the taste of my water.Cons? These filter replacement indicators are pointless. It has no idea how much water the filter has filtered. It never comes in contact with the filtered water to judge how well the filter is still working. It doesn't indicate anything. I reset it when I first used it. If I fill the pitcher to the brim and close the lid, it will blink "Good"... I don't know how this sealed plastic can tell the quality of the filter by telling me the unfiltered water is good. It's supposed to measure the time you've used the filter... but not how much water it has filtered, which is more important.I just don't get how these types of indicators are becoming the standard. They're confusing. They don't measure how much the filter has actually filtered so how do they know when it should be changed?  They only light up when you fill the container to the brim. It's the most unintuitive, inaccurate measure of a filter's effectiveness. Either the FILTERED water should pass over a sensor or the sensor should be connected to the actual filter, but sealed in plastic and only indicating "good" if I over-fill the tub and close the flap is senseless. How is this ineffective, unintiutive, glitchy system becoming the norm? I thought it was just my Brita.

The good? I love that Brita made a hand-held filter of this size.The ill-fitting components don't ensure that all water is filtered. It's such a simple contraption. You'd think that, with all the experience Brita has in this department, they'd have the basics down by now.The filter indicator light has no idea the quality of the water or quantity of water I've used. I has no idea the status of the filter. It's sealed in plastic and takes a stab in the dark as to how much water I've filled the device with when it tilts up and down.The filter tub cannot be removed. Condensation builds up in a pitcher that can never be cleaned. Potential mold health hazard.This is not some complicated piece of machinery. I mean, Honda can build a whole car and it runs well for years. In situations like this, I can't help but wonder why companies don't just use their own product. If they try it at home, they'd know the filter doesn't quite fit and the indicator doesn't indicate a thing. They'd see the condensation build up. Car-makers don't just throw a car together and hope for the best. They test it.  Brita can't even engineer a plastic filter pitcher... after all these years?Maybe I got some Chinese knock-off.

Instead of repeating what it can do, I'll offer my my personal experience with Mecca.It's a real conversation piece, both ways. I volunteer at a convalescent home. I brought Mecca along with me. These seniors had a blast. It really seems futuristic to them. Hell, my mobile phone seems futuristic to them. So, this is not just some kid's toy. It's not just something for boys. Everyone seems to love it.No matter who comes over my house, they all want me to turn it on. Once I give them a demo, they can't stop playing with it. Really... like, well past dinner time. They won't leave! ...They're still here.Although building Mecca is a chore, approach it as you would a train set or model airplane. Not something you sit down and complete in a day. It's something you build and work on over time. If you approach the task that way, building it will be sort of a project and accomplishment. One that will be well rewarded. There are over 1000 pieces to assemble, but everything is so well organized. Meccano really took their time to make things as straightforward as possible.This thing's just got personality. The responses and vocabulary surpasses my expectations, not to mention Mecca's ability to learn. Between the numerous configurations and phrases and movements, I nearly lost my whole day playing with it. ...and the next day as well. I couldn't wait to get home to it.  ...I'm missing it right now.If you see me in a 12 step program for this thing, say hello. You aren't alone. Stay strong!

Quite an elegant, comfortable and nicely constructed timepiece. The nice, but simple packaging speak to the attention to detail. The only caveat is that the watch is quite large, both in diameter and in thickness. The "rose gold" (or bronze) color has already drawn a few compliments.I'd stopped wearing watches for a while & relied on my mobile phone. I love the idea of wearing a classic-looking watch again. Well done.

(UPDATE:  These pills & the bottle smell like bug spray. I mean, they smell like an actual can of bug spray. I get the smell of bug spray whenever I put these in my mouth. I know. Sounds crazy. Doesn't happen with anything else I take, yet it happens every time I take one of these pills. I can only imagine what that means. For the record, Garden of Life does make organic probiotics. It's not my house or my fingers or my breath, because it only happens when I take this supplement... and I get that smell/taste every single time. I first thought it was my imagination or just some other lingering odor from elsewhere. Several pills and weeks later, it's still like a can of Raid. So, I stopped taking these pills. This is kind of serious, but I'm hoping my bottle is the exception to the rule)Before you buy those popular Pearls probiotics, have a look at the strains & colony forming units. With 15 strains per capsule, 50 billion CFUs per capsule and 30 pills per bottle, the going price is a steal. You can surely find cheaper options, but you won't find them of the same quality or potency.Garden of Life makes superior supplements. I've used them many times. This product is no exception. Unlike probiotics of yore, these are constructed in such a way to resist normal temperatures which makes them easy to travel with.Probiotics restore beneficial bacteria killed off by antibiotics (pesticides, GMOs, who know what else?). Even if you haven't taken antibiotics directly, our meats in the US are chock full of antibiotics fed to the animals. So, if you eat meat, you're constantly killing some of your gut flora bacteria. The higher the CFU and strains, the more likely you are to replenish what you've lost.As for the benefits of probiotics in general, they depend on how your digestion issue manifests itself. Some folks have gas. Some have acid reflux. Some may have bone or teeth issues because they're unable to digest & absorb a specific nutrient. What you suffer from depends on which of the billions of bacteria you are missing. In my case, after taking probiotics, my skin becomes extremely smooth which suggests that it improves my liver... or is it kidneys? One of the two. This is something I've noticed after using probiotics many times. Interestingly enough, drinking fresh lemon water three times a day has the same effect. Probiotics may also reduce allergic reactions to foods because you now have the proper bacteria to digest it. For my father, that means he has a lot less mucus after eating wheat when lays down.As Once Daily doesn't need refrigeration, it is easy to travel with. The strains and CFUs make it quite potent. The price is reasonable. For these reasons, I love and recommend Garden of Life Once Daily Men's Probiotics.

Although there are 3 card slots, each of the slots can hold 2 cards and the case will still shutIt's very slim line so, even though the AM7 is a large phone, the case doesn't add much bulkAll cut-outs and buttons are exactly where they should beThe fingerprint scanner is still useable.The leather is more matte than shiny. Very tasteful, understated caseYou simply can't beat the price. Then again, it's just cardboard covered in thin leather.The vendor, Fettion, is from China and says to expect a minimum of delivery time of one month. Much to my surprise, mine showed up in 12 days.This is a wallet replacement. There aren't many wallet cases available for the Huawei Ascend Mate 7. This is one of the more attractive and better built ones.The price is an absolute steal. The shipping time from China is very impressive.Two concerns: Because the AM7 is so big, they made the case & claps very slim. I just hope it holds up over time. I usually remove my phones from their wallet case when I'm home, but, removing my phone from this is like pulling teeth. It's actually ridiculously difficult. I was tempted to give it only 4 stars because of this. At the end of the day, the case is doing what it's supposed to do - keep the AM7 safe & not allowing it to pop out. Well, it certainly won't be leaving this case any time soon. I nearly scratched my phone and cracked the case trying to unleash my phone. So, just wrap yourself around the fact that you might never see that silvery matte back finish again.

Exceptionally high-quality hedge trimmer. I have a great deal of hedges at my place. The Dewalt chews up and spits out everything I throw at it with ease. The battery lasted with energy to spare. No smelly gas. No cords tethering me to an outlet. Sharp blades. Built to last. There's not much else one needs in a trimmer.It may be a bit pricey if you just have a couple of hedges, but if your place is Hedge Heaven like mine, then Dewalt's DCHT860M1 will be your Heavenly Father.I've used others, but, for all have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God.This will not be my last Dewalt product. Thank you.

Hot damn! This is one helluva bag. I won't bother to parrot what's abundantly clear, but I will make a suggestion.(UPDATE: Of course a bag this size does not qualify as carry-on. However, if you wish to carry-on 70-ish liters, you might consider buying a 40-45 liter backpack (Osprey Farpoint 40, Tortuga, Pacsafe, Kelty). Most airlines allow for one personal item. I used my 22 liters laptop bag and strapped it onto my front. I was able to pack 67 liters as carry on. ...or you can buy this 70-liter back, bring pretty much the same amount of stuff, but find yourself waiting in baggage claim or paying fees for checked luggage. Another option is to buy Outlander's 30 liters packable daypack. )Just after I ordered this bag, I did a trial run to see how much I could get into a carry-on sized bag. (Shoes, sandals, 3 pants, shorts, 4 tops, jacket, underwear, laptop, toiletries, even my hair clippers)Guess what? Everything I needed fit into a carry-on sized bag.I'm not one of those obnoxious, "I traveled throughout Asia for 90 years with only a 5 liter backpack" types but, unless you need to carry large pieces of equipment for work or you're traveling with kids, it might behoove you to pack a lot less into a smaller bag for more than bragging rights. Here's why...1. Save money on baggage check. Checking bags can cost $50 each way. (to put that in perspective, the cost of a flight from Mumbai to Delhi... 2 round trips from Bangkok to Chiang Mai... 2 round trip bus tickets between LA and San Francisco... 5 days in a decent cheap motel in Thailand or India.)  If you're hopping about the globe, then you could easily save $200.2. Save time at airport. Baggage claim can add an hour onto your travel on each end. The two hours you spend waiting could be spent on a round trip flight from LA to San Francisco.3. Your carry-on is a lot less likely to get lost or damaged, or be picked through.4. Even if you're on the road for a year, you really don't need an outfit for every day of the week.5. Less weight to carry around is never a bad thing. You can always carry a foldable daypack for side trips at your destination.(for foldable daypack, search for "Outlander Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Backpack Daypack+Lifetime Warranty")What's more is that you can still get Osprey quality, warranty and beauty if you opt for the carry-on-sized Osprey Farpoint 40.As much as I love the looks, quality and function of this bag, it's just too big. That's not a bad thing, however. It's just not for me. I'm guessing that if you're a frequent traveler who purchases this bag, you may come to this realization on your own eventually.... after paying for baggage claim.. waiting in baggage claim... damage or theft to your checked bag... the extra bulk.The only strike is that there's no excuse for a modern-day bag not to have hip pockets for easy access to passport, money, keys, lip balm, mobile phones. It should be standard these days, really. That said, the hip belt is so strong & the suspension so finely-tuned that it's responsible for most of the bag's weight being transferred to your waist instead of shoulders. Well done. It almost improves your posture.If you're sold on Osprey for its looks, lifetime warranty and truly superior suspension, consider the Farpoint 40. (There is a Farpoint 55 but, even without the 15oz daypack, the frame of the 55 is too big for carry on.) However, if you want an additional 4 liters of space, but still a quality carry-on bag, try the Tortuga backpack. It carries 1 gallon more of stuff; it has substantial hip pockets for easy access to keys, passports, money & phone; it has larger, more accessible side pockets which aren't cut-off by compression straps (as the Osprey 40's is). Tortuga is very well made and its focus a little more on travelers than backpackers. They don't really advertise, so it has sort of a cult following amongst digital nomads. Tortuga is a purely functional bag, though.  That is to say, she ain't pretty.If you need or simply want more of the comforts of home with you, or if you need to carry lots of equipment, then you surely can't go wrong with this pack. Pacsafe makes a 65 liter pack, but it has no detachable daypack. I still need some things with me when I'm onboard an aircraft, so I'd end up carrying a second back if I used the Pacsafe. I prefer Osrprey's built-in daypack with bottle holders. The Farpoint 70 is the only large bag I would consider. Osprey should really include hip pockets on all packs, though.

I wanted as much space as possible w/o having to check my bags. I wanted quality and versatility. I wanted a good suspension that places the weight on my waist, not my shoulders. Along came the Farpoint 40. I fell in love with this bag... then I found another option.Some folks say a 40oz bag is only good for a few weeks. Truth be told, it's good for a year+. You really don't need an outfit for every day of the week. Unless you need to carry around lots of equipment for work or you need to keep items for children, you're better off keeping it simple & carrying less for a number of reasons.Checking baggage can cost $50 each way. (That will pay for a side trip somewhere.) Checked baggage is more likely to get lost. Checked baggage is more likely to get damaged. Checked baggage can add an hour to your travel time. (An hour that could've been used taking a side trip.)You really can get by with a full-size carry-on. Don't believe me? Do a trial run for yourself. Try packing one of those roll-along, squared, wheeled carry-on bags that's in your closet. If you roll your items tightly (and/or use packing cubes) & avoid all of those "just in cases," you'll find that 40 is sufficient. Most folks find that they really don't need that spare suit or ballroom dress. You don't really need those boots or four pair of shoes. In the event you need something particular on the road, buy it then.So, why the 40 over the 55? Some folks think that, if they simply remove the 15L daypack from the 55 bag, it will be carry-on-worthy like the 40. That is not true. The very frame of the 55 is too large for carry on.Daypacks do come in handy, when you want to make a side trip to the beach. If this sounds like you, there are well-rated,  *foldable* daypacks to be had on Amazon for $20, some of them with up to 30 liters of space. When you don't need it, you can fold it and pack it or push it into one of the mesh pockets or put it under the compression strap, so it won't take up more space.As well-made, versatile and handsome as the Farpoint 40 is, sometimes you pick up an extra item along the way and need just a little more space, but you still want the bag to fit as a carry on. Sometimes you wish you had hip pockets for easy access to your keys, passports, money, cards and mobile phone. Sometimes you wish you had easy-to-reach side pockets that aren't cut-off by compression straps.If this is you, you might consider the Tortuga backpack. It's squared-off corners provide 4 more liters (1 gallon) of additional space within the dimensions of a carry-on. The 2 hip pockets are convenient and generous. The side pockets are easier to reach. Tortuga does not advertise. It's sort of an "insider's" bag with some digital nomads. (Features and convenience niche.)Minaal also makes a carry on backpack, but it has only 35 liters of space. Great for absolute minimalists, or those who simply don't need 40+ liters of space. The nail in the coffin for me is that Minaal doesn't offer a good waist belt, so the bulk of the pack's weight rests on your shoulders. Packs with good waist belts transfer more of the weight to your hips. Minaal is the most conservative-looking bag and comes with briefcase-like pockets which makes it great for business use. (Minimalist niche & professional niche.)Pacsafe offers a 45 liter carry-on backpack as well. It's also bigger than Farpoint 40, but it doesn't have the convenient hip pockets that the Tortuga has. It does, however, offer a wire mesh made into the bag to prevent slashing and tearing, as well as a steel locking cord, RFID blocker & many other safety features. (Security niche.)Kelty offers the Redwing 44. (They also have a 50 which doesn't quite meet carry-on dimensions, but I've seen them on a number of flights.) The suspension system is excellent & probably better suited to those who wear their packs for longer periods. It can accommodate a water bladder as well. However, There is no built-in cover for the suspension. Should you need to put the bag below on a bus, the zippers are not lockable. There are no hip pockets either. It's more affordable than the others and it better suited to longer treks. (Affordable & longer treks niche)Although I must disqualify the Minaal for not having a hip belt, you really can't go wrong with the Farpoint 40, Tortuga, Pacsafe or Kelty. They each have their own niche. Osprey is the most well-known of the quality backpacks, so many buy them having never heard of other options. So... here you are.Your call.

No CD to download... No website to visit or join... Nothing to "calibrate"... No "community" to join... Didn't ask for my email... Didn't ask me to send feedback...  Doesn't require research to get up & running... Doesn't interfere with my existing bluetooth connections... Doesn't need any instructions... No complicated packaging...  No pop ups... No "reminders" of its presence...Just plug & go. Simple as that. However, as long as the mouse is 'on,' my computer won't go to sleep. I have to put the mouse sleep if anybody else plans on getting any. This is probably why the battery lasts so long, though.  <--- I see what ya did there, TeckNet.I'm so tired of self-important tech and apps. I'm tired of having to download or register just to use a toenail clipper these days.TeckNet's mouse is just an affordable, nicely featured mouse that starts working in seconds and doesn't stop for 18 months. Doesn't get any better than that.  It shuts the hell up and does its job like tech used to doWhat a relief!
