That's why I got Swan. That's why I'll always use Swan.Point blank. End of story. That's all she wrote. Thanks for coming. Best

The amount of storage + transfer speed + water proof + temperature proof + X-Ray proof + magnetic proof + reasonable price = The absolute best memory card on the market.I store 1000s of songs and a number of HD videos on the card. Everything plays smoothly and downloads quickly with my Huawei Ascend Mate 7.This is the only type of memory card I will ever buy.

(Update below)PROS1. Most modern Android flagships have 3gb of RAM and quad core processors. The Mate 7 has 2gb of RAM, but comes w/an octacore processor. A processor is not the same as RAM memory, but it does use the RAM differently which seems to level the playing field. I'm a multi-tasker. At any given time, I have at least a spare .7gb of RAM. Plenty for safe, smooth operation, as well a bit of future-proofing.Huawei was smart to keep the screen resolution at 1080p. QuadHD pixels aren't noticeable to the human eye, they take up a lot more battery power & they require more memory to operate. Huawei's choice of 1080p, 8 cores & large battery is a much more efficient combination. Huawei does offer a 3gb version of the AM7, but that model doesn't work with USA LTE frequencies, and costs $800.2. Unlike iPhone, you needn't wake the phone up to activate the fingerprint reader. However, you do have to pick the phone up to do so. Unlike Samsung, you needn't wake phone up, then swipe repeatedly. Simply touch and it awakens. It's very responsive, but takes a couple of tries first thing in the morning, when it's cold. Although you must pick it up, you can program the device to lock only after you click the side button, but to stay unlocked for 30mins when the screen fades to black on its own. You can store two fingerprints profiles. One for you and another, limited-access profile (for example), for someone who needs to make a call.3. AM7 has dual sim slots for two phone numbers. Their profiles can be activated with different fingerprints. So, you can have your personal and business line in one phone. If you travel overseas, you can rent a local sim but still receive and make calls with your home number. However, if you plan to use dual sim regularly, you cannot use a memory card. The memory card resides in a sim slot.4. AM7 will work on AT&T as well as T-Mobile, however, MMS will not work on T-Mobile, unless you're using WiFi. I don't know if it works on AT&T. In the end, this all depends on which LTE band T-Mobile uses in your area and reception at any particular point. This is a GSM device so neither Sprint nor Verizon are supported,but you can take it overseas and swap SIM cards.  It supports LTE frequencies for China, Germany, Spain and many other countries. It supports Cat6 LTE-A which hasn't yet come to the US, but contributes to making the phone future proof.5. This phone has the largest battery in the business. End of story. The Kirin processor isn't as power hungry as the latest two Snapdragon processors running in the competition. LG's new G Flex 2, for example, has the latest Snapdragon processor & 3gb of RAM. It's prone to overheating so it has a mechanism which slows the processor down, rendering the speed irrelevant. (YouTube channel "PocketNow" has a video demonstrating this) Huawei's Kirin processor is more efficient. It runs incredibly cool and isn't as taxing on the battery. When you combine that with the largest battery in the business, you're left with a device that lasts two full days. I play videos, shoot HD videos, use widgets, etc... and it still last two full days.... with +/-18% battery remaining when I go to bed. I don't need a car charger or battery pack. I've left home w/ 50% charge and made it to be w/o charging or having to monitor curtail usage. I'm not even slightly exaggerating.6. Speaking of the battery, Mate 7 offers reverse charging. You can actually charge other folks' mobile devices (or your tablet or smartwatch) from the AM7. With a battery twice the size of most, you can surely afford to be so generous. It requires a special cord, though. (Huawei Reverse Charge Cable - $10)7. The camera functions well in low light. The front-facing camera lets in a surprisingly good amount of light in dim situations. Like other Chinese phone, the front-facing camera has "beauty mode" which noticeably smooths creases in your skin, makes you yellow, and makes your eyes look alien. (WTF?). In regular mode, it takes flattering selfies as it adjusts very quickly to light and dark subjects8. In The States, you'll be the only one of your friends to have one. It's bigger than the Note and the iPhone 6 Plus, plus it is made of far better materials and has smaller bezels.9. Huawei's Emotion user interface is lighter than Samsung's TouchWiz. There is not much lag or stutter. Because it's an Android, M7 is far more customizable than any iPhone, plus you can have scrolling widgets. I even use an old version of aDownloader which allows me to download movies and current TV shows quickly and for free. iPhone is a Lexus - smooth, silky, slick & high-end. It should be smooth, it's only capable of driving on surface streets. Flagship Androids are like multifunctional Range Rovers - high-end, but a little rougher around the edges because of that capable off-road suspension. They just do so much more, though not always so silky. Tradeoffs. Not so much better or worse. Different philosophies for different types of users.OTHER INFOQuick pics: If the screen has already gone black & you want to take an instant photo w/o waking the phone or swiping a lock screen and then snapping the shot, tap the volume-down key twice and a photo will be taken instantly. That doesn't simply open the camera app. Your second tap actually takes a photo.Screenshots: You can pull the notification bar down, then swipe to shortcuts, or you can press 'power' and volume-down keys simultaneously.CONS1. For the inexperienced user, there are too many built in alerts that might make one paranoid. Alerts of an app using 4mah of battery life (that's minimal & most don't know what that means)... an alert that a power-hungry app is open, even though you have RAM and battery life to spare. It's all about optimizing performance, but it's too obtrusive, scientific & unnecessary. It's like having a car that goes 200mph, but you get a warning at 100mph, then at 110, yet another at 120. Yeah...no. That's one of the first things I (thought I) disabled. That's one thing I like about iPhones. I don't wanna know all of that, just handle it. You have a to be techie to get the most out of an Android. With an iPhone, if something is using up too much memory, iPhone closes it, no fanfare. Androids will either tell you to do it, or slow down & stutter until it finally gives in and does it for you. The thing is, the apps Mate 7 constantly warns you about are far from taxing the phone. Which brings me to my next point.2. If you're new to Android, you'll find it is still a bit of a science project.  For example, my previous device was a Galaxy which comes w/a lot of unwanted bloat apps you can't remove. When I updated my M7, it automatically downloaded all my apps from Google Play.... including the unwanted Samsung/T-Mobile bloat apps. :-/ On top of that, the average person wouldn't have a clue as to how much their Android can truly do. That said, any American who knows about the Mate 7 is not the average smartphone user.3. Another peeve is that WiFi has been known to disconnect after the screen is locked for a while. Knowing Android, there's probably some mislabeled setting (buried so deeply that I'll never be able to find twice) which disables this... or offers a timer... or a time of day that it does this. You get the idea. ***Too much customization on silly stuff.*** Perhaps it's another superfluous, unnecessary power-saving trick. This phone has more power-saving tricks than any phone I've used and yet it has a battery twice the size of most. There are so many settings on high-end Androids that, when you stumble upon a setting to change something you didn't know could be changed, you'll most likely forget how you found it. Textbook Android. Soooo textbook Android.4. Huawei complicates Android further by putting a "Protected Apps" function. This doesn't hide or lock apps. It "protects" apps from being closed when the screen goes off. To monitor what runs in the background is one thing, but "when the screen is off" is a bit vague.  It's hard to know what should and should not be open. It indicates that a vital Google Android app uses too much power and should be disallowed. That Google app runs Android operating system! Note to Huawei: Android is convoluted enough w/o poorly worded,obtrusive monitoring apps. An alert told me WhatsApp was using too much power & to close it, so I did so. I didn't know it would prevent the app from alerting me. But there's also a "Notification Manager" which is apparently overridden by Protected Apps. Then there's a "Dropzone". WTF?  The way Protected Apps is executed doesn't work as a monitor of background apps because it disables the app's functionality. Background apps aren't a function of a screen being on or off. Stopping an app should not disable alerts. Notification manager clashes w/ Protected. To this day I don't usually get my WhatsApp messages. An absolute unnecessary mess. I really hate this because this something Huawei added to this phone. It was on purpose.  I just want my phone to manage power and apps. I don't want to have to take a class or do research. Folks who are used to iPhones might think twice. As one who has used Android since 2011, I despise this feature. It's important enough to give me a few regrets.5. The earbuds that come with the M7 are for the birds. Too big for my ears, hard, poor sound.  Everything else is so tactile and high-end. I threw mine in the trash.6. As this a Chinese phone, the unit is shipped with a plug converter for American consumers. Unfortunately, the prongs are too small for American outlets, so I find myself pushing a chair against the charger so it stays in the wall. Adapters are not some strange, rare thing. This isn't acceptable for a flagship phone.7. Samsung's 2013 Galaxy just got Lollipop. As of March 2015, Huawei has said nothing of Lollipop or it's coming for AM7. That's not acceptable for a flagship device that was released only months ago.One more thing, if you're looking to root the M7, Huawei doesn't offer an unlock for the bootloader. There are a couple of bogus videos out there that say otherwise, though. Fortunately, Huawei doesn't load the M7 with as much bloat as *some* companies. As you're not buying this from a carrier, you won't have additional T-Mobile or AT&T bloat, but there's still some. I don't know why they must have any. iPhones don't.LET'S WRAP THIS UPIn summary, what makes the Ascend Mate 7 great and so unique is... 6" screen... well-executed fingerprint scanner... gargantuan battery that charges other batteries... optimized processor and user interface... dual SIM... 8 core processor... tiny bezels & high-quality metal body... Cat 6 LTE-A... unlocked to be used by multiple carriers... you'll be the only one of your friends to have one.I've read complaints that it's too big. It's a frickin phablet, for crying out loud. Would you buy a sedan then complain that it has too many doors? Why would you buy a sports car, then say that it's too fast?AM7 is a well-spec'd device for a seasoned Android user. However, the incessant, confusing warnings of RAM and battery usage, along with misleading "protected apps" could make this phone a paranoid nightmare for someone who is new to Android. It would seem to require more babysitting that it truly needs. Huawei manages to make Android more confusing by making these alerts the default. Not to mention constant update messages for theme pictures you don't even use. Twice a week, I get alerts (that I cannot turn off) about picture updates for themes. For the sake of Android newbies, and even my annoyance, I'm going to have take back a star & leave the Ascend Mate 7 with 4 stars... a generous 4 stars, mind you.In the end, I compared the OnePlus One, Note 4, LG G3 & even the iPhone 6 Plus. I settled on the Huawei Ascend Mate 7, not because it's perfect, not simply because it's the best value, but because it's the best combination of features & efficient engineering... along with some imperfections that one could easily find by spending time w/any other device. The Mate 7 seems to be the best overall package for me, even down to the meticulous packaging & attention to detail. From software to hardware, it's really a quality device. If this will be your first Android, however, I'd steer you in another direction without question.UPDATE - Late May 2015I've used smartphones since Symbian of 2003. I've used Android since 2011. I've had this phone for nearly 3 months now. Between the Notification Manager, Protected Apps, Drop Zones, constant intrusive alerts about picture updates for themes, constant alerts about apps that are barely using any power, constant alerts about system apps that are supposed to be running - I'm finding the AM7 annoying and undependable. Protected Apps disables notifications... even though there is a separate Notification Manager. Notification manager gives options to Allow or Notify which makes little sense. If you try to swipe away certain types of notifications w/o reading or listening to them, AM7 will "cause exception to the application sending it" and you will no longer get any alerts from that app. So, you have to read every message from certain apps to remove it from notification bar. You can't just swipe them away for later w/o the phone telling that app to never alert you again, but this is Android so defaults don't always stick anyhow. For the life of me, how did this make sense to any engineer? ...."Drop zones" What the hell is that? I'm tired of having to do so much research & study for Androids.  .... I still get warnings of apps using minimal energy and RAM even when I'm not multitasking & there's RAM to spare. ....Like many Androids, the calendar alarm only rings once, briefly. If you miss it, you miss your appointment reminder. Eventually I aligned it with Google Now, but defaults don't dependably stick (with most Androids I've owned).  All of the defaults I choose for gallery and browser disappear when I restart the device. This was the same for all of my Androids. What else? Like every Android I've ever owned, album artwork for my music is completely worthless. The call log, doesn't indicate if the logged number was ingoing or outgoing.  I mean, the list goes on and on. I configured a guest profile, using a second fingerprint. I chose to lock certain widgets. I tried it out & it worked. When I signed back on as owner, the widgets were gone. I had to re-customize and sign in again. I lost all of the pending information on my sticky note widget.  Almost done. ...The phone has no app drawer/tray. So, your homescreens will be crowded with countless folders. Either that, or you'll have need 5 screens to accommodate them, and AM7's homescreens don't loop. So, I had to download a launcher just to reduce the number of & clean up my homescreens. So much work and research. Not user-friendly. Not intuitive.I'll put up with quirks for customization, but this is a bit much. I need dependability and consistency - the basics - over tricks and dual sim cards and style. If all you've ever had is Androids, then you have nothing to compare. You've no idea how much more consistent, "common-sensical" an OS & phone can run.As much as I like about this device, I do regret buying it and would not recommend it, even to a seasoned Android user. Too much work and research and inconsistencies. It is, w/o question, the most annoying phone I've ever had, and I'm used to Android quirks. I've been using smartphones since the Nokia's original 6600 in 2004 & their N-Series in 2007. Way too many alerts. Way too much babysitting. Way too many inconsistencies. ......***Way too many convoluted (contradicting, overlapping, superfluous) settings.*** It is a parody of Android stereotypes.As you can see, I've gone from liking it a lot, to really disliking this phone. If it wasn't for the specs and build, I would give it 2 stars. My review is based on actual usage, not initial impressions. It's based on having experience with other Android devices, as well as iPhones & Nokias. My review is not based on a list of specs, some YouTube review or "wanting my phone to be the best," as i suspect many are. I gave it the benefit of the doubt and have been as discerning as I can be. It's an insult to not give a flagship phone, from only months ago, the latest Android Lollipop. It's already behind the curve.The stats, performance and build are indeed supreme in every way. It's a really elegant, tasteful device. It feels *far* more expensive than the Note 4 & the iPhone 6 Plus. This is the first Android device I've used where an app has (literally) *never* crashed... not once. The phone has never locked-up or froze... not once. (Must be those 8 cores.) Unlike the more popular Snapdragon processors, Huawei's Kirin never gets hot. The 8 cores & Kirin processor are very efficient. The phone doesn't need all of the managements built into it. The Ascend Mate 7 is truly smooth & fluid in it's operation, without even a single hiccup. If only Huawei could've just left it alone and stopped trying to do so much. The last thing Android needs is more complications and settings.After all is said & done, I do not recommend this phone to anyone

I never thought I'd like a hose so much. It's disarmingly light and small for a 50-foot hose. (I needed a dolly and a mule for my last one.) So easy to transport and a small footprint when coiled. As it's lead-free and doesn't have that toxic smell, I have no guilt quenching my dog's thirst with it. It never twists up on me. It's just a light, durable, well-made, quality  hose.

The keyboard folds back flat. That is the star of the show, for me. When I'm done w/the keyboard, I barely know it's there. It doesn't add much bulk or weight, yet I can get the job done more quickly than on the touchscreen and just as accurately as on my MacBook.The case is well-made, nicely stylized and offers good protection.If you're in the market for a keyboard case, this is the one you need.

I know. It's a cardinal sin not to like Converse All Stars. I just don't like the ubiquitous, "bubble gums," but I wanted a sneaker I could wear everything from shorts to casual, sporty, summer suits. I didn't want some bright shiny neon thing, but I didn't want something as low key as Ralph Lauren Polo canvas shoes either.Enter Adidas Samba Classics. A timeless, versatile shoe, without the hipster or preppy connotations of Chucks or Ralphs. Unlike the 'updated' Samba Originals, the Classics don't squeak.My only complaint is the arch support. It is huge. I have a mild arch and it's just too much. The shoe is so narrow and arch so prominent that I feel bound, even when I tried a larger size. If you need/want humongous arch support, you should know that the only reason I deducted a star is because of it. Arch supports are fine, but I don't need to walk on Annapurna, for Christ's sake.Other than that, these shoes are a winner. I'm going to need a pair in white. ...I can just feel it. Maybe the Milleniums don't have such a prominent arch.

The selling points: Very easy to set up... adjustable handles for those wider bodies... goes underneath the toilet seat so you can still close it... sturdy enough to support heavier folks.... installs very securely.FYI: Your toilet seat must have removable screws. Their must be loops in your toilet seat where you can insert the much longer screw that comes with this product & connects it to the commode. I had to purchase a new toilet seat with removable bolts to use this. I just bought a new toilet seat a month ago. I had to shell out another $30 for another decent seat just so I could use this product. Minor inconvenience, but added expense. There should be an obvious warning in the description.The function of the seat is 5 stars. That it can only be used on certain seats is why I give it four.

This is a budget vacuum. Even at that, the price is too high. Even budget vacuums have hepa filters these days.The best part of the vacuum is the telescopic wand. It's the only piece that feels well-made.After puting everything together, I began vacuuming, only to have the thing cut off/on on its own. So, I checked the plug, the brushes, the fit of the canister, the angle with which I held the handle. It seems to have a mind of its own. At one point, I just stood there, holding the handle & listened to it turn on and off at random. I then plugged my old vacuum in the same outlet. Had no problems. Tried it again a few days later, and it seems to stay on. Let's hope it doesn't change its mind again.The canister is tiny, so you'll be emptying it often. When you have a bagless vacuum, the minute you go to empty it, all of the crap your vacuum sucked up is released into the air anyhow. Eureka suggests you "shake the dust" from a foam filter (What's the point of having a filter?), then rinse filter, screen and canister. By the time you're done shaking dust, everything that filter filtered is now on you, in your hair or in your lungs. What's the point of having a filter if you're just gonna handle and inhale it later?The build is very flimsy (even the handle). The tools routinely fall off. Fresh out of the box, the vacuum stuttered a few times. The canister is too small. I'm not about to shake a filter & have all that it filtered released into the air. A vacuum priced at $200 should have a hepa filter.For the same price, you can get a Bissell Healthy Home with a better build quality, bigger canister & a hepa filter.'Tis a good thing they reduced the price from $200 to $140. Of course that just tells you how grossly overpriced this machine was. Don't you hate it when companies knowingly overprice a cheap device? Another strike.I'd give it one star, but it does pick up dirt (when it finally decides to stay on). The telescopic wand is very well made. It's lightweight. ...but it's still certainly below average. So, two stars.

I love it. It's the size of a 4"-screen Galaxy so it fits into your (other) pocket very easily. The best part is that it charges my device 3+ times and does so as quickly as a wall socket. The matte finish and soft carrying case are the cherries on top. I love attention to detail. Real winner.

I have dark skin which shows dryness very easily. For most manufacturers, the answer is to make a greasy product, or a thicker substance. Somehow, without the density or greasiness of some lotions, Jack Black has managed to engineer a light, but effective cream to keep me moisturized. It doesn't leave my shiny or feeling coated. Just moisturized.The scent is light & pleasant. Maybe a tad on the feminine side, but nothing overbearing.

We brush, floss, have modern dentistry, eat organic foods... and our teeth still don't looks as good as fossils or as good as folks living in tribes. Most of us have cavities, root canals, bridges, etc. That's because even mass-produced organic food is still grown in mineral-depleted soils. Herein lies the need for this product.The combination of D & magnesium with calcium saves money & time as both D and magnesium aid in the absorption of calcium.What's more, D3 is the most bioavailable form of D. Unfortunately, many folks are told their D is low but no one tells them that D3 is what they need.If you're concerned about the health of your teeth and bones, this would be the product to purchase. If you have a diet that is more acidic than alkaline, I'd recommend this product. If, like most of us, you're eating food grown in mineral-depleted soil, you really do need this supplement. You might also add a "trace minerals" supplement.Not only is it the right combination of the right strain of minerals, the product is organic & plant-based, so it's free of pesticides & useful for vegetarians & vegans as well.Garden of Life makes excellent products - high-strain probiotics & organic supplements like this which include absorption minerals.Well done.

Let's be honest, folks. This is candy, first & foremost. Corn syrup & sugar are the first two ingredients. So, whilst it may draw the kids closer, make sure they brush just a little bit better. Aside from that, this is a decent, mild probiotic. Depending on your bacterial flora, you may have different responses to probiotics. For me, my skin becomes very smooth. They say your skin is a reflection of your liver health. Whatever the case, smooth skin is good, so I'm happy with the product.

Forget that laser printer. Someone is finally serving up an inkjet properly. I won't bother parroting the stats above but, in terms of actual usage, the machine does everything well, with speed and quality. Incredibly easy to set-up. Solid, well-made work horse. Perfect for a small office.My biggest beef with most printers is having to buy ink every other day. If a printer is perfect in every other way, but I find myself constantly shopping for ink, I will hate it. Not a problem w/ the 4640. The cartridges are large and ink management is optimal.Printing from a mobile device is easy to set up either via local wifi, or sending a file from your mobile (anywhere in the world) to your printer's email address. It works for Android & iOS. Works much better than Canon's system.I use the 4640 for my small business office. Epson also offers a WF-4630 which I use for my home office. The only difference is the 4640 has a larger touch screen & can hold 580 sheets of paper. The 4630 holds only 330 sheets. $100 extra for this 4640 is pretty steep but the additional paper storage comes in handy if many folks are using the machine throughout the day.This is the first time I've been completely satisfied with how long ink lasts, quality of print & printer, speed & ease of use on one printer. If any issues arise, I'll edit this review. 'Til then, when you factor in the long list of features with my review, you'll understand why I say Epson hit the ball out of the park.

Forget that laser printer. Someone is finally serving up an inkjet properly. I won't bother parroting the stats above but, in terms of actual usage, the machine does everything well, with speed and quality. Incredibly easy to set-up. Solid, well-made work horse. Perfect for a small office.My biggest beef with most printers is having to buy ink every other day. If a printer is perfect in every other way, but I find myself constantly shopping for ink, I will hate it. Not a problem w/ the 4630. The cartridges are large and ink management is optimal.Printing from a mobile device is easy to set up either via local WiFi, or sending a file from your mobile (anywhere in the world) to your printer's email address. It works for Android, Apple and more. Works much better than Canon's system.Epson also offers a 4640 model for an additional $100. For that extra cost, you get a larger touch screen & a printer that holds 580 sheets of paper instead of the 4630's 330 sheets. I'm not sure those features warrant spending an additional $100.This is the first time I've been completely satisfied with how long ink lasts, quality or print & printer, speed & ease of use on one printer. If any issues arise, I'll edit this review. 'Til then, when you factor in the long list of features with my review, you'll understand why I say Epson hit the ball out of the park.
Really a complete kit. I use it on my waverunner & motorhome. Has everything I need & works well. I would definitely purchase again.

I've been using the Ambit2 for a month. My partner got his Garmin Fenix 2 a few weeks prior. Here are some differences.If you want a shorthand comparison, Garmin's Fenix 2 is like a high-end Android. Suunto's Ambit2 is like an iPhone. This pretty much sums up the differences, but read on for specifics.The Garmin has more features than the Suunto - vibrating alerts, receives text messages, virtual partner, edit profiles on device, connects to Android & iPhone. Unfortunately, Fenix 2 doesn't have the best software. The system can be glitchy and unstable. The user interface is not very responsive, has a bit of a lag.The Suunto has fewer features than the Garmin, but what it does, it does really well. It's very well-executed. The screen responds instantly. The GPS locks on notably faster than the Garmin every time. In place of Virtual Partner, vibrates & text messages, Suunto has quality upgrades like frequent updates, 10-second & 1-minute GPS pings which saves battery life. It's also waterproofed to 100m (Garmin is 50m). You can download apps. So, you never know what your Ambit2 might be able to do down the road.If you want a lot of tricks & customization, the Garmin will deliver. If music is important to you, Fenix 2's vibrating alerts make it your guy. ...but at the expense of reliability and a stable platform. You never know when these features will or will not be working properly. Fenix is sort of like an Android phone - lots of tricks, but not very consistent. We thought this dependability problem might just be a lemon issue, but we've since read similar complaints about Fenix 2. **To be fair, Fenix 2 does work most of the time.** Really, it's not a bad watch. I'm no fanboy. (I wish I did have vibrating alerts & Bluetooth.) It's just temperamental, unpredictable & the UI lags a bit.If you want a very capable, versatile, quality device that is always up-to-date and can grow with apps, with a dependable & well-executed user interface, then go with the Suunto.  However, the Ambit2 will have you tied to your computer and WiFi to edit profiles. It will not connect to your Android or iPhone because it doesn't use Bluetooth. You can't listen to music because there's no vibrating alert. Real issues to consider.They both have their pluses & minuses. 'The best' depends on your taste. I chose Ambit2 because there's nothing worse than running 20 miles or so, only to have your watch stop working or lose your info, even if that only happens twice a month or so. What good are bells & whistles if the basic functions of the unit are unpredictable? I'm also quite fond of the frequent updates and downloadable apps for the Suunto. It keeps the device relevant and future-proof.There's a bit of snob appeal, too. Suunto is sort of the Vitamix to the Garmin's Blendtec... The Audi to Garmin's BMW... The Osprey to Garmin's North Face. ;-)If you're considering either of these two devices, keep in mind that Polar has just released the V800. Pretty awesome stats, so you might wish to compare the three before making your purchase.In the end, Ambit2 does a lot, does it well & is always up-to-date. I just feels more 'professional'. It's the best overall package for me.

Perfect for a dorm room, too. It's not too pricey and bluetooth works well. However, the sound is just okay.  Folks over 15 will probably want a more premium sound. I've heard better sounding speakers for close to the same price. This is best suited to a kid 15 and under. The cool lights will amuse them & they're probably too young to discern quality sound. $25 is the absolute most I'd pay for this item.  I'd never pay the original $80 asking price

I'm a 6', 200lb man. I figured this soft Pedi-Rock wouldn't do much for my well-worn feet. So, I scrubbed like a man should... and nearly tore my foot up. This thing is no joke. It does the job on my crusty feet w/o the extra elbow grease. ...but I'm still a man, damnit!One thing, though. Black specks do come off here & there. No bueno.

Finally, a printer with only 2 cartridges to buy.. and the cartridges are big enough to last. In this day in age, that's 4 stars right there.Printing from mobile devices or from out-of-town isn't as easy to set up or as well-executed as Espson's system. The apps and system for printing from a mobile just aren't up to par.Once you install new ink, there are too many unnecessary options: Nozzle check, cleaning, deep cleaning, head align, roller cleaning, bottom cleaning. WTF? My old printer lasted for ages & didn't have all of these superfluous, needless, confusing settings. Note to Canon: Visit Apple in Silicon Valley. They have a lot to teach you about the value of simplicity.Neither of these gripes are major deals. The printer is quick, quiet, dependable. I don't get harassed with a million updates or spam. The ink lasts forever (Be careful with refilled cartridges because these cartridges have microchips that tell the printer when ink is low. Refilled cartridges will still send a signal of low ink, so you'll have to press & hold 'start' for 5 seconds to print).I'm very happy with this machine.UPDATE: So, I changed my ink. There are a million setting for aligning, cleaning, etc. Even after changing settings between 'normal,' 'scaled,' & borderless, I cannot get this printer to honor a bottom margin. It prints right to the bottom of the page, no matter the setting. It even splits photos and text. This pretty much renders the machine useless for business use, and even non-business as photos are split on two pages.

I like low-profile, slim-line, casual flip-flops, but I also like them sturdy & comfortable enough to traipse around an urban city in. Enter Havaianas' Power Flip Flop. Well-cushioned & slightly contoured to make for a comfortable sandal, but not some big, honking leather thing. You might think there's not much that can differentiate a flip flop, but it's the type of padding used in this sandal that makes all the difference, especially for a 200-pound man.My only warning is that these run quite large. You can easily get a size smaller & both the base and the straps will fit well. I had to exchange my larger ones because I felt like a platypus walking about. Get a size smaller, for sure.I love these flip flops. They're casual and summery, but still comfortable and sturdy.

This is a pretty anemic probiotic supplement, especially for the price.45 pills3 billion colony forming units per pill6 strains per pill$22Garden of Life RAW Probiotics90 pills85 billion colony forming units per pill31 strains per pill$30I've used both. Garden of Life is a more complete & affordable supplement.

Deodorant: Instead of rubbing God-knows-what chemicals under my arms everyday, I use this simple compound.Toothpaste: Instead of rubbing fluoride and God-knows-what chemicals into my gums, I use this simple, alkaline product. Read your toothpaste label. I'll bet it suggests you only use the product for a limited time. So, you change to a different toothpaste, right? Well, that one has the same harmful ingredient.Body wash: You got it. I mix baking soda w/glycerine & sometimes egg (for delivery). The slight abrasiveness exfoliates. It also deodorizes. No drying lauryls or suds. My skin doesn't need lotion when I'm done because it wasn't stripped. It was cleaned. Sometimes I do apply coconut oil, though.Mouthwash: Seeing as bad breath comes mostly from within, gargling w/mouthwash won't alleviate most bad breath. So, before I go on a date, I put a teaspoon in hot water and drink it down.Laundry: You bet. It's cheaper. It gets out stainsCleaning: Toilets, sinks, rugs, cement, etc. Mix it with water and spray on sofas to freshen them up.At the end of the day, most of us smell like toothpaste chemicals, soap chemicals, lotion chemicals, shampoo chemicals, detergent chemicals, deodorant chemicals. The skin absorbs what we put on it. That's how patches work. Take inventory of all of these chemicals in all of these products you use daily. That's what you're putting in your body daily.... then wondering why you have this ailment or migraines or some other unexplained condition.Instead of absorbing 100 chemicals into my body every day... Instead of spending all of this money on separate cleaners for this that & the other.... Instead of smelling like roses and mint and musk and summer breeze all rolled up together - I smell like a clean human. I smell fresh, not like some manufactured scent from a factory.My point? Well, if you haven't figured it out, I like to keep it clean, simple & healthy. You don't need most of the individual products you waste so much money on. You're simply paying to fill your body with harmful chemicals that have no business on our skin.Baking soda is one of the most versatile & useful products and it's incredibly affordable and healthy to use. Arm & Hammer is a trusted brand and, if you used baking soda like I do, 5 & 10 pound bags are the way to go.

$24 and the first two ingredients are sugars? This is *mostly* sugar. More on that later.D3 helps our bodies absorb calcium. Many of us aren't getting enough sun. We're either stuck in offices or we're kids staring at electronics instead of playing outdoors. Taking a Calcium/D3 supplement will surely help with bones, teeth and overall health.That said, as with most multi-supplements, Sundown doesn't use the most bioavailable type of calcium. That would be calcium orotate, but I'm sure something is getting through.My main issue is that the first ingredient in this supplement is SUGAR. The label claims it supports teeth health.  ...Yeah-NO! Calcium does, sure, but when the *first* ingredient is sugar, what you have is candy. Primarily, this supplement supports tooth decay because it is mostly sugar.America's obsession with sweetness has to stop. Everything doesn't have to taste good. If you're taking these for healthy teeth, you're shooting yourself in the foot as it is mostly sugar.What's most obscene is the price. When the first two ingredients are sugars, you have no business charging $20.

This supplement has 90 pills w/ 5 billion CFUs (colony forming units) & 6 probiotic strains each. Cost - $23Garden of Life RAW Probiotics also have 90 pills, but with **85 billion** CFUs & 32 probiotic strains each. Cost - $28See where I'm going with this?This is an anemic & overpriced probiotic. It has more CFUs than Pearls, but, seeing as I don't know which bacteria of my flora is damaged, I'd rather have a supplement with more strength and strains than Pearls' & Nutrigold's, especially for close to the same price.A minor side note - The huge, self-important packaging is ridiculous. It doesn't make me feel like I'm getting quality. It just seems wasteful.Message to Nutrigold: Look at what the competition offers for close to the same price. Either step-up your game or lower your price because there is a huge difference in your 5 billion colony forming units & Garden of Life's 85 billion. I'm calling you out.

I've been lifting weights since 1994. I've had the occasional shoulder joint pain that would go away. A few months ago I pulled, twisted, or otherwise injured my shoulder yet again. This time, the pain refused to dissipate. It had set-up camp and was in for the long run. I couldn't even sleep on my elbow in bed.So, I enlisted the help of GC. Within a week, the pain had gone.My only complaint is that I wish there was a concentrated supplement so I wouldn't have to take 4 large pills daily.I only hope that the pain stays away & I don't have to keep taking these.In the end, it's a great supplement that works... if you don't mind taking 4 pills per day. For all I know, that might be the norm with GC, though.

It's a multivitamin and, like most, it's hard to tell if it's doing anything. The thing about multivitamins is they rarely use the most bioavailable forms of the vitamins they use. For example, you can buy a calcium orotate, magnesium citrate or D3 supplement, but most multivitamins, Vita-Mini included, don't use these bioavailable types of vitamins/minerals.As multivitamins go, Vita-Mini is... okay. Two issues, though. It's not the most potent supplement by a long shot. A bigger issue is the soy. Why must *everything* in the American diet contain GMO soy or corn... even our health foods & supplements? "Let's add some unnecessary GMOs for (God knows what real reasons). This wasn't always the case. So, for that weak dosage and intentionally adding soy & corn, 3 stars... and that's generous.

Very tasteful & versatile case. Soft inside w/o the bulk of thick cushioning. Simple and slim-lined yet protective.Some complain that the case covers the charger. This is only a minor annoyance to me.I recommend it, but there are more affordable options.

This potent & reasonably-priced product is delivered in oil. D3 is best absorbed in fat, so, in one way, this is a good thing. The downside is that, instead of using organic olive oil as some other brands do, Vita-Mini uses soybean oil & corn oil, some of the most genetically-modified and pesticide-laden oils there are. It also has other unnecessary additives like coloring.If you're D-deficient, you'll need to take D3, not D. You'll also need 50,000-70,000 IU per week for 8 weeks (look it up). If you're overweight, have diabetes or take meds which deplete your D, you should take the larger dosage. This high dosage is great for those who are deficient and it's also convenient for those who are simply trying to sustain and don't want to have to take it daily.I've seen improvements in my health. It's reasonably priced. It's delivered in oil. However, there are other similarly-priced options that use organic olive oil & have no coloring additives, so I'll have to give this supplement 4 stars for charging that same whist using cheaper, unhealthy oils.

D3 is best absorbed in oil. Not only does Nutrigold use oil, it uses organic olive oil. Many other supplements use GMO corn or soybean oil, if they use oil at all. So, for absorption & overall health, this is a supreme supplement.Nutrigold offers a 1,000 IU supplement which is great for maintenance. For those with a serious vitamin deficiency, you need to take 50,000 - 70,000 IU per week, for 8 weeks. 70,000 is for the overweight, diabetic or those whose D is lowered from meds. Herein lies the reason for the range in potency of D3. The 1000 IU dosage is excellent for maintenance for those who don't get much sun.I was taking a drug that is known to tax D supply in the body. Most folks are okay, but I don't get much sun either, so I started to have bone issues. Not good for a runner. Now, I'm able to take the drug w/o any issues at all. I've also witnessed an improvement in my dental health.Other than that, the pills are tiny and easy to swallow. The average person will need no more than 7,000 IU per weeks, so this is more than a year's supply of top-quality D3, even if you take 50,000 IU per week for two monthsNutrigold is just a good, quality D3. I appreciate that it's delivered in oil and they made the effort to put it in organic olive oil. Health products should be healthy, not surrounded in GMO soybean and corn oil. .

Perfect for my work-outs. Now I can set my mobile down, instead of strapping the big sucker to my arm or trying to keep it in my pocket.Very easy to set-up and use.Small & well-madeEasy to switch to phone callsHold volume keys to skip tracksThe option to clip-on or wear around my neck is a nifty, functional option.Holds a charge wellThe sound is mediocre. Fortunately, you can replace them with your own ear phones/buds.Overall, a nice product.

What a quality product - attention to detail, well padded, spacious & versatile... with a small footprint.Unlike offerings from Targus or Swiss Gear, the Case Logic has padding & insulation more akin to what you'd find on an Osprey backpack. Everything from the shoulder straps to the back which allows for a bit of air flow between your back and the pack.If I need to tow a change of clothes for the day or overnight, I don't want to have to lug two bags just to have my laptop. This bag will fit my laptop and even a change of clothes & shoes. I've used it on day trips, hiking, overnighters.There's a safety pouch on the back where you can stow valuables like your passport, instead of carrying them in an outer pocket.The two zipping pockets on the side also have a mesh catch so you can stow your water bottles within easy reach, or zip up items you need easy access to. They thought of everything.There's a large, sturdy loop at the bottom of the bag for jackets or wet gear....and of course the pockets. So many pockets of differing sizes. Easy access, hidden, expandable.Like any other computer bag, it holds your laptop. However, Case Logic added design elements that make this a wonderful bag for overnight trips, day trips or hiking - the extra padding, zipping water bottle side pockets, space provided between your back and the bag, external loop, variety & flexibility of pockets and the light weight.You get a lot flexibility, quality & space for your money, in a small footprint. I love this bag.

My initial review was singing the praises of this features-packed, reasonably-priced device. It delivered on it's promise... for a while.After using the watch only four times, it fails to charge. It discharges very quickly in the first place. Just sitting on my desk, GPS off, it lasts only one week. Whilst out of town, I let the watch completely discharge. The screen was completely off. Upon plugging in the charger, I received, "Built in Self Test... Charger Fail!"Seriously? I've had 2 Garmins, a Runtastic, a Motorola and a Polar. I've never had an issue like this, particularly after only 3 months.  In spite of being totally discharged, when I unplug it, the screen still reads, "Charger Fail!" just to spite me.If you read other reviews, or simply search, "Times Run Trainer 2 charger fail," you'll find this is a common issue.You can put exotic woods, leather, diamonds & pearls on a Ford Pinto... it's still a Ford Pinto. If a Rolls Royce lasts only 3 months, it's cheap piece of junk. This... is a cheap piece of junk.I even contacted customer service. The info & file they gave me just reset the phone, but didn't provide the firmware update I needed to keep this from happening again.It's a Timex, for crying out loud. If Garmin, Polar & Runtastic can make reliable watches, wouldn't you think Timex would have it down by now?Conclusion: Great for those who only wish to work-out for 3 months. Trash for everyone else.I'm off to toss the piece of crap in the trash. Don't waste your money.

One part social commentary, one part politics, one part religion. Marry it to groovy, chill beats & haunting riffs. You'll find Greydon Square's mesmerizing, "Summer's Ending".If music w/a message isn't your thing, the groovy track & Greydon's soulful voice offer a smokey, late night, introspective feel that's real easy to move to as well.

Though very touching and nicely photographed, this kid is no different than the *millions* of other kids who grew up tribally & went on to pursue school in The West. There are millions of tribal kids who grow up communicating with animals just as their parents and parents' parents did. She's not special. Her story is not unique.All of those photos of her with tribal *men* beg the question, "Weren't those men once *boys*  in Namibia?" Don't these men have their own kids who do the same? Of course they do.Sorry. Being white doesn't make her story any more special than that of the countless black tribal Africans who left their tribes & sought schooling in The West. It's neither groundbreaking nor any more "sweet".Furthermore, I'm not aware of many Bushmen who grew up with bottles, diapers, jellies & sneakers. For a girl who grew up so raw in "The Bush," she seems to have many Western trappings. A quick Google search will yield doubts about the authenticity of this story. 'Hoax' & 'Fake' come up right after her last name. The photos look like a professional photographer snapped a kid with some curiously tamed animals in posed settings. Wild animals don't pose. How many true Bushmen are professional photographers like her parents?She didn't 'grow up in The Bush,' fetching water from some far away source or lake. She had shoes, running water, a refrigerator & parents with jobs. I doubt her income-producing, French photographer parents were chucking spears at game for dinner, in spite of the posed, misleading photo with true bushmen in loincloths who actually do so. Seems very phony.If you want to see genuine photos of animals with folks who *actually* grew up in 'The Bush,' chucking spears & such, you'll probably get a more accurate photo by Googling it or looking on YouTube. You'll get a more genuine read from someone who is from these generational indigenous cultures, not someone posing with diapers, a spear & a bottle on tamed, posed animals. Her story, if even true, is nothing new.Simply put, this book is about Tippi's whiteness making her special. It somehow suggests that her story is unique or that she has special, unheard of insight & can relate to animals like no other. Tell that to that tribesman whose family has (really) been living that way (for generations) sans the sneakers, bottles, art direction, diapers, bank accounts, jobs, money & shoes. You think she grew up without a refrigerator? Actual Bush men don't have fridges. This is no Bush girl and you all know it.Consider the Editorial Review,... "A white child, she was born in Namibia". So, I'm not too far off base in that the book is a 'thing' simply because of her race.If you have a dog named Bella or Molly, drive a Prius/Subaru/Volvo or perhaps the type who says 'peace' all the time, you'll probably want to punish this review or read me the riot act (shored up with, 'Namaste,' of course... always), but race & Western trappings are really the only differences in Tippi and the millions of other children who were (truly) raised in The Bush, not by parents with jobs, incomes, running water, etc.Don't get me wrong, I find the photos touching and beautiful. That's surely reason enough to enjoy the book. It's just that I find the very premise insulting and the story rather questionable.

Instead of parroting what you've probably already gleaned, I'll focus on why/how I use this as a juicer; pricing; organics & Blendtec options. Although I'm a big fan, I try to be discerning & will includes some 'peeves' below.JUICINGAside from making nut butters, ice creams, hot/cold soups, flours & smoothies, the 5200 does a decent job juicing. If you use a base of watery veggies like cucumber or celery and blend half of the pitcher first, they will create enough liquid such that you needn't add much water. To give you an idea, I blended a full pitcher of only kale, adding only 1 1/2c of water. Once strained, the end result was 6 cups of liquid, 4 1/2 of which was pure kale juice.  This will vary depending on the vegetables. So, if you're on the fence as to whether you'll get a juicer or a blender but can't afford both, go w/ Vitamix because you can do both.Once blended, strain the smoothie through a 'nut milk bag' ($9) or an old pillow case/tee-shirt, if you're really pressed for cash; just squeeze it into a large bowl.  An Omega or a Breville juicer might be more ideal, but chances are you'll have a lot more to clean, take up more space & be out an additional $150+. So, if you're concerned with cost, space or ease of cleaning, the 5200 is a good alternative for juicing."Isn't fiber good for you? What's the point of juicing?" Although fiber is good for you, the air & fiber in smoothies is quite filling. I can only drink so much at a time. By juicing, I can ingest a greater concentration of minerals & enzymes, instead of so much air & fiber. If you have digestive issues, juicing is a sure way to make sure those nutrients get into your system. I do prefer smoothies for fruits as that fiber regulates the absorption of sugars. This is why I love the Vitamix. I can do juices as well as smoothies, butters, etc. If you look at it this way, the Vitamix is both convenient & affordable...ish.PULPOnce juiced, there's not much nutritional value in pulp fiber, but if you want to stretch your dollar, you can put the flavorless pulp to good use. You can use it as a flour-type base to bake with, make pizza with or throw into a dehydrator to make raw cookies, crackers or crust. I flattened & dried mine, added sesame seeds & spices, then baked them. Made some delicious, healthy crackers for the hummus I made the day before. Tons of recipes online. Try 'liferegenerator' on YouTube.WHY 5200 IN PARTICULAR?Unlike the cheaper 2-speed TurboBlend, the variable-speed 5200 allows me to blend at the exact speed I need for a salsa or hummus, for example. The 5200 has no presets, but I've noticed that the time I blend a smoothie depends on the amount & type of smoothie I'm making. There is no preset time that's best for all smoothies. I prefer to manipulate each dish. Most times you'll only blend for a minute or so, so I doubt you'll have time for laundry in between. Of all the variable-speed Vitamixes, this is the most affordable.COSTThis exact model is available at Costco (not online) for $375. Comes with nice recipe book & DVD. Save your money. Some Costcos only carry the 6300 which costs as much as Amazon's 5200, but comes w/presets. Costco's *online* offerings for the 5200 usually cost more than what is found in stores because they include a second pitcher.The only model I'd consider, other than the 5200, is the Professional 300 (aka Professional 7500, not to be confused with the more expensive 750 w/presets). It runs a bit more quietly, has a shorter carafe, wider blade & wider base so it blends more efficiently and is easier to clean and remove thick contents. If you prefer the next generation Pro 300, Vitamix has the refurbished model on offer w/a 5-year warranty for $399. Go to VM site & click 'Specials'. They only have so many available every month or so. They also have a $330 refurbished, variable speed model w/like warranty. Bottom line, you needn't pay over $400 for a good Vitamix.AFFORDING ORGANICS"May not be organic, but at least I'm ingesting more veggies." Mmmmm....Yeah-NO. Consider that, if you blend to increase your intake of vitamins, minerals & enzymes, but you're not using organic produce, you'll also be giving yourself direct, concentrated shots of harmful pesticides & other genetically modified material. Spinach is one of the more popular green juice/smoothie ingredients. Spinach, along w/ celery & apple, is some of the most sprayed & treated produce if not organic. (Do a Google image search for: dirty dozen organic). Pesticides are known to cause a host of neurological diseases, like Parkinson's... which my dad had.Don't fret. You don't have to break the bank as there are many options for organic produce than overpriced, gourmet Whole Foods, or those three items at your local store. Check local farmer's markets, warehouses, co-ops. Some online stores will deliver. I just got a 10lb bag of organic carrots for $5 & about 12 organic apples for $8 at Costco. If you're in So Cal, 'Better Life Organics' is a great place for a huge variety of goodies. Google 'organics' for your area. Don't be discouraged by the high prices and little variety at your local market. Of course, you can always start growing your own.BLENDTECThe shorter, wider carafe & wider blade create a better vortex to suck down ingredients of a full pitcher, particularly the Blendtec with Wildside jar. So, for making a full pitcher of smoothies, you're less likely to need a tamper. However, you simply need a tamper to make nut butters and ice creams. Blendtec doesn't have a tamper, so you must keep stopping, removing lid, stirring, replacing & restarting. Gets real old, real quick. (Search YouTube for "Blendtec Total Blender vs. Vitamix 5200, Part 3 of 5 - Peanut Butter"). Blendtec does offer a "Twister Jar," but it costs over $100 extra & it still doesn't work as well as the tamper. If you don't make nut butters or ice creams, then you might consider a Blendtec as you can use the same pitcher for dry blending. The 5200 *can* make flours from hard items like popcorn seeds, but VM suggests buying a separate jar to keep the blades sharp. (Blendtec uses blunt blades and more horsepower in regular pitcher whereas Vitamix uses sharper blades that might dull w/lots of hard/dry blending. Blendtecs are a bit louder, but they do fit under most cabinets. Blendtec looks more slick and pretty, w/animations and flat buttons. Vitamix looks more industrial and 'hardcore'. It looks like it means business. Vitamix has been around much longer than Blendtec & lots of raw vegans seem to prefer VM, so there's a bit of snob appeal for some. Make no mistake, you can't go wrong with either.CLOUDY PITCHERYes, you can easily clean your blender with a few drops of soap & switching it on high. However, if you wish to keep your pitcher from turning cloudy, I suggest using a soft sponge on it a couple of times per week. Most importantly, *dry it immediately*. Letting the blender drip-dry will cause clouding. It will also turn the black top grey.PEEVESThe tall, skinny carafe. If I'm blending a full load of a thick smoothie, the vortex created by the narrow jar doesn't always recycle the mixed contents at the top w/o a bit of prodding. Minor annoyance because it will ultimately blend it all if I blend half of the mixture first, then add the other. Here is where the Next Generation Vitamixes and the Blendtec's w/Wildside Jar excel. The wider blades, wider bottoms and shorter profiles recycle a full pitcher more quickly and efficiently. The 5200 will get the job done just fine, though, with a few extra pushes from the tamper stick. On the other hand, if your making nut butters, the narrow pitcher comes in handy.CONCLUSIONIn summary, you don't need a juicer & a blender to have it all. You needn't pony up extra cash for presets. The 5200 does everything you'll need. You needn't pay over $400 when Costco & Vitamix' site have reasonable options. Blendtec simply needs a tamper, costs more & is louder, but creates a better vortex, thanks to the shorter, wider profile carafe. Affordable organics are available if you look hard enough & buy in bulk. If you live alone, consider that my neighbor & I go in on bulk items together. Where there's a will...I've made dishes I've never thought of - Brazil nut milk... dandelion green juice (hardcore)... raw vegan pizza w/my pulp... mango/mint smoothies... coconut/almond yogurt... raw vegan cookies... pistachio ice cream. (Banana or coconut or avocado all work wonderfully for a creamy ice cream base.) All of these recipes take only minutes to make.In the end, the 5200 is the best price/value Vitamix. It will front as a blender & juicer. Vitamix is simply the best all-around blender for most uses, but don't spend over $400 when you don't have to. [YouTube: "Equipment Review: Best Blenders"]

Armed w/a robust mobile app & a new GPS heart rate monitor watch, Runtastic is serving up a well-made, nicely stylized sports band w/ key holder/money slot.My 4.5" Samsung fits perfectly. I can easily control side keys & volume rocker. Touch response through the plastic screen cover is good.I'm a muscular guy, but not huge & I find the adjustable armband to be too tight, even in its most generous position. When I get to pumping, I feel like I'm having my blood pressure taken. If the band was just an inch longer, Runtastic could rectify the situation & make this a one-size-fits-all like most others are. Unfortunately, you'll have to dole out an additional $6 for a longer armband. That's not acceptable when the competition doesn't require this. Muscular, larger & overweight folks won't get much use out of this which is too bad because I quite like it otherwise.Although the phone is well protected, you might find a bit of moisture has formed on the back of your phone when running longer distances in warmer weather. That seems to be par for the course with these sports bands, to be fair.Some folks seem to expect this product to fit all phones as well as any phone case. That's just ignorant. There are a million different case sizes in addition to the numerous different phone sizes. The tight armband & neoprene covering will surely protect your device, people.Overall, it's a good product, limited by its sizing. It's just not the best for muscular, larger or overweight folks. Taken together, that's a large swath of people. For that, I gotta take away a star. I'm not about to drop more money for something Runtastic should've provided in the first place.Other than that, kudos to Runtastic for a quality product.

Features-packed & very competitively priced GPS-HRM.If you're new to GPS & heart rate monitors, this is a great pick. Before investing in a $300 unit, I'd suggest this Runtastic. My sister dropped $300+ for a Garmin only to find that she doesn't like the scientific approach to running. She doesn't like concerning herself with numbers, graphs and tracking. She likes to freely run, not analyze graphs or keep checking her stats. You don't need one to train competitively. So, if you're unsure, I can't think of a better GPS-HRM watch than this one. Gives you what you need, but won't break the bank. That said, it's capable for more advanced runners, too.It has more goodies than a similarly-priced Garmin plus it has bike mounting, compass & better warranty. The quality is far superior to anything Polar has ever put out and it can easily front as a daily driver.Good quality & easy to read. The GPS locks quickly and is pretty accurate. The online site is decent. Not as robust as Garmin's offering w/o paying a fee. Not too keen on that, but if your a novice, you probably won't use all the bells & whistles for a while anyhow.Peeves? It only comes w/a USB charger, so you'll need a free or spare USB/plug converter if you're not near your computer. When I plugged it into my computer, there was some unnecessary drama in downloading a driver. I had to Google & search for it. Also, I wish there was a level indicator of charge strength, so I'll know if it's charged enough for a run. Finally, customer service is absolutely horrible. It's non-existant.Although my Garmin 410 has more goodies, I find the Garmin much easier to understand and operate. I thought I could just figure it out on the run, but I had to go home and read a bit before taking the Runtastic out. It's not as intuitive. I still haven't figured out why, after a random time & with no pre-programming, the watch beeps. Everything my Garmin does makes sense to me. Maybe it's just me. Unfortunately, customer service doesn't exist.Once you enroll on their site, your inbox will be BLOWN UP. I don't want a community or penpal. I want a GPS-HRM device. Leave... me... alone, Runtastic. I had to uncheck email options I never checked in the first place so that I wouldn't get 2 emails every day. ..but Runtastic continues to find new reasons to contact me & remind me of its presence.In the end, it's a great piece. I didn't expect such an impressive package for such a reasonable price. I do wish it was more intuitive, or at least it came w/good customer service. Runtastic is way too intrusive with emails. This, alone, has me using my other unit a lot more. ...and really makes me wanna give it 3 stars, but it's a nice, well-priced unit that works well, so a solid *4* for Runtastic's first GPS-HRM offering.

Sometimes, you just need the exacting flow of a keyboard, but the portability and ease of a tablet.Enter Microsoft's well-designed & features-packed 'Surface'. It's surprisingly easy to use and comes loaded with goodies.Instead of the usual screen of apps & images you'll find on most tablets & computers, Windows 8 is a portal for information. Although not quite as intuitive as Apple's offerings, with live personalized widgets, Windows 8 serves up more goodies and customization than its brethren.The compact keyboard manages to squeeze in a mouse pad & clickers, yet remains quite user-friendly. I had concerns the keyboard would be somewhat of a work around for my large hands. In fact, it's accurate & easy to navigate.Surface packs a snappy quad-core processor, complete Microsoft Office, HD webcam up front, second HD camera on back, Bluetooth 4.0, USB 3.0 port, 16 or 32gb of storage, plus a micro SD card slot. You simply won't find all of this on an iPad.It's relatively lightweight, has a small footprint & the swappable cover/keyboard comes in a rainbow of colors.With the functionality of a laptop & size of a tablet, Surface is the perfect travel companion. Definitely worth a look if you're in the market for a tablet, netbook or small laptop.

Unlike many inkjet printers that use 4 ink cartridges, the MX452 still uses the 2-cartridge ink system. The cartridges last much longer. You can have them refilled at Costco. You only need keep up with two.If you're considering a printer that does use 4 cartridges, keep in mind that many of them (like Epson WF2450) will not allow you to print anything if just one of the cartridges is low on ink. With 4 separate cartridges, one of them is almost always low.Although it allows for printing from a mobile device, I was unable to figure out how to do it with my Android. Epson's printers assign your printer an email address that allow you to print from your mobile anywhere in the world. Doesn't have all the bells & whistles, but, at this price, it's a great little printer and one of the best budget printers.This printer is fast for its price point. It's easy to set up & use. Works well. Great buy.

Truth be told, it's difficult to discern whether or not this product is actually 'facilitating the metabolism of carbs,' or 'transporting fatty acids into energy units' or 'preventing muscle atrophy'. Interestingly enough, all of it's many so-called benefits are not-so easy to gauge. This raises a red flag for me. I don't want to be one of those people taking 20 supplements I can feel nothing from "just in case" or because I'm told they do something I cannot notice. Folks will try to make money off of anything. I've felt no discernible results.However, after using this product, I became itchy all over, all day. I looked up *L-Cartinine itching* only to find that itching is a known side effect. Unfortunately, you won't know if you're allergic until you've purchased and partaken. This is not a reflection of Jarrow's supplement, but of L-Cartinine in general.I can't down-rate this product for my allergic reaction to the amino acid. I don't want to give the impression that it's only Jarrow's L-Cartinine that I find has no effect. Taken together, and considering the high price, I can't give it 5 stars either.If you're able to feel some notable difference from these pills *and* you're not allergic, I suppose you'd like them. Jarrow's is probably a good choice as I enjoy some of their other products. Just don't get caught up in every new trend, fad, or 'study' designed to make folks money. There are tons more supplements that promise the world, too. Ya gonna buy those, too? At $23 per bottle, I need to know it's doing something.

First off, D3 is delivered through fats. So, the added olive oil is a functional part of this product. Jarrow's D3 provides cholecalciferol D3 which is far more bio-available than ergocalciferol found in many D3 supplements. It also doesn't have the added Vitamin A or sheep lanolin that some supplements have. Per usual, Jarrow offers a quality product.Now, if you're Vitamin D deficient, you'll need to take 50,000-70,000 IU per week. That's right. Do your own research or ask a reputable doctor. You'll need to take this dosage for 8 weeks, then you can get away with 1 pill per day. Until then, you probably won't be putting much of a dent in your deficiency if you only take 1-2 pills per day.D

You'll love this printer for the first few weeks... until you start running out of ink... and you always seem to be running out of ink. Only then will you get it.Contrary to what it may seem, ink for this printer is *not* cheap. It's a racket. There are four ink cartridges you must buy. If Magenta, Cyan or Yellow runs low, the machine will not allow you to print in black (even if black is full). That's right. That black cartridge I just bought is off limits simply because magenta is almost out. It's a racket.With average use, the black cartridge doesn't even last one month. So, it's not as cheap as it seems and it's awfully inconvenient. You're forced to have all cartridges full at all times. In other words, you'll be buying ink every single month, sometimes twice a month. I'm constantly buying ink for this thing & lifting the hood.This printer is too obtrusive for wireless connections. It has more updates and reminds me of its presence more than I care to be reminded. I'm tired of self-important software, apps, etc. I like my printer to shut the hell up until I need it. I don't need it 'updating' every week. I don't wanna be a part of a community.I miss my old HP. I never heard from it unless I was about to use it. The ink cost more, but it lasted for months. When color ran low, I could still print in black. When black ran low, I had the option of printing in blue. When I use this Epson, I feel like I'm being taken advantage of.It's also a very wasteful printer. Print heads/nozzles in Epson printers are embedded in the printer. So if you don't print everyday, the system wastes ink to unclog the nozzles for a normal printout (without white lines). HP printers have empty spaces where cartridges with built in nozzles glide in. Every time these cartridges are replaced, it's like you get a new printer. HP cartridges cost more, but you get a lot more ink in the cartridge, use less ink for maintenance, and get better printouts.Although WF-2540 has some good reviews here, I'm guessing many of those come from folks who have only had it a short time or who rarely print anything.I'm now selling mine on Craigslist & buying an HP laserjet. All-In-One laserjets cost a bit more upfront, but they're more convenient to keep inked, cost less in the long run & are cheaper to operate.I would not purchase this printer. It is a scam.

Unlike North American Herb & Spice, Teliaoils oregano oil is not cut with anything. It's pure. It's the only one I've found that isn't cut with olive oil & is wild. This doesn't mean it's the best for you, however.If you're using this topically (to treat toenail fungus, for example), you can't beat this item for strength. (You really don't need to put anything mixed with olive oil on a fungus anyhow.)If you plan to ingest the oil, do not drop this undiluted product directly in your mouth. It's too strong. You will irritate your mucous membrane. If you put it in a capsule, your tender insides may burn. Your best best it to drop it into a teaspoon (or capsule) with coconut oil, or some other oil it can mix with so as not to irritate your insides. For this reason, it may not be the most convenient oral supplement.However, considering it's pure, wild, high-carvacol oregano oil *and* it's a fraction of the cost of less-potent North American Herb & Spice, it's a *much* better buy & worth the effort. The popular North American costs $34 for a less-potent mixture.As for oregano oil itself, here's my experience. My stomach flora was damaged from a few bouts of antibiotics. I had bloat, yeast overgrowth & sinus/fungal issues. Every review I read swore by oregano oil. So, I did my candida diet, oregano oil and probiotics. After 2 bottles of oregano oil, my stomach will only remain flat as long as I stay on candida diet. My sinus infection didn't change much. I finally dropped the oregano. Only after I bought a high-potency probiotic, did my sinus infection go away (and my vision improve) because I could better absorb nutrients.Sorry to have to say this but I just think oregano oil is "snake oil." It didn't do a thing for my fungal issues - sinus or toenail. Starving the fungus through diet & boosting my good bacteria with a decent probiotic (50 billion colony forming units & 12 strains) is proving more effective.If you think oregano oil works, however, Teliaoils has the most potent, affordable oregano oil around.

It's pretty much impossible to know if this product is doing anything worthwhile. We're told turmeric is good for inflammation. Curcumin is that ingredient in turmeric with all the powers. If you believe this to be so, then you will like this product. If you're having some serious issues, I suggest taking a *much* higher dosage than is suggested. Other than that, I use other Jarrow products. Their supplements are some of the best.

2:51 MinsAfter 4 bouts of antibiotics & nearly a year of horribleness, I've come to learn that nearly everything is connected to my gut. No matter how well I eat, if my digestion is off, my body is off. If too much of your good bacteria has been killed off (from antibiotic pills *or* meat which is stuffed with antibiotics), you might have a tough time fighting off certain ailments (like sinus conditions, rashes). Your digestive system may no longer be able to process nutrients or digest foods properly, so your skin, teeth, bowels, sinuses, mood can all be affected. You can call it IBS, candida, leaky gut, 'periodontal disease' or whatever. Those are all seemingly just the symptoms of poor digestion/absorption of nutrients.I've been all over the map trying figure out my bloated stomach, critical sinus condition & receding gums. Is it 'leaky gut,' candida, not enough good bacteria? Are my eye twitches and toenail fungus connected to this? Docs are clueless. They tried to prescribe more antibiotics for my sinuses & top it all off with Diflucan antifungal medicine. Ignorant.I tried P73 oregano oil. I tried Pearls Probiotics. I tried Candida diet.Only after severe problems did my docs even suggest probiotics to follow-up the antibiotics. ...but no one told me about the different strengths (colony forming units) or strains, so I wasted more time & money on weak probiotics like Pearls.Then along came ProBiota with a potent probiotic formula (50 billion cfu & 12 strains) that, when combined with somewhat of a candida diet, is getting my digestive system back in check. It has also cleared up my 6-month long sinus condition. It's no magic pill, but if you're not digesting vital nutrients, you're body can suffer in a number of ways. Probiota helps set your system right.Considering our meats (in the US) are stuffed with antibiotics, is it any wonder probiotic supplements are suddenly all the rage? Is it any wonder folks are suddenly gluten-intolerant or have unexplainable receding gums (periodontal disease) or can't get rid of 'belly fat'? Antibiotics kill good bacteria preventing your body from properly processing your *fuel,* even if you're taking in 'high octane' fuel. Unless you're a vegetarian or can afford grass-fed organic meats, you should probably be taking at least a low dosage probiotic. ...before your dentist starts telling you that you have periodontal 'disease' & can't tell you how it came about or how to stop it.I take 2 of these pills 2-3 times a day. That's more than the 2 they suggest, but I had serious issues. I've had zero side effects. I no longer look like Humpty Dumpty with muscles. I can breathe out of my nose whilst lying down. Too bad I wasted so much money on a new mattress & high-end air purifier & anemic probiotic brands.It's a process. My sinuses are better (as long as I take probiotics). My digestive system is well on its way. I'll give it 2 months of avoiding yeast, grains, sugars (including fruits) so that I can starve any fungus & thoroughly replenish my good bacteria with probiotics.With the condition of food these days, however, it might be a good idea to do probiotics a couple of times a year anyhow.Two issues, though. This product has 60 pills with 50 billion CFUs at $42. 'Garden of Life' offers a product with 90 pills, 80 billion CFUs per pill & 12 strains for $32.  Seeking Health has this product way over priced.The other issue is the inconsistency in results. I used these 3 times & I can tell the potency is not always the same.  Most good probiotics ship with a cold pack to ensure potency. Seeking Health claims there's doesn't need to be. Probiotics are probiotics. These things aren't hermetically sealed. Considering the inconsistency in results, they might consider it. ProBiota isn't packed in any special way and, at this (over) price, they should offer complimentary cold pack shipping.If you buy Garden of Life Raw Probiotics from iHerb, you will have a stronger supplement, more of it, for cheaper & shipped in a cold pack.

Everyone seems to agree that 'Abbey' is a fine show, so I'll take time to discuss what the show is not.'Abbey' relies not on gratuitous sex scenes... thigh-slapping humor... action, car chases, shoot-outs... whore costumes or hideous weaves... slam-bam editing or annoying music.You'd be surprised how a quality show can hold interest without all of the usual suspects Hollywood has conditioned us to rely on to make up for a dearth of talent & substance on its part.
Take your 60s psychedelic trackAdd some British flavour & a 'classic rock' overlay.Shore it up with a fair dose all out Supafly pimp-funk...and there you have it.

After irresponsible doctors/dentists stuffed me with 4 rounds of antibiotics in less than a year, my stomach flora was crap. Any type of sugar (even fruit) or bread (even gluten-free) turned this runner & fitness nut into Humpty Dumpty. I couldn't comprehend. So, I looked into it, and here I am. Unlike many others, however, "Nature's Bounty" hasn't produced any noticeable results whatsoever.Now I know why. "Nature's Bounty" offers 2 billion active cultures per pill (or colony forming units/CFU). I've since found products with 10, 30, 50, even 200 billion CFUs. In other words, just two pills of a 30 CFU probiotic pill is the equivalent of THIS ENTIRE BOX.'Bounty' offers 6 different probiotic strains per pill. There are products with 12 different strains (anything over 12 is usually strains of other minerals, not probiotics). This is a weak, incomplete supplement. As I've no idea which strains were killed off, I'd rather cover as many bases as possible. (Ridiculous that modern day meds/docs/food has brought us to this).If you're simply taking these to maintain good flora due to the antibiotics in every day meats, I suppose this may be sufficient. If you have a specific issue, I wouldn't pussyfoot around with this  weak, anemic dosage."ProBiota 12 Maximum Support" has 50 billion colony forming units per capsule plus 12 strains of probiotics. That's 25x more potency and twice as many strains of probiotics per capsule. There are 60 pills for $43. ProBiota probiotics also cleared up my chronic sinus issues.If you have serious issues and you only take probiotics, you'll probably find that your issues return if you stop taking them. Why would a money-making business formulate something you can wean yourself off of?If you have an extreme case of bloat, 'leaky gut,' yeast overgrowth or candida, I suggest following a candida diet & shoring your regimen up with P73 oregano oil for a couple of weeks (or up to two months), in order to kill over any fungal overgrowth. The probiotics will only restore the beneficial bacteria, not kill the overgrowth. Prepare for the crappy feeling when the fungus dies-off and exits the body. This is *not* the time to stop what you're doing because it doesn't feel good unless you want to me hooked on probiotics for the rest of your life.

Fits securely & comfortably. Water proofing works well.After 2 months of serious running, it's showing a bit of wear. Cord way too short, especially for sport. Sound quality is okay, but not up to par for this price.I'd recommend the XBA if it was $50. At this price, I'd recommend looking elsewhere.
