This is my second Urbane thermos and I have to say that I was extremely impressed with the temperature control properties with the first one and am equally impressed with this one. Whatever you put in it (hot or cold), this thermos does a fantastic job of maintaining temperature. In fact, it's almost *too* good as very hot liquids don't tend to cool down over time. My husband uses one of the two we have and we have had to send a mug to work with him so he can decant his coffee and allow it to cool. Even leaving the top off doesn't cool it down appreciably. If temperature maintenance is your concern, you really can't beat this thermos.The interior has a small strainer with a little handle that you can put in if you want to drink tea while leaving in the leaves. It would also serve to slow down the flow of whatever beverage you're drinking. The only point about this which some may not favor is that it has no push-button drinking ability (like Contigo designs often do). I've been using the push-button design and I would prefer this screw on/off cap type because the push buttons always have problems with leaking or build-up around the mouthpiece as time goes by. This seals perfectly - no leaking risks with this design.The design seems to be a sticking point for some people because it has a cute little saying on it. I lived in Japan for a long time, and the saying just reminds me of being there. It's cute and nonsensical and these types of things were super common there. I take the presence of the saying as a good conversation starter and I rather like it. It gives the otherwise staid black tube design some interest value without being gaudy or ostentatious.Note: I was given a free sample of this product for my assessment.

This is my second experience with packing cubes/organizers and I am liking them more as time goes by. Part of the reason for this is that I've moved 7 times in 3.5 years and being able to sub-divide what is in my suitcases has shown its value. It is much easier to pack and unpack if you can divide your possessions rather than tossing them all into one cavernous space.This cube is very light, but seems to be pretty strong in terms of the fabric and zippers. It has mesh insets to allow the packed items to breath so there won't be as much of a chance of musty smells if you're packing long-term. The size for the price is the only disappointment. In the picture I've included with the review, you can see the empty interior and the filled size both in comparison to a standard large suitcase (this is the largest most airlines will accept as a checked bag). You can also see how it compares to other packing organizers in terms of size and capacity (the blue things are also luggage organizers). This cube is better than the others that I have because the fabric is sturdier and it has a nice handle on top, but it could be deeper. The size is pretty perfect for underwear, socks, or rolled up dress shirts. In fact, I think it'd do a great job of keeping shirts packed in rolls from wrinkling or unfolding as well as making it simple to keep undergarments (which can be small and get lost in the mix) together for simple packing and unpacking. All in all, this is a pretty good packing cube, but I wish that they were offering two for about 50% more rather than a single one at the current price.Note: I was given a free sample of this product for my assessment.

First of all, I have no doubt that this is a high quality product that is highly pure and has benefits for specific health issues (particularly magnesium deficiencies and muscle fatigue issues). I found that it helped with achy joint and muscle pain after a day of heavy exertion. I rubbed it on my legs from my knee to my ankle and put it on the bottoms of my feet. My feeling is that this accomplishes some of what a hot bath in Epsom salts will accomplish without the time and effort of taking a bath (though the bath would bring the other effects related to hot water immersion). If you don't have time to deal with an Epsom salts bath and have a diet which may be deficient in Magnesium, I believe this would be an efficient and quick means to supplement Magnesium (which does permeate the skin, though I don't know if ingested vs. absorbed Magnesium operate similarly - there is little research on the effects of things like topical Magnesium preparations because it is not particularly profitable to sell such things).The main issue with this is that, while I do believe it is beneficial, it is not really enjoyable to have it on your skin. It burns/tingles/stings after application because of the salt. The most unpleasant aspect though is that it leaves our skin tacky and sticky throughout the day. I think the oil is actually a good addition to keep your skin from drying out from the salts, but it does have the side effect of leaving your skin feeling sticky.Note: I was given a free sample of this product for my assessment.

When purchasing spices, there are several important criteria. The primary one is freshness as that affects nutritional content as well as flavor. I cannot guarantee the age of this spice, but it smells fresh and appealing and is flavorful and tasty. It is also brilliantly colored and shows no sign of being faded by age. Another aspect is quality and that is reflected both in the origin and the growing process. This is organic, which should mean that it hasn't been grown with toxic chemicals. The origin is given as "indigenous organic farmers" and the Iza Organics web site doesn't specify the location of the farmers, but photos and other information indicate it is grown in India. So far, so good.The price is also a consideration, but even that is promising. I did not research the cost of every bit of turmeric on the market, and I know that you can buy cheap spices in some stores in small portions. This is an enormous amount which, on a per ounce basis, costs about half of what you'd pay for mass marketed spices such as that made by McCormick. It is ideal if you want to incorporate regular consumption of turmeric into your diet on a daily basis because you will need to consume it in a timely fashion to take full advantage of the freshness and nutritional benefits.Note: I purchased this product at a discount for my assessment.

I tried this product in two different ways. First, I applied it to damp hair after a shower to the ends and the mid-portion of my hair (as instructed). Second, I applied it to my dry hair in the morning. It was the second type of application that I found most useful. You can see in my picture a comparison of my  hair with oil (left) and without (right). The hair with the dry application of oil is darker, smoother, and shinier than the hair without it.The oil itself is thicker than common mineral oil (which is one of the ingredients) and smells very, very lovely. You don't need much to get a good application. I strongly recommend putting a small amount (about the size of a dime) on your hands, rubbing them together to distribute it more lightly over your palms, and then rubbing it into your hair from the tips upward. If you apply it too thickly or directly, it'll saturate your hair at that point and make it clumpy and greasy. You can rub it more evenly over your hair using both palms with a light coating of oil. This was what worked best for me and left my hair shiny and manageable.This worked great on my hair, but my hair is very thick, very long, and has good body. Since this is a direct oil treatment, I can't speak to how it would work on finer, thinner, and limper hair - it might be too heavy for such hair. I would recommend it for hair that can take some heavier treatment and needs shine and smoothing of frizzies and flyaways.Note: I was given a free sample of this product for my assessment.

Some products are marketed to fill a particular niche in a market and these should not be confused with paper towels. They are disposable clothes that are thicker, more durable, and more re-usable than a paper towel. The type of job you would want to use these with are those that might burn up a lot of paper towels (each of these costs about the same as 20 standard paper towels if you assume 2 cents per sheet for regular towels) or require something sturdy, but disposable. Certain types of jobs, especially those which handle jobs that would destroy a rag or make it impossible to re-wash and sanitize, would benefit from this type of cloth. These would also be good for situations in which sanitation is an issue and you don't want to keep using rolls of paper towels throughout the day. These cloths are appropriate for things like greasy food clean-up or an exterior cleaning job (like patio furniture) in which you would need to use many towels. I found that you can rinse these out and wring them out. I used them to clean some pretty dirty outside surfaces and could rinse them in a bucket of water repeatedly and they did not fall apart.I think that this is the sort of product that you will only want to buy if you engage in very specific activities. Another reviewer has mentioned that they do contain natural oil because they are made from flax so that is something to consider. Since they are marketed for food service, my guess is that this is not something the manufacturer's consider an issue.

Note: There are reviews of many different items on the same page. My review is for the Lenox Holiday Square Dish - 6" x 6".This is a small, square dish which is appropriate for candy or small snack service. It has a solid, quality feel to the ceramic. The design is simple and elegant and looks hand-painted. The edges are evenly painted with gold and the dish is a good white with a glossy finish which isn't so shiny as to look cheap. My dish arrived in a small holiday box wrapped in bubble wrap. It seemed adequately protected, but the outer box was form fit to the gift box and I think it could have been padded a bit better. The dish itself is beautiful and classy and would make a good gift or be used as a holiday serving item.

This is an oil-type moisturizer that has a fantastic scent and feels great on your skin. It's hard to explain if you've never tried one, but it's not greasy while still being satiny and moist. It is absorbed more quickly and easily into your skin than you might expect. Depending on skin type, applying an oil-like moisturizer can provide a much better experience than a cream-based one. I found that a straight oil, provided that it is pure and refined, makes an excellent post-shower, night-time moisturizer without leaving your with residue that can transfer to your pillow when you go to bed. I recommend using it sparingly by dotting it on your face and rubbing it in rather than pouring on a lot. You don't need a lot and the bottle will last you for a very long time.My experience with creams tends to more frequently be either something which is dry and powdery and doesn't provide long-term softness for your skin or they don't get absorbed and are wet-looking and shiny (though I have had some good experiences with creams as well). If nothing else sold me on this, the scent would certainly pull me in. It smells mild and exotic without being perfumey. It carries a variety of subtle natural scents that is lovely.Note: I was given a free bottle of this product for my assessment.

These solar lights are waterproof and have multiple modes. They have little rubbery caps on them that make them look like flowers which help to reflect the light and make them appear bigger and brighter than the tiny lights behind them. They are ideal for putting outdoors in trees or bushes since they are activated by darkness, solar powered, and you can just set their mode and forget them. There are two buttons on the back. One turns them on or off and the other sets the mode (flashing, fading, alternating).The box comes with the lights, solar panel, and a stake to put in the solar panel in the ground. I charged mine for a day before trying them out. It does need direct sunlight to charge the panel. Everything was pretty simple to manage except untangling the lights. It is wrapped in a bundle and I may have done a bad job unraveling them, but it was a lot like dealing with poorly stored Christmas lights. Fortunately, this was a one-time thing.Note: I was given a free sample of this product for my assessment.

There area lot of sellers offering this product and I chose this deal because it is the cheapest one at the time of my review. I've been buying this cocoa now for years and I love it and hope that it continues to stay on the market despite the high cost. Though this is only 20 calories per serving (3/4 cup), it tastes rich, sweet, and chocolate-y. Be sure when you make it to measure the hot water because it won't taste nearly as good if it is watered down.I used to pick this up at Safeway when it was on sale (for around $4.70, but the usual price is around $6 in retail stores - but it is generally not available). If you're trying to lose weight, this is an amazing way to satisfy a chocolate craving without blowing your diet. I would recommend doing a search for the best price (as I said, there are lots of sellers). Since each can provides so many servings, it is well worth the price.

I've tried a variety of Luseta hair care products and they are attempting to product salon quality results at a consumer-level price point. For the most part, I'd say that they succeed, though the way in which their products perform varies based on hair type. Part of professional formulation seems to mean that the products aren't a one-size-fits-all type of experience. That being said, the coconut milk shampoo and conditioner struck me as being the  most accessible to people with all types of hair. The shampoo cleans well, but doesn't leave hair stripped. My scalp felt clean and my hair's shine (what is left of it, I'm 51 and have aging hair) was enhanced.The conditioner is pretty effective for all issues. It contains flyways to some extent, frizzies to a greater extent, and does a good job in improving comb out (and this is important for me because my hair is super long and thick). My  hair felt super soft after using both the shampoo and conditioner together and the body and waves were definitely maintained if not enhanced. The scent of these products is amazing. It is stronger though when you're using it than it is when your hair is dry so it's not obnoxiously potent.Note: I was sent samples of this product for my assessment.

Most people are using digital planners in this day and age, but I find that being able to put the schedule in front of me on paper where I can look through it helps me conceptualize the schedule better. This planner is ideal in that it has both a monthly calendar and weekly ones so you can note appointments for at-a-glance reminders and detailed information in the weekly calendar. There are spaces on the sides and bottom to jot down notes. The size is also quite good in that it's big enough to write comfortably in, but not large and unwieldy. It's easy to carry in a briefcase or backpack. It also has the nice touch of a ribbon bookmark to allow you to mark the current date. I would say that it's expensive for a planner, but the truth is that I've checked the prices on a variety of planners and they all fall within a similar price point. If you're looking for an "analog" planner, this is an excellent option.

Jump ropes are one of the cheapest and most compact pieces of exercise equipment and, though they are very simple in general, certain features can be added to make them better to use. In the case of this rope, the handles are much better than a basic rope. They are thick and padded with grooves for your fingers so they're easy to grip and won't slip out of your hands easily. The rope won't twist up because the string rotates inside of the handles so it moves rather than twists up.The only weak point to this is that there are no instructions about how to shorten the rope. The rope comes in a box with information on the back so there's no reason those instructions couldn't have been printed on the box. I figured out that you have to remove the cap from the bottom of a handle and pull it through to the length you want. The tricky part then is getting the metal clamp off the part you're trimming off and then re-attaching it to the new end. You'll need a pair of flat-nosed pliers to bend it both to get it off and back on. If you're not handy, this can be a bit tricky.This is an excellent jump rope. Once you get it to the size you like, it'll give you a great and comfortable work-out.Note: I was provided with a free sample of this product for my assessment.

The primary function of a watch is that it keeps time and this one, in my short experience with it, seems to keep time very well. It's actually not difficult to get a decent watch that keeps time, so the other properties of value are comfort, design, and usability. This watch scores big points on at least two of those. First of all, it's a beautiful watch with a warm and natural look and feel. The wood is smooth and polished so it's comfortable against your skin. It feels quite sturdy and not brittle. As the marketing blurb for this mentions, wood is neither hot nor cool against your skin so you can wear it in all temperatures without risk of sweating under the band or getting cold damage to your skin in super cold weather. I grew up in the northeastern part of the U.S. and we were explicitly told to avoid metal jewelry on super cold days because the metal could get colder than your skin and damage it.The usability in terms of daily wear is very good. There's a button on the side of the clasp that you push to release it and it's a folding/unfolding type that lies flat against your skin. In the short term, setting the time if your fingers aren't sufficiently padded is a little troublesome as the crown is fairly flush against the wood. Once it's set though, you're not going to have to bother again. The watch has a very large face (see picture against my wrist) so it is easy to read at a glance. The instructions are clear and easy to follow. Extra links are included in the box to re-size it if you need a larger band. Chances are you will need to remove links rather than add them, but given the unique quality of the watch (the wooden band), it was a nice touch to include more links.The first thing you notice when you open the box is that the watch smells great. It would make a good gift not only because it is unique in appearance and presentation, but also it is packaged beautifully. It is both memorable and functional. The watch arrives wrapped around a tweed pillow in a wooden embossed box. The top slides open and the empty box could be used for other purposes or for storing the watch in the future.Note: I received a sample of this product in exchange for my assessment.

This is my second experience with vacuum compression bags and these are more expensive than the Ziploc ones that I'd tried before. The price per bag with Ziploc's were a little more than $2 and these are a little less than $5 (at present). The main difference that I've noted, and this is either irrelevant or very, very important, is that these do not "leak" like Ziploc bags do when you put items in the bags for long-term storage. Within weeks, my experience with Ziploc's bags was that they re-inflated and expanded. These bags stayed compressed (or at least they have so far). If you're looking for short-term (less than a month) storage, then you can get by with cheaper bags. If you are looking for something for long-term storage, these are a good choice despite the higher price per bag. If you're looking for something which is for a temporary purpose (like a move), then you can go cheaper.As another review noted, the packaging on these bags is very utilitarian. They are sent in a plain bag with no instructions. It's not hard to figure out how they work, but if you are confused about what the little plastic parts are for (in the extra bag), you're out of luck or will have to search online for a how-to. Also, though I think the little black screw-on cap is a better seal for the vacuum hole than the plastic snap-on caps that are common in other types of bags, it would be a lot easier to lose track of them when the bags are not in use.Note: I was provided with a free sample of this product for my assessment.

If you take any supplement or eat a particular diet in order to reap potential health benefits, you are always doing so on faith. This applies to eating an apple or a piece of fish as well as taking a probiotic capsule. It is impossible to assert with any certainty if any choice of what you put in your mouth will have a positive effect on your body. For this reason, I make it clear that my experience with any supplement is highly subjective and I mainly focus on the usability and my sense of the value of the product.I do believe that probiotics assist with increasing good bacteria in the stomach and gut. I edited research about such bacteria when I lived in Japan and this physicians research discussed the affect of "bad bacteria" on the development of stomach cancer and that fuels my belief in addition to other research that I've read. In my own experience, I can say that taking the Viva Labs supplement lessened my stomach distress (and eating probiotic yogurt does as well, but I don't care for yogurt that much). The relative immediacy of the relief I felt after taking this supplement was far greater than that I've had with other supplements that carried a lower price tag. I am impressed.In terms of how easy these are to take, the capsules are rather average in size - not big, but not small. They are easy to swallow and have no odor or taste. Unless you have particular difficulty swallowing capsules, these should be quite easy to take.Note: I was given a sample of this product in exchange for my assessment.

A lot of people are not fans of Hershey's chocolate, but I actually enjoy the slightly sour taste and almost signature "chalky" texture. One of the disappointments of this candy is that you actually can't taste much chocolate. The milk chocolate version has almost no chocolate flavor and the dark chocolate version has only slightly more chocolate flavor. The real star of this candy is the caramel which is sweet and soft. It could be more buttery, but is still a very serviceable consumer-level caramel offering. The texture is very, very impressive and, as someone who really values texture in food, this scored points with me.The bonus to all of this is the tin which is quite attractive and re-usable. It makes a good gift or simply provides for future storage of something else.

This is my second cable management system review (I was offered a free sample of this type) and it is far easier to use than the previous one. The package contains 4 neoprene sleeves with zippers. You wrap the sleeve around your cables and zip it up. It's as easy as that. The zippers are very easy to engage and pull up and down. Each will easily contain about 4-6 cables (depending on thickness) you can even stuff unwieldy lengths of cable back into the sleeve to tuck them out of the way. This system works best for cables that run from one location to another and is less useful for a situation in which cables are snaking off in various directions (for that, the type of system with various holes that you can pass cables through works better).I found this very easy to use, relatively attractive, and easy to clean. All of the zippers on my sleeves moved smoothly and were securely attached. The flexible design also made them easier to arrange than some of the cable management systems which are like plastic tubes. It also allows the sleeve and cables to lie flatter if the cables run behind desks or tables.

I wear a women's size 8 1/2 shoe and these socks fit me pretty much perfectly. You can look at the pictures I took to see where the toe and heel fall on the sock's pattern. That being said, they are designed for the Japanese market (the writing on the back of the tags is Japanese) so my guess is that they will run a bit smaller than socks designed for the Western market, but any woman with average feet (or smaller) should find the fit quite decent.The socks are about average in thickness and are neither warm nor cold. They fit very well in your shoes and are thick enough to prevent chafing with the edges of your shoes. They have a festive winter design and the colors are varied, but they are types that will likely match any clothing you wear as they incorporate, white, black, and red with black tending toward the dominant color. The socks are quite comfortable and made up of stretchy material. My only issue with them was that I felt the inner seam near the top of the toe could have laid flatter. I could feel the seam along the top of my foot for a little while before it conformed to my foot. After a few washes, it is fine, but those with sensitive toes  may find them uncomfortable. All in all though, I think these are attractive winter socks that would be appropriate for gift-giving in the winter season and the full set comes at an economical price. The packaging is pretty utilitarian (see picture) though, so you'll want to wrap them in a different package if they are gifts.Note: I purchased these socks at a discount for my assessment.

I used this on a pair of leather shoes that I first used Leather Nova leather cleaner on. The cleaner had already done a good job adding a nice patina to the shoes, but the restorer was supposed to add even more and make them look new and "restored." The "before" picture shows perfectly decent recently cleaned shoes. The "after" shows how the restorer makes them look shiny and new.There is little to no scent to the conditioner and it is easy to apply with the included sponge. It doesn't leave behind any residue (though you do need to let the leather "dry" or be absorbed). It only took a very small amount to do both shoes. I imagine one bottle will last a very long time unless you're conditioning very large pieces of furniture on a regular basis.Note: I received a free sample of this product for my assessment.

There will always be an England! As a confirmed Anglophile I enjoyed this immense doorstop of a book. Dr. Robert Tombs Professor of History at Cambridge University teaches us about English history from the days of the Anglo-Saxon Kingdoms to 2014! Tombs writes in a fine narrative style easily comprehended by the average reader who has some basic knowledge of the broad sweep of English history,. The book covers all the reigns of the English monarch as well as such seminal events as:a. The Norman Conquest of 1066.b. The impact of the Protestant Reformation in England.c. The English Civil War of the 1640s.d. The literature of England from Shakespeare to Dickens to modern novelists and playwrights,.e. The development of modern English is chronicledf. Major wars from Napoleonic to World War I and World War II are covered with insight.g. The book contains excellent maps and photographs.h. Tombs shows us how democracy was established in EnglandI. The rise of the British Empire and the impact of Victorian culture is dissected with skill.  A short summary is impossible for such an important book. The work will serve well as a college textbook or a great read for those interested inEnglish life.  A long but anything but dull book! Rule Britannia!

This is a huge final volume of the three volume autobiography set edited by Benjamin Griffin and Harriet Elinor Smith and other editors of the Mark Twain Project. The books are essential in a study of Mark Twain (1835-1910) our greatest American writer, humorist and contrarian! The book deals with events from March1907 to December1909. We see the boy from Hannibal in old age as he receives a degree from Oxford, mourn the death of his daughter Jean and enjoy the friendship of everyone from famous Wall Street tycoons to young girls. The oversized book is beautifully illustrated. Essential for fans and scholars of Mark Twain!

A few weeks ago I finish Eric San Juan's excellent book on the Mad Men TV series which ran on AMC. I decided to purchase his earlier bookBreaking Down Breaking Bad from Amazon; I am glad I did! This little book will give you a good analysis of the excellent Vince Gilligan directed series which ran five years.  The series focuses on brilliant teacher Walter White. Learning of his fatal cancer diagnosis he decided to make money to leave his family secure following his imminent demise. He and a former chemistry student Jesse decide to cook meth to make a bundle. The descent of Walter White from respected family man into a monster is a fascinating journey into the heart of darkness of a human being. The series is notable for its excellentwriting, acting and story line. The acting of Bryan Cranston, Aaron Paul and a strong supporting cast make this series a television event. Kudos to Eric San Juan for his sagacious and concise comments on the show!

Hitler dies on April 30, 1945 in the Dantean depths of his Berlin Bunker. Poison and a gunshot ended the life of the cruel dictator and his new wife Eva Braun Hitler. The next ten days would witness:a. The dispute among the Allies (the Soviets, and the United States) on the most appropriate place to stage the Nazi surrender. The Nazis surrendered at both Eisenhower's Rheims France headquarters and also in Berlin to the Soviet conquerors of that capital of the Reich.b. Hard fighting would continue for a few days on the Eastern Front.c. Prague was the last city to be liberated as the SS had to be defeated in that large capital city.d. The roads of Europe were filled with refugees fleeing from the Soviet advance westward into Germany.e. The horrible evil of the final solution was revealed as British, Canadian and American troops liberated the extermination camps.  Michael Jones is a British historian who is the book's author. He is a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society and a member of the British Commission for Military History. This book is valuable for:a. The eyewitness accounts of those from several nations who participated in the final events of World War II in Europe.b. The chronology the book includes regarding the last days of the war.c. The descriptions of the celebrations of V-E day in the capital cities of London, New York and Moscow.  The book is  worthy of being and provides interesting insights into the horrors of war and the joys of peace.

The authors review the lives and controversial careers of former POTUS Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton. Rumor or facts? Read the book and make up your own mind. The book is poorly written and edited. The reader should be aware that Roger Stone and Robert Morrow are both Republicans who are political opponents of the Clintons. The book is tedious reading as the authors regurgitate old rumors and scandals that have been hashed and rehashed for decades. Books like this make this reviewer ponder the questions of whether the American people will decide on casting their vote for someone who has many skeletons in the in their closet but benefit the majority of the people they are elected to serve. The book also represents the freedom we in the United States enjoy to criticize popular and powerful politicians. Such books never see light in dictatorships.  I am a person who reads material on our leaders from both liberal and conservative viewpoints. Use your mind and decide what your verdict on Hillary Clinton as a presidential hopeful will be as election 2016 approaches.

Salem Massachusetts was not the place to be in1692! The year saw nineteen people hanged (fourteen women and five men including clergy)and two dogs hanged! The small village had less that six hundred inhabitants. Neighbors accused neighbors, husbands said their wives were witches and parish members turned on their pastors. Schiff examines:a. The lives of the judges and accused persons including Increase Mather and his son Cotton who were famous New England Puritan preachers and theologians.b. Schiff relates many details involved in the trials of the accused.c. I felt the book went on way too long with a long list of people and cases which were hard to keep straight in the mind of the reader!d. The rational explanations for the witchery are not adequately addressed by the author.  This book by a Pulitzer Prize winning historian should have been much better. The author has done tremendous research but her narrative is too abstruse for the general reader. OK!

Celebrating Mad Men is a succinct and informative study of the seven year season hit television series. The series explored in depth the lives of ad men working on Madison Avenue in the 1960s. The quality of the writing, acting and plot development make this series one of the best ever presented on American television! The book by Eric San Juan explores:a. The complicated career of Don Draper who is really a man named Dick Whitman. He is a womanizer, drinker and schemer who is the center of the series.b. Peggy Olson-She works her way up from secretary to a position of power in the firm. A young woman with a modern attitude.c. Joan-The sexy secretary who knows how to play easy to please with the boss but ends up rich and secure do to her skills at work.d. Roger Olsen-The spoiled and hedonistic co-owner of the firm. A cad but fun to watch!e. Peter Campbell-The scion of a New York family of wealth and prestige he grows in maturity during the seven years of the series. f. Betty Draper-The second wife of Don who is a stern and spoiled woman.  The book also explores race in the 1960s, the role of women in the time period covered and explores each of the seven seasons. This book is a fun and interesting volume which was better written and more entertaining than I thought it was going to be!

Charles Dickens (1812-1870) is the greatest English Victorian authors. His immortal lives will live as long as human eye can scan the thousands of pages he wrote so long ago! Every few years this reviewer travels to old England to revisit the unforgettable characters etched with humor, wit and pathos by Boz. The Everyman's Library has republished all of the Dickens novels and stories in sturdy hardbound yet affordable editions. In "A Christmas Carol" that 1843 classic is there for us to feast upon as well as a quartet of other fine stories. The stories are:a. A Christmas Carol was published in 1843 by Bradbury and Evans Company. The story is the most famous secular tale in all of the vast treasure of Christmas tales. Old Scrooge is a miser who is visited by the three ghosts of past, present and future. He is redeemed by love and kindly cares for his nephew Bob and his crippled son Tiny Tim. The story is the one Dickens work everyone seems to know even if they have never read it or perused any of the other Dickens works.b. The Chimes-In this story we see how the British poor were cast aside by greedy and pompous political hypocrites. Toby Vetch and his suffering family have revived hopes as they listen to the cheerful message of the bells.c. The Cricket on the Hearth: It started with a teakettle and a cricket on the hearth bringing cheer and love to the humble home of John Peerybingle and his young wife. The plot concerns John's suspicion that his young wife  is having an affair. The tale and secret of the old man who visits their humble abode is solved with the joys of an old time Christmas dance and party! One of Dickens' best Christmas tales!d. Dr Jeddler and his two daughters Grace and Marian live on an ancient English battlefield. The doctor is cynical but is redeemed by the love revealed by his two daughters. Marian yields her lover Alfred to her older sister Grace in a touching and sentimental story.e. The Haunted Man-A chemist asks a ghost to remove his memories of sorrow and pain. He regrets this and is made thankful for our memories as he sees a woman named Millie reach out in love to a suffering student. The theme is "Lord, Keep My Memory Green."  Charles Dickens had a way with words in which he can make the world come alive in all of its sadness, joy and beauty. This book would make an excellent Christmas gift! As Tiny Tim might put it: "God bless us everyone!"

Dr. Timothy Snyder is a brilliant historian of the unspeakable and horrific crime of the Nazi holocaust against Europe's Jews and other victims of their crazy cruelty. Snyder shows us that:1. Hitler believed human beings were no more than animals asserting a twisted belief in survival of the fittest in which the strong destroy the weak regardless of society or morals.2. The author is fluent in Yiddish, Russian, German and Polish so his research shows us the holocaust and Hitler's war against humanity in a brutal new perspective.3. Hitler hoped to invest Poland as an ally in his war against Communism and the Soviet Union. When the Poles refused he invaded their country on September 1, 1939 launching World War II.5. The Soviets were cruel killers who killed millions of peasants in relocations and in their invasion of Poland and the Ukraine in 1940.6. The Nazis did not believe in national borders and viewed Eastern Europe as fair game for their colonization schemes.7. The key to Nazi belief was the triumph of the Germanic race over the Slavs and Jews.8. Jews were considered as poisonous and had to be removed from the universe  Snyder is the author of Bloodlands dealing with Soviet-German murder in Eastern Europe. This new book looks at Nazi and Soviet horror in the conquered lands of Poland, Czechoslovokia, Austria and other lands which they conquered. A horrible period of history is presented this book. Excellent text, strong bibliography, extensive footnotes and graphic maps of the spread of Nazism in World War II. Essential for holocaust studies!

Ken Follett  is a British author of countless bestsellers from The Eye of the Needle to the Key to Rebecca. This reviewer has just read Edge of Eternity. It is the third volume in The Century Trilogy. Fall of Giants dealt with World War I and Winter of the World with World War II. All three books follow the lives of English, Welsh, Russian and American families who live their  days in exciting and historic times. Edge of Eternity follow the various families in the events from the erection of the Berlin Wall through 1989 when the Wall came down and Soviet Communism ended in victory for the values of Western Democracy. In this huge volume of over 1,000 pages we follow the many characters involved in:a. The erection of the Berlin Wall-Rebecca Hoffmann a teacher and her lover escape to West Berlin .b. George Jakes a young African-American intellectual and graduate of Harvard becomes an aid to Bobby Kennedy working with him in the White House.c. Maria Summer a beautiful black woman becomes the mistress of President John F. Kennedy.d. Tanya is a reporter for Tass the Soviet News Agency. She travels to Siberia to meet with Soviet dissidents.e. Tanya's brother Dimka Dvorkin is an aide to Khruschev  The book is epic in scope. We visit Castro's Cuba, the Soviet Union, the American South during the Civil Rights Struggle, Washington D.C. Berlin and Vietnam as well as several other lands in the history of the Cold War period. We even get a good story regarding Dave and the rock world of the 1960s. The books have many sex scenes and loves affairs abound!  Follett is a popular historical novelist who will keep you turning pages. The book is not a masterpiece but it will lead to many enjoyable hours of reading pleasure. During this past year I have been reading all the Ken Follett novels I can get my hands on. He is fun to read and you learn a great deal about the world we have inherited from our forbears.

Continental Congress Delegate John Adams wrote his wife Abigail a letter. In it he compared their lives in the vortex of revolution and social upheaval as a whirlwind. Surely the American Revolution is the seminal event in the story of the United States. Dr. John Ferling, the emeritus professor of history at Western Georgia University, is the author of several books on the Revolutionary War and the years of the early American empire of liberty. Among those books are A Leap in the Dark and Almost a Miracle. In this new book he tells the story of the American Revolution from the beginning of colonial disaffection to the Mother Land of Great Britain in the 1760s following victory of Britain in the Seven Years War against France from 1758-1763 (called in America the French and Indian War). to the Treaty of Paris ending hostilities in 1783. There is much to learn in this book even for those of us who have teeming shelves filled with books on the subject. Among the facts I will remember from my reading of this text:a. Over 30,000 Americans died fighting for Independence.b. More African-Americans served in the American military than any other war until the time of integration in Korea in the 1950s.c. About 60,000 Loyalists fled the new United States during the war.d. Great Britain had a terrible time with logistics and keeping their troops supplied in a distant war over 3,000 miles from the British Isles.e. George Washington practiced a Fabian strategy against the might of George III's Army as he continued to retreat from major battle as much as possible in an attempt to win a long and protracted war. This strategy proved to be a winning move in the chess game of war.f. Major battles include Bunker HIll, Princeton; Trenton; Morristown; Harlem Heights, Saratoga  and several key battles in the Southern Theatre from the fall of Charlestown to Cowpens and the final victory against Lord Cornwallis at Yorktown Virginia in 1781g. Washington was the indispensable man in leading the American army to triumph.  The book is well written. As a former high school history teacher this book could well be used as a resource in a unit on the American Revolution.Essential!

Jeremy Poldark is the third book in the famous Poldark series by the late Winston Graham. The book was first published in 1950. Poldark is a native of Cornwall who returns to the county after service for King and Country in the American Revolutionary War. He marries Demelza a servant girl; operates a mine and is a respected member of the tightknit rural community. In this book Captain Poldark is arrested for inciting riot and plundering two British ships which are wrecks on the beach. The trial of Poldark is the highlight of this book. Jeremy Poldark is the son born to Ross and Demeza after their first daughter baby Julia died. Meanwhile the evil George Warleggan seeks to destroy Poldark. Dr. Dwight Enys is a good friend of the Poldarks; an old landowner attempts to seduce Demelza and cousin Francis Polkdark is depressed and suicidal.  What a story!The Poldark books will hook you and incite you to read more! Beautifully written. The books are now being serialized on a PBS series.

When is the last time you hunkered down with a thick history book which read like a thrilling novel? My answer is today! I have just completed James Holland's excellent first volume of his projected three book history of the War in the West during World War II. Holland is a British historian, novelist and broadcaster. He has advised the British government on history curriculum and has his own collection at the Imperial War Museum  In this first volume Holland spends his time exploding old myths about the beginning of the most destructive war in human history which claimed over fifty million lives. The book is based on the latest current research, interviews, travels made by Holland to the combatant nations and an impressive bibliography. The maps in the book are easy to read and the period photos are fine. Holland asserts based on his study that:a. Germany's Army was not well mechanized depending on horses to carry their artillery.b. Great Britain was at a distinct advantage over the Nazis due to its extensive and supportive world empire which provided soldiers, equipment and needed iron ore.c. Germany made a terrible mistake when they went up against the RAF in the Battle of Britain.d. Winston Churchill and FDR were much superior to Hitler as a strategist on the world stage.e. Mussolini's Italy was a poor and agricultural land and did little to help their German allies.f. Hitler's attack on the Soviet Union was a fatal mistake.g. The British Army's retreat from Dunkirk led to their being able to rearm against the Nazis.h. Allied planes and the British Navy were much superior to the Nazi Luftwaffe and Navy.I. Germany was short on tanks, trained soldiers and natural resources to sustain a long war of attrition against the powerful Allies of Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union.  James Holland's book also looks at the lives of individuals caught up in the maelstrom of war from soldiers at the front; to airman and tankersto housewives and young people. This approach makes the book more human and interesting.  I eagerly await volume II from an outstanding young scholar of an old war. Excellent!

Doc Martin is one of our family's favorite television series! It is an English series but if you think that means dull and dry you have a delightful surprise in store! My wife and I have watched every episode in the first six seasons at least once! Doc Martin is a London surgeon who has a phobia about seeing blood. He decides to move to a small Yorkshire town where he hangs out his shingle as a GP. He falls in love with Louisa a schoolteacher and they have a child named James. The good doctor is irascible and does not entertain fools gladly! He can be rude, abrupt and hateful. He is, though, a good man and excellent doctor ! Martin is surrounded by a cast of eccentrics such as Bert Larger the fat restaurant owner and his son; his aunt who is a psychiatrist; a lamebrain policeman and several others. The stories are warmhearted and will make you both laugh and cry. If you are looking for good clean humor which can be enjoyed by the entire family then I urge you to meet Dr. Martin Ellingham and hiswonderful friends! Enjoy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

History is never dull but how we read that history is sometimes as lackluster and banal as reading a cereal box! This ability to narrate good popular history is well exhibited in the series of "Killing" books by Bill O'Reilly of Fox TV fame and Martin Dugard. I have read all the books in the series and this one on Ronald Wilson Reagan is one of the best!  The authors tell the story of Ronald Reagan the smiling Irish actor from Dixon, Illinois who broadcast games for the Cubs, starred in 53 Hollywood films and served as the popular TV host of the General Electric Theatre and Death Valley Days. Reagan was divorced from Academy Award Actress and was a womanizer when he met Nancy Davis. The couple had a great marriage and were the parents of Pattie and Ron Jr. Reagan had two children from his previous marriage to Wyman (Maureen and the adopted Mike). Reagan was a New Deal Democrat but his growing opposition to Communism in Hollywood, testifying for HUAC and working as an FBI operative turned him to the right. Nancy was a tough woman who was a conservative true believer. Reagan served two terms as a Republican governor of Cal. He challenged sitting POTUS Gerald Ford for the nomination in 1976 losing a squeaker. Reagan defeated President Carter in 1980 and won a second term as chief executive against Walter Mondale. Reagan' is considered a great president. During his time in office the Berlin Wall was torn down and Communism in the Soviet Union collapsed. He survived the assassination attempt made against his life by John Hinckley  on March 30, 1981. Reagan survived the Iran-Contra scandal and led the USA to victory in the Grenada invasion. During his time in office he was a close friend of Margaret Thatcher the Conservative Prime Minister of Great Britain though he did disagree with her on British strategy in the Falklands Islands war.  Reagan became feeble and died of Alzheimer's disease.  Ronald Reagan was a man with few real friends. He could be cold and aloof but he was beloved as a father figure to a resurgent American public. He loved America and served this land well!  This book is well illustrated, contains a good bibliography and offers objective insights into the life and career of the Gipper! Well done and worth reading!

Hillary Clinton was born in Chicago in 1974. A graduate of Wellesley and Yale Law she has served as First Lady of the USA; Senator from New York and Secretary of State. Ed Klein in this short screed against Clinton notes:a. She has an explosive temper and is a narcissist who loves power.b. Hillary is an inveterate prevaricator.c. Hillary is very difficult to work for and did a poor job as Secretary of State.d. Hillary and Bill Clinton dislike the Obamas.e. Bill and Hillary have used the Clinton Foundation in unethical ways.f. Both Bill and Hillary have serious health concerns which they try and keep from the public.  Whether you like or dislike Ms. Clinton this short book will get you thinking about whether she has the ability to serve as America's first female POTUS.g.Hillary loves her role as a celebrity enjoying a luxurious lifestyle.h. She is a dull speaker and is not a good people person.I. She puts up with Bill's sexual exploits by living a separate life. She does rely on him for political advice.

World War II was the greatest collective tragedy in the history of the human race. The war began when Germany invaded Poland on September 1, 1939. Nearly fifty million persons died during the war including millions of Jewish victims of the Nazi holocaust. All of these facts are well known. The numbers of books on Germany under the Nazis fills large libraries. Dr. Nicholas Strargardt's new book The German War is one of the best account of this horrible time. The author:a. Covers the major strategic moves of the war with skill and conciseness.b. Shows how the war impacted German people from soldiers on the front to housewives at home. Stargardt  performs this feat through a skilled use of letters and short biographies of everyday men and women.c. The book clearly shows that thousands if not millions of Germans knew the truth of the murder of the Jews in extermination camps.d. Most of the eighty million Germans believed the Allies surrounded the Reich with lethal intent to destroy their nation.e. Germans were taught to hate Jews and Communists.f. Dr. Joseph Goebbels the master of Nazi propaganda skillfully if maliciously used the media to instill hatred in the hearts of his countrymen.g. The Nazis were an evil criminal regime.h. The Roman Catholic and Protestants did little to protest Nazi atrocities against the Jews though they did oppose medical euthanasia schemes against the mentally ill.  Germany comes across as a conformist and cruel nation in this excellent book. Well recommended!

Jay Winik is one of America's foremost popular historians. He won a Pulitzer for April 1865 and his The Great Upheaval was an outstanding work.In 1944 the master historian takes a poignant look at Franklin Delano Roosevelt in the crucial days of World War II. Among the milestones ofthe pivotal year 1944:1. Roosevelt's health continues to decline; his impending death was only months away in April 1945. He continued to travel, govern and lead the great arsenal of democracy the United States as it and allies Great Britain and the Soviet Union squeezed Nazi Germany into an inescapable box.2. D-Day on June 6, 1944 put the allies on French soil as they drove towards Germany on the Western Front while the Soviet Army moved in on the Third Reich from the Eastern theatre.3. The plight of the millions of Jews who were being ruthlessly murdered in Auschwitz and several other death camps was, arguably, history's worst crime.4. The United States State Department was filled with Anti-Semite officials and bureaucrats who stymied immigration efforts for Jews who sought solace and freedom in this country. Winik spends many pages on this topic; his account of life in a death camp and a daring escape from Auschwitz make for fascinating though horrified reading. Man's inhumanity to man knew no bounds in the satanic world of Himmler, the SS and Adolf  Hitler's sadistic and murderous compass.5. Winik includes a good overall discussion of Western War strategy from North Africa to Sicily, Italy, the invasion of France and the Battle of the Bulge.6. Winik is a historian who knows how to write and keep the reader's interest from flagging.7. This book would be an excellent volume to give to a young person or student whose knowledge of World War II and the Holocaust is elementary. I8. The book reveals how great leaders such as FDR., Churchill, Eisenhower can inspire and lead a nation and military force with gusto, guts and a genius  get the job done.9. The book provides several short biographies of several brave Europeans who sought to inform the West of the horrors going on against the Jews and other captive people in the Nazi controlled nations.10. This book is one of my favorite reads of 2015 and should be on the bookshelf of any person who values freedom and morality!

I have read Judith Barker's fine historical account of the Battle of Agincourt fought on October 25,1415. However, I thought a fictional book by Bernard Cornwell would also be enjoyable and informative. I was correct on both counts! Cornwell, a very prolific historical novelist, spins the tale as he tells us the story through the eyes of an English archer and outlaw. The violence of battle is bloody and the action is swift. Cornwell includes a section on the development of the English longbow and an interview with the author is included. A good popular read backed up with good historical research make this book a page turner. Good fun!

Demelza is book two in the Poldark  saga. I first this book in 1975 when the series was featured on Masterpiece Theatre. With the new Polkdark series now on PBS I decided to reread the Poldark books. I am glad to revisit the fictional characters who people the pages of Poldark. In Demelza the fetching young farm servant has married RossPoldark. Demelza gives birth to her daughter Julia. Ross is busy trying to keep copper and tin mines open in Cornwall. The book has several interesting characters such as Jim Carter who is prison for debt; a farmhand married to an actress with a roving eye; Elizabeth who though still in love with Ross has married his dissolute cousin Francis; Jud and Trudy the feckless couple who work for Poldark  Graham's book was first published in 1946 and still holds up well. Enjoy!

There are few historical figures who have an entire age named for them. Napoleon was one of this exalted pantheon. He was born in Corsica to an upper class family. His father was a lawyer and involved in the Corsican political scene as a supported of Paoli the liberator of the island. Napoleon studied the military arts in France becoming the hero of the battle of Toulon where his artillery defeated the English. Napoleon became the hero of the Revolutionary armies victories over Austria in Italy. He also won battles against the Turks in Egypt. Napoleon became one of the three consuls who governed France; led a coup and became emperor in 1802. He was the victor at Marengo and popular with the public. Napoleon was a good administrator and a brilliant general. He was married to Josephine but had countless affairs.  The author is an expert on Napoleon. This book is the first volume of a projected two book set on the life of one of history's most controversial figures. This first volume is very long at over eight hundred pages; is detailed and deals with politics, diplomatic and personal issues in the life of the little corporal. The work is not an easy read but is an essential book in the Napoleonic scholarship.

Lord John is a minor character in the long string of Outlander novels (eight to date) by Arizona novelist Dr. Diana Gabaldon. This author is an accomplished modern master in the genre of historical romantic fiction. Her novels focus on the eighteenth century. In this novel she has given her readers three novellas concerning Lord John and his adventures. Those tales are:a. Lord John and the Hellfire Club: The death of one of his officer peers. John investigates his disappearance turning up at the Hellfire Club where human sacrifice, gay sex and murder comingle in an unsavory stew. This is the shortest and the least interesting of the trio of tales in this collection. Gabaldon does much better as a novelist of doorstop size novels than it these shorter worksb. Lord John and the Succubus. Lord John is posted in Germany during the Seven Years War. Many of his superstitious men believe that a succubus is abroad in the land. This is a female demon who has intercourse with unsuspecting men whom she often murders. The tale is complicated with many characters and is a mystery difficult to solve.c. The Haunted Soldier deals with a cannon explosion which causes Lord John to look into the past of the English officer and his family life. What he finds is scandal.  As one who has read all of the Outlander novels published to date I diligently read the Lord John novels. They are so-so and quite a comedown in interest from Gabaldon's huge novels about the love of Jamie and Claire Fraser.

The buck did stop at the desk of Franklin Delano Roosevelt (1882-1945) the President of the United States from 1933-45. On December 7, 1941FDR and his team were surprised by the Japanese Empire's dastardly attack on Pearl Harbor in Hawaii. Roosevelt had fought hard to ensure America would defend freedom on the land, sea and air. His plans of lend-lease  and sealing of the Atlantic Charter with Prime Minister Winston Churchill in 1941 were instrumental in the defeat of the Third Reich. America grew from an isolated nation with a third rate military to the mastery of global power. What began at Pear Harbor ended with the failing of nuclear bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  How the United States progressed on the path to war and what made our nation great in the eyes of the world is the story told by Jonathan W. Jordan in this excellent popular study. Four men  are put under Jordan's microscope in this eloquently written and researched study. Those men are:1. Franklin Delano Roosevelt-A brilliant president who became Doctor Win the War. In alliance with Britain under the great leadership of Winston Churchill and his magical ability to reconcile feuding politicians and military men into a winning formula for victory make for an inspiring story of courage, valor and patriotism.2. General George C. Marshall-The chief of the Army was the leader into turning America's armed forces from a small force of 200,00 into the mighty brigades of millions of soldiers who defeated Nazi Germany, Japan and Italy. Marshall was a cold man who was a perfectionist brooking no levity in his command. He worked well with FDR  and was keen in the ability to reconcile feuding military associates. One of the United States greatest captains of war.3. Admiral Ernest King. An irascible, demanding, rude and very effective head of the United States push to Japan. He was hard to work for but got the job done. An essential tool in FDR's tool chest of great leaders.4. Henry Stimson-The elderly Secretary of War and a New York pal of FDR he came from old money, was a lifelong conservative Republican and did an outstanding job in directing the military effort against the enemy.  If I were teaching a college level course on America in World War II this book would be on the assigned reading list. It makes clear what an enormous effort of blood, sweat, tears, production of weapons and deployment of troops was necessary to strike the head of the viper that was Fascism and Nazism. The book contains a few maps, has  an excellent bibliography and useful footnotes. Highly recommended!

My father was a staff sergeant in General Hodges First Army. He fought in the Hurtgen Forest and in the Ardennes in that bitter winter of 1944.Bringing the Battle of the Bulge the last strike of Hitler's hammer against the Allies to modern readers in a challenge. This feat is well accomplished by Dr. Peter Caddick-Adams. He has written earlier books on Monty and Rommel as well as the Monte Cassino Campaign. He is a professional soldier who has led troops in Bosnia, Iraq and Afghanistan. He is British but has a refreshingly positive attitude to American contributions to winning the global struggle against the hideous Axis powers. Snow and Steel is a soldier's eye view of the battle as we read first person accounts by both American and German soldiers. Caddick-Adams also lets us look over the shoulders of SHAEF commander General Dwight Eisenhower who had to keep peace between British General Bernard Law Montgomery and General Omar Bradley who led 12th Army in the Ardennes. The Germans launched their surprise last gamble attack on December 16, 1944 but after over a month of bloody fighting were turned back. Their goal was the port of Antwerp where massive Allied supplies were being unloaded for use in the field. The Germans had poor logistics and Hitler's plan was insane. The very readable text is accompanied by photos of the battle and a massive bibliography and footnotes. This is one of the best battlefield books I have ever read! Caddick-Adams is one of World War II's finest young historians. Superb!

Waterloo was a turning point in modern history. The all day battle of June 18, 1815 was fought south of Brussels pitting the Allied armies under the Duke of Wellington (1769-1852) future British Prime Minister against Napoleon Bonaparte (1769-1821`) and his French legions. Wellington was assisted by General Blucher and the Prussians as they defeated the little corporal. Napoleon had escaped from St. Helena's and returned to France where he quickly deposed Louis XVIII and fought to protect France from her many enemies. The battlefield was small encompassing only a few miles but was extremely bloody. Wellington protected his troops with his reverse slope strategy and his strong defense destroyed the might of France. As a result of the battle:a. Napoleon was finally deposed as Emperor of the French and sent into exile on Elbe where he died six years after the battle.b. Great Britain was at last triumphant over Revolutionary France and went on to extend their already vast empire. The nineteenth century balance of power in Europe would lead to almost a century of European peace..  The book is richly illustrated with colored art work and includes many first person accounts from generals to foot soldiers. We learn how armies were armed, fed, transported and fought in this early nineteenth century milieu.  Bernard Cornwell is best known as a historical novelist featuring the British soldier Sharpe who fought against Napoleon. In this first book of nonfiction the author has done a fine job of explaining a complicated battle to general readers. I have many huge tomes on Waterloo but this is the one I will most turn to as a refresher of information on Waterloo. Recommended!

The late Winston Graham was a Welshman who is responsible for books turned into film such as Marnie and the Poldark series. I first read most of the books at the same time as watching Poldark on TV over a quarter of a century ago. Now the series has returned to Masterpiece Theatre. It features splendid acting and beautiful seasons of Cornwall. This first book in the series is excellent. It tells the tale of Ross Poldark who returns to his Cornish farm following service in Virginia in the American Revolution. Poldark's parents are dead and only Trudy and Jude, two feckless servants, are still on the property. Ross learns that the beautiful Elizabeth with whom he loves is now married to his cousin Francis. Francis is a weak character with an affinity for drinking, gambling and whoring. Ross hires the young Demelza as a maid when she is only 13. They later marrydespite criticism from Ross' gentry friends. A friend named Jim Carter is arrested for poaching and sent to prison despite Ross' plea for mercy to a cruel court. The book is lyrically written with passages descriptive of nature's changing season. There is also many pages devoted to the mining business which Polkdark operates in a tough economic time. Anyone reading this book will want to move on to volume two Demelza. Ross Poldark was first published in 1945. The writing and story hold up well!

Lord John and The Brotherhood of the Blade is the second in the series of novels based on Lord John. He first appears in Diana Gabaldon's lengthy series Outlander. John is a gay major who has a torrid affair with Percy Wainwright. The two are assigned to Germany where they take part in the Crefeld battle pitting the English forces and their allies against the French. The battle occurs during the Seven Years War. Lord John spends a good deal of time seeking to discover who murdered his father. The book is 400 pages in length and will keep your attention. However, there are parts that drag and the series lacks the drama of the Outlander series. A good historical romance for general readers and lovers of the works of Diana Gabaldon a talented American author.

I have made the journey through all of the eight published volumes in the Outlander series by Diana Gabaldon. There may be future volumes in the popular series which now is running as a cable television series on the STARZ network. Now I have turned my historical romance reading to the Lord John Grey series by Gabaldon The chief character is Lord John Grey. He is a major in the British Army in the 1750s who is in London awaiting assignment to a new posting. Grey is called in to investigate the murder of Irish sergeant OConner. He is believed to have had on his person secret papers vital to government security. Meanwhile, Lord John is dealing with a family crisis. His niece Olivia is engaged to Cornish Colonel Joseph Trevelyan. While in the loo at a local pub, Gray sees a syphilis sore on Trevelyan's penis. He seeks to prevent Olivia marrying this man and becoming infected with the disease.  Much of the action takes place in low life London districts featuring the Lavender inn where homosexual men gather for assignations and liquor. There are also scenes set in brothels. The story is slow moving with several characters to keep track of as the complicated plot is unraveled. The novel runs to 300 pages making it a baby among the behemoth 1000 paged doorstopper novels produced by the author in the Outlander series.

The Rev. Charles Ludwig Dodgson (pen name Lewis Carroll) 1832-1898 is the comic genius of children's Victorian literature and a British treasure!  On July 4, 1862 he and a fellow Oxford don joined the three daughters of Dean Liddell up the Thames River on a picnic excursion. Thegirls asked Dodgson to tell them a story. The result was the story that became Alice in Wonderland published in 1865 and Alice Through the Looking Glass published in 1872. Alice follows a rabbit down a hole as her adventures begin. Along the way she will meet the Mad Hatter, the Caterpillar, the Chesire Cat. the  the Duchess, Tweedeldum and Tweeldee, the Queen of Hearts and many other fabulous creatures. The two stories are beautifully illustrated by John Tenniel who was the chief artist for Punch magazine. The tales are filled with nonsense rhymes, puns, songs which will enchant and entertain you. Every literate person should read these great classics of childhood which can also be enjoyed by adults of any age. The Penguin Anniversary edition is beautifully designed. Enjoy!

I have read over one hundred books this year. Among that century number this book by Dr. Robert Douglas-Fairhurst, an Oxford scholar and author of a bestselling biography of Charles Dickens, has risen to my personal top ten books for the year. Fairhurst's book is a delightful exploration of the life and career of Charles Dodgson (1832-98) who was the author of Alice in Wonderland in 1865, Through the Looking Glass in 1872, The Hunting of the Snark and countless poems, short stories and mathematical works. Dodgson was a Church of England clergyman who was a bachelor throughout his life living in his Oxford don digs. He was also a genius who took the pen name Lewis Carroll. He enjoyed photography, word games, puzzles, long walks, poetry and short story writing, trips to London for theatre and a wide assemblage of friends. He met Mark Twain and knew the Tennyson family. Alice's creator stayed closed to the Oxford he lived but did take one long trip to Russia. The author explores Carroll's life from his birth in the north of England to a clergyman, through his study at Oxford and his writing career. Carroll was a perfectionist and a solid conservative Christian and a prim Victorian gentleman. Alice was based on his adult-child friendship with Alice Liddell one of the daughters of the Dean of Oxford.  It was on July 4, 1862 that Dodgson, a male friend and the three Liddell girls journeyed by boat up the Thames. Rev. Dodgson told them the story that became Alice. We see Alice grow to womanhood and make her trip to New York a year before her death in 1933.  This beautiful book is well illustrated including copies of the photos taken by Carroll and the original drawings done for the Alice books by John Tenniel.  Along the way you the reader will learn all kinds of facts about the Alice books and enjoy the company of Lewis Carroll. So take the plunge down the rabbit hole with a great scholar and buy this book!

I am a devoted fan of The Outlander series of novels and the fine STARZ cable network production based on those books. I have read all the Outlander tomes  so turned to this graphic novel The art work by the Vietnamese-American artist Hoang Nguyen is superb. The colors are rich and the pages fly by until the end. The story begins with Claire Randall being transported back in time from 1946 England to the Scotland of the Jacobite Rebellion in the mid-eighteenth century. She is rescued from harm by Jamie Fraser who becomes her husband. The graphic novel serves as an easy way to work your way into the complexity of a series which runs to over 6,000 pages.

Dr. Stanley Wells the author of Great Shakespeare Actors is an acknowledged expert on the works of the Bard William Shakespeare (1564-1616).In this 308 page book he gives the reader a glimpse behind the drawn curtain to learn more about famous and great actors and how the production of Shakespearean drama has evolved since the days of the Globe Theatre's heyday in the sixteenth century to today. Shakespeare is the world's greatest playwright and his immortal tragedies, comedies and history plays will live as long as humanity roams the earth.  The book looks at the acting careers of several Shakespeare actors from Richard Burbage the star of Shakespeare's company to such luminaries as Sarah Siddons, David Garrick, Edmund Keen, Edmund Booth, Ellen Terry, Michael Redgrave. Sir Laurence Olivier, Sir Ralph Richardson, Dame Peggy Ashcroft and many others. The author also provides information on the staging and acting styles which have been favored over the long centuries of Shakespeare acting on the boards. This book is a fun read filled with pictures and facts. It would be very helpful for acting students, students of drama and Shakespeare and anyone who want to enhance their cultural literacy.

Shakespeare Basics for Grown-Ups by E. Foley and B. Coates (I was disappointed there was no biographical information on the co-authors)are two British authors who have written an excellent popular guide to the life and works of William Shakespeare (1564-1616) the world's greatest playwright. I did not expect much from this book. Boy was I surprised! The book is filled with information on historical information on Shakespeare's times; a brief biography of the Bard of Avon; famous speeches and quotations and how they would sound in modern English; the sonnets and how the folios and quartos came to be published. Succinct summaries of several of the comedies, history plays and tragedies are also included. Summaries of them are given and their critical reaction among scholars and the public. A section on famous Shakespearian thespians was fun to read. The tome concludes with a sixty question quiz on Shakespeare and his works. This is a wonderful resource which can be used with profit by students and general readers! Enjoy and learn!

Who were they? A talented and patriotic group of good women who served as first ladies of the United States. From Martha Washington to Michelle Obama you can learn their fascinating stories in this excellent book published by C-SPAN. The book is based on the C-SPAN series on the First Ladies which ran a few years ago. The book does not present detailed biographies of each of America's forty-five first ladies; what it does do is present the scripts of each of the shows featuring sage comments by historians on each of the women profiled. Such scholars as Richard Norton Smith and William Seale add their thoughts and research on the first ladies. The over 400 page volume features a picture and short biography of each woman including anecdotes and the major issues facing the United States as a nation during their husband's administration. The personal lives of the first ladies is also briefly discussed. Images remain in my mind of Abigail Adams doing laundry in the East Room: Dolly Madison saving a portrait of General Washington from the invading British in 1814, Eleanor Roosevelt speaking to the nation following the Pearl Harbor attack and many more. This is an easy to read book which would be well suited to a class on the First Ladies for students. The book is well illustrated and fun and educational to read! Kudos to C-Span and Susan Swain!

Dr. Mark R. Levin is a conservative radio host and a bestselling author. Despite your politics or chronological age you should inform yourselfof what is going on in the United States! The book is aimed at awakening young people to the growing  soft tyranny of the federal government and the greedy claws of an overregulated and centrally administered government. Levin looks with scholarly objectivity at the following areas of the American republic experiment which need to be fixed or at least challenged by the rising generation. The chapters are:1. Plunder and Deceit-An introduction to the book and a challenge to parents and community leaders to foster a love of country in children as they become informed of the sad state of the American republic.2. On the debt-The government is in debt for trillions of dollars!3. On Social Security-Entitlement programs from Social Security to Medicare and Medicaid are wide open doors to adding to the national debt and not really helping those who need help.4. On Medicare and Obamacare-The them of this chapter is the invasion of the federal government into medicine and old age benefits.5. Education-America spends more than almost any other country in the world on educating our citizenry but our young people are failing to be educated into good citizenship. Programs like Common Core have failed. Education seems to be for the professionals involved in the endeavor rather than the students. Student loans put an intolerable burden on the present generation.6. On immigration-The overwhelming flood of constant immigration from peasant cultures is doing great damage to American citizens and our common culture and values.7. On the Environment-Levin gives an F to the EPA and the Interior Department for overregulation and their war against capitalism and the industrial age. The EPA's war on coal production was frightening to read!8. On the minimum wage-The minimum wage actually hurts young people in getting entry level jobs that  will strengthen their work resumes and give them job experience.9. On National Security-The world is a tough neighborhood from China, Russia, Iran and terrorist organizations such as ISIS and Al Queda. Young Americans need to pay great attention to foreign policy since it is they who are called to fight in the nation's wars.10. On the Constitution-The seminal written document of American freedom is disregarded and trampled by many politicians and activist judges. The Obama administration has acted with too much executive power in blatant disregard of the separation of powers.11. Levin calls upon all Americans to fight for individual American freedom rather than meekly give in to government tyranny.  Mark Levin is a brilliant American patriot who is doing his best raise the Paul Revere cry to his fellow citizens to the dangers of a runaway softtyranny government.  In the last paragraph of his book, Levin calls on young people to stand up for liberty and against tyranny. I have read all of the Levin books. They are short and are based on sound scholarship. This book deserves a wide readership.

I am slowly reading through all the murder mysteries by Agatha Christie published by Harper Collins in an attractive paperback format. The covers of these books are beautiful! The Christie series is reasonably priced and will afford readers hours of lighthearted British murder cases. Murder in the Mews was published in 1937. The four cases are:1. Murder in the Mews-A woman is found dead in her apartment without any explanation of whodunit until Hercule Poirot is called in to investigate.2. The Incredible Theft-The story reminds this reviewer of the The Naval Treaty story by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. The plot deals with the theft of an important letter which will determine whether a politician involved has a future in his government.3. Dead Man's Mirror-A rich old man is found dead in his study. Conflicting reports as to his mood during the day and who among the guests at his estate may have had a motive to slay the chap.4. Triangle at Rhodes-A marital triangle leads to foul murder but theending will surprise you.  A pleasant diversion of old Agatha Christie stories.

Henderson the Rain King was published in 1959. The author is Saul Bellow the American Nobel Prize winner in Literature who was born in Montreal in 1915 to Russian Jewish immigrants who eventually migrated to Chicago where the author grew to manhood. Bellow usually deals with intellectual characters living in an urban milieu. Among his great works are Herzog; Dangling Man; Humbolt's Gift; Mr Sammler's Planet and other novels and short story collections.  Henderson the Rain King departs from his usual stories for the following reasons:1. The book takes the hero to Africa a continent which Bellow had not visited at the time of the novel's publication.2.The author is not an intellectual but an Ivy League School millionaire who is a veteran of World War II who has won a Purple Heart for his being wounded in the Mount Cassino campaign in Italy.3. The  subject matter is ribald and Rabelaisian as the 55 year old Eugene Henderson leaves his second wife and family for a vacation in Africa.  The book includes long philosophical and unrealistic talks Henderson conducts with the medically educated King of a local tribe. Henderson confronts a lion and experiences his love of life. He becomes known as the rain king who is able to bring rain to a drought stricken region of Africa.  I prefer Bellow to stay in more familiar territory but this foray into Africa does manifest the author's ability to convey the love and excitement of life well lived. A good read!

The four novels contained in this volume I of a projected three volume set by The American Library are very entertaining to all of us who enjoy hardboiled crime works.
