The quartet of notable novels from the 1950 s are :a. Filled with a relish for the English language. MacDonald enjoys the use of metaphor that puts him near Raymond Chandler in this literary choice.b The evil which exists under the sunbaked landscape of Southern California is made to come alive in Macdonald's brilliant prose.c. Chapters are short and to the point. Their is little in the stories which is extraneous to the development of the plot.d. The author's stories are much easier to follow than those of Raymond Chandler or Dashiell Hammett two behemoths of the American school of hardboiled crime works.e Macdonald's characters are well drawn.f. The plots deal with blackmail of the wealthy and corrupt, family secrets which are brought to life and the violent and dark underbelly of life in and around Los Angeles.g. Lew Archer (his name derived from Macdonald's affinity for General Lew Wallace, author of Ben-Hur, and the last name Archer which refers us to Miles Archer the murdered partner of Raymond Chandler's Sam Spade in The Maltese Falcon.  The American Library edition is well produced. It features a detailed chronology of Macdonald's life, letters from the author and pages of footnotes which illuminate the text. Recommended!

Mad Men will hook you! It is a great drama series. What makes it so?Writing-Director and Writer Matthew Weiner has written smart scripts which remind this reviewer of the prose encountered in a good novel!Acting-Headed by the outstanding Jon Hamm who plays the tormented ad man Don Draper the series sparkles with acting from each of the featured actors. These actors give their roles depth and make you care about what happens to them.Costumes and Sets-Evoke the period of the late 1950s and early 1960's in beautiful pastel colors. The period detail is astounding! Evocative of the palettes drawn in his motion pictures by Alfred Hitchcock and his talented team.Plot-Sterling Cooper and its ad men and support staff show us how an ad agency worked in the days of male chauvinistic behavior in the office; constant cigarette smoking and the crass sexism and racism of this earlier era in American history.  Being your journey with Mad Men by watching and absorbing season one!

This book is based on the historical docudrama series Legends and Lies: The Real West hosted by Bill O'Reilly of FOX news TV fame. The book was actually written, though, by David Fischer.  It is devoted to chapters on the following legends of the American West: Daniel Boone; Davy Crockett; Kit Carson; Black Bart; Wild Bill Hickok;Bass Reeves the real Lone Ranger; General Custer; Buffalo Bill and Annie Oakley; Jesse James ; Doc Holliday; Billy the Kid; Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid whose stories are fascinating! Short chapters also deal with the West and Movies; the American Indian and Gun usage in the Old West.  The large coffee table size book is lavishly illustrated with period illustrations and photographs. It is a good read!

Last year I enjoyed the STARTZ production of Outlander series. The eight books written so far deal with the lives of time traveler Claire Randall who travels back to eighteenth century Scotland. She soons weds Jamie Fraser a Highland land who joins the rebellion of Bonnie Prince Charlie the Stuart pretender to the English throne. This revolt ended in disaster for the Highlanders at the Battle of Culloden Moor in 1745. An Echo in the Bone is the seventh novel in the series. Like all the others it is huge logging 814 small print pages! The book recounts the adventures of Claire and Jamie following the burning of their home in Fraser's Ridge North Carolina. They become involved in the American Revoutlon fighting for the colonists against the might of Great Britain. All of the characters we have come to love in the series return! Such characters as Ian the nephew of Jamie who lives with the Mohawks; Lord John the British friend of Jamie; William the son of Jamie who becomes a British officer; Fergus the French lad Jamie rescued from a Paris brothel and several other fascinating people! Diana Galbadon is adept at love scenes which are tastefully presented; battle accounts and good information on eighteenth century medicine, clothing, Scottish culture, agriculture, bird life and many other subjects with which the author is familiar. Gabaldon is a great historical romance adventure novelist. Her work will delight you and fill up hours of delightful reading1 Enjoy!

Richard Milhous Nixon was born to Quaker parents in Southern California in 1913. He graduated from Duke Law School and served as a naval officer in the South Pacific during World War II. Nixon became a congressman and United States Senator. He served two terms as Vice-President under Nixon and after losing to JFK in the presidential contest of 1960 returned to California. Nixon lost the gubernatorial contest for the golden state in 1962. Many Cassandras thought he was done in politics. Nixon returned to win the 1968 race for the White House against Vice-President Humphrey and slaughtered George McGovern in the 1972 reelection battle. Nixon was forced to resign from office in August 1974 as a result of the Watergate scandal. He became an elder statesman and author of several books on world leaders and issues.  All of the above facts are well known. What Thomas is able to do is to get inside Nixon's brilliant but flawed personality. Nixon hated the eastern elite epitomized by communist spy Alger Hiss whom he was able to bring down. He also hated the press and preferred foreign issues to domestic affairs. While in office his administration did inaugurate the EPA. Nixon was a crafty Machiavellian politician who was also personally kind and sensitive to the needs of others. He loved his wife Pat and his daughters Julie and Tricia but was adverse to wearing emotions on his well tailored sleeve.  Evan Thomas has written a good book which all persons interested in Nixon or American politics will enjoy./ Recommended!

My father was a combat veteran of the Battle of the Bulge. I am proud of his service along with all the others who fought for freedom against tyranny. As a longtime student of World War II and the holocaust this new book on Ravensbruck stands out! Sarah Helm,a British author, has done holocaust studies a favor by her detailed study of the little known atrocities which occurred in this hellish SS run camp. Ravensbruck is located about fifty miles north of Berlin. The Nazis opened it in 1939 to serve as a detention camp for asocials, lesbians, freedom fighters against Nazi tyranny and foreign nationals held in detention. Almost 50,000 women from over twenty nations would die in this hellhole. Death came by starvation, gunshot, gassing and disease. The famous "rabbits" were women forced to undergo terrible medical experiments which ruined their health and in many places led to their deaths. About ten per cent of the inmates were Jewish.  This book is not an exercise in dry statistics since Sarah Helm tells the stories of many of the women who spent time in this Dantean hell on earth. The book is quite lengthy running to over seven hundred pages but its grim story needs telling. Kudos to Helm and her research and to the memory of the brave women who died at Ravensbruck.

Saul Bellow grew up in Chicago though born in Montreal.  He emerged from Jewish culture and was one of the most intellectually and gifted authors in American literary history. The Penguin Classics Edition contains three good stories by Bellow.  The Bellarosa collection is a humorous story of the attempts made by Harry Fonstein to thank Broadway producer Billy Rose for helping him to escape from Fascist Italy. The story is narrated by a  man who has known the Fonsteins for many years. An interesting story about Jewish life at them midcentury in a New York milieu which no longer exists.A Theft is a story about Clara Velde a wealthy, beautiful and much married woman who loses a jewel given her by her longtime lover Teddy Regler.The story is told by Bellow with warmth and wisdom.Something to Remember Me By is a Great Depression era story set in Chicago. A young boy is enticed into a sexual encounter in a hotel room by a woman who steals his clothes.  Saul Bellow is always worth reading. Enjjoy!

Tommy Wilhelm has just lost his job. He is separated from his wife Margaret and  his two children are living with her. He has a difficult relationship with his Dr. Adler, his elderly father,r who is a famous New York doctor of medicine, Tommy lives in a fading but European style New York Hotel. He is out of work and seemingly out of luck. He speculates in lard on the commodities market. His financial and spiritual advisor is Dr. Tamkin. Tamkin is a mysterious old man who is an inventor, self proclaimed expert in human psychiatry and an advisor to Tommy. The short novel is only 114 pages in this Penguin edition. The book ends when Tommy has an epiphany concerning the meaning and connectedness of human life as he attends the funeral service for a stranger. Bellow is great at character sketches reminiscent of Charles Dickens. His novel was published in 1956 portraying New York and Broadway in that era of Eisenhower and the Brooklyn Dodgers (Tommy attends Dodger games with his sons on weekends when they visit him at the Hotel Gloriana where he resides. Bellow writes out of a Jewish tradition which is informed by vast reading and experience of the human condition.

Swan Song is a collective diary of the final days of the infamous Third Reich. The author is Walter Kempowski (1929-2007) who was a famous German novelist and historian.  Swan Song is the final of ten volumes in which the author used diaries, letters and memoirs to tell the story of Nazi Germany. This volume is 479 riveting pages of first hand accounts of the horrors of the final hours of the 2,007 days of war and murder in the European Theatre of Operations. The material is translated from the German by Shaun Whiteside and published by W.W. Norton Inc.The chronicle provides first hand accounts of the mopping up of Nazi Germany written by persons who were German, Russian, Italian, Polish, English and Americans as well as other nationalities. Many famous names appear in these pages including Winston Churchill; Dr. Albert Scweitzer working as a medical missionary in Africa; Benito Mussolini; Adolf Hitler; Harry Truman; General Dwight Eisenhower; novelist Thomas Mann; German General Keitel and several more. The stories they tell are sad, funny, tragic and heartbreaking. The stories recounted by survivors of the Nazi extermination and death  camps are especially horrible to hear and ponder. The book is filled with riveting quotations. A sampling:"On the hill, a view of the city spread out below. How many cities have been turned into piles of rubble by now? The angels have protected Paris.-Thea Sternheim, p. 4"...the whole terrible surface was covered with a whimpering grey carpet of humanity."-Sigmund Graff describing the Bad Kreuznsch prisoner of war camp.-p. 23"The Russians and Americans are outside Berlin, and have launched the final attack."-Weert Sweetsp. 54"American reporter bring stories from the occupied concentration camps...Such a thing cannot happen in the land of Goethe! Not in the most primitive country on earth could it be possible!"-Ulli S.-p. 61"...the good does not unweigh all the terrible things that in the end befell our German people because of this man." (Hitler). Marthel Kaiser-p. 73"He liked children and dogs and sunshine and flowers, and they are all around him now."-Anna Eleanor Roosevelt the bereaved First Lady of the United States commenting on the burial of her husband Franklin Delano Roosevelt-p. 107"Will we never be normal people again? This age has taken us like a piece of filth in its bloody fists and slapped us into horror, into sadism and madness."- Franz Ballhorn-p. 153"The battles for Berlin were characterized by particular toughness and resistance on the part of the Germans."-Ivan Kovchenko-p. 281"Above all I charge the leaders of the nation and those under them to scrupulous observance of the racial laws and to merciless opposition to the global poisoner of all peoples, international Jewry."-Adolf Hitler is his Political Testament-p. 285"The war against Germany is over...advance Britannia. Long live the cause of Freedom. God Save the King.-Winston Spencer Churchillp. p.300  Those readers who like their history raw and at first hand will relish this important historical work.

This fine  murder mystery novel was published in 1934. It features Agatha Christie's Hercule Poirot working in tandem with Mr. Satterthwaite the eccentric and wealthy gentleman who often appears in the Harley Quin stories. The case concerns the murder of a clergyman which is Act one of the story. Act two culminates in the murder of a doctor and act three with the murder of a woman in a nursing home. The plot is energized by the young and beautiful girl Hermioine "Egg" Lytton Gore. It revolves around the English stage star Charles Cartwright. The book is not overloaded with characters and the plot is easier to follow than in many of Christie's complex novels. It is one of my favorites by the Queen of Crime and is a good novel to begin a relationship with the doyen of murder. Excellent murder mystery!

The Witness for the Prosecution and Other Stories is a collection of stories by Dame Agatha Christie. Most of the tales come from her early writing career in the 1920s and early 1930s. The tales are well written, clever and will keep the reader guessing Whodunit! Pure escapism.The stories are:The Witness for the Prosecution: This short story was  seen in a popular film starring Charles Laughton, Marlene Dietrich and Tyrone Power.It concerns the murder of a rich old lady. Did the defendant in the case do her in?The Red Signal-Rival lovers quarrel in a minor story.The Fourth Man-Three professional men including a doctor, lawyer and study of psychiatry discuss murder but the common sense of the fourth man makes more sense.SOS-Two sisters and the story that one of them will inherit a fortune. Enter poison!Wireless-An ironical tale in which a dying woman has the last laugh!The Mystery of the Blue Jar A golfer hears a scream of a woman and thinks this indicates he is going crazy.Sing a Song of Sixpence-The murder of a wealthy old man and the important clue of a sixpenceMr. Eastwood's Adventure-A crime writer discovers he is involved in  real mysteryPhilomel Cottage-A newlywed suspects her husband of foul deeds done prior to the marriage.Accident-A much widowed woman has buried several husbands. Is she a black widow of murder?The Second Gong-The crime is solved by the inimitable Hercule Poirot. This is the only story featuring him in this collection.  Good Christie!

The Fiery Cross weighs in at 979 text pages in this edition! The large book is the fifth in the series of Outlander novels written by Diana Gabaldon the famous author of historical romance fiction. The action takes place in colonial North Carolina on the eve of the American Civil War. Claire and Jamie Fraser are now middle aged. They live with several family members. During the book, Jamie takes up arms as a leader of the state militia to suppress the Regulator movement. This group demanded fairer taxes and better government in the Royal British colony. The revolt was a foretaste of the impending American Revolution.  The book gives us a good look at life on an eighteenth century farm. Many pages are devoted to medicine procedures and prescriptions as everything from a snake bite to bullet wounds are treated by Dr. Claire Randall Fraser. There are generous accounts of sexual episodes recorded in a tasteful way by Galbadon. The book is good but is too long!  Anyone who has been bitten by the Galbadon bug, though, will enjoy every page!

Alfred Hitchcock(1899-1980) is the subject explored in this brief book by Dr. Michael Wood, British born professor emeritus at Princeton University., The book gives a brief account of Hitchcock's career while reviewing several of the director's best films. Reviews deal with such Hitchcock hits at the box office as: The Lodger, The Man Who Knew Too Much (both films); The Birds; Vertigo; I Confess, North by Northwest, Notorious and others.  As a person who has read a vast amount on Hitchcock there was little information in this book which was new to me. However, the book many appeal best to readers who know little about the rotund director and wish to know more. The book includes a filmography and bibliography which prove helpful to those who want more insights into the tortured genius of Hitchcock.

Joseph Stalin was a cruel and evil man. He was also a person with the ability to move up the slippery slope of political life in the newly formed Soviet Union. Stalin was born in Georgia in 1879; his drunken father was an alcoholic while he worshipped his hardworking and religious mother.Stalin attended a Russian Orthodox Seminary in Tiflis which he hated and left before graduation. He became  bold revolutionary and spent several years in Siberian exile. He became the right hand man of Lenin but prior to the latter's death in 1924 he turned against Stalin. Stalin assumed total control over the Politburo and the vast expanse of the Soviet Union. He murdered millions during the Great Famine and Great Purges of the 1930s. He allied with Hitler in the rape of Poland in 1939 but was attacked by Germany in a massive invasion in 1944. Over 20 million Soviet citizens died in the Great Patriotic War. Stalin ruled the eastern European nations take by his armies during World War II. He died in 1953.  This new biography of the dictator is by Oleg V. Khlevniuk a Soviet scholar of renown. The book is written in an interesting way as alternate chapters deal with the life of Stalin chronologically while the every other chapter deals with the death of Stalin in March, 1953. The book is not as detailed as many other Stalin biographies now on the market. The text is written in a scholarly style which makes it a good resource for teachers of Russian history. Recommended.

William Augustus Wellman first saw the light of the New England day on February 29, 1896. Wellman came from a good family. His mother worked as a probation officer for troubled youth and testified on this issue before the United States Congress. His father kept the family fed and clothed despite his serious alcoholic disease. Bill grew up wild! He dropped out of high school following a career as a fine athlete in professional minor league hockey. Wellman enlisted in the Lafayette Flying Corp winning several French decorations for valor. He married a French girl who was killed by a German bomb. Following the war he married a movie star and began a distinguished film career. Wellman never won an Oscar for directing but did win one for his writing  A Star is Born in 1936. Wellman wed five times and had seven children with his fifth wife Dottie. Wellman was a man's man becoming an expert flier, biker and general all around hell raiser. He directed 82 films among them Wings which won the first Oscar for Best Picture. Among other notable films: The Ox-Bow Incident; The Call of the Wild; The High and the Mighty, Battleground, Nothing Sacred, Public Enemy and many others. His favorite actress was Barbara Stanwyck and his greatest pleasure was spending time with his family.  As one who has a teeming shelf of books on Hollywood history I consider this Wellman biography as one of my favorites! It is filled with period photographs on almost every page; a  detailed filmography and  a personal touch on the life of the Hollywood icon by his son Bill Jr. Wellman was a good man, an American patriot and an outstanding director. His story is fascinating and worthy of your attention. Enjoy!

Drums of Autumn is the fourth book in the eight volume Outlander epic by Dr. Diana Galbadon. The story in this volume is as exciting and riveting as those transpiring in the first three books in the series: Outlander,. Dragonfly in Amber and Voyager.  The plot deals with the successful hegira of Jamie and Claire Randal across the ocean to their new home in the hills of North Carolina. The action transpires in the eighteenth century as the Randalls must deal with savage Indians, disease, and the hardships of life in the new world. Their daughter Brianna and her lover Roger Wakefield seek t travel back to the Randall farm as they forsake the twentieth century world of Boston to reunite the family.  Galbadon is a writer who able to escape her labeling as a romance author. She is adept at thoroughly immersing the reader in both a tender love story embellished with gobs of sex along with thrilling adventures in the American wilderness. Her ability to etch sharply defined and memorable characters is a treat. Once you have read one book in the Outlander series you will be hooked. While away the hours as you travel with Galbadon to exciting places with the inimitable Jamie and Claire Randall.

Raymond Chandler was born in Chicago in 1888 but spent most of his youth and young manhood in Great Britain. He attended Dulwich Collejge a fine secondary school near London. He served in the Canadian Army and later in the Royal Air Force during World War I. Chandler moved to California in 1919 where he worked in business and began  career as  a professional writer. His greatest creation is detective Sam Spade. Many of his novels have been turned into movies including The Big Sleep[ with Bogart and Bacall, the Glass Key with Ladd and Lake and The Lady in the Lake. His short stories were published in hardboiled magazines and collections. He had a major drinking problem and was a faithful husband to his wife Cissy who was several years his senior. Chandler loved cats and hated the Hollywood Studio system in which he earned a living as a screenwriter. Chandler is best known for his brilliant use of similies and his graphic painting of Los Angeles between the wars. His plots are weak and quickly forgotten. It is the poetry of his language that we remember and celebrate.  Author Barry Day has compiled many of the best of quotations culled from the works of Chandler and also included many photos of Chandler and the Los Angeles he would have been familiar with during his life. As I read the book I listed many of the quotes from Chandler's pen which I thought to be of interest. A small sampling:"The average "educated" American has the all round mental equipment of a fourth form boy in an English public school."-p. 26"Hemingway with his eternal sleeping bag got to be...tiresome."-p. 31"Phil Marlow...the shop-soiled Galahad."-p. 41"I watched the last of the sunlight sneak over my windowsill and drop into the dark slit of the valley."-p.77"Organized crime is just the dirty side of the sharp dollar."-p. 86"The swell is as gentle as an old lady singing hymns."-p. 109"Spring rustling in the air like a paper bag blowing along a concrete sidewalk."-p. 111"The memory of old cigars clung to its lobby like the dirty gilt on its ceiling..."-p. 115"I smelled Los Angeles before I got to it. It smelled stale and old like a living room that had been closed to long."-p. 122"Good original screenplays are almost as rare in Hollywood as virgins."-p. 136"Trouble dwelt in her eyes."-p. 163"Put some rouge on your cheeks...You look like the snow maiden after a hard night with the fishing fleet."-p.167"A blonde to make a bishop kick a hole in a stained-glass window."-p. 174  This little book is a small gem which is fun to read. One wishes we had authors of Chandler's genius working today!

Diana Preston is a wonderful popular author of historical subjects! The London born and Oxford educated Preston has written about such subjects as The Boxer Rebellion, The Road to Culloden Moore, Antony and Cleopatra and The Lusitania. In this latest volume from her prolific pen she delves into three horrible innovations in warfare which transformed warfare in the twentieth century. During 1915 battle in the air, on land and under the seas was forever changed by:a. The invention of the Zeppelins led to aerial warfare in France and to bombing in England by the German Air Force.  This was a forecast of the Battle of Britain in 1940. The author traces the development of the zeppelins and World War I combat in the skies.b. The use of poison gas by the Germans at Ypres in 1915 led to terrible deaths in the trenches. Poison gas was used by both the Germans and Great Britain during the war.c. The German navy resorted to undersea warfare against shipping in their unrestricted submarine warfare by the U-Boats. The attack on the Lusitania in May 1915 is covered in detail by Preston.  This book is a good study of warfare as we remember the one hundred year anniversary of the tragedy of World War I and the beginning of the bloodiest century in human history.

Cecil B. DeMille will live forever in Hollywood history! He was born in 1881 and died in 1959. DeMille along with film pioneers Jesse Lasky and Samuel Goldwyn founded Famous Players Lasky film company. CBD directed "The Squawman" which was the first super film feature hit; He was there at the beginning of film and lasted longer in active directing than any other film pioneer. Among his smash epics were The Ten Commandments in both silent and talking versions, Samson and Delilah, The Greatest Show on Earth, Cleopatra, The Frontiersman, The Sign of the Cross and many other epic films. Among the stars he nourished were Gloria Swanson, Charlton Heston, Judy Holliday, Claudette Colbert and many others. DeMille was often accused of being hokey but his films were and are loved by audiences. He was a Christian whose pulpit was the movie screen. DeMille was a faithful husband and father.  The book contains dazzling photographs collected by Mark Vieira  who is a Hollywood historian. Cecilia de Mille Presley, CBD's grandchild, has written a fine commentary on the films and the career of her grandfather. A great and fun book chock full of delights for those who enjoy film history !

Give it to Dr. Diana Galbadon! The woman can write a lengthy yarn while keeping the reader turning pages into the wee small hours of the morning! In this third volume in the  Outlander series we find Claire Randall and her husband Jamie facing dangers from Scotland to the West Indies to the colonies of British colonial America.  The book begins when Claire learns that Jamie survived the bloody battle of Culloden in 1746 in which Bonnie Prince Charlie and his Highlander army were soundly defeated by the British under the command of the Duke of Cumberland. Jamie is imprisoned for many years where he comes to meet Lord John Gray a prominent figure in the story.  Claire returns from 1968 Boston to Scotland in aid of Jaime. the pair sail the seas for the West Indies in order to rescue Jamie's nephew Ian from captivity by pirates. The book is filled with ribald sex, violence and beautiful writing. Anyone having got through three hefty volumes of the series will want to continue reading. The series of books is now being featured as a hit series on the STARZ cable network!

The lives of most professional writers is somewhat dull! Hours spent before a computer or doing research online or in a library is not the stuff of drama. However, the life of Saul Bellow (1915-2005) dispels that perception. Bellow was born in Montreal to Russian Jewish immigrants. His father had a volatile temper but finally made good money in a coal company. When a young boy the family moved to Chicago where Saul grew to adulthood. Bellow was a brilliant lad who was street and book smart. He studied at the University of Chicago and Northwestern studying anthropology and working at his writing craft. Bellow held many teaching posts though he only had a bachelor's degree at such prestigious universities as Princeton, Bard and many others. Bellow was a charming ladies man who wed five times. Three of his wives and his relationships with him are covered in this book which ends in 1964 with the publication of his blockbuster 'Herzog." Bellow soared to fame with his "The Adventures of Augie March" in 1953. SB served six months in the merchant marine in World War II and traveled widely in this period to Europe, Israel and Mexico. Bellow won three National Book Awards, a Pulitzer Prize and the Nobel Prize.  This book by Dr. Zachary Leader an American born professor who teaches in London is a detailed account of the first half of Below's life.All the bitchiness of life among the New York Literary set and academia is captured in these pages. Bellow was less than an angel in his dealings with women and fights with fellow writers. He, Philip Roth and Bernard Malamud were the top Jewish writers of the era. Leader is very detailed in discussing Bellow's family and Jewish culture in the early twentieth century in America. Bellow could speak Yiddish and French learned in his days in Quebec Province. Bellow loved America and his hometown of Chicago and celebrates this culture in his many novels and short stories. He is a cerebral writer willing to experiment and expand the novelistic form. His influences were wide from Dickens to Flaubert to Henry Fielding and many others. The reader awaits for the second volume of this sterling biography of a great American and world caliber author.

As a Presbyterian minister I was intrigued by Stephen King's novel "Revival.' The story is narrated by Jamie Morton as he recounts growing up in the rural backwater of Maine in the 1960s. One day a new minister named Charles Jacobs arrives in town to begin his first pastorate. Charles and James become close friends as the preacher wows the youth group with his electric Jesus and ability to make electricity a teaching tool. Rev. Jacobs even heals people until a horrible accident ruins his ministry in Maine. Over the years we see how Jamie becomes a rock guitar player strung out on heroin until he meets up with Rev. Jacobs. This reviewer does not want to reveal the plot as it will decrease the reader's enjoyment of another strong entry. Stephen King is an American icon despite what ivory tower professors may say about his writing style. What a mind this man has as he tells his story. A relatively short novel but one that is hard to put down! Enjoy!

Ludwig Von Beethoven was born in Bonn on December 16, 1770. His father Johann was a professional musician at the ecclesiastical court of an Elector of the Holy Roman Empire. His mother was beloved by Beethoven,. The genius spent years learning the piano under the harsh tutelage of his father and several outstanding teachers. At the age of eighteen he traveled to Vienna to make his reputation as a freelance musician. Beethoven studied with Papa Haydn and met the incomparable Mozart. Fame followed for him as a great pianist and composer of nine symphonies, countless choral and instrumental works and his only opera Fidelio.  Beethoven was a hard man to love and had a complex personality. He was a functioning alcoholic, was sloppy and ugly with a pockmarked face. LVB courted several aristocratic women though he remained a bachelor until death. His was combative and aggressive in business but underneath all he had a good heart. Beethoven suffered greatly from encroaching deafness and stomach ailments. His health was poor throughout his life. Swafford states that three supreme artists represented genius in the Romantic movement of the nineteenth century in Germany: Kant in philosophy; Goethe in literature and Beethoven in music. Along with Shakespeare he towers as one of the greatest geniuses of all time. This long biography of nearly one thousand pages is difficult to read for those like myself who are unable to read music. Swafford spends many pages in a detailed analysis of the major Beethoven works. Nevertheless, the book is outstanding for general readers who want to examine the beautiful and profound music of Beethoven. This is a great biography which every music lover should read and savor.

Review: THE ENFIELD HORROR TRILOGY by Ron RipleyWow, what a story! THE ENFIELD HORROR TRILOGY definitely wins my commendation for implacability in horror [a necessary criterion for me] and oh!! that powerful, knock-out ending! I couldn't stop turning pages. I've been a huge fan of Ron Ripley since reading the outstanding BOYLAN HOUSE TRILOGY, and this one is just as good. Don't miss it--but do read in the sunlight.

REVIEW: TOM AND THE COLORFUL DRAGON by Ortal Zeret, Hadas Korb, Emily Zieroth (illustrator)A delightfully heartwarming bedtime story, TM AND THE COLORFUL DRAGON relates the tale of a lucky little boy who receives a very special birthday gift from  grandparents: a toy dragon which is much more than a toy. It's a very special friend.Highly recommended.

REVIEW: TOM AND THE COLORFUL DRAGON by Ortal Zeret, Hadas Korb, Emily Zieroth (illustrator)A delightfully heartwarming bedtime story, TM AND THE COLORFUL DRAGON relates the tale of a lucky little boy who receives a very special birthday gift from  grandparents: a toy dragon which is much more than a toy. It's a very special friend.Highly recommended.

Review: CLOSURE by Larry QuartleyFrom a stunning first chapter that blew me away, CLOSURE hits the ground at near the speed of light.From there it's nonstop and I couldn't put it down. Author Larry Quartley has an articulate, literate, approach which shines gemlike in the context of a plot both gritty and noir-ish. I eagerly anticipate this author's next entry.

Review: CAESAR AMERICANUS: AN AMERICAN CIVIL WAR -INTO TYRANNY by John-Allen PriceOne of my special interests is alternative history. Since childhood I've been a "what if?" person. I am overjoyed to discover (thanks to NetGalley) the exceptional independent historian and author John-Allen Price. INTO TYRANNY is the first volume in an incredible alternate rendering of not just the U.S., but Europe, on the eve of World War II. [Socialist France! The U. S. on the verge of Fascism!]Mr. Price not only paints the broad landscape of politics and politicians, of war and peace, of the American economy post-Depression. He also delineates human emotions: greed and respect, aggression and compassion, ego and altruism, grief and surrender, vengeance and hope. His chapters on the American populace's grief at FDR's early and untimely death in 1939 made me weep; it was similar, for me, to the grieving at the assassination of JFK. Even the characters who loom larger than life are still clearly individualized: the late FDR and Hitler, MacArthur and Patton, Hoover, Father Coughlin, Huey Long.INTO TYRANNY is an incredible novel. The next volume of CAESAR ANERICANUS: AN AMERICAN CIVIL WAR, INTO FIRE, releases December 1.The author and publisher generously provided a digital ARC via NetGalley, for review purposes only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: DEADLY DELICIOUS by K. L. LinuxMagic--conjure and hoodoo--suffused this delectable cozy, as  a young girl is caught between a fire demon and its evil female adversary . Josephine Elle DeLune is the child of a Parisian chef and a renowned soul food chef. Living in little Paris, Missouri, is far from haute cuisine, but still Josephine is a danger in the kitchen. She really must come to terms with her magic...before it overcomes her permanently.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review:  KIDS BOOKS: FAMILY FUN SERIES: Volume 1  by Mae Segeti and Nic MontyThis volume contains 3 books:LET'S GO TO THE FAIRLET'S MAKE CREPESLET'S GO TO THE PARKThe first tells of a fun outing for the three siblings--Ben, Zach, and little Chelsea--with Grandma. The second describes learning to cook with Mom (and Dad). In the third, the family visits the park (and meet a mischievous puppy). All three promote family harmony and close interaction, teaching respect for others, and responsibility. These are good for parents or grandparents to read to younger children, while elementary -age readers will be happy to tackle the stories on their own.

REVIEW:  WE ARE MONSTERS by Brian KirkDon't come to this novel expecting only light-hearted horror [is that an oxymoron?]. WE ARE MONSTERS will inspire you to think, ponder, consider, and wonder. WE ARE MONSTERS is psychological horror, suspense, mystery, thriller. Brian Kirk pulls no punches. Clearly he has researched the spotty and often unpleasant, even ugly, history of mental health "treatment." His two opposing protagonists, Dr. Eli Alpert  and Dr. Alex Drexler, are both highly-educated, intelligent, psychiatrists, with experience. But they are so divergent-how can they harmonize? Eli believes in respect, Alex in pharmacology. Indeed, Alex is working on a formula to affect a complete cure from mental disorder.WE ARE MONSTERS poses a conundrum pondered for centuries by great minds:  what constitutes insanity? Who is insane? Who is qualified to determine? What treatment can be effective, and at what cost to the patient? In the end, we all are monsters.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review:I've been searching for a product to carry my iPhone and keys while outdoors. I don't jog, but I do walk my dogs several times daily. This product is perfect. Phone and keys are with me, but out of my hands, and I don't worry about dropping either.
Good product. Very effective, especially so when used in Conjunction with metal lice comb [not included with this product]

Review: great product! The fragrance is light and appealing, the texture smooth and creamy, which I prefer to thinner, more liquidy moisturizers. Easily absorbed into the skin and feels good. I like to wait 24 hours after testing a skin or hair product because I am allergic to a lot of brands. DermaSafe came through with flying colors, and my skin feels smoother already. I will definitely make this a twice-daily product.

I absolutely love this scarf! It's beautiful, it's stylish, it's comfortable, it's warm. It's a perfect complement to my two red/black jackets and my full-length black coat. I don't often rave over fashion but this scarf is both gorgeous and well-designed--very attractive.

REVIEW: PET SHOP HEROES by Stanford CrowPET SHOP HEROES is truly delightful and magical!  A super read for elementary and middle grades, and with lovely and comical illustrations, great to read to younger children. Kids who love super heroes [what child doesn't?], magic and fantasy, or science, will each enjoy this story, which combines all of these, and gives a good moral lesson as well. I hope this will become a series of adventures for the four heroes of the pet shop.I joyfully reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author via NetGalley, for review purpose, at no remuneration.

Review: THE BONE BOX by Jay AmbergAn archaeological excavation in Turkey uncovers an ossuary with documents possibly dating from the first century A.D. If verifiable, these documents could change both religion and history. Now the race begins, either to translate, expose, and publicize; or to literally and figuratively bury the discovery and discredit the archaeologist. A grieving American businessman is trapped in the middle, coming to Turkey at the behest of the site's philanthropist, but kept very much in the dark as to the recent discovery, its wide-ranging ramifications, and all the hidden agendas involved.I reviewed  a digital copy provided free of charge by Partners in Crime Book Tours, for review and blog tour.

Review: THE ENFIELD HORROR by Ron RipleyI've been captivated by this author since devouring THE BOYLAN HOUSE TRILOGY.  THE ENFIELD HORROR is the first of a trilogy also, set in a bleak New Hampshire landscape where the residents are hardened and taciturn from decades of hard winters, and a failing economy. Up in the woods, violent storms have uncovered a long-abandoned hunting lodge. Abandoned, but not uninhabited, the lodge appears newer and newer, attracting the attention of hikers. Unfortunately for area residents, that which had been confined deep inside the lodge has now been released, and it's very, very hungry.THE ENFIELD HORROR presents an entity new to me, sentient and willful. I anticipate the next entries in the trilogy.
This is so delightful! I loved it both as a dog lover and a grandmother of small children. What imaginative suggestions! Young children will adore hearing/reading the rhymes.

REVIEW: STRONG LIGHT OF DAY by Jon LandThe useful term "prolific author" might have been termed for Jon Land, with 38 novels in 3 series pus stand-alones. Mr. Land's novels constitute the "thinking person's thriller." STRONG LIGHT OF DAY is the seventh entry in the Caitlin Strong series, featuring the fifth-generation Texas Ranger noted for her interference in others' business and her insistence on modifying others' behavior (frequently at gunpoint). Very visceral and very outspoken, STRONG LIGHT OF DAY is also notably vivid and not easily forgotten. Ranger Caitlin Strong is an unforgettable character who stands on her own and stands out, loved or hated but never overlooked.I reviewed a digital copy generously provided by the author, via Partners in Crime Tours, to review for a Book blog tour, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: LICENSED TO THRILL 5 by Diane CapriIf I had to select my 3 favorite male series protagonists, they would be Lee Child's Jack Reacher, Preston & Child's Agent Pendergast, and Sam Witt' s Night Marshal Joe Hark of Pitchfork County. All 3 are masculine, strong in character and physique--and eccentric and individualistic. Needless to say, I devour every book in which they appear. But in the case of Jack Reacher, there is even more to love.. Prolific author Diane Capri writes a series on "the Hunt for Jack Teacher" in which two intrepid FBI agents virtually crisscross the continent, in and out of danger, on a quest promulgated by their superior. He has his own, unspecified, reasons. Agents Kim Otto and Carlos Gaspar frequently exhaust themselves searching for the iconic, elusive, invisible Reacher; but oh, what great enjoyment for readers!!LICENSED TO THRILL 5 is a boxed set containing Books 4-6 in the "HUNT FOR JACK REACHER" series:GET BACK JACKJACK IN THE GREENJACK AND JOE.These don't  have to be read in order, nor must you have read all of Lee Child's Reacher series. (But don't you want to read every book in both series? I know I do.)The author, Diane Capri, generously provided a digital ARC, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: EMBRACING THE WILD IN YOUR DOG by Bryan BaileyWow!! Never your ordinary dog book here! Bryan Bailey comes barreling out of nowhere (actually, out of Nature and evolution) with an entirely new standpoint. That dog you think you own (in my case, they own me) is not just some domesticated, human-trained creature, here for its owner's delectation. Sorry: that "dog" is a domestic wolf, product of millions of years of evolution; and as Wolf is, so is Dog.Author Bailey advises: look at Nature! Examine Wolf behavior! Here is where you will find the template for your Dog-- not by studying human behavior and interactions. It's definitely an education in which I intend to engage.I devoured a digital copy generously provided by the author, via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration,

Review: SALVAGE by Duncan RalstonOne of the best debut novels I have ever perused, SALVAGE had me enrapt from the very beginning. A terrifyingly real portrait of depression and grief, SALVAGE is also an intense tale of life after life, of extension of life powered by Will, rage, and intense commitment to something beyond oneself: group, principle, religious belief, mental disorder.I joyfully reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author, via NetGalley, for review purpose, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: CRIMSON SHORE by Douglas Preston & Lincoln ChildI am ecstatic to discover with CRIMSON SHORE that  my decades of fascination with the elusive, eccentric, and deep FBI Special Agent A. F. X. Pendergast (of New Orleans) has returned, after 2014's BLUE LABYRINTH (which I still haven't completed). CRIMSON SHORE unfolds with the high quality and puzzling multiple mysteries of which Pendergast is past master. Incited by a theft case at the isolated Massachusetts lighthouse residence of a sculptor and oenophile. Where the useless police chief is clueless, Pendergast uncovers mystery after mystery, this time allowing his ward Constance Greene to accompany him in the investigation.The small Massachusetts community near the sculptor' s home immediately reminded me of Lovecraft' s Innsmouth, that fishy seaside community, and indeed, as Pendergast and Constance soon discover, Exmouth has over the centuries been noted for its contingent of evil, especially in the 18th and 19th centuries. Pendergast uncovers evidence of demonisn and a 19th century ship disappearance. Quickly it's  evident that the wine theft was not the point, but a cover-up for the actual theft.. .and the brutal and bizarre murders continue.I gladly reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the authors and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: DEAD-EYED GOD by Sam WittI fell in love with Sam Witt' s fictional Pitchfork County from the first pages of HALF-MADE GIRLS, and I have devoured its incredible tales ever since. The newest, DEAD-EYED GOD (November 2015) blew me away, and I can only ponder " Where in the Universe can the author go from here?"Pitchfork County's Night Marshal Joe Hark, a character after my own heart, takes on a trifecta of evil in this story. Elder gods with whom he has battled bloodily in the recent past return, combining with a new [really gross] threat. If DEAD-EYED GOD doesn't chill your spine, curl your hair, and make you weep--then you don't recognise true horror.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: MANIFESTATION WOLVERINE by Ray Young BearReaders who love exploring the vast intricacies of the English language but find most poetry difficult and time-consuming deserve to be introduced to the imaginative creativity of Ray Young Bear, a Native American poet and musical artist whose poetry makes the language both sing and dance. MANIFESTATION WOLVERINE includes the earlier collections, WINTER OF THE SALAMANDER; THE INVISIBLE MUSICIAN; and THE ROCK ISLAND HIKING CLUB; as well as new pieces.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW:  LOOK BOTH WAYS by Carol J. Perry[WITCH CITY MYSTERY #3]At once both intriguing and engrossing, LOOK BOTH WAYS is third in the exciting WITCH CITY MYSTERY series, set in that most magical and mysterious community, historic Salem. Massachusetts. After ten years in television, Lee Barrett has returned to her childhood home, a recently renovated Victorian, to reside with her reference librarian aunt. Synchronicity leads Lee to locate and purchase a rare antique bureau seemingly identical to hers, lost when the upper stories of the home burned. This bureau also contains cleverly concealed compartments, and had been owned by a woman allegedly murdered by her husband. Lee has barely installed her new bureau, when she discovers the shopowner murdered, and the race is in for intrepid Lee to discover the murderer' s identity before the killer can silence Lee permanently.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley for review purpose only at no remuneration.

My terrier tends to get odorous, even though he's a house dog, and he hates baths!so I thought to try this-and it's perfect forever few days, between-shampooing, touch-ups! Works great on my big dog too!

REVIEW: SENTINELS by Matt ManochioAuthor Matt Manochio debuted with THE DARK SERVANT in 2014, a novel which subsumed contemporary suburbia into Teutonic medieval legend, and consequently scared me senseless. In SENTINELS, he tackles an ugly historical era and turns it inside out. Reconstruction in the American South was probably, along with the Civil War, the most widespread brutal period in U.$  history. In SENTINELS, the horror is both man-made [ignorance, bigotry, jingoism, the Ku Klux Klan] and otherworldly: unearthly, destroying both friend and foe, good folks and bad. But there are also strong characters, such as Sheriff's Deputy Noah Chandler and freedman Toby Jenkins, whose integrity shines in an era of dross. Yet will they be sufficient to withstand the otherworldly forces summoned to protect--forces bloody, unbeatable, and implacable?I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: DROP DEAD PUNK by Rich ZahradnikA well-written, fast-paced suspense thriller set in the month in 1975 when New York City's financial concerns nearly teetered over the precipice into bankruptcy, DROP DEAD PUNK sends veteran reporter Coleridge Taylor on his second adventure, this time to a paired murder in Alphabet City--one dead cop, one dead punk. Just maybe Taylor might be covering his yearned-for front page story after all.I reviewed a digital copy via Partners in Crime Tours, provided by the author solely for review  purpose. No remuneration was exchanged.

REVIEW: GOOD DOGS, GREAT LISTENERS:  THE STORY OF CHARLOTTE, LILY, AND THE LISTENERSby Renata BowersOh, I love this delectable children's book!! What a great lesson it contains, and such vividly depicted imagination! Young Charlotte dreams of being a vet--but as yet she doesn't comprehend the long years of diligent study. She has a wonderfully exercised imagination ("the Litter" consists of her several beloved stuffed pets), but she doesn't love to read. In fact, Charlotte doesn't like reading at all. Until one day....I reviewed a digital copy generously provided by the author via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW:  ANOMALY FLATS by Clayton SmithHow do I love ANOMALY FLATS? Just let me count the ways. First, the title. For a reader who is fascinated with science, science fiction, horror, and the English language, the title alone is sufficient to excite my admiration and quicken my heartbeat. Twilight Zone, Missouri: here we come!!Second, the blurb: One of my favorite books of recent years [a novel which always reminds me of an Outer Limits version of Los Alamos and the Manhattan Project: "what if?"] Is Robert Jackson Bennett's AMERICAN ELSEWHERE: a small Southwestern community which is--different, in oh so many ways.So too is little Anomaly Flats, Missouri. Tucked away beyond primevally immense forests, Anomaly Flats Is a most special locale. Its ongoing charm is hypnotic. So magnetic--I hope to be moving there shortly. [Smile]I reviewed a digital copy, generously provided directly by the publisher, Dapper Press, solely for review purpose, at no remuneration.

NOVEMBER MOD READ: THE PROFESSOR by Robert BaileyTHE PROFESSOR is an incredibly polished, truly larger-than-life novel. I'm not fond of converting books to film, but the nature of this novel is so vast that in itself, it resembles the Big Screen. From the first episode, I felt as if I viewed the events, not visualized them. Secondly, there's so much here that in a lesser hand than author Robert Bailey's, would have been rendered trite and flat, two-dimensional. Good VS. Evil. Greed vs. Common humanity. Lust vs. Integrity. Instead, it is all fully rendered, consuming, encompassing, and engrossing.I won't go into deep detail--the novel speaks for itself--but you owe this immense reading experience to yourself. According to the author note, Mr. Bailey went through 3 complete rewrites. Whatever he did produced a seamless and perfect narrative. I can't speak to the legal matters, nor to the Alabama settings, but characterization rings true and powerful, and the pace, especially during the trial, is rapid-fire. I recommend THE PROFESSOR wholeheartedly and without reservation! It ought to be required repeated reading for all debut and budding authors: THIS is how you polish the craft.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: PLAYING WITH FIRE by Tess GerritsenI shan't forget this new novel, a masterpiece of music, writing, and history. As we turn the pages, following the quest of accomplished professional violinist Julia to uncover the history and lineage of a waltz she discovers in a Rome antiques shop, the clues seem to always be hidden just around each corner. Yet like Julia we persevere unstintingly, refusing to turn away unrewarded.As Julia's story unfolds in the present day, we are treated to the unfolding of one of history's most infamous periods, the alliance of Naziism with Mussolini' s Fascist Italy during World War II, and the horrendous suffering and destruction of Italian Jews. In unfolding the story of the waltz "Incendio," Julia incites secrets held for decades.Be aware:  PLAYING WITH FIRE will most definitely break your heart.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley for review purpose, at no remuneration.

REVIEW:  DEVIL'S ROW by Matt SerafiniSome readers will enjoy DEVIL'S ROW as a prequel to FERAL. Others will acclaim it as excellent, breath-taking historical werewolf fantasy. Me? For me, it's the lyricism and the imagery: Mr. Serafini 's prose flows like poetry. I never thought a battlefield could be made to seem poetic, but I found that here. I know the phrase "not your ordinary werewolf story" is trite; but if it doesn't apply here, it applies nowhere. THIS is literary Werewolf prose-poetry.The author generously gifted a digital copy for review purpose, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: A WINTER WEDDING by Brenda NovakChristmas is approaching for Whisky Creek, a charming small community in California's Gold Country. So is major snow cover--and a celebrity. Solar manufacturer Kyle Houseman has the ex from Hades, a pestering money drain. Suddenly he acquires the tenant from heaven, country singer Lourdes. She is rabidly isolated, and her determination to avoid fan discovery throws them together, at the advent of a snowstorm sure to isolate the comm tunity. Welcome to magical, romantic, Whisky Creek at Christmastide.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: FLIPPED FOR MURDER by Maddie Day [Country Store Mysteries #1]A delightfully enticing and tasty cozy mystery set in Southern Indiana (a scenic region that doesn't receive enough fictional attention, in my view), FLIPPED FOR MURDER is a page-turner starring Robbie (Roberta) Jordan, former chef, daughter of a cabinetmaker mother. After her Mother's demise, Robbie visits tiny South Link, Indiana, home of her aunt Adele and her Mother's hometown, and falls head over heels with the community's gentle enduring pace. Both a chef and cabinetry artist at heart, Robbie buys a country store building and turns it into the revitalized Pans 'n Pancakes, a combination restaurant and country store featuring vintage cookware. The night of her glorious grand opening, however, Robbie's only opposition,the mayor's assistant, is discovered murdered--with evidence directly suggesting Robbie.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, without remuneration.

Review: SHUNNEDThis novel, a literary exploration of the inroads of the pharmaceutical industry and of a marriage after one of its foundations has been knocked asunder, has strong and intentional overtones resonating of Nathaniel Hawthorne' s classic tale "The Scarlet Letter" (the minister's wife commits a crime, is jailed, then shunned and ostracized; the CEO' s surname is Dimsdale; the community is small and insular). Yet throughout I was constantly reminded of the Old Testament Book of Hosea, in which a humble, godly prophet is commanded by God to forgive and forgive and forgive his philandering wife, demonstrating mercy. In SHUNNED, Baptist minister Amos experiences the call to prophet role following the suicide of his son John due to an overdose of antidepressant medication. Simultaneously his wife Carrie experiences a call to activism, vandalizing  the local pharmaceutical plant, being jailed instead of receiving community service. The "A" on her jail uniform, for her surname, symbolizes the immediacy and extent of her ostracism from a community which ignores her very present grief and labels it insanity.SHUNNED is a very thought-provoking tale, not easily overlooked, nor forgotten.I reviewed a digital copy, generously provided by the author, via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

I reviewed for Partners in Crime Tours. The author generously provided a digital copy.REVIEW: FORECLOSURE: A NOVEL by S. D. ThamesCommercial litigator David Friedman has worked punishing hours for seven years in order to make junior partner; but on cusp of 2008, his dream fails. He's already lost his future wife; his dream of blues guitar like his dad, long ago shunted aside. Now his partnership hope has dissolved. So will he resign? Or will David jump through another year of hoops designed by the philandering, often intoxicated, managing partner?David perceives that he has been betrayed, cheated, by the partners, particularly the managing partner. His choices now are three: bill even more hours for the calendar year of 2008, providing yet more immense profits for the partners; resign; or get revenge. He chooses extortion, of the managing partner and the other senior partner, and corporate espionage on a potential client bank, of an account handled by the man who is David's ex-girlfriend's current boyfriend. He seems determined to take down everyone who's crossed him!I enjoyed the novel, but I was never sure how to feel or think about the protagonist, David Friedman. I tried to empathize, but he often seems so emotionless and robotic [witness his "speech" about how everything is business, all choices are actually business decisions (I.e., survival, money, greed, "getting ahead.") And all this delivered to his former girlfriend] . Then, as revenge against his firm, he takes on a client he should have left well enough alone. It's almost like he's living out a death wish.I chose FORECLOSURE as the October Mod Read at Goodreads group Anything Legal.

Review: OTHERNATURALS Book Three: BLOODFATHER by Christina HarlinI've been enraptured by this series since the first pages of Book One. Here we get to find out psychic Andrew's background, and why he had disappeared from the paranormal world for a decade, after a tragedy in Chicago high society.Stefan, his deceased friend-companion Brentley, and Kay, p,ay startling roles too.We also encounter a type of ghost powered by blood magick, called "bloodfather."  This construct powered by belief, egotism, insanity, and blood might prove to be more than even the vastly talented Othernaturals can conquer.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author for review purpose, via NetGalley, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: DANGEROUSLY DARK by Colette London[A Chocolate Whisperer Mystery]Acclaimed "chocolate whisperer" Hayden Mundy Moore, she of the exquisitely sensitive taste buds, is fresh from her recent discovery of a murder victim in the San Francisco Bay area, and anticipating leisure and fun visiting college friend Carissa in hip, bohemian Portland, Oregon. She's not expecting to be Jenny-on-the-spot with yet another corpse, nor to be pressed into service to fulfill the deceased' s "Chocolate After Dark" Tour. At least it's chocolate, after all.This second in the series which debuted with CRIMINAL CONFECTIONS will definitely appeal to foodies, chocaholics, aficionados of smart, feisty, heroines, and armchair travelers such as this reviewer who enjoy learning local color.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW:  INSINCERE by Joanne Clancy[Elizabeth Ireland Series Book Two]Author Joanne Clancy leads readers on a merry mystery chase in this second installment starring protagonist Elizabeth Ireland, former detective with London's Metropolitan Police, more recently private investigator in Cork, Ireland [and close personal friend of the local Chief Superintendent]. Elizabeth reminds me much of Angela Marsden' s series protagonist, DI Kim Stone, but I find Elizabeth mire abrasive and solitary. Throughout the story she seems almost destined to be close, but not quite there--yet she perseveres, and readers will revel at the constant mind-turning twists.

Review: WATER ON THE MOONLiterate women's fiction whose premise is almost unheard-of, WATER ON THE MOON put me in mind of a New England pen sister of Anne Rivers Siddons or Lee Smith. The kind of richly satisfying novel to take to the beach or to a mountain cabin on vacation, WATER ON THE MOON is the story of an older mother of adolescent twin daughters. Lidia is awakened early one morning, in the nick of time to save herself, her twins Carly and Clarisse, and their dog Opal (herself a rescue dog). What can't be saved us their farmhouse, the only home any of them have ever known, the home of four generations. A private plane,with a single female pilot, crash lands on the house--a plane whose flight plan scheduled it to be several states away. What caused this life-altering event?The author generously provided a digital copy for review purpose and blog tour, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: THE DEAD STUDENT by John KatzenbachA compelling and truly deeply convoluted novel of psychological suspense, terror, addiction and recovery, psychosis, revenge, and murder. Yes, this novel contains all that, and rivets the reader. Commencing with the apparent suicide of  noted middle-aged Miami psychiatrist, the storyline proves to be not only contemporary, but three decades in the making; with a cold, clever, planning killer who is not the garden-variety psychopath.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley and Edelweiss.

REVIEW: DARK SCREAMS VOLUME FIVEThe outstanding DARK SCREAMS series from esteemed Cemetery Dance Publications is consistent for high-quality horror. I hope the series continues into infinity, as long as readers and writers of horror exist. This installment offers two of my long-time favorites, Kealan Patrick Burke and Bentley Little, plus Mick Garris, J. Kenner, and Del James. If your goal is a surfeit of scares in a compact package, not to be read after lights' out, here it is.I reviewed a digital ARC via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at noremuneration.

REVIEW: A VANISHING GLOW by Alexis Radcliff(THE MYSTECH ARCANUM VOL. I & II)An utterly fascinating and intriguing blending of epic fantasy with cyberpunk,  A VANISHING GLOW proves yet again that even non-aficionados can fall in love with a well-written and intriguing fantasy . This volume includes the first two novels in this series: SHATTERED DREAMS and DARK OMENS. Volume WII is in production.The author generously provided a digital ARC for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: MUTATION Z: CLOSING THE BORDERSMUTATION Z BOOK ONE impressed me with its vivid reality. Set in a West Africa treatment center in the jungle, staffed specifically (and allegedly) to treat Ebola symptoms and strive to mitigate the suffering. Also impressive were the author's use of the necessary nitty-gritty details and the personalization of the danger through a young American medical worker. When an educated First World professional like Emma is injected with the disease, and temporarily becomes something irrational and antagonistic, you know that you're reading very deep, very possible, near-future possibilities.BOOK TWO: CLOSING THE BORDERS expands the medical research of the Mutation Z program, alluding to its political backers and pharmaceutical company hand-in-hand with certain unscrupulous politicians AND the military, for whom the potential uses of Mutation Z are endless and all are optimal.The author generously provided a digital copy for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: THE LOST GIRLS by Gwen MoffatHere is yet another mystery which has my highest praise. Gwen Moffat is in the pantheon with Angela Marsden and S. J. Bolton. She takes a sad little town in England's Lake District, abandoned 45 years ago for a dam [another subject I can never resist] and sets in it a series of crimes and sinful behavior, all of which never seem to come to light. Well, not for 45 years, and a continuing severe drought that begins to uncover the drowned village. Now, of course, a whole new series of crimes commences, but their inspiration is long, long, buried...I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: DEADLY MESSENGERS by Susan MayRelease Sept. 15 2015EXPECT THE UNEXPECTED. That's what DEADLY MESSENGERS delivers on every page! Riveting, engrossing, mysterious: the suspense is immense, clues dangle tantalizingly just out of reach [and sight], and the events seem like they should be impossible--the content of horror films--but yet they occur, and continue to occur, leaving law enforcement as much stultified as the news-devouring public. Such tragedies just don't happen...yet they do. Implacability is the hallmark of this novel, as it is the hallmark of horror for me. Superbly written and tautly crafted, DEADLY MESSENGERS is the creation of a far-ranging imaginationI reviewed a digital copy generously provided by the author, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: CAILLOU AND THE BIG BULLY by Christine L' HeureuxBullying is an issue that needs to be addressed at any level. Here Caillou is victimized by a bigger, more aggressive boy at day care. Caillou' s parents and teacher work to find peaceable solutions.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: CAILLOU: EMMA'SEXTRA SNACKS --LIVING WITH DIABETES by Anne ParadisI'm sad that such an issue exists--young children with diabetes--but glad that it can be addressed in a manner helpful to children with this disease, and to their friends. Caillou is puzzled--and a little envious--that his good friend Emma gets more frequent snacks at preschool. Their teacher carefully explains the situation, and Emma talks about how it effects her. Later she proves to Caillou that she can still be fit and active.Written in cooperation with the American Diabetes Association. (the print edition contains an ADA poster,)I reviewed a digital ARC generouusly provided by the author and publisher via NetGalkey, for review purpose, at no remuneration.

Review: DEADLY LULLABY by Robert McClureDEADLY is the key word when operating in the Los Angeles underworld. You won't see any pretty side of the vast city here. Instead, it's all grit and gore, seamy underbelly and crime, crime, crime. The moral lesson here might be: "if you did the time, be smart: no more crime." even a clever criminal's luck will run out. The publisher recommends this for readers of Harlan Coben and Robert Crais. My suggestion is: for fans of the down-and-dirty, impossibly gritty noir of Frank Bill, Jim Thompson, and Ken Bruen.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose, without remuneration.

Review: CAILLOU: LIGHTS OUT by Chouette Publishing and Eric SevignyAn electrical blackout can be a scary time even for adults. For young Caillou and even younger Rosie, the lights going off at supper time is frightening. Fortunately, Mommy and Daddy have flashlights and candles, and a wonderful campout supper is fixed over the fireplace. Then everyone "camps" in the living room to sleep, and when morning comes, the snow has stopped, the sun is out, and the power is on. A heartwarming delight for Caillou fans.I reviewed  a digital ARC generously provided by the publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: CAILLOU: THE SCHOOL BUS by Marion JohnsonI test-drove this picture-and-text book for young readers on my nearly  four-year-old  granddaughter, a real Caillou fan. Of course she loved it. She enjoyed turning to each new page and identifying each illustration as I read the text posted.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: COUNTDOWN TO DEATH by Iain McChesney36 stars for this wonderfully imaginative, well-created, and finely-tuned, "locked room" style mystery!  It kept me puzzling throughout, choosing first one villain then another,  but the author kept ahead of  me throughout, leading this reader on a merry chase. I cut my mystery teeth on Dame Agatha Christie's AND THEN THERE WERE NONE. I 've never forgotten it, and I venture to state that COUNTDOWN TO DEATH is every bit as memorable. It certainly highly impressed thus reviewer.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: LIGHTLESS by C. A. HigginsI love many genres and subgenres, but when I'm engrossed in the midst of British crime fiction, something special is required to jolt my attention. LIGHTLESS did it. This outstanding science fiction debut left me breathless--and yearning impatiently for more. There's a kickin'9 female protagonist with a steel-trap mind akin to the illustrious Stephen Hawking, a spaceship she knows like she knows her own mind, a three-person crew, a System which makes Orwell' s 1984 resemble a child's sandbox, two very efficient terrorist-thieves-saboteurs--oh, it's just glorious. A must-read on so many counts!I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: PRETTY GIRLS by Karin SlaughterPRETTY GIRLS is the novel from which BLONDE HAIR, BLUE EYES is the predecessor.  Like modern life, one of the underlying themes is missing young women, whether runaways, abducted and murdered, trafficked--no one knows, not police, family, nor media. Claire Scott, married nearly 20 years, is the younger sibling of a girl disappeared [the narrator of the single BLONDE HAIR BLUE EYES] and suffers her own legal difficulties. But all she has known pales in the face of the truth. PRETTY GIRLS shares author Karin Slaughter 's trademark twists and denouements.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purposes only, at no remuneration.

Review: BROTHER by Ania AhlbornAnia Ahlborn has been a must-read author since her first publication. In BROTHER, she examines the history and contemporary practice of a group which might be considered the ultimate dysfunctional family. What delight anthropologists might find here!  The title noun proves to have multiple meanings, but a reader must persevere to discover them. Although violence is a foundational component of the story line [and will perturb the sensitive] I found that the real horror lay in the emotional and psychological arenas.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purposes only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: DEAD MAN'S BLUFF by Roderic JeffriesHeartwarming, delightfully convoluted, peopled win characters both enduring and pesky, DEAD MAN'S BLUFF is pure classic British country mystery, penned by an author of more than 160 novels. The juxtaposition of dedicated rural detection vs. sophisticated  city Detective Superintendent driven to success is scintillating, and impels the storyline. This mystery is so cleverly done as to keep readers guessing. Roderic Jeffries ocean author worth reading, any time.

REVIEW: THE TRUTH ABOUT CAROLINE by Randi M. ShermanCaroline was three decades late for the Sixties' Free Love era, but nonetheless she persevered in exploring her sensuality while doing as little useful activity as possible, shirking responsibility, and deliberately appearing muddle-headed. She fulfilled the phrase, "of no redeeming social value." When she had a good relationship, she purposely messed up, becoming pregnant with twins, and marrying the birth dad, who then ran off to the army.Two decades later, his proclivity for streetwalkers ends him in an untimely grave, and subsequently, his widow, who can't organize her way out of a paper bag, ends up in jail, charged with hiring his killing. Poor Caroline...out of the frying pan, into the fire, out of the fire, in it again. If this was a comic strip of the 1950's, Caroline would wear a permanent Doom-Cloud above her head. Some people just can't win.The author generously provided a digital copy, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

REVIEW: AIN'T NO GRAVE [THE PENANCE OF LEATHER #1]  by S. A. SoftleyA search for literate end-of-the-world narrative will lead you right here, to AIN'T NO GRAVE, in every aspect far from the usual routine apocalyptic. AIN'T NO GRAVE is creatively imagined, lyrical, and thought-provoking. It ought to be on the bookshelf of every aficionado of The End.I reviewed a digital copy generously provided by the author, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

Review: TIME TO DIE by Caroline MitchellSecond in the paranormal  series featuring English Detective Constable Jennifer Knight as a sort of psychic detective. A member of the detachment known as Operation Moonlight, Jennifer's gifts are put on the line, and in danger, while simultaneously tensions among her immediate family are exploding. The villain here is one of the oldest I've ever encountered, and he kills by proxy, both factors adding to the intrigue. Additionally, the paranormal levels are very high, which I totally enjoy. No suspension of disbelief needed here!I reviewed a digital copy generously provided through NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no,remuneration.

REVIEW: FEAR THE SILENCE by Iain CameronThis third entry in the DI Angus Henderson series finds the Scottish expatriate to Sussex Detective Inspector in the sights of a Brighton criminal gang into whose imports he has thrown a socket. Simultaneously his new Detective Chief Inspector commands his attention to a missing persons case, one Kelly Langton, former top model, wealthy businesswoman, mother of two, who has disappeared, without passport, clothing, or car. The case is not at all what it seems, and tosses the diligent DI into constant twists, dead ends, and imminent fatality.This is the kind of down home British police procedural I so admire.I reviewed a digital ARC generously provided by the author and publisher via NetGalley, for review purpose only, at no remuneration.

This book could use some editing.  I'm not sure if it's because she's not originally from America, or if it's just bad altogether.  With that being said, I was rather disappointed in this book's delivery.  While I don't expect anything profound from a supermodel, I do expect to be somewhat impressed.  I'm not a supermodel (most of the audience isn't), so it would have been interesting to read what her supermodel life is like - the trials and tribulations of a supermodel. While I do appreciate her vulnerability, the advice she gives is rather basic.  For instance, she had on shoes that was too big, and one flew off her foot as she was on the runway.  She smiled and walked on her toes, with one shoe on and one shoe off.  Well, I've had a shoe fly off before and life goes on, you can't just sit there and cry.  "Smile" is rather basic advice.  Maybe this book would have been better suited for a teenage audience?  (Her writing style is a little choppy, so it doesn't necessarily flow like Louise Hay's books or Doreen Virtue's books.  I would expect a published work to be polished, and the more I think about it, the more I think that this should be geared towards teenagers, or people with less life experience.)What I did enjoy and found impressive was her background and how she got in Dolly magazine.  This is what stood out for me.  Sharing more of those types of things (like her eyes being burned on shoot) would have made this book stand out from the rest of the other hundreds of thousands of self help books on the market.  Writing about a shoe falling off, not so much.  As a woman, I feel like most women have had that happen to them at some point in their lives.  I would not be opposed to reading "Embrace Yourself" though because her vulnerability is engaging and she is likable.

I liked the plot twists.  I always try to stay one step ahead of whatever I'm reading, and I couldn't do it with this book.  The ten horses had me guessing until we find out what that meant.I can overlook a few typos.  Unfortunately, there were some major issues with this book, which discredits Kendra as an English teacher.  I don't remember the exact passage, but I think she was discussing something along the lines of  "Janette and Pia . .  . her brother", referring to Justin.  If that's the case it should have been "Pia and Janette...her brother" (as the pronoun refers to the noun directly in front of it).  There were other issues, but this is the most glaring one.I knew that this was the fifth book of five, so it was disappointing that the very last thing the author has us focus on is Carl's letter, which we don't even hear his side (Kendra reads the letter fade to black).  What a cop out!  So there's no good excuse for them not to have stayed together, but what was his excuse?  We, the audience, would like to know.  Don't just leave us hanging.  This was a good book until the lame end about Carl.

I enjoyed the plot twists.  I had an inkling who the murderer was, but for different reasons than Kendra laid out.  (I wanted to scream when it was Trish with Rollins. Really, Trish?)Answers to Discussion Questions (which is a nice addition to this particular book):I enjoyed high school.  I'm a nerd and love learning:-)Kendra is a nosy, busy body, so I can only imagine that she had those traits in high school.  She reminds me of Lt. Columbo.  She's very persistent and pesky.  It isn't that surprising that she wasn't all that popular.Yes, Kendra had reason to be on high alert with Carl spending time with his ex.No, as Kendra didn't have secrets.Kendra was wrong and obviously doesn't listen to reason, but there wouldn't be a story if she did the right thing.I'm undecided on this question.  Some people can change, but most people don't.I was a little surprised that she was conflicted because she knew she was going to get married and get payback on Lynette for putting her in that mermaid bridesmaid's dress.  I think she just didn't want to marry Carl.  Had someone better offered her a proposal she definitely would have swooped up on it.  I have turned down a marriage proposal or two and it was because of the guys in question.  I think Kendra got caught up in the right now.  Rollins isn't the one either.It's a no brainer, what the heck is Trish doing with Rollins?  URGH!!!  Well, she is the polar opposite to Kendra.

I was laughing all throughout the book. These books (the Kendra Clayton books) are quickly read in about 12 hours, give or take an hour or two.  As usual, the perp is not who you think it is, and that's what I love about the series - the plot twists.
