Thumbing through my copy of FROM HERE TO FRATERNITY served as a reminder of how a once-mighty beacon of collegiate camaraderie has fallen to nothing more than stereotypical tabloid fodder.FROM HERE TO FRATERNITY states that it is the first and only comprehensive guide to fraternizes and sororities and statement still rings true.  While I have searched for an updated volume or a similar book, there are none available.  Even though the book is dated, its contents are still relevant and provide a handy education on the Greek system, the individual organizations, their histories and habits.  The presentation of the material is interesting and inviting with plenty of charts, lists, pictures and drawings throughout.  You do not have to be a member of the Greek system to appreciate what it offers.  All national fraternities and sororities are represented (including historically black organizations).  Egan presents the book as celebration and a touch of humor runs throughout (silly college kids).While FROM HERE TO FRATERNITY has a 1980s date stamp, it is still the most authoritative and honest education of the American fraternity/sorority system available to date.  These days, the media embraces anything negative associated with these organizations (whether it be hazing, binge-drinking or accusations of date rape); I consider myself fortunate that my fraternity experience happened in a much happier, light-hearted time 4 years of college was nothing more than an extension of childhood.  I treasure this book now as much as I did 30 years ago.

Pulled from historian Rick Atkinsons The Guns at Last Light (the third segment of his excellent World War II trilogy), BATTLE OF THE BULGE is designed to educate younger readers about Americas epic final battle in Western Europe.  While I feel the book does a fine job condensing the nuts and bolts of Hitlers Ardennes offensive, I felt the books presentation diminished its overall quality.As someone who was first introduced to World War II at the age of 11, I developed a passion for studying the conflict that has lasted to this day (over 35 years later).  To my surprise, my 8 year old daughter has cultivated a keen interest in the conflict and I have started to assemble a small World War II library for her.  A battle book aimed at young readers seemed to be a logical addition, but I soon realized it was a little too advanced for her budding knowledge.First and foremost, THE BATTLE OF THE BULGE does an excellent job encapsulating the battle and addresses almost every facet.  It sufficiently breaks down the essence of the battle into a multitude of interesting topics (weapons, personal accounts, key individuals, data, etc.); the chapters are brief and chock full of photos  the book certainly doesnt bore.  While I found the text easy to read/understand, it may be a hard pill to swallow for those younger than 10 (the suggested age range is 8-12 years of age).  Even though my daughter has a decent foundation of basic World War II knowledge, this book proved to be a challenge for her.  While it is understood that the Battle of the Bulge is a significant American battle, I am disappointed that this battle and D-Day are the only young reader adaptations offered from Atkinsons comprehensive trilogy (which covers the entire spectrum of US participation in the European Theatre) and would have preferred books summarizing each book of the trilogy to provide younger minds with a better understanding of how the Battle of the Bulge (and D-Day for that matter) were significant parts of a more significant event.  I see this book as being just one piece of a large puzzle  the other pieces are needed to see the full picture.Something else that I found irritating were the random silhouettes of planes, tanks and infantry that adorned the start of each chapter.  Rather than silhouettes of objects related to the Battle of the Bulge (an American/German battle), the images of a Soviet tank destroyer (SU-52?), an early war Soviet plane (Rata), a seaplane (the Bulge was fought inland) and what appears to be a column of infantry sporting Brodie helmets (British?) are repeatedly presented throughout the entire book.  Even worse, the section describing the weapons used in battle appears to use a silhouette of a modern day assault rifle and an image of a Soviet T-34 seems to be used as a description of a Sherman tank.  Maybe Im being picky, but there are certainly enough related photos/images readily available to match the topic being discussed and certainly no need for the use of unrelated/Eastern Front imagery.THE BATTLE OF THE BULGE provides an adequate synopsis of a major American battle in World War II, but its value is best served for young readers that are already familiar with the battles place in the war.

When I think of what kind of person it takes to pilot/co-pilot one of the most sophisticated military aircraft in the world, a 20 year old man certainly isnt what comes to mind.  But, 70+ years ago, 2nd Lt. Truman Smith was just that  too young to drink, inexperienced with women and life in general, but responsible for flying a 4-engine bomber deep into Germany at 27,000 ft. with 9 fellow crewmen much like himself.  THE WRONG STUFF clearly reveals how the war fought in the skies of Europe was never a glamorous affair and certainly no safer than the battles being fought by the ground-pounders below.Smith explains in his introduction that the books title, THE WRONG STUFF, is about Natures Law of Equal and Opposite  the good offsetting the bad and right offsetting the wrong.  While the book is one mans vivid account of his wartime experience in a B-17, its also a testament that the good of winning the war was offset by the cumulative effect of the bad  mishaps, mistakes and bad luck  the wrong stuff.  Rather than simply telling his story, Smith chooses to actually take readers back with him to experience what he went through first-hand  the movie vividly plays out while your read!The book is presented in a unique manner.  The chapters seem to be misleading and/or mistitled, the text is choppy and Smith frequently emphasizes using ALL CAPS, but it oddly works  very well.  It only took me a few pages to get acclimated with his writing style and simply become immersed in the unfolding story.THE WRONG STUFF presents that sought after you-are-there/fly-on-the-wall feeling that allows readers to have a better understanding of what these young men had to go through.  While I hesitate to classify Smiths wartime duty as anything but serious and deadly, it is hard not to read his book and sense the whole affair as a grand adventure full of fear, frustration, misery and even humor (which was more a coping mechanism to offset the general sentiment that the odds favored a fiery death, severe injury or even captivity over surviving the mandatory 35 missions).  Smith documents each of the 35 missions he achieved and while some were more exciting to read about than others, they all presented challenges of one sort or another.  I found the interaction among Smith and his crewmates to be the most enjoyable aspect of the book as they all shared the burden together and developed a bond that centered on trust.  This bond also generated a great deal of humor, even in the heat of battle.  From the superstitious habit of kissing props and peeing on tent pegs before missions to the dilemma of suffering the runs and needing to relieve oneself at 27,000 ft. with German fighters attacking, Smith offers details of things Id never previously considered.  Its hard to imagine the author being only 20-years old considering his responsibilities, but when he reveals his inexperience with alcohol and women youre reminded hes still just a kid.  I find it equally amazing how vivid Smiths memory was in recounting his wartime service.THE WRONG STUFF is a terrific and unique account of the air war in Europe.  There are numerous books that detail events, but few that actually bring events to life like this book manages to do.

As a former powerlifter whose beloved gym is slowly transforming into a softer, more family-oriented facility; I see the gyms big money being steered toward cardio-related equipment, yoga, spinning, etc. while the free-weights section gets ignored.  Gone are the heavy-duty locking collars that we powerlifters and Olympic lifters needed to safely move heavy weights.  Instead, we get the cheap, metal spring clips that seemed to be purchased from a discount stores impulse-buy bin near the check-out line.  If youve ever experienced a side of weights sliding off a bar during a heavy squat workout because a cheap collar isnt doing its job, youre better off buying your own collars.  Im glad I opted for the LOCKJAW OLYMPIC BARBELL COLLAR.WHAT IT IS:- The LOCKJAW look and feel solidly built.  Each collar (you get 2) is made of hard nylon with molded rubber grips in the middle to grab the bar.  A simple lever serves to open the collar enough to slide onto the bar and clamp it down.  The collar fits snuggly on the standard Olympic barbells (50mm).HOW IT PERFORMS:- I generally only use Texas Power Bars for heavy lifting (squats, bench and deadlifts); but I have tested to the collars on York, Rogue and other generic bars in the gym.  The LOCKJAW provides the same snug grip on all bars I tested.- Tough.  I found the biggest test of these collars to be heavy deadlifts as the weights hit the floor rather hard.  Our gym has accumulated numerous sets of plates over the years and while the weights are accurate, they dont all line up evenly on the bar and tend to bang apart after each successive rep.  Spring clips are not sufficient in holding the plates together.  Uneven plates tend to jar spring clips loose, causing the plates to slide along the bar and make a lot of noise.  On one occasion, a spring clip freakishly flew off the bar.  The LOCKJAW works as well as the old spin collars, but they are lightweight and can be kept in my gym bag.  The collars stay secure through entire deadlift workouts and keep the plates tight and in place the whole time.- Easy on, easy off.  The thick wide lever is easy to hold and operate  good for both large and small hands.- The red LOCKJAWs look cool as well.Such gym gadgetry may seem superfluous, but I tend to enjoy the comfort and safety of using my own gear.  I find the LOCKJAW OLYMPIC BARBELL COLLAR a worthy purchase as they are easy to use, perform flawlessly and are quite durable.

A prime factor in having a blood pressure monitor available for home use is that you are apt to get more reliable/accurate readings in a relaxed environment.  The cold, clinical atmosphere of my doctor's office, combined with the anxiety of being examined for potential maladies has often led to me needing multiple readings due to odd results (which the nurse always attributes to "office visit nervousness").  The OMRON 7 SERIES BP MONITOR is a simple, high-quality tool that provides users a way of getting pertinent health information in the comfort of their own home.  Eliminating the cold nurse fingers, icy stethoscopes, rigid chairs, blinding fluorescent lighting and lab coated doctors scribbling who-knows-what in a file with your name on it significantly reduces one major contributor of negative BP results:  anxiety.WHAT IT IS:The OMRON 7 SERIES BP MONITOR is a rather simple device that consists of 2 major parts:  a monitor and an upper arm cuff that plugs into the monitor via rubber tube.  The device operates on 4 AA batteries (included) or AC adaptor (not included).  The arm cuff is secured by Velcro to ensure a snug fit and is suitable for larger arms.  A stop-start push button provides a one-step, no-nonsense process of monitoring blood pressure ... the user simply seats him/herself as instructed, wraps the cuff on the upper arm, pushes a button and waits a minute for the machine to test BP and show results.  The monitor offers numerical diastolic, systolic and heart-rate readings as well as light next to each vital that easily identify any exceeding the "healthy standard" (green light = normal range, orange = hypertension range).  The OMRON 7 SERIES is designed to separate/manage readings for 2 individuals and has Bluetooth capability for the purpose of viewing results on specified devices.PLUSES:- Commenting on the "accuracy" of such a device is traversing a slippery slope.  MY experience with the OMRON 7 SERIES BP MONITOR yielded lower numbers, but still in-line with my historical record of BP readings ... I contribute the lowered vitals solely to the elimination of "doctor office anxiety".- Ease of use:  Set up, function and readings are extremely user friendly.  The monitor unit has an angled face, grey background and large digital numbers that are easy to see.  I like the green and red light functions that offer an at-a-glance indication of "standard health" BP readings.  The monitor sits firmly on any hard, flat surface.  Can be set-up and used individually, with no assistance from others.- Up to 2 individuals can manage their BP in the OMRON 7; the unit will store 120 readings (up to 60 per user).  The monitor can even average readings (3 within a 10 minute period) for better accuracy.- The arm cuff accepts larger arms ... a big plus for me.  My lifestyle (powerlifter) has created problems with BP cuffs in the past.  While it states the cuff can handle arms up to 17 inches, this cuff fits snuggly on my arms (18+ inches) and yielded no deviation in my historical BP readings over the years.THE ONLY NEGATIVE I COULD FIND:- I cannot test the Bluetooth function.  No app for iPad 2 and no luck finding the android app to side-load to my Blackberry Z10.  After hijacking my daughter's Dell Venue tablet, I was able to retrieve the app but could not set up an account (the "submit" button was greyed-out/not functioning) ... frustrating.  While having ready access to BP history is not really a necessity for me, it might very well be for those who need such information available on a portable device (to share with their doctor).  The manufacturer states it is working on expanding Bluetooth capability to include additional devices, but nothing works for me at this point.Other than the Bluetooth limitations I experienced, I believe the OMRON 7 SERIES BP MONITOR to be a well-made, useful and reliable addition to our home's "medical shelf".  Blood pressure issues are related to a host of serious health problems and having the ability to conveniently monitor it any time and at home is a pro-active step in monitoring my family's health.

Years ago, I would have considered owning a laminator as more of a luxury than a necessity, but having two children totally changed things.  Nowadays, there is desire to preserve/protect/document almost everything they generate, not just pictures.  The FELLOWS LAMINATING POUCHES are PERFECT in getting that job done.WHAT IT IS:Each pouch is 9 x 11.5 and consists of 2 sheets adjoined at one end (the term pouch is somewhat misleading) and are suitable for any laminator that can accept letter-sized documents.  The design allows you to open the pouch like a book, place your document(s) on one sheet, fold the other sheet over and slide the pouch into the laminator.  The laminate coating on the inside of the sheets effectively keeps the document(s) from sliding around the pouch (like some photo albums).  Directional arrows are embossed on the pouches to ensure proper loading into the laminator (they disappear when processed through the laminator).  The pouches are UV protected, so they are great in keeping docs/pictures from fading.  They are to be used for THERMAL laminating.3 mil POUCHES:- I found these pouches providing the perfect thickness for most laminating needs (pictures and papers).  The laminating sheets are suitable for preserving the textured artwork my kids would create (papers with glued-on glitter, sand, yarn, etc.)  the documents are preserved/protected, but the textured element still remains (not a stiff sheet of plastic).  These pouches seal nicely and (when loaded in the proper direction) do not create any air bubbles.  The laminated items are clear and yield a slight gloss.  Trimming the sheets after laminating is easy.5 mil POUCHES:- I found this thickness to be more suitable for laminating items that may be subject to heavy use or heartier protection as it results in the laminated document having the stiffness slightly less than a credit card.  Laminated items are crystal clear with a higher gloss.  Because of the thickness, these sheets are a little more difficult to trim.I am impressed with the easy-to-use design of the FELLOWS LAMINATING POUCHES and more importantly, the results.  These are high-quality laminating sheets that protect but do so without reducing clarity (very important to me).  The last thing you want to do is laminate a precious picture or document and end-up with them being cloudy.  While I believe 3 mil is the best thickness for general use, I really like the heavy duty protection provided by the 5 mil sheets.

It is mind-boggling that almost 70 years after World War II, accounts of previously unknown or lesser-known (but significant) events are still emerging.  OPERATION CHOWHOUND details a unique Allied operation to feed 3.5 million starving Dutch in the final week of the war.  While the goal to feed so many people at once would seem interesting enough, the steps needed to pull of such a feat are what make the story so captivating.Stephen Dando-Collins sets the stage from the start:  After almost five years of occupation and the failed Allied attempt to liberate them (Operation Market Garden), some 3.5 million Dutch were facing starvation.  Despite the war drawing to a close, the Germans still had reinforced its grip on the Netherlands and appeared ready to defend it to the bitter end, this put the population at greater risk of dying every passing day  something had to be done to spare the unnecessary deaths of innocents.  The effort to save the Dutch required some high-level/high-stakes negotiations between the Allies and Germans, as well as the logistical challenge of safely and effectively delivering food (US Army K-rations) in enemy territory.  From beginning to end, the entire missions fragile nature seemed likely to fail, resulting in massive casualties for all sides involved (military and civilians).Dando-Collins presents this unique operation in a storytelling manner that makes for a quick and easy read.  He does a good job of illustrating stakes involved and more importantly the almost pipe-dream uncertainty that US heavy bombers could deliver humanitarian payloads in lieu of ordinance over enemy territory defended by some of Hitlers most loyal soldiers  the SS.  I found the effort of piecing-together the operational puzzle to be one of the most interesting aspects of the entire story  even more than the event itself.  The thought of high-ranking Allied and German officers/officials entering each others lairs to negotiate a cooperative effort to pull off an Allied operation that involved the use of hundreds of B-17 bombers (that were recently used to bomb German cities) is hard to fathom.  Dando-Collins puts you in the middle of these negotiations and you feel the tension, particularly the meeting that involved Eisenhowers cantankerous Chief of Staff, Lt. Gen. Bedell Smith.  Paralleling the planning effort, Dando-Collins injects stories of the (very) young men who would be carrying out the mission and the plight of those they were trying to save (including a young Audrey Hepburn).  The book joins everything together in a concise manner with short, but eventful chapters that chronicle pivotal moments from beginning to end without losing any of the storys momentum.  The sorties that carried out the mission reminded me of the Ploesti Oil Refinery operation in 1943  4-engine bombers flying at treetop level to deliver their payloads  the only exception being the bombers conducting Chowhound were not capable of defending themselves if the Germans reneged or were unaware of the negotiated truce (and there are moments where this does happen).  I particularly like the retrospective provided in the final chapters which brings to light the lasting impact of the entire operation.I found OPERATION CHOWHOUND to be a pleasure to read in that it highlights a rare instance of cooperation between enemy combatants to achieve a greater good.  It is a well-rounded read that tidily opens and closes a relatively unknown chapter of good amid mankinds most destructive event.

I remember watching two co-workers participate in the Beanie Baby craze of the late 90s and was entertained as well as frustrated by the amount of money they continued to sink into their Beanie investments (one had the means to support her habit  the other did not).  Zac Bissonnettes THE GREAT BEANIE BABY BUBBLE provides a very detailed understanding of the Beanie Baby mania and more importantly the shrewd, somewhat ruthless, dark and creepy man behind it all  Ty Warner.Rather than simply chronicling the rise and fall of Beanie Babies, Bissonnette digs much deeper and presents all facets of the fad and most interestingly, a somewhat disturbing biography of Warner, the reclusive Beanie creator.  I found THE GREAT BEANIE BABY BUBBLE to be far more interesting (and educating) than I anticipated it would be; I attribute this to Bissonnettes ability to successfully merge Warners biography, economics, marketing and social aspects of the great Beanie Baby run in a colorful, informative, yet fun manner that keeps readers interested from beginning to end.The meat and potatoes of the book is dedicated to Warner and it paints a somewhat unflattering portrait of the man.  Considering the father of all things Beanie has avoided interviews for almost two decades, Bissonnette successfully worked around that roadblock and found more than enough people willing to divulge their experiences with Warner over the years  including two women romantically linked to him through the rise and fall of the Beanie craze.  I found Warners path to immense wealth (hes a billionaire) to be quite interesting  a masterful, shrewd salesman and marketing genius with added dashes of vanity, obsession (to minutiae) and control (of everything)  someone who liberally used people he found beneficial only to unceremoniously dump them when his use for them expired.  On one hand, Warners obsessive nature is arguably attributed to his financial success as his dissatisfaction with something as small as a single stich in a Beanie Baby would result in it being removed from the market and replaced by the improved version (resulting in the retired Beanie Baby gaining value and stoking the Beanie mania fire).  On the other hand, Bissonnette reveals Warner as an insecure, untrustworthy, self-absorbed loaner addicted to plastic surgery.  Regardless of Warners fortune and success, its hard not to view him as somewhat icky.The book reveals the business side of Beanies as a cautionary tale that is creepy in its own right.  Bissonnette provides an ongoing history of the plush (stuffed animal) industry that led to Beanie Babies and it is a case of innocence gone awry.  The simple concept of the Beanie Baby was to create a small, high-quality, bean-filled stuffed animal marketed for kids that was affordable  high quality at a bargain price.  What started as cute, quickly became cult as the retired Beanies became collectables  and the adults began showing up to ruin everything.  The book reveals the seediness of the Beanie craze as values of retired (rare) Beanies soared, sending collectors over the edge with a desire to find/buy the retired Beanies at all costs (whether it meant liquidating the kids college funds or even killing someone).  The whole story is as shocking as it is pathetic  how something as insignificant as a cheap stuffed animal for kids could generate such hysteria  only in America.  Bissonnette shares the stories of numerous people wrapped-up in the craze, from soccer-mom types hoarding Beanies to fund their futures to people jumping on the Beanie gravy-train by publishing self-made collectors guides sold to millions of like-minded Beanie nuts.  The whole Beanie saga (from the beginning of the craze to its sudden crash) is strange, sad and unsurprising to a degree (as these cute fads seem to flare-up like a case of the shingles every few years).  But, the money that was made during its multi-year run is staggering (Ty Inc. earned more from stuffed animals than mega-toymakers Hasbro and Mattel).THE GREAT BEANIE BABY BUBBLE certainly proved to be an enlightening, unique read.  Reading the book reminded me that we have several Beanie Babies laying around our home; dont know if they have (had) value and dont care  they were purchased for our kids (and Ill bet the TY tags are bent, if not partially chewed from one of our Labs  gasp!).  The book prompted me to check out the TY website (a gaudy ADHD-inducing visual carnival that Liberace may have designed from the grave) and after seeing the products (including a garish line of NASCAR Beanies), I still dont understand the big deal.

I believe that one must approach dietary/workout supplement intake with caution as there are way too many powders and pills that promise a lot and actually do nothing.  With that being said, I dont find EAS HYDRATE providing any significant benefit to my workout other than sweetening my water with sugar.The nutritional content of a single serving (1 scoop added to 8 oz. of water) amounts to 25 calories:  270mg Sodium, 189mg Potassium, 6g carbohydrates (5g sugar) and 10mg Chloride.One thing to notice is the serving size of 1 scoop per 8 oz. of water.  If you are serious about hydration (even during a light workout), 8 oz. of water is like asking a bartender for a beer and getting it in a shot glass.  Most water bottles that people lug around hold at least 32 oz.  and many of the more serious lifters/athletes in my gym bring their water in 1-gallon milk-jug containers.  In other words, 4 scoops of HYDRATE are required for an average-sized 32 oz. water bottle which amounts to 20g of sugar.  While sugar may spike energy levels, its effect is very brief.  Basically, HYDRATE is orange-flavored sugar with a little sodium added for hydrating effect.If water flavoring is what is needed to drink more, I would stick with a simple liquid water enhancer like Mio or Dasani Drops as they have no significant nutritional value, have better flavor selection and are flavored with sucralose, not sugar.  If you want sugar in your water, Gatorade is probably the best bet.  Additionally, there are better hydration powders out there that contain BCAAs (Branch Chained Amino Acids), like Scivations XTend, that not only hydrate and taste good (without sugar), but actually contribute to protein synthesis  in other words, better taste/more flavor options, better nutrition (0 calories/0 sugar/added vitamins/minerals) and more overall function and benefits for those serious about lasting hydration through a rigorous workout.Other than improving the quality of the orange flavoring (and believe me, the taste of supplements have increased exponentially over the years), I do not feel there is any significant benefit to using EAS HYDRATE as part of my water intake during workouts.

I have two older Yellow Labs (9 and 10 years old) and weve grown accustomed feeding them premium dog food since the younger Lab experienced a bout of pancreatitis in 2013.  NATURAL BALANCE SYNERGY DRY DOG FOOD was in line with the other brands of high-end dog foods weve experimented with over the last few years.  It offers a combination quality (natural) ingredients that noticeably improve the texture of their coats, does make cleaning up the yard easier (solid), helps them maintain a heathy weight and is certainly appetizing to both.A partial list of ingredients emphasizes the natural aspects of the dog food:  Chicken, lamb and salmon meal, oatmeal, brown rice, beet pulp, barley, dried spinach/cranberries/parsley/carrot/egg, oatmeal, flaxseed and multiple vitamins.  The salmon meal and flaxseed provide good fatty acids necessary to maintain a healthy coat (our dogs are notorious shedders and we do notice the difference in the plushness of their fur as well as a reduction in shedding).  The food is presented as kibble (small, flat pellets not balls) which make it suitable for dogs of all ages and sizes.  I like the fact that NATURAL BALANCE SYNERGY is actually designed for dogs of all ages (puppies to seniors)  a one-for-all approach is nice considering the wide array of foods that cater to ages, sizes and sensitive diets.  Switching to this food on the fly had no negative impact on either of my dogs.The aroma of the NATURAL BALANCE SYNERGY is certainly not as appealing to the human nose as other premium brands and I attribute it to the mix of dried vegetables.  Regardless, my dogs certainly had no problem inhaling this food as soon as it hit their bowls.  The main issue I have is that even though I see it as a quality product, it is rather pricey.  With all the premium dog food available these days, its hard not to factor cost.

Having "mastered" the Rookie and Original versions of the Perplexus puzzle series, I thought I was ready for the challenge provided by the EPIC and ran into a brick wall as it's definitely frustrating ... in more ways than one.WHAT IT IS:- A clear plastic sphere with a plastic "jungle gym" of obstacles (125 of them) inside.  The goal is to navigate a single ball bearing through the obstacles without dropping it off course.  Larger than the Original and almost twice the size of the Rookie, the EPIC feels to be about the size of a volleyball.- While it isn't necessary to have practiced/mastered the Rookie and Original versions of the Perplexus, it certainly helps as the EPIC offers little relief in terms of easy obstacles.THE GOOD AND COULD BE BETTER:- How tough is it?  Odd as it may seem, the various levels of Perplexus puzzles is somewhat like the hot sauce levels of chicken wings at Buffalo Wild Wings ... EPIC = "Blazin'" In other words, you need to not only like hot sauce, but crave high levels of heat in your sauce to eat (let alone, enjoy) a plate of "Blazin'" chicken wings ... better to start off with the milder flavors first.  The EPIC has some interesting, fun and frustrating obstacles, including a see-saw, sliding track and one level that involves a free-fall into a funnel with a large snaking tube (getting to that cool level is a serious sticking point for me).  The more-complex obstacles in this puzzle require a gentler touch, more patience and higher sense of awareness.- As with the other Perplexus models, the various obstacle numbers (and direction arrows) are etched into the plastic.  Fortunately, the light blue, white and gray plastic make it easier to see the obstacle numbers (unlike the Rookie and the Original).  While etching the numbers and arrows in black or contrasting colors for better understanding the navigation path; I accept blind navigation as simply being an added element of difficulty.- The complexity and size of the obstacle course generates other potential issues.  One issue is the difficulty in locating the ball bearing when it enters the "guts" of the maze as other obstacles obscure the view.  The maze's design also includes a few delicate, moving parts that are subject to precision manufacturing in order to work right (fortunately, all parts of my EPIC are working as intended).  A possible design flaw (at least with my EPIC) is that the points where the maze attaches to the sphere create narrow alleys that trap the ball-bearing.  Freeing the trapped ball-bearing requires a not-so-gentle bump to the sphere which may damage the sphere or any delicate parts of the maze.- In addition to the starting point at obstacle #1, there are 3 additional starting points (named "Practice" A, B and C) that allow you to begin deeper into the maze.  The multiple starting points are helpful in letting you work on developing methods to master some of the more difficult obstacles without having to start from the very beginning.  As others have pointed out, using a magnet to drop the ball in a desired location is another practice method (but not as easy to do as it sounds).As someone who enjoys these puzzles, the EPIC provides the challenge I'm seeking.  It certainly brings more to the table than the Rookie and the Original, maybe too much for some.  For a better understanding, check out the (few) YouTube videos that show how some have mastered the puzzle (level 1 to 125).  I honestly don't know if I'll ever master the puzzle, but part of the fun is obsessively trying ... over and over and over again.

Unfortunately, the ubiquitous politicizing of the 2012 attack on the US Ambassadors compound in Benghazi has somewhat clouded what actually transpired that September 11.  With 13 HOURS, Mitchell Zuckoff and the members of the Annex Security Team provide a much clearer picture (and understanding) of what happened on the ground that fateful night.  Instead of sifting through a diatribe of finger-pointing, Presidential-election politics and blame, I found myself fully immersed in reading a modern adaptation of David vs Goliath.Several years ago, I was similarly absorbed in another Mitchell Zuckoff book:  Lost in Shangri-La (an astonishingly unique and amazing account of events that followed an obscure story of a transport plane that crashed in an unexplored area of New Guinea during World War II).  The author certainly knows how to present a story in a way that doesnt settle on hovering over events, but puts readers smack-dab in the middle of the action so they can see and feel the story first-hand.  That same gripping format really brings 13 HOURS to life  you are there, with the Annex Security Team, watching this small group of immensely skilled, deadly and fearless warriors working as one against an larger, unseen enemy that possesses superior firepower and a home-field advantage.Zuckoff preps readers in the initial chapters by providing background on the individuals involved in the Benghazi attack (key State Dept. personnel, the ambassador and the security team members) and the tense, but seemingly manageable American presence in volatile Libya (largely in part to Ambassador Stevens work).  From that point forward, the book is a detailed chronology of events occurring before and during the September 11 attack:  the initial assault on the Ambassadors compound, the attempt to rescue those at the compound, the evacuation to the Security Team Annex and subsequent defense of the Annex).  The attention to detail is meticulous and effective; it provides readers a fly-on-the-wall perspective of elite operators in action.  While reading 13 HOURS, I often found myself thinking of Easy Company, the American paratroopers immortalized in Stephen Ambroses Band of Brothers  a group of specially trained, brave men who volunteered to be put in the middle of extremely dangerous scenarios; scenarios that served to solidify both their effectiveness and cohesiveness.  The Annex Security Team exhibited those same brotherly qualities in Benghazi and the entire book illustrates just how tight the bonds between these special operators truly is.  With the surviving members of the Team co-authoring the book with Zuckoff, there is an added degree of authenticity that is thankfully devoid of any politically-slanted journalism  the story is told very matter-of-factly.While I have read numerous accounts of combat, most are broad in nature and cover multiple engagements.  The majority of 13 HOURS is dedicated to a single, but multi-faceted defensive battle.  The action described in the book illustrates how fearless, skilled and intuitive the members of the Security Team truly are.  We are given an opportunity of watching these men thrive in their natural element (a deadly, uncertain environment) and showcase their innate ability to react aggressively, no matter how uncertain the outcome appears to be.  The end-result of the Benghazi attack may be well-known, but the nut-and-bolts of what really happened that night have been sadly ignored until now.  That any of these men survived, let alone saved so many others (another untold aspect of the incident), isnt a matter of luck as much as it is a testament to their training, confidence and willingness to take the fight to the enemy.  Outmatched in numbers and firepower, these guys knew EXACTLY what to do with the limited resources they had in order to project themselves as a much larger force  all without the desperate need of air support.  That any survived to tell their story is hard to believe.For those wanting more than a news report of what happened at Benghazi  this is your book.  Its hard not to read 13 HOURS and feel fortunate that these warriors actually volunteer for such bleak assignments  doing so is second nature for them and a big plus for the rest of us.  A thoroughly gripping read from beginning to end.

The Perplexus Rookie is a big hit in our house and once my 8 year old daughter mastered it, I was eager to get her the next puzzle on the difficulty ladder:  the ORIGINAL PERPLEXUS.  The "Original" proved to be the perfect challenge for her (and me as well).WHAT IT IS:- This is the one that started the Perplexus series.  A clear plastic sphere with a plastic "jungle gym" of 100 obstacles.  The goal is to guide a ball bearing through the maze of obstacles by tilting, tapping, turning and even shoving the sphere without knocking the ball bearing off course.WHAT SEPARATES IT FROM THE ROOKIE PERPLEXUS:- First of all, this obstacle course is less forgiving than the Rookie ... not only are there more obstacles (some 20 more), many of them leave little room for error.  Everything is stepped-up a notch:  retaining walls are shallow (so controlling the speed of the ball bearing is critical) and the obstacles are really cool.- The obstacles are definitely more challenging and require not only a more delicate handling and balancing of the sphere, but even new "moves" are needed to guide the ball ... one particular obstacle (I believe it's #30) actually required a quick shove or shirk to move the ball quickly across a short distance.  Additionally, the suspended "track" obstacles that were so fun in the Rookie are back, but they are tighter, with sharper turns and narrower tracks.- There are 3 starting points located in the same area:  one that put you at obstacle #1 and two more that puts you at obstacles further into the maze.  This allows you to practice some of the more difficult obstacles without having to start from the very beginning if you drop the ball (the "Rookie" only has one starting point).- Two obstacles that actually move:  a swinging arm and a bucket that flips.MY BIGGEST FRUSTRATION WITH ALL PERPLEXUS PUZZLES:- Like the Rookie, the maze obstacle numbers and direction arrows are simply engraved into the colored plastic and can be difficult to see at times (especially considering the glare that a light source can generate on the sphere).  I really wish the company would color the engraved numbers and arrows in black or some other contrasting color.- Another annoying issue is that a rather large Perplesus logo is impessed into the sphere ... twice.  Neither my Rookie nor Epic have this issue.  I find it rather annoying that the designer/manufacturer would/could do something as ridiculous as impede the critical element of clearly seeing the ball bearing with such a marketing ploy ... totally unnecessary and wrong.The smaller, more forgiving Rookie certainly served as good prep for this Perplexus (especially for kids), but it is not really a necessary step.  Figuring out what to do with the ORIGINAL PERPLEXUS isn't the problem, the real challenge is being consistent, patient and controlling the ball bearing's speed.  It is much easier for the ball to fall and that kicks the frustration factor into full gear ... the good thing is that the multiple starting points keeps you from starting all over again if one of the later obstacles becomes particularly troublesome.  This Perplexus is a lot of fun and after a few days, I stepped up and purchased the PERPLEXUS EPIC ... that one's a real monster.

I first noticed kinesiology tape being used in the 2012 Summer Olympics (on volleyball player Kerri Walshs shoulder) and it took me a while to realize it was tape and not a weird tattoo.  During the course of those same Olympics, I saw the tape being used by athletes from numerous nations and in varying forms  it certainly intrigued me.  Experiencing an unpleasant case of Achilles tendonitis provided me enough incentive to test the effectiveness of KT Tape and I was quite pleased with the outcome  but it certainly wasnt easy to apply.WHAT IT IS:- KT Tape is a specially designed tape that can be stretched to provide a pulling effect between the ends when applied.  The tape is meant to be used for a variety of therapeutic and support purposes on numerous areas of the body.  The KT TAPE PRO serves as an improvement over the original tape in that it is synthetic (not cotton), washable and is intended to adhere to the skin for a longer period (up to 7 days).  The tape can come in either an uncut roll or pre-cut  there are a variety of color options as well.- Critical to the potential effectiveness of the tape is proper application.  While the tape does come with a sheet of graphic application instructions, it only addresses the more common injuries (mainly joint and tendon issues).  These instructions only cover the tip of the iceberg considering the numerous possible uses of the tape.  I found the website particularly useful in that it offers quite effective/informative videos on how to apply the tape, as well as covering more body areas.My KT TAPE PRO experience is based on using the uncut roll version (black).HOW IT PERFORMED FOR ME:- I found the KT TAPE PRO being surprisingly effective in alleviating my Achilles tendon pain  most notably the aggravation I was experiencing when first getting out of bed.  Immediately after applying the tape in the instructed manner, I felt a noticeable increase of support in the affected area and a significant reduction in pain.  The main issue with the effectiveness of the tape was that after 3 days, the segment of tape running down the bottom of my foot started to peel back and its super-sticky nature caused it to adhere to the floor and pull off when walking barefoot.  This was the only portion of the tape that gave me issues (the rest of the tape was solidly in place) and I blamed part of it on the rather difficult location (sole of the foot) and it being my first attempt to apply the tape.  A more-educated subsequent application proved to be much more effective.  Bottom line, the tape actually worked and worked well.- My biggest aggravation was with the application of the tape.  Most (if not all) the instructional videos on the website show pre-cut tape being used and it certainly seemed easier than cutting estimated lengths, especially considering all applications involve two or more independent strips of tape.  Prepping the tape was also cumbersome in that each application requires a specific degree of stretching the middle of each tape strip.  The tricky part is that prepping/stretching the tape first requires pulling off the paper covering the adhesive side  its advisable to have a second person on hand to help as you really want to avoid anything but the designated area of your body touching the sticky side.Overall, Im totally impressed with the tapes performance.  Yes, it will take practice (and possibly another person) to correctly apply the tape, but the KT TAPE PRO has yielded surprisingly effective results.  My Achilles tendonitis is fading and now Im concentrating on weightlifting injuries:  inner elbow tendonitis (golfers elbow) and shoulder pain (from heavy bench pressing).  I plan on having a roll of KT TAPE PRO on hand as I believe it delivers what it promises  only I will opt for the pre-cut roll instead (the uncut roll is probably better suited for athletic trainers).

There are a lot of mice on the market for just about every niche of gaming.  Being a casual online gamer, I prefer a mouse that can transition easily from gaming to general computer use  without the need of swapping between two.  The LOGITECH G302 DAEDALUS PRIME has the capability of being a go to mouse for gaming (specifically Multi Online Battle Arena gaming) and everyday computer use.PERKS:- The DAEDALUS PRIME is a wired mouse which generally contributes to the devices reliability (not only in terms of power, but uninterrupted communication between the mouse and the computer).  For many gamers, this is a plus.- The mouse can be thoroughly customized though a user-friendly downloaded Logitech program.  With 6 programmable buttons and lighting options (the color and mood of the lighting can be set for personal preference.- There are 4 DPI (mouse sensitivity) settings that can be set from 240 to 4000 DPI through a button behind the mouse wheel.  The user can opt to reduce the number of DPI options, if desired.  This is a pretty wide range with a high-end  4000 DPI is way too sensitive for me.- The DAEDALUS PRIME is lightweight and shaped in a manner that fits snuggly into the palm with slightly curved left/right buttons that enable your index and middle fingers to relax comfortably without impeding reaction time.  The buttons click easily and the middle-wheel is rubberized for smooth scrolling.  I found this mouse to be extremely comfortable, reliable and a pleasure to use for non-gaming purposes.POTENTIAL DRAWBACKS:- As a casual non-MOBA gamer, I found the mouse to be too lightweight for me.  My large, heavy hands require a heavier mouse for gaming.  Its a personal preference.- The umbilical cord.  I have grown quite comfortable with the freedom of movement that wireless mice provide and going back to using a wired-mouse is something I cannot seem to get used to.Overall, this is simply a good quality mouse that is aesthetically appealing (with lighting options), quite comfortable and easily customizable.  While it may be designated as a gaming mouse, I find it well-suited for general computer work.

Networking isnt my forte and TP-LINK has always delivered in providing good quality networking devices that make it easy for network noobs like me to set-up and use effectively.  The ARCHER C5 is a solid router that delivers a nice, strong signal that makes every nook and cranny of my home network accessible.WHAT IT IS:- Dual-band wireless router (2.4GHz and/or 5GHz) with 6 total antennas (3 outside the router and 3 inside), 1 gigabit WAN port, 4 gigabit LAN ports and 2 USB ports (2.0).WHY IT ROCKS:- First and foremost, setting up the ARCHER C5 was a cinch and I cannot stress the importance of this.  Connecting the router takes 4 simple steps and configuring the device (wired or wireless) takes only 5 steps from start to finish.  A CD is provided, but I found it completely unnecessary.  The entire startup process only takes a few minutes (and that included removing my old router from the system).- Once the router is up and functioning, you can configure your router through a user-friendly direct website that will guide you through a customization process (if desired).  What I really appreciated was that the customization processes were organized into tabs (such as setting up guest network access) and all the options within the tabs were thoroughly explained on the right side of the screen.  This thorough presentation allows users to make INFORMED decisions and reduces the likelihood of errors caused by confusion.- The router itself projects a STRONG signal (2.4GHz, 5GHz or alternating between the two).  The signal is strong enough to provide complete network access for every room in my home.  I have found the 2.4GHz band as being stronger and more reliable than the 5GHz  this may be an issue for some, but it more than meets my household demands.- Provides secure network via 64/128-bit WEP, WPA / WPA2, WPA-PSK/ WPA2-PSK encryption.- There are a myriad of options/customizations including parental controls, guest network access, the ability to schedule access times, etc.- The router is silent and stays cool.I find the TP-LINK ARCHER C5 to be a solid router that should address most basic networking needs, plus the bells and whistles for those demanding more functionality from their network.  The biggest plus, in my opinion, is the user-friendly setup that gets things up and running quickly and easily, regardless of ones networking expertise.

Living in house where the computer hardware is on a different floor than most of the gadgets using WiFi can occasionally be a problem, especially when multiple connections are going on simultaneously.  The TP-LINK AC750 RANGE EXTENDER proved to a simple, but most effective tool in our house.WHAT IT IS:- A device that simply plugs into a wall outlet to extend the range of your routers WiFI coverage.POSITIVES:- First of all, the set up for this device is a cinch  a big plus for those (like me) who understand computer-related issues, but feel a little less comfortable dealing with networks.- It can be plugged into any wall outlet, so you can position it to reach more remote areas of your home (in my case, a separate floor).  This range extender allows full coverage in every room of our home.  With smartphones, game consoles, tablets, internet connected TVs and DVD players all connected via WiFi, I have yet to experience any connectivity issues or drops since implementing this range extender.- There is a port on the underside of the range extender that allows internet access to non-WiFi devices (Ethernet bridge)  this is a big plus, in my opinion.Not being a network person, I was particularly pleased with the quick setup and ease-of-use this device offers.  I especially liked its ability to be moved from room to room in order to maximize its effectiveness.

The SMART WEIGH DIGITAL PRO POCKET SCALE has proven to be an extremely handy device in my house because of its many uses, size, accuracy and toughness.WHAT IT IS:- A flat digital scale that is not much bigger than many of the smartphones on market (3.94 x 3.7 inches).- Easy-to-read bright blue digital display, the scale can provide reading is 6 different weight measures:  Grams (G), ounces (OZ), pennyweight (DWT), carats (CT), grains (GN) and troy ounces (OZT).  This versatility allows the scale to be used for measuring food portions, jewelry and even mail (for postage purposes).  It can weigh items up to 500 grams.- Runs on two AAA batteries (provided).  Scale will automatically shut off after two minutes of inactivity (preserves battery life)HOW IT FARED:- For almost a year, Ive been measuring my protein portions for meals using a myriad of plastic kitchen scales that were cheaply made but not cheaply priced.  The DIGITAL PRO POCKET SCALE immediately revealed the significant inaccuracy of the other scales.  Ive actually been shortchanging my protein intake for months!- This scale has the ability to provide EXACT measurements.  Even better, I can toss a container on the scale, calibrate the scale to include the container at the push of a button and measure the weight of the contents being added to the container (tare function).  This is a big plus as most of the simple scales Ive used involve guessing or manual adjustments to calibrate.- Portability  this is a big plus.  The SMART WEIGHT DIGITAL PRO is quite inconspicuous and can be packed in a suitcase, briefcase, backpack or purse  a shirt or pants pocket might be stretching it a bit.  This is something I will bring when traveling without a doubt.- Durability  the scale is made of stainless steel, not plastic and its heavy and flat enough to sit on a countertop or table without sliding around or tipping over.  There no loose or movable parts to worry about.  For added protection, there are two separate plastic covers (one covers the entire bottom of scale and the other covers the weighing platform).- The digital display is bright with enough contrast to see in a variety of lighting environments.While my use for the scale will primarily be associated with weighing food, I like the fact that I can drop a stuffed or oversized letter on the scale to calculate postage (rather than wasting stamps guessing that additional postage might be needed).  The versatility and accuracy of the SMART WEIGH DIGITAL PRO POCKET SCALE make this scale a worthy device to have in the home  collectors of fine jewelry, reloading, measuring medicines accurately  this is a well-made and useful device.

After turning my back to the heavily marketed disposable razors, aerosol creams and other shaving junk, I was actively seeking alternatives to meet my needs.  The standard aerosol gels generate a lot of foam/lather for one razor pass, but always left my face dry and the cans simply never stop oozing foam after the first use.  I tried CREAMO CREAM after hearing a radio add and decided to give it a try.  First impression was:  strange scent, but super slick.A small dab of CREAMO with a sink or cup full of warm water is really all that is needed to provide a well-lubricated lather to accommodate multiple razor passes.  I found the key to this products success being the addition of a little water to each application of the cream.  Adding water to the cream is what generates the silky, slippery quality that allows your razor to glide effortlessly across your skin with having to apply pressure to your razor.  The only drawback to using this product was that it does create buildup on your razor that doesnt rinse away so easily and this can reduce the blades effectiveness over time.  The scent is rather unique and the only tangible aroma I can tie it to would be a hint of orange.I use a brush to apply shaving soap and find CREMO to work just fine:  simply wet the brush, apply the dab of CREAMO CREAM to the brush and use your face as the mixing platform (dabbing your brush lightly in warm water every so often to generate more lather)  or you could use a mixing bowl (which I consider more of traditional tool than a necessity)  or use the palm of your hand as the mixing bowl (I used this method until I discovered the simple convenience of using my face to generate the lather).  The key is getting the water/cream ratio right  too little water = dry/uncomfortable shave  to much water = messy/uncomfortable shave.  Lightly dipping the edge of my brush into a sink of warm water allows me to add water in small increments to generate the lather I want.While I find CREAMO CREAM to be a quality product, its not as widely marketed as other shave gels/creams and I can only buy it at one particular drug store in town.  The cost for a single tube seems high until you realize how many shaves a single tube will provide (with a pea-sized dollop for each shave)  its definitely worth it.  The biggest drawback for me was the buildup on my razor, so I use CREMO as a back-up or add it to my shave soap when trying to shave several days of hair growth  its the only product Ive ever used that minimizes the uncomfortable tugging associated with shaving longer facial hair.

I dont know how I initially stumbled up on the series of Perplexus puzzles, but I found them somewhat fascinating the minute I saw them.  Two years ago, I purchased the PERPLEXUS ROOKIE for my 6 year old daughter and until a few months ago, it was nothing more than a shelf ornament in her room.  The last few months, however, she finally discovered the challenging fun it presents and navigating the puzzle has become an almost daily ritual.WHAT IT IS:- The PERPLEXUS ROOKIE is a unique puzzle maze that requires a person to navigate a ball bearing from a starting point and through series of 70 progressively more difficult obstacles to reach an end point (each obstacle has a number and a directional arrow to keep you on course).  The entire puzzle is enclosed in a clear plastic sphere that allows one to see the ball bearing and determine the approach necessary to negotiate each obstacle.  Completing the puzzle requires a combination of patience, logic and focus, along with the ability to gently twist, tilt, flip and tap.  One misstep and the ball bearing drops off course, requiring the player to start over from the beginning.- The PERPLEXUS ROOKIE is the introductory puzzle to the Perplexus series of similar, more challenging puzzles.IS IT FUN?- Absolutely!  First of all, I found the unique nature of the puzzle quite appealing.  The jungle of interconnected obstacles crammed into the sphere is somewhat intimidating at first sight.  But, once I started playing it, the fun and frustration took over.  The key to working these puzzles is to address the approach needed for each obstacle just before the ball bearing reaches it.  Failing to do so will most always lead to the ball dropping off the obstacle.  Mastering the PERPLEXUS ROOKIE doesnt merely mean completing it, but the ability to successfully navigate the obstacles without having to think your way through it.SERIOUSLY?  SUITABLE FOR A 5 YEAR OLD?- The games says its for ages 5 up, but that may be a stretch.  The PERPLEXUS ROOKIE might be the easiest Perplexus, but it will present a challenge to most adults.  A soft/gentle touch is needed to work the puzzle, not just logic.  The ability to hold the puzzle and visually guide the ball bearing throughout the intricate maze of obstacles might be too much for such small hands (and I havent met a 5 year old yet that does anything gently).My daughter revisiting this puzzle has been fun for the whole family and the Original Perplexus is on the Christmas list this year (with the Epic and Twist looming as future gifts).  The only issue I have is with numbering on the obstacles, they are etched into the colored plastic and are difficult to see when light creates a glare on the sphere  clearly seeing the ball bearing and the course it is on is critical.  Simply coloring the etched numbers in black or a contrasting color would certainly alleviate this problem.

Buzz Bissingers seminal Friday Night Lights is one of the better sports books Ive ever read.  The immersive nature of the book made it too difficult to simply read-and-forget  it had me begging for a follow-up.  AFTER FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS may have filled a void to some degree, but it left me feeling somewhat shortchanged.After reading this brief (albeit informative) follow-up, I quickly realized the purpose of the book was less about satisfying fans of the FNL book and more about the authors ongoing struggle with the success of his best-seller at the unfortunate expense of its star, Boobie Miles.AFTER FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS focuses on Miles miserable plight following an injury that ended his starry-eyed dream of playing professional football.  It is easy to sense the gnawing guilt Bissinger has experienced since writing his successful book (which spawned a decent movie and an arguably better television series).  Glaringly contrasting Bissingers success over the years is the chaotic and somewhat wretched life of Miles; a life that includes fathering numerous children with different women, unstable employment, legal issues and mounting debt.  While AFTER FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS details Miles woes it also illustrates the almost fatherly bond Bissinger has formed with him over the last 20+ years.  The sincerity of the relationship (from both sides) is difficult at times (considering Miles primary contact with Bissinger usually centers on a need for money), but it is definitely sincere and deeper than one would expect.  The guilt Bissinger expresses doesnt always pertain to material things as we learn one particular passage in FNL proved to be as emotionally devastating to Miles as his physical injury.  Ironically, as depressing as the story may sound, its somewhat uplifting as we see Boobie as being more resilient and happy, despite his life of suffering.While AFTER FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS allows readers to catch up on the divergent lives of the author and his prime subject, those hoping for a more thorough then-and-now perspective on the coaches, players, parents, Permian High School and Odessa itself will be disappointed.  Bissinger knows how to tell a captivating story and he actually does so with AFTER FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS  I simply wanted more.

OXO makes great, common-sense kitchen products that have always proven to be useful, easy-to-use and durable.  The GOOD GRIPS NON-STICK FRYING PAN is yet another quality product added to the list.WHAT IT IS:- Gray colored, 10-inch frying pan made of anodized aluminum.  The interior of the pan has a 3-layer non-stick coating.  The outer rim is rolled to allow contents of pan to be poured easily, without dripping.  The handle stays cool, regardless how hot the pan gets.  The pan is dishwasher safe.HOW IT PERFORMS:- This pan works great.  My first experience was making pancakes and the second the batter hit the pan, I could slide the pancake around simply by tilting the pan.  Same with cooking vegetables for dinner.  The surface is super slick; this is one of those pans that allows you to flip the contents without a spatula.- I thought Id miss the standard Good Grips rubber handle, but the pans brushed aluminum handle is thick, has a comfortable shape and provides enough texture for assured handling.  The handle is attached solidly to the pan and does not retain heat.- While the pan is dishwasher safe, the non-stick surface makes it a cinch to clean in the sink.THE GOOD GRIPS NON-STICK FRYING PAN is sure-bet for the price  it performs as well, if not better than any of the higher-priced pans we have in our kitchen.

I love the scent of coconut.  I wanted to give this shampoo and conditioner a try for that reason.The set came in pump bottles that are able to be screwed shut again after use.  When I used it the first time, I didnt really smell the coconut.  The second use I did.  The product is in lotion form and lathers up nicely and rinses out easily.As to the management of my hair, I wasnt as happy with the results as I wanted to be.  While they cleaned and conditioned my hair well enough, it lacked volume and my hair was flatter than I wanted.If you are not looking for volume, this will work well."I received a free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."

I have read about using olive oil for moisturizing but never done it.  This product gave me the chance to try.The bottle contains 4.09 ounces of the combined oils of Jojoba and Olive.  I have never liked the feel that oils of any kind leave on my body so I tried a different approach.  I take it into the shower, get my body wet and then apply the oil.  I wait a few moments and then wash as usual.I find this moisturizes my body and prevents the feeling of putting oil directly on after a shower.  I have also added a small amount to my regular lotion and that doesnt make me feel oily.It doesnt have a scent but it does smell fresh and clean.  The bottle has a screw on cap and under the cap is a dropper type lid which prevents the oil from just pouring out.  With over four ounces in the bottle, it will last me a long time."I received a free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."

Are you trying to get away from using a prescription product for sleep?  Then this product might just make the difference you need.I have trouble sleeping either staying asleep or falling asleep.  Our bodies produce Melatonin and I feel mine doesnt produce enough.This bottle contains 12 mg of melatonin per tablet and has a natural berry flavor.  I can taste the berry before I can get a glass of water to swallow the tablet which mean to me that the tablet will dissolve quickly. There are 60 tablets in the bottle.If you are looking for something for sleep and dont want a prescription product, this could be the very thing you are looking for to resolve those nighttime woes."I received a free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."

This brush is 10 long and 3 wide.  There are ten rows of bristles.  The handle has a silicone bumpy grip so it is easy to hold.  The handle also has a hole so it could be hung up for storage.With it being such a large brush, I would recommend it to those who have long hair or for when you are brushing your childs hair.  My short hair isnt enough competition for it.It felt good in my hand and the bristles felt good on my scalp.  It is just too much brush for my short hair.  If your hair is longer, this would be a great brush for you."I received a free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."

I'd rate this 4.5 stars.No one writes quite like David Mitchell. His last book, The Bone Clocks, made the list of my favorite books I read in 2014, and now I was utterly captivated by the quirky, slightly creepy, and utterly compelling Slade House.Slade House is a bit of an anomaly. If you go looking for it most days, you won't find ityou'll simply go down the narrowest alley you've ever seen and search in vain, and if you ask passers-by whether they've heard of Slade House, chances are they'll look at you like you've gone mad. But the truth is, Slade House is only visible every nine years, and only if you've been chosen by the house's owners, a mysterious brother and a sister, will you get the chance to enter. You'll be amazed by the beauty of your surroundings, the grandeur of the houseand then you'll start to realize all is not what it seems. But by then, it's too late.Slade House spans five decades, beginning in the 1970s, and follows an unlikely group of people as they encounter the house and its owners. A misfit teenager accompanying his musician mother for a recital, a recently divorced policeman with an eye for the ladies, a college student who joined her college's Paranormal Society to get closer to one of her fellow students, and an investigative journalist all enter the house; some have knowledge of its existence, some are totally unaware. And then it becomes difficult to distinguish what is real and what is in their minds.I'm not going to say more about the plot for fear of spoiling it. Once again, David Mitchell has created a tremendously unique story with lots of twists and turns (and there's even a tiny overlap with a character from The Bone Clocks, but you don't have to have read that book to enjoy this one. This book has vivid imagery, fascinating characters, and even takes some trips into the territory of authors like Stephen King, Peter Straub, or Dean Koontz, but still remains completely Mitchell-ian. (If that word doesn't exist, now it does.)Give yourself a little post-Halloween treat that won't pack on the calories, and pick up this book. Chances are, like me, you're going to want to read more of Mitchell's books afterward.

When I pick up a book by Jojo Moyes, it's a pretty fair bet that it's going to make me cry at least at some point, although none of the other books of hers have left me the sobbing mess I was while reading Me Before You, which was one of my favorite books of 2013.Given how much I loved that book, I'll admit I was slightly dubious when I learned that Moyes was writing a sequel. Would it be able to capture the emotion of its predecessor without feeling like a retread? Was there more to Louisa Clark's story that still needed to be told? And perhaps most importantly, would it leave me an emotional wreck? I'd say pretty much, yes, and, well, sort of.Since Will Traynor's death, Louisa's life hasn't been the same. She promised him she'd live boldly, and she tried, but in the end, she found herself going through the motions more than anything else. When a freak accident forces her to return home to live with her family, she is confronted by the feeling that she never made any progress with her life before she met Will, and she doesn't know what she wantsif anythingfrom her future.Stuck in a job she hates, with only her family and members of a bereavement group to commiserate with, Lou feels guilty about not keeping her promise, but she isn't sure she has anything more in her. But then lifein the forms of an unexpected figure from Will's past, and the paramedic who rescued Lou after her accidentintervenes, and once again she is forced to make a decision as to whether to do what is best for her, to step outside of her comfort zone, or should she just do what is easiest, even if it means letting chances pass her by?After You is a book about how hard it is to move on and start living again after you've lost someone you love so deeply. It's about how grief affects everything you do, and sometimes paralyzes you, and how even when you are pushed out of your rut, it can still be far too hard. It's also about whether you are willing to let yourself take chances again, even if those chances may lead to you being hurt again.I really enjoy the way Moyes writes. Her style is breezy, accessible, conversational, and it just draws you in so quickly. I really liked most of the characters in this book, and it didn't really feel like a retread of Me Before You. I'll admit that at times I felt the book was going to veer into territory I wasn't going to like, but for the most part, Moyes kept us out of there. (There was one brief shift in the book's narration that would really have irritated me if it continued, but fortunately, it didn't.)This book didn't hit me as hard as its predecessor, but I still found myself getting choked up. And while I didn't think this book was quite as good, it's still a really good, enjoyable, emotional read, so I wasn't disappointed.

Loved this, loved this, loved this.There's a lot of fiction out there these days about extraordinary situations that threaten the worldusually it's an attack by aliens, monsters, or vampires, or otherwise the country is in danger because of war, dystopia, or political manipulation. It usually falls to one person, or a group of people, to save the world and solve the problems facing it.Patrick Ness' terrific The Rest of Us Just Live Here turns that concept on its head. While a small community is under siege by mysterious forces and a group of "indie kids" (aka hipsters) have to figure out who (or what) is responsible before they destroy the world and keep killing people, Ness' book focuses on a group of friends who aren't the chosen ones. They're just a group of best friends, each dealing with their own problems, and just counting down the days until they graduate from high school and can leave their town behind."Not everyone has to be the Chosen One. Not everyone has to be the guy who saves the world. Most people just have to live their lives the best they can, doing the things that are great for them, having great friends, trying to make their lives better, loving people properly. All the while knowing that the world makes no sense but trying to find a way to be happy anyway."The book is narrated by Mike, a sensitive high school senior battling OCD, who wants nothing more than to pursue a relationship with his friend Henna before they graduate and she heads off to Africa on a mission trip with her parents. His sister Mel has had more than her own share of problems but is trying to stay above water and pursue a relationship of her own. Mike's best friend Jared is more than just a smart, generous football playerhe's the most complicated of them all. And Mike and Mel's problems get exacerbated when their ambitious politician mother decides to run for the U.S. Senate, since her last political campaign nearly destroyed their family.Each chapter of this book starts with a brief description of what is happening among the indie kids who are fighting the menacing problem threatening to destroy the town. It doesn't really mention those events again unless Mike or one of his friends comes across a related situation. They're sad that the indie kids are dying, but mostly, they're just hoping their high school doesn't blow up (again) before prom and graduation.As I've said many times, I love books that make me feel all the feels, and this one definitely did that. Ness so perfectly captured not only the typical teenage angst about how life will change after high school graduation, and falling in love with one of your best friends, but he deftly balanced that with all of the other emotional issues the characters dealt with. I totally identified with Mike's fears that he was the odd man out among his friends, and that he was the neediest one of them all.Ness is a great writer (I'm definitely going to have to read some more of his books because he has a new fan in me) and I felt his dialogue and pacing were close to pitch-perfect. Until I understood the concept of the book I was a little confused, because I kept expecting the chapters to actually contain elements of the story that their introductory blurbs hinted at, but once I got the idea, it didn't matter. This is moving, funny, and utterly enjoyableit's nice to read a story about (mostly) "ordinary" teenagers in the midst of extraordinary circumstances.

I recently devoured Lori Ostlund's short story collection, The Bigness of the World, which I absolutely loved. (See my original review.) I so fell in love with her writing and her storytelling ability that I very quickly jumped into reading her debut novel, After the Parade. While I don't think I loved this book as much as her stories, I continue to be dazzled by Ostlund's talent and her ability to provoke so many different emotions with her writing.Aaron Englund has been with his older partner Walter for 20 years, since Walter rescued him from a lonely existence in his small town of Morton, Minnesota. But while the two shared a strong bond, Aaron felt that Walter always controlled him, and never let him forget that he saved him. So one day, Aaron leaves their home in New Mexico and heads to San Francisco, where he hopes to start a new life and continue his career as an ESL teacher."Perhaps that was the nature of love: either a person was not in it enough toc are, or was in it too deeply to make anything but mistakes."Settling into a small garage apartment in San Francisco, Aaron begins to realize that a new life isn't all it's cracked up to be. While he enjoys helping his students maneuver their way through the idiosyncrasies of the English language, he spends most of his time alone, knowing he did the right thing in his relationship with Walter yet still missing him, and feeling ever more alone and isolated, but scared and unwilling to try and make new friends.Through flashbacks we get a better understanding of what has shaped Aaron into the man he has become. His angry, abusive father was killed in a freak accident when he was five, and his mother vacillated between smothering and distant. He never felt he was the same as his fellow classmates, and he often was the object of ridicule and/or bullying. Throughout his childhood and young adulthood he encountered a number of people whose differences were either physical and emotional, yet he felt at home with them. And then, while he was in high school, his mother left home in the middle of the night with the town's priest, and she never connected with Aaron again.After the Parade is a moving story about feeling isolated, feeling different, and how our relationships and personalities are shaped by the things that occur in our lives. I felt for Aaron so much as I learned more about him, his likes and dislikes, and his inability to feel comfortable letting his guard down. But at times the emotional distance at which his mother kept Aaron, and Aaron keeps the world, translated into an emotional distance for me as well, so at times I was frustrated by Aaron's inability to act, to say what was on his mind, to do something that might bring a change in his life, although I understood why.This is a story that unfolds slowly (very slowly at times), and while the flashbacks are tremendously valuable for insight into his character, I would have enjoyed spending more time with Aaron in adulthood than in childhood. But while this isn't a book I necessarily enjoyed, it was a book that moved me, and Ostlund's talent is on full display here. It's definitely a book that has me thinking.

I'd rate this between 4 and 4.5 stars. Maybe 4.25?Sometimes you read a book you know very little about, and it utterly surprises you. That was the case with Sung J. Woo's Love Love, a moving, thought-provoking, endearing, and slightly zany novel about two siblings whose lives aren't quite going the way they plannedand every step they take seems to throw them another curve.Judy Lee is, to put it mildly, unhappy. She hasn't pursued a relationship since her marriage ended, she hasn't forgiven her father for her mother's death, she has no career prospects, and she doesn't know what she's going to do with the rest of her life. And when she meets a new man she might be interested in, he's a little more complicated than most, plus he may or may not have been a member of the Japanese Yakuza gang at some point."Everyone else she knew was doing productive things like buying bigger houses, raising smart kids, getting promotions. And here she was, a temp at age thirty-eight, with no husband, no house, no job, nothing. She knew she should be concerned, and to some degree she was, but whenever she fully recognized her utter lack of everything, the sheer emptiness of her life filled her up, leaving no room in her heart to even feel scared."The only constant in Judy's life has been her older brother, Kevin. But Kevin has more than enough problems of his own. His career as a professional tennis player never really hit its stride, he's still mourning the end of his marriage, and he's just had one heck of a bombshellafter preparing to donate one of his kidneys to their dying father, he learns he isn't a genetic match. That's right, he's adopted, and he's finding this out for the first time at age 40, and all his father can give him is a nude picture of his birth mother from the 1970s.Love Love is about trying to cope and move forward when nothing in your life seems to be going right, and when every possibility turns up more chaos than you expected. It's the story of two siblings trying to decide whether to wallow in their misery or take control of their lives when they seem utterly, completely out of control on all fronts. It's also an interesting meditation on how we choose to live our lives, on the difference between selfishness and independence, and how much of a role fate plays in the choices we make.I found this book utterly endearing and enjoyable. I really liked both Judy and Kevin's characters, and found many of the supporting characters to be so much more fascinating and complex than I imagined. At times things happen as you expect they will, at times Woo really throws some crazy twists into his story, and while it makes the book a little quirkier than I imagined it would be, it also makes it more entertaining. Woo is a terrific storyteller and you can tell that he cares about his characters, which makes you care about them, too.What a pleasant surprise this was! Nothing like some good family and relationship dysfunction to entertain you.

When Walter was five years old, his mother left their family, driving away in her blue Volvo, and he never saw her again.
