He wants to solve the mystery of who the girl was, and solve the mysteries of his own life. Neither challenge is an easy one.Paul Tomkins' The Girl on the Pier is fascinatingthe plot takes all sorts of twists and turns, and Tomkins provides so much interesting detail, particularly around Patrick's career, and the steps he takes in his work. (I'll admit, with all of the crime novels and thrillers I've read, I don't believe I've ever read about a forensic sculptor, so that was pretty cool.) And Patrick is an intriguing character, one who demonstrates how powerful memory can be, and how moldable memories are.My one criticism of this book is the non-linear way the story is told. I found myself having to double back more than a few times and re-read passages, just so I could better orient myself to the flow of the story and figure out what was being talked about. But once I got further into the story, I didn't find that as unsettling, although it took some getting used to.If you're a fan of crime novels and thrillers, definitely add this one to your list. It's tremendously intriguing and different, and you can't say that about every book you read.

I'd rate this 2.5 stars.The title of Michael Coffey's new story collection refers to the main character in the title story, who has made a living naming products, housing developments, and other things. But it's also appropriate for the entire collection, which focuses on people trying to get a sense of their own identitiesas parent, friend, lover, child, priestand figure out their place in the world.Of Coffey's eight stories, the ones I enjoyed the most were: "The Newman Boys," which followed a teenage boy's friendship with a physically disabled neighbor, and how that relationship ripples through the rest of his life; "Moon Over Quabbin," in which a mother pictures her former town, which was submerged under water when a river was dammed, and envisions her son alive through those to whom his organs were donated; and "Inn of the Nations," which follows a priest in the 1960s, trying to get control of his life, which seems no easy task.While Coffey is a very talented writer, and I enjoyed his use of imagery, many of these stories eluded my grasp. They started out strong, and I understood what Coffey was trying to say, but then the stories veered off course. In some cases, it seemed as if he just threw so much stuff into the stories they were going in many directions at once. This was particularly the case with the final story, "Finding Ulysses," which borrowed heavily from James Joyce.These stories are intriguing and unique, and Coffey has a strong voice. I look forward to seeing what he comes up with next.

I'd rate this 3.5 stars.George Pelecanos has been one of my favorite crime writers for a number of years now. I've read everything he's written, and I'm always blown away by the crackling action scenes, his exploration of racial tensions, and his opening up a new perspective on the Washington, DC of the 1970s and 1980s. I also love the complexity of his charactersmuch like real life, no one is completely good or bad, which makes them tremendously compelling.The seven stories in Pelecanos' first collection, The Martini Shot boast many of the same characteristics which make his novels so appealing. For the most part, these aren't the happiest of stories, as each of the main characters is struggling with somethingaddiction, greed, violence, guiltor often more than one of these. And although you can often figure out the path these stories will take, Pelecanos' writing ability raises them up a notch or two.Some of my favorites included "Miss Mary's Room," where a young man remembers the carefree days of his youth and a close friendship before crime changed everything; "When You're Hungry," about an insurance investigator who travels to Brazil to find an allegedly dead man, but finds his perfect case closure record may be in jeopardy (among other things); "Plastic Paddy," which illustrates how letting your friends see you vulnerable is never good for your friendship; and "Chosen," which provides some back story on Spero Lucas, a character from a few of Pelecanos' most recent novels. (This story reminded me how I'm more than ready for another Spero Lucas novelhope that's next from Pelecanos!)The collection also contains a novella, "The Martini Shot," which goes behind the scenes of a television crime show and follows one of the show's writers (probably loosely based on Pelecanos' own involvement with The Wire). But this is just more than a you-are-there type of story, as the writer finds himself caught between the woman he loves and the trouble a friend finds himself in. Even though the story was tied up at the end, I found this really interesting, and would have loved to keep reading this.There wasn't anything I didn't like about the collection; I just wasn't blown away by every story. I felt as if a few duplicated themselves a bit, and some didn't grab me as much the other stories, or other Pelecanos novels, have in the past. His excellent storytelling ability is on display, but some of the stories needed a little more time to develop.If you've never read anything by George Pelecanos, you need to remedy that. While this collection isn't his best work, it's still a great example of why he's one of my favorite writersand why I can't wait for his next book to come out, even if it's a year or so away.

<<possible spoiler-ish info, so use caution>>Paula Hawkins' debut novel hooks you pretty quickly.Rachel Watson takes the same train to and from her suburban London home every day. She has grown accustomed to the people on the train, and the things the train passes along its route, especially a set of houses set back from the tracks. Most days the train stops at a signal which allows her to observe the people in those houses, and she imagines they are living happier lives than she is. She often sees one attractive couple, whom she's named Jason and Jess, and she's invented careers for them, and feels so good about their relationship.One day, what she sees from her seat on the train shocks her. "Jess" is kissing another man! How could she jeopardize the perfect relationship that she and "Jason" have? Rachel is devastated and angry, since her own life is in a shambles, and she has idealized this couple she doesn't know. And when "Jess," whose real name is Megan, disappears the next day, Rachel is shockedand feels that she needs to tell the police what she saw. Little by little, she gets more involved in the investigation about what happened to Megan, because she wants to do her part, and she feels that she knows something.The thing is, though, Rachel isn't entirely reliable. She has a bit of a drinking problemwell, a big drinking problem. And sometimes she has trouble remembering what happens when she drinks. But she has this feeling she might have seen what happened to Megan. If only she could remember..."I have lost control over everything, even the places in my head."The Girl on the Train is the story of a woman who feels as if life has tossed her out, and she cannot regain her momentum. She is desperate to feel needed, to feel wanted, included again, so when she sees an opportunity to try and help out with the investigation into Megan's disappearance she jumps at the chance. But she doesn't count on her own lies and inadequacies being revealed, or being forced to confront her own issues.Hawkins is a terrific writer and has written a taut, compelling book, despite the fact that many of its characters are pretty unlikeable. The book is told from multiple perspectivesRachel, Megan, and Anna, Rachel's ex-husband's new wife. I found my mind spinning with all of the different possibilities of what happened, and what was going to happen. I came up with outlandish theories, theories that seemed they had merit, and one I hoped wouldn't be the case.Then sadly, in my mind, Hawkins punted. She took the easy way out, and it honestly killed the book for me. I don't think I'm smarter than many people, although I guess I read a lot of thrillers, but I totally saw the ending coming. I was truly disappointed.I'd definitely encourage you to read this book and formulate your own opinions. So many people have absolutely loved it in its entirety, and been shocked by the way everything transpires, so perhaps you will as well. I think for the most part, this is a pretty great book, and I look forward to seeing what comes next in Hawkins' career.

I loathe when a book is touted as "the next [fill in title of bestseller]," or "as funny," or "as suspenseful" as another popular book. As I've said before, I believe that type of comparison cuts both waysif you're a fan of the book that the new one is being compared to, it sets up unfair expectations, and if you're not a fan, you may skip a book that you might have really enjoyed.Jennifer Niven's All the Bright Places is hailed as The Fault in Our Stars meets Eleanor and Park. Having absolutely fallen in love with both of those books, I couldn't resist reading Niven's, even though I knew that the comparison wasn't fair. But after reading Niven's book, I can say that it does share some commonalities with the other two booksnamely characters who speak far more eruditely than real teenagers do, and the books' ability to leave me a puddle of emotion when they were done. And neither of those facts made me love All the Bright Places any less.Violet Markey and Theodore Finch have one of the most unusual meet-cutes I've seenthey meet on the ledge of the bell tower at their Indiana high school. Violet is grieving after the tragic death of her older sister, and has shut the world out. Finch has been known as "the freak" for years, despite his good looks, snarky sense of humor, and intelligence. He's fascinated with different methods of suicide, and has contemplated it more than a few times, but something always stops him."I'm fighting to be here in this s***ty, messed-up world. Standing on the ledge of the bell tower isn't about dying. It's about having control."After Violet and Finch essentially save each other from possible death, Finch makes it his mission to save Violet from herself, and convince her to start living her life again, and allowing herself to enjoy things, and people, she used to. The two become partners on a class project called "Wander Indiana," where they are encouraged to visit some of the wonders of their state. But in doing so, they also discover that despite all of their challenges, they can truly be themselves when they're together, which both find truly cathartic.As the two begin to acknowledge their feelings for each other, and Violet starts feeling comfortable again, Finch continues struggling with his own demons. As much as he tries to be present, to enjoy every moment they spend together, the weight of the feelings of others around him, the problems he's always dealt with, become too much to bear. Violet must make a crucial decisiondoes she try to save Finch as he saved her, or does she let him handle things on his own?Niven does an excellent job in portraying the struggles of teenagers dealing with grief and mental illness, and while the obliviousness of those in Finch's life is appalling, this sort of "ignore it and it will go away" behavior is all too true. While as with many YA books published recently, the characters are far more articulate and intelligent and sarcastic than most teenagers really are, the dialogue was beautifully written, and I found the characters, Finch in particular, to be truly memorable.Sure, this book is a little predictable, but I found it tremendously well done. I can't get it out of my head. I'm sad that I'm done with Finch and Violet, much as I felt after Hazel and Gus' story, and Eleanor and Park's story were done, too. This is a special book, and an important one.

Full disclosure: I received an advance copy of this book from NetGalley in exchange for an unbiased review.F. Scott Fitzgerald is one of my favorite writers of all time. Like many, I was first introduced to his writing in high school through The Great Gatsby, which I fell in love with pretty instantaneously, and then devoured everything else he wrote. But while I am familiar with F. Scott Fitzgerald the author, I honestly never knew much about F. Scott Fitzgerald the man, save his tumultuous relationship with his wife, Zelda.Stewart O'Nan's new book, West of Sunset, follows Fitzgerald at the end of his life. In 1937, despite the successes he achieved with his first few books, he is teetering on financial ruin, and his renown has been eclipsed by other American writers, such as Ernest Hemingway. His reputation has been soiled by his days as a violent alcoholic, as well as Zelda's mercurial and sometimes destructive behavior. With nowhere else to turn, he lands a job as a screenwriter in Hollywood.Scott finds Hollywood to be a garden of temptation, of both the alcoholic and female persuasions. He begins working at MGM, and is reunited with old friends like Dorothy Parker and her husband Alan Campbell, and Humphrey Bogart and then-wife Mayo Methot. He finds life as a screenwriter not particularly challenging, although he doesn't enjoy having to navigate studio politics, which cause him to be bounced from one film to the next, and he sees his work get edited by other writers and directors. He uses his spare time to try and write another novel, about a powerful movie director, but can't quite muster the confidence.While he tries to immerse himself in Hollywood life, he also tries to be a dutiful husband to Zelda, who is living in a mental hospital, and their daughter, Scottie. And as he struggles with his addiction to alcohol, he meets Hollywood columnist Sheilah Graham, and promptly falls in love with her. Their tumultuous relationship, juxtaposed against his financial woes, his on-again, off-again binge drinking, and his guilt over betraying Zelda, causes his health to decline, and his career to do the same.As a fan of old Hollywood, I found this book very interesting, as it touched on movies, actors, directors, and writers that I've heard of, and whose work I've seen over and over again. O'Nan paints Fitzgerald as a tremendously flawed character, desperately trying to redeem himself as a writer, a husband, a father, and a man, and not having much luck on any front. I've always been a fan of O'Nan's storytelling ability, having read all of his books, and while this one moves a bit slow at times, and feels repetitive after the fifth or sixth time Scott's alcoholism relapses, O'Nan's talent is once again on display.This is an enjoyable, but somewhat melancholy, look at an entirely different side of one of literature's leading lions, and some of Hollywood's glory days. If you're as fascinated by movie and literary nostalgia as I am, pick this one up.

Schlage makes an excellent product. I've installed a metric ton of Kwikset knobs and they are, frankly, cheaply made in comparison. Not only is the finish good on the Schlage knob but the mechanism is smooth and the install is easy. As another reviewer noted, you can really crank down on the attachment screws and get this knob on tight. Not that you need to, but there's no worry of anything breaking or popping out of alignment. The same cannot be said of the competition.Can't recommend this enough. I got the satin nickel so I cannot speak to the other finished but in terms of engineering and overall construction, this knob (family) is fantastic.

Fantastic stuff. I bought this for two very dark scars on my forearm that looked like cigarette burns (mechanic accident...don't ask). Actually, I bought this thinking it was just Vitamin E oil, not knowing anything about Argan Oil at the time.I've used a few drops on each scar once a day for about 3 months and the scars are almost gone. Completely. I've also started using it on my face and (shaved) head with great results. I've since done research on Argan oil and needless to say I'm impressed. Highly recommend.

Love this as much as my two Rambler mugs. This does not come w a lid but the 20oz lids fit perfectly. Bought this locally (Austin) for $24 and I like it as much if not more than my othe Yeti products. They are really making awesome stuff. And if you don't know- these mugs are the real deal. Not just a branding gimmick, they work better than anything on the market. Well worth the money.

I had dulled the blade that came with my Ridgid JobMax flush-cut saw sooooo bad that when I was cutting an outlet hole in a cabinet it looked like I was using a wood-burning tool. No joke, like Cheech and Chong style. Definitely time for a new blade. Took a chance on these and they work great. Disclaimer: I've only used one but if the rest are like it, and they should be, then this is a great deal.

I broke the tip of my Fat Max jab saw and thought I'd take a chance on this Milwaukee, as I have a lot of other Red tools and they are great. This saw works well but I have to say I don't think it cuts quite as well as the Fat Max. On the other hand, I think the handle is more comfortable and the rasp feature is great. I'm not disappointed but it's also not a night-and-day difference from the yellow and black saw I had.

Bought these for under-counter lights over a small wet bar. The install is easy and the light is perfect. I really didn't need three for my application (only about a 42" upper) but I went ahead and used all three and the light is great. These aren't built like a tank but for the price and for what they are they are fine. My only complaint, and a little one at that, is the variation between the two settings (low and high, essentially) isn't very different. It's kind of like "On" and "On-a-little-more". Oh well. I'm not sure I would do a whole kitchen with them but for a small area they work great. Install was very easy.

I'm a big fan of these Cooper LED nightlights, in all the configurations (with a switch, with an outlet, and the full nightlight). They are easy to install and look very slick. I tried another brand and it was way too bright and way too blue in color. These are a warm white and the dimming feature is fantastic. At full blast I think they are too bright, but at full dim they are just a soft moonlight-like glow that isn't overpowering even when you wake up in the middle of the night.Pro tip: If you are building or remodeling, position outlets about every 6' on the path to the kitchen and bathrooms to illuminate your way at night. And if you have a separate toilet room put a full nightlight version in there.They are a little expensive but I think they are money well-spent.

Great gun. We are on our second one through no fault of the manufacturer...my son was on a hunting trip with me and he figured out that if he poured South Texas dirt/sand down the barrel it would "smoke". Haha, wellllll that was fun for about an hour and then the gun locked up. Oh well. Minus an influx of dirt, it is a great toy that is easy to operate even for a 3-year old. Hours of fun. Highly recommend.

It seems like I had one of these years ago and wasn't that impressed. Well, now I'm working on a whole-house remodel and I ended up with a 5-gallon bucket just full of tools and misc junk. It was getting pretty bad so I ordered this and WOW, what a great item! Solid construction and really functional. I know commercial guys need tool belts to be more mobile but for me, just going room-to-room, this rocks.

This is the perfect solution for small parts in a working environment. The design is great as are the materials. I have wirenuts, tape, screws and staples in mine. I wish I had a need for another one! At this price it's a no-brainer. I think this would also work well as a range bag for brass and even for kids' toys/crayons, whatever. A million uses.

Bought this for a kitchen remodel and I'm very happy with the product. Installed and trimmed easily and looks like it will be there forever. The previous cabinet had a press-board bottom that had, at some point, gotten wet and warped badly, demonstrating the need for something like this. I think all new kitchen and bath base cabs should be produced with composite bottoms but for retrofit applications this is a great solution. I trimmed mine with an oscillating flush-cut saw and it worked great. I don't know about using a knife...this thing is pretty stout. But you can definitely trim it.

Works great for the intended purpose. They are a little tall for my liking but (obviously) easily cut down. MTM has some great products and smart designs. I used some packing tape to secure all the folds on mine.

I'm a big fan of Columbia "breather-back" shirts. In the hot Texas summers these things are no joke- they really do keep you cool. For no good reason, I only had one of these for many years and I only used it for fishing. This past summer I snapped out of that nonsense and started buying more and wearing them all over. Here's my take on the different shirts, hope this helps you. (for reference I am 5'8", 175#, 32" waist and usually wear either an athletic-cut large shirt or a medium if it's cut normally...yes, I live in size hell)Bonehead: This shirt is 100% cotton and is very tough. Makes a great work shirt. It wrinkles easily and has the traditional PFG assortment of pockets on the front. It is the quintessential PFG shirt. It does not fly under the radar but it looks fine for what it is. I have several of these and if you can get them less than $15 that's a great deal. Given the pros of the other shirts, however, I must say this style is my least favorite (but still a great shirt, and my go-to work shirt). I always get a small in this style and it's still roomy at that. It's cut VERY large.Bahama II: Much like the Bonehead in terms of pockets, but it's made of a synthetic fabric. Breathes better and wrinkles less but can still wrinkle. The "Super Bahama" version has a print rather than solid colors. Heavier material than the Tamiami. I wear a small in this shirt as well. Not super lightweight but tougher and can be used as a work shirt.Tamiami II: This seems like a refinement of the Bonehead and Bahama. Very light cloth, kind of parachute-like. Different pockets. This, to me, is the coolest (temperature-wise) shirt of the bunch. The "Super Tamiami" is the printed version. I wear a small in this one as well and it's my favorite for very hot weather but I would be very hesitant to wear it for work applications. Not as tough as the Bonehead or Bahama. Pretty much wrinkle-free.Baitcaster: Lightweight like the Tamiami but different cut and different pockets. It's kind of a cleaner version of the Tamiami, however, because of the cut I wear a medium in this rather than the small in most of the others. I tried a small and it would button but was tight in the shoulders.Low-Drag Offshore: Another lightweight version with far more conventional pockets and a very clean look. Some colors have contrasting stitching which, in my opinion, looks sharp. The sizing on this is smaller than the Bonehead/Bahama/Tamiami but slightly larger than the Baitcaster. I ordered a small and it fits, barely. By far my favorite design. When I order another I may or may not order up a size to a medium.So there you go. If I seem addicted to these shirts it's because I am. In a hot climate you may be able to find a cooler shirt but if one exists I don't know about it. Retail you can expect to pay anywhere from $30-$60 for these but if you keep an eye out on Amazon getting them as cheap as $11 isn't unheard of. Money well-spent if you spend a lot of time outside.

Makes a great work shirt. It wrinkles easily and has the traditional PFG assortment of pockets on the front. It is the quintessential PFG shirt. It does not fly under the radar but it looks fine for what it is. I have several of these and if you can get them less than $15 that's a great deal. Given the pros of the other shirts, however, I must say this style is my least favorite (but still a great shirt, and my go-to work shirt). I always get a small in this style and it's still roomy at that. It's cut VERY large.Bahama II: Much like the Bonehead in terms of pockets, but it's made of a synthetic fabric. Breathes better and wrinkles less but can still wrinkle. The "Super Bahama" version has a print rather than solid colors. Heavier material than the Tamiami. I wear a small in this shirt as well. Not super lightweight but tougher and can be used as a work shirt.Tamiami II: This seems like a refinement of the Bonehead and Bahama. Very light cloth, kind of parachute-like. Different pockets. This, to me, is the coolest (temperature-wise) shirt of the bunch. The "Super Tamiami" is the printed version. I wear a small in this one as well and it's my favorite for very hot weather but I would be very hesitant to wear it for work applications. Not as tough as the Bonehead or Bahama. Pretty much wrinkle-free.Baitcaster: Lightweight like the Tamiami but different cut and different pockets. It's kind of a cleaner version of the Tamiami, however, because of the cut I wear a medium in this rather than the small in most of the others. I tried a small and it would button but was tight in the shoulders.Low-Drag Offshore: Another lightweight version with far more conventional pockets and a very clean look. Some colors have contrasting stitching which, in my opinion, looks sharp. The sizing on this is smaller than the Bonehead/Bahama/Tamiami but slightly larger than the Baitcaster. I ordered a small and it fits, barely. By far my favorite design. When I order another I may or may not order up a size to a medium.So there you go. If I seem addicted to these shirts it's because I am. In a hot climate you may be able to find a cooler shirt but if one exists I don't know about it. Retail you can expect to pay anywhere from $30-$60 for these but if you keep an eye out on Amazon getting them as cheap as $11 isn't unheard of. Money well-spent if you spend a lot of time outside.
Works great, easy to wire up and solid construction.

Great construction. An iPhone 6+ will fit as far as width, but it's too tall and doesn't allow the velcro to fasten. I actually purchased this to hold the power brick/charge for a MacBook (without the extension cord) and it works great for that.ATACS looks great as well. My only gripe is the MOLLE straps are kind of goofy. They work, but compared to the 5.11 slick sticks the Hazard4 ones are overly complex and don't hold it as tight to the host as it should, in my opinion. But for this application (inside a backpack) they are fine. Overall a really nice case and I would not hesitate to buy another Hazard4 product based on this one.

I got tired of trying to find the perfect backpack so I decided to create an almost-perfect insert and be less picky about the bag. This one from 5.11 pretty much does the trick.I got the small one and it fits perfectly in a normal-sized backpack (Oakley Panel in my case). As with most 5.11 products it is constructed well and has some nice touches like the detachable handle.I'm not crazy about the horizontal PALS webbing on one side...what in the world would you really use that for? I ended up threading a long BlackHawk strip through and then weaving the molle attachments behind that. I think they could have just done conventional vertical PALS on both sides and for most people that would be more useful.I wish it had loop velcro as well, but it doesn't and that's that. Whatever is inside it that makes it "rigid" isn't really that rigid, but the nice thing is that it's easily accessible via a velcro flap so if you want to add something to stiffen it up you can. I think I'm going to add a sheet of kydex or something, but it's not a priority.Overall I can recommend this if you're looking for a backpack insert. Not perfect but it does a good job.
Works just like you would expect. Good quality and seem like they'll last a long time.

I almost always carry a knife and am a fan of larger assisted openers. I needed a smaller, slimmer blade and the Skyline consistently popped up in reviews as a great, slim EDC knife. I've never owned a Kershaw and quite frankly they didn't do anything for me compared to Benchmade, ZT, etc. But for the price I figured sure, why not.This knife is borderline perfect for EDC, for me. It's very slim, has a great feel and stays sharp. I got the Damascus steel version and I've worked it a lot harder than it should be worked and it's never missed a beat. Example: I had to cut the tires off of four golf cart wheels (they were glued to the rim). This should have been a utility knife job but the only knife I had on me was the Skyline so I used it like a rented mule. Never a hiccup. Couldn't be happier with this little gem of a knife. I'm going to skin a deer with it this fall just to say I did.

Hard to go wrong here. I got these on sale on Prime Day (what a joke) for $7-something...a whole year for $7? Year sign me up. Way better than paying through the nose at Walgreens or CVS. I can't tell a difference between this and the name brand or the store brands. I guess everyone reacts a little different to Zyrtec but for me it's great.

I bought these mainly for tractor/yard work to keep dust and grass out of my eyes. They work really well. The lenses are distortion-free and they are surprisingly comfortable. They haven't fogged up on me but they are hot. Which, of course, is a trade-off for being sealed to your face with foam but just be aware. I was hoping for a little more air venting going on but oh well. Still great glasses that I'll wear a lot. Will probably order another pair to have at another property.
Ordered these for my 3.5 year old son who can be a little unforgiving on sunglasses. He loves them and they are going strong. Good purchase. They fit great.

Super bright. I replaced the backup lamps in both a 2010 Silverado and liked that so much I ordered a set and did the same in a 2015 Honda Accord. Zero complaints. Of course time will tell on longevity.

I've hunted for years and have a pretty good idea about how coolers work and should work. I bought mine via a charity auction so yes it was expensive but I'm probably a little less sensitive to the cost than someone who bought it retail (even though I paid more). That said, I have very mixed feelings about this cooler.First the good: It's built like a tank. You'll probably own this the rest of your life. Most coolers crack at the hinges even with modest use. Not the case here. I'm about buying quality ("cry once", right?) so I feel good about not having a buy a new cooler every 2-3 years. Lets be honest, it's also a cool brand. So there's that. And from a performance standpoint it does work well. I don't think it's a game-changer, but it works well.The bad: It's built like a tank. Meaning, it's HEAVY. Really heavy and I'm not a lightweight. Even empty you kind of go "Gee whiz this is heavy" and loaded up...yeah, it's a beast. And I have the 35-quart! The big ones, loaded down, would simply be immovable. The capacity is also a bummer. For the size--because of the insulation--it hold less than a comparable normal cooler. I hope that makes sense.Other things to consider: It's a target for theft so you have to lock it down. That's a pain. And lets talk about ice retention for a minute. Does it work well? Yeah I guess so. I totally understand pre-cooling it and not leaving the thing in the direct Texas sun. And I don't want to under-sell it but for me, it's just not that impressive. Especially given the cost.Do I regret the purchase? Nah, it's cool. But honestly my expectations were not that high. If this purchase is a budgetary stretch for you, and/or you expect it to change your life...be prepared. On the other hand, if you are an avid outdoorsman and you have the disposable income, go for it. I give this 5 stars for design, 4 stars for performance, and 3 stars for value.

Ordered this to help organize the punches, picks and chisels in my rolling toolbox. Great quality and simple design. This looks like it will last for years. It's expensive compared to an office-grade organizer but when you pick it up and use it you'll know why. Very robust. I would order more but the price makes me hesitate.

Great for what it is. I am using it to organize the "junk drawer" section of my rolling toolbox. Yeah you probably don't want to use this as a prying instrument for rocks but come on people...some of the other reviews made me scratch my head. It's great. And cheap.

Typical Klein quality. These are a little stiff to open and close at first, which is to be expected. Work some oil into the joint and over time it will loosen up. Handles are very comfortable. I know they aren't "insulated" but whatever...look at the construction of a wire nut and tell me these handles won't protect you from 120V stuff. You'll be fine.

This is a great grinder and a great package. I bought it to replace an older 3.5A Makita 9501B grinder that was missing the guard...almost cut my thumb off so that was the end of that one. This grinder has a solid feel and lots of power. The case actually isn't bad, and the extra guard and included blades make this a great value. I don't have a lot of experience with other brand grinders but I do own DeWalt and Milwaukee tools...this Makita seems every bit as stout as those if not more so. If you are doing some serious industrial work you might want a 9A or higher tool but for normal stuff this 7A (or whatever it is) seems more than adequate. Heck, the old 3.5A wasn't horrible for most tasks so this is a monster compared to that.

This thing works great. Gets into tight places if you're sawing something with multiple small branches or trunks like understory bushes or trees, super sharp. Locks up pretty tight and the safety lever is nice to make sure it doesn't open up on you. Makes sawing even medium size branches a breeze

Holy crap these things are bright. I bought these to replace some old halogen PAR lights in a house we are moving into and the difference is just indescribable. With two on each front corner of the house the (very large) front yard looks like it's being lit up by a helicopter spotlight. Factor in the energy savings and the lifespan of these lamps and it's a no-brainer. My only complaint, and it's a small one, is that I'm not crazy about the stark white bezel; would have much preferred something darker to match my fixtures but who cares, really. 5 stars.

I have been without a creeper for years, instead using an old piece of cardboard to slide under the car for oil changes and the like. I finally snapped to the fact that I have great tools and a creeper should be one of them, so I did a bunch of reading and ordered this one. And yeah, it's that good. Very comfortable, easy to roll around on, high quality wheels, and it doesn't even tip up when you get off it like almost all other creepers do. So yeah maybe it's a little pricey but it might be the last one you every buy so if you spend any time under vehicles or equipment do yourself a favor and buy this one. Personally I like the yellow color but I think the red, blue and black ones are functionally identical.  An easy 5+ stars

I have been using a pair of yellow handle Ideal strippers for years and finally lost the spring. I've got a big project coming up so I bought these and WOW- what a difference. Work great and very comfortable in the hand. They are larger than my previous ones so that takes a little getting used to but it's not a problem, just different. They work great which is the bottom line. Maybe a little pricey but it's Klein so I'm willing to pay more for good quality.Update: After about a month of very light use these strippers are almost shot. Blades are not lining up and the cutters are binding on stranded wire. I am very disappointed. I tried adjusting them and to no avail. I will be going back to Ideal. Save your money. As you can tell I was very impressed but the quality is not typical Klein on this one. Junk.

Good quality light that is SUPER bright. Casts a great deal of light over a wide area. Also runs very cool which is such a great benefit of LEDs. This light seems to be of high quality and installed in less than 5 minutes to replace an old PAR-style dual head assembly on the side of a garage (vertical application). My only gripe is price...in a day where LEDs have gotten so inexpensive this is a little on the high side for me. Also, if you really want the dawn/dusk operation then this is what you want. I, however, wanted to bypass the photo sensor and the proved to be all but impossible as the sensor is integrated into the light head. So I just covered it with foil tape and it works on the switch. Good light.

Really pleased with these lights. I was in the market for four of them for a covered walkway and back patio. It's just shocking how much outdoor light fixtures cost. These were very, very reasonable and I was completely satisfied with the quality. Rubber gaskets on both the body and the lens, and everything was finished nicely. Highly recommend.
Looks sharp and high quality. Easy to mount. Time will tell on durability but it looks like it will last a lifetime.

Shocked that no one has reviewed these yet, so here goes: I recently realized that my work boots were (wait for it) 10 years old. They used to be worn daily and now they are only worn on weekends...but still. I realized how bad it was when I went from running shoes to my old boots and the insoles of my old boots had the give of a granite countertop.I went to a local western wear place and tried on a bunch. The Ariats were, to me, hands-down the most comfortable. I didn't need a steel or composite toe and I like a round toe rather than square. The Groundbreakers were OK but didn't seem as comfortable, so it was a toss-up between the Workhog and the Rigtek. Really liked the sole on the Rigtek so I went that route and ordered them from Amazon.I normally wear a 10.5D in running shoes but the 10D Rigtek seemed to be a good fit. I wore them around the house and while the length was perfect they were just too narrow. Which is odd, because I don't have wide feet and I have never purchased anything other than a D width. So while I LOVED these boots and they look great, ultimately I had to return them due to the narrow width squeezing my feet to the point of being uncomfortable.Follow up: Rather than do the order-and-ship song and dance again I went back to the local store and tired on a BUNCH of Ariat boots. Here's the conclusion I came to... The size, in terms of length, is pretty much spot-on. I think what throws the width off is both the toe configuration (round vs square) and/or the waterproof lining that some boots have. I ended up buying the square toe Workhog in a 10D and it fits like a custom boot. The same boot with the round toe was noticeably more snug, and the waterproof boot was again too tight. Moral of the story: buying these online is a tough deal. But they are great boots.

I re-wired a small utility trailer and it worked great. High-quality wire. Be aware, though, that it won't go as far as you might think. My little trailer is only 5' x 8' with a pretty short tongue and this roll of wire just barely finished the job. When you allocate for the hook-up pigtail, side spans for marker lights and your tail lights, it will go fast. If you have a larger trailer I would imagine you are going to need two rolls for sure. Smaller trailers or just repair applications should be fine with one.
Great little dump pouch. Works great for my application. Not bomb-proof like Maxpedition but works like a champ. Zero complaints.
Great quality. I am using them as a kind of dump pouch but they work like a champ. I have a lot of nylon gear from good companies and these rank among the best.

Nice switch but unforgiving on installation. Needs a pretty exact-tolerance hole which I found hard to do in the metal panel I installed mine in. Wouldn't recommend using a hole saw as it's not a precise-enough cut. You really need one of those step bits. Also, the material you mount it in needs to be pretty thin. You can make it work with glue/epoxy in thick material but just be aware.The switch itself is nice and looks to be of good quality. I'd buy it again if I had to install it on plastic or aluminum but not for a thicker steel panel.

I'm goofy about keeping my car clean and for years have pulled a wheeled shop vac around, fighting cords, etc. I've always wanted a wall-mount vac and finally ordered this one. All in all it's a good setup but it's not perfect.For being a WALL MOUNT shop vac the wall mount part is pretty flimsy. I suppose companies like Apple have spoiled us to expect great attention to detail and in this case I'm disappointed. Not to say it's faulty or bad, just cheap. Example: At a cost of exactly $0.00 they could have molded the hose keeper on top another 2" longer and you'd never fight the hose falling off. As it is, it's barely adequate.I knew going into it that the accessories were kept in a mesh bag. That didn't bother me until I mounted it and now it seems (detect a trend?) cheap.  Look at other models from other companies and you'll see thoughtful designs that integrate accessory storage.So in the end, this is a relatively good value vac that will serve it's purpose. Suction is good and ultimately that's what you're buying this for. If you love great design and attention to detail you'd be wise to spend an extra couple bucks on a nicer machine. For the average homeowner, though, this should be fine.
Needed these to mark sprinkler heads. Worked like a champ.
Saved a ton getting wheel locks on Amazon as opposed the the dealer. Took all of 5 minutes to install and they work/look great. Highly recommend.
Fits great, thick and slightly grippy material. Highly recommended, would def get another one if I had the need.

I have an older Yamaha G14 golf cart whose previous owner had given a poor paint job. Rather than re-paint it I thought I'd order this vinyl kit. The camo is cool, but it for me it was really just about covering up the paint.I'll say first that the vinyl is very, very high quality and extremely tough. You can pull, stretch, peel it on and off- it's tough stuff. And it looks really good. 5+ stars for quality.The installation is kind of tricky. "Mossy Oak Graphics" has a very good YouTube video and I highly recommend you watch that a couple of times. I did my cart myself but this would be so much easier with two sets of hands, even if your helper isn't too handy just having them there would assist you greatly. As the video shows, applying heat makes this vinyl so much easier to work with. If you dont' have one already, buy a $20 heat gun. Not a hair dryer but a heat gun. Trust me, it's money well-spent. You'll also want an Exacto knife with new blades, alcohol to prep (and other alcohol to drink :), lots of paper towels and something comfortable to sit on.Make sure your cart is clean. Make sure your work area is clean. TAKE YOUR TIME. Don't do this when you have an hour to kill and you're in a hurry. You'll regret it. Also, cut carefully. It's not like you have 150% of what you need- they give you just enough and if you cut off scraps like you're trimming a fatty steak then you'll be short in the end. And obviously this stuff isn't cheap. Mark my words: you'll open the roll and think you have waaaaaay too much, you'll get half-way done and be convinced you are going to be short, and in the end you'll be just fine.When done right, the end product looks very, very nice. Try to enjoy the ride- doing curves and radiuses can be a challenge but again, if you take your time and apply heat then you can make this work. I would recommend doing this over the course of at least a few days, if not a week. Do a panel, take a break. Patience and time is your friend here. Rush it and you'll be sad.ON THE OTHER HAND (!), if you don't have the patience or the time, I would suggest you consider either painting your cart, getting the body hydro-dipped, or getting a professional to do this. It's not brain surgery, but it certainly isn't for the faint of heart. If you're thinking you're going to be slapping on an over-sized bumper sticker think again.

A month ago I would have rated this 5+ stars. Love it. Then I noticed that one side of the string had pulled through from the rubber part. A quick tug and the OTHER side pulled out. See attached photo.This looks cool and worked good for a short while, but for the long-term it's a poor design. They should have made a loop and molded the rubber around the loop, not open ends. Or they could have knotted the ends, something to keep it from pulling loose from the rubber. It's a crappy design. Unfortunately it's not unique to Chum's products- I had a set of aircraft cable sunglass keepers and the cable pulled out of the rubber end in the same way. Chums could be really, really awesome but they haven't done a good job, in my opinion, of figuring out the rubber overmold process. Lame.

Bad design. I've had this for years, so I guess that means it's not horrible, but the flat... "lid" (?) causes oil to splash out. I've gotten good and aiming the oil flow to the center hole and that helps, but in general this thing is just a mess. The spout also drips in spite of the cap. The only good things I can say about it is that the construction is decent and the little lip for draining the filter works as it should. Save your money and pass on this thing. Life is too short to be cleaning your driveway.

Have this in our kitchen and it works great, about like you'd expect. It's a little wider than our Keureg, but I suppose these are different models so they probably make it to fit a bunch of different ones. If I were to make a recommendation it would be to eliminate one row (column?) of cups (so 5 instead of 6) to slim it up a bit. But even as-is it works great.

Bought this and mounted it on the side of my console in a VW Jetta. Works GREAT. I had an HTC M7 for a while, and now an iPhone 6+ and it holds both equally well. Easy to adjust and then solid when you lock it down. Also easy to mount and dismount the phone. Highly recommend.
I'm a sucker for foot massages and this thing works GREAT! I had it on my Amazon wish list for the longest time and finally bought it. Works and feels great. Highly recommend.
My son LOVES the "Bear Books". Can't go wrong with any of these.

Got this for giving (and getting) back massages. It's OK- not as easy to use as you would imagine. I think you'd almost be better off with just a fixed round/spherical object. But that said, I like really hard pressure and that may be some of the issue I have with this- if you press down really hard it's harder for the ball to rotate in the holder. So for light and medium pressure, in all fairness, it works well. But for really deep tissue massage I think something else is in line.

Ordered these to mount a silver Redfield 3-9x42 on a stainless Marlin 983S .22WMR. Solid rings as you would expect from Millett. Very low profile and went on without a hitch. The finish doesn't absolutely match the scope and rifle (and base, for that matter) but that is to be expected and it's not a big deal. It's very close, and that's more than good enough for me. Highly recommend these rings.

I've used all different types of earbuds (Etymotic, Shure, JVC, Panasonic, Philips, you name it) and am always on the lookout for a budget earbud that's a real find. I've never owned any MEE but the Head-Fi reviews were solid so I thought meh, why not. In short: Great decision. I'll try to keep this brief. Overall construction is solid with a good cable and good attention to detail. The remote works like a champ and in fact is one of my favorite features while running. I haven't used the mic yet so I can't speak to call quality but the volume control and button work great.Fit is above average, in my opinion, with the memory wire working well and the in-ear fit being excellent. You get 6 sets of tips, I believe it is, so play around and you should be able to find a combination that works for you.Sound is good with excellent bass and overall good sound. Are they my favorite for sound? Mmmm, jury is still out on that one. I have a burned-in set of JVC FX40's with Comply's that are kind of my go-to earbuds in terms of great sound, but for what these are--working out and running earbuds--the sound is great.You also get a very nice zippered case, a shirt clip, and as I mentioned 6 different tips. All for what, like $21?? That's a steal. That would be a steal if the sound quality was just OK, but it's actually very good. I know reading these reviews can become exhausting, and you are NEVER going to find the perfect set of earbuds because so many of the qualities being rated are personal and subjective. But speaking as objectively as possible, these are good earbuds with an excellent value. Hard to go wrong here.
We have had the Ooma service for years. Works great, cheap, and a shockingly good website. I could actually do without a "landline" but it does come in handy. And for the price you can't beat it.

I find that Melatonin helps me sleep if I've gone a few days not sleeping well. For me, it gives me CRAZY vivid dreams! Like watching a movie in HD. not bad, just vivid. One thing to note on this particular item is the dose: depending on what you read 5mg can be a lot. It certainly is for me, and I end up just pulling the caplets apart and using between 1/4 and 1/2 the powder, not the whole thing. Which is fine, but if you are looking for a lower dose you might pick another option.
Great little booster seat. Not much to say but it's a pretty simple device. Straps in tight and cleans up easy. No complaints.

My poor kitty Charlie caught a viral eye infection, and an upper respiratory issue. My veterinarian recommended that I feed him a couple of these every day, to help keep his immune system strong. It took a bit for me to figure out how to ensure he was eating them every day. I noticed just putting them in with his dry food wasn't working, he was actually eating around them! Finally I discovered giving these to him before breakfast is what finally worked. My cat is 18 lbs so I give 3 to eat, one for every 5lbs of cat. This seems to be doing the trick. There's have been no relapses, and he's doing well.This brand appears to be the tastiest, as I tried a different brand that he'd have nothing to do with. This brand has ingredients which addresses occular issues, so this is the one for us!

Finally a way to stream from my 4th generation Kindle Fire HDX. Fast, easy plug n' play. My only issue, I wish Amazon had made the the Kindle Fire HDX 4th gen. with 2 micro usb ports, like they did for my older Kindle Fire HD. Though in all fairness, the HDX does seem to have a bigger battery, and there is enough battery life to get through an entire movie, and then some.It's just you get to my age and end falling asleep through most movies which is the true reason I wish I could keep my tablet charging after the movie ends

My kitties love the way this feels, I love the way it helps groom their fur. This brush pulls that fine under coat which causes cats to cough up fur balls. I notice since I've started grooming them regularly, I haven't seen or heard any cats hacking up  fur balls. They sure enjoy being brushed to being fed fur ball medicine. It's better all the way around for both of us!

LOVE these, crunchy, cheesy, spicy puffs. I'm not big on snacking, particularly chips n' things. But every rare once awhile you get that craving for something salty, crunch..., spicy, this does it for me! Barbara's are an organic product which just makes them that much better. If you've not yet tried these, give em a chance.

LOVE the creativity, and graphics! What an ingenious way to give kids an idea of the inner workings of a mind. Not that I think kids will grasp this, (but what do I know, I have no children). It's been a heavy week of bad news, I just needed something light and enjoyable to escape the reality of the past week, and this most certainly did the trick.A terrific family movie fun for all ages, one of Disney's best in quite awhile.

Well constructed, feels durable. The on off button feels like it is well made. I like that I can use either an AA, or a 14500. Throw it in a pocket or purse, also has a clip for clipping on a shirt pocket. Lightweight 3" in length. LED bulb. It's bright and handy. 3 modes.

Basically it's easier to tell you what I don't own in pencils, than list all that I do. The only 2 (two) colored pencils of the professional/artist quality are the Pantone, and Fellisimo that I don't own. Coloring is not a new trend for me, which is why I've been collecting art pencils over a course of several years. While Caran D' Ache is one of the best and highest rated products for artist, I hate to say that this is my least used colored pencil, at least for using in coloring books. I'm sure I still need to try using these on an art quality paper like Stone Hedge, or Bristol board. My experience using these in coloring books was they did not lay down enough pigment, I could not layer with them, but the worst part was, using these as a watercolor pencil. When I applied the water it made the pigment all but disappear. Colors seperated, and faded away.I've got the set of 120, aside from a few other artist quality brands I owned at the time Prisma, and Derwent, I had great expectations for these being from Caran D' Ache. I also had thier water color crayons, which I ended up using over these. I'm afraid I put my set of these away, as I have other colored pencils I place well above these on performance.

I love these. I tend to get a very dry mouth at night, so I keep these on my night stand. The reason I find these are the best for aiding a dry mouth is that the citrus flavors make my mouth water, hence solving the issue of a dry mouth. Less calories than a typical candy 25 calories per 2. Usually 2 are all I need. Terrific citrus flavors lemon, orange and grapefruit, plus I'm getting some vitamen c at night which I believe aids in  better absorption.

My cats went nuts!  This is made with fishing pole swivels, so it moves more like a bird, and less like a toy that a human is on the other end of. The wand is long, which allows for fast easy movement, giving the cat good leaping range. It also required minimal movement from me, making play time much easier on me! First night I had both cats huffing, and puffing. The kitten thought she'd caught a real bird, and dragged it off to defend-feather it. My only complaint is the feathers aren't in very securely, I would recommend applying a small amount of non toxic glue, inside the rubber cap to prevent your cats from so easily pulling it's feathers out. Otherwise this is the best feather toy I've bought, and I've gone through several other types as cats seem to enjoy the feather teasers best.

This arrived much earlier than was predicted by Amazon. Well made of durable acrylic, and well thought out for practical use. Because I like to keep several tanks filled with a variety of flavors, and keep coils from getting mixed, this allows me to have up to 7 tanks, and 6 different e juice out which helps me keep track of which flavor is in which tank. It holds 6 /30 mil. Bottles, 4 /15 mil. And there are 6 holes on the back row that could hold  tanks. The 7 holes on the front bottom row can either hold tanks, or 15 mil bottles. I like that the holes on front row also have a small hole in the very bottom, which accommodates the thread on the bottom of a tank, so they sit flush upright. The piece of wood they sent, with the company logo, I used as a base to the whole unit, that way if a tank should leak it won't get on my table.I think this was well thought out. For me having 6 tanks, and 6 different flavors loaded at one time is plenty.

I've been feeding my cat the Vitri-Lysine brand for about one year, he's accustomed to eating a few every morning. I thought I'd try this less expensive version, but to my dismay, he won't eat a single one! Uncertain what the difference of ingredients could be, but in this case, It seems I get what I pay for.He's now been without for one week, which only leaves me sorry for waiting until it was all we had left, before learning he'll have nothing to do with this brand

Marjorie Sarnat is making quite a splash with what I believe is now her 3rd coloring book. Most enjoyable, well drawn, highly detailed, and intricate. So glad to see that her coloring books are also being published under Dover's Creative Haven title. As I think many are aware of by now, Creative Haven coloring are single print on a pretty decent quality paper, that takes all mediums quite nicely.31 images just waiting for you to color.I used to scan and reprint my coloring books, but thanks to the Creative Haven line, this is no longer necessary. I enjoy coloring with my Prisma markers, which are an alcohol based marker and notorious for bleed through. I also apply colored pencil over the markers for a more vibrant look, thankfully the weight of paper used in all Creative haven books allow me to color in the fashion I enjoy.This book will take me considerably longer, as each page is such a full compostion, but well worth the time and effort.

Marty Noble is such a wonderful artist, who else could make bugs SOoo much fun to color?! I'm pretty sure I've got most all of Marty Nobles coloring books. I held off on acquiring this one, now that I have it, not sure why. Just colored my first, only to discover this isn't like coloring bugsat all, but more like coloring very well balanced, intricate designs.Like all of Marty Nobles illustrations, each one is a well thought out compostion, complete with beautiful borders, florals, and well balanced designs.I feel so very fortunate that Marty takes time to illustrate such incredible coloring books for the coloring community. There is not a page that doesn't beg to be colored.Being a Creative Haven means there are 31 single print pages ready for your enjoyment. Because they are print on one side only, these books are ideal for using markers, water color pencils, color pencils and gel pens. On my example I've colored directly in the book using my Prisma markers, and some colored pencil over the marker. The paper, which is of a very nice quality stands up to all markers. Because Prisma's are notorious for bleed through, I just placed a sheet of printer paper behind it.

I LOVE ALL of Ming Ju Sun's fashion illustrations, and this one is one of her newer. Illustrated in a great size for coloring, clean, concise fine line illustrations, with good detail, and floral backgrounds. Lovely prints on fabrics. What I enjoy about coloring fashion is deciding how I want the fashion to look. One of my favorite genres for coloring is fashion, as I love to bring the fabric to life.This being a Creative Haven means each page is single print, nothing on the backside, which makes these great for using all mediums, from watercolor, felt markers, colored pencils ect...,31 pictures to color, all ranging from the 1920's through the 1950's. Day wear, evening wear, hats, fur, lace, you name it it's all here. Every outfit a detailed fabric begging to be colored.If you love coloring fashion this book is a must have , even if you don't, this is a good book to discover your own potential for  fashion and fabrics.This is just one more book I don't see a single page I won't want to color. The two I've posted are the first two in the book, as I planned on starting in the begining and working my way through the book from front to back.

I was most pleasantly surprised after receiving this book. Sent as gift by my 80 something year old mother, who has an excellent eye for well drawn figures, and details, which this book has. Fashion is one of my favorite genres for coloring,so are florals, this book has both, beautifully detailed faries, surrounded by lovely detailed florals done in  art nouveau style of dress, and background.30 Lovely clean line black and white illustrations, print on both sides, while this is a Dover book, it is not a Creative Haven, I was also pleasantly surprised by the quality of paper my professional grade colored pencils worked very nicely on, I haven't felt the need for scanning to reprint this one.This is one of my favorite fairy coloring books.

I love foreign and indie films, this was no exception. Enjoyed it for the different story, and plot. Well acted, an overall enjoyable fiction. None to bloody, no gore, suspenseful, and quite different.

Well Pam S. took the words right out of mouth. I've been using this for the past 11 years. I can't shower without it, this has become such a central part of my daily hygiene. I Use this before I step out of shower, applying with water still on skin. Then air dry, or towel blot, this does not leave my skin all oily. It does have a lovely light scent, which I equate to a very light clean powdery smell (that does not over power or inter mingle with fragrance) it actually helps carry my perfume, and seems to make my perfume last longer.This is such a terrific product. I have used lotions and potions sense I was a teenager. ( now a senior) while even the best and lightest lotions, body butters etc... can leave your skin feeling waxy and suffocated, with fragrance that can clash with perfume, this body oil does not.While lotions only give dry skin temporary relief from dry skin, this really seems like giving your skin a good drink of fresh water, leaving your skin so moisturized, there is no need for lotions.Well I think I've said more than enough, without saying the words 'I love this product' and I truly do, can't shower without it!

Absolutely elated after carefully looking at each page, the day it arrived. Every page just begging to be colored. From very creative styles of Victorian based Steam Punk fashion, Marty tied it all together with exactly the right hair style, and accessories. Her figures are in perfect proportion, NOTHING is out of step or amiss.As a serious colorist I favor Marty Nobles coloring books because her illustration are always well balanced use of space, beautiful designs, boarders, intricate, and detail oriented, clean concise line drawings, with no broken, disconnected  or over lapping lines. Coloring fashion is one of my favorite genre for coloring, but this book I found to be exceptionally awe-inspiring reason for being is with this book there is not a single page I won't want color. Being of the Creative Haven series means this book contains 31 black and white illustrations, print on one side of very nice quality paper. This is a toothier paper than typical bond type paper which is used in many coloring books. This paper is heavy enough to accommodate all mediums from colored pencils, and felt markers to water based colored pencils, and gel pens. Each page is perforated for easy removal.I believe this book will fast become a favorite for many of my fellow colorist. This is one book you don't want to pass over.

This book is 8"x8".Out of 70 drawings I found about 20 that I liked. but again, these designs are SOoooo small and intricate, about the only thing you could color with is the micro fine felt pens. Even gels pens would be too large in most cases, and because these are double sided print, unless you scanned and reprint the drawing you wanted to color, you'll ruin the page on the opposite side.This is just a different type of coloring than what I typically am inspired to do. I enjoy shading, and coloring space, be it fashion, floral, or designs. About all you could do is struggle with fine tip pens, just not my thing.There were some nice designs in this book, but very intricate, too small to be enjoyable for me. I've included the prints I liked, but felt too small to enjoy coloring. Be your own judge. (29.95 buys alot of coloring books)!

NOT my idea of an enjoyable coloring book. This book is 83/4" x 61/2".  out of 50 drawings i found only 5 that I liked, but everything is SOooooooo small, even coloring with gel pens wouldn't work. I really don't understand why something like this has even been taken to print? I have enclosed some sample pages so you could judge for yourself.

Sorry to say for the price I was sorely disappointed. I guess this is just not what type of coloring I enjoy. These drawings are small, overly simple line drawings. The overall book is only 63/4"x 61/2". Too small to be enjoyable. The book is print on a nice quality paper, and is put together in a nice format whereas each page is preforated, however these are  the best attributes to the book. The drawings lack consistancy and theme. Overall I was very disappointed with this purchase.Nothing against everyone that loves or enjoys this book, this is just not my personal idea of what makes for a nice coloring exercise. Also I have been purchasing and collecting coloring books for many years, I own more than I could comfortably admit to, which accounts for my being more critical as to what I will keep for coloring.In all fairness this book requires different type of coloring than that which I am accustomed to.  I have included photos since I there were noneavailable to aid me at the time of purchasing.

Marty Noble illustrates the nicest books for colorists, being the artist she is,understand how to illustrate pictures that will inspire to be colored. Clean concise line drawings, complete compostions. Nicely detailed, without being overly intricate. I am also happy to say that Dover has gotton away from that 'green' paper they were using, it seems they have listened to their customers, and have gone back to using a much better quality paper. The Creative Haven books are print on one side, the paper used in these books are of a nice weight. Great for all mediums, colored pencil, felt markers, gel pens ect...,This book is a lovely compilation of the designs from from Magnificent Mehndi Designs, and her first Mehndi Designs. The first Mehndi designs were based more on the Henna tattoo body art, while Magnificent Mehndi designs are more animal, floral, and paisley inspired. All the designs reflect an style from authentic Indian, African, and Middle East designs. This book contains 60 black and white illustrations.I colored using an alcohol based marker, and colored pencils.

Like Lola I have most professional colored pencils in my collection such asFaber Castell  (Albreicht Duer) Caran De Ache (Pablos), Faber Castel (Poly Chromos),,, Stadler (Karat), Mitsubishi Uni, Tom Bow (Irojiten), Lyra, Derwent,(Colour Soft, Artist) Prisma, Creata Color,( Urban So Ho & Karmina) etc...,at first I compared these to a poly chromos, but now after having used these quite alot I can honestly say they color like nothing else. They color smoother and creamier than a Stadtler Karat, ( and Albreicht Duer which are about the creamiest pencils) I find the Holbien is what I prefer to lay down first because it colors the smoothest of all my pencils. What sets these apart from the poly chromes is they color with a transparency I've yet to acheieve with any other pencil. Just when I think I can't get down another layer, with the Holbiens I can, no matter how much pencil I've put down, even after burnishing and I don't get ANY wax bloom!Always pencils behave differently according to the paper you are working on. I have found several coloring books with a smooth bond type of paper that almost seem to repell some of my best artist pencils like the Faber Castells, and Caran De' Ache. So again, this is another bonus for the Holbiens, so far I've yet to discover a coloring book or paper that these don't color beautifully on. These have become my favorite of all my pencils. I still don't work with them alone, typically I work with at least 3 to 4 different brands at once, due to coloring in many layers.The Holbiens arent as soft or waxy as the Prisma, and don't put down quite as much pigment, so if I had to compare I'd say they color more like a poly chromo, but I believe they are much softer than a poly chromo, and you can acheive a beautiful transparency to your colors that you can't get with a poly chromo, or a Prisma.The other thing I love about this set of 150 colors is the pastel tray. There are such beautiful colors that are not available in any other set. These have become colors I find I'm using the most. I've also not had a single broken lead, they sharpen the best.As far as wondering if your set is 100 or 150 colors, read the description. Most vendors use a 'stock' photo which may or may not be exactly what a person is expecting, so always read the description. My set was the 150 pencils set, I got it for such a steal, I was afraid possibly it's because it might be the set of 100 instead, which led me to call Amazon to verify exactly what I could expect. I was assured it was the set of 150, I couldn't be happier for getting these, as they are still a very difficult pencil to acquire in the states. Well worth the money when you can secure these from Amazon, and not have to pay for shipping charges from Japan.

Extremely well made like every thing else I've bought from Catit. Catit is to cat toys, what Fisher Price is to toddler toys. Made from durable plastics, pieces that snap together securely, and remain together. Very well thought out. This item really deserves a 5 star, the ONLY reason I gave it 4, is because my cat just has absolutely nothing to do with it.  I thought given his propensity to chewing, and having his facial glands rubbed, he would love this...,but I was wrong. Based on my experience, the best I can mention is how well made and well they out Catit items are, like nothing else I've found anywhere else.

At first I thought this was great, the version I used on my pc worked great, making it very easy to upload all my music. BUT for some unknown reason even though this app on my tablet shows me my music files, it won't play them...,what am I missing? It won't even play opening/ sending to a different app. Looks like I need some tech support.

Having not been familiar with Impact books, or this illustrator Barbara Lanza, I was surprised to see my mother's completed copy. Good clean contour line drawings. 47 pictures of fairies, of all ages to color. Her fairies look original, none that I have seen before. No broken, unconnected, or over lapping lines. The paper is of a reasonable grade. Not toothy but smooth, heavier than what I see being used in many books. These pictures are an excellent size for coloring, not too small, or overly intricate, and not too simplistic, just nicely drawn, well balanced compositions. If you enjoy coloring fairies, I don't see why you wouldn't enjoy coloring this book also.My example pages have been colored directly in the book, this paper took professional grade colored pencils very nicely, and was a joy to color on.

Extremely well made, and well thought out in terms of what cats enjoy. Sturdy built to last. The people designing these toys have really gotten into a cats head, they understand the  activities come natural to our feline friends. I play with my 2 year old, 17lb boy, Charlie twice a day, though sometimes I wish he'd play be himself, which is why I've begun making this nominal investment, in these Catit toys. Both pleasantly surprised, and very pleased with the quality put into these products.I love that you can build and add to making this as complete as you please. Oh...,one more thing to love about this, is the way the ball keeps a pretty consistent movement, due to the way this is designed. The end caps are shaped in such a way, that pushes the ball back the other direction, which in turn helps keep the ball in motion, which also helps hold the cats attention. I definitely plan on adding to this system. Anything that helps keep my Charlie active and healthy.

Having developed an interest in Asian history, this book is still the beginning of my reading journey. Sought, based on the author's credentials and awards, I was moved, and not disappointed. It breaks my heart seeing this side of American human nature.

Disgusted with television news..., ALL of it! When I'm trying to stay current on affairs, I want straight forward, unbiased reporting. I want the facts, not opinions. Ill gather my own opinions thanks, and I don't need to hear both sides, plus a spin doctor.So far I'm quite pleased with the journalistic quality, and that I can get both am, and pm news. My only complaint, is that while I was enjoying the free version, there weren't any ads to contend with. I pay Amazon to give me ad free time on my tablet, yet even still, there's no such thing as ad free kindle time, as individual app's can use them, then Amazon is not responsible,Or in controlling. It could be worse, but I am still enjoying getting my news from the Washington Post app.

Could not have played or finished this game without this beautifully illustrated, and well written guide. I am not a 'gamer' I only recently stumbled onto these RPG's. ( role play games) which are good clean, addictive fun. I guess if your familar with this line of Harvest Moon games, you'd probably be able to play without the strategy  guide .But come on folks give me break, I'm 57 years old, and before I stumbled onto Harvest moon ect..., I was only playing Animal Crossing city folk!! LOLAnyhow, sorry, about the guide..., Laid out very well, information presented in a much needed chronological order. Very complete, without giving up the spoilers. There is SO much in this game, and things that need be done in a certain order, if you're to get the most out of this game. I do resent paying more for the strategy guides than I do for the games, especially the older ones, which are more difficult to find. I've got one game left in this series 'Rune Factory Tides of Destiny', unfortunately I've yet to locate a guide. I'm most likely familar enough by now to play without, but I'd really like to have these great guide books, they are as much a keep sake as the games are.

FINALLY!!!  My computor  wasn't having any reall serious issues, just 6-7 years old. As with any older operating system, each update, download, software change ect.., starts leaving pieces behind, duplicating files, until eventually software, and or hard drive , your registry becomes corrupt. My PC had finally started crashing, short cuts that would no longer work, files that could not be located ect.., I was first considering purchasing the more expensive " Fix IT' soft ware. I was also considering restoring my PC  ( Uh, doing the dreaded restore ) but there are programs I would lose, that I would not be able to get back. Unwilling to go through a system restore, I decided BEFORE I spend the money for the 'Fix IT' software, starting with the Professional grade Ccleaner might be my best move., and so it was!!I've always run the free version, C cleaner has always been a good product..., I am SO glad this was the route I chose to go. So far my PC is behaving lighting fast, no more crashing, and it's working like a brand new PC.I would say, if you are experiencing issues, even if your not, Ccleaner is simply just GOOD software to have in your PC, even before you start having problems! Money well spent, problems fixed, and now I've got my piece of mind back!

My cat LOVES this stuff!, and since everyone has jumped on the 'awareness band wagon of nutrition', I do also. Real chicken, and salmon listed as the first ingredients. Granted there are still better choices out there, when considering ingredients, but those cost a small fortune. Purina( who's been around forever) has listened to what consumers are asking for, and made it available in an affordable, and what I believe to be reasonably decent nutritional recipe. After having tried several different dry foods, (and my Charlie wasn't particularly picky) he did begin to show a preference for this particular food. The others this won out over were Science Diet,  and Fancy Feast, just to name a few.

What an app!  One I thought I didn't need, or would use often, since I'm usually at home where I can just use my remote, and television. BUT...,what I only recently learned from a call over tech support,  there is much I can do with regards to controlling my tv, that I can't do using my cable remote. Checking the guide, programming to record, watch live on tablet, or send to tv. I've been experiencing some unresolved issues around the 'on demand' lately, issues I am not having when I use this app in support of my television. So far, so good gliche free, I'm learning I'd rather use my tablet, and this app than my cable remote!

The BEST mandalas I've seen, and 50 of them, print  on one side only!  Which as every colorist knows is ideal for coloring with markers. Angie Grace has been a busy lady! Not sure exactly how many coloring books she's published to date, but I am wildly impressed with her mandalas. Beautifully intricate, nicely balanced, and uniform. Clearly she must have training in technical pen, as her lines are impeccable, no unconnected, or unfinished or broken lines anywhere. Intricate without being overly so. Balanced in the amount of size and shapes. Uniform in that her designs maintain perfectly even spacing all the way around, which are difficult to find in hand drawn designs. The paper used in her books is consistent from one book to the next, which is a better quality than what most coloring books are using today. I enjoy coloring mandalas for an exercise in playing with color, when I need a break from my regular type of coloring. This book makes an excellent gift, or addition to any colorist book collection, if you've not yet added this one to yours, you don't know what you're missing!

Chewy, spicy goodness. Guilt free candy. Love the chewy texture, and the spicy sweetness. Made from pure cane sugar, and wholesome goodness. Mango, and orange are my two favorite, though I enjoy all of them.

My cat LOVES these, and because there is 1.4 ounces of real seafood I know he's getting good protein in his diet. No offensive odors. These look and smell enticing. Because my cat shows more interest in the broth, I add just a couple teaspoons of water just to help extend his meal. My cat is 17lbs, so these are really more of an appetizer, or treat. Since adding this as part of his daily diet, he has trimmed down, and gotten leaner.

As an adult colorist, I don't need 'adult' themed coloring books. Well drawn, and preferably print on reasonably decent paper. The pictures in this book are very cute, sweet, and well drawn. I am quite fond of this coloring book. The illustrations remind me of ' Childrens first cook book', and possibly even reminiscent of work by Mary Englebreit. Fairies, Fashion, Florals, and Fantasy..., this one has it all, and I personally am quite pleased for my 80 year old mother bringing this one to my attention. I own far more coloring books, than I'm willing to admit. I've been collecting them for many, many, years. This particular title holds a place somewhere in the top 20 favs. I think it's worth checking out, whether your buying it for a child,  yourself, or a friend.

Easy to assemble, easy to clean, runs quietly, the low hum does not deter my cat. I don't see much room for improvement. I think this drinking fountain was very well thought out, right down to the fact that you can even take apart the pump for cleaning, and for me this was an important feature, as you can clean the bowl and parts, but it's usually the pump that start building mold, and algae.
