My biggest complaint is the crayon isn't as moist as some are so it takes a bit of an effort to do the lining (i.e., stretching the lid of the eye. The shadow portion compliments the liner. I've had this for several months and have used it several times a month. I'm not sure how long the shadow portion will last as the shadow is in the cap and is, looking at the cap, a very small portion. This is a good combo pencil for when you want a different look!

I have several liquid pencil type eyeliners and this is the best. I find it easy to apply and it goes on easily with no problems. Other liquid pencil eyeliners tend to go on erratically, but this one is truly moist enough that it lines smoothly and evenly.

I generally buy only black mascara, but occasionally use a black-brown or a brown. I've had this for awhile and it has lasted...still moist. Goes on easily and the color gives a softer look. It is a good mascara for the price.

If you use black mascara this is a nice dark black on your lashes. The mascara is waterproof and stays on well. My biggest issue with the mascara is the brush. I found it difficult at times to get the mascara evenly distributed on the long-bristled brush so therefore the application of the mascara was uneven resulting in redoing, recovering. Sometimes the brush got too much mascara on parts of it and then clumping occurred which meant I had to take a towel (I cut up old cotton dish towels into make-up size squares) and get the mascara off the brush in order to even out the clumps.

I'm not a big fan of mineral blushes and foundations. They don't look good on me, but this blush's color was perfect for the look I wanted. As with many powdered mineral blushes you need a light hand with the brush. I generally turn the product upside down and then right side up and use the residue on the lid. My biggest issue with this product was getting it to apply evenly. No matter what brush I used (expensive, inexpensive, fake hair, real hair etc) I couldn't get it to apply evenly. Had to really work at it and look closely under natural lighting to make sure it was evenly distributed. However, that said, it is a decent product for the price and if you use a Rose blush--it is a great color.

I got this mascara in a subscription box. I'll be blunt--it certainly is not worth $65 as there are cheaper ones out there that do a comparable job. The packaging is nice and the mascara is a step above many lower priced ones, but still $65? Sorry, but I can't seem to get beyond the price. Okay I've dealt with, for me, a huge negative, now the positives. I did think it applied easily. The brush bristles are a bit different than most mascaras...a spiral around the wand. I had no problems with clumping, dripping etc. My lashes do look longer than usual with this product. A big plus to me is that the mascara does not come off on my lower eye or skin. As I said earlier, and this is just my opinion, and why I gave it four stars, the price is astounding to me for mascara, but for those of you who don't mind paying the price it is an excellent mascara.

My Dior lipsticks have all been gifts, but they are my favorites. The color is true (this is a nice dark plummy lipstick. Goes on smoothly and best of all, if you are not a lipstick biter, stays on. Some of my Dior lipsticks are several years old and I suspect the giver got them at a discount somewhere--they are still as smooth and creamy as they were when I received them.  Are they worth the price? Depends on your wallet and your passion for lipstick!

Dior lipsticks are very expensive and the few I have I've received as gifts. The color is true and they go on well, but most importantly if you don't bite your lipstick off your lips, the color tends to stay on. Are they worth the price? Depends on your pocketbook and your love of lipstick. I love the ones I've gotten as gifts, but not sure I could spring for them with  y own money.

I like the bold color that this Bombshell eyeliner has, however, I don't find it easy to apply evenly. I like to use the amethyst or teal bombshells under my eye and no matter how steady my hand it tends to leave a blob of liner in places. Ditto for application on the top. The staying power also is not as good as some other eyeliners.  If you want a pop of color, the liner is perfect for this purpose. If you want to use this as a liner--you need a steady hand!

This is my favorite concealer. It is lightweight and goes on easily. The color is a good one for me (light/medium) and this blends well with my foundation. Most of the time I can apply it in the morning and it still looks good in the evening. Occasionally I need to reapply. The concealer also feels good going on. It isn't a thick concealer that you need to rub in in order to cover the under eye area. This is more liquidy.

This is a nice waterproof mascara at a decent price. The brush is of higher quality than many cheaper and comparably priced mascaras. The product goes on easily and evenly due to the evenness of the bristles on the brush. The black is a true black. I find the mascara wears well and I only need to apply it in the morning and it lasts all day. Although this has nothing to do with the mascara itself--the metal mascara tube has a very rich luxurious feel and look to it!

As the grandparent of a child who has a rare kind of Down Syndrome--Mosaicism--I want to help him develop his communication skills as much as he can. A Mosaic is a child with Down Syndrome where the cells are not all affected with the T-21 chromosome abnormality. I found this book several years ago and purchased it and ended up giving it to one of his preschool teachers. I repurchased the book to review activities for DS kids that are exiting the toddler stage and entering Kindergarten.This is an excellent resource for those trying to teach a Down Syndrome language, speech and communication. The book is written so that a parent/grandparent/teacher can understand it, but contains facts and research to back up many of the suggestions (the academic component).Most of the reviews of the book so far are very brief. Here is a listing of the chapters to help you decide if you want to purchase the book and if it will be helpful to your child:PLEASE NOTE; AFTER the lengthy chapter listings and CD-Rom summary--you can read my thoughts on some of the content. Just scroll past the chapters if you want get to those thoughts right away.Chapter 1:  Language, Speech, and CommunicationChapter 2:  Speech and Language Characteristics of Children with Down SyndromeChapter 3:  Busy Baby--Busy ParentsChapter 4:  Before the First Word--Precursors to LanguageChapter 5:  The One-Word StageChapter 6:  The Two-and Three-Word StagesChapter 7:  Meaning and GrammarChapter 8:  Speech and Intelligibility ProblemsChapter 9:  Articulation and Phonology: Learning the Sounds of LanguageChapter 10: Pragmatics: Communication in ActionChapter 11: Communicating without SpeechChapter 12: Understanding Speech and Language EvaluationChapter 13: Understanding Speech and Language TreatmentChapter 14: Reading, Literacy, and LanguageChapter 15: School and Community IssuesChapter 16: Concluding ThoughtAppendices:  Communication Evaluation Guidelines for SLPs: For children with Down Syndrome  Speech and Language Referral Guidelines for Pediatricians  Early Intervention Speech and Language Treatment Program Planning Form  Developing a Transitional Communication System  Comprehensive Speech and Language Treatment Guidelines for Children with Down Syndrome from birth to six years  Speech and Language Treatment Program Planning Form: First Word to Age 6  Speech Intelligibility Evaluation Summary Form for children with Down Syndrome  Speech Intelligibility Treatment Program Plan for Children with Down Syndrome  Record form for ArticulationResource GuideReferences and Suggested ReadingChildren's Books for Language StimulationIndexWith the 2012 edition there is a CD-ROM which contains:Forms for Recording Early Communication Milestones (11 forms)Forms for Developing Plans (3 forms)Forms for Evaluation (8 forms)Forms for Treatment Planning (9 forms)My thoughts:The author in the acknowledgements states "For many years, I have worked with infants, toddlers, children, adolescents, and adults with Down syndrome and their families...There is still a great deal to be done to ensure that people with Down syndrome, at all ages, are able to communicate and live a fulfilling life, and I intend to continue to work for that goal." This book is a result of Libby Kumin's efforts to reach that goal and if you have a Down Syndrome child it will help you help them with communication, language and speech.I will admit upfront that I have not read the entire book. I have used chapters and pieces of it to help my grandson's language skills. Communication for anyone is a critical skill and the techniques that Kumin describes and uses will help a DS child increase their chance for success in communicating their needs and become a person who can interact with others.The first chapter details what communication is and gives you some ideas for finding a qualified speech pathologist. The second chapter, while talking about each child developing at their own pace, contains a really nice chart of the Development of Early Communication Skills in children with Down Syndrome. This is what I like about the book--the simplicity for us non-academics. For instance the chart is very easy to understand and the author includes the corresponding research that supports the fact. So if you don't believe it--you can find the research!  Children with DS often having hearing issues and the author addresses this as well as physical characteristics of the muscles/structure of the facial area followed by a chart that shows how each characteristic can affect speech and language. Each chapter is packed with understandable information on speech and how to teach a DS child to formulate words, to "think" about communicating and to the like.The author gives many suggestions in working with a DS child and how to slip learning into every day activities. For instance in Chapter 8/Speech and Intelligibility problems Kumin discusses the factors for affecting intelligibility and gives lists of home activities (in many of the chapters) to help your child speak clearly. There are many activities to choose from and you can pick and choose those that work best for your child. DS kids range from severely impaired to "almost normal" with some of the Mosaics. Some of the children will obviously learn more quickly than others so I feel the author is doing a great service to those of us who are teaching DS kids language skills by providing us with lots of ideas, activities and information that can be tailored to our individual children.The forms in the back of the book and on the CD are great for tracking your child's progress. If your child is in school then you know how complicated and lengthy the IEP's can be--this is much more simple. You can pick and choose the forms you want to use to follow your child's progress. The back of the book provides resources for help which are mainly the larger DS and other organizations that deal with disabilities. The suggested readings are mainly references (lots of academic speak). The very last appendix is a list of children's books to help with language development. They are grouped by subject, i.e.,  Single word objects, Two word books, Finger Play, Manipulatives, Predictable Phrases, TV characters, colors, semantics/vocabulary and more. These are books that are easy to find at a library or bookstore and if you have kids you may already own many of them.Having a child with a disability can be exhausting, but some of this exhaustion comes from trying to communicate. Are you hurt? Are you hungry? What do you want? Simple things a "normal" child can tell you easily, but a child with speech issues cannot. This book provides the means and techniques to help maximize your child's communication skills. Even, if like me, you don't use the entire book--it is worth every penny if you can find even one nugget of information that will help you help your child. And to be honest I can't imagine how you could not find more than one nugget.I do want to emphasize that many of the home techniques are easy to incorporate into your daily activities. Many are activities that we do automatically for a child without DS, but don't think about doing the many simplistic repetitions of for a DS child. A lot of what you can do to help your child with speech is just constantly and consistently (i.e. use the same words) talk to them about "things." There is so much in this book that unless you are a professional speech therapist you can get overwhelmed. Don't be. Just take what you can and incorporate it into your daily life with your child. You will see an improvement. I have...and I'm only with him three or four days a week. I have enlisted the entire family for many of the activities and when we all work together we see a lot of improvement!

I got these to hang a heavy picture--about ten pounds. I realize these are for 30 lb pics, but the hangers for the 10 lbs seemed a little flimsy even hammered into a stud. The nail hammered into the stud easily and the picture is still hanging after a week--so I guess these worked out fine for a ten pound picture/frame.

I just wanted a simple mouse and keyboard. I don't need the bells and whistles since I rarely use any of them...so why pay for them. They keyboard is responsive and is okay with fast typing (80+). The mouse fits my hand well and is responsive.

I don't usually use hair or beauty treatments that take a lot of time to "set" or use as I don't have the patience for waiting. Let's just say my hair suffered greatly at the hands of a beautician who colored it and I needed a deep conditioning to try and start the reparation process. The directions suggest you sit under a dryer or let the steam from a hot shower help it along. I didn't have a dryer and my hot water heater wasn't going to allow for a 15 minute steam, but after a five minute steam, the product seemed to work well. My hair was much healthier after I used this along with an oil based product like Moroccan oil. For me it was worth the 30 minute wait.

I really like this beauty balm. It goes on easily and covers and protects with a 45 SPF. My biggest issue is with the tint. It shows. So blending is imperative if you don't want to go out looking as though you have make up on.

As with many other reviewers I received a sample of Lumiere's reconstructing masque and I love it! Basically you put it on your newly washed hair and then wait two to five minutes (I did five mintues each time I used the sample) then rinse it out. My hair was soft and silky and very manageable which is saying a lot since it is very fine.

Perfumes are obviously a very personal choice. I received a sample of this and really like it. When I first put it on I got a burst of smell like pepper, but it soon settled down to a very light floral fragrance. It is very difficult for me to find a perfume that reacts well with my body chemistry. Before I found Folle De Joie only two other perfumes react well with my skin--Joy by Patou and Byblos. No matter how expensive or how cheap all other perfumes I've tried (which have been hundreds as I do the "tester" test every time I'm in a department store) react negatively with my body chemistry. I'm estatic that Folle De Joie can be added to my very short list of perfumes that don't, within 20 minutes or so, start smelling chemically. This is much lighter than Joy and has a completely different smell than Byblos--so it gives me a third choice when I want to wear perfume. So I'm doing a happy dance!

I wash my hair daily, sometimes twice a day and use products such as Moroccan oil on it to help retain moisture and for shine. I wanted a product for knew I couldn't wash it daily and tried this. Works well. My hair looks clean and shiny and the product is much lighter than the heavier oils so washing your hair daily doesn't need to occur.I rated it four stars because there are no instructions on how to use it. And I like instructions!

My hair is fine and has some natural curl. I found that this product enhanced the curl so that I didn't have to blow dry it and then curl it. I could let it dry naturally and the curls were enhanced...kind of Meg Ryan look with more curl to it. You apply to damp hair and I hand crimped my hair several times during the natural drying period which set the curls.

This is a very rich night cream that is 100% natural and organic. I've used it with First Aid Beauty Ultra Repair Cream-6 oz. on my extremely dry skin and it keeps my skin soft and supple in cry climates. I also have used this with a slight sunburn and it is very soothing. The bottle states you can use it as a hand lotion, but it is pretty pricy if you need to moisturize your hands several times a day, but it does work well!

I started using this at night for severe dry eyes upon my eye doctor's recommendation. This works well, but beware it is an ointment and if you are planning to read or use your tablet after using it--well--everything will be blurry. It lasts most of the night and when awakening you'll find your eyes are not dry, but instead feeling good and most importantly not dry.

My eye doctor recommended this Gel when I suddenly developed 'severe' dry eye. Works great although applying it frequently to moisturize the eye if they are really dry is a bit of a pain.The Gel comes in a container that has a nozzle type opening so that you can apply it easily. I am very careful with anything that I put in my eyes and after not using this for a couple of months I took the cap off and it had mold around the nozzle. I don't think this was GenTeal's fault--most likely mine as I must have touched it with hands that hadn't been washed. So make sure you handle the applicator tip with clean hands. My future purchases have all been perfect as I have wiped the nozzle down with a cloth dipped in boiling water when I know I won't be using it for awhile.

This sunscreen goes on smoothly and gives general protection against the sun. My biggest issue with it is that I really had to blend it due to the tint. I don't really care for blending any type of sunscreen into my face or body...I prefer to think they sit on the surface of my skin doing their job.

My skin is very very sensitive and I found skin nirvana with this cream. The container states it is allergy-tested and fragrance free. Don't know about the allergy testing, but I love that there is no strong smell. There are no harsh chemicals in the cream so this soothes your skin if you have issues with redness or sensitivity.My skin is also very dry and this is great in alleviating the dryness. I use it on my rough elbows and my dry face. My face soaks it up and feels so much better with it. The cream is not greasy so you don't have to worry about looking as though you applied an oil to your skin.I've used a lot of skin creams over the years and this is my absolute favorite.

This is a very pricey scrub in a small plastic-metal lidded container. The scrub does work, but I think the price reflects the packaging more than it reflects the product. The scrub comes wrapped in a cute little bag with a nice quality wooden spoon to get the scrub out (fingers work better in the shower). I used the scrub on my nose and some got in mouth--very salty! Like one other reviewer I found the smell of the scrub to be nauseating...nothing like burned sugar or honey. I think if you like the smell you'll love this, if not, like myself you probably will give it to someone who can tolerate it.So three stars for the scrub and because of the price and smell.

These are my favorite nail files. As I have aged my fingernails have developed slight ridges and this board allows me to file my nails and to even my nails out. When evening the nails out  When evening the nails out I just use the file on the nail that has grown out rather than the whole nail.

I'm big on pillows. At any one time I tend to have at least six to eight on my bed. I use them obviously for sleeping, but also for propping my body up when I read, for propping a book or Kindle up, or for use as a body pillow.  I really like this pillow as a sleeping pillow. It gives me good support for my head and neck, but not so much that I get a crick and not so little that I feel like I'm sleeping on the bed instead of a pillow. One of the inserts states that the pillow may have a slight odor due to the new foam--mine did--but after letting it air for 24 hours like the instructions mentioned--it dissipated.The promotional materials also state that the pillow is hypo-allergenic.Recommend this product!

Hallie Hartley has been taking care of her half-sister Shelly for what seems like forever, but especially since the death of their parents. Shelly is a very self-involved, selfish "user" type of person and Hallie has gotten used to helping her, covering for her and basically putting up with Shelly's meanness and self-centered actions until Shelly tries to steal a vacation home in Nantucket from her by pretending to be Hallie.Hallie stands up for herself and goes off to Nantucket. She shares the home with Jamie who is badly in need of physical therapy from wounds suffered in the war. Jamie is also suffering from PTSD and hovering relatives who tiptoe around him because they are afraid of bringing back memories or upsetting him. Part of the bargain is that Hallie will give him physical therapy.The story is slow and there are a lot of moments that make no sense. I started with this book, but I believe it is either #2 or #3 in the series. Perhaps this would have made more sense if I had read the first book(s). There are ghosts in the book and a lot of characters that I think the author assumes you know. Not sure. Deveraux does a good job with the PTSD and the physical therapy descriptions, but I was somewhat confused by the ghosts, the willing of the house to Hallie and all the characters attending the wedding. I also thought that the "resolution" of Shelly and her issues (I won't go into it as it would be a major spoiler) was rather strange. This needed much more back story and explanation than what was given.To be honest I have gone back and forth over giving this three or four stars and if there was a 3.5 option I'd go for that. The story kept my interest even though I found myself thinking things like "seriously?" or "come on this is so unrealistic!"  If you are a die-hard Jude Deveraux fan you'll probably like this. I do like many of the books that she has written and this wasn't the worst, but wasn't her best either!

Size large is perfect for my very tall 8 month old.  It keeps him warm at night when our home dips down to 60 degrees.  My son wears a cotton footed pajama by Old Navy underneath.  When even colder he also wears a Carter's onesie beneath the footed pjs.  We also have a sleeping hat from Gymboree in case its needed though my son tends to take it off while trying to fall asleep.  I love that this has cotton and not fleece on the outside as polyester makes me itch like crazy.  I actually wish though that this sack was a tad thicker thus warmer because we live in southern CA and do not heat our home... so our house may get down into the 50s in winter.

The cowboy is great, but the bull did not meet my expectations.  The bull is smaller than Fisher-Price's cows which is a bit odd... I guess I will have to teach my son its a young and not fully grown bull.  The bull also has a shiny look, meaning the entire bull was painted.  I prefer by far when the plastic is dyed for the body so there is less paint per animal especially because these toys end up in children's mouths.  Overall, I wish I could have bought just the cowboy.
I did not like the illustrations for either the hardback or the paperback.  Both were odd in completely different ways.  Returning.

After 10 years of searching, these are the ONLY vitamins that I could tolerate.  I had no bladder pain, no stomach pain, no throwing up, and no allergic reactions... it even got me through a very difficult pregnancy in which I lost 17 lbs.  I intended to take these vitamins for the rest of my life because I cannot find any other multi-vitamin that I could tolerate... BUT THEN they changed the flavors to include ORANGE?!  I am deadly allergic to oranges... now what am I supposed to do?  I have so many nutrient deficiencies and I desperately needed these vitamins to make it through just one day at a time.  I am devastated.

My son LOVES his Noah Ark set that was given to him as a gift... and this bonus set adds pandas and turtles to a set my son enjoys so much.  HOWEVER - why does the set add more lions?  The original Noah's Ark already comes with 2 lions and the male and female clearly distinguished (unlike the two in this set).  Plus the original lions are better in nearly every way... I mean this male lion came with paint on his chin like a goatee which was really odd - it needs a mane!  Frankly, it makes NO sense to include more lions in the bonus set because Noah's ark only had animals like lions in twos (not fours.)  Fisher-price put in some rhinos or alligators or toucans or heck Noah's Wife -all of those molds you already have so just use them...  then this set would be 5-star.

I like these so much - I wish they made them for older kids too.  my son is 4.5 inches long in the foot and only 8 months old.  He was able to wear these dog booties until he reached about 4.25 inches.  Perhaps mine were cut longer?

The just prunes did not taste all that wonderful, but it works wonders when a baby is backed up.  I was never able to produce enough milk for my baby so he was struggling with constipation from drinking formula.  At 4 months old we added brown rice cereal into my son's diet which helped but not enough... so we added in some prunes.  First, we learned you really should not do too much (two entire pouches over 2 days) because our baby got the runs!  Now we use this only when our son needs it and mix it with other flavors like mango so it tastes better.... My son has no more constipation!

OK little coloring book with dinos not usually put in kids books. Scan and enlarge the images so you can print them at a good size for your little one - however the artwork is not that great compared to other Dover mini coloring books, so I wonder if its worth all that effort to scan.  Teaches your child coloring in the lines, names of the dinos, some facts about the dinos, and reading.  The paper is of a good weight - you cannot see the image on the back side.  Dinos are presented in alphabetically with a large letter to color.  My only complaints are:  a few of the dinos look strange and not quite what I expected - I suspect the dimensions of the dinos are not correct.  Also, a few of the facts are wrong/outdated... for example the T-Rex is not the largest carnivore to have ever lived.  On land, the largest discovered was the Spinosaurus and at sea, there was a lot more that were bigger.  Lastly, the dinosaurs are not the main focus of each two-page spread... the alphabet letter is which was not the focus I expected.  A larger coloring book focusing on the dinos would have better met my needs.Here is the the list of the animals:- Apatosaurus (states is the same as Brontosaurus)- Brachiosaurus- Compsognathus- Deinonychus- Elasmosaurus- Fabrosaurus- Geosaurus- Hadrosaurus- Iguanodon- Janenschia- Kentrosaurus- Lambeosaurus- Megalosaurus- Nanotyrannus- Oviraptor- Parasaurolophus- Quetzalcoatlus- Rhamphorhynchus- Stegosaurus- Tyrannosaurus- Ultrasaurus- Velociraptor- Wannanosaurus- Xenotarsosaurus- Yandusaurus- Zephyrosaurus

This is my FAVORITE gluten free chocolate icing.  It does not have artificial flavors and other such things which makes it a good choice for my family (with a lot of allergies and health problems).  I make the icing with cream cheese so it has a nice thickness to it plus some protein to balance out the sugar.  Even my husband (who does not need to eat gluten free) looks forward to eating this icing on a number of things from cupcakes, muffins, cookies, etc.  He always asks when I will be making something to put the chocolate frosting on.  Just make sure you do not put too much icing on each item... because of course its really sweet - its icing!  Its ok to eat sugar now and then, just don't overdo it.

This is my FAVORITE gluten free cornbread and I am on a strict gluten-free diet for medical reasons... so its VERY nice to actually have something this tasty to eat.  I add in sweet corn kernels which makes it extra special.  Even my husband (a wheat eater) looks forward to eating this cornbread and always asks when I will be making it next.  Just make sure you do not over cook it or it will be too dry and crumbly.  Always check for done-ness with a toothpick or knife as the cooking time will greatly vary (at least in my experience). Also, I found the mix a tad too sweet so I half the amount of sugar I put in it especially because I am adding in sweet corn.

Though I love sauropods, I have to say this model has some issues and more than the other dino models I purchased from the same company.Cons: After one touch from my son, the paint on its muzzle is coming off. That does not show longevity and it means you better not clean this with anything moist or barely damp. The apatosaurus model is also approximately 13" long x 5" tall x 3" wide. This size compared to the T-Rex model is too small; the apatosaurus is a much bigger dino. In fact, its too small compared to all the other dinos I bought from this company.. The company needs to work on accurate comparable sizes for different species.http://www.amazon.com/Schleich-14525-Tyrannosaurus-Rex/dp/B0073RSVMC/ref=cm_cr_pr_product_top?ie=UTF8

Pros: Well done. It is approximately 6.25" long x 3.5" tall x 2.25" wide. Great coloring - you actually feel like it is alive, ancient, and staring at you!  Very engaging and was actually around at the same time as the T-Rex and on the same continent (unlike the stegosaurus).Cons: I think the company needs to work keeping the relative sizes between dino species as accurate as possible.Comparative Size: Below are links to the stegosaurus, saichania, and T-Rex I bought. In reality the saichania and styracosaurus are pretty similar in size though the styracosaurus is shorter in length.  In reality, the styracosaurus is much smaller than the T-Rex and stegosaurus.  BUT though smaller, it is still about half the height of a T-Rex, so its not THAT small.  But in the toy form, the styracosaurus is too short next to the T-Rex, too big compared to the stegosaurus.  I really want my son to see the correct size difference in these models because its not like we cannot see dinos at the zoo. So that was my only complaint.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0073RJRZM?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0073RSVMC?ref_=cm_rdp_producthttp://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0073RFP6C?ref_=cm_rdp_product

Though I love stegosauri, I have to say this model has some issues and more than the other dino models I purchased from the same company.Cons:  After one touch from my son, the paint on its muzzle is coming off.  That does not show longevity and it means you better not clean this with anything moist or barely damp.  The stegosarus model is also approximately 6.5" long x 4" tall x 1.75" wide.  This size compared to the T-Rex model is too small; they should be nearly the same height.  Also, its too small compared to the saichania (as it should be significantly taller and slightly longer.)http://www.amazon.com/Schleich-14525-Tyrannosaurus-Rex/dp/B0073RSVMC/ref=cm_cr_pr_product_top?ie=UTF8http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0073RFP6C?ref_=cm_rdp_product

Pros: WOW this dino is sturdy and well done.  It is approximately 6.5" long x 2.5" tall x 2.25" wide.  Great coloring - you actually feel like it is alive and staring at you!  Its not as engaging at the T-Rex, but it was actually around at the same time as the T-Rex though in a different continent (unlike the stegosaurus which are much older).Cons:  I think the company needs to work keeping the relative sizes between dino species as accurate as possible.Comparative Size:  Below are links to the stegosaurus and T-Rex I bought.  In reality the saichania is smaller than both the T-Rex and the stegosaurus.  BUT though smaller, it is still over half the height of a T-Rex, so its not THAT small.  But in the toy form, the saichania is way too short next to the T-Rex (like a 4th its height).  The model also has the about the same length as the stegosaurus (I also partially blame the stegosaurus for not being large enough). I really want my son to see the correct size difference in these models because its not like we cannot see dinos at the zoo.  So that was my only complaint.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0073RJRZM?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0073RSVMC?ref_=cm_rdp_product

Pros:  WOW this dino stands on two feet, is big (approximately 11" long x 5" tall x 3" wide), and more impressive than I thought it would be.  Great coloring and VERY engaging - you actually feel like it could come alive and bite you!Cons:  In order for the model to stand on only two feet, I think they shortened its tail from its real length.  Also it has a movable jaw to chomp everything - which sounds nice until you realize such things can break.  I would be gentle on the jaw to ensure it lasts.  The biggest issue for me, was that its size is significantly greater than the other dinos by this same maker that I already owned.  I really think the company needs to work on accurate sizing between dino species.  As a side issue, most of the sauropods related to the T-Rex have been revealed in the fossil record to have feathers - it seems pretty likely that the T-Rex did as well and I want to see models with feathers ;-)Comparative Size: Below is the link to the stegosaurus I bought = in reality the stegosarus and T-Rex were nearly the same height through the T-Rex was about a third longer and much bulkier.  But in the toy form, the T-Rex is 2 inches taller which is way too tall and not accurate enough for me.  I know that the stegosaurus and T-Rex did not actually co-exist (coming from completely different times in Earth's history), but I really want my son to see the correct size difference in these models because its not like we cannot see dinos at the zoo.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0073RJRZM?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00

Bigger than I imagined.  So the perfect size for a toddler.  Very sturdy and well made.  I feel they should have had tiny holes in the top to let air in and out.  Those air holes allow the molded sand to come out easier plus it prevents air pockets from holding the sand away from the former thus prevents misshapen sand prints.  I am pleased because nothing of this quality was available locally.

I was looking for books on how animals behaved in each season for younger children ages 3-5.  For spring, I went with animal life cycles since many reproduce in spring like birds nesting etc.  For fall, I had a book on preparing for winter as well as a book on migrations.  So, I got this one to cover animals in winter.  I was a bit disappointed that the book rehashes fall animal behaviors like migration, storing food, etc since I already had books on those topic.  I understand that since many fall behaviors are preparation for winter, and so they are connected to winter behaviors.  But mentioning all those things again made the book feel redundant and made the winter section feel slimmer than the title seemed to indicate.  I will probably use the slimmer fall book with a younger crowd and use this longer book with an older crowd.  I may add in a few other winter behaviors though like bears raising their babies undergound etc. just to make the content longer for winter.

I think this is a great game to use with 2-3 year olds to build their observation skills.  You cannot just grab a yogurt - you have to [ay attention to if its the right flavor/color.  I would play only one board at a time with a young child and let them point out what is in the lunchbox then find the tile that matches it.  I could also could use the food pieces for sorting games, but I will need to mark them as to which game they go inside - in order to not to mix them up with the pieces in other games by the same company.

I bought this for the stand and the veggies/foods and coins that came with it (not for the game itself).  I already own a cash register and a number of vegetables/foods from IKEA which will form an activity center with this veggie stand.  I intend to use it to learn food groups, naming veggies, counting coins, etc.  I love the strawberries, potatoes, peppers, and wooden eggs... all of which I did not already own.  I think getting only one carrot in the set was a bit underwhelming - there should have been 2-3 carrots.  Also, the set is not self contained, meaning there is a gaping hole in the over so there is nothing to store the pieces in.  Adding a piece of cardboard that can be interested as a lid would have been a good idea.The actual game was not that exciting because there was only so many items that could be purchased and those items chosen on each card were not ingredients to cook something fun... so it really did not catch our interest... but I liked all the individual parts.

The big "crystals" look totally plastic, cheesy, and don't work.  They are not completely transparent (ie: are cloudy) so you hardly can see through them and reflects light poorly, they are poorly made/misshapen/dented, the sticky on the bottom is uneven and distorts the image of what is beneath it, and they don't really sparkle.  Frankly this is WAY too expensive for junk.I am sure we can use the rest of the supplies to make photo ornaments... but we could have done that for a FAR lower price.  I feel stupid and ashamed for buying this.

Seems well made and I like the bright colors.  The blocks actually look like trees, people, and a home, etc.  The non-circular face has a smile in the opposite direction on the back so it can placed flat side up or down and still have a face in the right direction.The puzzles to solve are shown visually in a spiral book.  The "day" side (called starter) shows you where every block piece goes in real color.  These puzzles appear good for ages 2/3 because all you have to do is place the blocks on the pegs in the right order and the correct direction so its identical to the image.  The "night" side (called master) only shows the shadow of the final structure which is a far greater challenge because you have to pay attention to each blocks shape and the shadow it makes.  These puzzles appear good for ages 4/5 though I can see some 3 year olds or gifted 2 year olds picking up the idea but they might need a little assistance in learning the skills/concepts.MY SUGGESTIONS:  Only take this toy out to use when doing each puzzle so it keeps its interest.  Also, have some kind of reward like a sticker card for each puzzle completed with a grand prize when all the starter level is complete and another grand prize when the master level is complete.  Before doing the master level, I also strongly suggest kids do a science unit on shadows, make shadow puppets, and even play with this game's blocks in a darkened room with a flashlight so they get used to what each pieces' shadow look like.  I also think that for master levels, you should check each puzzle's completion by making its shadow with a flashlight in a darkened room.  You can look at the back of each shadow page which shows you the solution in full color, but that is not as fun and smart kids will learn to cheat by just turning the page over.  Also, once a level is complete, I would have your child tell you what they see in the scene that made in order to tap into their art/imagination.  You will be surprised how different students interpret the same image.CONS:  The spiral book is a bit flimsy with thin pages and will not last with regular use.  I prefer thick cards so you can set one out at a time as in the bunny box game from the same company.  I wish the pegs had been the same heights as that would have enabled a greater number of blocks to be on each peg and thus increase the number of puzzle possibilities.  I also wish the set came with a few extra block pieces.  These extra pieces would again have increased the number of puzzles to solve PLUS would make the game more complex as it went along.  Basically, once you figure out each pieces' shape/color for the basic level and each pieces shadows for the master level... even the highest numbered cards are not that challenging.  BUT if you add in a few new shapes now and then it would really mix things up and make this set far more valuable.  Overall, the price is a tad much for only 24 puzzles (the same image shown as day and again as night).  If it had been 75 total unique puzzles (instead of the day and night puzzles being identical) it would be worth the $20-25 price tag in my opinion.TO LENGTHEN USE:  Pick up some additional blocks that fit the pegs or you can even drill holes into blocks you already own.  You can leave the blocks natural or paint them with child safe colors.  Then either you or the kids themselves can design new puzzles intermixing with the old and new puzzle blocks.  All you really need is a camera, a color printer, some blank flashcards, and acid free glue/double sided tape.  Also, for kids learning to read, you could even have them follow written instructions in order to build the correct image.  However, making master shadow cards would be more of a challenge as its difficult to photograph shadows, but it is possible if you scan the block images into the computer, reduce their image size by the same amount, then all you have to do is turn the blocks a dark grey on a white background, and rearrange them any way you want - then print.  It definitely would be harder than the day images that can just be photographs.Overall, the product needs improvement.  There needs to be a greater umber of puzzles, a greater range of complexity, the day and night puzzles should NOT be identical, the puzzle images should be on sturdy cards, and there should be a greater number of blocks to lengthen the usefulness of this educational toy.  I will use this product, but I am going to have to do some supplementation which was not something I expected.  The Logic Street game was far better in execution.

This review is about the PRODUCT not the price.  Please note the VAST majority of negative reviews are about amazon's pricing which has nothing to do with the product itself.  I buy the boxes for under $4.00 at various locations.About the product...I buy these teethers because they are gluten free, organic, and NOT made in China.  I have gluten intolerance as well as a number of other allergies - there is a chance my genes were passed to my son.  Eating gluten as a child ruined my life and I want to protect my son from that suffering.  These teethers are a great alternative to oat / wheat teething products for crawling babies.  I have found nothing else in the stores that meets that need for us.At first, my son was confused as to what these things were.  He thought they were a toy and was confused when they broke off or started to dissolve in his mouth....  But once he got familiar with the idea (and his first baby teeth) - he was chomping away and working on his dexterity.  Now he gets really excited when i pull out a teether cracker.  He loves them and the ability to feed himself.These crackers do dissolve, but it takes a little time to do so unless your child is drooly.  Because of this, i suggest you first dip the chewing end in a little formula (quickly so they don't dissolve compeltely) then give it to your baby.  That way the baby can get used to eating them safely.  Slowly wean off the pre-dipping and then your baby will gradually learn to chew the hard cracker by himself.Warning - Never leave a baby eating these crackers unattended!  My baby had enough strength to crack the teether in half and a sharp shard came off.  He then put the long sharp piece in his mouth.  I rushed over to grab it, but he swallowed it before I could get to him.  Thankfully, he did not choke - so the teether was already starting to melt.  Just in case, i gave him a few sips of his bottle to make sure it was fully dissolved.  Afterward my son was perfectly fine and reaching for more.  The whole incident did scare me as a mom - So I strongly suggest you stay right next to your baby while they are eating these.  Its for this reason that I took one star off the product.  I think the crackers could dissolve a little faster.Also, the teethers leave a sticky mess so be ready to wipe your baby's hands and anything else down after eating these.
A lot to love here and re-read for years to come, but as with all books of poetry... i never like them all.  What I did not like however seemed to be the minority of the book.

This book was just ok for me.  I got it because I wanted a mini-encyclopedia-like book that was a simpler intro to planets for 3-5 year olds than the other options on the market.  I have a number of other books in the same series all on biological science and liked them enough to buy this one on astronomy as well.  However, it does not exactly meet the standard set by the other books in the series and I probably will return it.Pros:  Real images of the objects.  Content separated into smaller sections with a table of contents.  Pop ups that at often show closeups of objects.  Bolded vocab.  Info is up to date with Pluto being a dwarf planet.  Talks about more than just the planets and our sun like stars, galaxies, and rockets.Cons:  Images spread over the crack which distorts them / hard to really see (same issue in all the books of the series).  If the text is bolded than the vocab is unbolded (again same issue throughout the book series).  Some of the images are actually rendered and do not necessarily match reality (like Titan's surface.)  I also felt the pop ups sometimes brought up information that cannot be clearly understood without more details because a word was not defined or that topic had not yet been explained anywhere else in the book. The book shows the major moons for Jupiter, Earth, Uranus, as well as the dwarf planets, but skips the major moons from Saturn.  There are a lot of good images of certain things that the book just skipped over like a REAL closeup photo of the rings.  In the end, I just felt that this book should have done a better job of presenting, explaining, and even organizing information.

I wanted some creative ideas with dinos.  I was blown away by this book.  Seriously, I was expecting lame and can't ever really look good kids crafts.  These are far beyond that... in fact these projects can be done from the very young to the oldest of us all.  Yes they were that good.Projects:1. Long necked dino - appropriate for youngest kids adn could even do the same steps for giraffes.2. Dino mouths - could be appropriate at any age because could use as the front of the card and open up the mouth to read what the dino is saying.3. Water dinos - techniques applicable from elementary school onward to adulthood.  Could use also with flying fish, whales, dolphins, etc.  BEAUTIFUL.4.  Standing dinos - seen better on this craft for older children and adults, but this version is designed with the littlest kids involved.5.  Hatching dinos - seems to be a version of decopauge... elementary school through young adults... or for the odd scientist who wants hatching dinos as an Easter decor = )6.  Volcano painting - techniques applicable from elementary school onward to adulthood.  Could use with other painting techniques to have a starry sky, sunset, etc.  Really liked this one.7.  Another take on standing dinos - for ages 5-7 I think.  Still seen better for older kids and adults.8.  Glowing eye pterosaur - only project in the book I thought was lame and would never do.9.  Doodling dinos - great for all ages.  I was surprised how such simplicity was so cute.10.  Layered paper and cut outs picture - could really do this with any dino or animal or anything else you want.  Ages 6+ is my guess.11.  Swamp painting - techniques applicable from elementary school onward to adulthood.  Could do all sort of misty swampy ecosystems like the Egyptian Nile, Louisianian, Floridian, etc.  I can even see Egrets in farmland in the misty morning or misty bamboo forests with pandas.12.  Mobile pterosaur - takes a bit of logic to do it so 6+ if the teach makes the lines ahead of time.13.  Dino collage - WOW this technique could be done with anything - just so impressed.  never thought of collages as a true art form until I saw this.  All ages if you vary the complexity.14.  Drawing dinos with spots - all ages and can vary the method to be more cartoony or more realistic.15.  Dino shaped greeting cards - can be done by all ages because i know a lot of grandmas who would love to send dino cards to their grandsons.16.  Bubble wrap printed skins - can be used for more than dinos and i am sure other things besides bubble wrap can be used.  So many possibilities in this idea.17.  Moonlight animal - WOW I never thought of that but its so simple - chalk gives a hazy edge around the moon that just makes the whole picture work.  I can so see doing this project with nocturnal animals, things for Halloween, etc.I was so pleased with this that I am going to buy their 1000 collection in the same series.

I am impressed.  Some ideas were repetitive and others were no-brainers.. but some were just breathtaking and really opened up my imagination to all the possibilities.  As a scientist, I enjoy art and crafts, but its not my forte at designing...  This will help me design and implement engaging art-based projects with a variety of skill sets/methods.  For 20 dollars, I feel like I can approach homeschooling art in a far more meaningful way.  So glad I bought it.  These projects could be done from preschool through high school, just varying the size of the projects, expanse of materials, and skill difficulty depending on the age of the students.  For example : the teacher could pre-cut some shapes for making the collages so kids only have to glue them together OR the teacher draws an outline on the page to give kids a guideline to work from.Here is SOME of what you get in the book.... i stopped trying to list things at page 222 and even then i was just summarizing what was on each page.  There is really so much here.- Drawing / Doodling:  Cats, Castles, Dogs, People, Decorated elephants, traffic, city skyline, fingerprint crowd, hearts, flowers, birds, buuterflies, patterns, under the sea, hands, day vs. night, trapeze artists, chalk under sea image, superheros, curly animals, athletes, faces, and much more.- Paper cut outs / collage:  Monkeys, Cupboard collage, Winter city/street, Clowns, Sea boats, Bird tree, Valentine cards, Trees, Plants, Under the sea animals, Gift tags, Shoes, Robots, Faces, Outer space, Fall tree, Tissue paper aquarium, monsters, crazy animals, penguins, scribbling bugs, stadium and town from above, cats, birds, bugs, faces, embossed cards, rubbing space collage, princesses, button flowers, reindeer garland, paper weaving, figures, robots, dogs, kimonos, owls, cakes, Christmas ornaments, kites, and much much more- 3D art out of cardboard cut outs / folding paper / foil / etc.:  Dinosaurs, Palm trees, People, Box monsters, Pop up cards, spiders, birds, cats, bugs, Christmas cones, paperdollish chains, Butterflies, elephants, Utensil people n creatures, cats, dogs, paper beads, beach animals, layered town, decoupage boxes, pipe cleaner bugs, box cities and much much more.- Paint/Painting focus and may be combined with another art type:  Textured paper butterflies, Blow-paint monsters, Safari picture, Textured paper ice cream, Dragon, Stamping with veggies, Windy day picture, Colored paper towel chameleons, flamingos with soap, spooky castle, parrots, thumbprint birds and bugs, wax repelling paint reptiles n birds, fruit/flower patterns, dot mosaics, drip poppies, spooky shadow forest, rats, handprint sea animals, lab experiment art, fingerprint snowmen n penguins, sponge creatures, trees, rabbit tunnel painting, deep sea fish, Fingerprint animals, Stenciled shark, printed Cars and trains, and much much more.- Stitching: Felt animals, Beads and sequins hearts and flowers, etc.

I was underwhelmed.  The images were beautiful but the book seemed out of order and disjointed.  Pages 14 and 15 seemed like they should have been at the start of the book since it introduces the topic and defines vocabulary.  Plus, each animal's "story" was split having a section before and after pages 14/15 - so you felt like it was really two books or was assembled wrongly (I checked the page numbers and it was correct).  Returning.

Great little coloring book with animals not usually put in kids coloring books. Scan and enlarge the images so you can print them at a good size for your little one. Teaches your child coloring in the lines, names of the animals, and reading. The paper is of a good weight - you cannot see the image on the back side.  Animals presented in alphabetically order.  My only complaints are:  a few of the animals (a very small portion of the book) don't look quite right to me... but the rest is wonderful and well worth the purchase of the book.  Also, most of the names are very specific as to the species but then the camel is just a camel... I wish they kept the specificity throughout the book.  Lastly, the tortoise is labeled a turtle - there is a difference.Here is the the list of the animals:- Aardvark- Addax- Adelie Penguin- Alligator- Armadillo- Baboon- Bat- Beaver- Bighorn Sheep- Bison- Bobcat- Bottlenose Dolphin- Camel- Cape Buffalo- Caribou- Cheetah- Chimpanzee- Crested Porcupine- Eagle- Elephant- Fawn- Flamingo- Gazelle- Giraffe- Goat- Gorilla- Grizzly Bear- Hawk Owl- Hippopotamus- Kangaroo- Leopard- Lion- Llama- Moose- Mountain Goat- Mountain Lion- Musk-ox- Opossum- Orangutan- Panda- Pelican- Puffin- Rabbit- Red Fox- Rhinoceros- Saki Monkey- Sea Lion- Snowy Egret- Swan- Tarsier- Three-toed Sloth- Tiger- Turtle (really a tortoise)- Vervet Monkey- Walrus- Weasel- White-tailed Deer- Wolf- Yellow Rat Snake- Zebra

This is a pretty good book on how animals prepare for winter.  Deals with fattening up, hibernating, migration, fur changes, etc.  Each "chapter" is around 4 pages long with about 8-10 lines to read.  Read only one chapter at a time for really small kids like 2 year olds and read read the full book at once for older kids like 6-7 year olds.

Great book on simple machines, more complex machines, and musical instruments.  I was very happy and surprised at the quality.  I suggest however that the book be used with older aged children since most of the explanations are written out with only 1-2 diagrams.  Maybe you can look at some of the images with a 6 year old, but its more like an 8+ book to me.

I bought the cards to use in a unit on light and shadows... because I felt putting images on the wall would be very engaging and a good introduction to the topic of study.  But the set ended up being useful in SO many others ways.First, the cards can be used with a light to create bright images on the wall if the room is darkened.  I tried it out and it works really well.  I don't trust that the provided light will last that long, but any flashlight should do.  This can be a fun way to practice names of objects, letter sounds, and even do a puppet-like show.  I can even see doing it in a tent while camping, in a classroom with the lights dimmed, with homeschool kids down in the dark basement during the heat of summer, at bedtime, etc.Second, the punch outs can be used as name what object makes the shadow, as a sorting game of the different types of animals (birds, fish, reptiles, amphibians, and mammals), and there are a lot of other odd shapes that would be great pieces for making a mosaic/modern art project.Third, the cards can be used stencils for tracing scenes on paper then coloring or decorating the scenes.  Since there are so many objects shown, you could make quite a number of themed scenes (examples: the umbrella, boy, girl stencils plus cotton balls as the clouds to make a rainy day... or an underwater scenes stenciling all sorts of sea creatures then using tissue paper to make the seaweeds.)  Honestly the possibilities are pretty extensive.VERY VERY pleased with the item except for three things.... first, the backing on the cards tries to come off espcailly when you are trying to take out the punched pieces.  Second, I think the card should have been a slightly stronger cardboard for longevity especially with the stenciling.  Third, I wish the images of objects and letters were done in as few sections as possible - too often the divisions were not necessary (for ample the jellyfish was divided into 3 pieces when the octopus was only one piece).  A single whole cutout object works better for both the light show and punch out usages.Overall, for only $5 bucks or so that is ALOT of possibilities.

Three reasons I do not like this product.1. It was not clearly labeled as a water squirter. I thought I was purchasing fully sealed plastic animals for teething. I never ever buy bath squirters.2. Since squirters have a tiny hole in it - it will grow mold inside if used in the bath AND bacteria/viruses/food will be sucked inside if the child teethes on it thus can transmit disease. Bleaching them will not effectively clean the inside of the squirters so you would have to replace them regularly which is waste of money and resources.3. The paint comes off and a child will ingest it. All i did was wash them gently with soap and lukewarm water... then the paint started transferring and staining each the other animals. These were cute enough that they did not need paint at all.Overall, it was a waste of my money to buy these. I didn't realize they were squirters until after the return date when i got them out to use with my teething 7 month old. Won't use them.

I never ever buy bath squirters.2. Excellent. Exactly what I wanted. Spiral bound journal to use with ages 3-5. Has a place to draw a picture then 2 lines afterward to write a simple sentence. Each assignment is one side of the page. Each book holds 60 assignments which is enough to do 2 journaling assignments per week for an entire year or for two years (minus the weeks with holidays that shorten teaching time).  Assignments are left in the journal so students can reflect back on their progress. The paper quality was exceptional. Cover is nice and sturdy compared to journals I typically purchase.  Extremely pleased especially with the price at Lakeshore which was around 3 dollars

Excellent. Exactly what I wanted. Spiral bound journal to use with ages 3-5 year olds. Each two-page spread has the letter and a sample word at the top, then spaces for 7 words to be written.  Has a place to draw a picture for each word.  There are 24 assignments (as XYZ are combined).  There are also tracing pages for the alphabet at the start and end of the book.  Assignments are left in the journal so students can reflect back on the words they have learned or add additional ones when they learn them. The paper quality was exceptional. Cover is nice and sturdy compared to journals I typically purchase. Extremely pleased especially with the price at Lakeshore which was around 3 dollars

Spiral bound journal to use with ages 4-7. Has a 2-page spread for each letter of the alphabet.  On the left side has a list of words starting with that letter and on right side there are 12 lines to write words starting with that letter.  Each assignment is on the back of one page and the front of another page. Each book holds 24 assignments (because XYZ are combined).  There is also tracing pages of the alphabet in the front and back of the journal.  I would have students write new words in their book as they discover/learn them,  The pages are left in the journal so students can reflect back on their words and add to their lists. The paper quality was exceptional. Cover is nice and sturdy compared to journals I typically purchase.  However, I felt including word lists defeated the purpose of finding and recording words... many students will just copy what is already given.  Pleased especially with the price at Lakeshore which was around 3 dollars.

Excellent.  Exactly what I wanted.  Spiral bound journal to use with ages 4-7.  Has a place to draw a picture then 19 lines afterward to write a simple story.  Each assignment is one page front and back.  Each book holds 30 assignments which is enough to do 1 journaling assignment per week for an entire year (minus the weeks with holidays that shorten teaching time).  Assignments are left in the journal so students can reflect back on their progress.  The paper quality was exceptional.  Cover is nice and sturdy compared to journals I typically purchase.  Extremely pleased especially with the price at Lakeshore which was around 3 dollars.

This was given to me at my baby shower and I could not imagine being able to scrapbook my son's infancy without it.  I used it together with Carter's First year Calendar Wonder and some scrapbook stickers by various companies.  The pages have turned out ADORABLE.  My only issue is the photo frames provided were not enough - especially given most people are not going to want to use pink boarders with their boys.  Plus most of the provided frames were on the smaller size, when I needed more larger ones.  I started putting some photos in without boarders and accenting them with stickers instead of the frame.  Also, some pages did not really apply to us, but that is ok because I just strategically decorated it and placed a photo on top so you would never know the page was designed for something else.  Lastly, for the longer journaling sections.  I started writing above each "By 8 months..." etc. that way I can keep track of which time period the journaling is talking about.  This method enabled me to literally journal for every 2 months during my son's first year.Overall, it was the perfect baby shower gift.

I own the Watch Me Draw Dinosaurs book but it did not have enough variety and did not explain each step very well... ultimately with the premade worksheets that other book was good for 4-6 year olds, but I wanted something better for ages 7+.  That is why I bought 123 Draw Dinosaurs.  This book had a large variety of organisms and clear steps even specifying when to erase (which was missing the previous book).  I was very pleased that a list was provided at the end of the book specifying which time period each animal came from.  This was a HUGE plus because I had just spend hours the day before looking for such a chart online to no avail and wallah! it was in my recently purchased art book!  Most kids think all the pre-historic dinos lived together, but the didn't.  It was not until I was an adult that I learned T-Rex did not eat stegosaurus.  If I could help this book in any way, it would be to include feathers on the dinos shown to have them by recent fossil evidence, accurate colors when the fossil evidence provides that information, and accurate measurements/stature.  There were a few dino dimensions/stature that I questioned particularly the spinosaurus and ankylosaurus, but the book was created in.  I also think an image comparing the size to an adult human would have helped kids understand how big these creatures really were.  Overall, I will look into buying more books in the series.

Its the only history workbook for little kids that tries to not merely listing facts to memorize, but explains what history and time lines are and solidifying it with things a child can connect to or find interesting.  However, it falls short of its vision.  I would have designed/presented info a tad differently and the book started feeling too random instead of scaffold-ed learning.  I also feel the book tries to do too much social science when it should just stick to history and timelines.  Because of that, I give the book only 3 stars.  Overall, I think the book should not be used with kids under the age of 5 just because of how much reading is involved and not everything is shown in illustrations.  Some of the projects you could do with younger kids if you simplified the knowledge.  Also the book seems aimed at Christians if that is an issue for you.Here are some of the changes I will do in using the book:pages 6-7.  Instead of placing pennies along the number line, tie something durable onto the yarn at equally-set intervals that way you can measure once and reuse the time line for this book and for years to come.  Things you can tie on could be colored ribbon or yarn, beads, rocks with a hold in them, etc.  These markers can represent first second third, decades, centuries, days, years... anything you want.  Its really important that when history is taught, you can place in immediately in context and this time line will do just that IF you remember to use it.pages 10-11.  Instead of having a very little kid try to draw modern objects, why not cut them out of newspapers, magazines, or print off the internet then tape it into the book with double-sided tape?  A little kid is not going to be able to draw a modern warship, car, shoes, or jet that easily and they need to be able to recognize the object and compare differences to the past... so real images would be best.page 13.  Instead of drawing a photo of yourself, why not put a real baby photo to see how far they have grown/matured.pages 14-15.  Take the yarn timeline made at the start of the book and place all these photos and events in order on the timeline.  Place them at the approximate dates so kids can see that things do not happen at equal distances from each other.page 17.  Skip the floppy tree and just make a 2D one on a poster board.  The family tree can be made well enough to be hung as a family treasure (in the dining room for example.)page 22-23.  They do the history of Thanksgiving, but I felt the information was lacking.  I read a lot of words, but did not feel I really learned much.  So I would supplement this topic with a lot of other information.... there is more information on pages 24 & 25 on the pilgrims which would help, but not really much more about how Thanksgiving meals have changed over time which is the focus of the kid's project.  I think instead of just drawing your own thanksgiving meal, it would be best to choose a few different versions through time and/or a few different ones from different areas.  I mean in my household we eat tempura for Thanksgiving and no we are not Asian... its just what we consider to be a very special celebratory meal.pages 26-27.  I would have preferred for the child to look up each style of boat, print the image, and place on the yarn timeline.  Maybe even researching the types of people and cultures that used each boat and for what purposes.  That would have taught more history and reinforced timelines more than simply folding an origami boat.Page 28-29.  Find images for one toy in each time period, print, and put them on the yarn timeline.. can even find the exact dates released to place them as accurately as possible.  Seeing the real images in the real placement along the number line is better than what is in the book.  Randomly choosing 4 toys, drawing them in 4 boxes, when the time spacing between toys does not equal reality.Page 30-31.  This is Christmas history very light.  Would have preferred something you could actually timeline here... or at least taught different cultural practices that were adopted into our Christmas celebration.  I wish the info was at least was honest about the true history of Christmas.  It was a pagan holiday and the church put the celebration of Jesus on that same day in order to change the holiday to be Christian.  A lot of the rituals had pagan roots, but have been adopted to mean Christian ideas.  There is no project really for this page which again is odd.Pages 32-33.  Really liked the honesty of the history here regarding the 3 kings visiting Jesus... but the project was too history light - just make a Christmas ornament.  No timelines here or cultural comparisons.Pages 34-35.  If you are going to draw the floor plan of your home, I strongly suggest you keep to only one floor and measure it all out as a math project.  Again I would have preferred placing different types of home styles on the yarn timeline.  I also bought a book called Houses from Long Ago by Usborne to supplement this teaching.Pages 36-39.  Not as much teaching history as it is random facts about towns.  I suggest you actually research the history of your own town and place those facts on the yarn timeline.Pages 40-41.  Why not put all the states on a number line?Pages 42-43.  I would argue the Southwest is separate from the Northwest... believe me, I was born in the deserts of California and my husband came from Portland - our cultures have very little in common.  So I say, our country actually has 5 main regions.Pages 50-51.  If you are going to recognize minority holidays like St. Patrick's Day... also include other cultural holidays like Martin Luther King's Day, Chinese New Years, etc.  Then place the start of each of those holidays on a timeline and discuss their significance.  In fact, I think Martin Luther King's Day should really be celebrated by everyone and not just minorities because he wanted us to never judge by the color of one's skin but by their character.  What a lesson for us all.Pages 54-55.  Empty tomb craft and no timelines...Pages 58-59.  WAY too much music listed - seriously unless your kid is music obsessed, just pick a few of them to listen to and add in a recent song - place each on the timeline after listening to it to get an idea of how music has changed over time.Pages 60-61.  Research a number of different weapons then place in a timeline... maybe even include things like chariots and the different metals like bronze, iron, steel etc.  Explain what gave each people group military advantage.Pages 62-63.  Goes over some church theologians but does not give much really... then does a memory game.  Really think you should use the number line and at least say something about what they believed.

I look forward to doing some of the projects.  However, I was sorta underwhelmed.  I just expected a bit more science-heavy projects.  Too many of the projects seems arts & crafts instead of experimental.... with a brief connection to a science topic but only brief.Here is what you get:- Baking soda and vinegar with dish soap - to make a wizards brew.- Straws and cardboard with tape - to make a flying zoomer- Fingerprint cartoon robbers - craft but can still investigate the fingerprint shapes- Dusting for fingerprints - can even set up a mystery to solve- Sail cars - a bit building intensive but uses regular items- Shadow puppets (craft but still allows for the observing of shadows and light)- Invisible ink map (needs an oven - I like other forms of this concept like using phenolpthalein but you have to pick the right procedure for the safety of the age group)- Bouncing raisins - uses soda and raisins- Layering densities- Rocket ship with glitter booster flames (teaches reflection with the glitter but its mostly a craft)- Sprout bean seeds in baggies- Straw and cardstock with tape - to make a floating ball game- Try to move things together with one eye covered (craft/game but does reveal something about how the brain uses both eyes)- Wax drawings then paint - teaches waterproof but mostly a craft- Dangling monkies see-saw forces- Melting chocolate to teach states of matter- Tessellating patterns - crafty- Robot - teaches two half make a whole but its a craft- Leaf prints- Two sided card spinner to trick the eyes to seeing one image out of both- Flip book to make a moving picture- Cutting out a spiral snake than balancing on top of a straw- Mirror reflection art- Fruit ice cubes - to teach states of matter- Melting ice boats and if use dye can see how spreads- Windsock- Use tea to paint (craft)- Fluttering ghost shows how air travels around objects- Balloon zoomers by letting air out back- wobbly/teetering eggs- Diluting paint makes paler colors (craft)- turning carnations colors- opening paper flowers as they become wet- climbing animal toy based on friction- spinning mobile shows forces- static and balloons- static and tissue paper fish- flingers / catapults- eye tricking drawings- Squirting whale - supposed to teach water pressure but jsut soak and ruin craft whale- Balance paper on edge by folding - craft- Triangles make a sturdy tower- Back bread- Salt in paint art- Blowing over bottles- Building pan pipes from straws- Spreading colors through coffee papers- Bouncy bugs due to elastic- Illusion of size in drawing perspectives- Spinning helicopter- Bendy balances - seems like a frustrating project- Light catcher to teach transparent but just a craft- Floating paper animals- Soap powered swimmers- Plane catapult- Blow down a straw onto pain to make funky monsters- Cornstarch slime investigation

I wanted a children's atlas that was not too much in depth, had great illustrations, and thus would not loose the interest of a 4-7 year old.  This book surpassed my expectations and in fact may be useful even with older kids.Pros:  The start of the book teaches all sorts of info in small easy to understand chunks... PLUS each section has pictures to find in the maps the correlate to that topic.  What an ingenious way to get kids to know the REAL difference in placement around the world.  The maps were filled with little icons that significantly added to the knowledge being introduced.  A big plus for me was that (Unlike the lift-the-flap atlas also by Usborne) this atlas had Ecuador on the map!  My 2005 edition also had no reference to controversial things like global warming etc.  Honestly, I found no agenda here at all - it just teaches the world, what lives there, and cultural diversity.  I also really liked that the end of the book had review questions.Cons:  It was difficult to read some information as in was in the crack of the two-page spread.  It is SMALL at only 5.5 x 7 inches.  If it had been slightly bigger, the information would have been easier to read and/or more information could have been included.

This product:  This was given to me as a gift and I am not keeping it.  The keys are terribly out of tune.  Most people may not care because they plan to use it for babies and then donate it... HOWEVER why waste the money and resources by getting a toy that does not work properly so you just get rid of in a few weeks/months?  This is not a good buy in my opinion.  If you want temporary things for your baby to bang on - use plastic Tupperware then when they grow out of it, you can go back to using it as Tupperware in the kitchen.Better product:  What I wanted was a xylophone that could be used for years not just as a baby toy but for learning to play tunes, basic music knowledge, and even the science of sounds... so for just a few more dollars listing price I bought the one from Lakeshore.  Its in perfect tune and even has the letter scale imprinted on it!  Lakeshore often has coupons so in the end, I was actually able to purchase the Lakeshore model for LESS money than the Little Tikes version was listed for on amazon.  Only now I am happy.

I liked this one better than the First Sticker Book Trucks but less than First Sticker Book Jungle.  As part of a 2-3 year old curriculum, I wanted to use this as a way to introduce how a town functions and what each shop/building is for etc.  Though I felt the book had a number of teaching opportunities, I felt the book could have tapped into them more to make it a true learning while having fun experience.Here is what scenes you get::A busy Shop lines streetTown Square with cultural places like a museumIn the parkThe town by day/nightStreet market (like a farmer's market/street fair)Building housesOn a busy roadMap of townOverall, night quite what i wanted by good starter for a little ones into social science curriculum age 2-3.

I felt the educational value in the book was lower than expected (given the jungle sticker book was exceptional.)  This book is just ordinary to me but then again I am not a little boy obsessed with cars.  The book is pretty straightforward to use - find the sticker page matching the scene, then you place the vehicle stickers onto scene.  The vehicles are labeled on the sticker pages but those names are left behind as they are stickers themselves or part of the vehicle stickers that are removed.  I also don't really know if the names for each item is the same in the USA as in the UK... I am pretty sure a motorway is like a freeway or highway.Here are the scenes:In the country (farming)In the townAt the factoryOn the motorway (freeway?)At the building siteIn the mountainsAt the portMake your own picture (gives a road but you put in the scenery stickers in addition to the vehicles.Overall, I am sure a little boy would love this book, I just don't know home much he is learning from it.

Seems like a good place to start.  Topics are brief with pretty good images.  Have a kid pick a topic of interest and read the blurb in this book then research an experiment and/or further reading on the topic for rounded learning.  I bought it for my niece and liked it so much, I returned to buy a copy for my son.Topics covered:What is scienceCharacteristics of living thingsClassifying living thingsMovement of creaturesSensesEatingHealthLife cyclesPlantsEcosystemsProtecting the Planet (its tasteful - nothing too controversial)Properties of materials (including buoyancy and magnetism)States of matterPhysical and chemical changesWater cycleForcesLightSoundElectricityAstronomyDay/NightSeasons/YearsScientific methodMeasuringDisplaying results in graphicsOverall Nice very first book - has brief intros to science topics and at times needs more depth.

This refers to the red and grey outfit with doggies on the feet.NOTHING like what Carter's made for newborns and young babies!  I should have returned them immediately.#1 We started with the newborn-styled footed cotton pajamas from Carter's and loved them:My son at 6.5 months of age, grew out of his Carter's brand size 9 month pajamas.  This occurred because the leg portion of the pjs was not long enough and so he was starting to rip the seams around the feet and crotch area.  The 9 month pajamas were more than wide enough, soft, comfy, etc. but we needed them longer.  So we went online to buy more of the same pajamas just in the next size up.  An inch or two in length would do the trick...#2 Those great newborn-style pajamas end at 9 months:BUT there is no size 12 month pajamas with the snaps for easy diaper changes.  Everything jumps to using zippers or being 2 piece sets.  My baby was only 6 months old and still needed pajamas for babies not toddlers....  I was a bit worried and checked a lot of other brands, but ALL of them had the same transition.
