I figured Carter's and all those other companies must know what they are doing and with this being our first baby, we trusted their judgement and bought what Carter's was offering in 12 months.#3 The toddler-style footed cotton pajamas DO NOT in any way fit BABY body shapes, meet their needs, or are even designed well:So when the new toddler-style pajamas arrived, the legs and torso of the new pajamas looked nice and long.  Since length was our issue and we had been so happy with our previous Carter's purchases, I really did not think much about the pjs.  I just washed them on cold and dried on delicate.  Then I put them on my then 7 month old for bed time.  I instantly I realized that buying these pajamas was a BIG mistake - I SO should have paid attention to the subtle differences and returned these pajamas immediately.  First, the fabric is stiff, not soft or stretchy.  A child trying to roll around, crawl, or be active is not going to have the flexibility they need in the pajama.  Second, there is elastic at the back of the each ankle that tries to cut my son's blood supply off to the foot.  It is easy to rip out the elastic since its not on a seam just set on top of the fabric but that means I now have to rip out the elastic on 12 feet!  The non-slip footing is also attached/sewn on with seams that protrude in on the foot area putting unneeded additional pressure.  Third, the zipper only opens on one side so you have to awkwardly remove both legs every time you need to do a diaper change then redress which completely wakes my son up and cannot go back to sleep.  Four, the wrist area is so tight I could not get it over my son's hands without him crying and that is a diameter issue as there is no elastic sewn in there.  Fifth, the legs and arm areas assume a thin and frail baby.  Seriously my son is AVERAGE weight and his only issue is being tall not too wide - he is only 7.5 months old and cannot fit into a 12 month toddler-style outfit?  That is ridiculous.  Every other baby i know is cubbier than my son and could never get their arms or legs in this outfit.  Going up to the 18 month size did not fix the issue either, these just are not made for babies.Now I know some of you are going to say just go out an buy the fleece pjs because they are looser.  Polyester makes me itch from head to toe so I cannot put my baby in it.. and is frankly way too hot to wear where i live.  We need lighter weight cotton footed pjs.I really thought Carter's was going to be the store i shopped at most, but they just lost my loyalty.  I bought a few things in advance and put them in the closet... I really hope they will fit my son.

I bought the emergency vehicles with the navy background, the blue stripes with the fox in a canoe, and the dinos wearing multi-colored pjs.  They were cute, but NOTHING like what Carter's made for newborns and young babies!  I should have returned them immediately.#1 We started with the newborn-styled footed cotton pajamas from Carter's and loved them:My son at 6.5 months of age, grew out of his Carter's brand size 9 month pajamas.  This occurred because the leg portion of the pjs was not long enough and so he was starting to rip the seams around the feet and crotch area.  The 9 month pajamas were more than wide enough, soft, comfy, etc. but we needed them longer.  So we went online to buy more of the same pajamas just in the next size up.  An inch or two in length would do the trick...#2 Those great newborn-style pajamas end at 9 months:BUT there is no size 12 month pajamas with the snaps for easy diaper changes.  Everything jumps to using zippers or being 2 piece sets.  My baby was only 6 months old and still needed pajamas for babies not toddlers....  I was a bit worried and checked a lot of other brands, but ALL of them had the same transition.  I figured Carter's and all those other companies must know what they are doing and with this being our first baby, we trusted their judgement and bought what Carter's was offering in 12 months.#3 The toddler-style footed cotton pajamas DO NOT in any way fit BABY body shapes, meet their needs, or are even designed well:So when the new toddler-style pajamas arrived, the legs and torso of the new pajamas looked nice and long.  Since length was our issue and we had been so happy with our previous Carter's purchases, I really did not think much about the pjs.  I just washed them on cold and dried on delicate.  Then I put them on my then 7 month old for bed time.  I instantly I realized that buying these pajamas was a BIG mistake - I SO should have paid attention to the subtle differences and returned these pajamas immediately.  First, the fabric is stiff, not soft or stretchy.  A child trying to roll around, crawl, or be active is not going to have the flexibility they need in the pajama.  Second, there is elastic at the back of the each ankle that tries to cut my son's blood supply off to the foot.  It is easy to rip out the elastic since its not on a seam just set on top of the fabric but that means I now have to rip out the elastic on 12 feet!  The non-slip footing is also attached/sewn on with seams that protrude in on the foot area putting unneeded additional pressure.  Third, the zipper only opens on one side so you have to awkwardly remove both legs every time you need to do a diaper change then redress which completely wakes my son up and cannot go back to sleep.  Four, the wrist area is so tight I could not get it over my son's hands without him crying and that is a diameter issue as there is no elastic sewn in there.  Fifth, the legs and arm areas assume a thin and frail baby.  Seriously my son is AVERAGE weight and his only issue is being tall not too wide - he is only 7.5 months old and cannot fit into a 12 month toddler-style outfit?  That is ridiculous.  Every other baby i know is cubbier than my son and could never get their arms or legs in this outfit.  Going up to the 18 month size did not fix the issue either, these just are not made for babies.Now I know some of you are going to say just go out an buy the fleece pjs because they are looser.  Polyester makes me itch from head to toe so I cannot put my baby in it.. and is frankly way too hot to wear where i live.  We need lighter weight cotton footed pjs.I really thought Carter's was going to be the store i shopped at most, but they just lost my loyalty.  I bought a few things in advance and put them in the closet... I really hope they will fit my son.

Good book for under 6 dollars.  My son at 8 months thought it was great and wanted to read it a second time.  We got it because he loved the Zoom Zoom Baby book so much.  He liked the large high contrast letters, flaps, and mommy saying noises.  Mommy did not let him touch the flaps though because they could cause paper cuts esp with his current dexterity.  This is definitely going to be one of his top 5 favorite books for a while.  The only cons are the wording rhythm is changed from the Zoom Zoom baby book, so I simply adjust it to match AND the sounds do not really makes sense so I do my own.

About me:  I love science - in fact, I teach science, I have a vast science library, and I spend my free time watching science shows.  One thing I especially love is children science books and great rhyming!  I even read myself kids books like 10 Tiny Tadpoles because the rhymes make me smile from ear to ear.  This is why my mother-in-law thought a Cat in the Hat rhyming book on weather would be perfect for my son and I... HOWEVER, I - a science obsessed person who loves rhyming - could not finish reading this book.My review:  This book bored me and made my brain hurt - seriously!  I have tried to read it 3 times now and I literally have to drag myself to even reach page 20 and then my brain shuts down as there is 21 more pages to go!  Yes, the book has a lot of facts on weather - but seriously it does not teach any of those facts very well, jumps to the next topic without any continuity, the rhyming plus images were awkward and strange, and placement of words in pop up boxes or around images was hard to follow.  Therefore, the entire book felt disjointed, poorly written, confusing, and tiring to read.  If I used this book for teaching, I could only use 2-4 pages at a time and would have to supplement every topic.  That makes the book not that useful.  There were a few nice moments like "a tornado picks up everything it goes by, like a huge vacuum cleaner way up in the sky" but moments like those are not able to save this book and frankly are not as good as what Dr. Sues would have written himself.Overall, I have never complained about a science book in my life unless it had inaccurate content - this is a first for me, but the book was just too random, too confusing, and poorly done.  I will probably sell or donate it.
I have used these for over a decade.  Never had a problem with them.

I bought this book as a first introduction to sea animals for my son and I expected to use it as part of my homeschool curriculum for ages 3-4, but after looking over the book I think its more of a 4-6 year old book.  Right now my son is just a baby, so we will just look at the pictures and names of the animals, but later on we will read the text.Cons: Text is a bit advanced and I think the parent might want to consider reading only as much text as is appropriate for the age of the child.  For children reading alone I think the child would have to be in 3rd-6th grade for words like polyps.  The photos for certain animals like the blue whale and shrimp just don't give the best view of what an animal really looks like.  Photos extend over the page divide which can make the image awkward to see and those images are unfortunately the large main image for the creature. The dispersal of animal types is pretty diverse though I thought a few more basic fish would seem appropriate - it only did a general coral fish and mackerel. The book does a lot of pre-knowledge assumption instead of teaching so a parent really needs to explain things in more detail as they read along.Pros: Good intro to sea animals. Includes some fun facts kids would find interesting (though you might need to look up more info or better pics online.)  Does show a lot of different species in a very short compact book. Bright bold colors for most of the animals and real life photos. Easy to read text with bolded vocabulary (though why so few words considered vocab?). Hardcover for durability. Includes contents, glossary, and index so can show kids how to find info for themselves.The animals included in this book are:Invertebrates: Coral, Anemone, Urchin, Starfish, Jellyfish, Sea Slug, Shellfish, Octopus, Shrimp, Crab, LobsterFish: Mackerel, Coral Fish, Seahorse, Ray, SharkAmphibians: NoneReptiles: Iguana, Sea snake, Turtle, CrocodileBirds: Penguin, AlbatrossMammals: Otter, Seal, Walrus, Dolphin, Sperm whale, Blue whaleOverall the the book seems like an early elementary book to introduce sea animals... but some of the language/text is not quite appropriate for that age group.  The text is more appropriate for middle to late elementary children if reading alone.... but at that age you might as well buy your child a full on encyclopedia of animals as it will be more thorough in species represented.  It would work with younger ages IF the parent / teacher reads it to the class and answers questions and teaches vocab.  I suggest only one animal at a time them a project regarding that animal.

I like that the book teaches half past, quarter past, quarter to, etc. as those are typically harder phrases for a child to get.  It also includes the digital times in the bottom right for comparison.  You can check how you set the clock to the text as there is a small clock in the left side of the page spread.  Also like that the clock can be used without opening the book so it can be used for quizzing on time or using in time projects.What I did not like was the book never taught that the short hand pointed to the hour and the long hand to the minutes and that hours are listed first etc.  This seems like such basic things that I am surprised it was not outright taught in the text.  Also did not teach am/pm, 24 hours in a day, etc.  This is why the book lost 2 stars.Also, our family schedule (and no one else's I know about) matches the book's times in any way... I work evenings so our entire schedule starts at 9:30 am not 7am.  My friends work during the regular workday, so they get up between 5-6am.  But, I understand the book had to choose a general schedule time-frame to reference to... so its only a minor issue.  But it is something you should be aware of - that the schedule will not match whatever you do at home.

Excellent book with high educational value.  I wish more toddler books were like this.  Board book so very sturdy.  Realistic images, lots of labeling, and even provides scenes without words so kids can practice naming things then check themselves on the next page.  Not all of the animals are included in the scenes, but enough are to make it challenging.  Great time spent together with my son.  He is only 6 months old but loves me reading to names of everything and making noises.  We only do 2-4 pages at a time throughout the day and its about what he can handle at his age.The only downsides are....1. it does not include a desert scene and I live in a desert so its odd for my son to not see something similar to his home to compare to.  The book only has: farm, country (British countryside), forest (North American), savanna (African), jungle (South American), and ocean (I cannot tell which particular region, but definitely not tropical and not kelp forest.)2. Not all of the continents are represented as I had hoped... It did have Europe, the Americas, Africa, Ocean, and Man-Made farms.  But, I wanted to use this book to enforce basic geography knowledge of the continents and their ecosystems.  It would not have taken much to include all the continents... Australian desert, Ice world of Antarctica, and the bamboo forests or high mountain ranges of Asia.Overall, I love the book.  The content is far better than most toddler books.

Overall, I think the book is work about 2 dollars.Content wise, I think this book is appropriate for a 3-4 year old.  Some of the areas to color are smaller than I would expect for that age group though.  Some would even be appropriate for age 2 esp if scanned and enlarged.  Note: I have only on son so I am not making duplicates.What it contains:- 18 pages color by capital letter- 16 pages color by basic shape- 15 pages color by number

Overall, I think the book is work about 2 dollars.Content wise, I think this book is appropriate for a 3 year old, but the coloring pages seem aimed more at a 5 year olds.  Why 3 years old?  Presents capital and lower case letters.  I usually only do only capitals with 2 year olds.  Plus it uses bigger words like alligator and butterfly instead of ant and bear so again not at the 2 year old level.  Why 5 years old?  Because some of the areas to color are pretty small and 5 years old is the soonest I think that level of fine coloring can be achieved.  However, the content is too low for many 5-year olds.What it contains:- A-Z coloring pages using animals.  Oddly it uses Fox for X instead of X-ray.- Counting coloring pages spread in the back: 1 sea lion, bear clown has 2 feet in the air, 3 carrots, juggling 4 balls, 5 kites, 6 fish, 6 flowers, 7 turtles, 8 butterflies, and 8 octopus legs.  Missing items of 9, 10, or higher.Seasons coloring pages spread in the back: summer beach, spring rain, winter snowman, and fall scarecrow.Holidays coloring pages spread in the back: jack-o-lantern and elf painting eggs.  Should have had something for Christmas and Thanksgiving at least.Random coloring pages spread in the back: artist yak, zebra in a blimp, alien in spaceship, mermaid, farm animals, and train engine.In my opinion, the extra coloring pages at the end are not really organized into anything useful, but with effort they can be included in curriculum.  I kinda wish they were organized into themes like numbers 1-20, seasons with major holidays, etc.Because of the above, I can only give it 3 stars... though I will be using it and am glad I bought it.  Overall my favorite alphabet coloring book is Nature ABC by Dover, but its for older kids and I needed something at the 2-3 year old level.

Its the best sticker workbook I have found on the market for 123s and for 2-3 year olds. The only con is that its too short - it stops at number 12 when it should have gone to #20 then covered the tens to one hundred.Stickers are specified as to which pages they belong but the exact number needed is the exact number of stickers given so kids are not really forced to count to place the right number of stickers on the page.  Therefore this book does not have as much educational value as the ABC sticker workbook.Why is the book so good for two year olds? It enables the kid to show what they learn without having to write or say everything... they can point at stickers and place them. Practice writing is brief so you don't exhaust a very young one. Great way to interact with your child to ensure kids learn instead of randomly placing stickers. Might even be a good daddy comes home activity to review what was learned during the day. Plus, its fun. I cannot wait to do it with my son.What the book covers:Page 1, numbers 1 through 12 visually shown and can clearly see you add one more to go to the next number.Pages 2-25, find the object stickers that match each number, then on the following page place more stickers into a scene, and there is usually some directions to follow like circle something or color something.Pages 26-31, count and place the correct number sticker in the box, then on the following page add more stickers of an object until reach the designated number.Pages 32, 38-41, complete the number line with the missing number stickers.Pages 33 & 35, dot-to-dot numbers.Page 34, color by number.Page 36-37, count and place the correct number sticker in the box.Page 38, 56-59, basic addition.Pages 43-47, compare amounts.Pages 48-51, basic counting of coins using pennies.Pages 52-55, telling time.Page 60-63, basic subtraction.Page 64, review of counting 1-12.Rest of the pages are stickers both to complete the worksheets as well as reward stickers.There is a parent guide inside the front cover and a certificate of completion inside the back cover.

I have never seen mazes so beautifully colored an interesting designs.  I think some of the puzzles are a bit challenging due to that creativity... so I would use this book with kids 4+ years old.  I think you could even do this book just using fingers so that its reusable.Warning - this book contains all of the mazes from The Usborne Very Big Maze Book (67+% of this book is identical).  So if your child already completed the previous Very Big Maze book, don't get this one because its too much the same.  I suspect all of the mazes came from previous books but I cannot verify that.Also, the colors are less bold than in The Usborne Very Big Maze Book... I was more drawn to the bolder colors and found them more engaging, but The Ultimate Maze Book had a greater number of mazes.  It was a hard choice, but I went with a greater number of mazes for my son and the bolder colors for my nephew.

I bought three cookie cutters at the same time.  The other two were twice the price of this one and promised to be sturdy stainless steel... and those two arrived mis-shapen and flimsy and worthless to me.  This cookie cutter was superior in quality and nearly perfectly shaped.  It is still a bit flexible but nothing compared to the two I returned.  Nice large size and happy.

This came mis-shapen and flimsy.  For the outrageous price I paid for a cutter, I expected it to be sturdy, perfectly round, and durable.  This was not worth at all what I paid for it.  I own 10+ cookie cutters in various shapes and never ever have returned a single one until now.

To be honest, I do not like the game and did not buy it for the game play.  I bought it for the game pieces so i could do sorting and educational activities with my son.  I wish the food/tool tiles had been cut the same size as for the shopping list game... these were unfortunately a tad smaller than the shopping list tiles.  I also did not like that only 5 meals were included and NO recipes or names of the meals are included on the cards for kids to see.  What is presented in picture form only are pizza, shepherd's pie, cupcakes, kabobs, and stir fry shrimp with veggies n noodles.  I love the meals that were included because I can make all of those easily with my son.... but I wish they also included a breakfast meal like omelets with veggies or pancakes with fruit.  I really expected eight different meals given the price of the game...  I also think using a spinner with this game is not very effective.

I bought this for the rhymes and fingerplays... and I was significantly disappointed.  No diagrams to show the movements.  Nothing really all that new and not that many for the price I paid.  There are ideas in the back had some good crafts and projects etc. but honestly, its not a lot either and no pictures to stimulate my thinking and not very thorough.  Returning because its not what I needed/wanted and will hardly use it.

I really could not connect to this and neither will my son.  Revealing the snowflakes falling outside and a snowplow pushing snow around was good.  But what babies ride sleds, throw snowballs, or drink cocoa?  And prairie dogs?  I understand that prairie dogs can pop up in winter since they go dormant for short periods but do not hibernate all winter, but if you are going to teach a BABY about what winter is and what to expect... why not teach its cold and you wear a jacket or hat... because prairie dogs are not essential to understanding what winter is.  After this, not buying the series like I expected to...

Its cute, but I would have made it with more words under the flaps and better thought through the flap usage as some are pretty small.  Also little kids could cut themselves on the paper flaps if their motor control and dexterity is not well honed.  Here is what you get in the book:When you lift the two mittens, I was expecting it to say hands, but it said "fingers" and the other mitten was blank underneath.... why couldn't it have said both since there were two flaps?  I will probably write in hands on the blank mitten.Inside of the boots is "toes" why not also feet?Under the hat is really under ear muffs... and it was only "ears."  There is no flap to look under the hat to see the head of hair.Beneath the scarf was a "nose" not a neck or mouth like i had expected.  Where i live, no one covers their nose with a scarf.Under the sleeve was an "elbow " but no mention of an arm.Under jeans is "knee" but no mention of legs.The image of the jacket is confusing because it covers the "back"... the drawing did not look like it was the back of the girl unless you really think about the head and hair placement... even the hand placement made it look like the front.The jacket also covers a "belly button."  Since we did a jacket on the back of the page... why not use a shirt instead and do it on a boy so can say it covers the chest and belly button?Hands lift up to reveal "teeth" inside the mouth... would have preferred both mouth and teeth to be under the flap.Moving a candy lollipop reveals the "tongue."  I would have preferred if that had used a fruit Popsicle instead of candy.Sunglasses lift to reveal "eyes."At the end you lift up the flap to see the whole child.

I am going to homeschool my son for pre-school through kindergarten at least.  Being a science educator, I already have a lot of ideas, but I needed a sense of what was age appropriate and specifically hoped for science center activities that I could leave out and slowly rotate throughout the year.  Ultimately the book ended up being useful but not completely what I hoped for.  Only some of the activities would do well for self-exploration at an activity center and it lacked the variety I wanted.  Many of the "experiments" seemed like it will take a lot to maintain like a terrarium, raising tadpoles, etc.  Personally I prefer raising butterflies because the care is much simpler and you can just release them into the wild.  Some experiments need more to prepare than you would think... like buying a quality horseshoe magnet and putting together assortments of magnetic and non-magnetic objects that are non-toxic, kid-safe, and can be left out for a while... or collecting and printing a lot of images like animals etc.  Other sections of the book were underwhelming as kids just cut out and pasted images of things that go or planted seeds in various places.  However, I did like the ideas for gases, electricity, and senses.  Some of these might be no-brainers to an experienced pre-school educator, but I have been teaching high school through college for so long that I had forgotten that such simple activities are so educationally valuable.  Watching gas escape a submerged object for example is extremely simple to set up, but wow it really does display that empty containers are not empty, they just contain air you cannot see.  Also the experiments range significantly in difficulty.  For example:  I think learning about the sun and its rotation is best for a four your old and watching bubbles come out of a submerged empty container can be done with 2 year olds.  SO carefully pick which experiment you do and really think about if its age appropriate.Do I think the book is worth 11+ dollars... no its not enough material, I would say more like 6 dollars.  Will I use it?  Absolutely.  Did I learn from it?  Yes, I learned what can be done with pre-school so now I can design the rest of the experiments which is no problem for an experienced science educator.  However, I am going to supplement with the elementary school experiment books that I have.  I think a number of those projects can also been done in preschool but just on a lower level of difficulty.Experimentally and content-wise, I feel pretty ready to face pre-K and K.... but I still wish I had more science center creative ideas, but maybe I am just overthinking what a science center is.  I could have a few matching games like putting together cards of an animal parent and its baby, classification velcro board where foods are separated into food groups or animals into their natural ecosystems, dexterity games of placing certain things in proper containers which is another classification game, or string boards in which yarn is wrapped around push pins to connect things together that are the same, opposites, etc... plus you can have live plants/animals to observe or care for each day, a type of hands-on experiment/observation like using magnets, nature collections, books to read, sequences to order or life cycles, etc... so maybe I don't really need a book to tell me how to do a science center.  Its the same as warm-ups just at a very young child's level.

We purchased one at a local store and loved it so much we got a second one off of amazon.  This was even better than the previous model.  First, the six or so dollar price was way better than what we paid in store - thank you amazon.  Second this dry rack is squarer so it takes up less space on the counter.  Third the stopper holder slots in the front has deeper groves on both sides - which eliminated the weird tiny prongs on the previous version that were a pain to get the stoppers to stay in.Why these work Dr. Brown's bottles...  on the tall spokes we place the circular rings and the the bottle on top.  On the first row of short spokes we place the blue internal part that allows air to move.  We place two upright, one upside down, and repeat the pattern across the row.  The second row of short spokes holds the white inner parts.  We poke the tip into the round holders at an angle so fluid can drip out if need be.  You can fit one in between each spoke and one at each end.  I then place the bottle nipples on top of these spokes.  In the very front, goes the stoppers into the slots.  I place the bottle caps on any open spokes and on top of the stoppers if stable.  So one dry rack holds 5 complete Dr. Brown's bottles.Why we got a second dry rack:  to hold the bottles, stoppers, rings, and other parts used with my breast pump.  Plus hold small bowls used for cereal and we intend to continue using these with sippy cups etc.  We don't put anything plastic in the dishwasher and do it all by hand so these dry racks will be used for a long time.The only con is.... it was a pale purple not white.  I can live with the purple, but its odd.

I posted my perspective because I felt the negative backlash to this book would dismay too many from purchasing it when there is nothing really wrong with it at all...  This book is exactly what I wanted for a 1-2 year old.  A book that just shows the continents, 3 animals that live there, and what the world looks like.  Simple, effective, and straightforward.Each two-page spread focuses on one continent - its good to only see one at a time.  However it still gives a lot of world map context (A smaller map in bottom right shows which continent you are in... in relation to which continent is covered next.)  The tactile sandpaper feel around the edges of the continent are nice but not scratchy enough for my tastes.  I like they are not indented into the page as that tends to lead to paper cuts.The main "con" others post are that the book colors do not match the color coding used in the Montessori classroom.... In my opinion, this is actually a VERY GOOD THING.  Let me explain my reasoning (as an educator who has taught 2 year olds through college).  It is VERY important that kids be able to see that things are the same regardless of color.  An apple is an apple whether its yellow, green, or red.  A bird is a bird because it has certain features like a bill/beak, feathers, lays eggs, etc. not because of its color.  So we should want kids to know that Asia is Asia by its shape, location on a world map, cultures, ecosystems, etc...  Classification and discrimination skills are essential to long term success in life, school, and in careers, so it is important that kids are taught to focus on essential characteristics for an object and frankly arbitrary country colors is not one of them.  I like a lot of Montessori ideas, but I take ALL educational philosophies under the microscope and the color coding part is way too rigid for true learning to occur.  Too often kids get questions right if you use the same color coding, because kids are remembering the colors NOT the content.  Others may disagree with my opinion, and that is fine - we each can choose to teach our children differently.  I just felt that the book is getting a far worse rap than it really deserved.

This was a gift for me to use with my little baby.  When he was under 4 months old the bouncy chair was not really appropriate because there are no shoulder straps, so his spine would twist and bend in inappropriate ways or hold his head in ways that could cause him not to breath.  We therefore waited and started using it when he was 4.5 months old and he had pretty good neck strength.  Unfortunately, the arch was not constructed right... only one of the two ends fit properly in the provided holes plus the arch is too high for my son to touch with his hands.. he could only use his feet.  When he was around 5.5 months old, my son hit the objects so hard with his feet, the whole arch came out and hit him in the face.  So, we could not use the arch anymore.  Then at 6 months he leaned forward in the bouncy chair and the whole thing flipped forward and his face slammed into the ground with the chair on top of him and it was very hard to get his belt unsnapped to get him out from under it.  Fortunately the surface was soft so he was not hurt, but we threw the chair out.  We did not even take it to good will or donate it to the poor because its so poorly designed that I don't want other kids to get hurt.  Plus, I noticed the legs were completely warped from use and my son was always under the weight limit which means it wore out in only 1.5 months of use which hardly justifies the price.

Very simple mazes for your little ones.  I think this is the perfect first maze book because very colorful, engaging, and instructions are clear (though a parent needs to read them out loud for non-reading children).  All of the puzzles are in color and are age appropriate down to 2-year olds EXCEPT for one image... that is a "Haunted Hollow" Halloween ride with ghosts and skulls.  This book does not need to be written in and can be used over and over by just running your finger through the mazes.  I just wish it was longer for the price I paid and that Halloween image was left out.

I really enjoyed this selection of bedtime appropriate material.  I was pleasantly surprised at the artwork which was incredibly realistic at times.  Plus, a number of the rhymes dealt with biological themes like nocturnal animals and baby animal names.  I did not all of the stories/rhymes because I have never liked "Hush, Little Baby" but I also did not like "Gaelic Lullaby" and "Sleep Now and Rest" even though I have a Scot-Irish heritage.  The rest of the material more than makes up for my dislikes.  I am very happy with my purchase.

Good book for under 4 dollars.  My son at 6 months thought it was great and wanted to read it a second time.  He liked the large high contrast letters, flaps, and mommy saying noises.  Mommy did not let him touch the flaps though because they could cause paper cuts esp with his current dexterity.At 8 months old, my son still loves this book.  Its in his top 5!

Contains four shopping carts, four shopping lists, and 32 item cards.The item cards depict: oranges, peppers, loaf of bread, bacon (different cut), apple juice, pasta, washing powder (laundry detergent), socks, strawberries, aubergines (eggplant), cheese (holey so most likely Swiss), frozen pizza, stir-fry sauce, water, toilet paper, teddy (stuffed toy), bananas, tomatoes, milk, chicken, baked beans, sweets (candy?), toothpaste, music CD, apples, carrots, eggs, soup, tinned tuna (canned tuna), cereal, bubble bath, and magazine.Pros: Contains a lot of items. Game is simple to understand and play.  I can use the tiles for a lot of educational purposes that have nothing to do with the game.Cons: The names of some items are different in the USA from the UK.  I thought the selection of items was a tad odd.  No common staples like butter, yogurt, or peanut butter etc.Overall, I really wanted all those wonderful item tiles to use for lots of other purposes including separating by food group, feeding the monster dexterity game, meal planning, learning words for common objects, etc. Just so much you can teach with these tiles.  We can also play the original game too but its not why I bought it.NOTE: A new updated version was released.  My review pertains the version before 2015.

Contains two shopping carts, two shopping lists, and 16 clothing cards.The clothing cards depict: sunglasses, shorts, belt, vest top (tank top), boots (rain boots), watch, shirt, scarf, jacket, flip flops, gloves, T-shirt, bag (backpack), trainers (tennis shoes), jumper (sweater), and cap (baseball cap).Pros:  Contains additional clothing items.  Shopping carts are additional colors from original game so you don't get duplicates.  I can use the tiles for a lot of educational purposes that have nothing to do with the game.Cons:  The shopping lists only have clothing so it makes them feel a tad odd if include in the original game.  Need more than 2 shopping lists for it to function as a game on its own.  There was a lot of other clothing or back to school items like pencils or dresses that could have been included to make it a 4 shopping list game.  The names of some items are not the same in the USA as in the UK.  I listed these difference in parentheses above.Overall, its a bit expensive given the feel of being half a game.  But, I really wanted all those wonderful clothing tiles to use for lots of other purposes including classifying, feeding the monster dexterity game (kid avoids and does not feed to monster because not food), clothing shopping planning, learning words for common objects, clothes to wear for each season, etc.  Just so much you can teach with these tiles.NOTE: A new updated version was released.  My review pertains the version before 2015.

Contains two shopping carts, two shopping lists, and 16 produce cards.The produce cards depict:  pears, potatoes, raspberries, leek, blueberries, onions, mellow, broccoli, peas, cherries, baby sweetcorn, kiwi fruit, grapes, pineapple, asparagus, and cauliflower.Pros:  Contains additional fruits and veggies.  Shopping carts are additional colors from original game so you don't get duplicates.  The names of the foods are the same in the USA as in the UK.  I can use the tiles for a lot of educational purposes that have nothing to do with the game.Cons:  The shopping lists only have fruit and veggies so it makes them feel a tad odd if include in the original game.  Need more than 2 shopping lists for it to function as a game on its own.  There was a lot of other healthy grocery items like yogurt that could have been included to make it a 4 shopping list game.Overall, its a bit expensive given the feel of being half a game.  But, I really wanted all those wonderful food tiles to use for lots of other purposes including separating by food group, feeding the monster dexterity game, meal planning, learning words for common objects, etc.  Just so much you can teach with these tiles.NOTE: A new updated version was released.  My review pertains the version before 2015.

Failure in design.The whole purpose of getting this was so my child can see all the numbers AT ONE TIME.  I even planned on combining this with the Theme Count Game also by Hape to create a giant math manipulative.However, the trees with holes and circles for #1-5 are ON THE immediate BACK of #6-10.  You cannot see both numbers at the same time.  Note: I had hoped they were at least on opposite sides so i could cut the wood in half and flip over one half of the wood to see all the number trees at once.... BUT since they are on the immediate back of each other, that is not possible.  If i cut the wood in half, all I'd get is two blank wood panels on the right... and on the left the trees and circles for #3 and #8 on the back of each other.This design flaw makes no sense because the manufacturer provides 55 pegs which is enough to fill all the holes at once for #1-10, BUT you can't fill all of the trees at once because they are on the back of each other.  You are also given by the manufacture 55 wooden discs which is also enough to fill all the circles at once for #1-10, BUT you can't fill all of them at once because they are on the back of each other.  So clearly the manufacturer was expecting you to use all the tree boards at once so why didn't they design it that way?On top of that, the trees show the number of dots needed on the bottom when the number of circles already shows the number needed.... this redundancy is not needed and I think the dots are ugly at the bottom of each tree.  But this is a minor design flaw compared to the above.Overall, I will use the cards in my Theme Count Game, the wooden disks/pegs for learning how to add and subtract but the wooden boards with the trees and circles will never be used in the way they were intended due to the design flaw of having the trees on the back of each other.I really wish I had not bought this because for that high of a price... there should not be such a huge design flaw.

I like this book, but its not quite what I expected.  In my opinion, sticker books should be aimed at 2-3 year olds who are just learning how to write and thus need a break from writing so need to express their knowledge in a different way.  Some of this book's material is appropriate for that age group, but some is not....  Overall, I am not excited to do this workbooks with my son because everything is covered too brief for any kind of mastery...  I liked the alphabet sticker book much better with all that repetition.  I still think this book is better than other sticker books because it does teach and has logic to it, but I just wanted more and it covered to great of a learning age range.What it covers:- Comparing size- Matching like to like- Completing patterns- Time (must be able to read written time like 4:00)- Coloring- Farm animals and babies (only 4 animals)- Match objects with their starting letter and letter tracing (brief and only capitals)- Simple mazes- Alphabet- Shapes- Dot-to-dot #1-10- Colors- Counting- Bar graph- Sequence/Order- Grouping/Classifications- Animal habitats/needs- Seasons- Money/Coins- Basic addition- Draw the second half- Match puzzle piece over image- Words- Opposites- Rhymes- Emotions- Rest of the pages are stickers both to complete the worksheets as well as reward stickers.- There is a parent guide inside the front cover and a certificate of completion inside the back cover.

The best sticker workbook I have found on the market for ABCs and for 2 year olds.  The only con is that its too short = )Why is this workbook so good?  Stickers are specified as to which pages they belong, but there are no hints as to where they go (in other words this book has no shadows of sticker shapes or object outlines, there is no word written as to which sticker to get, and no answers are hidden in the back of the book.)  So that means kids have to choose the correct answer from potential options.  That means they have to think the same way they would on a school test.  Excellent.  The book focuses on the alphabet instead of getting stuck on side activities which was the issues with other ABC sticker workbooks.Why is the book so good for two year olds?  It focuses only on capital letters (except on 9 pages in which words are used).  It enables the kid to show what they learn without having to write or say everything... they can point at stickers and place them.  Practice writing is brief so you don't exhaust a very young one.  Great way to interact with your child to ensure kids learn instead of randomly placing stickers.  Might even be a good daddy comes home activity to review what was learned during the day.  Plus, its fun.  I cannot wait to do it with my son.What the book covers:Page 1, find the object sticker to complete the alphabet.Pages 2-15, find the object stickers that match each letter then one the following page place more stickers into a scene.Pages 16-41, a rhyme is given using the letter, letter tracing for only capital letters and only 1 line for each, draw a line connecting all of the same letter, find stickers to match that letter and place in box, and write the letter two more times.Pages 42-45, find the stickers to complete the boxes must match a letter to an object starting with that letter.Pages 46-47, find the stickers to complete the alphabetPages 48-55, find the object stickers to match the word.  Circle these images in the scene. - Problem is the page uses lower case letters which this book has not taught the kid yet.  If the parent reads the word and has the kid point to the right sticker then this is not a problem... my 2 year old son can't read.Page 56, find the object stickers to match the word and the write the word - Problem is the words are in lower case and the book did not teach lower case.  This page should NOT have been included.Pages 57-64 is dot-to-dot with the alphabet.  I think its a bit too much for 2 year olds, but older kids will be able to handle it.  You could have the parent do the drawing and have the kid point to which letter is next.  Also, the alphabet is included at the top so the worksheets are for learning and memorizing the alphabet not practicing after memorization.Rest of the pages are stickers both to complete the worksheets as well as reward stickers.There is a parent guide inside the front cover and a certificate of completion inside the back cover.

This is an excellent children's poetry book esp for very little kids as the poems deal with swinging, going to bed, weather, day/night, bugs, seasons, etc.  Just love it.  Very happy I bought it.Reason it lost one star:  One poem in my opinion should be skipped entirely.  The "Threats" poem is a child threatening to run away in order to force parents/guardians to do what they want.  This is not the sort of thing we should be teaching kids to do.  I cannot believe it was included in this wonderful book.The other poem I did not like is "Bedtime" because the child instead of obeying the parent and going to bed keeps asking for more time to play... but I could see it not being an issue in some families and used more as a way to get over that problem.  The book would not have lost a star for this.

This is the entire and complete set for BambinoLUK.  The books are listed for age 3-5 but you might be able to use them even with a slightly younger child.  To use them you must place an open book under a Beyond123 BambinoLUK Controller... then you move tiles from the top to bottom page to answer the questions. These books range in difficultly so kids can work at their own pace.  For very young kids and special education... I suggest you get the age 2 special primary book set as it focuses on the images on those 6 tiles, how to read the LUK icons, how to do LUK self-checking, etc.Overall, I am surprised how tricky some of the questions are and how it gets kids to work on that critical thinking / visual perception at a young age by removing the need to write.I have organized the books by "difficulty packs" in the following lists...Set 1:- My First Workbook (intro to the type of questions kids will face and helps you explain anything kids do not get at first so they can succeed in the books on their own)- See and Sort- Zoo Animals- Concentration Games- What Belongs Together- Starting to CountSet 2:- Seek and Compare- Farm Animals- More Concentration Games- Think and Associate- Starting to Do additionSet 3:- Identify and Relate- Brainteasers for Kids- What Belongs Together 2- All about Colors and Shapes- Transportation and Traffic Signs

Book reinforces a number of learning concepts - it is not a teaching book but a practice book.  I think it would be good for kids age 3-4.  I actually got it to use with a 2 year old because it was simple in the drawings and page layouts etc, but a child that young cannot complete the pages on their own so its a book we will do together.  Plus the other book i had was lacking in the opposite department and this book had a number of worksheets on that topic (like inside/outside or wet/dry).  The biggest con is the pages are thin so you can see the images on the other side.  Also since the pages are not necessarily in the order you want to teach the subjects, I would usually xerox pages but by being see-through, I now have to scan, edit, then print the copy which wastes a lot of time.  I have only one son so I am not making copies for others, but I can't rip out a page, have my son complete one side, then store it for weeks before we use the second side of the page which is why i end up xeroxing.Here is what the book covers:- Matching same- Tracing lines- Drawing lines without tracing- Finding images within a picture- Drawing circles- Coloring images- Seasons- Clothing for seasons- Night sky- Hot/Cold- On/Off- Shapes- Sizes- Simple mazes- Inside/Outside- Finish a picture by drawing lines, circles, etc.- Where things belong- Counting- More/Less Amounts- Number tracing 1-5 (unstructured)- Opposite/Same- Positions/Directions- Out/In- Near/Far- With- Colors- Alphabet tracing (very simple 1 pager)- Uppercase/lowercase- Where animals live- Patterns- Sequencing- RhymingA tracking/reward chart on the inside of the front cover and a completion certificate at the end of the workbook.  All necessary stickers are included.

These seaweed crisps are a tasty hybrid between Annie Chun's Seaweed Snacks, Roasted Sesame, 0.35-Ounce Packages (Pack of 12) and Tabetai Inc Rice Crisps, Bngkok Sw Chi, 3.50-Ounce (Pack of 6).  Each of the Seaweed crisps has a layer of salty seaweed baked onto a thin rice crisp.  The result is a seaweed flavored snack that is not as delicate as seaweed snacks.The only negative is that by adding rice crisps to their already delicious seaweed snacks, the calories per serving go way up.  These snacks are 80 calories per serving (or more realistically 160 calories per bag).

The Duru shower gels smell great and lather easily.  The sapphire has a fresh clean smell and is our favorite. The rose has a gentle floral smell. And the mango is tropical and refreshing.  They all make a lot of bubbles so they work well as bubble bath as well as shower gel.As an animal lover, the fact that these very good bath products are also not tested on animals earns them a solid 5 stars from this reviewer.  These gels may not get you cleaner than the next product, but I will always pick natural ingredients that are not tested on animals over another product every time.

This super convenient and discreet little plastic bottle is perfect for an overnight bag or the guest bathroom.  It works by spritzing some essential oils onto the toilet water before you go, so that afterwards the only scent left in the bathroom is from the spray. We were fairly skeptical, but it does work even for the man of the house!  Everyone leaves the bathroom smelling fresh and clean.The Poo-Pourri eucalyptus and spearmint flavor smells very nice and lingers with an almost citrus inspired freshness for the commode.The packaging is lighthearted with plenty of #2 jokes and is about the size of a perfume bottle.  Poo-Pourri has a place on top of my toilet tank.  Great idea and great product, this one easy to give five stars!

I love my Multi-cooker.  I've had it for about a week at this point, and already I have used it as a rice cooker, crock pot, and bread machine! It is just an all-around great machine. Right out of the box it comes with a pretty handy full color recipe book that really got my creative juices going.The Multi-cooker itself allows you full control of time and temperature settings that allow you to slow cook, delay cook, and keep warm meals.  The best part of the process is that it is "hands free" once you set it to start.  The machine applies heat to a surprisingly heavy metal cooking pot.  The pot is built in such a way that food cooks evenly without crusting on the hot surface of the pot.  Better still, the nonstick surface makes it easy to use.I tested the nonstick surface with both "no-fry fried eggs" and a coconut flour banana raisin bread.  Both recipes usually call for a oil or butter on the pan, and in both cases I omitted this step in an effort to test the claims of the no-burn no-stick surface. My bread slid right out of pot, and I didn't break the yolks of my eggs!The easy clean up features of this Multi-cooker are also very nice.  All the accessories are dishwasher safe. So it was easy to rinse and put away.  The lid of the machine also slides off easily so if there is steam or boiling food that splatters the lid, it is easy to take the lid to the sink.The user interface works a bit like an alarm clock.  You press each control multiple times to make the numbers flash on the screen and then adjust the numbers with either "+" or "-".  Unfortunately the controls are the one area that could use a little work in a device that I otherwise like very much. It is not difficult to set the time and temperature that you want, but it is also not exactly intuitive.  I would've like to have seen a touch screen (or simply forgo the digital and include nobs or or controls).  As it is the Cooker definitely reminds me of trying to set my alarm clock. But this is a small note, and certainly not enough to take way from the stars.There are a few kitchen gadgets that earn precious space on my counters, and this one is definitely a great go-to machine.  Easy meals, with few dishes to clean up, are just a few button presses away.

Collecting: Wolverines #16-20This book concludes the Wolverines series that spun out of the Death of Wolverine event.  Readers are treated to a grand finale that showcases the unleashed brutality of the Wolverines team against the white-knuckled survive-or-die battle with Mister Sinister.In this final Wolverines volume, the Paradise and Wolverines team tangle with Mister Sinister. While I have not been a fan of the "control words" plot device used throughout this series, the problematic reliance on "control words" is finally exploited in this episode. And I don't want to spoil anything, but it is brutal.In the previous volume, Wolverines Vol. 3: The Living and the Dead, hints were dropped that Mystique was plotting something.  Mystique's duplicity and her skillful manipulation of people and events is finally put on display in this book.  Lady Deathstrike and Shogun/Ogun's romance is tested by Sinister.  The Wolverines team is finally interesting!  In fact the only character that didn't quite feel "right" was Sabretooth: Sabretooth's recent realignment to the "good guys" isn't particularly well explored.  As opposed to say Wonder Man (who espouses Pacifism), the "good" Sabretooth still disembowels people, but he limits himself to "bad" people.The artwork in this volume rises to the sublime.  Jonathan Marks work on issue #18 is not to be missed. Marks uses a bright almost "overexposed" style that is really mesmerizing.This volume is probably the best in the series.  If you've been reading Wolverines up to this point, you'll want this book because it finally seems to rise to the promise of the series. This book ends by pointing readers toward [[ASIN:0785198849  Secret Wars]] where the Marvel Universe undergoes something of a reboot.

Collecting: Night of the Living Deadpool #1-4----- Prelude to Deadpool Corps #4Despite the title, Night of the Living Deadpool is more an homage to Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead than to it's namesake Night of the Living Dead.  Artist Nik Virella uses a black and white palette inspired by the Walking Dead with only Deadpool appearing in color.  This artwork really pops and has a fantastic atmosphere.  As in The Walking Dead, the protagonist (in this case Deadpool) awakens to nightmare world overrun run by zombies.  Also as occurs in the Walking Dead, zombies are the least of the heroes' worries: deranged survivors (of sorts, I don't want to spoil the plot for readers) present a the greatest danger.Despite the paean to The Walking Dead, this book is all Deadpool.  The humor is dark. These zombies moan snippets from their previous lives: so instead of crying "braaaaaaaaiiinnns", these zombies attack with groans of "pot pies for dinner" and "walk the dog". Maybe you have to see it in order to get it, but these panels had me cracking up.  There is plenty of blood, dismemberment, and disemboweling while Deadpool and his companion try to stop a plague worse than zombies.All in all, I recommend this Deadpool mini-series to 'pool fans who are looking for a fun self-contained story.

Collecting: Uncanny Avengers (2015) #1-5Counter Evolutionary collects the entire run of the second Uncanny Avengers series. This book picks up in the aftermath of Avengers & X-Men: Axis .  After the stunning revelation that Magneto is not their father, Quicksilver and the Scarlet Witch travel to the High Evolutionary's planet to confront him about their origin.  Rogue attempts to piece together a new Unity Squad with Vision, Dr Voodoo, Falcon, and a newly good guy Sabretooth to back them up.  Voodoo's spell goes awry, and the Avengers are scattered across High Evolutionary's world.Writer Rick Remender has earned a his reputation as a masterful storyteller.  The pacing and plot work well as Remender weaves the scatter team's individual plot lines together to meet for a grand finale. The High Evolutionary makes a maniacal enemy for our heroes, and Remender uses the High Evolutionary's particular brand of crazy to sound some rather profound thoughts on the nature of perfection and the virtues of flaws. Finally, Sabretooth as a living, thinking character (rather than simply Wolverine's nemesis) has a lot of potential to develop Sabreooth into a sympathetic character. I am enjoying watching his transition from supervillain to superhero.Readers who've followed the Uncanny Avengers will want to pick this volume up because it details critical changes in Wonder Man and Rogue's situation.  Longtime Avengers fans will also enjoy the moments that The Vision and Wanda share. The conclusion of this volume points readers towards Secret Wars in order to follow these characters' adventures.

The hard plastic vacuum attachment arrived and snapped together easily. I love this attachment. I have an antique 1950's gas stove in my kitchen that is beautiful, but it stands on little feet so there is a clearance underneath the entire appliance. It is just a just trap for kibble and cheerios (they both don't eat on the floor but you wouldn't know it to look under the stove). Maybe once or twice per year we would move the refrigerator in order to do a "deep cleaning" in the kitchen. Enter the flat vacuum attachment!  Messes underneath and beside the big appliances are no longer a big chore. We also use it to vacuum the underside of the couches (dog hair goes everywhere!).Anyways, this attachment works perfectly with my Shark Rotator NV752 Powered Lift-Away TruePet Vacuum, Bordeaux and fits securely on the hose.

I have a Shark Rotator NV752 Powered Lift-Away TruePet Vacuum, Bordeaux and the Lint Lizard attachment fits the vacuum perfectly. The kit attaches to the vacuum hose with an adapter end and includes a long clear hose that extends deep into the lint trap area of the drier. I knew I needed something to help keep the trap clean because I could see the lint in the hole even after I removed and cleaned the screen.  The Lint Lizard solved the problem and should help my drier run more efficiently.The add-on Lint Lizard Dust Lizard Vacuum Hose Attachment with Brush is ok if you need help with small nooks and crevices.

I got the 34x32 jeans for a 5'10" 200lbs frame and they fit perfectly.Dickies dark indigo jeans are stylish and comfortable.  The stitching and construction quality is great. These are perfect everyday jeans.  There is one thing that I REALLY like about these jeans that sets them apart from other jeans.  These jeans have seven belt loops (instead of five which is what Levi's has) and that just helps them work better with belts.This product is easy to recommend to anyone shopping online for a new pair of jeans.

I'm 5'6" and about 150lbs, and the best size for me is the 32x30.  The waist line fits well. The legs have a little extra material, but they are not baggy. I think the stitching is stylish without being overstated.Dickies Jeans are a great product that I've used for years. These jeans are built to last, and they are very comfortable.  The indigo jeans are dark enough that they can be dressed up with a polo or even a blazer, but they are also perfect for casual occasions as well.  Overall, these jeans are a product I can recommend to anyone shopping for clothes on amazon.

I am very pleased with this knife.  In my line of work, I come across many types of knives and consistently find myself disappointed in one aspect or another.  My first impression with this knife was the incredibly sharp edge. It had no problem cutting through 3 feet of dried deer hide. I have been using this knife a lot over the past couple of weeks, and I still have not had to sharpen the blade.The LED lights are extremely valuable. They make cutting in low light very simple, and they cut my time in half when working on a project because I can see so much better.This knife is a must buy for any outdoorsman.

Collecting: Spider-Man and the X-Men #1-6Elliott Kalan's Spider-Man and the X-Men picks up after the tragic end of Wolverine's tenure at the Jean Grey School for Higher Learning (see Wolverine & the X-Men Volume 2: Death of Wolverine ). This book collects the entire run of Spider-Man and the X-Men.  At Logan's request and against Storm's better judgment, Spider-Man joins the school's staff.  Spider-Man teaches a class on Super Power Ethics.The strength of this series is the juxtaposition of Spider-Man's philosophy, "With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility," against the philosophy of the X-Men, "Protecting a World that Hates and Fears Mutants".  Spider-Man is well written and there genuinely funny moments in this book. The students in the book are written a bit less convincingly, but a lot of depth is added to younger members of the X-Men.Just like the Wolverine and the X-Men series that preceded this one, the series is very much in the vein of the original New Mutants.  That is to say, it is a high school/teen book.  But these super-teens deal with some serious enemies in this book.  From the laughable plot of Sauron to begin a new Jurassic world on Staten Island to the insane Mojo to the evil Sinister these teens have their work cut out for them.Artist Marco Failla has a cartoony style that worked well for the series even and there were even a few "show stopping" panels that I lingered on (especially the Deathbird symbiote!).The book concludes by pointing readers to Secret Wars .  Hopefully a new series will follow the X-Men junior team after the event of the season concludes.

Collecting: All-New X-Men #37-41Bonus: Variant Cover Art Gallery--- 16-page Art gallery by Sorrento and Asrar--- Digital copyFirst a small note to buyers: issues #38-39 are also collected in Guardians of the Galaxy & X-Men: Black Vortex. Within this collection, the crossover issues are little disjointed but complete-ists like myself appreciate having the full run of All-New X-Men in once collection.After the alternate-earth adventures in the previous volume ( All-New X-Men Volume 6: The Ultimate Adventure ), The Utopians opening issue in Madripoor by far my favorite in a while. Utopians opens with a training session: Emma Frost and young Jean work on telekinesis in the Mutant Growth Hormone underworld of Madripoor. Mike Del Mundo's watercolor inspired artwork is just jaw dropping in this issue.The Black Vortex issues are better read in context of the crossover collection, but Andrea Sorrento's art amazes with its gritty vibe that works perfectly for this space-faring epic.Finally, Mahmud Asrar's artwork in the final issues of this collection are the least arresting.  Issues #40-41 have the young X-Men returning to the ruins Utopia off coast of San Francisco.  SHIELD has encountered mutant squatters on the island and tries to defuse the issue. The moment between Karma and young Jean was good, and the story's conclusion was impact-ful since it drew a clear line between how SHIELD handles superheroes such as the Avengers as opposed to mutants like the X-Men.The All-New X-Men concludes in Uncanny X-Men #600 which is collected in  Uncanny X-Men Vol. 6: Storyville

These feature-rich fully wireless Xbox One headphones were a breeze to set up, incredibly comfortable, and produced beautiful sound.Set up was a breeze. A small USB stick plugs into the Xbox One. Then you turn on the headphones. That's it!  These headphones come pre-paired to the USB stick.  There are small red and blue lights on the mic that flash as the headphones search for the wireless signal.  The light will turn a solid color once the signal is connected.The power button also functions as a mute button.  It is easy to tell if the mic is muted because these headphones utilize a brilliant mic monitoring system: you can hear your voice through the headphones when the mic is on.  Headphones without mic monitoring tend to muffle your voice which leads to yelling/speaking loudly.  When the mic is muted the mic monitoring is also off, so you can't hear that audible feedback.A small button at the bottom corner of the headphones toggles between two available modes.  The mode displays a color code on the tiny LED on the edge of the boom mic."Red" mode is a bass boost. Explosions and rich thunderous sounds are perfect for gaming."Blue" mode is pure audio mode.  This mode is perfect for watching TV.The padded headband adjusts for different head sizes.  The leather-like ear pads are both soft and reduce external noise.  Above the ears, two volume wheels control the overall volume and balance between game and chat volume. The fit was overall very comfortable.The retractable boom mic worked well.  My friends reported a clear voice.  I really liked that the mic stows inside in the headphone for storage.The only "negative" I found with these headphones is the same negative I find with all the Xbox One wireless headphones.  The headphones work best with a fresh boot of the system, and the signal can be a little touchy if you move your head. Overall, I can recommend these headphones for anyone searching for a fully wireless option for their Xbox One.

Not every situation calls for (expensive) surround sound headphones.  My home theater produces good sound, so this chat mic offers everything I need to talk to my friends.First, a small caveat: unless you have the new Xbox One controller, you will need to buy the Xbox One Stereo Headset Adapter in order to use this headset. If you do have a controller with headset jack, then the Recon 30X has all the controls you need with in-line mute toggle and volume control.My friends report that my voice was crystal clear using this headset. I was very happy with the slotted ear piece design.  The design allows users to hear themselves talk, so I would speak at a normal volume.  Full-ear headphones often muffle the user's voice, and in order to compensate users will yell to hear themselves.  Moreover I could hear if family members were trying to talk to me.I would recommend these headphones if you have a good sound level from your TV/sound system and you need to be able to hear what is going on in your home.

These are perfect headphones for frequent flyers. The headphones are designed to muffle quite a bit of external noise, including the roar of a jet engine! I was able to clearly and distinctly hear my music and audiobooks on my flight.In addition to good sound quality, there are a couple features that make these headphones a good idea for travel.  The "lay flat" design allows them to fold easily into my briefcase.  They take up precious little space, and since they are so compact, I can keep them in the seat pocket when not in use.Finally price is really something to consider when travelling. Quickly opening bags for the NSA and the general confusion of our sardine cans in the sky means that items have a higher tendency to be lost or broken. There are, of course, headphones available that cost much more and offer a lot more sound and features, but these headphones offer great sound and compact design at a price point that won't make me cry too much if they get damaged.I am happy with the quality, sound, and value of these headphones.  They will have a place in my briefcase next time I fly.

Ice cold water or piping hot soup, this double walled bottle keeps drinks hot or cold all day long (and none of the contents' heat is ever transferred to the outside of the thermos). The bottle transfers almost no heat.  Boiling hot soup added in the night before is still boiling hot by lunch time the next day. Better yet, this bottle is surprisingly large--see banana for scale.  The one liter capacity is perfect for taking lunch to work or ice water on a day hike because it lasts!The stainless steel interior is naturally BPA free and wont rust or corrode. The exterior finish is also rather handsome in a timeless way.  A bottle brush and soap will keep this bottle clean and functional for years.  Note: the vacuum walled bottle is explicitly NOT dishwasher safe.

The Energy Use Monitor is a real eye-opener.  This simple device by Belkin plugs into the wall and then provides a plug for a device that you'd like to monitor as well as a digital screen.  The device will read how much energy is being used by a device as well as calculate cost of using the device over time. I was most curious about "always on" devices such as the refrigerator and alarm clocks.  The most surprising bit of information I learned from the energy use monitor was that the cable box uses almost as much juice as the refrigerator! Time to put the cable company on a power strip that I can turn off!I can recommend this product for its ease of use to anyone curious about household expenses.  I can see a lot of young people devising interesting science fair projects with this device as well. At the very least the Energy Use Monitor will help users save money and live a little greener.

This 80v string trimmer was the perfect solution for my 1/3 acre lot.The trimmer arrived and required some basic assembly (the only tool needed is a Phillips "X" head screwdriver). The trimmer guard has a reversible guide that needs is delivered in the 14" position. If you want the full 16" cutting swath, you need to reverse the guide (which is as simple as backing out two Phillips head screws and then putting them back in).  The large plastic handle was the most difficult part of the procedure: the plastic handle ships screwed together.  It should be a simple procedure to unscrew, fit the handle anywhere that is comfortable on the upper length of the trimmer and then screw together again.  Unfortunately the factor had tightened these screws very tight! And the screws are located slightly under the handle which makes it difficult to get a direct angle on the heads.  I had to use my cordless driver to back the screws out.The trimmer arrived with some string loaded, but you'll soon need more.  I was very pleased with how easy it was to load string into this trimmer.  I cut a sing 10-foot length off of SuperTrim2 SSQ080D1/2-12 1/2-Pound Spool of .08-Inch-by-200-Foot Home Owner-Grade Square Grass Trimmer Line.  The 0.08 thickness is the recommended string, but I have seen people use the 0.095 string as well.  After cutting the length of string, line up the lines on the trimmer head.  Insert the string through one hole and pull it through until both sides are approximately equal length.  The bump feed head has arrows showing you the direction to wind.  Hold the trimmer head and turn the button.  The button clicks as it winds the string into place.The bump feed also works brilliantly.  An easy tap or two on the grass and fresh string advances into place. This easy feed system means no down time even when working along the chain link fence line.Since I already had the GreenWorks GLM801600 80V 21-Inch Cordless Lawn Mower, I was familiar with the power in Greenworks 80v system. I also knew that I wanted the bigger GreenWorks GBA80400 80V 4.0Ah Lithium Ion Battery so that I could use it interchangeably with my mower.The trimmer equipped with the 4.0Ah battery has a lot of staying power. I was able to edge the front yard.  The handle allows you operate the trimmer sideways.  It makes beautiful lines along the edges of the sidewalk and driveway.  I still had plenty of juice to take the trimmer into the backyard. There is a turbo button on the handle that revs up the trimmer and slices through vines, weeds, and runaway stalks.The only downside to the 4.0Ah battery with this trimmer (besides cost) is that it can be heavy. Fortunately there is a shoulder strap that really helps balance the unit and takes all the weight off of the arms.  When I figured out the shoulder strap, it enabled me to use this trimmer indefinitely.Investing in this admittedly pricey system was worth it to me.  I had the freedom and power to do heavy yard work without the hassle of storing gasoline at my house.  Since my garage also doubles as a home gym, I can store the trimmer in the garage without introducing noxious fumes. I was very happy with how quickly the battery chopped through vines and tall grasses. Finally, the added convenience of a second battery to use with my mower means that I can work non-stop in my large yard by simply charging one battery when I trim and charging the other battery when I mow.

Excellent holds up to extreme abuseAs someone who tends to break stuff and wear out shoes and gloves rapidly, this Shoe Goo is an excellent money saver. Shoe repairs can be expensive and time consuming, leaving a critical pair of footwear held hostage by a cobbler for multiple weeks.  Before owning this glue, I frequented various shoe repair shops only to deal with the hassle of waiting for a pair of shoes or boots that I needed immediately.  With a few strong spring clamps along with a carpenter clamp, i am able to affix a sole to a shoe with a tighter bond than the original. Highly recommended.Tips:1) follow the instructions allowing the glue to dry for a few minutes BEFORE the two surfaces are mated2) have several different clamps at your disposal before attempting to use the glue so that no air pockets are created (air pockets will cause the shoes to squawk like a duck)3) if you really are a perfectionist, inserting weights into the shoe during the curing process can provide additional assurance of a nice bondThe most important concept to understand is that labor is expensive. Time is money even at a shoe shop.  If you have Shoe Goo in your possession along with the proper clamps, you can do a better job of sole repair at home because you have the ability to take as much time as necessary to clamp the mating surfaces.  Meanwhile, you won't have to waste time on transportation and communicating with the shoe repair shop.

This stuff is powerful.  So powerful, in fact, it will leave your lips numb which is a bit disconcerting.  Probably the biggest difference between 100% Deet and competing products is that trace amounts stick to surfaces of gloves, weight belts, and boots. This attribute was useful when I found myself finishing a late night service door insulation on garage where the caulk, paint and 500 watt halogen bulbs were attracting massive amounts of insects.  Just sprayed a perimeter and it worked great.  There is an oily film, however, that still adheres to the siding more than a month later.

This pad was originally purchased for an elderly family member who enjoys sitting upright at the kitchen table all day long.  Unfortunately, he couldn't get use to it.  However, I quickly coopted the pad so I could work on a formal dining room chair.  This pad makes a huge difference when sitting for hours. In fact, if you are not too self-conscious, this is a great item to stuff in your backpack for long days working on a laptop at Starbucks.

Purchasing packs of these batteries along with various other [rare] sizes makes a great deal of sense.  Going to the hardware store when an needed on short notice is an expensive strategy.  Somewhat paradoxically, I found that the batteries at the corner hardware store of often more than five years old, which is obviously bad and due to a retail store's needs to carry a wide range of SKUs even when some are destined to move slowly. Purchasing fresh watch batteries in bulk makes a great deal of sense in the long-run.  This is especially true if you have female family members with larger number of fashion watches.

Over the past few years, I have am amazed a collection of splitting implements including the this item and the Fiskars 36 inch super splitting axe.  In short, these mauls do not work well with extremely hard to split logs like freshly cut 24 inch diameter slippery elm.  This maul will bounce right off the face of the log. The perfectly cylindrical handle aggravates the problem as it takes a little practice to achieve perfect normal (i.e. 90 degree) impact.  The only success I have with tougher woods is multiple splitting wedges and a 20 pound sledge hammer.Sledgehammers for CrossFit workouts go up to 150 pound head weights. So clearly, there are individuals out there who can swing much heavier weights.  It would great if there was much heavier version of this maul with a sharper blade.  Of course, this would require periodic sharpening with a grinder but nonetheless could serve a different group of users.

Six years ago, I had a total quadriceps tendon rupture requiring a lengthy rehabilitation period.  Over time, I collected a number of knee braces with different levels of stability and bulkiness.  This brace it a moderately stable version with stays that can be used during everyday activities.  Yet, it is a bit long, making it somewhat more conspicuous than say a Futuro brace of the same style.  Also, if you have muscular calves and quadriceps, the extended material (compared with Futuro) could become an irritation. A slightly shorter brace eliminate problems with matching a brace to both the knee size and surrounding muscles.

As someone who has owned four different models of Vornado fans, I have generally been pleased with their quality.  This is a solid, quiet compact fan.  My only real complaint is that could use a more powerful motor.  Compact high-powered blowers can be ten times the price of this fan, which wouldn't be justified for most consumers. It would be nice to have an eight to ten inch fan with three times the power and twice the price of this fan.Depending on the application, I have found high performance, small-diameter DC radiator fans a better solution.  They do produce quite a bit of noise and require a sufficiently powerful DC power supply that the average consumer might not own.

None of the seeds germinated despite my using different potting soils, different locations and even different seed starters.  The only conclusion is that the seeds were neutralized at some point prior to my receiving them.

To complete various projects involving small motors and high output LED modules, I purchased five PWM controllers, including two of this specific module.  There was no documentation, so I was a little bewildered why neither of the two controllers worked at first with any type of load.  It was only until I pried the cover off that the presence of a three-way polarity switch was obvious.  That is normal-off-reverse.  Both switches were set to off?!?!  It is hard to imagine the logic of this design.  The switch isn't easily accessible or even visible with the cover still attached.  The perforations allow for manipulation of this internal switch but considering the potential damage to expensive equipment, it should be more visible with its status obvious.Having purchased different products from DROK previously, I am growing tired of the lack of documentation. Even the simplest of products has important parameters and feature that an electronics designer should know.

This fuse assortment is great to have in your possession before you really need it. Now that Radio Shack is closing many locations, it can be difficult to find glass fuses on short notice.  I learned this when our emergency sump pump blew a fuse during a power failure.That being said, this a great value considering its a domestic vendor. Similar products at reasonable prices are available from Asian suppliers but it may be weeks before they arrive

This is one of two wood moisture meters I have purchased.  They both well but provide misleading data to the uniformed user.  There can be a significant moisture gradient from the interior to exterior of a piece of firewood.
