Hence, the only way to get accurate moisture data is split properly-sized pieces of firewood to half size. That is to say the samples will be half the desired size. In my experience, exterior moisture values are extremely misleading with an absolute difference of as high as 20% (i.e. 8% exterior, 28% interior) even after a year of seasoning.

These wraps are excellent organization tools for the technical individual and homeowner alike.  I starting using these for electronics projects and started using them all over the house for AC cords.  The color variations are helpful when sorting wires and diagnosing problems in low-light conditions such as behind a home entertainment center.My only gripe a about these specific wraps is the unit cost should be WAY less as indicated by prices on larger bundles of similar wraps. Velcro must be making an egregious margin on this product.

Over the past five years, I have purchased several high-output ALZO bulbs and have never been disappointed. This latest purchase is no exception.  I enjoy working in extremely bright environments including the garage and basement.  These bulbs are excellent for such applications.The only downside to larger bulbs such as these is that the tend to get broken more frequently.  That is to say, since they stick out of fixtures farther than 100 watt equivalent CFLs (i.e. 23 watt), they inadvertently get clipped when say carrying large objects and the user misjudges the clearance.

IMPORTANT - don't destroy your computer by using batteries from this supplier - WARNINGAs a tech-savvy engineer, I generally purchase top-the-line laptops and accessories. Moreover, I have hands-on experience with computer repair and board level electronics. Two batteries (original and replacement) from this supplier were defective and/or improperly designed.  More alarmingly, they appear to have damaged my 2,500 dollar XPS laptop.  In short, the batteries would cause abrupt computer shut-downs without any warning.  The first battery would reach about 35%-45% level and the computer would shut down without warning. Restarting the computer would indicate 1% charge.  Even more ridiculous was the the second battery.  It would lead to computer shutdowns as high as 85%.  Of the 30 or so laptop batteries, I have had over the years, nothing like this has ever occurred.Worst of all, after this happened about 25 times, my computer is damaged and is totally unresponsive. It is appears that a board-level failure has occurred.  Even more odd, is that have always avoided running on battery power, including with this 17 inch XPS when in possession of these new batteries.  Recently, I have to travel and been unable to have an AC outlet in reach. There is sufficient evidence to suggest serious problems with this supplier and this particular battery.

This is a fairly rugged bag for the price. While it is great for transporting mattresses, I have found the bag excellent for covering other large objects.  In once case, it was used to cover my nephew's batting cage screen over the winter.
This is the second identical shirt I have acquired.  I wore the old one so much it developed holes.  It fits great in XL for guys with a large build and wide shoulders.

It is hard to imagine Cooper's manufacturing being so poor that basic tolerances for light sockets can't be achieved.  I have purchased a dozen twin sockets over the past decade and never had a problem.  Recently, I bought an additional two of these from Menards (Like Home Depot located mostly in the Midwest), and both were difficult to screw into the existing hard-wired sockets.  Moreover all four female sockets were extremely difficult to use. To be certain, I used different bulbs to clearly identify the Cooper twin adapters as the problem.  In fact, one of the CFLs broke in my hand due to the torque required.Just to be very clear, I have many different bulbs and many twin sockets.  The Cooper Industries model is the only presenting such problems.

Searching for a unique birthday cake, I came across this item at Costco. My instincts were correct as it was not only an excellent tasting cake, it is just different from any (commonly available) alternatives.  The party guests were rather pleased with the selection, especially one who was born in Kentucky.  While the cake is very dense, the notion that it serves 12-14 is somewhat of an exaggeration.  With eight adults, it should be easy to polish this cake off in one sitting.One item of note is the the attractive circular wooden box that houses the cake. This allows the cake to be a great standalone gift.  Unfortunately, there is really no good way to value the box aesthetics in a party setting.  It does make the cake rather portable if you need to bring it to restaurant or some other venue.

This bag was an inexpensive solution for storing the main netting of a 50 foot batting cage.  It works for that purpose but one of the zippers failed.  I would have gladly paid an additional $10 for a better zipper.
Works great, no issues.  I would strongly suggest purchasing a backup if you use for phone for business purposes.

Let me try to add a few pieces of information not already discussed.For those who are not handy with tools, don't worry as the Mystic Rainwater Collection system is very easy to install.  Be sure to double check your your measurements however because it would be difficult to correct too large a section removed from the downspout.BENEFITS OTHER THAN COLLECTING THE WATER:Rapid downpours can lead to pooling around your home where water can seep into cracks that would otherwise not be a problem.  Slowing down the rate of water releases the surrounding environment can help in this regard.CONSIDERATIONS - FOR ANY RAINWATER COLLECTION SYSTEM1) First, the aesthetics of the converted food-grade plastic barrels aren't all that great. Costco has some fancier barrels spring 2015 if you care about aesthetics. Even more sophisticated collection systems blend better into the home's aesthetics. The slimline tanks are one example.2) Second, collecting enough rainwater in the rainy season for drier months later would require storage of thousands of gallons of water storage. The paradox being is that barrel is getting filled when you really don't need the water. Small collection systems make the most sense where sporadic rains throughout the season exist but are insufficient. I use the water for fruit trees.3) Lastly, the water pressure is quite low -- even with the barrel elevated by a foot. Typical municipal water pressure equates to a water elevation of greater than 50 feet. In my case, I water fruit trees so I can leave the hose slowly trickle out for 10 minutes while I engage in other activities.

After receiving this mirror, I procrastinated several weeks before installing it.  Preparing myself for an afternoon of aggravation, I was surprised how easy it was to install.  There are few instructional videos on Youtube that last two to eight minutes.Note that the existing painted cover that matches your car's color can easily be popped off the old mirror and reused if it is still intact.

As I have mentioned in my previous reviews of electric heaters, ALL electric heaters are essentially 100% efficient once the electricity is inside your home. How the heat is directed can impact how efficiently that heat is used. Electric heat is so expensive because electric power plants are only 35% - 40% thermally efficient.  That being said, this Sunbeam heater is one of the only heaters that actually produces (i.e. consumes) 1500 watts. Most are much less, probably for safety reasons and to limit circuit breakers from tripping.Other nice features of the Sunbeam include a decent cool fan and the ability to tilt the fan to wear it is most needed. What is also important to note is isn't a tip sensor, which could be a safety hazard but great for when the fan is used in odd positions.

This item was one of the easiest cell phone/iPod aftermarket parts I have ever installed.  In the past, I have done repairs on iPhones and iPod nano's.  Both were extremely difficult to get right the first time -- even for a skilled engineer with myriad tools at my disposal.  Arguably this could be the result of initial product design for legitimate reasons.  That being said, no such headaches are created when installing this micro USB jack/board.

First, I am glad CafePress is working with Amazon so that purchases can be made with little effort.  While I have order directly from CafePress in the past, it is just easier through Amazon for stock items.The design speaks for itself.  It does convey an appropriate green message.  The shirt itself fits okay.  Perhaps it is a bit boxy for more mesomorphic or endomorphic guys.  The cotton is rather thick and not particularly compliant.

The results from my initial testing of this product were unimpressive. Using my cold cranking amp meter, this device demonstrated substantially fewer than the 450 amp rating/900 peak.  In fact, it was registering below 200 amps when the starter was in a warm environment and completely charged.  I tested and retested it.  Altogether, I am skeptical of this product.More real world testing is needed....

This unit was purchased to cool the master bedroom in a home with a single central air system.  Previously, I have owned other portable A/C units.  The quality of the device is so poor, I can only imagine that there was miscommunication between the parent company and its Chinese supplier.When first installing the unit, I noticed cracks and actual plastic missing on the hose flange that connects to the back of the unit.  I was never able to find the missing piece, so I assumed it was lost at the factory.  There was also large crack across the flange, which I taped up.  What was more horrifying, however, is that the blower fan (i.e. squirrel cage), had a broken blade on it.  It was just luck that I even saw the problem as I was attempting to insert the hose into the flange.  This strikes me as quite amazing as it must have been installed broken and the device never even tested.  It is improbable that this could have been broken in transit.Overall, the quality of this unit is atrocious, making the appliance a potential safety hazard.

As some reviewers have questioned the five amp fuse, let me explain a bit about the electronics employed.  Car chargers use  DC-DC voltage converters to reduce the output voltage to 5 volts per USB standards.  This charger has a max power consumption of 48 watts.  That is voltage*amps=power (watts).  At the 12 volt level, this is only about 4 amps, which explains why there is only a five amp fuse.  When the voltage is reduced to 5 volts, it can produce an output of 9.6 amp x 5 volts = 48 watts. The voltage decreases, current increases and power stays constant.  In practice, however, there are some losses by any voltage conversion device so slightly more than 4 amps at the socket would be required.********************As I have used about 15 different chargers for myriad portable devices, I can honestly say this one is the best -- so far. Longevity is often a problem with such devices, so time will tell.  I am often charging multiple iPhones and large Galaxy Note 2 and now a Note 3, which has an OEM wall charger of 2 amps.The Aleratec can handle whatever is connected to it.  I previously had another quad charger, which was a bit flimsy compared to the Aleratec, which has excellent build quality.  Moreover, the squarish plug holds firm in my second DC outlet, which is located in the [closed] center glove compartment.  When driving the previous charger, it often would shake loose.  As one can imagine, there is no safe way to push it back in while driving.Overall, the Aleratec is best car charger I have ever purchased and is worth the investment --- if it stands up to the test of time.

Aging mesomorphs may enjoy the benefits of these compression sleeves. They work wonders for pain and numbness in your hands and forearms. Cycling, chopping wood, weight lifting and even rowing can create such pain that OTC medication can't address. Yet, depending on how you are built, it may be tough to size these correctly as creating the necessary compression sufficient to relieve forearm pain may create a tourniquet on your biceps.  Oddly, this is true even if you have large forearms compared to your biceps. Rolling the upper part down to your elbows appears to work without too much discomfort.

Even when compared to other contoured ear plugs, the Super Leight are more comfortable.  For whatever reason, these can stay for hours in your ears without discomfort. This can be particularly helpful when attempting to sleep in noisy environments.

While there is nothing obviously wrong with this upgrade, I have to think about the 2002 Sharper Image lawsuit against Consumer Reports for its negative findings on Ionic Breeze air purifier. Granted we are talking Apples and Oranges here. It is hard to claim that cleaning up a tiny surface area of a home with have a tremendous effect on overall air quality due to many factors. These include untouched surfaces, unreachable areas and leakages in the house envelope. An industrial air purifier that guarantees removal of small airborne particles would cost more than the average American home.If Neato wants to sell such products and claim they help allergy sufferers, third party tests should be conducted to proof the upgrade does indeed the capture of various allergens in homes of different vintages and designs.

While I have tried to evaluate various CO monitors with crude experiments such as using the exhaust from a gas snow blower, it is  relatively difficult for any consumer to perform a true scientific test on such products. However, one important advantage this CO alarm has over previous versions we owned is obvious - no false alarms [so far]. It is a well-known fact that recharging lead acid batteries in the vicinity of CO alarms can trigger them.  This presumably is due to the release of hydrogen and/or hydrogen sulfide gas that fools the CO alarm.While I could clearly get the Kidde KN-COPP-B-LPM to trigger by using the exhaust of a snow blower, I was unable to do the same with heavy (10 amp) charging of a deep cycle battery connected to our emergency sump pump, unlike an older model of CO detector we own. Even with the battery bubbling, indicating sizable gas release, the ppm registered zero.

The tolerances on the threads of this container are poor.  Granted, it is quite inexpensive and the consumer can only expect so much at this price point.  I have tested about a dozen of these containers sold at various retail outlets.  Not a single one could be tightened such that I was unable to squeeze air out of it.  While this may not be a problem for highly viscous oil, other more volatile compounds which may contaminate the oil could leak out.Ironically, you can purchase a similarly sized kitty liter container at Aldi for the same price.  Use the litter for an oil absorbent if you don't own a cat.

After using these shears, I can't believe that I previously risked injury using a chain saw and reciprocating saw to prune large branches. This lopper cuts through 1.5 inch branches and tree roots like butter.

If you are spraying anything elevated, such as the upper limbs of a fruit tree, the two gallon size might be a bit much.  In fact, even at ground level, I find the rather thin, unpadded nylon strap rather uncomfortable.  This is coming from someone who is a big guy and former powerlifter.  After trying this sprayer for our fruit trees, I regret not paying an extra 25 dollars for a backpack sprayer at Costco.Regarding the larger picture, I definitely think any sprayer is better than a hose attachment in most cases.  Academic research suggests that only 2% to 5% of pesticides used in the US are applied to the appropriate surfaces. Hose attachments might be better for really tall fruit trees but these should be pruned to an appropriate height in most cases anyway.

As someone who has sat for quite a few grillings in banking, management consulting, engineering, and VC interviews, I have received my share of tough interview questions.  Moreover, I have taken a sizable number of brain teasers and IQ tests over the decades. This collection, which are designed for someone with a slightly different job description, really does include some tough questions.  In fact, younger job candidates who have sub-superstar credentials should thoroughly try all the problems in this book early in their job search process.Far too often, second-tier individuals get roped into bogus trader jobs at third-tier firms, where turnover is worse than at McDonald's and the income opportunity is poor.  In other words, in this "winner takes all" economy, it might be worth it to see if you are smart enough to answer such difficult questions before pursuing certain quant and trading jobs.

While this kit is very comprehensive and well thought out, there are some flaws.  More importantly, the install is quite difficult and doesn't justify attempting to do it yourself.  Even someone experienced repairing other items, your success rate is likely to be less than 50%.  Given that some repair shops offer screen repairs for 10-20 dollars more than this kit, it absolutely doesn't make sense to do it yourself.  In fact, a 50 dollar difference for an in-shop screen repair seems entirely reasonable given the probability that something else in the phone will get damaged.ProsComprehensive step-by-step videoSeveral tools includedConsKit too expensive to justify doing it on your ownNo home button -- must reuse original, which has a rubber skirt that tears easilyFlimsy spudger -- broke on first useTools missing: tweezers, knife/razor, heat gun (obviously)Need jewelers glasses to see tiny partsSome screws are extremely difficult to access (not iCracked's fault, but worth noting)

Despite trying several different brands of "heavy-duty" nitrile gloves from online sources, none have compared to the heavy duty versions sold by Harbor Freight.  The Venom are a bit better than regular duty nitrile gloves.  With the Harbor Freight gloves, you can pick up rusty scrap metal and not worry about tears.

This drop-in replacement bulb worked just fine.  My only complaint with this product is that it should never exist in the first place.  Appliance manufacturers should use either mainstream bulbs or widely-spaced LEDs that will last decades.

As someone who has fixed a few phones and iPod Nanos, I have employed both the "free" tools that some with screen repair kits as well as higher-end third party sets.  In short, this extremely inexpensive set is a decent value for one or two repairs.  The grips are much better (i.e. larger) than  than the free tools. This becomes important when a tremendous amount of force needs to be applied on screws that have had Loctite applied at the factory.The actual metal on the drivers is roughly the same quality as that of tools included within various kits and is not at the level of pricey hardened steel sets. Yet, they get the job done. Of note are the two pair of tweezers, which are somewhat flimsy compared to expensive Tweezerman or medical supply variants. Again, the quality implies that the set is intended for a few uses.Overall, even an amateur might a appreciate a higher quality set and definitely better quality tools than those that come gratis with repair kits.  In fact, because of myriad adhesive and Loctite hassles, individuals making a repair for the first time might really need the best quality tools available. Many of the repair videos on YouTube fail to explain the amount of adhesives and Loctite used on Apple products.

While I am not someone to spend the time on hand washing and waxing, I decided to give this product a try because of its claim to dirt repellency. Turtle Wax ICE liquid is not entirely dirt repellent but its results were impressive.  After application, the surface coating was so slippery that I almost lost my balance when resting my hand on the car's fender. Salt spray still sticks to the body but it easily comes off with a dry rag.  The manufacturer's claims are mostly valid because the exterior surfaces are so incredibly slippery, some dirt deflects off from the surface instead of adhering. That which remains is easily removed with a dry rag.In order to be somewhat scientific about application of this product, I carefully hand washed the car with 150 degree F water.  After thoroughly drying, I applied the wax in an 80 degree heated garage.  Cleaning the car was the 80 percent of the work because it only took about 15 minutes to apply the wax.  The one downside to Turtle Wax Ice is its very low viscosity.  This leads to wasteful over-application, spillage, etc.My overall opinion of this product is very positive. If you are someone that frequently washes your car, you may be able to save money by spreading out the wash intervals.

iFanze car charger is one of about eight (8) high-amperage car chargers that I have attempted to use with my Note II. In short, it doesn't provide suitable voltage/current for the phone.  While this may be more of Samsung issue in that the phone could be sensing a minute voltage drop and intentionally lower the current draw.  Yet, the iFanze can't even keep a level battery charge when navigation is being used with the screen at maximum brightness.  This is with no other devices attached to the second USB port.Again this may have something to do Samsung's circuitry as this phone is power hungry. The standard wall charger provides 2 amps. So far, the only car charger that has consistently worked (i.e. charged the battery while power-hungry features are active) is the PowerGen 4.2 Amp charger.

After trying applying Rain-X rain repellent on my windshield, I purchased this deicer hoping that it would well with another Rain-x product.  Basically, I didn't see any difference between its use and inexpensive deicer. .  In fact, I transitioned to -35F purple Splash de-icer and window washer fluid has worked better in several instances.  This particular product is less expensive and works as a strong deicer (i.e. mirrors, headlights) when in a warm spray bottle.  In fact, the Splash's methanol content is so high that it is slightly flammable. Rain-X de-icer sis just a mediocre  to promote the larger RainX

This simple, well made stopper keeps CO2 where is should be -- in the bottle.  Given the low price of the stopper and expensive price of champagne, the Super Seal is an excellent investment.  This is true even for the infrequent champagne drinker.  Somewhat conveniently, it also makes classy inexpensive gift for gift exchange parties around Christmas.

If you enjoy bicycle trips lasting less than four hours or so, this is an ideal bag.  It is large enough to hold a wallet, keys, cell phone and a small snack.  More importantly, is large enough to accommodate (i.e aggressively stuff) a thin long-sleeve shirt if necessary. This is particularly helpful during unpredictable weather.The quality of the Avenir Bigmouth is superb.  The heavy construction is impressive.  In fact, it is hard to conceive an incident where the bag would be damaged and the rider survive.

After losing a one glove from a pair of North Face E-Tip gloves, I purchased a pair of these Head gloves from Costco at 1/4 the price.  In short, they appeared quite durable initially.  However, they are not as precise as the North Face gloves when it comes to using my Samsung Galaxy Note II smartphone's touchscreen.  It almost seems as if the metalized fabric was an afterthought, even though I know this couldn't be the case. The thumb and index finger surfaces are not as seamless as the North Face alternative.The Head gloves have seemingly durable fabric but poor stitching.  The overall fabric is slightly heavier than the North Face gloves.  Yet, the stitching and construction appears less precise.  At Costco prices, they are definitely worth MORE than the North Face gloves.  If you find yourself using a touchscreen frequently outdoors, the North Face might be better alternative.Lastly, take careful note of the size you need. I am always on the edge of medium/large depending on what type of gloves: weightlifting, work, bicycling, dress.  In the case of the Head gloves, I was happy to purchase medium.  The fit snugly, but are comfortable.  They are perfect size used as a base layer under heavier winter gloves.

With the Celestron 93230 8 to 24mm eyepiece, I read license plate numbers up to 3000 feet away.  This scope is being used more as a novelty in a high rise but is entertaining nonetheless.  The one thing I can say about Celestron, is that when you start adding the accessories -- eye piece, tripod, etc, the price more than doubles.  The company is probably selling this scope at a loss to encourage add-on purchases.

While our Celestrn C90 spotting scope is used a novelty in an urban environment, this eyepiece really makes a difference. It particular,  I can now read license plate number 1/2 mile away while observing the thermal distortions created by the urban heat island effect.

As I have consumed tumeric in various forms - powder, raw root in stir fry, and capsules such as these, it is hard to make a distinction about the Nature's Bounty variant. The price is reasonable but 10x higher than powder if you can find in large bulk containers.My principal reason for using tumeric is to avoid common inflammatory pain due to heavy weightlifting and related pre-existing injuries. It "seems" to work but I have to rely on the research, which is getting more positive every day.

This device is limited by the current capacity of your vehicle's electrical system.  Most cars have a 15A or 20A cigarette adapter, which translates in 180 to 240 watt maximum output of this type of heater.  By comparison, the Tesla Model S, which must use an electric heater, provides 4000 watts of heating or ~20x as much. When I pre-heat my car in a subzero weather via a 110v timer, in an unheated garage, I generally use an 1100 watt modified pancake hairdryer for 1-2 hours. This is with no moving air around the  automobile to bring the interior temperature up to 75-80 degrees.Cars are not insulated that well because they generally don't need to be.  If the heating system was able to capture ALL of the waste heat from a 30mpg car using 2 gal/h, up to 43,000 watts of heat output would be available.  While this isn't feasible, it suggests the heating system of an automobile could conceivably capture 200 times the heat from a 12v plug-in heater. Hence, don't expect much from such heaters. These are for niche applications.Another way to look at the issue of electrical heating, is that 120 amp alternator will only have about 1000 watts of spare power after running the vehicle accessories. So, even if you had a special heater hard-wired to the battery, you still wouldn't be able to heat the car in extreme cold.

While I don't have access to a laboratory-grade pH meter to vouch for the accuracy of this device, I can attest to ease of use of this device.  It also interesting to see the pH of common fluids, like tap versus bottled water.Like many gadgets and tools, this provided an unforeseen benefit.  My sister's poor Bailey had an infection.  A tell-tale sign is the pH of the dog's urine. After the first veterinarian visit, I learned of the pH relationship.  With this meter, we were able to avoid a second expensive vet visit by confirming the effectiveness of the prescription medication.

For Christmas, I received eight (8) of these batteries as presents for use in my two 12x SecurityIng flashlights. In short, they are superior to any 18650 batteries previously employed.  Not only do they last longer, the circuit-protected 18650 appear to get over-current triggered occasionally and shut down. Not exactly sure why, but the problem doesn't seem to exist with these batteries. Also, the 18650 adapter were just clutter I wish to avoid.Another observation -- these Securitylng flashlights have three batteries in series.  Often when using them for 10-15 minutes, only one of the three batteries needs charging.  I also have two SecurityIng double battery chargers that I use with these batteries.  This may imply some sort of inconsistency or perhaps, need for more sophisticated balancing circuitry.******For those of you who are interested in physics:These batteries contain about 60,000 joules or 80 times the energy of .357 magnum bullet at the muzzleor1/35th (2.8%) of the energy contained in a Big Mac

In short, this is a solid product but really needs to be a bit more sophisticated (and expensive).  That is to say, it should provide clear indications of the car battery's voltage and a more precise charge state of its internal battery. Current flow in a numerical readingg would also be helpful. When testing this charger on a partially depleted, newly installed car battery that was sitting for a few hours or overnight in cold weather, the Stanley charger depleted quite rapidly -- well under 15 minutes. This was odd because the car battery charge state should have been about 95%+.  After showing total depletion, the Stanley charger would then indicate 3 out of 4 bars within ten or fifteen minutes sitting idle.  Given such information, I wouldn't trust this battery booster in extreme environments far from population centers.Another option is to consider a 30w, 15v hand crank generator by Humless.  It gives quite a workout but is always ready as long as you have the arm strength. You can use the included alligator clips by directly them attaching to the battery terminals or make a custom cable, as I have, with a cigarette lighter plug.  This setup clearly works as it provides up to three amps and demonstratively raises the battery voltage. Also, you don't have to get out of your car.

This is a great productivity tool if you enjoy the exercise. Unfortunately, Amazon doesn't sell the 48 inch wide version of this snow pusher from The Snow Plow. However, I was able to order it directly from the manufacturer/distributor. If you are a bigger/stronger guy and your time is valuable, this ultra wide shovel makes a lot of sense. Need to clear the driveway early in the morning before work but don't want to disturb your neighbors with your gas guzzling snow thrower? This could be your solution.While various descriptions suggest this is usable for light snows under four inches, I would suggest if you plan your work accordingly, you might save time (and gasoline) by making multiple passes while the snow is still falling with this snow pusher instead of waiting for the snow to reach 12" and then fire up a noisy, smelly snow thrower that is half as wide.Overall, it is a great design. The use of UHMWPE (Ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene) is good but polycarbonate used in bulletproof glass may have been better. Polycarbonate would be stickier, so there would need to be a slippery edge of Teflon or UHMWPE at the contact surface. However, customers would not be willing to pay for something that expensive.For durability, the fiberglass handle and wide v-brace (Tuffbrace) is a nice touch. I tend to break tools, so I am looking forward to seeing how this holds up.
This mouthwash is okay but the value is questionable.  I have had as good experiences with generic Target-branded whitening mouthwash at much lower cost.

This case is both durable and precisely molded to properly fit my 5G iPod Nano.  The latter is something not to take for granted as some of these inexpensive accessories have tolerance problems.  Not with this case.  Highly recommended as a primary or even as a  inexpensive backup case.

After eight years and about ~12,000 hours of use, the ballast in my $400 Sunray full spectrum light box failed.  It was extremely easy to replace. This cereal along with Kashi GoLean have the highest concentrations of protein in commonly available cereals.  They also represent a good value in terms of cost per gram of soy.  That being said, there is some mixed medical research on consumption of large amounts of soy-based products in that soy mimics certain hormones like estrogen. While I enjoy the taste of this cereal, I have decided to limit my consumption to normal levels and get more protein from rice protein powder and other products.

The basic premise of this product is solid.  Liquid monolayer pool covers are shown to clearly reduce evaporation and heat loss.  I have tested the Flexible Solutions Heatsavr liquid in a controlled setting.  The cooling rate of a volume of warm water with Heatsavr was significantly slower than an identical volume of water in the same indoor setting.That being said, there does appear to be discrepancy between the AMOUNT of liquid cover required per Flexible Solutions' data and what is contained in these fish.  In essence, significantly more money would need to be spend on a greater volume of liquid pool cover to achieve the desired energy savings.

Plugs are not simple items, especially when used in fighter aircraft and ICBMs.  While my application is less demanding than such military endeavors, I do still value my time.  That being said, my complaint may be a bit more targeted at the connector industry.  Sizes and pin configurations should be available in a simple table adopted by the entire connector industry globally.  Without such table, the purchaser finds himself purchasing multiple unneeded connectors.

We had a moderately priced (180 dollar) executive chair that was in pristine condition as it was seldom used.  Sadly, two 1cm welds broke that rendered the chair useless for its 81 year old owner.  In short, there was a [poorly] spot welded tube going through a hollow pyramidal stamped metal structure underneath the bottom cushion of the chair. Think vertically through the Pyramid of Giza.With the two welds fractured, the seat wobbled about 10 degrees, making the owner feel very unsafe while bending other structural components. The other stamped structures around the weld, it would have been cost prohibitive to access the weld area.  Yet, the exterior of the pyramid was easily accessible. So, after drilling three large holes in one side, I poured the mixture after 120 seconds into the cavity.  The next day, I drilled three exploratory holes to see how far the mix migrated. It got around 230 degrees of the vertical tube.  So, I injected a second mix into the the second set of holes.  At the same, time I dabbed a little mix around the hard-to--reach spot welds.In the end, the Permoxy firmly fixed the vertical tube in much more stress conditions that the normal user would impose on the chair.

For those of you enjoy the benefits of rack drying clothes - lower energy costs, humidity in the winter and reduced clothing wear -- Downy Infusions is worth the investment. You may have noticed that pure cotton towels become abrasive when left to air dry after being saturated. That problem can be eliminated This particular softener works especially well with HE washers as very little softener is needed.  Towels will come out soft and fluffy despite never being placed in a hot dryer.Does the cost of this product offset any energy gains from not using a dryer? Probably not. If you include gas, electricity and wear/tear on dryer, a load of clothes could cost 25 cents to dry.  If you live in the city, coin operated dryers costs as much as $1.75 per load.  So 15 cents per load cost for the softener at full strength, air drying would come out on top in either case.  Moreover, a little goes lot goes a long way, so if the goal is merely to avoid scratchy cotton, you could probably use a tiny amount when drying cotton towels.  This of course, doesn't take into the other benefits of air drying -- indoor humidity in the winter, outdoor cooling in the summer and increased clothing life.On side note, recent climate models have suggested that direct heating of the atmosphere from energy intensive processes may be bigger factor than previously thought. That is to say your dryer exhaust heats the atmosphere while making your air conditioner work harder.

For some reason, many 2A chargers don't provide sufficient current/voltage for my Samsung Note II. Years back I bought this very same bra on HSN in nude and black. I reorder many times.  When you first get the product, 'massage' the tube a bit to mix the contents as it may have settled.  When you squeeze a bit out it should be a flesh tinted color. If not, recap it and massage some more.  Once done, it's done.  I like that it is sanitary, no fingers dipping into a pot of potion. It's small but it lasts a long time. I squeeze enough out to do the entire eye, starting below the eye on the dark circles, and then using up what's on my fingers above the eye, lid and all.  I like it has a built-in SPF to protect the eye as most daycreams with SPF are not good to put on the eye area.  This product never causes any stinging or tearing. I am a licensed esthetician and this sells in spas for at least $75.  I buy it here when it's in the low $30 range.  It's the only way to fly!

The temps are chilling down and now back to some comfort foods and turning on the oven.  I have a few other of Joanne's books and like her TV cooking shows.  I have tried several of her on-air recipes, the baked Semolina Gnocchi Alla Romano w/sage...to die for.  Having company in early Nov, I want to make that as a company side dish with sage, much growing in my garden...Fall is the season for sage.Here are some of my tagged pages in this new cookbook...(1) Mississippi Mud: a simple dessert that my 9 yr old g'daughter should love, and no eggs (she's allergic) so that is one for me to try. (2) Rhubarb Crostata (I have frozen cut up rhubarb from summer in my freezer I was going to use for jam, now I think it's got other plans!). I make my own pastas and pizzas and breads, and in this book there are several to try...(3) calzone with sausage, greens, and ricotta (and I will add shredded mozz, gotta have it) is one of them.  There's also several interesting homemade pastas such as (4) pepper fettuccine homemade pasta.  Another recipe calling my name is (5) Roasted Garlic and Gruyere Souffl, love garlic anything. There are several apps worth looking at (6) Roasted carrot hummus and (7) Crostini with artichokes and grape leaves.  I've seen bottled grape leaves sold in market but I didn't feel like making my own stuffed grape leaves with them; but this is another way to use them that is much easier.  Might buy some today in fact. I like making ice creams and sorbets and there's one in here (8) a Citrus Coconut Sorbet I will eventually try.  There's a (9) Panna Cotta using Greek Yogurt as well.  Probably the first savory recipe I will try is (10) the Spiced Chicken with Vinegar, looks easy.  I have just listed ten items,  but there is so much more.  The author and I seem not only to share the same name and similar spelling, but  a love for easy-to-prepare, tasty food with novel uses of easy-to-find ingredients that make it all the better.  When I cook for company, I like to make at least one unique recipe  (like the Gnocchi Romano w/sage that most people never have tried) or kohlrabi I made...something different.  It becomes a conversation starter at the dinner table!  I will come back and report when I dig into these recipes--so many recipes, so little time.

This is my second carpet shampooer. The Eureka Atlantis model I had for yrs , it worked fine, but this is more compact and yet as good as the larger one I had before. I am very pleased. It's easy to fill up the tanks and empty them.  I can't find anything bad to say about it.  This model is Bissell's lower-priced model, it's all the better. So check out all the various cleaning solutions Bissell gives you for this machine...one for pets, one with scent, etc...I got the deep cleaning one with Scotchguard to hopefully repel some future stains.  This machine has it all.

Great authentic taste. I use this individual size can along with the 1.5oz individual bags of Garden of Eatin' blue corn chips (the best chips ever by the way). These molds snap tightly into the grooves so they stand erect and won't spill over the freshly poured contents. Unlike regular EVOO, you don't need huge quantities of lemon olive oil, it's use is more specific, so you can get away with smaller bottles.  It lasts long too, so the value stretches. No allergens present, and sometimes even olive oils are unsafe with those with food allergies, I know, I have had to return some bc of that. This is also certified organic, produced in Italy...what more can you ask for at a cost of just over $6 a bottle? You won't find a better lemon olive oil at twice the price.

My PC bible. This is the first and the best of the cookbooks written for WPuck PCookers, I have them all but this is the one I like best.  Yes, Wolfgang then had a digital setting PC using word settings preset to times; but I can use it for the newer version, you don't have to worry about 'rice' or 'fish' or 'veggie' settings anymore, so use this book for any electronic PC, just go by the time it cooks.  Same thing.  Someone was complaining about a 15 bean soup recipe being 'too store bought.' I love that recipe.  Beans are beans.  The company just mixes them up for you in advance, so if that's considered cheating, I'm in.  I still have to cook them. I cook from scratch too and this is a great soup.  Rinse them and dump them in, add canned tomato sauces along with the rest of pantry ingredients, it's the best, fastest soup I make on a wintry day. To make it vegetarian, leave out the ham bits.

I think every cook should have a book like this, it's a primer.  Most every sauce you need is in here starting with the 'mother sauces' and more, dessert sauces too.  Recipes to help you use them once made.  The recipes are simple and easy to read, with care taken to font and white space on the page.  It's amazing how simple the fancy shmancy sauces we hear about are to make...bchamel, beurre blanc, and the rest of them. Easy peasy. I love anything with a sauce or gravy on top. This would make a great bridal shower gift, but everyone can use this bc it is so practical for weekday or company meals and desserts.  I even liked that there was a Caesar Salad dressing in here without egg yolks bc my g'daughter is allergic to eggs among other things.  It gives me more options to make healthy alternative meals for her that we all can eat and enjoy.  Nice hardbound book you will be glad you own.

I found Michele Scicolone by a lucky accident, scanning my local newspaper yrs ago, there was a recipe printed from one of her earlier books to make Zeppole.  It is the real deal, I have never seen this recipe in any cookbook anywhere, nor on the many TV cooking shows, EVER.  It's my go to zeppole recipe, easy, fast, and is just like those you get at the pizza places that sell them.  The recipe was so stellar, I bought that book on that one recipe alone; then in that book, I found a Spumoni ice cream, just like the ones of yesteryear I remember as a little girl eating when going out with my parents to Italian restaurants for special occasions.  It is spot on.  You can't get Spumoni today at some of the most authentic Italian restaurants.  Based on that discovery, I bought this book too.  My only real objection to this cookbook is the TITLE.  It is ALL wrong.  It is not just about vegetables, it has chapters on soups, sides, pastas, risottos, etc., SOME of which use veggies, but not all.  I am fearful that most people will never have the pleasure of ever opeing this book bc of the misleading title alone.  Why they chose this title is truly a mystery.My first recipe was the Swiss Chard with Tomato and Garlic, straightforward and simple.  I made a baked slice butternut squash, but it was bland. I had to add a bit of sugar to brighten the taste.  I have a similar recipe that comes from a Lidia Bastianch cookbook that is to die for, so this one didn't measure up.  Then I went into the Dessert Section... the Polenta Berry Cake (no veggies!).  I love polenta and I always have it in my pantry.  It was easy, fast, and a great moist cake to even bring to someone's house.  I know 2 or 3 ways to make polenta, the usual way stirring in a pot, or a slow cooker, or even an oven. But she had a shortcut version of stovetop that saved some time stirring, it worked out very nicely!  I like learning new tricks.  I have other pages tagged, and will report back when I try them, but I had to give a preliminary shout out about this book to hopefully put it on your 'radar,' lest you dismiss it entirely; bc if the title is taken literally, and you like rice, grains, beans, fruits, etc., you might pass it up as 'just vegetables.'

Maybe I need more time to try more recipes, but this book is not a hit yet.  I tried the parsnips roasted, a non recipe recipe really, nothing wow.  I tried the chicken chili and wasn't thrilled.  The measurement of 4 cups of broth was all wrong and I knew it from the start bc I do cook a lot; so I cut back to only 2 cups, and that too was too much liquid. Too soupy and I had to now doctor it up in 5 mins that I had before serving it with a flour/broth slurry, which wasn't thick enough, so it still disappointing. My husband actually dug up a large slotted spoon to serve himself seconds bc it was that watery.  Chili needs to be thick and creamy.  So if you try this recipe, do NOT use 4 cups of broth, hold back to only one cup, if that.  This is not a minor error, it's huge.  I will try a few more recipes and report back and hope I can change my rating upwards.  The Chicken Chili in Ellie Kriegers book WEEKNIGHT WONDERS is great, made it several times, consistency great, and just as fast and easy to make.  I will stick with her recipe for chicken chili.  Her cookbooks stress light healthy eating too.  I hope I find some keepers in Bobby's book though.

absolutely love it.  I do not drink sugary sodas ever, but I tried this and was amazed bc it tasted so Unsweet.  If you love lemon anything, add a star.  My 8 yr old granddaughter loves it too.  She has it on occasion with pizza, and it's a special treat.  She loves lemon too.

I like this item but for one feature. The handle is too short and stubby. It needs to be longer.  When you are using this, the handle is so short, that when you apply the brush to whatever it is you are using it on, you can't see where you are putting the brush bc the handle is so low.  You have to almost tilt your head down and sideways to see UNDERNEATH the applicator. If the handle were a few inches taller, your grasp would allow you to tilt the brush with plenty of angle to see the brush in action.  It is the brush that you are looking at and using and applying, so your view of the brush and the placement of it is what makes this item work or not.  This is an annoying feature of this item...it could have been a home run, but the handle is too short and not user friendly.

Got this book as a gift in fall, and I used it to make peach pops with frozen peaches from our tree last August. It even uses the peel. It was simple but not sweet enough, so I would say, use common sense and taste it to decide if it needs more of 'this or that.' Use the recipes as a guide, and a very easy-to-use and follow guide it is.  I just made Raspberry-Mint pops today and it didn't need any extra sugar; surprisingly, it was sweeter than the peach pops.  WIth mint growing like crazy now in the garden, and the raspberries from our July pickin's last yr, these worked out well...trying to use up what's in the freezer.  Made the Fudge pops and Orange Creamsicles too, very good.  These recipes couldn't be simpler.  Next is the Chocolate-Banana.Other pluses for me are that most recipes are egg-free which I need bc my little granddaughter has allergies, so I am able to make these for all of us to enjoy.  I also appreciate it when recipes are given in a variety of measurements...this one gives grams, ozs, cups, you choose your preferred measurements.  It is SO much easier for me to whip out my digital scale and go by weight, especially with solid, fresh or frozen fruits.  Measuring by weight is so much more accurate and faster than putting berries in a cup and hope you have the right amount. Foolproof.  I give any cookbook HIGH marks if they do that, as it's one of my pet peeves when a book doesn't include all types of measurements to work with.The molds I had held only about 2 oz, good for making trial size pops, but now I find this book so good,  I just ordered the larger set of six 4oz molds. We want to want to make the pops adult size now.  Even though I do make a lot of churned ice creams, this has its place too bc it's faster and easier to throw together on a whim.  The pop molds that you put these concoctions into are small, so don't worry about a few of the recipes that use half n half or heavy cream.  It's barely going to register on the caloric chart.  That is another reason I like these recipes, even the ones with dairy...you can indulge a little without the guilt!  It's portion control this way, you eat far less calorically with a pop than you would of the same ice cream in a tub...we all know how we take extra scoops when we dip into that.So I say, go for it.  This is a good book to start or to add to other books you may have...the recipes are surprisingly easy and, more importantly, are very tasty!

It will do for now.  I go thru oven thermometers like crazy, but then again I spend no more than $7 on each one...I just bought this one, and if nothing else, the numbers are BIG and I appreciate that.  It's totally useless if numbers can't be read even with your glasses on.  When I preheated to 375, I checked it to see it said about 300 or 325 degrees, but it was in the front right of center shelf.  I moved it to the back right of shelf, and after my lasagna was cooking the 30 mins, and I checked the thermometer, it registered 375 for sure.  I know that the moment an oven reaches its desired temp, it still gets hotter as it continues to bake, at the same temp.  WHen I make pizza, I preheat to 550.  WHen the oven signals it's ready, I wait another 20 mins preheating it, bc the oven will be really ready at that temp of 550 by then.  THis tells me that the immediate set temp of an oven is not the same temp it will be 30 mins later, despite the setting staying the same.  I can't fault the oven thermometer for that.  So if this one stays true as it has so far, then maybe my search for oven thermometers is over.  To attach it in oven, place the hook of the thermometer on any rung of any shelf, and pinch it slightly closed with your fingertips to assure it won't slip off.

I use these for herbs yes, but now it also has a new purpose.  By accident, when I was opening a can of Mutti whole peeled tomatoes in a can, I went to grab a regular standard scissor from the drawer to cut them up and snip at them in the can, as I do, to make the tomatoes bite size.  I grabbed these by mistake bc they were in front, and I found they made short work of dicing whole tomatoes in the can.  Now I use them for this purpose all the time.  Just sayin'.  Easier than squeezing them in your hand over a bowl where it squirts left and right all over you and the counter and cabinets.  This does the job and is much neater!

I will agree, this being plastic it does mean breakage can occur over time, I have gone thru 2 and this is my 3rd...but the fact I keep coming back says i'm either crazy or I get something out of it...it is compact and stores it all in one place.  It came boxed unexpectedly in a lovely presentation box, good enough for gifting to a cook in your life.  I already assembled it and put it in my spice cabinet.  The other one I had was usable, so I still have that as backup.  The box says it is assembled in Mexico, but the microplane portion of this set is made in the USA.

Note the title says recipes 'for canning and preserving.'  This means there are not just long-term canning recipes.  Some are refrigerator jams/jellies, maybe more than I expected.  However the canning recipes that ARE in here are very interesting and ample; and I have a lot of pages tagged.  There's one called Honey Lemon Jelly I just made.  Simple and Superb!  Also made Cran-raspberry jam, using up some of last summer's garden's frozen raspberries to make room for the new. Probably one of the BEST jams I have made, not too sweet, beautiful red color.  I am going to try the Lime Mint Jelly and Lemon Marmalade, Raspberry Mint Jam, Watermelon Jelly, Champagne Jelly, etc...then there are savory pickled items.  A candied Jalapeno and Garlic one is calling to me.  There are pics for most recipes too.  I love that the book itself is spiral bound and it lays completely flat on the table, easy to work with.  I will report back as I try more recipes. Many more I want to dig into.

Wow.  Two HUGE bottles of Italian Garlic Extra Virgin Olive Oil, what a bargain for under $33 total.  It arrived well-packed,  crated on top and bottom with protective eggcrate material, like a precious crystal or ceramic item was inside.  I felt I was receiving a gift from me to me.  I would send this to a anyone for a gift in a heartbeat, what a wonderful presentation.  I always used another brand from California that was excellent, but it is no longer available; but that wasn't sold at such a good price as this. This even has a 'best use by' date stamped on bottle; since unlike fine wine, olive oil does not get better with age.  I love that the date is there for me, too.  These bottles have a Best By date of September of 2016.  That's well over a year from now.

I have been canning 1 1/2 yrs so I consider myself a beginner with one foot into intermediate.  I love these recipes both for their simplicity yet for their interesting combo of ingredients.  This explains it all with illustrations to guide the beginner in the craft of canning. Most recipes have photos.  I find it worth saying that when I buy a new canning book, I buy it for the recipes only and skip over the beginning bc I feel I know it already and ho hum.  But this book grabbed me so that I sat with my cup of coffee and read thru the beginning start up pages as if reading a prologue to some new novel.  I can't say anything negative about this book.  If I pushed myself, I'd say it seems more appropriate for the pressure canning recipes to have a section of their own instead of interspersing them in the section with watercanned vegetables...but like I say, I am nitpicking. The pages are laid out beautifully with many color photos of the finished product. There's enough white space so you don't need your Mr/Mrs Magoo eyeglasses to read it.  The headings/titles are big and bold and easy to see so you see at a glance what recipe is below it.  I never make marmalades bc to me right now they are too labor intensive, but this book had a 'strawberry lemon marmalade' which I dove into.  It was easy and a great way for me to test the waters. I made Honey Jelly, it set loose, so I am hoping it gels within a few weeks or else I will have honey syrup.  It didn't use lemon juice and sometimes  I think w/o acid, it does this.  I like also how each recipe states the size and number of jars needed, as many books do...but at the bottom it also mentions other sizes...4oz, 8oz, pints, etc...so you know you can have flexibility in how you portion it out.  As a beginner, I didn't know that and was too afraid to make any moves on my own for safety.  So even this little bit of info is something most books don't do.  So in short, good book and recipes, glad I bought it.

I tried a few brands I could grab of these baby clams.  I notice one brand was from China, another Indonesia, and this one from Thailand.  This was the only one that said "wild caught.'  I don't know if that means the other clams are farm raised?  No clue.  But the more info I have the happier I am.  I would buy this brand again bc of that.  I am making shrimp fra diavola tonight with one pound of jumbo shrimp, with linguine.  Not sure if I should have used more shrimp, so I decided to open a can of these clams and add it to the mix for good measure.  You could use these for baked stuffed clams too...instead of taking large clams and chopping them up, use these whole bc they are tiny, and proceed with recipe...less work.

Bc my young g'daughter has some food allergens to avoid, Bob's Red Mill coarse polenta is not for her, altho' we've used Bob's for years and liked it...but this brand is allergen free, so now we use this.  The label says "fine' cornmeal but quite honestly it is not...it's the same basic texture as Bob's Red Mill coarse polenta, which to me is the only way to go unless you like eating ultrasmooth baby food.  I tried another well known brand of polenta from Argentina that is liked by many, but not by me or my husband.  The babyfood texture was totally uninteresting and we hated it....This brand is now my go to brand.  No need to go for 'instant' polenta either bc this only takes 15 mins on stovetop, not a big time investment. Just know that it sells for $3.99 in supermarkets if you can find it there.  I find it in a specialty Italian market called Uncle Giuseppe's...you have a gauge, going by that, of what's a fair price to pay.  It is less expensive than my previous choice of polenta from Bob's Red Mill bc this package is larger and costs less.  La Grande Ruota is imported from Italy, the source of polenta... how bad can it be?

I never send anything back to Amazon, but this book is an exception.  Not for beginners first of all, not by a longshot.  There is absolutely NO explanation of how to properly can at all, I mean nothing. Each recipe ends with the instruction to "screw the lids on firmly, can the jars (see page 19 and following pages, then store as previously recommended).  On Page 19 there is nothing useful there, no instructions on how to do anything to can your preserves, they are purely encyclopedic-type passages, defining what chutney is, what conserves are, but not how to make them!  I am aghast.  I am canning 1 1/2 yrs now and have a good 8 or so books on canning...and no reputable canning book leaves you to your own devices and guesswork as this one does.  The book appears fabulous with glossy, colorful illustrations, but the love stops there. The recipes list ingredients and measurements and so on, but never tells you how long to process the jars for safety!  This is crucial to know; it is unacceptable to proceed with any shelf canning w/o this knowledge.  Size of jars and the ingredients contained in those jars all determine various safe processing times.  How are we to know this if the recipe doesn't state this?  Dangerous.  Just a BIG opportunity missed.  These 'recipes' make huge portions too, most often eight 8oz jars.  That in itself wouldn't have mattered, recipes can be halved.  But considering you can't approach the recipe w/o the info of how long to cook it, you won't make it anyway, you shouldn't anyway, for safety's sake.  Home Preserving is the title, but don't be fooled.  It is not a 'how to' book.  It's a "how not to" book if you enjoy Russian Roulette games!  The non-Amazon seller where I got this book also charges restocking fees and won't refund your shipping. To make matters worse, you need to spend more money to send it back, and they didn't have the courtesy to send me a prepaid mailing envelope...if not for Amazon's direct intervention to help me out, I would have lost everything.. Without a 'sneak peak' into this book, I couldn't possibly know just how badly these recipes were written.  I ended up wasting my money and my time to remedy the return of this book.  I hope I can help someone else avoid the same fate.

Did my first test drive with this today.  Because of the learning curve, it took me a bit more time and effort to work through the steps properly as expected.  First, i read thru the manual and highlighted items i had questions on and I made a few phone calls to the helpline yesterday  Then I needed to make one more call today before canning, and the woman there called me back with a clarification I needed and that she didn't even know herself.  This is so new we're all learning together.  I believe that those who write 'user manuals' should not be let loose sometimes; bc if you leave certain tidbits out, it creates questions...that being said, here goes:  The advantage to this unit over their autocanner is that it holds large capacity of jars (12) 8 oz jars, (8) pint jars and (7) quart jars.  I have the Ball autocanner too, love that, but that unit holds 6, 4, and 3 jars respectively.  You are more limited in recipes with the autocanner, altho' I have figured out to make almost anything in it, but I digress.  In this watercanner, you can preserve anything at all, without question--home recipes or from whatever canning book you have.  You turn it on and set a timer as usual.  You let it rest 5 mins in the pot as usual.  This also can be used on countertop to free up your rangetop to make potsful of what you're going to fill up the watercanner with.  It should be near a sink so you are not lugging it too far to empty it out with the spigot.  This unit is a multicooker, it steams and you can cook foods/soups in it, etc... This would make a good pot for lobsters or seafood boils.  If you do not care to make larger quantities of preserves, you probably don't need this. I for one didn't NEED this either, but I don't play tennis or golf.  This is MY hobby so I look at it that way.  If you want to do just 3 or 4 jelly jars, or 2 or 3 pint jars in this, you certainly can do fewer jars and not just the entire full capacity. In using this unit for canning, you only use the part of the dial where the green is and ignore anything else.  You basically dial it all the way to the right, point the dial to "canning" to preheat jars (one piece of info the manual left out) and to preserve.  You can also use 4 oz jars and 12 oz jars (the manual didn't mention that either)...so any size jar that fits with space around each one for heat circulation and a 1 to 2 inch water level above it, just like stovetop preserving, is good....you do NOT have to preheat lids or rims (also not mentioned in manual).  I made 6 pints of carrots today, 3 jars with spears, made spicy, and 3 jars of carrot 'coins' with dill seasoning. Each jar sealed and popped almost immediately upon removing them from the pot. You can use your own jar rack in this, but they say it must be set on top of the one included though.  I will do that as mine has circular 'grooves' to hold the bottom of jars more securely in place than the one included.  So basically, today I made 2 small batches, 3 pints each, of 2 different carrot recipes.  I deliberately made the batches small so I could practice twice with it.  You can reuse the water with each new round of canning you do, one after the other; so no need to dump water out and waste it.This sells for $150, but I bought this on sale at Cooking.com at about 15% off, no shipping; so you might want to wait for their sale or for Amazon's price to come down a bit.I will write more as I experiment more.

Spent a few bucks, and it shows...it doesn't work. I bought this to replace another oven thermometer that was discolored and getting hard to read...but... when used alongside this one, it is clear that this one is not accurate.  It is a good 50 degrees off.  I bought this one in January, it is now March and it never really performed well or even gave me a year of use...it is already useless.  Need I say more?

Several yrs ago, before the release of the movie, I rec'd this as a gift from a friend bc she knows how much I love to cook.  I have so many cookbooks, quite honestly, I didn't get to use it until just recently.  I made the white chicken chili and it was great, made it twice so far.  The list of ingredients at first blush look long and unapproachable, but the ingredients are common ones and all were in my pantry.  I made it once with ground pork and then again with ground turkey.  I hopefully will make a few more recipes...yes, the erotica is a bit much, but it's meant as a gag and not to be taken seriously....I think!
Bought this about $20 a set, prices go up and down. Came in a Belleek gift box and tightly wrapped inside with white tissue paper.  Can't beat the value.

I bought this for my gift drawer. It comes in a Belleek gift box.  It is small, but for the price, fair.  It is also well wrapped like a mummy inside with white tissue paper, so I didn't unravel it bc it would then look 'trampled over' if I tried to put the paper back on.  I can't comment on the vase itself for this reason, but I can say it is packed VERY well and should arrive intact!  I
Gave as a gift to my Irish friend who loves Belleek.  I had it shipped directly to her from Amazon. She said it arrived safely and inside a Belleek gift box.  She loves it.

This is a great wok. I don't cook stir fry often, but when I do, I feel like a pro with this.  Nothing sticks, and the size is great for 2 people who load up on lots of veggies in stir fries.  I don't miss a lid, as a lid is needed if steaming is needed, which for me it isn't.  I saw this wok sold last week at Sam'sClub for about $19.99, I almost fell on the floor. I wanted to buy it, but I had to remind myself that I had one already!  Just sayin'!

This is a staple for me.  I have a simple recipe using this ingredient as a rub for steaks, it is out of this world good.  It is mixed with spices such as red and black pepper, brown sugar, garlic powder, etc., fresh chopped garlic, and then made into a thick paste to 'smear' over one side of a steak when grilling or frying.  It adds so much flavor. I mix up a dry batch and always have it in my fridge.  Then when I want to make the paste, I just add some oil to make it like wet sand, and spread it over the beef.  You can use any kind of powdered mushroom, but Porcini is as good as any.

I just made savory crepes using Pasta Flour (3 flour blend) bc this is my pasta substitute; and it worked very well.  Nothing was sticking.  I poured a little extra-light olive oil on a paper towel and swiped the pan before each crepe.  I could have used butter, but since this was for pasta, I used oil.  This pan comes with basic instructions, do not use spray oils, and do not use too-high heat, do not cut inside the pan, all common sense warnings.  I layered wax paper between each cooked crepe, put them in a ziplock bag, and froze them. The pan made a decent-sized 8" crepe, good for stuffing with cheeses or meats for cannelloni.  I used 1/4 cup batter for each crepe.  I like the very low-sloped sides allowing easy maneuverability to get under the crepe to flip it.  I used a medium-high gas flame at first bc I found that browned the crepe adequately.  The first side of crepe you cook about a minute, then the other side 20 seconds or so.. Once you do about 4 crepes, the pan is hot enough to turn down the flame to medium-low.  Tomorrow I am going to try my egg-free chocolate crepe recipe.  I put a sticky-note on the pan when I put it away saying "Use for crepes only!"  I don't want anyone abusing this pan using it for anything other than crepes!

If you are Italian or Italian-American, you will particularly like this book.  It has some of the harder-to-find desserts found in this culture.  It's a hardbound, weighty, and  impressive book.  I bought an extra one to give as a little gift to my friend's daughter on her engagement as she loves to bake, and she is from an Italian family, too.  No ONE cookbook will ever have 100% of recipes we use, that's impossible; but if you find some unique recipes that are harder to find elsewhere, or a basic one with a new twist that becomes a family favorite, then to my mind, it's worth the investment.

What a fantastic book!  I bought this for my DIL for a C'mas gift bc she is the pie maker in the family.  I decided on this one when seeing only ALL 5-star reviews.  One review said there was a pic for each recipe, I liked that a lot, so I dove in and bought it.  As I gingerly leafed thru the pages, I was further enchanted.  I am buying this book for me, myself and I.  Mind you, I am a cook, I prefer savory things to eat and make, I rarely bake or make pies--only on special occasions and major holidays.  I am someone who has dozens of books on bread baking, canning and preserving, Mexican, Italian, Indian cooking, you name it, but not ONE pie book.  However, this pie book made me see religion...you will be converted, too.  I saw a recipe for Old-fashioned Buttermilk Pie in here, I needed to find a way to use my buttermilk in fridge, so I used the recipe in this book (copying the page lest I splash the one I am gifting).  I had another buttermilk pie recipe in one of my dedicated 'buttermilk' books, but I passed that one up for this one.  This one was easier.  It needs no electric mixers.  Mix the ingredients in a bowl by hand, pour into a pie shell (I had a store-bought frozen one), and bake.  So yummy with a dollop of whipped cream.  I am sold!Another thing I was impressed by is that many of the recipes don't need eggs. My little g'daughter is allergic to, among other things, eggs.  There are so many lovely choices w/o eggs, traditional and otherwise. I like the short list of ingredients and process steps, I also appreciate the "white space" around the print making it easier to read w/o a lot of 'clutter.'  And it can't be said enough, every single recipe has a picture with it, to entice you further. There is one disappointment in that the measurements don't use both cups/ozs./grams.  I like to measure flour by weight so it is consistent each time I make it.  So I had to resort to noting it the first time I made it, jot it down on the page, and move on.  Another reason where weight measurements would have helped is the Marshmallow Pie.  It said use 30 large marshmallows.  Ok, I can count to 30.  But I had a partial bag of large marshmallows and a partial bag of small ones...they had to be melted anyway, so I wanted to use both sizes for the pie; and of course, I have no idea how many little marshmallows equal a large one...if the weight were there, I could just dump them all in a bowl and weigh it.  So I will make that pie one day and jot down my weight measurement, assuming it turns out good enough to make again. Despite this one letdown in the book, I love the book.UPDATE--Valentine's Day, 2015.  I made the Cranberry Cherry pie and it is waiting for after dinner.  I will report back then.  It looks good!Dec 4, 2014: CAUTION: ONE CAVEAT...I am baking the Union Pie as I type this. While prepping it, I noticed there is an error in recipe.  The list of ingredients shows 1/2 cup sugar, but the directions never mention this ingredient whatsoever.  So using my limited knowledge, I added the sugar to the 'wet' ingredients and just assumed the proofreading went awry and it was meant to be in the pie.  I hope there are not other snafus in other recipes.Dec 5, 2014: The Union Pie according to my husband was good, but I liked the Old Fashioned Buttermilk Pie better. I would also suggest that the Union pie be done in a tart pan, not a pie pan, bc it didn't fill it up my 9" pie shell adequately from the get go, didn't reach the top of it; and then when it sat to cool, it deflated even further looking sad. More pies to follow, will report back.Dec 22, 2014: Made the savory chicken pot pie, I cheated and used store-bought roll-out pie crust bc the holidays made me pressed on time; but the recipe for the filling I followed and it was good, and the creamy base which is the most important part worked well...I just needed to add more broth than is called for, but that is typical.  Room to tweak it.  I added some poultry seasoning bc I always add that to pot pies.

For about $5, it is acceptable to me...however, I should have paid closer attention to the size of the numbers...my older one had larger numbers making it easier to read.  Since I hang it from the back rung of the oven rack, it sits in the back of oven and I would prefer to just glance to get a readout rather than taking it out and reading it...next time I replace it, I will know better.  Be advised if you need help with vision being at 'that age', go for another brand that has larger numbers...FYI.

What a wonderful find. I bought this on a Spanish food website and the cost of the product with shipping would have been close to $30.  With Prime, this product is much less money.  The expiration date was August of 2016, two years from now, so I decided since it lasts so long, to order another package of 10 at Amazon!  Each packet is sealed and fresh until you open it.  I like it better than buying and using an open bottle of saffron threads.  In addition, I like to share my food finds with family and special friends, and the packets allow me to do that.  This saffron infuses into liquids so quickly, as if it were powder, and gave a deep yellow color to my savory rice cake dish. One packet was plenty for the 1 1/2 cups of rice I cooked in 3 cups of water. Had I known the intensity, I would have used HALF a packet, thereby making this product last even longer!  On the side of the box is a website for exclusive recipes using this saffron.

Great Stocking Stuffers, and since they are not in glass but instead in unbreakable tin cans, easy to wrap and gift and transport.  The taste is good, made in Italy, a 'best use by' date is given too to ensure freshness.  Unlike fine wines, olive oil does NOT improve with age.  So the date stamp is important for me to be there.

This one is great, good price too...organic, made in Italy from Amalfi Coast lemons where they are best known...and the date stamp is on here too...unlike fine wines, olive oils do NOT improve with age...so for me, seeing the "best use by" date or harvest date printed on the bottle is important.  This one is best use by July 2016, two yrs from now.  It will be used much sooner than that!

Bought this on sale at WmsSonoma, it was next to M. Symon's other book, CARNIVORE, which I knew I would not want. I am a meat eater, but I don't want to overindulge in carnivorous meals.  This book was lighter fare, and altho' you will find some recipes using sausage, chorizo, and even bologna, there are other options that are lighter...like steamed mussels in white wine, salmon, shrimp of several varieties, and I like that several of his meals include canned or fresh tomatoes, I always have them handy as I have tomato sauce running thru my veins. There are many colored pics of the recipes.  He uses pork tenderloin a lot, the lean pork. He uses boneless chicken thighs WITH skin, but I always take the skin off, even if "Symon says" to keep the skin on.  His Chicken Milanese is really a Skillet Chicken parm, sounds fast and easy. You can always tweak a recipe to your liking here and there. I never expect a cookbook to satisfy me 100%, that is impossible. I don't get militant if there are some downright unappealing' recipes as deemed by my own personal preferences of course...one woman's unappealing is another's stupendous.  It is in that vein that I try to be accepting of a cookbooks plus and minuses, I embrace the good in it.  It's a hobby to enjoy and not get flustered over.  I think my fave chapter in this book is "Man with a pan" implying simple easy meals, sorry guys... but no matter female or male, they appealed in great part to me too bc the offerings are simple and fast and look very tasty.  I tagged many pages in that chapter alone.  The chapter on desserts is really scaled down to just the 'sauces' that go over vanilla ice cream.  You will not have ice cream recipes in here, only the toppings, and the toppings seem awfully yummy to me...chocolate chili, bananas foster sans rum so the kids can have it too, cherries in sauce, etc., I find them appealing.  So yes the dessert chapter is limiting in the respect that the toppings are the star, not the ice cream, but so be it.  I have my ice cream books, I don't need more from this book.  The toppings are just as interesting and something that expands my dessert repetoire.  So with an open mind I'd say check the book out especially if you get it at a good, low price as I did.I will update when I make some of the recipes I have tagged.  I will probably start with the easiest one, skirt steak with parsley (chimichurri) sauce, bc I have a lot of parsley in garden that needs to be used up.

From my perspective, it seemed that most everything in here you can learn in other regular canning books.  I was looking for the kinds of info that falls off the radar.  I wanted what other books fail to mention, that sort of thing.  I didn't get too much from this book that I already didn't read elsewhere. The format is good for brand new hobbyists to canning I guess as it's in a Q&A format. I just expected more. With that said, I must say I LOVE the author's "Put 'em up, FRUIT!" book.  It is excellent bc it has the unusual as well as the standard fare, and the illustrations are clear and the instructions are easy to understand. I am ordering her earlier "Put 'em Up!" preserving book now, even though it was published earlier.

As a previous reviewer stated, the picture is not accurate. It appears to be a summery metallic pink, but it is a metallic color of a deep purple pink. I bought it in summer to wear in summer so I was not happy to wear it then when I saw how dark the color was, but now that it is fall, it is on my toes and I love it for that. It wears like iron, looks like I just got the pedicure and it was actually 3 weeks ago. For that reason, I am now very happy I bought it...just be aware, the color is DEEP.

Add me to the list of 5-star reviews. Where to begin..  The list of recipes is vast here, and not the same old same old.  Bc I own too many canning books already, I wince each time I am roped into thinking I need another one, and the stellar reviews on this one did just that, gladly so. The only thing not in here are pickling recipes and tomato sauces/salsas.  This does not address pressure canning, just waterbath canning. This is a book that uses 99% fruit as the main ingredient, some recipes use onion, beets, etc., but they are in the minority.This book has the tried-and-true recipes and many novel and innovative ones...there is a chapter of "savory jellies" which use libations such as rum, Campari, wines, tequila, as well as others using teas for instance. There are not pictures galore, but the interesting recipes and ease of making them with few ingredients and easy-to-follow steps make it just fine by me.  Recipes are mostly for half-pint jars, but allowances are given for the smaller, 4 oz ones too, and of course, you can halve many of the larger quantities of recipes if you want less. I find sometimes the lemon juice (acid) added to some jams/jellies is insufficient and comes out softer set than I like. So Ii tend to increase it more myself.  Other than that, it is a great book. I made "Campari with a twist" jam and Strawberry Margarita jam, both came out great using liquid pectin. The Sangria jam also used liquid pectin but it set soft. I don't know if it will firm up as they sometimes say it will, so I will wait a while and if not, that one was not the greatest.  This is one reason I always make a half recipe of a new recipe 'just in case.' There are many watermelon recipes, the plain watermelon jam and the watermelon raspberry jam were great.
