I should have opted for the newer version! Its becoming more and more annoying to add something only to find whoever designed it had a fondness for lighting. This thing goes to the extreme and mine has 7-lights that are on pretty much constantly and one flashes. These lights are annoying and do light up a room. If you place it half way between the router and device perhaps you wont see it but mine is in the same room as the TV so Ill have to add another outlet to get it out of sight. Do we really need lights to tell us a TV or player is off? I just added two surge protectors that have lights to tell me theyre properly grounded and it would be better if it came on when its not grounded. Im guessing my small home now has at least 30 lights that never go off. It works but the lights are drops 2-stars.

I have a 1990 Chevy K2500 pickup and many years ago had a shop replace my muffler and lose the lower half of the rear hanger. I probably could have fabricated something but this was much easier and less expensive elsewhere. This works on trucks that take a muffler that has two 2.25 exhaust holes and a fitting attached to the frame that this will slide into. It doesnt go in the pic shows so flip it over and slide the formed round piece into your frame holder and put the flat piece under your tailpipes with the clamp plate of the U-bolt between it and the pipe on the underside. Really helps to get a better clamp connection because the only other hanger after the muffle is the one in the back where the two tailpipes extend behind the rear wheel. Without this, or a similar clamp, right behind the muffler is sagged and I couldnt get a tight connection.

Ford recommended this type for my 1999 Expedition and at about twelve fifty the price was right. However, there are others that meet the specs and the prices are all over the map plus they come in concentrate or pre-diluted which is what they are now calling the water added 50/50 mix. Once you know what type you need then its pretty much a search for the best price. In doing so, make sure you know whether the price is for the concentrate or the 50/50 mix so youre not comparing apples to oranges. This product is the concentrate and the same brand 50/50 AF2100 is going for about eight fifty a gallon. Since you need one of these to equal two of the 50/50 then this is the better deal. Ive always used Prestone usually the yellow bottle but this is fine for me. I need to change radiator hoses so changing the anti-freeze should be done also along with a new thermostat & gasket. In many cases the concentrate and the 50/50 seem to run about the same price per gallon even though youre getting half as much with the pre-diluted. I need 4-gallons to do a change and this was both what I wanted and at a good price so 5-stars it is since there arent any faults I can find with it. You just have to shop and carefully compare but when youre doing a whole drain/refill. I needed 2-gallons of this for about 25-bucks or 6-gallons of the 50/50 for about 51-bucks so the math made it an easy decision.

Were on the high desert of ID at about 4,700-feet and tomatoes are always a problem with cold, frost and/or winds especially at night and the wee hours of the morning. We were starting everything indoors but that gets to be a problem because once theyre growing we seem more hesitant to move them outside and chance the weather will turn. Forecasts are not all that accurate because they cover such a vast area but the Frost Warnings are usually correct and now we dont have to run out at night to cover them with pots and rocks. We used these for the fist time this year and were able to get plants in the ground in early April and thats 2- months earlier than normal. They warmed nicely during the day and retained enough heat at night to survive through some very cold nights and some high winds. We were eating red tomatoes in July so we just purchased another dozen of these for next year. Normally, a red tomatoes doesnt appear until early September after about a month of watching them go slowly through the orange color stages that seems to last a month. If you like store tomatoes then this may be a waste but if you like those fresh from the garden and have weather that can make it difficult this is the answer. We use them for determinates so they dont outgrown it. Not sure how long theyll last but well try them on green peppers next year before we finally give up on trying.

This was a reluctant purchase because I dislike buying technology that serves a single purpose. I already have a Sony BluRay player but it doesnt have all the things I want to watch specifically Korean shows. I was watching them through a laptop connected to my TV but the quality wasnt great and they buffered & pixilated even though the computer was hard wired to my router. We gave up entirely on Viki because it streamed so poorly and moved on to Drama-Fever which was somewhat of an improvement but not great. Since Drama-Fever streams only Roku we gave it a shot because it was on sale for just under 40-bucks and all I can say is WOW! What a difference in picture quality and having a remote that has some features is a real plus. It was an easy install once I found my routers password. My only complaint is that I had to provide a credit card or PayPal before I could finish setting up the required Roku account. Watching Drama-Fever is now light years better than with the laptop picture fills the screen and sub-titles are even larger plus theres a 7-second rewind now in case we dont catch everything that was said. Havent done much with it so far but so far its great.

This is a trailer towing chain but I used it with a shop crane to swap engines in my 1990 Chevy K2500 pickup and it worked fine for about a 500 lb engine. I'm not sure what its lift capacity is rated at but the minimum break force is 5,000 lbs so at 1/10th of that i thought I was good to go. It was too long so I used a Galvanized Anchor Shackle to shorten it a bit so I didnt have to lift the engine too high to clear the front of the truck. The S-hooks slipped right into the lift hooks that came attached to the engine so I didnt have to buy anything else. I looked for lift chains and some that looked just like this one came up so I went with the lowest price and this was about 7-bucks in June 2013.

I just pulled the 350 5.7L engine from my 1990 Chevy K2500 and replaced it with a 350 from a 1990 Suburban V2500 and they are the exact same blocks. However, the truck has oil cooler lines that run to the radiator and the Suburban engine did not so I had to swap the oil filter adapter over to the replacement engine. Without the oil cooler I would have needed a much larger filter but the fitment guide doesnt seem to factor in that pretty major difference. I did get the right filter for the oil cooler but its much too small to fit the same engine from the Suburban. The old truck engine had some major issues with oil consumption so I went through a lot of oil and changed filters often and went with several of these last year when they were under 5-bucks each and thought the description then stated these had a check valve but I dont see it now. It was a perfect fit and the price was great so no complaints here but I can see now how easy it is to get the wrong filter.

I replaced the muffler and tailpipes a few years ago on my 1990 Chevy K2500 350 pickup with extended cab (141.5 wheelbase) and this was a perfect fit. If youre using a Walker 22719 muffler and have pipes that turn out behind the rear wheel this is the pipe you need. Id suggest using the Walker site to get the correct part number and then shop around for the best price. I had to replace my engine because it was burning oil so I also replaced the crossover pipe, converter and had to add an extension pipe because the new converter was shorter than the one it replaced. All were Walker pipes (or Dynomax which is also Walker) and all fit perfectly. I now have to replace the muffler again because its filled with soot from the oil but I used a compression clamp and it bent the intermediate pipe in the muffler inlet so much I had to cut it off at the muffler and add a short extension so dont use compression clamps if you think youll ever need to get it apart later I went with the stainless lap preformed clamps the go over the pipes like the SmartParts 300300 & 320300 and Ill probably do the same with the 2-1/4 tailpipes.

I replaced the muffler and tailpipes a few years ago on my 1990 Chevy K2500 350 pickup with extended cab (141.5 wheelbase) and this was a perfect fit. As another viewer stated the pic is wrong and this muffler has a 3 inlet with two 2-1/4 outlets and Id also suggest using the Walker site to get the correct part number and then shop around for the best price. I had to replace my engine because it was burning oil so I also replaced the crossover pipe, converter and had to add an extension pipe because the new converter was shorter than the one it replaced. All were Walker pipes (or Dynomax which is also Walker) and all fit perfectly. I now have to replace the muffler again because its filled with soot from the oil but I used a compression clamp and it bent the intermediate pipe in the muffler inlet so much I had to cut it off at the muffler and add a short extension so dont use compression clamps if you think youll ever need to get it apart later I went with the stainless lap preformed clamps the go over the pipes like the SmartParts 300300 & 320300.

I have some large areas to mow that are pretty much an acre of weeds that once was a dumping ground for the former owner and no matter how much I clean it up I still run over stuff on with my lawn tractor and tires go flat. I put tubes in the front but the rear tires are still tubeless so I purchased both the 10056 & 10008 to see if it would help. My neighbor has having a similar problem and swore by this stuff. All four tires now have now been Slimed and no flats in the past few months and Im pretty sure Im still running over stuff and this product is sealing it off as it occurs. My neighbor has also no had a flat. I did use a similar Slime product on a truck tire that was always losing air to the point it needed to be pumped up about every week and after filling it with Slime it never leaked again. This stuff has worked for me and its definitely a lot easier than trying to plug the tires (I have used the Slime plug kit on my truck tire and it has held up well) or pulling those front wheels off the tractor to patch a tube. I pumped some of this into my wheelbarrows and so far theyre retaining air much better than before I did so. For the price and ease of use this will always be my first choice. However, you do need to remove the valve stem before you put this stuff into the tire/tube.

Im swapping engines on my 1990 Chevy K2500 350 5.7L and needed to replace the exhaust from the engine to the muffler the rest was replaced not too long ago. I was hoping that it would be an easy 3 ID into a 3 OD and I was wrong. The Walker 15034 converter I was installing had a 3 ID on both ends which was fine for the exhaust pipe from the manifold but that left me with my Dynomax 42606 connector pipe slipping into the converter rather than the other way around the connector pipe was needed to make up the difference with the shorter length of the converter to what was there previously. I tried SmartParts 300300 3" lap joint on the Walker exhaust side but the pipe was thick and it wouldnt work get a tight fit so I cut a 5-inch length of pipe to slip in as a nipple; added some Permatex 80335 Sealer; butted the pipes together; and then installed the clamp again and all is good. I had to cut four slits into the converter and use a compression clamp on the engine side. I used the SmartParts 320300 3" lap joint but on the extension pipe to the muffler and that was easy. My first time using this type of clamp and it was a mistake not trying them earlier. I couldnt get the old converter off the Walker 44461 Extension Pipe so I ended up have to cut it and it was buggered that I ended up replacing it because I couldnt get a new pipe far enough into it to prevent it from leaking the old clamp had made an indentation on the top that prevented the pipe from going all the way. Good news is if I ever need to pull it apart connectors that dont distort the pipes will make it easy. Since this was all one pain in the butt project the review is for everything I used. Everything was a quality product I have to go with 5-stars for them all. However, not all clamps fit 3 ID pipe like that on my converter, especially those from SmartParts, but the Dynomax 35794 3 clamps were a perfect fit. I cut slits in the pipe to get a better compression but a little torque would have worked but might have made the pipe bend and be difficult to impossible to get off if ever needed. Welding just wasnt an option for me.

The Walker 15034 converter I was installing had a 3 ID on both ends which was fine for the exhaust pipe from the manifold but that left me with my Dynomax 42606 connector pipe slipping into the converter rather than the other way around the connector pipe was needed to make up the difference with the shorter length of the converter to what was there previously. I tried SmartParts 300300 3" lap joint on the Walker exhaust side but the pipe was thick and it wouldnt work get a tight fit so I cut a 5-inch length of pipe to slip in as a nipple; added some Permatex 80335 Sealer; butted the pipes together; and then installed the clamp again and all is good. I had to cut four slits into the converter and use a compression clamp on the engine side. I used the SmartParts 320300 3" lap joint but on the extension pipe to the muffler and that was easy. My first time using this type of clamp and it was a mistake not trying them earlier. I couldnt get the old converter off the Walker 44461 Extension Pipe so I ended up have to cut it and it was buggered that I ended up replacing it because I couldnt get a new pipe far enough into it to prevent it from leaking the old clamp had made an indentation on the top that prevented the pipe from going all the way. Good news is if I ever need to pull it apart connectors that dont distort the pipes will make it easy. Since this was all one pain in the butt project the review is for everything I used. Everything was a quality product I have to go with 5-stars for them all. However, not all clamps fit 3 ID pipe like that on my converter, especially those from SmartParts, but the Dynomax 35794 3 clamps were a perfect fit. I cut slits in the pipe to get a better compression but a little torque would have worked but might have made the pipe bend and be difficult to impossible to get off if ever needed. Welding just wasnt an option for me.

Im swapping engines on my 1990 Chevy K2500 350 5.7L and needed to replace the exhaust from the engine to the muffler the rest was replaced not too long ago. The Walker 15034 converter I was installing was shorter than the one that was being replaced so I try adding a Dynomax 41976 connector pipe to make up the difference but I didnt factor in enough for what slipped into the pipes and I was a few inches short so I cut a piece from another 41976 to make up the shortage. That ended up being a little sloppy, had some leakage and then I did it right by using this pipe and cutting it to the exact length needed. Im in a very rural area so most repairs get done in my driveway and it costs a lot less than going to a shop 40-miles away so as a do-it-yourselfer I have never had a complaint with any Walker/Dynomax item Ive used and I have replaced everything on my 1990 Chevy K2500 truck from the engine all the way to the back. I use the Walker site to make sure I get the correct part number because this site often shows the correct item as not fitting my vehicle but the prices here have ranged from good to excellent and a connector pipe I just purchased was about one-third the cost from the auto parts store.

License plates here in Idaho have a mountain scene and a potato but a cracked windshield would be much more representative. I only drive on paved roads and in the last few trips I picked up 3 bulls-eye chips and a few minor chips and this kit did them all. The last kit I used was the Stoner 95141 and that was just enough for one large chip. Last year I went to a glass shop and had one repaired and it was no better than the results I got from  the Rain-X. Ive probably done about two dozen chips in the last 8-years and I have yet to get a repair anywhere near what many reviewers claim to have achieved and that is a repair that is so good that you cant detect it without knowing where I was beforehand. I know Im doing it correctly but if you want to believe your repair will be virtually invisible you may be open to disappointment. Im happy that this stuff stops the chip from becoming a running crack and my windshield doesnt look like every fifth vehicle I see on the road. This kit is about as goof-proof as they come and even after the first application you can still add a few drops more, put the plastic on it and let it cure and keep doing so until the repair is complete. Since I never expected an invisible repair I went with 5-stars primarily because I had not complaints with it but also because I did five repairs on the same windshield with it and I just purchased another kit for the next round of repairs on my truck because you really need to get something into these holes before a crack starts and you need to replace the whole windshield.

At around 20-bucks you cant go wrong with this handy little sucker. We have cats and lots of tiled floors and the vacuum we used for the carpet wasnt doing much on the lowest settings for those floors. This one is lightweight and rally picks up everything easily especially those little cat hairs that always seem to be falling out. cant find a negative with it and for the price I have no complaints. When you see thousands of reviews for an item its pretty much a safe bet to make a purchase.

I suspect your exhaust system will rust and wear out long before this donut will fail. Not much you can say about it other than it works as intended and it gives a little flexibility to your exhaust pipe to move around slightly with a spring bolt kit. If you bolted your pipe to the manifold without it youll have a leak and the flared end on the pipe couldnt move on the rounded surface of the donut and would likely break. If there are any rough spots on the side toward the pipe they should be smoothed out before installation. Prices vary and thats why I didnt purchase the two I needed for my 1990 Chevy K2500 here.

I received both the SAE & Metric sets a few days and since Im putting a new engine in my 1990 Chevy K2500 I thought Id give it a try. I used both the 9/16 & 13mm to get at the manifold spring bolts when installing the crossover pipe. I wasnt having any luck with a socket & flex joint so I was down to a bent wrench but these made it a breeze with a long extension rod. The fit was good at both ends and the finish seems good and easy to clean. Good thing theres a Lifetime Replacement on them because it may take a lifetime before I use them all. No complaints other than theyre made in Taiwan and its hard to believe Ive been working on my vehicles, lawn equipment, tractor, trailers and others for over 50-years and never purchased a single crowfoot wrench.

I received both the SAE & Metric sets a few days and since Im putting a new engine in my 1990 Chevy K2500 I thought Id give it a try. We do a lot of cutting on our acre and though this received some negative reviews I gave it a shot anyway, no disappointments here and it cuts grass nicely and we have rye grass thats more like a thick weed and it handles that nicely. If it starts failing Ill update the review but for now I have no complaints with it and running a stone over the cutting edges has kept it pretty sharp and doing its job. Fiskars has been our first choice in cutters and we have about 8 of their products from a small pruning shears to a huge bypass lopper and all have performed well for years.

I was swapping engines on my 1990 Chevy K2500 truck and getting the old pump off the engine was a pain that required a special tool to pull off the pressure fitted pulley to get to the bolts that held it in the frame. After that little ordeal it seemed foolish to put that old pump back in so I replaced it. The quart I purchased was just under 5-bucks and the same price as the closet auto parts store that is 40-miles away. It wasnt enough to top off the new pump & hoses but when I can back for another quart the price was over 6-bucks in just a few days. I did get another quart in town at the lower price and everything seems fine with the pump and steering.

I read a lot of reviews and checked a lot of mattresses and came to the conclusion the problems with waking to a sore back and knee pain was the box spring. In checking out possible alternatives to a new box spring I found that most countries European ones in particular either use a metal frame or just put the mattress on the floor. Not wanting to pay big bucks for another box spring I gave this a shot and no regrets whatsoever so far. It went together easily, is about the same height as my bed was with a box spring and looks good with the skirt around it. Ive had back issues for over 25-years and buying a new bed in the limited marketplace out here was not in the cards. I sleep comfortably, wake up without pain and weight is evenly distributed. What people choose to sleep on and how they rate those choices is very subjective but in our throwaway society I really didnt want to pay the price and out here mattresses & box springs are made locally and they just slap on the brand nametag so theres never a truck rolling into the sleep stores from the manufacturer. When its time to replace the mattress Ill likely buy one though Amazon comes compressed for shipping. I have no complaints with this other than the packing was pretty flimsy for a large heavy item but it arrived alive.

First, youll probably only get one hole with this unlike the Rain-X 600001 (which I just purchased to finish do my other bulls eye and will let you fill more than one ding). I found this to be a bit messy, hard to align right over the ding and though it didnt mask the ding much it did prevent it from getting a running crack. Perhaps some user error was involved but the rain-X is a much better system in my opinion.

Im swapping engines on my 1990 Chevy K2500 350 5.7L and I got the old engine out with a 1-ton engine hoist set all the way out at the 1/4 ton setting. However, going back in was a whole different story. Since I latterly pulled the old one out I didnt have enough reach with the boom to get the new engine over the motor mounts I was about 10-inches short. I purchased the lift based on the measurements but they were a bit deceiving on the reach because of the way the hook was attached and the pump hit my bumper both of which cut the reach down by about 5-inches. The boom on the lift is just like a 2-inch receiver so I removed the hook form the lift, slid this in, clamped it in place with a safety chain and installed the hook in the end with the hitch pin. For about 20-bucks this solved my problem and the engine went in easily though I was probably pushing the weight limit with my DIY extension. I did get the engine safely in the vehicle before I made my modification and then lifted it again to get it back where it should go. This was the alternative to about 250-bucks for a 1-time use of a 2-ton lift.

I don't really think that the Protected & Grounded lights need to be on constantly and a simple test button could eliminate it. I do have a peeve with things that need a constant light to tell me they're working or that they're on or off. I purchased this for my microwave because we're in a rural area and have some blips in the power that are so short the only way you know it happened is because a few clocks need to be reset. The last time it occurred when lost the use of a few buttons on the microwave keypad so a few bucks invested in this will hopefully eliminate that problem. It's really just a piece-of-mind item and I'll likely never know if it worked but I knocked off a star for the lights that will never go off if your outlet is properly installed. Before plugging any grounded cord into an outlet I always check it with my Receptacle Tester Klein Tools RT100 Receptacle Tester and I highly recommend this little tool because if your ground is not correct you could loose some expensive electronics.

Update I did respond to Tektons Comment and they sent me another tool.There was an improvement in the replacement bar but it seems they are designed that way and that could be a plus if the pin shears and it would be an easy repair. Perhaps I was too demanding of a tool in this price range but I can see how many may think its a good addition to the tool chest and that could make it an easy 4-5 star breaker bar. However, I said 3-star for the purpose I was using it and that was freeing some 25-year old engine bolts with a little leverage and some penetrating oil but it wouldnt work in a tight spot. The size, price, fit & finish should be enough to satisfy most but if youre really looking to get into some tight areas where you just need a few inches of full you may be slightly disappointed. I purchased a vintage bar with a fixed pin and it did the job for me but I wont hesitate to grab my Tekton replacement when I have a little more maneuvering room. Since this is a product review Ill just say I was not disappointed with the warranty and service. Check the top review for the TEKTON 1695 (Nice, but not a precision tool) to get another perspective on the same issue I had with it.Im swapping engines on my 1990 Chevy K2500 350 5.7L and my Craftsman 1/2" bar was a little too long at 18 to get into some tight spots. First use was with a Tekton 3/8-drive 13mm deep socket to remove a stubborn bolt on my water inlet to the engine. I went with this bar based on price & reviews but the knuckle seemed too loose and it transferred about 3-inches of play out to the end of the handle I could wobble it back & forth a bit with just my fingers so it was visibly loose. Tightening the set screw wouldnt compensate at all for the space on either side of the knuckle it needs to have the prongs pressed closer together. The 3/8-socket fit was tight so theres no play there and with an adapter to use the Craftsman theres so little play its not even noticeable even with the added length. The purpose of a breaker bar, for me anyway, is to be able to slip into a tight space like where the bell housing bolts up with the upper rear of the engine but having 3-inches of play defeats the purpose and now Im back a wrench with a short cheater. Not to be too picky here but the body of this bar is only 11-3/8 you only get the full 12 when the head is straight out at the 180-degree position. Also, theres only 1-detent and thats also with the head straight out and its made in China. Perhaps its just one that slipped by quality control but when you start laying into a breaker bar the last thing you need is a poor fit right where all that force is being transferred to the socket head. I had one with a similar problem a few years ago and when exerting some force on it the pin broke because the head was pushing on it rather then the inside edge of the fork. On the plus side, its a good looking tool with a nice finish and good feel in the hand. Im usually pretty lenient on ratings but I have to go with 1-star on this one because it not only is too loose but Id say its dangerous to use it since the intended use is with a lot of pressure applied and Ive already lost enough meat on these old knuckles over the past 50-years. Using a breaker bar is an effective way to gain more torque at the head with the same amount of force by increasing the handle length and removing the possible slippage from the teeth in a ratchet. The same can be achieved by using a wrench with a cheater pipe over the end. A solid pin is going to give more shear resistance than on that is threaded, hence the different selection for different applications. The weak point is still the transition between the head and the square dive stud.

I tried the Victor Reinz GS33272 first, which is similar to the Fel-Pro ES72671 set, but theyre the wrong ones. Im swapping engines on my 1990 Chevy K2500 with a 350 (5.7L) engine and finding the correct gaskets wasnt all that easy. I thought this was a perfect fit and well worth the price to get the correct gaskets but after a few months I had to pull the cooler adapter to swap it to the new engine. Its really hard to get to the engine mounting plate to remove the old gasket but if you dont do it correctly this will leak. When I pulled it the fiber gasket was split and falling apart. When I removed it the first time to install this set there was a metal plate about twice the thickness of these gaskets so I figured the Reinz kit was an improvement and installed it. What I just realized is this is not the correct set of gaskets but the ACDelco and/or GM OEM 88893990 is the correct part. Not only does it come with the same type of metal plate that was originally installed it has an O-ring thats about twice the diameter as the one in the GS33272 kit. The metal plate looks pretty much like the fiber gasket but it really isnt intended to be a gasket but rather a diverter that oil will slash against to fill a small reservoir that has the connectors to the radiator so the splashing was what shredded the fiber gasket and that prevented oil from circulating to the radiator which made the whole unit non-functioning after a few weeks.  With the GM kit you get only the two items you need and the job gets done correctly. The Fel-Pro gets 3-stars because it was the wrong kit and the fitment guide was also wrong and the GM gets 5-stars because its OEM and is the correct kit. If you have a small block GM engine the GM kit is likely the one that you need.

With the help of Terro I have created a large population of addicted ants and I doubt that anything has ever been carried back to the nest and killed the queen. We have a lot of ants sugar ants here in high desert and as soon as it gets hot they are everywhere and its not unique to our home. They are pretty much outdoor problems until the hot weather hits like now and they are also a problem with trees and aphids. Weve tried to keep them away from the house with many products to no long term avail. Weve been on Terro for about 2-years now and as long as the baits are filled in the kitchen and near the pet dishes were pretty much ant free. However, if a plastic container goes dry all that changes and theyre in and its back to spraying, wiping and sucking them up with a vacuum. Last night, a station went dry and in only a few hours there were hundreds of ants in the pet food dish. We have the plastic stations and now refill them with either the 1 or 2 ounce bottles. The 1-ounce bottle has a large piece on the top which makes squirting it into the plastic tray difficult but the 2-ounce has a much smaller one and its very easy to refill. After watching these ants parade for months to and from the stations I cant believe for a minute nothing has made it back to a nest, killed a queen and eliminated the problem. Not only do the ants never really stop eating this stuff it now seems to be evaporating faster than the products we purchased last year. I feel that I now have armies of crack head ants that when they are denied Terro will attack whatever food source they can find in very short order to get my attention and refill the stations. Believe what you want about the product claims and other reviews but I cant believe these tiny ants can consume a full station in about a week and appear to suffer no ill effects. I will be trying less expensive alternatives and making my own ant crack rather than spending about 5-bucks for a few weeks of ant chow. I went with 3-stars because it will keep ants out of my kitchen, food storage areas and pet food dishes if I keep the stations filled but killing off a nest is impossible to believe unless its quickly being replaced by ants from another nest. I have about 4 stations in the kitchen and room with the pet food dishes. Obviously, results may vary but Im just commenting on my particular impressions and perhaps others are seeing better results but Ill have ants from May until it gets cold in October. I have used the outside baits to keep the ants off the trees but it never removes/eliminates the population. We now have a lot of frogs that have spawned in our irrigation canal and they are doing a great job on making a lot of these ants disappear permanently and its free!

Im swapping engines on my 1990 Chevy 350 5.7L K2500 and needed this tool because the Chilton manual was wrong. All the pulleys, with the exception of the power steering, are held on with a bolt but someone at GM thought it was a better move to have one pulley pressed on so you need to buy a special tool to get it off. I thought it would be like the AC where you just pull a few bolts and move it to the side but theres no way thats going to happen because one of the block bolts for the frame is behind the pump. Anyway, I didnt buy this one but its identical in looks, case and number of parts to the one from HF (40749 for about 18 bucks) so all 3 kits may be from the same Chinese factory. I went cheap because I hate spending money on a tool I will likely never use again. As with most cheap tools the bolts are of a soft metal and dont take a lot of torque in stride like a hardened bolt. Leaning over the front end to use this tool isnt easy and even with the radiator and upper shroud removed its still difficult. I tried to minimize the amount of pressure applied by using some penetrating oil and I used Blaster. The pulley came off but I realized afterwards I used a wrong part in the removal process and it made it more difficult because the part I used was stuck in both the pulley and the jackshaft but absent decent instructions how would I know? There are some smooth shafts with an O-ring on one end and they are used for the removal process with the O-ring side slipping into the pulley (though the stubby one needs the O-ring in the jackshaft) to hold the stem in place just pick the correct length for your application. The threaded stems are only used for pressing the pulley back on once again the length is determined by your application and thats also where the bearing roller is used. Also, the collar is reversible with the flange on one side a little larger than the other so use the sides that fit the tightest on your pulley. When pulling it off the nut that slips into the clam shell will be at the bottom of the threads and for pressing it back on you start with it at the top end since youll be turning it toward the pump. You have to make sure you use the shaft in the pulley that leaves the most room in the bolt that threads over it or itll bottom out and youll likely break it off. I consider myself of average strength for a 63 220 lb guy and there was no way my pulley was coming off without a long 1/2" breaker bar attached to a socket and if your radiator is still in then youre looking at a pretty difficult process. I suspect that I could have broken something without first using Blaster on both sides considering the amount of pressure I had on it with that 24 breaker bar. Its 5-stars for me because even though I used a threaded shaft instead of a smooth one the pulley came off and it did press it back onto my new pump. I would guess that breaking something in this set may be because the right combination of parts wasnt used like I did. You can buy more expensive sets or a separate tool to remove and another to install but for the few bucks I paid for this one it was worth it and if someone tells you dont need a special tool for a pressed on pulley dont believe it.

Im in a very rural area so fixing a flat in the tread without removing the tire and running 12-miles to the closets garage was my goal. I have some big rigs with 10-ply tires and this kit made quick work out of a screw hole from one I dropped in my stone driveway on my Chevy K2500 pickup  I also have purchased a magnet to check for more before my tire finds it. Ive used the Slime liquid for years to keep my tires inflated but recently replaced a few tires so Ill also purchased more of it. I had a leaking sidewall that the Slime liquid fixed for years and I gave that 5-stars. This kit has everything needed and the T-handles are much better than the straight handles on a Victor set that I tried but couldnt get the plug in for lack of good leverage. This kit is 5-stars but it loses one from me because once you open the package theres no way to close it and keep the parts together so it ended up in a bag. Ill be buying another one for my Expedition. Not to insult anyones intelligence but if you want to use this on the road youll likely need a compressor but if you catch it quickly like I did you can get the tools out, pull whatever is in the hole, ream it out and leave the reamer in you stop the air, load up the other tool, add some glue to it, pull out the reamer and quickly insert the plug and you wont lose much air and should be good for a slow drive to an air pump.

I just finished replacing the pins & rollers on both doors of my 1990 Chevy K2500 pickup and, once I figured it out, I did the second door in about an hour. I have electric windows/locks and didn't want to undo the connections to remove the doors so I used my engine hoist with some tie down straps as a sling and it worked fine and I could do the work without help. There are other ways to support your door when you remove the pins and I was going to just throw the straps up and over a garage rafter but the hoist worked and gave me a little more control of the door. I watched some You Tube and read some reviews first but most didn't help. One video said you can do it without removing the door and one reviewer stated you need to press the roller pin in... both were wrong. The Dorman pin Dorman 38433 Door Roller Pin has a knurled end that is much too large for the hole so it could never be pressed in: hammering it home will only destroy the roller and it still is too large for the hole; and drilling out the hole on a welded hinge doesn't make sense so it had to be ground down to get a proper fit so it gets 4-stars for being too large. I used a bench grinder but anything would work that's stable so you can turn the roller to get an even reduction in size. I popped the door spring with a screwdriver but the spring compressor made putting it back in a breeze and it gets 5-stars... pay a few bucks for it and you won't regret it. I purchased a set hinge pins on the auction site under 7-bucks and it was for both doors (4 pins, 8 bushings & 2 retainers) and a perfect fit... not sure why so many sites sell pins separately when you should be replacing both. However, the bushings fit in the hinge frame from the inside so if you don't pull the pin and separate the hinge halves you'll never get the old ones out... let alone the news in so that pretty much means the door is separated from the truck but really doesn't come off if you're splitting semantics. Just pulling the door a few inches away from the truck gave me enough room to do some hammering and get the old parts out and there's enough electrical cable in there if you loosen the boot to move it at least 6-inches. If you use a jack stand you could probably do one hinge at a time but it's a little cramped and alignment would require some help with the door. A 12-inch drift punch would have helped but I used a 1/4" socket extension to drive the pins out. The roller was original and is stamped into place so a cold chisel to the top took it off quickly and the pin fell right out... remove the spring first. The pin set was great but the retainers were poor so I used the old ones and they are holding tight... just slip a socket over it and tap it into place. Considering the prices GM wanted for OEM parts I can live with the few issues I had with the aftermarket parts. Having parts left is usually not good but my doors didn't require bushings on the bottom pins... pins holes were smaller so they were snug and were replacing the original pins so not having bushings was by design.

I just finished replacing the pins & rollers on both doors of my 1990 Chevy K2500 pickup and, once I figured it out, I did the second door in about an hour. I have electric windows/locks and didn't want to undo the connections to remove the doors so I used my engine hoist with some tie down straps as a sling and it worked fine and I could do the work without help. There are other ways to support your door when you remove the pins and I was going to just throw the straps up and over a garage rafter but the hoist worked and gave me a little more control of the door. I watched some You Tube and read some reviews first but most didn't help. One video said you can do it without removing the door and one reviewer stated you need to press the roller pin in... both were wrong. The Dorman pin has a knurled end that is much too large for the hole so it could never be pressed in: hammering it home will only destroy the roller and it still is too large for the hole; and drilling out the hole on a welded hinge doesn't make sense so it had to be ground down to get a proper fit so it gets 4-stars for being too large. I used a bench grinder but anything would work that's stable so you can turn the roller to get an even reduction in size. However, the bushings fit in the hinge frame from the inside so if you don't pull the pin and separate the hinge halves you'll never get the old ones out... let alone the news in so that pretty much means the door is separated from the truck but really doesn't come off if you're splitting semantics. Just pulling the door a few inches away from the truck gave me enough room to do some hammering and get the old parts out and there's enough electrical cable in there if you loosen the boot to move it at least 6-inches. If you use a jack stand you could probably do one hinge at a time but it's a little cramped and alignment would require some help with the door. A 12-inch drift punch would have helped but I used a 1/4" socket extension to drive the pins out. The roller was original and is stamped into place so a cold chisel to the top took it off quickly and the pin fell right out... remove the spring first. The pin set was great but the retainers were poor so I used the old ones and they are holding tight... just slip a socket over it and tap it into place. Considering the prices GM wanted for OEM parts I can live with the few issues I had with the aftermarket parts. Not much I can saw to knock such an inexpensive watch except for the band. Im about a 63 male with a wrist thats about 7.5 and Im near the end of the holes on the band. There are 11 holes and Im at number 9 and on a hot day its number 10 so that leaves almost no band to slip into the little holder so theres a stub constantly hanging out. The watch is good, doesnt seem to be losing any time, the white face makes telling time easy and its a decent work watch because, at this price, I dont care what happens to it. I had the same band on a Casio digital and it didnt last long I end up adding a clip to the watch and used it as a fob. Watch gets 5-stars but minus one for the band.

I purchased these for my John Deere STX-38 and they look & feel about like the original tires that were on it. When I purchased them the title stated they were Oregon 70-316 but that didnt appear either on the tire or the package. The tires I received (2 purchased) are clearly marked Carlisle Turf Saver 2-Ply which was also in the title. I have purchased a lot of Oregon items (chain saw blades, inner tubes, wheelbarrow tires and more) and this is the first time Ive received something that didnt bear their name but I only mention that for those who may be expecting to receive something with their name on it. At a little more than 19-bucks each this was a deal and about half of what everyone other than Amazon wanted for just one. My old tires were lean on tread and mowing a few acres of fields was leading to flats from items long buried by the former owner. Im putting tubes in them because our hot days and cold summer nights leads to air loss not matter what I do and Im adding Slime Tube to them to avoid the further pain of trying to remove these to patch it. Anyway, nice tires but if I wasnt adding a tube Id probably opt for a 4-ply for my rough mowing terrain. If I was just mowing grass in a yard these would be fine going tubeless and they get 5-stars because I dont care about the absent Oregon name.

I purchased this to burn off weeds and the hordes of sugar ants that invade us each summer and it does the job, it's easy to light and the canisters make it lightweight and easy to handle. I just lift a rock and torch the ants,,, because it's a lot cheaper than Terro. I also purchased the attachment to refill my canisters from a 20-pound tank and that was a real help... be sure to chill your canisters to make the refill process easy and complete. However, my weed issue is now so large that I'm going with one of the big boys Red Dragon VT 2-23 C Weed Dragon 100,000-BTU Propane Vapor Torch Kit connected to a 20-pound tank but will still use this for lighting my burn piles and burning off my irrigation canals every spring. I'm sure Bernzomatic has another one similar to this one and I only paid about 30-bucks for mine and it was well worth it... years later even the igniter is still working. I even bent the tube on it when my overhead garage door nailed it in the rafters and it was easily bent back into shape without a crease. No problems or issues with it worth noting.

Were trying to reclaim an acre from wild rye grass and about 20 types of weeds that blow in on the winds. The only successful way weve found is to plant fruit bearing bushes & trees and lots of clover. Unfortunately, the rye can grow so quickly when were irrigating that its often hiding things we dont want to cut and many of the bushes start out as sticks so they get lost quickly. We tried little fences but they were also lost quickly or also mowed over. We had some utility work done and the phone company marked their lines with neat little orange flags on metal sticks so we put a few near what we planted and nothing was mowed over. We purchased these and now everything is marked even starter plants in the big gardens and they are working perfectly. The rye grass the country version can grow to 6-10 inches in about a week when its in an area getting watered and it will quickly hide things that grow close to the ground so for a few bucks these flags were well worth it even though our acre looks like a construction zone.

I have a single cable running from my router to the TV room and my Sony Blu-ray is connected to it. I wanted to add my laptop because we stream from Viki and that's not on the Sony unit and only use 1-device at a time. I tried an "Ethernet Splitter" RJ45 CAT 5 6 LAN Ethernet Splitter Connector Adapter PC but the description doesn't explain it fully enough and it didn't do what was expected. The splitter neither split nor allowed a shared connection. They allow you to run a second line over the same cable if you connect two lines to the router by using a connector at each end which allows you to use all 8-wires in a cable rather than the 4 normally used and it took a few You Tube videos to figure that out. Since I didn't have an extra port on the router I tried this device and it's perfect for what I needed. Just push a button and your signal goes to another device exactly like it should. Wish I had purchased this item first.

I have a single cable running from my router to the TV room and my Sony Blu-ray is connected to it. I wanted to add my laptop because we stream from Viki and that's not on the Sony unit and only use 1-device at a time. I tried an "Ethernet Splitter" but the description doesn't explain it fully enough and it didn't do what was expected. The splitter neither split nor allowed a shared connection. They allow you to run a second line over the same cable if you connect two lines to the router by using a connector at each end which allows you to use all 8-wires in a cable rather than the 4 normally used and it took a few You Tube videos to figure that out. Since I didn't have an extra port on the router I purchased a switch MT-VIKI 2 Ports Network Switch Splitter Selector Hub 2-In 1-Out or 1-In 2-Out 100M MT-RJ45-2M and it's perfect for what I needed. Just push a button and your signal goes to another device exactly like it should. Wish I had purchased the switch first because one of these will do nothing for you... you need two and two router ports and if you have that this is likely a 5-star item but the description is very misleading.

I have one key and just needed a backup so I purchased a single AM131841 on another site. It was a perfect fit for my STX38 rifding mower and it was just like the one pictured here rubber coated with the Deere logo on it. If you need two then this isnt a bad price because I paid about 5-buck for one. it gets 5-stars because it works, it looks like my OEM and its a genuine replacement.

I was worried about the size of this brush when I ordered it, but the price of the bigger brushes was a lot more than I wanted to pay without knowing that I would love it.When I got it, I was pleased to find that the brush is  a fair size.  It is 3 fingers wide and the brushing surface is the diagonal length of my hand.  Sure it is smaller than some of the paddle brushes I own, but I don't find the size inhibits the brush in any way.The bristles are nice and firm.  The biggest problem that I often have is that natural bristles often bend too easily to be of any real use in my hair.  The bristles on this brush are nice and firm... I love it!Super glad I got this brush.  If I had known I was going to love it, I may have gone for the handy size, but I still don't think I can justify the expense of the largest sizes.

Ok... yes, it smells... henna smells!  It doesn't smell great - it smells like stale tobacco and hay if you ask me.  All henna smells, there is really no getting around that!  So now that we have gotten past that truth, lets get to reviewing!I like this color.  It is just henna and hibiscus (which intensifies the red), so if you are dying from color treated hair (not bleached) or want to go back to color treating, it shouldn't kill your hair (*I am not a hair expert).  I had chemically dyed my hair in the last month, but I am not satisified with the speed that chemical red dyes bleed out of my hair.  I decided that I want to start using henna since it is more permanent and gentler on the hair.Applying is messy (just like with all hennas).  I got my henna mixed to a thick consistency about like brownie mix - kind of like a clay.  It spread well, kept moisture in while the dyes set, and it didn't run.  It could have made the rinsing a little more difficult, but I am jazzed about the results.  I left it on for the recommended 3 hours (I know some people leave it on 6-8 hours or overnight but I wanted to go by the package directions and see where that gets me).  The color is fantastic - it tinted my hair a nice deep red.  No orange tinge to this henna application!  It was exactly what I was going for.Update:  Still using this henna and still loving the results.  The biggest problem I have is thst the color doesnt relly fade on otherwise virgin hair, so my roots are very noticeable and I need to stay on top of it more than I did with chemicals.I still have a lot of bleeding but have some thoughts on that.  A bit more than half my length is previously color treated, which damages the hair cuticle, so that  could certainly be contributing to the bleeding.  Furthermore, the previously dyed length is where I have noticed fading after 3-4 weeks.I have found that reducing the time I leave the dye in my hair reduces bleeding.  Leaving it on the recommended 2-3 hours gives me the same color with less bleesing than j get with 6-8 hour processing times.Also, I have also found that doing an apple cider vinegar rinse after your first shampoo really helps to close the cuticles and stop the bleeding!

I like Clarks shoes.  They are built to be comfortable for a day on your feet - after you have broken them in!  I got these shoes to replace my year old shoes that I have beaten up pretty well.  The old shoes are super comfortable, and while they show wear and tear, they are still usable, but for work, I decided to get a new pair - you know, professionalism or something...  I did make the mistake of wearing these shoes for a busy day on my feet right after I got them, but after that mistake, these shoes are nicely broken in and providing the expected comfort and support that I am used to.  The only bad thing about these shoes is that they do have steel shanks (which make the shoes comfortable) and if you use TSA pre-check, you will need to take these off.

I love this coloring book.  The pictures are great and have tons of intricate detail for your coloring pleasure.  I use this with my collection of Steadtler Triplus Markers and Fineliners.  I have had no issues with bleed through.  I will need to break down the binding a bit to be able to color in the multi-page pictures though.
Easy to assembleSturdyWorks great with my Best Price 8 inch Memory Foam MattressOnly potential negative is that it will come when on a hard floor - consider putting down a rug to help avoid slippage.

This mattress is a winner for the price and comfort!  If I had to complain about anything, it would be the smell, which my guests commented on when they arrived (3 days after the mattress was opened), but they said it was significantly less noticable after a day.  I didn't really notice any significant smell and it seems to be gone now.  I would also have liked to see this mattress be a little more firm, but my guests said it was a very comfortable mattress!

These pillows were purchased for my guest bedroom.  I wouldn't say they are excellent, but they certainly get the job done and you can't beat the price.  They aren't especially substantial.  I would have liked a little more firmness/bulk to these, but 2 pillows stacked seem to be adequate for use.
So this is not a genuine Coach product.  The tags are not right and the coach logo is a little off.  That is disapointing for the price on this.  That being said, it is still cute.

These pens are great and Amazon's price is awesome (I bought them at a specialty store for almost twice the price).  The colors are vibrant and perfect to expectation which is nice.  The colors are easily differentiated on paper despite the fine tip.So far, the only paper I have found that these pens that don't work great on is midori paper for some reason.

I love these pen/markers!  I have been doing a lot of coloring in my Johanna Basford coloring books and these have been great for getting into tiny details!  They are awesome pens.  The ink is vivid, consistent, and the pens won't dry out if left uncapped for a while!The only thing I can complain about with these markers is that there is a fair ridge where the cap meets the body that is uncomfortable when coloring for a long period of time.  Moving back makes it hard to have as much control of the pen and further forward is really narrow.  I do find that I have fatigue after hours of working with these pens and my middle finger hurts from where the ridge digs in.  Other than that, these pens are awesome!

My boston terrier has a habit of destroying toys!  If it is stuffed, it has a life expectancy of about a day (especially if it has a squeaker).  I have had a kong wubba for over a year now and it is still holding up to my dog's abuse!  My dog loves to bring this toy to me and then try and keep it away from me.  She loves to chase it.  She loves the squeaking.  This has become one of her go-to toys when I tell her to go get a ball.  Despite my dog's love for destroying toys, this ball only shows minimal wear!  I highly recommend this toy!

Basically, these are just overpriced alcohol wipes.  The ingredients are just water and alcohol.  That being said, I have no problems with the wipes.  They work fine and are easy to throw in a pocket or purse for times when I am out in public and need to empty my cup.  I should also note that these wipes are bigger than your standard alcohol wipe!

I bought this toothbrush as an upgrade to my rechargable e-series that I bought a few years ago.  I am perfectly happy with the basic level sonicare and don't needs lot of different settings, so this brush suits me just fine.  There is an easy start function if you are new to electronic tooth brushes (it eases you into these brushes with vibrations that increase each time you use it until you reach full power); obviously I don't need this function, but it would be great if you are just getting started with these brushes.I like that the head on these does not leave a huge crevice for paste and water to get caught in and grow - which was an issue with the e-series (BTW, if you have an e-series, clean out undre the cap with bleach each time you swap heads, and you won't have any funk growing).  It is great to have a brush that won't get funky!  The special bonus pack is great since you get a second head and a handy case.  This brush does change on my old base (although it does come with its own base as well).  It is nice to know that I have an extra base if I need it.The only things that I don't necessarily love about this brush is that the head is a little smaller than the e-series, but there are bigger heads that you can get.  Also, this brush is a little louder than the e-series, but it isn't anything that will stop me from using it.

I got one of these as a gift from a friend that couldn't say enough good things about this band.  I have seen the videos and was skeptical, so I put it to the test.  I can say with 100% confidence that this band did absolutely nothing!  I wasn't faster, I wasn't more coordinated.  I even had someone come over to me and tell me that I was an idiot for wearing one while I was in the gym!I guess if you like holographic stickers or silicon bracelets, this would be great for you, but don't expect that the sticker has any magic that will improve the way your body works!

This is a reliable mouse.  It lasts a long time on the batteries (it even has an indicator between the buttons to let you know when it is about time to change).  It fits easily in a backpack, but it won't get lost.  The buttons and roller are very defined in their clicks and rolls, which I love (unlike mice that work primarily on touch).  It has a nifty magnetic slot on the bottom for the dongle.  The only thing bad I can say about it is that the price is a bit more than other wireless travel mice (but then again, it doesn't have some gawdy printed pattern on it either)!

I have had this remote for a couple years, but I can still say I am mostly happy with this remote!  It is easy enough to program and use; you can program special functions (like when you want to play a blueray, it automatically turns on the TV, Blueray player, and surround sound with a single button.There are a couple things that are a pain:-Frequent requests for you to update the remote (I usually ignore them)-The rechargeable battery life is just OK.I do love that I can use my phone since the remote works through your home network though!

I have been a user of Diva Cup for almost a year and a half.  This is my second cup.The packaging: The packaging is not what is shown in the picture. The company has switched from a plastic box to a sturdy plastic bag.  The cup does not sit fully open in the bag, but this does not seem to have any impact on the product.Contents:  The package included the cup, cute cotton bag and instructions.  The instruction insert was only in English- not a problem for me, but could be an issue for people who are not native English speakers.The Cup:Material- Like the Diva Cup, the Sckoon is made of medical-grade silicon.  This particular silicon has an almost jelly feel to it and is a little softer than the Diva, but the material also feels thicker.Construction-  I have seen reviews that cited a layer of dust or silicon dust on their cups.  I did not see any dust on my cup.  Other reviews said that there were a lot of seams that were left on the cup from the mold and that holes were not punched all the way through.  Again, I didn't have these problems.  Presumably, there has been an improvement of QA on this brand.Use and shape- This cup has a different shape from most other cups.  It is much more flared than other cups.  I haven't had any issues with insertion or effectiveness so far.I am not sure this will become my go-to cup, but I definitely don't hate it ;). I think I will need to use it some more before I make up my mind though.

I love that menstral cups are becoming a socially acceptable thing (it even had a cameo in the movie Blended).  While there is definitely a cringe factor to using a cup, but the rewards also certainly exist.  I have been using diva cup for about a year now.  I have had one or two leaking incidents where the cup was not correctly positioned, but overall, these far out perform disposable alternatives for me!Pros:-Cheaper-Less leakage-No smell-They last up to 12 hours-No need to change at work-You get more familiar with your body-Green-No hazardous chemicalsCons:-You have to be comfortable with your body (and a lot of people aren't)-The plastic stains even with vigialant cleaning (I have used Lunette wipes and boiling between cycles)-Learning curge (learn a fold that works for you)I will also say that I don't typically talk about my cup use with anyone (except for my boyfriend) because I am concerned that they will think I am some crunchy, granola hippie or otherwise excentric (plus, you know, it is none of their business).  I can assure you that I am none of these things and I still prefer using a cup!Tips:-If you are new to cups or changing cups, wearing a panty liner or pad may help build confidence in the cup and catch any leaks until you get the hang of things.-Clean, clean, clean!  I have used lunette wipes - you don't need to use them every time you empty, but I have found every other is about good.  I also make sure I at least rinse unless I am in a public restroom.  Then I boil between cycles!Note - Cups don't work the same for everyone.  Every body is different!  What works well fo rme is not necessarily what will work for you, but for me, this thing is great!

This lotion, as a moisturizer, is effective.  It does leave a little bit of a greasy residue on your hands, so if you want something that you can use while handling stuff (electronics, crafts, etc), be aware!  If you just want to remoisturize, then it isn't an issue.My biggest beef with this lotion is that the smell is pretty strong!  I tend to find that any smell that is strong, no matter how delicately fragrant, can become cloying!

Ok, let me start by saying that this tracker is not for the super serious fitness folks.  It is not a replacement for polar and garmin fitness products.That being said, this is still a great product!  It is basically a smart pedometer!  It counts steps and estimates distance and calorie burn.  It also tracks sleep.  When it does all of that, it integrates with an app that allows you to visualize your data.The app allows you to track your weight and body composition (either by aria scale or by manual entry).  It allows you to enter the food you ate through the day (it has a good but not excellent food database).  It allows you to set step goals (and progress through the day is available on the tracker).  It also allows you to use silent alarms.If you want to take a closer look at your fitness, this tracker will help you to see patterns about your daily life.  Of course, the more you interact (entering food, weight, etc), the more powerful and insightful the data will be.One other thing to note is that this band has a lot of accessories.  Fitbit makes bands in all different colors (the tracker comes out of the band to charge or change the bands).  If you want to try other colors, this band will let you do that.  There are even metal bracelet and pendant holders for this tracker that will draw less attention to the tracker on your arm.Things that aren't the best:This tracker is not 100% accurate!  The step count is based on typical movement of the arm while you walk and run.  If you are pushing a shopping cart or otherwise keeping your arm stationary, your steps won't be counted.  Conversely, if you are doing something with your hands that mimics the movements of walking, you will get additional steps counted.  For me, this isn't a huge deal - you win some, you lose some.The clasp on the band has been reported by some users to be unreliable.  This has not been a problem for me, but for those who are concerned, there are plenty of fitbit keeper products that are basically just a band that holds the band together so it can't fall apart.
A good low sugar and excellent protein/carbs balance bar. Taste is a little bland for my liking, but I still like it.
All these Kind bars are very low sugar and excellent protein/carbs balance. Oh yea baby! What an excellent taste combination. One of my favorite Kind bars.
All these Kind bars are very low sugar and excellent protein/carbs balance. An excellent bar.The taste of ginger with the cashews is awesome.

All these Kind bars are very low sugar and excellent protein/carbs balance. I have other flavors I like better, but it's still an excellent bar. This is a little more spicy than most honey/mustard combos.
All these Kind bars are very low sugar and excellent protein/carbs balance. I have other flavors I like better, but it's still an excellent bar.
All these Kind bars are very low sugar and excellent protein/carbs balance. Sweet and chewy.
All these Kind bars are very low sugar and excellent protein/carbs balance. Love this one alot.

All these Kind bars are excellent with very low sugar, good carbs and protein balances. This one is a little weak on the taste, but by no means bad. I just prefer some of their other bars better. But tis' an excellent bar.

All this is good for is cleaning up threads and maybe taping plastic and very, very soft metals. Every time I use it i expect a tap to snap. So far it's has not, but I'm only taping very soft materials. For the money ($30) it's just okay.

Truly one of the worst movies ever made. Basically this is an updated version of Flash Gordon (1980), but not as well written, not as well acted and not as well directed. It does have lots of CGI and people and things "whishing" around in space shooting at everything and never hitting anything. Mila Kunis acts like she's still on The 70's Show. I was waiting for Donna & Eric to come out. One word review: Absurd.

Really like this a lot, however it did not come with a short extension. Really a big mistake in my opinion. It's a real knuckle buster w/o an extension. One of the reasons we use deep sockets is for that offset they provide. This tool puts the handle and your knuckles right at the surface of whatever you are working on. Otherwise its' a very good tool and I like it a lot. Just need an extension. Also I do not care for the ratchet handle. Not at all ergonomic.

Better than the built in mic, not outstanding audio quality  but it's an inexpensive improvement. You will likely have to experiment with your audio input controls to get the best quality and reduce hiss/background noises.

Works very well and easy to use. Just make sure you fill to the bottom of the meniscus for both the water and fuel. You go by the bottom of the meniscus. Do that and you'll have no problems getting an accurate reading. Also I used a plastic syringe to add fuel to the tube as it's easier to control the flow to get the precise amount needed. You can use a glass pipette as well. Only takes about 5 minutes for the 2 liquids to separate. No need to shake hard, just a normal shaking for 5 or so seconds is fine.

Well made, nice smooth finish. (In fact, depending on your usage it could be too smooth, you might want to rough it up a little with sandpaper it you need a good grip) But it looks so good, it'll be hard to do that to it. :-) Turns out it fits standard 1/4" PVC Pipe perfectly. Just need a die (metric 10-1.5) to put threads on it and screws right on.
Love them. Fit very well. Not too tight, not too baggy. (almost 3 year old)
Cheap, fun toys. He plays with them a lot. No sharp edge. Good for the money.

Very cute. Love the colored waist band. Potty training a 3 year old and having the colored waist band allows us to teach him where to pull up this shorts after potty. They are a bit loose fitting tho, (our boy is on the small side of average for his age.)

Great on ants. Just okay on cockroaches. So far I've not seen a single roach die from it, they just crawl off after being sprayed. I have no idea if they die or not. Completely ineffective on most spiders. Black Widow and Tomato spiders laugh at this stuff. The only reason I give it 3 stars is it smells awesome and I love the idea of no poisons, but it's really not that effective.  A combination of 2/3rd cedar and 1/3rd orange oil works better on spiders, but even that you have to spray a Black Widow a couple of times (days apart) to kill it. I wish I had better news, but I think this only works on the "easy" bugs.

UPDATE: The car functioned very well for the first 1.5 years. No complaints there. HOWEVER the gears broke in the drive, so we went over to the manuf. website and ordered a new gear set. Thought "no problem, easy to fix." However that is when the trouble started.First we could not place the order on their website. For some reason they show all the parts, but you can't order directly. So we called and placed the order on 7/4/15. Waited 10 days, got nothing. Called and they said they were moving and lost the order and would resend. Waited another 7 days, and got nothing. So emailed them and on the 24th they replied. After several emails back and forth they said the person who took my order was no longer there and they would resend. Never got anything. Emailed again on 8/4/15. Same excuses. Emailed agan on 8/12, "sorry..." same excuses. Finally on 8/15/15 they provided a tracking no. However the postal system showed only that the label had been created. The item did not ship until almost a week later. 8/21. We got the new parts on 8/24/15 but they are the wrong parts. They are for a different car and do not look anything like what is on the car or their website. The website shows the exact part we need, but they did not send it. So I called and put on hold for 15 minutes, had to hang up. Emailed again and they just said "sorry we must not have that part, you can send them back for a refund."So now my son has a none working car. This WAS his favorite toy. He drove it every single day. Now I have to come up with another $200-$400 to buy another car because the company can't ship me a single $25 part! If you are a parent you know that feeling when you child looks at you with that face. "Why can't I drive my car?"I will NOT buy another "Best Ride On Car" because they have the WORST customer service!

UPDATE: The car functioned very well for the first 1.5 years. No complaints there. HOWEVER the gears broke in the drive, so we went over to the manuf. website and ordered a new gear set. Thought "no problem, easy to fix." However that is when the trouble started.First we could not place the order on their website. For some reason they show all the parts, but you can't order directly. So we called and placed the order on 7/4/15. Waited 10 days, got nothing. Called and they said they were moving and lost the order and would resend. Waited another 7 days, and got nothing. So emailed them and on the 24th they replied. After several emails back and forth they said the person who took my order was no longer there and they would resend. Never got anything. Emailed again on 8/4/15. Same excuses. Emailed agan on 8/12, "sorry..." same excuses. Finally on 8/15/15 they provided a tracking no. However the postal system showed only that the label had been created. The item did not ship until almost a week later. 8/21. We got the new parts on 8/24/15 but they are the wrong parts. They are for a different car and do not look anything like what is on the car or their website. The website shows the exact part we need, but they did not send it. So I called and put on hold for 15 minutes, had to hang up. Emailed again and they just said "sorry we must not have that part, you can send them back for a refund."So now my son has a none working car. This WAS his favorite toy. He drove it every single day. Now I have to come up with another $200-$400 to buy another car because the company can't ship me a single $25 part! If you are a parent you know that feeling when you child looks at you with that face. "Why can't I drive my car?"I will NOT buy another "Best Ride On Car" because they have the WORST customer service!
Fine kit of glass fuses, but these are all the very small ones, not the larger, older automotive type. These are the ones they use in electronics.

Pretty good for the money. Not really "washers," but better than some I've seen. Just stamped out rings of copper. No finishing to them. However, they are copper and for my purpose they worked well. The price was very low.
Cheap fun for the kids. So far they have not broken them.

Junk just like every other tarp I've purchased on Amazon. 1 week and the eyelets are already ripping out. Using very light bungee cords to anchor it. Hardly any stress on them, yet they are tearing out.The Camo print is awesome and looks great, but it's not going to last more than a month at this rate. VERY DISAPPOINTED. I paid $50 for this tarp thinking it'd be a higher quality than the $15-$20 tarps, but I just wasted my money. (I've bought at least 4 tarps here on Amazon, and they are all the same junk regardless of price.)The ONLY use I can think of for this tarp would be a backdrop for photo/video shooting. For that it might be useful But for protecting something in the wind and rain, it's trash.

One my my favorite "go to" tools.This set is an adjustable wrench with a ratchet socket in the handle. It takes the sockets that come with it and they snap in nicely. It's all open ended so you don't really need deep sockets as the bolts will pass thru.  Note the sockets are the spline type, which means they fit US and Metric bolts/nuts, 12 point, 6 point, spline or many other types of nuts/bolt heads. So you basically have 3 sets of sockets here. The range is from 3/8"/10mm/CPT50 all the way up to 3/4"/19mm/CPT59. They are all very thin wall (both a blessing and curse) except for the 9/16-14mm which is massively thick.The adjustable wrench has some very nice features. First is that the jaw is reversible. The way it comes it's a standard adjustable wrench with parallel face jaws to engage a bold or nut. However if you open it up all the way, you can turn it around and put it back in and now you have the serrated jaws of a pipe wrench. Very nice idea.Also the adjustable wrench is indexed. By that I mean there are markings on the jaw that will show you want size the wrench is open to. So if you open the wrench and see the pointer at 3/4" or whatever, that tells you want size socket or fixed wrench need. A simple and rough caliper of sorts.The only thing missing is an extension for the sockets.I bought mine at a big box store for less than $30. (actually bought 2, keep one in the car, one in the shop.)This is my 3rd Crescent brand tool and I'm very impressed with all of them. They have the quality and feel of the old days Craftsmen stuff. (I good thing.)
Works great. Had to buy one to replace one lost (or stolen, not sure.)
tiny, bright, small, unobtrusive, there when you need it.

Very expensive, but I'm glad I bought it. I have zero fears of my camera flying off the car. It is SOLID. I was thinking of mounting it to the roof with a baby seat on it... just kidding. But it's really very strong and stable. Also, and this is way cool, you can take it apart and have 3 single mounts, or a single and a double. I also bought the extension kit , but it only offered liimited usability. This works great on it's own.

Very disappointed in this. Yes it will start a car just fine. But it only has 400mah reserve. We have an isound 16,000mah and it lasts all week. This will not last a day and I'm afraid if we use it, it won't be there to jump the car should we need it.So as a very lightweight jump box.. good. But as a power supply for devices? Not so much.
I loved them for being light and compact and nice looking, but forget using them for a car. They are too unstable for that. Had to return them.

Really just okay. There are 2 problems.#1, you have to find the perfect material to go thru the pickup. So far I have not found it.#2. the hose fell apart in 2 weeks of setting outside. I just leave all my blasting/cleaning gear outside in a "blasting/cleaning" area and in just 2 weeks the hose fell to pieces.Otherwise worked okay.

Love these supplements. They really have helped me keep my cool in very stressful situations. One of my "must have" daily morning supplements. Highly recommended for those with stress fill lives.. (all of us?)
Works well and just toss them, but the cost can be expensive if you clean your toilets a lot.

This is nice, but it's not the extension I thought it would be. Still useful, but it really needs either a double male ball and/or another slider to be really useful. Trying to provide a long arm extension with an additional mounting point to steady it.

I don't know if I got a bum set or they changed this part, but I am unable to get any fuse to fit into these fuse taps. Yes, they will go in if I bang on them or use pliers to get them in, but if I need to put them out that means I'll have to use pliers to get them out.  Also if you are not pushing straight in, they are so hard to get in the legs of the fuse will bend over 90 degrees if you are not careful.

UPDATE: Due to poor customer service from the manuf. of the car I have to deduct one star. I ordered replacement parts on 7/14/15. By 7/24/15 when nothing showed up, I contacted the company. Was told on the 27th my order would ship "tomorrow" the 28th. Here is is Aug 4th and nothing is here. Pretty good product, lacking in customer service followup.I still recommend the car for the fun/price ratio, but it needs improvement in lacking important features and customer service. Manufacturing quality is very good.Original Review:This is my first remote car so I didn't know what to expect. For looks, it's just great. Looks like an F430, and for less than $200, I think it's decent, but there are areas it needs to be improved:1. Movement is all on or all off. It really jerks the childs head around. It really needs a 2 stage throttle, ie, Low/high, or better yet a real progressive throttle. It's just too jerky for me.2. One wheel wonder. Ie, does not have a solid rear axle or posi.
