This may sound stupid, but the problem is on tile and hardwood floors, due to the power of the motor, it spins the one drive wheel and actually turns the car right. It's very hard to go left on tile. You have to turn the wheel all way to the left and even then you only can go straight or slightly left. If you keep the wheels straight and hit the gas, the car goes right. Also on gravel or anything other than carpet or brick/pavers, it's easy to get stuck. Forget going up or down slight elevation changes. ie from the patio to the grass or vice versa. A solid rear axle or posi and some sort of suspension would solve this problem.3. Wide turning radius. For such a short wheelbase I expected it to be very nimble. It needs a bit more turning angle. If you want to play inside, you'll need a pretty big area to drive.4. I wish the on/off button was hidden or had a key. Super easy for the child to find it and play with the car when you are not around.5. This car has no suspension. Not a killer, but it's a little rough on anything other than carpet.Overall it's a pretty good toy. Our boy loves it and he was playing in it while I was putting it together. :) All the other remote cars I looked at were double the price. If it had a real gradual throttle or at least a hi/low switch, posi, and hidden power switch it'd be 5 stars for sure. I think all of these things would add only a modest amount to the price of the car, but it'd make it a much better toy.If the $500 remote cars have these same problems, then by all means get this one. It's worth the money. But if the $500 remote cars have a real throttle, posi, a real suspension, and hidden switch, you might want to one of those instead.

This is nice and small, but I don't like the wifi connection. It's a bit of a pain to get it to connect to the phone. I have to unconnect to the network, and then try to connect to the unit. With bluetooth you can have many items able to connect and it's easy to select between them. The problem with a wifi connection is the phone wants to connect to the home network not this device. So I had to force the phone to ignore the home/best network to get it to connect. Bluetooth works better. Yes it's nice and small... but you will have a problem if you use your phone with a home or business wifi network.
Very thin wire. Works for small & light items, but not for anything that has much weight. (ammo, liquids, not so much)

Pumps well, will draw up a short amount. (1-2' only). Pressure not tested yet, but seems to be close to the rated 100psi. A bit loud.One thing, the connections are weird. They do not seem to fit any known connector. At least nothing I could find. What I did was use standard 3/8" ID, 1/2" OD polyethalene tubing with the plastic collars that came on the pump. Pull out the little red inserts, thread the collar on the poly tubing, (it's a very tight fit) then shove the tubing over the very short barb. Then screw down the collars hand tight (no tools or you'll pop the threads or snap the collars). It does hold pressure. All plastic, so I'm not 100% confident, but we'll give it a try.Depending on your use, you might want to put in a feedback loop with a valve or restrictor pill as it will cycle on/off rapidly if you are not using all the flow available.

These will work with a lowered car very well. They only lift the car 3" but they fit under the spoiler of even the lowest car. Use them for a small lift or to lift the car enough to get a jack under it for further lifting. The "stop" is only 1/2" tall and I cut mine off easily with a saw so it'd clear my ultra low car.

So this book. I hate when something starts out so unbelievably amazing and then dissolves into complete mediocrity. The 1/3 of MAGONIA was awesome. I had all these wonderful John Green vibes and I actually cried at one scene. The voice was so intoxicating.But then...not so much.As soon as Aza goes up, the amazing voice gets strangled in a complicated world full of rules and history and just strangeness that failed to captivate me. One of the big problems with this book (and others like it) is that Aza is thrust into this sky world with a million questions (rightfully so), but guess how many get answered? Not many. And instead of demanding answers, Aza just lets people dismiss her and literally put her to work swabbing the deck. It was extremely frustrating. Worst of all though, is that the plot and worldbuilding is so complicated and unique in the sky that Aza's character fades into generic girl in a fantasy novel. Maybe if she hadn't be so dynamic and alive in the first 1/3 of the book, I wouldn't have noticed as much, but she was so I did.Also the introduction of a love triangle was so anemic as to be pointless. And yet it looks like it might develop more in the sequel. Bleh.Overall, this would have been one of my favorite books if the last 2/3 of the book (the fantasy) had lived up to the 1/3 (the contemporary). I love fantasy YA, but this just didn't work on that level. I will anxiously await this author's next contemporary offering, but I won't be returning to Magonia.

This is a fantastic vacuum. It's extremely lightweight and very quiet (my baby doesn't scream in fear from the noise and my Dyson used to terrify her!). And the extra long cord is a godsend. I usually have to breakout extension cords with my previous vacuums, but this one lets me reach the entire main floor of my house! The swivel head is also a nice perk that I haven't had before.I expected the suction power to be adequate (compared to my old Dyson), but it is fantastic. In fact I have to use the release valve regularly (another nice feature). Oh and there is an optional separate power button to turn off the roller brush--which is absolutely necessary if you have rugs that occasionally get tangled or have strings etc.
They tend to break more easily than the black elastics I own. I like them for my one year old with her very fine hair, but not so much for my three year old who has much thicker hair.

I was pleasantly surprised by how well this worked. I've read other reviews that said this worked best on fine hair, but it gave my thick straight hair the most beautiful romantic curls. I would have been happy with one day curls since I didn't expect them to last beyond that, but even on day two, I had soft waves that were just as lovely--with no added styling product at all!  There is a bit of a trick to getting these romantic curls (in the picture my hair is freshly washed with no added product).-Hold the Instyler vertically with the cord at the top-Wrap the hair around the barrel once but DON'T overlap-Twist the Instyler as you pull down so that the hair moves up the Instyler even wrapping around the handle--which helps cool and set the curl-Use your hand if needed to help wrap the hair around the brush as you twist making sure NOT to overlap

Nope. This did absolutely nothing. I'm in my mid thirties so I am starting to see wrinkles in my forehead. I thought this might 'diminish' them as the product claimed, but not so much.  I'm not even going to bother posting the before and after pics I took because I legitimately can't tell which is which.

I've wanted one of these forever but I held off because of the price. Let me just say that it is well worth every dollar. I can actually give my hair that just-stepped-out-of-the-salon blowout every time. I have very thick, slightly wavy (in places) hair that is currently just past my shoulders. Using the Instyler, I get silky smooth hair with body and bounce and perfect barely turned under ends that make it look effortless. I'm in love. I only use this once my hair is dried because I don't care about the whole style damp hair thing, but on dry hair, yes, yes, yes!

3.5 starsI had the wind knocked out of me reading the first book in this lush and gorgeous YA series with it's transportive but still immensely accessible fantasy/historical landscape.  I still get chills thinking about the impossibly heart wrenching love story between Kestrel and Arin. So while I quickly and eagerly embraced them and this world in THE WINNER'S CRIME, the book does fall prey to the second book syndrome with some slow parts.i understand that the trilogy as a whole dictates that Kestrel and Arin be apart for most of this book, but that doesn't mean that the story delivers the same engrossing experience that the first book did. There is a lot of guilt and pain due to numerous misunderstandings between the couple. Sure much of that is because Kestrel is nobly sacrificing herself for Arin's good, but it did skirt the frustrating line for me a few times. The middle of the book especially felt slow as very little happened to advance the plot or characters. In the hands of a lesser writer, that may have fatally wounded the book, but not so with Marie Rutkoski.  Her words paint beautifully and provocatively throughout. And the ending of this book is simply gutting. I was so caught up in the anguish of these characters that it felt like my own.Marie Rutkoski has crafted a masterful story in The Winner's Trilogy. This second installment may have slowed some in the middle, but there is not a force on earth that could keep me from the final book. THE WINNER'S KISS is scheduled to be released on March 1, 2016

In the 90s this was THE scent. Everyone I knew wore this scent or wished they could.  It was the epitome of cool. Over a decade has passed since then and I really wasn't sure how I would respond to this scent now, but I still love it. For some reason it is striking me as a more masculine scent now than I remembered, but it's still very much a unisex scent. It's that bright warm scent that I find timeless.

My husband thought these would be great for him when he's out hunting in the desert. Sadly, after only one day he passed them off to me. They were just too small on him and after a couple hours they became uncomfortable. I decided to try them out for driving and I LOVE them.  The fit on me is a dream and the extended lens make them ideal for super sunny days (which are no joke in Arizona). Since these are men's sunglasses, they do look a little more masculine than I would prefer, but they work so well I don't even care.

This book is a Twilight knockoff. I knew this going in, but since I fell hard for Twilight when it came out I figured a little something similar might be fun--and it was, for the first hundred pages or so. After that, it became derivative and tedious.First, lets go through the Twilight checklist:-A girl (Caitlin) moves to a small town to live with family she barely knows.-She immediately catches the eye of the lethally hot loner (Adrian) that all the girls want.-After witnessing an inhuman feat and Adrian leaps in to rescue her from some unwanted attention, Caitlin learns he's a vampire-Adrian tries to stay away from her and even tries to be a jerk to protect her for her own good-Adrian's eyes change color, he's rich, and lives with his family of beautiful loners,-Adrian has a sister who has visions-The sister has a vision about Caitlin in danger so the whole family decides to protect her-Adrian sneaks into her room each night-So. Many. More.But honestly, I was fine with the initial setup, and the writing wasn't bad (it was intentionally funny in places), what killed this book for me was the non-Twilight stuff and the overwhelming need for an editor to cut all the extraneous stuff.  This book is close to 400 pages which is about 200 pages too long. It drags, big time. If someone told me this book started out as Twilight fan fiction, I wouldn't doubt it for a second. It feels like the authors just wrote extremely long, meandering chapters to meet some arbitrary word count. And as for the non-Twilight stuff involving a demon trying to impregnate teenage girls and really unsettling nightmares, blech. It was creepy with a big side of eww.Also, cliffhanger. Yep, this is the start of a series.
Didn't really stay on. The head opening is just too shallow, so I basically had to hold it on.

I'm torn about this review.On the one hand, I really like this case. The textured leather feels great in the hand and provides a little extra grip that makes me think I won't be dropping my phone again, maybe ever. I also like that the bright tangerine color makes it easy to spot my phone in the endless abyss that is my purse. I even like the cute little owl logo.My only drawback is the price. This is easily twice as expensive as any phone case I've owned before (and twice, sometimes three times as expensive as other leather cases here on Amazon). I know this is 'handcrafted premium leather' but still. It just doesn't feel like it should cost this much. I showed it to a friend (who loved the look) and asked her what she thought it was worth and she guessed $20. That's probably closer to what I'd feel comfortable with too.

0:59 Mins Set up was slightly time consuming (maybe if you are a veteran juicer you'll be able to figure it out easily enough), but it took us about twenty minutes. We decided to try one of the included recipes, Cucumber Refresher, in the video using the low pulp screen (which should be called no pulp because there was nothing much to my delight). Probably not one I'll repeat from a flavor standpoint. I'd also forgo the foam guard since it backed up and started to overflow (see pic at the end of the video). Overall, I loved how quiet this juicer is compared to cheaper juicers I've owned in the past. The so-called 'wide feed chute' leaves something to be desired. Oh and the drip tray is great--it lifts right out so you can pour back in any overflow.

This is my second piece of jewelry from the Amazon Collection, and I'm increasingly impressed the high quality and affordable price. The box is something I'd expect from a high end jeweler. These earrings are beyond lovely and they catch the light like crazy. They aren't tiny, but they aren't so big that they look fake. They also feel surprisingly light.

I've had this hand vacuum for nearly a month and I use it almost every other day (spills, pet hair on the couch, dirt trailed in etc) for an average of 5 minutes each time (not counting when my 2 year old plays with it) and I've only had to charge this once!There are so many times when I don't have the time to pull out my vacuum, but this little handheld is perfect to clean up after the kids knock over the paper shredder or the dog tracks in the entire back yard or someone upends a bag of chips...or just anything. I could not be happier with this cordless vacuum. Love, love, love it!

*Updated* They have updated the description to remove TracFone from the list of compatible networks. I've updated my rating to reflect that.I got this phone specifically to use with Tracfone's service (which I love and currently use on two phones). I had previously activated an iPhone 4s using Tracfone's Bring Your Own Phone (BYOP) option and it was a breeze. The compatibility claim on the very top of this page says:"US Compatibility Nationwide on all GSM Networks including AT&T, T-Mobile, Cricket, MetroPCS, Tracfone, Straight Talk and others"I saw the name Tracfone and I was sold. I didn't even notice that this is a GSM phone, and Tracfone's BYOP program only works with CDMA phones (see screenshot). The bottom of Tracfone's BYOP website says:" TracFone network access code works only with CDMA phones that are compatible with our service. Branded phones including, but not limited to Blackberry, Sprint, Virgin Mobile, Metro PCS, Boost Mobile, TracFone, Net10, Straight Talk and Safelink are not eligible for this program. Your device must be in good standing to be activated. Network access code and plans are not refundable."I still went ahead and tried to register and activate it with Tracfone since there are often conflicting reports about the BYOP program, but as you can see from the picture of the online activation page, it is not compatible.  I'm disappointed because this is a great phone for the price with a huge screen (that's an iPhone 5 next to it for size comparison).

Not my favorite hot tool. This does smooth, but the volume and curling claims are a stretch. I have thick, shoulder length hair that typically holds curls for days, but this heated brush produced limp, flat, barely there waves that my sister described as, "like you tried to curl your hair but your hair refused."  I don't think this a game changer for me.

For most people, this case is going to be great. The earbuds sound good, retract easily, and it's simple to switch between the phone speaker and buds. The problem for me is that I use my car charger daily since I'm in my car constantly, and it does not fit through this case, so I have to take the case off to charge it. My regular home charger fits fine, but I rarely use that charger...so this case isn't a great fit for my needs.

I don't get to equate eco friendly with high performance that often, and I didn't really expect to with these diapers. Let me tell you it's nice to be wrong. These diapers did not leak even overnight. I'm very impressed. I'm also wishing more brands had the little tab to wrap them up after use (extremely handy).

Pretty cute. My 2yr old was instantly excited and loved that this toy was just her size (we've had others in the past that were to big and cumbersome for her to hold and play at the same time). The sound is good--and fortunately has an off switch--but there is only one default volume, and it's quite loud. Still, this is a great little guitar for the price and it'll be a big hit with Dora fans.

I've been using Biore Pore Strips for years and they work amazingly well at removing black heads. Comparing this new version to the Ultra Deep Cleansing pore strips, I can't say noticed a real difference apart from a slight tingling feeling. The charcoal strips do leave some bits of black residue on the skin too, although it washes right off, and they are slightly smaller. Since the Ultra Deep strips cost a dollar less than these new charcoal ones, I'll stick to the original ones, but both work great.

I did not think it was possible to buy a laptop for $159, let alone a good one. I was also leery about the Chrome OS since all I've ever used was Windows, but wow. I mean wow do I love this.I needed something light and basic (email, Facebook, documents etc.) and I needed it on the cheap. This Chromebook arrived the day after I ordered it and there was absolutely no setup required. I've used Chrome as my browser for years, so there was no learning curve there at all. I had't realized how much of my laptop use is online now anyway, I barely noticed that I was using a non Windows OS. Google Docs is every bit as functional (and intuitive) as Word, and the rest of the Google apps have more than met my other needs.Oh and the battery life. Seriously amazing. I forgot what it was like not to have to haul a charger with me. I can use this all day and still have power. This isn't going to be the best laptop if you are concerned about viewing angles since the screen is only view able from straight ahead, but I actually prefer the privacy that provides me in public. And did I mention the 100 GB of Google Drive storage?All in all, this laptop is perfect for me.

I picked these up solely because they claim to be 'The Best Diaper for Dancing.' My 2 yr old is always dancing around and the price is hard to beat. I have to say that I thought these would only be suitable for daytime wear since they seem a little thinner than our normal Huggies, but after a week, we haven't had any leaks even at night! I'm a big fan and will absolutely repurchase these.

Ever try to use a dry erase marker as an eyeliner? Now you can! This eyeliner was every bit as big and unwieldy as a kids marker. I normally use the Kat Von D Tattoo Liner in Trooper and I adore it for delicate barely noticeable looks as well as fierce cat eye looks. I had hoped this liner would be equally versatile at a more affordable price, but it's not. I really did feel like I had a massive magic marker in my hands.It was impossible to get right to the lash line, it skips, and it isn't as black as I like. I can't imagine anyone using this with any kind of precision. The only positive thing I can say is that it is relatively easy to rub away until it sets--and you are definitely going to need a few tries with this.

Using this razor made me think of the Hummer slogan: it's not more than you need, just more than you're used to. That sums it up perfectly. I've used various electric razors over the years, but never one at this price point. Now that I have tried it, I can't imagine going back. The shave is so smooth, so comfortable, and just so efficient that it is worth every penny.I was a little intimidated by the size of the instruction manual included with this razor, but everything is so intuitive that I really only needed to glance at it. And the cleaning/lubricating doc is a nice touch. After about two weeks of daily use, it feels brand new every time. The only way this razor could be any better was it I could use it in the shower.

Yummy. That's the word. I tried this pasta in the Pioneer Woman's Bowtie Chicken Alfredo recipe and it was simply delicious. My whole family loved it--even the ones who normally don't like fortified pastas. There was good chew and I honestly couldn't tell the difference between this and the plain version. Big hit. I will definitely repurchase.

Great gate and we love the auto-close function. It did arrive with a rather large scratch (see photo), but other than that, it's working great for us. I will say the instructions were less than helpful (no written instructions all all, just tons of diagrams that made my eyes want to cross). I ended up finding two videos on Muchkin's Youtube channel that perfectly showed me how to install and add the extension (do a search for "Wood & Steel Designer Gate/The Deco by Munchkin: Installation" and then "How to install extensions on Munchkin pressure-mount baby gates"). Do yourself a huge favor and skip the included instructions in favor of the video.It does come with the option to screw in anchor cups, but the gate can mount very securely without them (in my opinion) and then you have more flexibility to move the gate between doorways if you need to (which we do).

Another excellent new Middle Grade series from Jennifer A. Nielsen. I adored the Ascendance Trilogy and expected Nielsen's new series to be just as exciting, smart, and adventurous, and that's exactly what this debut is.I love the blend of magic, mythology, and history in MARK OF THE THIEF. And of course we get another smart mouthed protagonist who is wise and crafty beyond his years. While not quite as compelling as Sage from the Ascendance Trilogy, Nic proved to be a worthy successor. Both boys start out on the dregs of society (an orphan and a slave) yet rise to notoriety through a series of seemingly coincidental circumstances.The romance was a bit stilted for me, but I think that had to do with the timeline of this book. Everything happens very quickly (I think the entire book spans less than a week), so that is going to be something that hopefully stretches out more in subsequent books. Since the romance is a very small part of this book, I'm still sticking with five stars. If you love Percy Jackson, you are going to find a new best friend in Nic. Can't wait for the next book.
This purse is massive. I could have carried my five year old around in it. It looked ridiculously large. I do like the embossed leather, but I had to return this.

This is a light, crisp fragrance that smells very strongly of grapefruit. It's a very clean almost unisex fragrance. In fact, I had to double check Amazon upon receiving it since the box this perfume arrives in looks more like what I'd expect from a men's cologne. The bottle is decidedly feminine though.I will add that I received a few comments while wearing this that is smelled like an older woman's perfume. Not exactly the reaction I was looking for, but I still like it quite a lot.

I am trying this product because, although I do eat a fair amount of dark leafy greens, whole grains, and other foods which contain magnesium, I'm not sure I do so consistently enough. I became interested in magnesium because it is said to help with sleep, and also because I know it is a necessary nutrient to aid in calcium absorption, especially calcium from non-plant sources (such as dairy). I have some bone issues which lead me to believe I may have inorganic calcium deposits in my body, and I am curious whether the magnesium will help with that, or at least prevent future damage.Normally I shy away from supplements and try to get nutrients from a healthy diet. But these tablets are chelated, meaning bound to an amino acid which supposedly enables it to be absorbed more easily through the intestinal wall. For that reason I consider it to be better than non-chelated supplements.I have been taking it for a short time and nutritional supplements usually take some time to make a difference. But I do think my sleep is somewhat improved. Time will tell whether it has other effects.

I loved the look of this charge and sync dock when I first took it out of the box. It has a super-sturdy cord, and I like standing the phone up in the protective cradle to charge and sync rather than leaving it on the desktop. I love the red color; it's a pleasant change from black or white tech devices.What I first noticed though, was also mentioned by another reviewer: if you do not have a case, or use a thin case, the phone stands rather awkwardly with nothing supporting it in the front or back. Sounds like some other reviewers have the opposite problem: lack of space for their case.I own and use other Belkin chargers which seemed to charge fairly quickly. This charger seems to take longer. It also seemed to take longer to start up. Like my other Belkin chargers, this one came with no instructions or literature of any kind. I know that's because it is supposed to be self-evident how to use it, but it would help to have some kind of booklet so I would know if my expectations for the device are realistic and if it is working as it's designed to. Even the Amazon product page says very little, so it's hard to know what to expect.Plugging it into my laptop and inserting the iPhone in the cradle automatically opens up iTunes on my computer. This, too, seemed to take a long time for some reason. And, unlike when I sync my phone directly from the laptop, where I can see on iTunes that it's syncing, there was no indication, either on iTunes or on the phone itself, that it synced.So I give it three starts for looks, and for basic functionality, but it's not what I hoped for.

I got this for my 12 year old daughter who is an avid reader and writer. Despite not being a big history buff, she could not put this book down. The event that serves as the backdrop to the story-- the sinking of the MV Wilhelm Gustloff with the largest loss of life on a single ship in history-- was something neither of us had ever heard of, despite studying World War II extensively in home schooling as well as reading other books on maritime disasters! And believe me, this is a story worth telling. The format of the book, with characters speaking in turns over just a few pages each, makes it a real page-turner. Sepetys takes the story from being simply a "historical event" down to the very real, personal level of individual lives, relationships, and emotions. The characterization is excellent. Heartbreaking, inspiring, and gripping, this book and its author really stand out from the crowd of today's teen/young adult literature.

My husband and kids are really enjoying this dartboard. The darts seem to be of very good quality. The scoreboard is small (and the "eraser" would have been better off left out, it's so laughable) but we're just using this for family fun so that doesn't matter. We do notice that the fibers don't heal over to seal the holes made by the darts, but my husband thinks that continued use will cause the fibers to get pushed back by darts hitting other places. (I'm not explaining that very well!) It was easy to mount, the only difficulty being how to protect the surrounding area from getting damaged! That is a definite consideration when choosing where to mount the dartboard. We think it's a great board for the price. The darts will be flying fast and furious in the upcoming winter months when everyone is cooped up indoors!

I bought this book after a friend recommended the author's blog. As a contemplative, I was immediately drawn to the title of her blog (which is the same as the book) and enjoyed some of her writings as well as the beautiful images she finds for her blog, though I admit I don't read any blog very often.However, I was a bit disappointed with the book. I found it repetitive, but especially, I was surprised that the author was apparently unaware that the concept of a cloistered heart (which can be described using a variety of terms but is basically a heart set aside for God and removed from the world) was not at all new. She spends some time sharing this discovery, and I confess I grew impatient with it early on. I hoped the book would go deeper. Instead I felt it was kind of surface-level.The book contains the author's journal entries from some years ago. I wish she had updated it with some of her more recent blog entries. And I think some commentary to flesh out the passages from her journals would also help flesh out the book. I think it's a beautiful concept that needed more depth beyond just journal entries. I can imagine a format where the author shares a journal entry, then comments on that entry, then offers a brief reflection.  That would be a great meditation resource for Eucharistic Adoration.

As a student in a Natural Healing program, this book is incredibly useful to me for a number of reasons. The descriptions of every disorder, its etiology, symptoms and signs, how it is diagnosed, and the standard medical treatments are extremely clear. It is helpful to me as an alternative health practitioner to know and understand the medical tests and treatments a client may have undergone before coming to me. The book contains all sorts of other aids: tables, diagrams, and more. For example, in the section on the elderly, there is a table of questions to ask to determine if depression is present, and a two-page spread on a home assessment for hazards that increase the risk of falling. I could list many things like this, but suffice it to say that the book is as useful as a home reference as it is for professionals.Naturally, the book has a certain bias toward standard western medicine and away from alternative practices. While it sometimes mentions alternative modalities such as acupuncture, herbs, and others, it rarely attributes to them their true effectiveness. For example, the book will say that "well-designed studies" have shown that this or that herb is ineffective. However, I am familiar with these herbs, and also with these "well-designed studies." They often isolate one chemical component from the plant, instead of studying it the way an herbalist would use it: as a whole plant. Or, they give laboratory animals the equivalent of enormous doses of herbs that no human being would ever take, and then conclude the herb is dangerous. Or, they use the herb in isolation, not with other herbs that accentuate its effectiveness, and usually without the dietary changes or other changes a holistic health practitioner would recommend, and then yes, the herb is less effective than it might be.The section on rheumatoid arthritis made me laugh; under "Rest and Nutrition" in the Treatment section, it reads "An ordinary nutritious diet is generally sufficient...Food and diet quackery is common and should be discouraged." Well, I know what most doctors and hospitals call "ordinary nutritious food," though the book fails to spell it out for the reader. While there certainly IS dietary quackery out there, a well-balanced vegetarian diet, for example, is hardly quackery and has proven very helpful for many arthritic patients.In short, this book is very thorough, but use it for what it is: an extremely useful guide to every conceivable "western" disorder and the standard medical interventions used to treat them. Don't expect to find complete or balanced coverage of alternative treatments here.

I got this book for my son who is a huge James Patterson fan. What strikes him about this book is that, unlike previous Patterson books he's read which clue the reader in fairly early on as to whodunit while the characters try to solve the mystery, this one leaves the reader as much in the dark as the characters, which makes it a real page turner. My son is a teenager, and I appreciate that Patterson's books are gripping and exciting with a minimum of bad language or sexual content.

Once upon a time I thought affirmations were somewhat silly, probably because the ones I was exposed to were really simplistic and uninspiring, the tone often like "cheerleading" which is not my style. The affirmations in this book, though, are beautifully written and really speak to my heart. There is something in here for virtually every life situation, though many are general enough to use simply when you feel chaotic, stressed, upset, or any other negative emotion that you want to turn around. They are poetic, never seem false, and really impart a sense of peace and confidence. reading these affirmations really feels like truth, rather than something forced which I am trying to convince myself is true. After reading them for awhile, I find myself making up similar affirmations of my own in difficult situations, when I can't sleep, etc. I love this book and hope there are more by this author. I'd like to find one that is not in Kindle form to carry with me!

I have been reading a lot lately about the power of affirmations, forgiveness, and basically, most of the themes represented in this book. And so when offered this book for free in exchange for a review, I thought I would give it a try.First of all, I am growing very weary of the "Ten Things You Need to Know About XYZ," "The Five Most Important Points About PQR," "The Twelve Best ABC of All Time," etc. I see that device all over the internet on blogs, as well as in a plethora of book titles, and I'm really tired of it. It gives the impression that the author has summed up all there is to know on a topic. It taps into our need for a quick fix, for a simple plan all laid out in easy steps. In short, it's a marketing tool, and when I see it in spiritual or self-help topics, I cringe. So the subtitle of this book, "7 Spiritual Practices to Heal Your Life," does not appeal to me.Second, this is an expensive book. It's a small hardcover with thick pages, kind of gift-book style, that could have been produced much less expensively. The content could have fit into a thin paperback.Much of the book consists in a conversation between the two authors. I found much of the conversation to be simplistic-- things you will have read before if you've read anything at all on these topics. I felt the conversational style took up unnecessary space and took many words to convey what could have been said in far fewer.Some of the concrete suggestions, such as the Affirmation Board where you will make a collage of everything you say "yes" to (not what your parent, spouse, or anyone else says yes to, just you), are creative and helpful. I like the idea of a visual Affirmation Board rather than a list that will get lost somewhere in a journal. It's meant to be an evolving self-portrait, and I like that idea very much; I might actually do that one.  Other suggestions, such as using a Forgiveness Scale of 1-100 to determine how much I've forgiven self and others, does not resonate with me. Those numbers would be hard to gauge and kind of meaningless, as well as possibly another reason for guilt.To sum up, there are a few good concrete ideas in this book, but otherwise the content, though valid, is nothing new: forgiveness, loving your inner child, learning to receive, gratitude, choosing love over fear. It's a very quick read somewhat expensively packaged. Wait for the paperback or try the authors' other books first.

This was going to be our cat's Christmas gift (and it would have been the biggest gift in the whole family!), but we just couldn't wait so we went ahead and set it up. Actually, my 12 year old daughter set it up fairly quickly and without any major hassles. This Cat Tree is HUGE. Kind of like a penthouse for cats. And it's heavy, which is a good thing because we have a hefty 15-pound Maine Coon. This cat tree or tower is very sturdy and can easily handle the weight of my cat or even a heavier one. The hammock might sag a bit under a heavy cat's weight, but no big deal, and I don't notice any other wobbling.We are placing this in front of a sunny window where our indoor cat likes to watch birds, squirrels, and passers-by. So far she has scratched at the ramp and explored the various sitting/sleeping surfaces. She has always been wary of going inside small spaces, especially if she's not sure there is space to turn around, so she hasn't tried the little hidey-hole or the tunnel yet, or put her head through the hole at the top of the ramp. But she also dislikes being observed until she perfects things, so she will probably try these out late at night when no one is standing there saying "Come on, Virgil!" and trying to coax her into it.The little "tunnel" (as I call it) is kind of oddly placed near the very top of the tree, so that when a cat emerges from it, there is nothing to step onto. That's one concern; I'm not sure she will like going through a tube that leads nowhere. And, as with every other one I have ever seen, the little roofed hidey-hole is rather snug for a large cat. I'll be hiding some treats in there, and she can either muster the courage to go in, or simply challenge herself to find a way to get them out! But she often surprises me with the places she likes to explore or sleep (for example, sleeping on a pile of coat hangers when a soft pillow is right nearby... or exploring the dark, cobweb-draped basement...or napping in the bathroom sink...) So she might end up loving those features.I am going to attach a few items to dangle from the tunnel so she can bat at them while lounging on the big pawprint below. I like the fact that there are scratching surfaces everywhere, a big plus for an indoor cat. Most cat scratching posts, since they offer no other interest or appeal and tend to topple easily, are pretty much worthless as far as diverting my car from the pleasures of scratching at our upholstery, but I think this Cat Tree just might do the trick and save our couches.I am extremely impressed with this Cat Tree for size, sturdiness, and the variety of places and surfaces to explore. Its soft carpeted surfaces are really cozy, with plenty of scratching surfaces to boot. Just be aware that you need a pretty big chunk of real estate in your house to accommodate it!

I seem to be the first person so far who is not happy with this ring. It comes in an impressive presentation box, though one might want to remove the "Made in China" sticker before gifting. But upon opening the box, I was struck right away by the lack of sparkle to this ring. The white cubic zirconias just have a somewhat dull appearance, almost like ordinary glass. The green ones are so pale that they don't really stand out. The rhodium looks cheap and kind of industrial, more like stainless steel than a fine metal. Granted, Amazon is offering this ring for $14.30 (marked down from $39.99). But that's exactly what it looks like to me: a $14 ring. Another reviewer says hers sparkles and shines and catches the light; unfortunately mine definitely does not. I was hoping to open that box and exclaim "Wow!" but I'm afraid this ring is not at all eye catching.

Cheap. Cheap canvas, cheap construction. I realize these are a low-end pair of Vans, but they're still pricey enough. I expect a low-end pair of Vans to be a lot better than a low-end pair of sneakers from Walmart, and these just don't cut it. Rather narrow also. Disappointed.

This book is definitely not what I expected. The author is renowned and obviously knowledgeable, but what I was hoping from a book subtitled "An Integration of Western Herbs Into the Traditional Chinese and Ayurvedic Systems" was just that: a book on Western herbs, used according to Chinese and Ayurvedic principles. As someone trained in Chinese herbology, while I have a great love for the principles and system of Chinese medicine and believe it can be applied to anyone anywhere in the world since it is based on natural laws, I have lately been drawn to using local, or at least American, herbs instead of Chinese. It makes sense to me that the plants available in our own region would be best suited for our healing, just as local and seasonal foods are the healthiest for us. I hoped this book would use Western herbs according to the Chinese system.Instead, many of the herbs in this book are Chinese and Ayurvedic, mixed in with western herbs. The formulas, too, contain a combination of Asian and Western herbs. To me, this simply confuses the picture. Yes, the meridian and organs that western herbs enter are given. And they are placed in broad categories, though even here I find the same east-west mix, with some of the categories ("Surface-relieving") being Chinese, and others ("Emmenagogues") being western. But as far as, say, categorizing Western herbs according to Chinese or Ayurvedic properties, or taking a Chinese or Ayurvedic pattern of disharmony and offering a formula to address it using western herbs, that does not happen in this book.Therefore, while good basic information is given for each herb, this book did not serve the purpose I had hoped for.

This is a wonderful book by one of the best-known old time American herbalists. I hear Dr. Shook referred to again and again in my herbal studies at the School of Natural Healing, founded by Dr. John Christopher, another great old-time herbalist. The book is in the form of lessons, which were based on a lecture series. Each lesson introduces different herbs as well as preparations and formulas that include those herbs. Many of the preparations and formulas are quite simple (this being an Elementary Treatise, but also because there is no need to complicate something when it works well). Dr. Shook also includes some questions after each lesson to self-test your grasp of the material, with answers provided after the following lesson.What I like best is the conversational style of Dr. Shook. He speaks to the reader like a friend or esteemed colleague, sharing lore and experience. His love and respect for herbal medicine is infectious (no pun intended!) Like every herbalist, Dr. Shook had his favorite herbs, and many of those he favors are quite well known. A few others, however, were unfamiliar to me.There are 20 lessons, and if one read a lesson per day, preparing one or more of the formulas for each lesson, you could acquire a considerable foundation in herbology in about 3 weeks, as well as a medicine cabinet full of remedies for common situations.There is a second volume, Advanced Treatise in Herbology, which is twice as long as this book and which you should definitely get for a more thorough treatment of herbal medicine.

These 100 percent cotton sheets and pillowcases are perfect for me. The texture is smooth without being slippery. The fabric feels substantial. I love the clean, fresh appearance of white sheets. Comes with top sheet, fitted sheet, and two pillowcases. The pillowcases snugly fit queen-sized pillows without extra fabric flopping around. These are basic, well-made, all-cotton sheets at a reasonable price.

I absolutely love this planner. And where planners are concerned, I'm very hard to please! I can never seem to find one that suits my planning style, that has a design I won't tire of, or what-have-you. This one is perfect for me.First of all, "Beautiful Day" is a very apt name for this planner, as it is really lovely, from the matte, suede-like violet cover to the floral pages within. Each season's calendar pages are a different color, with a subtle watercolor flowered design.I like the way the cover partially covers the metal wire binding. This will prevent the binding from getting bent or damaged, which has happened to me with some other binders with the metal binding fully exposed, after being carried and knocked around for some months. This one looks like it will hold up.Labeled tabs make it easy to flip to the desired month. Opening to a month first takes you to a 2-page spread of the entire month at a glance, with lines to record the major events of that month. That makes it easy to see in one glance which days are booked and which are free for events, vacations, etc.After that is a two-page spread for each week, with space from top to bottom for each day. The day's space is divided into hours from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m., with plenty of space for recording scheduled activities. That's one of the things I love about this planner: it gives ample space to actually write! And, the spaces are lined, unlike some planners which just leave an open block to write in. I find the lines encourage me to write more neatly; if there's just an empty space, I tend to scrawl. Saturday and Sunday are each given half the space of the weekdays, with lines but without an hourly breakdown.The planner goes from January to January. If, like me, you have found yourself needing to schedule things for early in the year without having next year's planner yet (or not wanting to carry two planners around, or scribble notes all over the December page), you will appreciate this. I can schedule January 2017 while still using my 2016 planner, and then simply transfer those items to the new planner.After the calendar pages, there are 4 pages for contacts, 6 pages for notes, and a one-page Event Calendar with a space for each month. Finally, there is a one-page Holiday List giving the dates for a large number of holidays (including Canada and Mexico!) from 2016 through 2019. It's helpful to have these all in one place so you don't have to flip through the planner to find them. This includes things like Daylight Savings Time, for which I would never know where to look if I had to flip through the calendar to find it.One reviewer commented on the need to copy everything from the contacts page to a new planner the following year, since the pages aren't removable. Well, this just isn't that kind of planner, and most in this price range aren't. There are plenty of Day Runner-type planners with removable pages that cost a fortune. The covers alone can cost several times what this planner costs, without even adding pages.A very attractive, very functional planner. It's uplifting to just look at it!

Based on the title, I thought this was a votive candle, though the fine print does say it uses tea lights. So rather than a votive candle burning down and glowing from within, the little tea candle sits in the uppermost part of the candle holder, where its flame always remains visible. The candle holder has a matte, snow white finish, a subtle gold rim around the top, a somewhat chunky style, and the quality Lenox is known for.The pretty raised design, of Santa in his sleigh pulled by reindeer, wraps all the way around the candle holder so that part of the design is visible from any direction. It would be an attractive part of a greenery centerpiece, on a mantle, a side table, or anywhere.The price and size make it a perfect hostess gift, or a gift for your child's favorite teacher. Goes with any decor. Very pleasing tea light holder!

In our family we play a lot of games, and the age gap is fairly wide. What I like about this game versus Scrabble or Boggle is that building upwards instead of just two-dimensionally gives the younger kids a better chance of forming words. Their vocabularies may be more limited and so they are often frustrated in other word games when they play against older opponents because they can't make as many words. This game kind of "levels the field" while remaining challenging as well as exciting. Great game.

We are big board-game players in our house, but playing at the dining room table (the only suitable space) has always presented certain problems. Only one person gets the board facing them, and trying to turn it around causes pieces to get moved, etc. Someone always has the most uncomfortable seat. Someone is always too short for the table. So a certain amount of time is spent adjusting all this while trying to focus on the game.I was kind of reluctant to get this game set, as my 14-year-old is a bit too obsessed with his X-Box One, and I have a knee-jerk prejudice against anything high-tech, always being staunchly loyal to the old-fashioned or low-tech version of anything. Then it dawned on me: not only would this game pack solve some of the problems of playing at the table, but it would also involve the whole family and draw my son out of XBox-Isolation!It's great for everyone to be able to find their comfy spot in the living room and all be able to see the whole game from the same perspective. Great family fun with some classic games. I'm glad we found this!

I purchased this for my 14 year old son. His friends bought similar unicorn masks at the mall, and they all decided to wear the same thing as a group for trick-or-treating. I wasn't going to have time before Halloween to make a trip to the mall, so I ordered this using Amazon Prime. My son loves it! I was worried it wouldn't fit; he's 6'2" and has a big head and thick hair. However, it fit perfectly. It is both hilarious and creepy at the same time. All the sculpted features-- the nose/mouth, ears, horn-- stand out just as they should without flopping. He wore it riding in the car with the windows down and turned a lot of heads. Makes an instant costume. This mask really saved his Halloween!

I really like these shelf liner rolls. I won't be using them in the fridge, but in my china cabinet, glass cabinet, and the cupboards where my pots and pans are. I like the fact that they come in rolls, which means no unsightly folds or creases and they lay flatter on the shelf. I also like the fact that they have a different coordinating pattern on each side. I have a set of vintage Johnson Brothers dinnerware in the "Friendly Village" pattern that has some red in the pattern. We only use it during the Christmas season, so all year it sits in my china cabinet, marking up the finished oak shelves. This shelf liner will match the red in the china pattern and protect my shelves. I will also be using it in the cupboards where I keep glassware, for protection from breakage but also to keep the rim of upside-down glasses clean. Nice product.

My 12 year old daughter devoured this book. These are her thoughts. "The story gives a strong example of family love through several generations. In the book, a girl fulfills her destiny, which she found in a dream, to save a place her family loves. The town had a community that really cared for each other, and they also showed a special respect for the dead in the graveyard. The book was well-written and kept my attention all the way through." She is pleased to discover that the author, Natalie Lloyd, wrote a previous book, "A Snicker of Magic," which we will certainly purchase. Great story!

This lovely Lenox Winter Greetings utensil crock with sturdy wooden servers will really add a festive touch to your kitchen this holiday season. Place this on your kitchen counter and it says "it's Christmas cookie baking time!" It's the same great quality I've come to expect from Lenox, and the crisp colors stand out brightly on the snowy background.This would be a great gift for so many people. Among those I can think of: my kids' godmothers, Sunday school teachers, aunts, grandmother...possibly with a cookie recipe and ingredients tucked inside... would be a popular item for all those holiday raffles you're asked to donate to. The men in my family also cook, and this item is not too "feminine" to give to a male chef.With its classic red, green, and white color scheme, the holly and the ribbon, this crock and utensil set will blend right in with any holiday decor. Love it!

This is the best chocolate I have even eaten, hands down. And I've been given a lot of chocolate in my day, being a member of a family of foodies and inveterate chocolate lovers.First of all, it arrives at your door packed in a fitted heavy outer cardboard box to protect the precious contents. Nestled inside that is the cello-wrapped chocolate box itself. Around this, as a hint of delights to come, is a ribbon attaching a little colored booklet containing a photo and description (in English and French) of each type of candy in the box. Have you ever bitten into a chocolate without knowing what was inside and winced because it wasn't what you expected? Well, this little booklet solves that problem-- or WOULD solve it, if it wasn't for the fact that you will love EVERY kind of chocolate in this box!Once past the plastic, the next part of the ritual is to break a sealed sticker that assures the box has been reserved just for you. Then, on one side of the box, you press a little opening with your finger, which pushes the box containing the chocolates, drawer-like, out the other side.Lift the paper covering the chocolates, and the moment you have been waiting for has finally arrived."Silken" is the word that comes to mind when I eat these chocolates. First of all, they are visually beautiful and perfect. But the proof is in the pudding. Biting into one reveals them to be delicate, rich yet understated, and yes, silken, with melt-in-your-mouth chocolate combined with just enough other special ingredients to make each one a unique experience.The names of the different chocolates are as evocative as their descriptions in the little booklet. Some of the delights you will sample includeMidnight Delight: "a crisp dark chocolate shell reveals a velvety heart of tempting dark ganache."Dark Lemonette: "Rich cocoa center with a delicate hint of lemon, decorated with a fine arabesque."Mocca Gianduja: "Rich, coffee heart embraced by smoothly melting gianduja with a light cocoa note."Those are the only ones of the 11 varieties that I am going to reveal! You'll just have to wait and wonder about the rest...These chocolates are a little pricey, but they are completely worthy of any special event you might think of: as corporate gifts, a gift for that important person you want to impress but don't know what to give, Valentine's Day, Christmas, or any occasion. Everyone who has sampled these (and believe me, it was not easy to share) has agreed 100 percent that these chocolates rate the highest possible number of stars.

The workmanship on this shirt is excellent. The buttons are all sewn on tightly, the stitching is precise. The check pattern is nice and clear, and the fabric is substantial and thereby avoids the see-through look of some white shirts. In fact, compared with some other oxford shirts with the same pattern/color scheme, this one is quite bright. The fit IS a tad "trim" as the description states (I missed that when ordering!). But to me the main issue is, the fabric is a bit stiff. Hoping it will soften a bit with wear and washings. Not sure how it can be "100 percent Polyester, 100 Percent Cotton" as the description states! It's actually 60% cotton, 40% poly. Which may account for the stiffness; that's a high percentage of polyester, but as another reviewer pointed out, that will help avoid excessive wrinkles. A good quality, serviceable shirt for a reasonable price.

I considered buying "Spilling Ink" instead of this book based on some of the reviews, especially one that stated the buyer had tried all the other young writers' books and liked that one best. But as I skimmed through it online, I felt it had a jaded quality. I also concurred with one reviewer who thought it had some harsh topics and language to which her children had not been exposed, and I certainly did not want that. So I went with this one. Its title, cover, unpretensiousness, and lack of "attitude" appealed to me and seemed a better fit for my daughter.I am so glad I did. It fits my daughter's interests, personality, and writing style so much more. It's not trying to turn her into a young sophisticate; it is geared toward bringing out the magic, wistfulness, creativity, and wonder in a young writer's heart. My 12 year old will be receiving this for Christmas along with a special journal and other writing supplies.I know she will love it.

This scanner is great. It doesn't really come with much of a manual, so it took some time for me to figure out how to use it. I would use it to scan book ISBN codes in order to inventory the books on Amazon Seller, or to search for the book on the internet, or within Amazon, to find its value. Really, all you have to do is have its little dongle receiver plugged into a USB port, have Amazon's search function open, or have a search engine open, with the cursor within the search bar, press the trigger and scan a bar code. The ISBN code is automatically pasted into the search bar, and the search brings up whatever data is available.It can also be used to check inventory, and various other purposes.It is implied that it works with cellphones, but a closer reading of the scanty manual seems to indicate that it only works with Windows phones.It will also send the barcode number into other applications. For instance, if you set it on the store setting (using the handy barcode card provided; the scanner has no controls other than the trigger) it will store a large number of numbers scanned from barcodes, and then when you do the upload (again with that card) it can upload the data into a word processor, or spreadsheet, with line returns so that the data is entered vertically in a column.Aside from the fact that it was hard to figure out how to use it from the manual, I like it very much. It is quick, accurate, and fun to use, and if I knew what some of the other functions listed in the manual were, I could probably find other uses for it. Alas, the manual doesn't tell you what they are, so you'd have to either guess from the title of the function, or do some research on it. I could not find a website for the scanner, but maybe someone else has, and maybe there would be more useful info there...? I'd like to be able to use this with my iPhone at book sales.It came charged, and charges via the usb port of the computer, but could also be charged with a usb charger adapter. It seems to hold a charge for a good long time.It wills stand on its own, but precariously. The handle has a flat bottom, but it is narrow. I would only want to do this if I wanted to leave it standing and pass barcodes in front of it, but, you still have to pull the trigger, so what's the point of having it stand by itself. I'd just lay it on its side.

I seem to be in the minority here, but I am not as enamored of this laptop cooling fan as most other reviewers are.The fan does not mount well universally to all laptops. On mine, the plate in one position will block the laptop's fan air intake, in another position, the plate is blocked by the laptop's rubber foot. So, I was not able to get a perfect mounting position.Also, the fan uses the laptop USB for power, which would seem to add an electrical load to the laptop, making it run even hotter, so does this balance out, cooling what would not be so hot if the fan were not plugged in? Perhaps one could plug it into an adapter rather than the laptop, IF you have an adapter. It doesn't come with one.At a median speed, it does not seem too loud. Once mounted, I could feel warm air exiting the fan, which seems to indicate that it is cooling the laptop. At a higher speed it is pretty loud.I was not able to get a really secure seal between the laptop and the silicone "lip" due to the awkwardness of the positioning in order to avoid the rubber "foot," but it seemed to be fine as long as the laptop didn't move. It is nice to be able to remove the fan easily by sliding it off of its mounting plate.I'm not positive there is a true advantage to using this fan, but I am guessing there is a little advantage. To me, the results simply were not as dramatic as I'd hoped.

I bought my daughter the $49.95 Kindle Fire for Christmas along with the Amazon Fire Case. The case had already been shipped when I was offered this NuPro Fire case for free in exchange for an unbiased review. I thought, great, I'll return the Amazon case and let her use this!I am sooo glad I did not do that. This case is a real disappointment. First, the cover for her Kindle Paperwhite (also a low-end cover) is made of similar material and got really scratched and torn up fairly quickly with normal use. This case feels cheap and bulky compared with the Amazon case.Second, this case simply does NOT stand. It just flops over annoyingly often. And when you fold the stand, you have to expose the inside lining of the case to the table surface, which means, when you close the case again, anything that may have been on the table could now be directly on the screen of your Kindle Fire: crumbs, a dab of butter, etc. These $49.95 Kindle Fires are being marketed for kids, so this could be an issue.The third problem is obvious right from the start: it ONLY stands in landscape mode, not portrait mode. That's a major drawback. Especially for reading Kindle books.Lastly, this lacks the auto-sleep function of the Amazon case. That function is really such a convenience. It seems like a small issue, but when you use the Kindle Fire a lot, pressing the on/off button repeatedly becomes a pain. With the auto-sleep function, you never have to close the case and then wonder whether you turned it off or not, and this NuPro case does not have that.Since the Kindle Fires this case was made for cost a mere $49.95, don't stint the extra $10 bucks for the Amazon case which is so much better. We're talking a ten dollar difference between this NuPro case and the Amazon one which has many features this one lacks. I love the Amazon case I got for my Kindle Fire HD 8. It is slim and trim, folds quickly and crisply to stand the Kindle Fire in either position, has auto-sleep, and is made of better materials.  I am so glad I held onto the Amazon case I ordered for my daughter's Kindle Fire because I will NOT be giving her this NuPro case!

This light is excellent. The floodlight feature has 2 brightness settings, one bright, another VERY bright. It also has a flasher for emergency use on a dark road.It has an adjustable stand, which seems to work pretty well. It didn't get as tight as I would have liked, but the light stayed in place without flopping over. I can imagine that if I were using it while working on something that required me to move it a lot, I'd have to be occasionally readjusting the positioning of the stand. It has a carrying handle which allows you to carry it sort of like a lantern, which is nice, but you can carry it by the body since the light doesn't seem to get hot.It came partly charged, and it didn't take too long to get it fully charged.I am very happy with the light, and look forward to the difficult applications, such as working under a car in the dark when usually I can barely see anything, and my former trouble light is difficult to position in a useful way.It is light enough to carry, too, so if a kid wanted a bright light for the walk home from a late football game, or for Halloween, it would definitely work for that. It would also be great for camping trips, fishing trips, power outages, hunting for things in the dark corners of my attic or garage, as a workroom light...the possibilities are endless.I think it's incredible that this can be used to charge mobile devices as well! What is worse in an emergency than a dead cellphone battery! I'll be keeping this unit charged and ready to go in my car.

Everything about this watch is BIG! You will definitely have to be a fairly large person to carry off a watch of this size.It's an attractive watch and works well. Though it would look best on a larger man, I think most men will still have to remove some links. Note: the edges of the watch face where the incised grooves are (at each of the hours) are a bit sharp, sharp enough to scratch and possibly to snag clothing.Some features I like:1. the tachymeter for measuring speed.2. It's waterproof to 330 feet.3. The subdials and date window.4. The substantial feel.5. The burnished gold color.The packaging for the watch I received is black faux leather with red lettering, not yellow as in the photo. The packaging is kind of overkill, but your recipient will be wowed as they open layer after layer to reveal the treasure within: First is a heavy outer cardboard box. This opens to reveal some fancy patterned tissue paper hinting at something precious beneath. Within that is the large faux leather presentation box, with a decorative rippled design and stitching. Inside that is padded white faux suede holding the watch. A little cloth covers the watch, while inside the box's lid is a pocket stuffed with instructions, warranty, extended warranty offer, owner's manual, etc.The attractive watch and snazzy presentation would make this a great gift.

I wish I knew before buying this that her protocol involved trying to convince my physician to perform certain tests and prescribe metformin. This was not what I expected. I expected a more natural approach. I cannot believe that her "solution" is to take a pharmaceutical for the rest of my life. I know there are alternatives to that. I am very disappointed.

My daughter has a dog-walking business, and it's nice for her to have healthy treats to offer them to distract and calm them when sticky situations crop up. She tried these on a pair of corgis she walks every day, and they loved them! She walks them around the neighborhood and then to a wooded area where she lets them rest and sniff around on their own. They have a habit of barking at another dog they meet just before getting to those woods. Using the Nylabone, she distracted the corgis till they got to their usual stopping place, where she was able to reward them with these treats for not barking. As others have noted, they don't last long, but they serve their purpose! They loved the taste.

I got this for my 6'2" fashion-conscious 14-year-old. He's big enough to wear a watch of this size, and this watch is BIG. My son has a penchant for black clothing and so this watch goes well with everything he owns. He also has a penchant for walking in the rain, so the waterproof feature is a plus. The watch arrived in a bulky, black cube-shaped presentation box, pre-set and ready to go. I feel that this watch looks much more expensive than it is (based on the current $59.55 price, NOT the absurd $550 price). Which is a good thing because he's lost every watch he ever owned. It's very eye-catching without being gaudy. This will be a Christmas gift and I know just what he'll say when he opens it: "Sick!!!" This is a personal note, but as a mythology fan, he will love the model name, "Neptune," and the little trident on the watch face. I'm very pleased with this watch!

This is a wonderful game. Very challenging, great for occupying time while waiting in a doctor's office or any other time. The goal is to make each of the sides the same color, which is not as easy as it looks! The parts move smoothly, which is important for enhancing the enjoyment of the game. My 12 and 14 year olds are enjoying this! Requires strategy and patience.

These credit card sleeves and passport holder are really attractive! I love the colors and patterns. In addition to the security issue these are designed to prevent, they also protect the electronic strip on my credit cards and bank cards from getting worn and scratched.There are other uses for these as well. They make pretty, decorative holders for gift cards. My daughter is using one for her library card. They're very sturdy and hold up well. They don't take up much space in my wallet. Very nice set.

With two adolescents always borrowing my electronic devices, I am constantly charging things and we go through a lot of cords, especially with my kids' rough handling. I've been using this Kash Technology cord for awhile now for both my iPad and iPhone, and it's standing the test of time very well. The cords that came with those devices quickly broke and frayed at the point of attachment. This cord has taken a lot of abuse and still seems brand new. Highly recommend for all your Apple devices.

This is a swell little desk caddy. I like the compact size, but despite the small size it holds a lot. The mesh is quite sturdy, and I like that you can see through it, which makes finding things easy. The variety of spaces gives you a lot of options for what to store here. I'm using the drawer to tidy up our pile of USB cables. I home school my daughter and am a tutor, so there are always pens and pencils lying around. I was previously using a little basket for these items, but this desk organizer keeps everything separate and in its proper place. There are 4 sections deep enough for pens, pencils, rulers, or scissors; three small shallow sections for things like paper clips, stamps, etc., and one longer shallow section I am using for a scotch tape dispenser, plus the drawer. It's easy to rinse this under the faucet if it starts to collect dust, and it dries quickly and easily.

These are wonderful socks! I received them at a reduced price in exchange for an honest review, but after trying them out, I definitely think they are a bargain and would happily buy them again. They are really high quality socks at a very reasonable price. My daughter, aged 12, wears a size 9 to 9.5 and these are very comfortable for her. There is plenty of elasticity to them. She ice skates a lot at the local rink, and these will keep her feet warm on the ice. She is thrilled with them. The wintry patterns remind me of snowflakes. They'd make great stocking stuffers. Very pleased.

First of all, my kids and I agree that these Teriyaki Beef Steak bites are definitely NOT tender. In fact, they're kind of chewy. In a way, that makes them more satisfying because they last longer, which is a good thing, because, at 70 calories per three smallish pieces, I don't want to consume too many of these, which I would definitely do if they went down too easily.My 12 year old daughter (the most adventurous eater in the family who likes venison, beef heart, and snails) could take them or leave them. The real revelation was when my 14 year old son's face lit up at first bite. An inquisitive lad with very eclectic interests, when it comes to food his tastes are extremely pedestrian and narrow. He refuses to eat anything served in the school cafeteria, and for his lunches packed from home, he will eat only three things: fried chicken, rotisserie chicken, and plain turkey sandwiches with nothing else but ketchup, on white bread or rolls only. For snacks, he will only eat cookies, crackers, etc. Believe me, I have packed many a healthy, varied lunch for him, only to learn that he either traded it for junk, or else literally didn't eat all day rather than let salad, whole wheat bread, or fruit pass his lips. The fact that he loves these Jack Links gives me another snack alternative for him beyond junky baked goods. And, they actually taste pretty good! I don't usually like teriyaki, but I liked these. He LOVES them.Now, don't get me wrong, these are NOT health food. They contain sugar, hydrolized corn solids, potassium sorbate as a preservative, and, perhaps most troubling of all, MSG. (Hence the 4 stars instead of 5). So this is not something anyone should be eating on a daily basis. Also, they are, I think, quite expensive, and there's not a whole lot in the bag. But as an occasional high-protein snack that is fairly satisfying to eat, they have their place.

This is a lovely book that gives an intimate look at a truly holistic model of therapy and client interaction. I was trained in the Worsley school of 5 Element acupuncture, and am now completing Master Herbalist certification. My next step is certification in the Bach Flower remedies. But this book can enrich one's practice of virtually any healing art which aims to address wounds of the soul and psyche along with physical ailments. The detailed client questionnaire in the back, while designed to steer you toward specific Bach remedies, could serve, if adapted, as a wonderful model of the kind of questioning that could lead to effective treatment in any holistic modality. The author also gives advice for short and long term treatment protocols.I only wish there were lots and lots more case histories, because I didn't want this book to end!

We go through a lot of water bottles in our house, especially my 12 year old daughter who is very athletic and is always bringing bottles of water, juice, or smoothies to her dance class or games--and and then leaving them there. So I liked the idea of an 8-pack of bottles. My husband refuses to drink anything stored in plastic, and likes to keep some chilled water on hand, so these will be handy. So I was excited to be offered these bottles in exchange for an honest review.The first problem was, they were packed in a smaller box inside a larger box, the smaller box arrived opened and upside-down, and one of the bottles had smashed. So I have a lot of glass chips and glass dust to clean up.The second problem is, the caps are really flimsy plastic. They bend easily in my hand and I can imagine they will not hold up well to repeated washings. They just don't seem really snug. They are also completely smooth, which means you can't get any grip on them at all with your hands, so tightening them or loosening them is a bit frustrating. I wish they were stiffer plastic with some texture so that they could be gripped more easily.The glass seems cheap; the seams are visible, and the glass appears to be of inconsistent thickness. Time will tell how easily they break.I do like the inclusion of the bottle brush. That was a thoughtful touch which will make it easier to keep these really clean.

Wow, I really dislike the smell of this cat food! But my cat seems to like it. We have dry food available all day, and then put out wet food for her in the evening. We've found that if we put it out during the day, it just sits there in the bowl, but if we put it out later, she makes multiple nocturnal trips to the bowl and it is gone by morning. The price is a little bit high compared to other brands we commonly purchase in the supermarket, but still reasonable. Our cat is definitely a sauce lover, usually licking the sauce up first and going back for the chunks later. I like the flavor assortment, as our cat has never liked beef cat food in any form. Which makes sense; when would a cow or a steer ever be a cat's natural prey? The lack of grains also makes it a little closer to a cat's natural diet of meat.

Got this for my history-buff 14 year old son who has a dry sense of humor much like the author's. He reads it at the breakfast table before school and can't resist reading me passage after passage-- when he can stop laughing, that is. I think it helps that he knows at least some of the historical figures mentioned from other sources. Gotta buy the paperback edition because the footnotes are integral to the humor (all based on history!) and they are harder to access on the Kindle. Looking forward to Cuppy's other works.

Bragg's organic, unrefined, unfiltered , first cold pressed extra virgin olive oil is the absolute best and most reliable, consistent product. It has a very fresh, green taste. I have never purchased a Bragg product that was not first rate. The bottle in front of me says that it includes oil from a 100 year old olive tree in Greece! It even shows the tree's photo! The label also gives interesting health information. My local health food store is usually something of a rip-off, but they have this oil at $18.99, a few dollars less than Amazon's current price of $23. But it's still worth it even at that price, and it's nice to have a big bottle to use liberally. I've replaced all the butter in my diet with this Olive Oil.

This is the second volume I have purchased by this author. I am an herbalist and have often been surprised when, on walks through the woods when I encounter intriguing mosses, lichens, Indian pipes, etc., I realize I know nothing of their medicinal uses. For a long time I assumed they had none, until a book on the history of western herbalism clued me in to the fact that they do, in fact, have uses. That book gave scanty practical information, though.So I was pleased to discover this volume on ancient medicinal remedies. It gives a lot of little-known information on these ancient remedies as they were and are used by Native Americans in our own country, as well as in other parts of the world. The author includes a lot of historical information on each form of primitive vegetation included, as well as anecdotes and clinical experiences of other practitioners, including personality traits and spiritual aspects associated with each remedy. The book really breaks new ground and makes a unique contribution to herbal literature.However, the book suffers from a few problems:The first is, disorganization. The reader has to work awfully hard to figure out which member of the genus or family the author is talking about. For example, under Club Moss, numerous variations are listed, and throughout that chapter, the author switches back and forth from one to another instead of describing each in an ordered, systematic way. In a book on medicine, it's important to keep this information straight so as not to confuse one remedy for another.Second, the lack of clear separations between the chapters, the varieties of typeface, and the lack of paragraph indenting make the book hard on the eye, as the material seems to all run together.Third, the book is a little uneven. The types of information given for each remedy are inconsistent; for example, chemical composition is given for some but not others, and so forth.Fourth, the almost total lack of footnotes. There is a bibliography, but it lists literally hundreds of books that I seriously doubt were all used for this particular volume. In fact, the other book I own by this author uses the identical bibliography, and I suspect it is used in all his books, and therefore isn't helpful in figuring out what sources he used to research the present work. The lack of footnoting is very unhelpful because it leaves the reader unable to either verify or follow up on the material. Various Native American tribes and their usage of these remedies is mentioned throughout; I'd like to be able to delve into that more. And various other herbalists offer their experiences and perspectives on these remedies; where did these come from? We are not told.In short, this book and the others by this author, while containing a wealth of information, appear hastily put together and poorly edited. If the organization was cleaned up and the information properly footnoted, this would become a first-rate series.

This is the best salad dressing I have ever used. The olive oil is SO fruity and fresh-tasting. Everything in this bottle is organic and of the highest quality.
