Any other bottled dressing tastes stale to me after using Bragg's, and making dressing from scratch can be time consuming. But I feel great about everything in this bottle. It is SO flavorful, yet contains only simple, natural ingredients. It goes to show what quality ingredients can taste like without all sorts of additives. They have a Ginger and Sesame Dressing as well which I must try!

I received a review copy of this book for free in exchange for an honest review. I selected it with my 12 year old daughter in mind, as she loves fantasy, loves to write, has a best friend with whom she is involved in a lot of creative endeavors, and so I thought this would right be up her alley.Although our uncorrected proof did not have the graphics (it did contain descriptions of the graphics which will appear in each section), my daughter rates it at 5 stars. She felt the plot was extremely creative, and liked the way Libby, the missing girl, used the Princess X story she and her friend May had created together when they were younger as a call for help, using clues only May would understand. She liked how someone they did not know helped capture the antagonist, and return Libby to her best friend May. She found it held her attention throughout.She would rate it 5 stars, but I took off one stars because of two concerns. First, there are two instances of swearing in the book. But more importantly, I am disturbed that so many recent books for this age range include a tragic and disturbing scenario-- in this case (spoiler alert), a man kills Libby's parents and kidnaps her to replace his own daughter who is dead. For a 12 year old, I find such a distressing plot device to be unnecessary. Yes, my daughter liked the book-- but I'm not thrilled with her becoming inured to stories of parricide and kidnapping. She hears enough about such things just by living in the modern world. Yes, there are other compelling aspects to the story-- the power of friendship and the meaningful bond created between the two friends through the Princess X character and how it ultimately leads to a semi-happy ending. But I feel about this book the same way about James and the Giant Peach by Roald Dahl: there too, the parents are killed right off the bat, and the "happy ending" has James living with a bunch of friendly insects. Both endings left me with a bit of a heartache.I LOVE the plot device of the Princess X character created by May and Libby. Very unique! I just wish it were used to resolve a less disturbing scenario.

It's hard to review this product because my cat won't eat it. Another reviewer mentioned that it has almost no smell-- I agree, and that's a plus for humans perhaps, but might result in not enticing a cat to try it. Or maybe it's just not my cat's cup of tea. Cats are all individuals with individual tastes.As far as nutritional content, I applaud the absence of grains, and not only because they are potential allergens. Grains are simply not something a cat would ever choose to eat. They only do so when the grains are flavored by other ingredients. But then again, most of the ingredients in this product would never be naturally eaten by cats, such as peas and potatoes.Which brings me to the reason I give this three stars. There are SO many nutrients listed, such as vitamins, minerals, probiotics and various plant extracts, that it seems like the shotgun approach. I can't imagine that there can be much of any one of these in this food. I mean, come on, Green Tea and Spearmint extracts are at the bottom of a list of about 50 ingredients. How much can there actually be in this food? There's more canola oil in this product than the Duck which features so prominently on the label. Canola oil is a very unhealthy oil. It is genetically modified and has been shown in numerous studies to have many health risks.I think we as pet owners are making the mistake of thinking that what's good for humans must be good for our pets, and the more supplements we can cram in there, even if each is in such a time amount as to probably be ineffectual, we have "covered our bases." Most of the items in this food are things that are not a natural part of a cat's diet.Why can't someone make a cat food that contains, simply, what a cat in nature would choose to eat? The animals the cat would naturally hunt, and the kinds of greens they would naturally nibble? On a trip to Ireland I noticed cans of Squirrel and Rabbit cat food on the shelves. Why not here?I am glad some people's pets enjoy this product, and have appeared to be healthier for it. But I can't agree that this is "optimum wellness" for a cat.

I use a lot of fresh-squeezed lemon juice in cooking but always dread squeezing the lemons. No matter what method I use, it seems to be messy and inefficient.This Superjuicer has changed all that. This product has good, old-fashioned quality; you can feel that it was made to last for years. It's very heavy and sturdy, which is necessary to survive squeezing lemon after lemon.This tool keeps your hands virtually free of lemon juice. No more picking seeds out of the juice. Just pop in a lemon half, give it a good squeeze, and the juice comes out of the 7 holes in the bottom into your cup, leaving the seeds and peel behind. Just open it up and drop the lemon seeds and peel into the compost, garbage disposal, trash, or whatever. All you need to do to wash it is just rinse it off, but it IS dishwasher safe. The silicone coating on the handles is non-slip and makes gripping the Superjuicer completely comfortable.It makes an annoying job so easy. I will never be tempted to use bottled lemon juice just to avoid squeezing lemons again. Great product. I received this product free in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.

A great idea, though I'd seen similar attempts by others on the internet before I heard if this author. It's a concept I thought would appeal to my 14 year old pop-music-fanatic son who has an appreciation for Shakespeare. The sonnets are cleverly written and have an authentic Bardic ring to them. The book is aesthetically pleasing, with its archaic-looking typeface and illustrations. It's a convenient size to carry in order to regale your friends. The tongue-in-cheek introduction gives us the "history" of Shakespeare's sonnets which purportedly "inspired" pop songs. So far so good.However, there are two problems with the book.The first can't be helped, since this IS a book of "Shakespearean Spins" on pop songs, with a Shakespearean meter to match. But to me, the Shakespearean versions lose some of their humor when you can't sing them to the original music. They don't fit, and so the book is a bit more cerebral and a bit less fun.Second, the author cast his net wide and the choices of pop songs span generations and styles. That means, unless you are a "person of a certain age" who nonetheless listens to current pop music, or someone younger who has dug deep and appreciates pop music of bygone eras along with current hits, there will be a fair number songs in this book with which the reader will be unfamiliar. That, too, takes away the fun and makes the book's audience a little fuzzy. But there is a generous number of sonnets in the book. And the real fun, for me, is the way the book elevates the pop artists' work to a higher level. But you pretty much have to know the pop lyrics by heart to fully appreciate these "spins."

We have a small family and for years I have blindly bought the cheapest individual rolls of toilet paper in the store, deceived by the high number of "sheets" per roll and the length of the roll. Despite the need to use excessive amounts of this cheap paper due to the fact that it tears easily and doesn't absorb a lot, I kept buying the same thing.Finally I bought Quilted Northern "Soft and Strong" toilet paper on sale, and discovered that we needed to use dramatically less paper. However, the "soft" feature caused the paper to leave behind little bits which hardly seemed clean.I had the opportunity to try this Charmin Ultra Strong paper for free, and it's fantastic. Strong enough so you don't waste sheet after sheet, and it leaves behind NO maddening little bits of paper. The price is only slightly above $1 a roll, which is what I was paying for my cheap store brand, and is cheaper than other "strong" brands in my local store, so I need look no further. I have converted and will buy this brand from now on. Getting it delivered free with Amazon Prime is another plus-- no shipping, and no lugging it home from the store!

Our whole family uses the XBox One to watch movies on our widescreen TV. It can be maddeningly slow to use the XBox controller to hunt-and-peck each individual letter on the screen to search for a movie or TV show. I have always been stunned that something as high tech as the XBox couldn't find a better way. This keyboard installed quickly and easily and has solved that problem, making searching for movies, TV shows, or youtube videos much quicker and easier.My son, who uses the XBox primarily for gaming, does not like it as much. The keyboard makes the controller a bit awkward to hold, which interferes a bit with gaming (he says), and since it attached to the headphone portal, he can't use his headphones and the keyboard at the same time. So he can't really use it to speed up his chat on the XBox while playing a game. But it's not a big deal; he removes the keyboard when he plays games, and we reattach it when we gather around to watch a movie. Hopefully it will hold up despite the detaching/attaching.Great concept, and it does what it's meant to do. There really isn't any better way to add a keyboard to the XBox controller, and the fact that it's removable gives us the best of both worlds. It does need an audio jack to make it fully functional.

I am thrilled with this battery-operated pepper mill. I have a problem with chronic pain, and while I prefer fresh-ground pepper, it can be difficult for me to use hand-operated grinders which I have to repeatedly twist. With this mill, with the press of a button I can grind just the right amount. I love the transparent compartment for the pepper so you can see how much you have left.A fun thing about this mill is the ability to create your own seasoning combinations of different kinds of peppers, salts, seeds, and herbs. I have several favorite combinations that I am always hand-grinding in a mortar and pestle, and now I can do it in this mill instead. I love it!

This is a good, basic sleeping bag. While not warm enough for winter camping, it is warm enough for most situations. It rolls up to a very compact and portable size, easy to carry attached to your backpack for camping. We will be using this for sleepovers, summer camp, and local camping trips. The bag is a tad on the narrow side, so a very large person would not fit well, but it's plenty long. Nice smooth feel.

This is such a handy item with a multitude of uses. We make a lot of trips to local lakes, and it's always been a problem separating our wet towels and bathing suits for the trip home. With this bag, we can just stuff all the wet items into it and pop them in the laundry when we get home. My daughter also goes to camp and can use this as a dirty laundry sack. We have also used it to transport snorkeling equipment and goggles to various swimming places. It can also be used in the opposite way: to store dry clothing or other items in a wet environment, such as when boating or camping. Really handy!

This is an excellent quality exercise ball. My daughter, age 12, is a dancer and very athletic; she uses the ball for a variety of exercise routines and incorporated it into a dance routine she made up. She also uses it in the pool! It is very easy and quick to inflate with the enclosed pump, easy to clean, and stays inflated with no air leakage for a long time. Love it!

I'd give this book 5 stars for the author's first-rate analysis of the events and testimony pertaining to the Borden murders, sifting through thousands of pages of testimony to find striking contradictions and inconsistencies that no one else noticed or cared about. However, her style is so plodding and contrived that, while I forced myself to continue for the sake of the subject matter, I could only bear to read it in small bites. She describes certain characters in the book as confusing, dull, or long-winded in their testimony or letter-writing, yet the author really loves to hear her own voice and doesn't spare us any of it; her narrative is overly precious and she condescendingly addresses her readers as if we were hanging spellbound on her every word. Her style really mars what would otherwise be a great book. She also vacillates between rejecting her hometown of Fall River (which she left 40 years before writing this book) as possessing a mindset she cannot relate to, and using her familiarity with the attitudes of the town and her proximity to the Bordens to cast an air of authority over her book. Lastly, the Kindle edition (purchased August 2015) is rife with typos and grammatical and punctuation errors which render some passages incomprehensible. A cursory proofread would have been appreciated.

Great jeans and a real bargain at the $24.99 price tag. They are relaxed fit, but the extra bit of stretch adds even more comfort. I think the stretch feature will also help them wear longer, as the fabric at areas of stress will "give" rather than tear. They are "distressed" but not to the point of totally being torn and falling apart as some distressed jeans are; I really resent paying top dollar for pants that are already ripped! (When I was a kid that was a DIY job using scissors, repeated washings, and strategically-placed diluted bleach!). The fabric is a bit thin, but it makes them a comfortable choice for the transition from summer to fall. My high schooler loves them.

This Green Square Tray from the Mexican Kitchen line by Rick Bayless is very attractive. It was larger than I expected, measuring 14" across instead of 13" as in the listing, and it weighs a ton. It's very substantial! I'm not exactly sure what makes this especially "Mexican"; the color scheme, green glaze over terra cotta-colored stoneware, is somewhat rustic perhaps, but it's a more sophisticated take on Mexican pottery. As you can see in the photo, there is a central, flat square area of about 10". From there, there is a very slight 2" rise on each side, but at its deepest point, the tray is not more than 1/2" deep. Very shallow. At 5.2 pounds, this is rather heavy to function as a tray. I think of a tray as something that can be passed, holding appetizers or cocktails and so forth. This is more of a platter. In any case, you're not going to want to carry this around!I can imagine many uses for this tray/ platter. If we're thinking Mexican, it wouldn't work for things that need support to stand upright, like tacos in a crisp shell. But for tamales, nachos, burritos, empanadas, quesadillas, all sorts of appetizers, meats, anything that can lay flat, it is perfect.Rick Bayless has designed companion items for Gorham's Mexican Kitchen line including individual square bowls with the same glaze. A very nice, understated line which will showcase your culinary offerings. For lovers of different types of ethnic cuisine, the style is compatible with Asian or Spanish cuisine as well.

EL Spence's "Bear Heat" is an interesting addition to the paranormal romance genre, most specifically the shapeshifter sub-genre. For paranormal romance fans, this is a great book for these hot, restless summer nights.The main character Becky, lives in a small town and has a quiet, simple life. One day she finds a wounded bear in her backyard- definitely not a normal situation. However, her instincts tell her that the bear needs her help and he turns into a sexy man. Becky doesn't know if he'll love her or kill her. That's the story in a nutshell, but obviously, as with an EL Spence novel, there's so much more than a brief synopsis. I was pulled in immediately to this story and found Becky to be extremely likeable and relatable. If you're looking for a refreshing change of pace or something to make your summer nights sizzling, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend "Bear Heat."

Komura 420's "MILF Money" is a thrilling satirical novel. Another reviewer used "Tarantino Grindhouse" to describe the feel of this novel and they were spot on. I always thought pulp fiction was long gone, but then writers like Komura 420 come along with gems like "MILF Money."In "MILF Money," protagonist Anna Hanks, a MILF, must make several decisions very quickly after her husband is murdered in front of her. Anna is a kick ass, take no prisoners sort of heroine and she was so much fun to read about.If you're tired of the same old James Patterson sort of stuff out there, this will be a refreshing break for you. Highly recommended.

I've been wanting to learn a computer language for years and for one reason or another, never got around to it. A friend recommended Ray Yao's "Java: Java in 8 Hours" and I'm so glad that he did! Yao's book made it easy to pick up Java in 8 hours (or, broken down over the course of a few days for me). He writes clearly, concisely, and in simple steps.I've been wanting to develop an app and I think this may help me get on the right path!

Author Don Mardak has an interesting background in Christian mysticism. Couple that background with a talent for writing and you get "Armageddon and the 4th Timeline," a thriller with metaphysical, religious, and new age themes. The inherent beauty in this novel is its ability to reach a wide audience with its main themes. Fans of Vince Flynn, Tom Clancy, and Richard Bach will all find something to enjoy in "Armageddon and the 4th Timeline."The historical synopsis caught my attention. It was both heartening and disheartening- thousands of years of humanity and we've done so much, both incredibly good and incredibly bad. The main characters, Kathy and Eric were relatable and interesting. The stakes are tremendously high for them and you (along with the rest of humankind) are rooting for them to succeed. I love how Armageddon was across two planes (physical and spiritual). It seems that oftentimes Armegeddon is only talked about on a physical level because it feels more immediate, but there are so many spiritual elements and implications as well.If you don't believe me or all the other reviewers who obviously enjoyed this novel, Mardak's novel has won various awards, including silvers in the IBPA Benjamin Franklin Awards, among numerous other accolades. I highly recommend this!

I must admit that I was skeptical at first. There are so many cheap and shoddy books out there on this subject, as well as "How to Keep Your Man Excited" and so on. It can be very difficult to find a gem. Eugene Walker's "How to Catch a Cheater in 48 Hours or Less" is a diamond in the rough of all those titles out there. This book is the real deal.I thought it was interesting that there were more tell-tale signs if a woman is cheating than if a man, and even more interesting to me were the parallel signs and completely different signs (such as men being more apt to do something than women). The myriad of chapters were also interesting, such as how to catch them in the act and how to deal with toxic relationships. I found Walker's guide to be very thorough, interesting, and readable.I would toss out all the other books that you have in this genre- THIS is the only one that you need!

Growing up, I knew a boy in my class whose family adopted a little from Russia. It was the early 90s and the Iron Curtain had fallen. She was intriguing and very interesting to all of us that got to meet this little girl and I can't imagine how many other classrooms, neighborhoods, and families probably experienced the wonder of bringing a child over from Russia to America. Fortunately for her, her situation was not like Alina's.The protagonist, Alina, suffers a heartbreaking journey in "Estranged From Russia." It was almost like a Greek tragedy. The only thing that keeps her going is her faith in God. This inspiring work would be enjoyed by adults and teens alike. 5-stars and beautiful.

Book*Sense never ceases to meet my needs for a summary and analysis and exceed them, satiating my cravings for more of the author's story and world. In this case, "Seveneves" is dissected and presented to us in an easy-to-digest format. There was so much that I missed in Neal Stephenson's original novel, and this companion shed a lot of light on some things that were lurking below the surface, just waiting to be discovered.I particularly enjoyed the "story plot analysis," "major symbols," and "themes" sections in this particular companion. If you're looking to get more out of your reading experience of Neal Stephenson's "Seveneves" or are perhaps looking for a summary and analysis with excellent discussion questions for your book group, this would make a great addition to your library.

Emily Walters' "Investment in Love" is a sweet contemporary romance that follows Calvin Barnard and Ellie Parker and how their paths cross. The premise is simple enough- young, handsome man inherits millions and a house from a little-known great-aunt, but with one caveat: he must marry a local girl in order to inherit his millions. Calvin finds his girl, but in Ellie, he may be finding more than the paper wife he was searching for.All this being said, "Investment in Love" was a quick read, but an enjoyable one. This would certainly make for great beach time reading. The characters and storyline were well-developed and engaging. I've read a few of Ms. Walters' novels in the past, and I think this one might be my new favorite.

Tracy Sherwood's "Death Grip" is a compelling tale about a recent return from the Middle East and her battle with PTSD. Kat is a soldier, a mother, and a wife. While each role may be challenging, to be placed in all three at once is imaginably very difficult. Combine this with returned from the Middle East and a near-death experience, PTSD is added to the mix and you have an explosive story.This wasn't just an amazing story with fantastic writing, but a wake up call that if you, or anyone you know, has PTSD, to see help immediately. This is not a battle that anyone must fight alone. There is help. This should be required reading for high school and college students and need a place in your summer reading list.

Nathaniel Oliver's "Elon Musk: Renaissance Man" is a compelling look at the life, accomplishments, and philosophy of Elon Musk, the famous CEO of Tesla Motors and other well-known corporations.Musk's tale is entertaining and inspiring- he started with nothing and now has everything. His story embodies the American Dream and still proves that an idea, hard work, and determination can pay off. I didn't really know about him before this book, let alone the fact that so many famous companies are his brainchild. This book will definitely educate and enlighten you about this interesting man and his vision for the future.Must reading for biography fans and anyone interested in an inspiring story and looking towards the future.

What's the first thing that you notice about the majority of telemarketers that call your home? You hang up immediately, right? They fail to sell you their product or service. Claes Simonsen's "Telesales Secrets" is an extremely informative guide for those who are looking to up their sales game, make the sale, and improve their income."Telesales Secrets" is an easy-to-follow guide to selling on the phone and is jam-packed with so many helpful tips. This guide belongs in any telesales professional's library and is great for beginners and pros alike.
The book is packed with action that seems very close to stories in the press today. A great sequel to Spear of ISIS.

I found Wade Migan's "Leaky Gut Syndrome: The Ultimate Cure Guide" to be an eye-opening book. I have explored several different books related to various problems in the abdominal region and "Leaky Gut Syndrome" is very accessible for the average reader. Migan offers a brief anatomy lesson before launching into what Leaky Gut Syndrome is, symptoms, and how to tell if you might have it. There are also invaluable chapters about supplements to take and the sort of diet you should follow if you suffer from Leaky Gut Syndrome.This is definitely a great book at a great price to help get you started with managing Leaky Gut.

Wade Migan's "Pescetarian Diet" is an informative guide for beginners interested in pursuing a pescetarian diet or for those of us who have heard the term thrown around and weren't sure exactly what it entailed. I found this guide to be extremely interesting. I've met many vegans, vegetarians, and people who would eat chicken, but not red meat, and so on. I've met one pescetarian and I always wondered a bit about her diet and what sort of benefits she was receiving from it, especially because she was so passionate about it.As stated in the guide, pescetarians are "vegetarians who eat fish" and they may or may not choose to eat dairy products and eggs. They receive a myriad of health benefits from following this diet and the author highlights many of the upsides and downsides to the diet. There are also some delicious recipes to help you get started and tips for how to cope if you find yourself missing meat.All in all, I would say that this is great guide to help get you started on a new, healthful path in your life.

As we continue to lose more and more of "The Greatest Generation" with every passing day, we continue to lose their stories. Many stories have been recorded, but what about the ones that disappeared with the passing time? I imagine that one of them would be a lot like Shirley Rumming- full of adventure, life experience, and secrets.In Leanne Wood's short novel, Shirley Rumming's life is shaped by one event set amidst many world-shattering events. That backdrop, to me, was amazing and it showed life going on despite, or in spite, of what may be happening around us.I really appreciated all of the thought and research that went into examining Australia during WWII and the Great Depression. I found that to be very interesting and will definitely set this novel apart from other novels that my only examine Americans during those moments in history. For lovers of great writing and lovers of history, I highly recommend "Pages of Your Life."

Patrick Hatt's "A Not So New World" is a quirky story about Jack, a man wrongfully framed for a crime that he did not commit, and his ensuing adventures with a sympathizing FBI agent in his cat time machine. This book would be appropriate for YA readers and adults, and especially lovers of adventure. There are, of course, elements of sci-fi/fantasy and some mystery/suspense.I really enjoyed Hatt's smooth and engaging writing style, which kept me turning the pages until I found that I had suddenly finished the book at 2AM. I was so pulled in to Jack's and Agent Milano's adventures and I so badly wanted to know what would happen to them. Plus, whenever I think of a time machine, I think of that one in that old classic movie, not a cat, so that kept me interested. Sort of reminded me of the cat bus in "My Neighbor Totoro."All in all, this was a fun read and I am looking forward to checking out more of Hatt's work.

Anne Glynn's "Twisted Games" is a riveting paranormal romance/mystery novel packed with sensual romance, paranormal elements (werewolf, anyone?), and a murder mystery in a race against time. The main characters, Dravon and Kelli, were well-developed and interesting. In this page-turner, the reader wants to find out what happens to those two and if they will ever get back together and whether or not Dravon was framed.Paranormal romance fans will devour this novel.

Having spent three and a half years of my life living in the countryside of Honshu, the large main island of Japan, I can safely say that I know a few things about Japanese cuisine. I had the great fortune of spending a vacation in Okinawa and I was struck by the beauty of the string of islands, the different culture, different dialect, different rhythm of life...and the different cuisine from the rest of the Japan. Of course, Okinawans do eat the same foods as other Japanese people do, but their traditional cuisine is very unique and full of so much healthy goodness. For one week, I enjoyed a diet that was extremely varied and very rich in seafood, vegetables, and tropical fruits.Wade Migan does an excellent job of introducing Westerners to this delicious diet, while also thoughtfully warning against the possibility that you might not be used to the tastes. Personally, I love goya (bitter melon) and it is SO good for you, but it is an acquired taste for many people, Japanese included. Migan also introduces the reader to other common, healthy ingredients in Okinawan cuisine and what their health benefits are. This is a great diet for adventurous eaters who want to maximize superfoods in their diet.

Kirk Bailey's "The Death of Pat Bannon" is a unique, often quirky, often funny, and always thought provoking social commentary and speculation about the afterlife. I would definitely recommend this book for older readers as a lot of subjects aren't suitable for younger readers. So needless to say, Pat's adventures through the afterlife had me snickering and laughing out loud as she navigates this path.I highly recommend this! I can't wait to read the next book.

"Bible Scriptures to Combat the Spirit of Depression" is a great option for those seeking something spiritual to help ward off depression. There are a lot of inspirational passages and scripture for Christians to turn to in their time of need, for every particular situation that can stem from depression. Some particularly inspirational scripture are Psalm 33 V20-22, Psalm 63 V4, and Isaiah  26 V3-4. The Bible is so uplifting and inspirational and Alicia Grant has highlighted all the very best parts to help combat the spirit of depression.

Instaread's summary of this book was a major help for me. When you're cluttered, you want to get to the root of the problem and quickly, without spending hours reading about it. The KonMari method for tidying sounds logical and like it would work out for me and make my life less cluttered. The "key takeaway" points were very helpful.

Cathy Simpson's "50 Easy Paleo Recipes for Gluten-Free Kids" is 50 recipes of deliciousness and health benefits for all ages. There are so many substitutes for kid favorites in here that not only give your child that particular taste that they were craving (think grape skewers dipped in homemade peanut butter- PBJ flavor!), but also follow the paleo lifestyle.Pumpkin pie ice cream? Yum! I love how many yummy recipes there are in this book and how simple they are to make. Part of the art of writing a cookbook is to make sure that you write in such a way that your audience can successfully replicate your recipes, which is exactly what Ms. Simpson has done. I really enjoyed this cookbook and it will definitely remain on my "Kindle cooking shelf" for future use.

I decided to  check out Dr. Aaron Laird's "Resilience" a bit on a whim and a bit on the knowledge that it had debuted at #1 in poetry here on Amazon back in October. I didn't buy it then, but something about it stayed with me these past few months and I decided to buy a copy. I wish I had bought it earlier! Lovers of poetry will enjoy this book for its innovation, variety, and brilliance.The poems are lyrical and beautiful, and Dr. Laird has a way with words.This is the poetry book of the year.

As another fellow reviewer said, this story is quite unique. We've all read stories or seen TV shows/movies about people who are able to see the dead, but what about dragons, knights, and the like? What would a story like that be like? Fun is what it's like!The main character, Desdemona, can see knights, dragons, and all sorts of fantastical creatures. I don't want to give away too much, but I really enjoyed this novel. I'm hoping to see more adventures of Desdemona in the future and more of Ms. Linton's captivating style!

I've read some of Holy Ghost Writer's work before (such as The Sovereign Order of Monte Cristo) and had enjoyed it. Since I'm fascinated by all things Jack the Ripper, I figured this one would be worth a shot too. What a fun and captivating read! There was even a connection to "The Sovereign Order of Monte Cristo" and I loved that.I loved the idea of combining the murders with Sherlock Holmes. No doubt Sir Arthur Conan Doyle would have approved. The writing did not let up and I was so bummed when the book was over- I didn't want it to end!

...you could start over? At first, I thought this book would be about covering your tracks (such as getting rid of troublesome social media) and not putting yourself "out there" as much and being careful about what you are using in your day-to-day life and so on. It is, but this book is also about legally creating a new identity and why you may want to consider a new identity or alternative identity.The author provides updated, sound, and well-researched advice for everything from being mindful to what your current technology is doing to you to completely disappearing. Very interesting read!

Diana Artene's "The Old Chocolate Diet" is an interesting and sound response to the plethora of diet books available today: eat what you want and only eat until you're full. Eat what you crave, and nothing else. The idea is to enjoy your food and not be a glutton. Combined with an active lifestyle, I can see this diet being successful for many people.Ms. Artene's research and thesis were very interesting. Her ideas were clear, concise, and easy to implement. I've set out on a healthier lifestyle and this book will be in my arsenal. Highly recommend.

"Vacation with a Star" is another of the talented Kate Goldman's hits. I'm sure many of us can sympathize with Melanie, who becomes jaded after catching her rock star boyfriend cheating on her. She decides to never get involved with another musician. I know that I could sympathize with her- have you ever been burned by a man and decided to not go out with another man who had maybe a similar job, similar hobby, etc?When she meets the irresistible Daniel, I couldn't help but think, "Don't do it, Melanie! You're only going to get hurt again!" since he is also a musician. But as luck would have it for our heroine, she finds her true love.This was another excellent book by Ms. Goldman and one of the reasons that I keep seeking out her work. "Vacation with a Star" was great and I highly recommend this for contemporary romance fans!

From partying and hitch-hiking his way across the U.S., to sailing the seas with an alcoholic sea captain, to hanging out on the beach in Honduras working for the mafia, Adam has done it, and he writes how he did it, escaping his imprisonment of the boring nine-to-five life. This writer absolutely takes you in. He is deep, and funny. There were points where I couldnt stop laughing the entire time. I giggled so much. He writes with a lot of warmth. I havent been entertained like this in years. Epic. Borderline masterpiece. I cant wait for part two.

Emily Daton's "Cartomancy: Fortune Telling Using Playing Cards" is a cartomancy guide using playing cards instead of a tarot card set. While tarot cards may not be accessible to everyone, it is so easy to pick up a deck of playing cards at a local store. Ms. Daton carefully explains all of the basics of cartomancy, what each cards symbolizes, how to begin, and what to look for. She also explains different reasons for cartomancy with playing cards that go beyond fortune telling. It was pretty amazing- I had no idea that the cards could be used for meditation purposes.People who are serious about cartomancy should definitely heed her advice. This a great book for both beginners and advanced practitioners alike.

Amanda Roberts' "Crazy Dumplings" is a gift from the Dumpling Gods. Having experienced authentic jiaozi firsthand while living in China, the author has taken them to new, transcendent heights. From sweet to savory, eastern to western, there's a flavor and combination for everyone in this book. All the instructions were clearly and concisely written. I also loved Ms. Roberts' "from scratch method." All I had to do to prepare the dumplings that I chose was use basic ingredients that I had around the house. I didn't have to run out anywhere and search for dumpling wrappers.For a dumpling lover like me, you think you have died and gone to heaven. It's difficult to find a substantial dumpling book and I am so pleased that I found this one.There are so many dumpling ideas that just never would have occurred to me, such as the Key Lime dumplings and S'mores dumplings, but they're genius! I highly recommend this book!

Jill Vance's "Dark Between Shadows" is a collection of short stories with intriguing twists and turns. None of the stories ended how I thought they would, even though I was expecting a twist at the end. I absolutely loved it. I finished the book in two sittings, although I easily could have sat for one! Such is life- we have other things that we must take care of sometimes that gets in the way of our reading! My two favorite stories were "Letters from the Grave" and "One Bad Apple." There is truly something for everyone in this collection and each story felt like a fresh, new start.It's so hard to find a decent collection of short stories and "Dark Between Shadows" did not disappoint. I highly recommend!

For many, exercise and change go hand in hand; changing your body, changing your habits, and so on. Many of us fall flat in our attempts to affect change in our exercise routine as well as our lives. This book gets to the heart of the issue and concisely and expertly explains to the reader what can be done.I have recently begun a diet and exercise regimen and have been looking to make several changes to my life and it hasn't been easy. It won't be easy, but I know with the tools from this book I can succeed and it will be easier than going it alone. Highly recommend this book.

"The War of Alien Aggression" is a collection of A.D. Bloom's five novellas in a single volume, which makes for an excellent bargain. Fans of science fiction will thoroughly enjoy this collection. I really loved the development of Bloom's universe and the characters. I look forward to reading more from this author in the future!

I tried reading the original "Mindset," which was repetitive and long-winded, but I found this summary to be exactly what I was looking for. Just like the summary says, this summary contains all of the main points without all of that unnecessary filler. That being said, I enjoyed chapters 3 and 6. As I get ready to move forward and begin married life, I recognize that having the proper mindset is tremendously important.

Like other reviewers said- the graphics are amazing! Tammy Brown Elkeles has a natural talent and ability for storytelling in this first in a series of adventures featuring Dirty and a cast of interesting characters. The story was unique and there were plenty of tongue-in-cheek laughs to keep me entertained. I can't wait to check out what else Ms. Elkeles has in store for us and Dirty! Keep up the great work!

C.J. Lake's "A Hot Winter" is a new adult romance in "The Attraction Series" with Emma, a widow, and Matt, someone from her past.There were so many pluses to this novel. The main characters' romance was fresh, relatable, and most importantly, believable. So many times in romance novels the main characters and their situation are completely unbelievable, but not in this case.The love scenes were not trite or vulgar, but well executed. You could really feel their passion.I particularly liked the easy-to-follow plot that still kept me guessing what might happen next with Emma and Matt. Lake also executed the characters very well- Emma and Matt had excellent development for a novel under 400 pages.Overall, this was a steamy love story and a fun read, with very likable characters, great sexual chemistry, and some really touching moments. Treat yourself this winter to "A Hot Winter!"

...well, not entirely to themselves, but Harry was a boy, after all, and in Michael DeAngelo's "Tales of the Tellest" and "Child of the Stars" series, girls finally get their main heroine, Adelia Kreegan. Adelia is a young girl who loses her family, but in the process gains an amazing power. She receives mentoring from Gaston, a sage, who teaches her how to harness her powers.I really enjoyed the storyline progression and the character's development. I would not hesitate to recommend this to any pre-teen/teen reader or their parents. This is just the sort of novella that I would have been crazy about as a kid!"Mageborn" was a fun read that belongs in any pre-teen/teen's Kindle library this holiday season.

You should never judge a book by a cover- but I'll admit that when I saw this cover, I was intrigued. I'm glad that I stopped to look! Jonathan Sturak's "A Smudge of Gray" is about Detective Brian Boise is hunting down Trevor Malloy, a murder suspect. The action was fast-paced and at times extremely tense. The characters were well-developed and interesting and the plot kept me guessing and wondering what would happen next.I've never watched CSI, but I do watch Law and Order and I agree- if you like shows like that, you'll love "A Smudge of Gray." Fun read!

If you haven't read any of Kate Goldman's novels before- grab this steal! You'll get a sampling of her work (three novels) for a bargain price. Each novel is completely different, with a different heroine, dreamy guy, and unique plot.My personal favorite was the first novel in the bundle, "In Love with a Haunted House." It could be because I'm a Chicago girl, where Mallory's story begins. Goldman's pacing was done very well and there were no holes or dull moments in her plot and she effectively developed her characters.The other two novels were just as entertaining and well-written. The Sweet Romance Bundle would make a great gift for any contemporary romance lover this holiday season- or as a special treat for yourself!

Frank Marcopolos' "Infinite Ending" is a collection of two essays and ten short stories that are the result of a "story a month" challenge. Each story's ending is open to interpretation. One thing that I particularly enjoyed "Valhalla House." Every time I read that story, and the other stories, I feel like I pick up on something new and then the ending changes again. I love novels and short stories where I can take away something new every time.Fans of postmodern lit looking for something new in the dearth of selection from new authors will be thrilled to find this. This is definitely a diamond in the rough. Fans of short stories and essays will also find something to enjoy in "Infinite Ending." Highly recommended.

I  found this book by accident. I was previewing audiobooks and I found the sample for this. The vocal artist in the sample was wonderful, but I decided I wanted to read the book for myself first. Im glad I did. The book is one of those strange finds. You wonder why they didnt have something like this before. A story about and by magical girls. There are funny, scary and amazing moments in the story. Im putting the Sisters M on my watch list for their next book. This is a book to share with any of the younger ladies you know (11  14) and anyone who enjoys a good adventure.

Wildcard opens in Grenoble where 16 year-old Martha (genetically altered) has been made to have a baby in a corporate prison. Escaping with the boy - Karl, she is phoned (in hiding) by a secretive Artificial Intelligence. He forces her to abandon Karl for his protection. Years later, many entities (not all people - who have titles for names like the General - a quirky technique Mitchell sorts the characters with(maybe?)) - Sergeant, Mechanic and Benefactor, for example. The Sergeant emerges as the principal character which generates some narrative confusion since Karl is the seeming lead character. Anyway, the Sarge is holding the Mechanic, who negotiates a deal - they have to locate Karl and put him across the barrier into Mansworld - a creation of the unapproachable A.I. Wildcard. First, however, the team must send Martha to the Benefactor for a pretty awful fate.Thats chapter 2 of 60, so you can see its a pretty twisty tale. If complex stories float your boat, its a wicked read, but if simple is your preference, youll dislike it.Next, the General creates a crew- the Sergeant, RJ Sublime (gene altered luck), LuvRay Chose (wise primitive raised by wolves - very cool sub-story), together with Karl. They must work with Juniper a Manufactured Entity or M.E. (Mitchells cutesy term for A.I.). They trick Juniper and essentially kill him.Dartagnan and :3: - the remaining M.E.s - get Karl into Wildspace - the multi-verse generated by Wildcard. Wildcard was the first M.E. and was isolated by accident for 100,000 years (subjective timerate). He (they/it?) communicates through cryptic poetry to individuals. The poetry is not really great, but its not that bad. Its a unique device, too, so credit for that. Wildcard is pretty much a god, and has some need or goal beyond human understanding. He cant do it alone and absolutely requires Karls aid. And Karls requires the others aid. Its a sort of cosmic danger of going mad and living forever in that state. When WC was trapped, the human created part went totally crazy and out jumped this wiser aspect. Now the two are locked in a sort of death struggle to save/destroy humanity.At the same time, the Benafactor mentally racks Martha - a big spoiler, Ill skip over - very cool twist.Karl makes it over (of course), since no one else has the ability. The gate unlocks for everyone else who all follow into different parts of Wildspace. Karl makes his way to the Center, where a gentle elderly man and wife live - WCs attempt to create humans. Karl has to exit, though, to save Martha, knowing he will not be allowed back - no one can enter the Center twice.S-2 - the boy Sergant - finds Karl, but has secret orders to murder the old man at the Center. Karl attempts to prevent this, and I will not tell the outcome - another Big spoiler.Next, the pair go to find the Poet - who pens WCs questionable communiques, with Dartagnan in pursuit. Karl and the Poet become lovers. He leaves her world and is soon killed by the Mechanic - a fascinating concept and scene. The Sargeant finds RJ, Dartagnan and Luvrey. Together, the seek out Karls reincarnation - who happens to be the Poets unborn child by Karl. (A little fun weirdness).Ill hold back the end, but you can guess that WC and the Wound (the crazy part) battle it out with the humans caught in the mix, struggling and mostly failing to stay sane while reality comes apart at the seams. It falls to the Sargeant to save the world from the Wouond dissolving everything into chaotic soup.Bad - Probably too many sub-plots and some tenuous connections. Readers who prefer tidy stories should avoid it. Those who enjoy somewhat ramblin and wanderin tales will love it. Too many ends left loose - devices dropped. A few come back in the next book, I know. If a straightforward, clean narrative is your preference, give this book a pass.Good parts - The book has incredible imagination, a lot of gripping adventure and dialogue and a depth of philosophy seen in very few contemporary books. This is metered out and slipped in quietly so its not heavy-handed or boring. Mitchell has a great skill with that area. Quite a few intriguing questions are brought up with no impediment to the narrative. Each scene makes you eager to keep reading - nice style in ending scenes cryptically. The many sub-plots are great and well-twined into the main plot, so it doesnt get lost in the complexity, although it seems it will at times. Luvreys backstory (Ill leave it for you) is amazing, and revealed in a very cool way - however, its not integral to the overall story - which weakens it somewhat. The story does match up thematically with Marthas alone-liness. If youre a fan of complex stories and large multi-verses, then buy it.

M.B. Manteufel's "Jackalope Season" is a thrilling book of nine short stories with the theme of monsters both human and not human. My two favorite stories were "Jackalope Season" and "A Grimm Day." The reader can easily get through this book in one sitting.I'd highly recommend this for horror short story fans. I can't wait to see more of Manteufel's work in the future!

Mark Caldwell Jones' "Opal Summerfield and The Battle of Fallmoon Gap" was a delightful tale of young Opal who must battle evil and find her way back home. I thought that the Veil was really creative and I really felt swept away into this fantasy world. In addition to the well-developed fantasy worlds of the Veil and the Ozarks, the characters developed appropriately and interestingly with each passing page. By the end of the book, I was ready for more of Opal's adventures! I hope that Mr. Jones continues with this series.The illustrations were also fun and would be loved by children and adults alike. Any fan of Harry Potter, C.S. Lewis, or Tolkien would really enjoy this book!

Margaret Gold's "Lose the Booze" offers a fresh solution to the old problem of over-drinking.Ms. Gold's no guilt, non-12 step, practical approach is helpful and she utilizes the latest research and science around what works and what doesn't for people who have decided that they need to quit drinking. This is an excellent resource for individuals (and the people who love them) with a drinking problem and an important step in the right direction.

Richard Smiraldi's "Seven Murders in Sussex" was a thrilling murder mystery with the affable heroine, Reilly Swanson. Smiraldi carefully weaves an intriguing thriller where Reilly must decide between right and wrong and race against time before she becomes the eighth murder in Sussex."Seven Murders in Sussex" kept my attention until the very end and I couldn't put the book down!

"A Motive for Murder" is the first book i the Misty Sales series by Morgana Best. I am always a bit leery of reading a mystery series if there are only a few books in that series out because what if I really like it? Then I have to wait until the next one comes out! In this case, I did enjoy the first book very much and am almost done with Book 2!This was a fun, suspenseful book with several interesting puzzles for Misty to solve. And Diva, the cat, is an entertaining cutie!I gave my copy to my mother, who is a serial mystery reader, and she devoured it in one sitting and wholeheartedly gave two thumbs up. A must for mystery fans.

"Flying Heroes" is a cute adventure tale for children about Bugsbee the bee, and Genie the butterfly. "Flying Heroes" teaches kids about ecosystems and the damage that we are having upon other species, including our own. This is a great book to teach kids about being mindful of nature and stopping to think about how their actions may negatively affect others and other life forms, such as bees and butterflies.Adrian Schafer's "Flying Heroes" deserves a place in every child's Kindle library.

Heather Choate's "SWAB" is an intriguing sci-fi adventure written for young adults. The story follows Cat and her fight against the scab, an alien race that have taken over her planet and taken everything away from her. The plot was fun and I had a hard time putting the book down so that I could get necessary sleep. "SWAB" has all the elements to become a big hit with the YA crowd."SWAB" belongs in any young adult sci-fi fan's library.

I found D.R. Farmer's "Thrift Store Profits" to be a very useful and interesting guide about ten common items that you can find at thrift stores, yard sales, etc. that you can sell for a huge profit later on. A few of the items I was aware about, but others I had no idea could be resold for such a great profit. Plus, there was a bonus at the end of the book that directs you to a website with a few more high profit items.I would highly recommend this book for anyone starting out with thrifting and looking for a bit of direction before branching off to selling other thrift store finds. I hope Farmer puts out more books like this soon!

Francis Coyle's "Guards of Theildon" is set in a fantastical world reminiscent of The Lord of the Rings, with equally interesting and fantastical characters. The characters, especially Gynsst (the main character) were exceptionally well-developed. Gynsst and his bad day grabbed me from page one and I couldn't put "Guards of Theildon" down until I finished! Fans of Terry Pratchett or J.R.R. Tolkien will enjoy "Guard of Theildon."

Sara O'Connell's "Back Bay Bride" is a cute, heartwarming romance with realistic characters and a plausible plot. The plot was cute and entertaining without being the least bit trite. From the first page, Claire's tale grabbed my attention and by the time Patrick entered the picture, I was hooked.I could definitely see a novel like this as a cute romance film.Ms. O'Connell is a talented author and I look forward to seeing more of her work in the future.

Amy Rose's "Zentangle: Zentangle for Beginners" is a fun, relaxing, and enlightening book about Zentangle. For the uninitiated, Zentangle is essentially an abstract drawing using repetitive patterns. There are a few guidelines to follow and then you're off. Zentangle is a great way to manage issues such as anger, stress, and anxiety. It's also a great meditative device.Ms. Rose's guide is a good go-to guide for beginners about how and why to zentangle. She explains all the basics that you need to know, why you should zentangle, and how to get started. This is a fun, easy, and concise guide to get started with this great activity.

I've had HS for three years (35 year old male, used to smoke cigarettes when I was younger). Saw loads of doctors, dermatologists and endocrinologists; tried everything..cycles of Accutane, Prednisone, Remicade, Humira, you name it, I've done it. Through my own research I started to read how different foods can have a dramatic impact on inflammation and HS flare-ups, and indeed I started noticing a difference when I was careful with my eating. I bought this cookbook to help me come up with ideas for meals and Im very glad I did as 150 recipes are more than enough! Barely a week and a half following this cookbook to a T, my skin started clearing up. The boils shrunk and the lesions have started healing. Thank you for this wonderful cookbook!

Eric Monroe's "Make Him Desperate to be Yours Forever" is a simple three-step solution to scoring that dream guy that you have always wanted. For whatever reason, you have not been able to get his attention and you want to change all of that. Monroe's to-the-point guide is written from a male relationship expert's perspective that is no-hold's barred, classy, and informative. It's all about changing your mindset and approach, not you as a person like many other similar guides out there.Never expected it to happen so soon, but I'm very happy to report that I tried Monroe's three steps and I already have a date this weekend with the guy I've secretly had a crush on for years!

I work with addicts and their loved ones on a daily basis and I am very pleased to be able to offer this selection to my clients on our e-readers. This selection is a great value with three different books in one convenient package.In Book 1, JC Anonymous starts the reader out with solid strategies for dealing with an addict. While many people may think of alcohol addiction right away, this books covers so much more than just alcohol. JC Anonymous clearly knows his strategies and addiction psychology.This is not a quick process, but JC Anonymous has it broken down as quickly as possible in Book 2, which is a 31-day plan for coping with an addict.Book 3 gives the reader 101 quick tips for dealing with addicts that can be implemented daily, as needed, or on the fly. Overall, "Substance Abuse Help" is one of the best resources for coping with an addict that I have seen available, especially in recent years.This is an excellent compend for coping with addicts and I highly recommend it.

Dmytro Bondarenko's "The Seventeenth Floor" is a plausible tale of a young man who, although he loves and cares for his wife, has found his attentions wandering since the birth of his daughter and the passing of the sixth year of his marriage. At the suggestion of a co-worker, Kostya, the main character, visits a brothel. This is the story of his desires and the resulting consequences.Bondarenko writes in a very straightforward style that does not beat around the bush. From the first sentence onward, the reader will be drawn in to Kostya's tale. This is a story that has been written at its very essence and not fluffed up by extra, unnecessary words and situations. For the reader looking for a straightforward, realistic tale, this is a good choice.

If you've recently read "Zero to One," then this is a must-have summary and critique to own. A work such as "Zero to One" requires another viewpoint and opinion, and I.K. Mullins provided just what was needed. This book answered all of my questions about Thiel's views and shed some light on a few points that I wasn't clear about in "Zero to One." Wonderfully written and analyzed.If you've read or are currently reading "Zero to One," you need to pick up a copy of I.K. Mullins' "A Summary and Critique of Peter Thiel and Blake Masters's Zero to One."

Andrew L.'s "How to Live a Happier Life" is chock full of useful strategies for living a happier, more optimistic life. Each strategy is a subset of a themed chapter and designed so that anyone can implement the strategy, provided that they have the right mindset and are ready for a positive change.My favorite strategy is strategy #6, "deal with the past so that you can enjoy the present." That strategy really spoke to me because I know that I do (and did) harbor a lot of negative feelings about various things in my past that I had to let go of in order to be happier. With the help from this book, I've already been able to let go of some things and it's been a tremendous weight off of my shoulders.I can't wait to try some more of Andrew's strategies. This is a great book and anyone looking for a bit more happiness in their life should grab a copy today!

Cooking with spices and herbs? Using prescribed medical marijuana? You're gonna want to consider this grinder. As far as I'm concerned Golden Gate Grinders makes the best grinder out there. I don't even need to consider others.The grinders are made with aircraft grade aluminum thats harder than the fist of Chuck Norris and sharper than Einstein in his prime. I'm not even sure what aircraft grade aluminum is, but it sounds cool. And this is probably why the grinder has a nice weight to it. Just sitting in your hand it feels quality, and I don't have to worry about it slipping away or someone bumping me and off goes the grinder. It's heavy duty and certainly feels that way in my hands.The lid has teeth on the underside and a magnet around the rim to help keep the lid on and everything inside fresh. Be careful with the pieces with teeth - if you stick your finger in there you can feel just how sharp the teeth are even though they aren't knife-like.The chamber for the herbs and whatnot is pretty big, and there's a mesh pollen catcher at the bottom which is really cool. As for what you can grind - seeds, nuts, garlic cloves, cinnamon sticks, and of course medical marijuana. It can handle a variety of things and you can also leave your grounds inside it and rest assured they'll keep fresh thanks to the magnetized pieces.This grinder is great and I expect it will last a lifetime considering how durable and quality it is. It's also very affordable in comparison to other grinders that claim to be top of the line, so you're getting a great value too.

A while ago I was watching the show Gold Rush on TV and it had me thinking maybe I could try to find some gold. In my neck of the woods there aren't many areas where gold is plentiful, so you won't hear anyone talking about it around here.But what if the dirt came to me? That's where Pay Dirt Gold Company comes in. If you don't have the chance to go searching for gold in the wild, buying some pay dirt or a panning kit is a great gift idea. It's also something new to try. Unless you live in gold country (like Alaska), I bet you've never panned!I recently had the pleasure of trying this gold panning kit and it was a lot of fun to use. I had never panned for gold before and panning is more fun than you'd expect. The kit is guaranteed to contain gold, so don't worry - you won't just be getting a plain ol' bag of dirt! The amount of gold will vary, and in my bag I uncovered about a dozen particles after thoroughly panning. There's even a chance of getting a nugget, but the odds are 1 in 250. Although the odds are pretty good if you think about it.Swishing the water and dirt around and eventually uncovering the gold is pretty rewarding. My vial is in a safe place and my wife and I plan to check out a few places in our state known for having small cases of gold in the water. It's more for fun and the adventure than to become rich. I think it's safe to say that Pay Dirt Gold Company has given us gold fever and now the rush is on!

I liked this Takeya bottle in green so much that now I've got a second one in blue.And there's a lot I like about the Takeya bottle. It's dishwasher safe (no need to remove the silicone sleeve for washing), it fits in cup holders (so clutch while on the go), the flip cap comes completely off for big gulps and cleaning, and you can stuff your everyday ice cubes into it easily. The only thing more refreshing than water is ice-cold water.On that note, the silicone sleeve makes for easy gripping when the glass can be slippery from condensation. The carry handle is also an option for carrying the bottle around too.My green bottle has already handled some bumps and dings, and I'm confident this will last a long time. A word of advice - take apart the bottle so the cap and straw are in pieces when washing. It will be easier to ensure everything is clean that way.

We almost exclusively use reusable bottles for drinking water at our house. They're better for the environment and certainly cheaper than paying for the cheap plastic bottled water in stores. I'm a fan of glass bottles for keeping in the fridge at home, or for on my desk at work.There's a lot I like about the Takeya bottle. It's dishwasher safe (no need to remove the silicone sleeve for washing), it fits in cup holders (so clutch  while on the go), the flip cap comes completely off for big gulps and cleaning, and you can stuff your everyday ice cubes into it easily. The only thing more refreshing than water is ice-cold water.On that note, the silicone sleeve makes for easy gripping when the glass can be slippery from condensation. The carry handle is also an option for carrying the bottle around too.My green bottle has already handled some bumps and dings, and I'm confident this  will last a long time. A word of advice - take apart the bottle so the cap and straw are in pieces when washing. It will be easier to ensure everything is clean that way. I like this Takeya bottle so much that I'm planning to buy a second one in blue.

I live commute into the city for work, sometimes by bike. And when I take my bike out and about, having a reliable lock is a must. I like to use two locks at the same time - a combination cable lock and a sturdier U-lock as a safety net. I've been the victim of bike theft and the guy caught on camera just used his brute force to snap the cable lock. Had it been this CycleBeam lock, it could have been a different story!The CycleBeam cable lock is four feet long, comes with a mount for your seat post, and has a pretty straightforward method of setting your personal combination. The instructions are right on the packaging.The folks at CycleBeam are frequent night riders, so they know safety is important. Their goal is to bring their passion to developing and manufacturing cycling products, so as to enhance the safety of night riding. And the LED illuminated combo lock is perfect for when it's dark and hard to see. When it's dark - whether it's night time, early morning, or even in a dark basement or something, being able to see the combo can be a pain. With the CycleBeam lock all you've got to do is press the button and the dial lights up blue for about 10 seconds.As you'll see in my photo, the brightest part of the dial will be on the numbers that need to line up to unlock it. That's the important part obviously. The light isn't as bright for the rest of the dial, so it doesn't really matter. I've unlocked this in complete darkness a few times and it was pretty cool. No need for a flashlight or straining my eyes and fumbling around!

First responders are trained to look for the star of life on bracelets and necklaces, so wearing an Endevr medical bracelet will give you peace of mind. It's ideal if you have heart conditions, diabetes, and allergies, and it looks cool too. I mean if you like wearing bracelets to begin with then you might as well have one that can be useful too.I wear the sport bracelet for running and biking, and it's great for keeping my emergency contacts and vitals with me in the event something were to happen to me. Let's hope it never comes to that...While I don't wear it on a daily basis since I don't have serious medical conditions, I pick my spots like running road races, biking to work, that kind of thing. If it happens that you wear off the ID numbers or QR code on the inside of the band, Endevr offers a lifetime guarantee and they'll replace it.People have even asked me about the Endevr bracelet when they see me wearing it, and I'm happy to recommend it and explain the benefits of having important personal information just a phone call away. Setting up your MyID profile online is easy, and you can enter as little or as much information as you like.

Birdman is a black comedy about actor Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) and his descent into Hollywood obscurity. Previously famous as the superhero Birdman, Thomson struggles to get his Broadway play off the ground.A bit of a one-trick pony, Birdman appears as if it was shot in one, long single take. Daring or gimmicky, you decide. Personally I found it pretty fresh and something I don't believe I've seen before. At times I watched the camerawork closely to critique the transitions between scenes, and other times I just lost myself in the flow. And it flows very well.The dialogue is rather dramatic and satirical, but that's the intention. I mean, it's Broadway. The way backstage life shown is probably not entirely accurate, but what do I know? In this particular Broadway setting, you'll run into nudity, booze, and an uncomfortable rape situation. Come to think of it, there are plenty of uncomfortable situations that are done well.Michael Keaton is as good as I've ever seen him. While he didn't win Best Actor for this year's Oscars, the film deservedly won Best Picture. His role as a forgotten superhero is the perfect fit for him (ahem, Batman), and it's as if we're immersed in his actual life as the camera follows him around. His character is entitled, complains, and hates the idea of being forgotten.

I feel like I'm late to everything that's new in tech, but I recently got a Xbox 360 Bundle that includes the wireless version of this same controller. I had some doubts about the efficiency of the wireless controller, so I picked up a wired one as well.Despite my doubts, the battery for the wireless controller has met the expectations of 40 hours of usage and I haven't experienced any issues.Wireless is great for playing solo, but for the times when you play with others, wired controllers are key and will cut back on using batteries. The wire extends 9 feet, which is plenty far for typical gaming. I don't expect I or anyone I'm playing with will need to be farther than 9 feet away from the console. Well, maybe... but 9 feet is a reasonable limit.As for the feel in my hands, it's one of the more comfortable and ergonomic controllers I've ever held. And it's lighter than the wireless version since there aren't any batteries. I don't have a preference for weight, but it's something to consider. I'm seriously considering buy a couple more wired controllers for when company is over.

At first glance, I didn't expect much from a golden Oreo cookie. The tradition of the Oreo has worked perfectly for decades and now there's a golden version of it? Nah, that couldn't be any good, could it?But then I popped one in my naive mouth.So good. SO GOOD. The birthday cake Oreo could be my new favorite cookie! Tastes like funfetti too. I quickly grabbed as many as I could fit into my desperate hands and retreated back to my lair. Let me tell you this - limiting yourself to just one will be impossible. Resistance is futile.The cream is a bit sweeter than the regular Oreo, and the wafer might be yellow cake or something. It's actually not clear what the wafer flavor is supposed to be. Either way, I hope the birthday cake Oreo sticks around. They've got something here...

If you haven't already, it's time to try an eco-friendly toothbrush. A toothbrush is something that'll be throw away in a couple months, so if I can prevent a piece of plastic sitting in a dump forever I'll try to do that.The Smile Squared bamboo toothbrush is hand-crafted and features a handle made from natural bamboo. Each toothbrush comes individually boxed, and the packaging is completely recyclable. The brush is enclosed inside a sealed wrapper, and then enclosed within a box, so it's clean, protected, and completely sustainable.Did you know bamboo is one of the fastest growing plants on earth? It's a versatile and environmentally sustainable grass. Bamboo is awesome.The handle is sturdy and a good size for the average hand. The bristles are soft and good quality. I'm not sure how long they'll last, but I expect a couple months is reasonable. This isn't a fancy brush - it's a sustainable brush, and Smile Squared gives one brush to a child in need for every brush that's purchased. It's a good feeling knowing you're helping someone else in the world.And speaking of being a good size for the hand, there is also a toothbrush available in child size. Get bamboo brushes for everyone and become a sustainable family!

I'm a pretty active person, and I'm glad I have this knee compression sleeve. I use it at the gym mostly for lifting weights (legs).I've been dealing with a patella issue in my right knee for awhile now, and on the days my knee is sensitive, using this sleeve is really helpful for load-bearing (i.e. squats or lifting weights with my legs). Rip Toned provides good support, and it fits snugly. And I mean very snugly. It's also durable, not at all flimsy, and I expect it will last a long time.As for sizing, I believe it runs a bit small. To get your sizing, measure the circumference around your leg at six inches below the knee cap. Mine measured 15 inches, so I chose the large size. It's very tight, and even a bit constricting for running. If you're 15 inches or more, get the XL obviously. In general, you might want to consider ordering one size up.

Since my wife and I have oily, sensitive skin, I have just one demand of a health/beauty product - please don't irritate my skin and cause a reaction of some kind. So far, SK-II hasn't let me down.This is a small jar and you only need to use a little bit on your finger. With facial creams you can apply liberally, but with this you don't need much. And considering how expensive it is, you'll want to conserve!After just a week it's been leaving our skin soft and moisturized. More importantly, the skin around our eyes looks great.

I first discovered Squatty Potty while watching ABC's Shark Tank, a show where entrepreneurs pitch their businesses to investors. At first I chuckled when they did a quick demonstration to show how it's used. Let's face it, pooping is a funny topic.But then I started to take it seriously as the Squatty Potty founders explained how effective the stool is.As humans, we're designed to squat, but instead we sit on toilets. Sitting keeps the colon kinked, kind of like when there's a kink or wrinkle in a hose and the flow of water is slowed. Squatting, on the other hand, allows the colon to fully relax and empty quickly.I suffer from IBS, so constipation is a regular part of my life. My eyes lit up when I saw there's a solution that could help! And for less than $30, you're getting a lot of value for something that can be life-changing.And it works.At first, using the stool was uncomfortable, but I quickly adjusted to it. Being tall (6'5") makes the squatting position a bit cramped, but I manage fine. For me, using the bathroom just became a better experience. I still have constipation, but it's not nearly as severe while using this stool.

I can't have dairy, so there isn't a wide selection of protein powders to choose from unfortunately. I give the non-dairy varieties a try when I see them. I've tried several powders that tasted like chalk dust.Enter Vega Sport.It's vegan. Free of dairy, gluten, and soy. Just about anyone can consume this one safely.I think no matter what protein powder you try it will be a bit chalky, but I feel picking the right flavor is important. I've previously tried the berry flavor, which is ideal for me since I like to make smoothies with fruit. Vanilla with fruit is a good mix too. Yes, you still get the powdery, chalky consistency, but the flavor is decent paired with real fruit. I tried mixing it with almond milk and drinking that straight... it was tough to get down without wincing.

I first discovered Alaska Glacial Mud Co while watching ABC's Shark Tank, a show where entrepreneurs pitch their businesses to investors. I was intrigued.Lauren, the founder of Alaska Glacial Mud, runs her mud business out of the small town of Cordova, Alaska, a quaint little city regarded as a hidden treasure. She's also a commercial salmon fisherwoman, and she runs the fishing boat all by herself from the photos I've seen. My wife and I agree Lauren is one tough cookie! We also say she's living the good life in beautiful Alaska.I recently tried this purifying mud masque, harvested from the soft, buttery mud banks of the Copper River Delta in Alaska. Picture a serene, beautiful wilderness landscape with flowing rivers and no signs of humankind - that's where your mud is coming from!My wife and I love the masque! There are several different scents (I prefer the unscented) and you don't need to add water or do any mixing. It's ready to use when you open the jar, which is of very nice quality I might add. Nice packaging too.The mud detoxifies and softens my skin, and I prefer to focus my application on and around my nose where my pores are biggest. The facial brush is a handy tool for even application if you'd rather not use your fingers. The mud is also allergy-free and doesn't cause irritation, which is key for me as I have sensitive skin. I have to be careful with creams and the like. After 15 minutes and then washing away, my skin feels soft and refreshed.

I like blue and green colors for sheets and towels and the like, and these dish towels in aqua are a no-brainer for me.The towels have different patterns, which I like because then you'll know if it's been used recently (kind of like having different color shirts - you know if you've worn it). "Oh, we just used the striped towel the other day so let's grab the solid one." You could say I'm particular about usage...Despite the bright color the towels still hide stains fairly well. Obviously if it's something like coffee it's going to look soiled. Not the most absorbent towels I've ever had, but they're fine for drying hands and cleaning up little things.I recommend 'em.

I feel like I'm late to everything that's new in tech, but I recently got a Xbox 360 Bundle that includes this black wireless controller. I had some doubts about the efficiency of the wireless controller, but I've been pleased with it so far.I initially had these quick thoughts... How long will the battery last? Will I experience lagging all the time? Lag is the most frustrating thing, and we all know it. I have a wireless controller for another system that has always given me problems, thus my reservations about Xbox 360. But fear not, prospective buyer, because Xbox 360 is awesome.The battery is advertised as having 40 hours of life. That's plenty of life for a couple of AA batteries, and frankly I expected less. Being that I've had the Xbox 360 for just awhile, I'm approaching 40 hours of controller usage and haven't experienced any issues. The time will soon come, but I'm happy with the amount of playing time I've got from a couple AAs. Plus, no tangled wires or tugging at the console.The controller also has a 30-foot range. I haven't needed to be 30 feet away from the console, but it works just fine from the opposite end of a typical living room. Maybe in some fantasy when I live in a mansion with an auditorium for a game room I'll truly be able to test out the range.As for the feel in my hands, it's one of the more comfortable and ergonomic controllers I've ever held. I'm seriously considering buying more wireless controllers rather than wired ones. Check out the gold chrome design if you feel like royalty.

For years I've using Tide Original Scent and it's treated my sensitive skin pretty well. The original doesn't have an overpowering scent, but I've decided to take it a step further and go dye- and fragrance-free with these new detergent pods. My skin likes it!Toss one in before putting your laundry in and it completely dissolves during the wash. Pretty cool. Nothing to pick up after running a wash, and my clothes came out fresh and clean. My clothes almost never get stained badly, so I'm not sure how effective a single pod would be, but I imagine tossing in two of them would do the trick.Lastly, the pod is great for detergent conservation. You don't have to worry if you're using too much or too little detergent. And if you get the 72 count you can save more money on a per-pod basis.

For years I've using Tide Original Scent and it's treated my sensitive skin pretty well. The original doesn't have an overpowering scent, but I've decided to take it a step further and go dye- and fragrance-free with these new detergent pods. My skin likes it!Toss one in before putting your laundry in and it completely dissolves during the wash. Pretty cool. Nothing to pick up after running a wash, and my clothes came out fresh and clean. My clothes almost never get stained badly, so I'm not sure how effective a single pod would be, but I imagine tossing in two of them would do the trick.Lastly, the pod is great for detergent conservation. You don't have to worry if you're using too much or too little detergent. And if you get the 72 count you can save more money on a per-pod basis.

I liked this Glasstic bottle in green so much that now I've got a second one in blue.So Glasstic has a shatterproof glass bottle. How is this possible?! Well, the outside layer is hard plastic, and the inside is glass. Envision a bottle within a bottle.
