The glass will most likely never shatter, but in the rare circumstance it does, Glasstic will replace it for you, free of charge within the first year.There's plenty more I like about the bottle too. It's dishwasher safe, it fits in cup holders (so clutch while on the go), the flip cap comes completely off for big gulps and cleaning, and you can stuff your everyday ice cubes into it easily. The only thing more refreshing than water is ice-cold water.My bottle has already handled some bumps and dings, and I'm confident this will last a long time. For our convenience Glasstic offers replacement caps to buy, which is great since at some point I'll probably want a fresh cap.

We almost exclusively use reusable bottles for drinking water at our house. They're better for the environment and certainly cheaper than paying for the cheap plastic bottled water in stores. I'm a fan of glass water bottles, but it's risky bringing them places due to the danger of breaking it.Glasstic has something I've never tried before - a shatterproof glass bottle. How is this possible?! Well, the outside layer is hard plastic, and the inside is glass. Envision a bottle within a bottle. The glass will most likely never shatter, but in the rare circumstance it does, Glasstic will replace it for you, free of charge within the first year.There's plenty more I like about the bottle too. It's dishwasher safe, it fits in cup holders (so clutch while on the go), the flip cap comes completely off for big gulps and cleaning, and you can stuff your everyday ice cubes into it easily. The only thing more refreshing than water is ice-cold water.My bottle has already handled some bumps and dings, and I'm confident this will last a long time. For our convenience Glasstic offers replacement caps to buy, which is great since at some point I'll probably want a fresh cap. I like this Glasstic bottle so much that I'm planning to buy a second one in blue.

There are three things I care about when buying litter.1 - Clumping - most litters I've used have clumped well, but there are some brands that just don't do it well enough. Cat's Pride, safe to say, clumps as expected. My little guy doesn't hesitate to use the litter, and he approves. He'll use almost anything, though. I could probably dump Grape Nuts into the litter box and he'd still use it.2 - Fragrance - I'm not a fan of fragrance since it can stink up a room, and if dust gets on the furniture or something then it's going to smell like litter. Cat's Pride is advertised as "fragrance free" and that's mostly true. It still has a faint scent, but certainly nothing to complain about.3 - Price - I've been buying Fresh Step for years, and Cat's Pride is cheaper pound for pound here on Amazon. Jugs aren't the norm for litter these days, but if you get these jugs rather than the 28-pound box you can save more money on a per-pound basis.I may consider switching to Cat's Pride...

For years I've using Tide Original Scent and it's treated my sensitive skin pretty well. The original doesn't have an overpowering scent, but I've decided to take it a step further and go dye- and fragrance-free with these new detergent pods. My skin likes it!Toss one in before putting your laundry in and it completely dissolves during the wash. Pretty cool. Nothing to pick up after running a wash, and my clothes came out fresh and clean. My clothes almost never get stained badly, so I'm not sure how effective a single pod would be, but I imagine tossing in two of them would do the trick.Lastly, the pod is great for detergent conservation. You don't have to worry if you're using too much or too little detergent. And if you get the 72 count you can save more money on a per-pod basis.

This is probably the best screen protector I've ever had. If you have an S5, it goes without saying that you need to protect your phone. So look no further! Forget the price - this is the protector you need and you probably won't ever need a replacement. But guess what, if you DO need a new one, there's a lifetime guarantee if Glass becomes scratched, broken, or damaged.Glass doesn't leave fingerprints, and the touchscreen sensitivity is not affected by having the protector on. If you've got a bumper case like I do (the Spigen Tough Armor Case is great), you won't even know Glass is there.

Lots of negative reviews for this product, but I've given it a chance and it has been running just fine for me on Windows 7. Installation did not take long - maybe five or six minutes. All you need is a VCR/camcorder and a PC with or without DVD burner.With Easy Wizard Mode, you can easily transfer to DVD or digital formats. There are visual instructions which guide you through the process, so don't fret over the potential difficulty.Converting VHS to DVD is a fairly straightforward process. The image quality suffers with the transfer, but remember that VHS is not great to begin with, so take that for what it's worth.

I've previously used other bumper-style cases, and I like this Urban Armor Gear case much, much better. It protects the edges of the Note 4 (it's not for the Note 3, however), it's lightweight, but a little pricey. How it's better than other cases? It's sturdy, has a slight rubbery texture to some of the edges, preventing it from sliding on surfaces, and all of the buttons and ports function just fine.I also sometimes use a leather travel case for extra protection. The Urban Armor Gear case unfortunately won't allow me to get my Note into the leather case. Life isn't perfect.The naming of the color ("Ice") is pretty cool too. When someone asks you what style your case is, you could say "ice" and bite your teeth together like Ice Man in Top Gun. <cue the Top Gun theme>

As a former Boy Scout, the quality of your backpack is everything. Comfort and durability are very important. ERGObaby is making quality stuff (and the price is indicative of this).The straps and... well, the whole thing really, is great quality. A little heavy, but plenty of padding and comfortable to wear for the average person. It's supportive, secure, and you won't feel worried about it falling apart or having some kind of accident. Just don't wear it like a traditional backpack! The baby should only be in the front-carry position.If you're a tiny adult (not an issue in my family), this carrier may be too bulky or heavy for you.I really like the navy color as it's plain, no frills, and doesn't show dirt. The other two color options have patterns, and if you're a guy like me you probably won't care for them. To each their own though.

Good solid 2.5 way switch.  As other reviewers have pointed out, the threads were designed way too short, but adding a second rubber washer was easy and worked fine.  When set between A and B, there is much less total flow, but it does allow precise adjustment between the two outputs.  It's also very nice looking and operates smoothly.  It deserves about 4.4 stars, but I rounded up.

Nice looking and nice functioning banana plugs.  The tip and the back can both unscrew.  I found it a bit hard to tighten securly, and wish the outer edge of the back were insulated to avoid shorts, but overall it's a very good product and deserving of 5-stars.
Nice box of heat-shrink tubing's, exactly as pictured and described.

Real nice solid aluminum bracket.  Good looks and very functional.  I intentionally bent the sprayer receptacle to accommodate our slightly larger tapered spray handle, and being aluminum it allowed this nicely.

Bought this phone for my sister, it is unlocked and as described, but be advised that because it has the ATT specific software, there will be some AT&T branding, and with T-Mobile we were unable to make tethering work.  You can google the issue for more details.
Really great looking batteries.  No was to know if they last as long as more expensive cells however.

The biggest appeal to this AC is a very high 11.3 EEF, meaning 11.3 BTU/Watt, or less power for more cooling.  Also, it has some really nice + useful features such as digital temperature setting measured either (selectable) by the remote or the AC itself, and "econ" mode where the fan only runs while it is cooling.  Econ mode is smart enough to briefly spin up the fan on low every 10 minutes or so to accurately sample the room temperature.  Unit consumes ~700 watts while cooling, as measured.  Overall I'm very satisfied with this purchase.A note about Amazon Warehouse Deals, where you can purchase a used unit at discount:  It took me two tries to get a "working" unit because these guys use negligently grossly inadequate packing.  The first unit arrived destroyed, the second unit arrived damaged but working.  In both cases Amazon support and return policies were amazing, but this is still a hassle.
Good stuff, created a great seal, hard to write a novel about it though.

Very solid, functional and elegant faucet.  Easy installation, and the drain tube fits standards drains.  The drain is clever too, and is easily operated, or unscrewed to give direct access to the drain hole for de-clogging, etc.Update: While the faucet feels and looks very solid, and the action was initially very smooth and crisp, after potentially some aggressive use by visiting foreign in-laws, the action has become hard and mushy.  The solid metal handle is coupled via a non-metal material, and could be a weak link with overly aggressive users.  Not sure if the faucet or in-laws are at fault, or if it is shared blame, but Pfister seems dedicated to supporting their product so I won't deduct a star.Update2: Pfister's support is world class.  I would not hesitate to install their faucets throughout the house.

This is a super cute unpadded but lined bra.  It creates nice shape.  In the center there are two little "diamonds" to give extra sparkle.  Fit as expected, and the straps are very flexible.  Highly recommend this one.
Real nice set of heavy-duty cables.
Got them for my dad, these are real nice gloves.
Got them for my sister, she seems to like them a lot.
I prefer these skinny strips to the fatter version.  Silver (light grey)  is a good alternative to white and to me looks much nicer.
Gotta love Sakkas.  Their dresses are really interesting and for all except one major exception, have been super high quality.

High/Low is the way to go.  This gun on the high setting gets a lot hotter than my older general purpose gun, which is nice in that it heats up quicker, but with my existing glue sticks causes the glue to smoke and drip excessively.  Hopefully coupled with the right glue this gun is a 5-star performer.
Fantastic upgrade to any system.  For the T430, you can add this without removing your existing drives(s).
These work great, and are as advertised.  They stick firmly, though of course you should also use a tether on your expensive camera!

I purchased 4 of these from a different seller, your results may vary with this seller.  The four I received are great products except two major flaws:  First, the display will begin to fail after about 1 year, with the digits becoming progressively more scrambled.  Second, the temperature sensor will begin showing random numbers after it is hot for some period because the third wire which provides power to the DS18b20 is (in a Chinese way!) not connected internally in the metal sensor.  They ran but did not connect the 3rd wire, and without this 3rd wire, the sensor will work "parasitically" just fine at lower temperatures <~90C.  If you connect your own sensor this second flaw aspect will be resolved.Because the unit is sealed, you can't repair it when these problems occur.On a positive note, the display is nice and clear, compatible with other DS18b20 sensors, updates smoothly and quickly, and works great until it fails.  Again, my review is based on what I received from a different seller, so there is no guarantee that what this seller is selling has the same issues.  I've recently also purchased the blue version of this product also from another seller, and in this case it does not appear to have the "3rd wire problem" and potentially will last longer than a year, so based on benefit of the doubt, I'm giving the product 5-stars in this review though YRMV.

Bought this for my wife, size-4, 36-C.  The dress fit perfectly and was a slam-dunk keeper.  We'll be buying more from Sakkas!  Some nice things about this dress are that the bust is very accommodating.  The detailing is very pretty, and length was perfect.  Solid 5-star performer.

This will work for many countries different electrical systems but ultimately only powers a USB port. It's more useful (and takes up less packing space) to use a regular adapter for a US outlet and then pack a separate USB cable cord. The wall charger is very large compared with the equivalent adapter so I'm not likely to use this again. I didn't notice any difference in charging speed when using the device - it doesn't seem to affect the amperage.

This is a good piece of costume jewelry and is reasonably priced, though I'm not convinced of the apparent markdown from $100. The chain is small and thin while the stone is a medium size. "Made in China" is very clearly labeled on the back and there was a blemish in the stone on the piece sent to me for review. The box is cheap and would need to be switched out to make this look like an acceptable gift for a spouse. Overall, it's certainly good value but no better than many similar pieces in this price range and would certainly never be mistaken for a more expensive design.

These units are rugged and will withstand some rough treatment and bad weather, although the size is more reminiscent of a walkie 20 years ago than today. The user interface and buttons are easy to work out and there's a clear manual available if needed. Sound quality is very good and it's possible to increase the range of broadcast using the push-to-talk power boost feature.The biggest weaknesses are unfortunately really important, hence only 3 stars in my rating. The battery life is very poor, lasting only around 10 hours, and the charger takes well over 24 hours to get to 100%. Given the short battery life, I wouldn't want to be stuck somewhere remotely depending on this. The USB charging port seems flimsy and it's difficult to open - other models have a charging base which would have made it much easier.

Once installed, this is a great unit, operating very quietly compared with similar door openers, together with the added benefit of smartphone app integration. The battery backup ensures that you can get into the garage if the power is out, and wall controller has some nice additional features such as a temperature thermometer.The biggest drawback is that installation is a total nightmare, and while it's probably not much worse than many garage installers, the instructions aren't particularly friendly and it feels like the install process was never tested before roll-out. You can spend a good part of a weekend figuring out how to put this thing up and then in between multiple trips to Home Depot, it seems like better instructions would have made the process much easier. That said, if you can get professional help to avoid this issue, it's a great device and has been working wonderfully for the last 3 weeks.

What is initially set up as a run-of-the-mill stalker thriller (a family moving into a new neighborhood meets a stranger who turns their lives upside down) quickly becomes much more twisty and psychological, and is one of the best examples in recent years of how to keep audiences guessing what happens next. It's a little Fatal Attraction, a little Pacific Heights, but all with a fresh new angle that draws from the genre but leaves a mark entirely of its own.

I was excited to try this machine but out of the box found a number of severe limitations and annoyances, but first the positives. This is a relatively fast laptop for the size and works wells as a basic device for email and browser-based functions. It doesn't perform well for memory intensive apps (Photoshop, Office) and sinks like a stone if you attempt to make the graphics chip handle a second monitor, but for quick student and office tasks, it's fairly snappy and the battery life seems to average about 7-8 hours before charging.The unit arrived with no power at all and so needed charging immediately. It took about an hour of charge before the power button ever worked, so gives the impression of being dead on arrival. This is not smart on the part of the manufacturer since many people will understandably return the unit. Although the charging cable looks like a regular mini-USB port, you'll also experience vastly different charging speeds so I would recommend sticking with the Asus cable. Charging overall seems very slow and I've had to leave it plugged in overnight to get to 100%.As a tablet, this is a great device - the screen is large and bright and the touch sensitivity works flawlessly. You can almost throw away the keyboard attachment which is too light and flimsy for the screen part and tips over easily. The mouse pad is cheap and inaccurate, and the keyboard feels like a $20 add-on. This is a shame since the main body of the computer is much higher quality and even the snapping on of off isn't as smooth as other devices using the same trick (especially the Surface).Admittedly this is only a $300 device but it falls in the middle, feature-wise. For users needing the keyboard, the Chromebook is much better way to go due to the keyboard quality and battery life. For tablet users, some may find the screen too large and not need the keyboard. And for laptop users, some may find it under-powered through the memory is there. I like Asus products but this one doesn't quite fire on all cylinders.

While this isn't a bad budget case in terms of fabric quality and size, there are some drawbacks that you should consider even in this price range. Compared with the Amazon case that's $10 more, it doesn't have the auto-sleep function and the part of the case that wraps around the front of the device interferes with the buttons at the bottom and top of the screen.The stand feature isn't particularly obvious either - you'll see a number a reviews complaining that it falls over constantly. It actually doesn't, but it also doesn't show how to wrap the case and secure under the flap, and if you don't know this, it falls over. These are nit-picky items but since the number of case options in the market has exploded, they are worth thinking about. On balance, I would argue that the slightly pricier Amazon case is functionally a better alternative.

This is the perfect scent for me - I can wear it for work or for a night out and the odor is neither overpowering or too floral or artificial. Two light sprays on the neck in the morning will last most of the day and it leaves you with a clean, fresh feeling. The bottle shape and packaging is a huge talking point and everyone I've shown the product comments on the futuristic, curvy and sleek container. As a gift, this would be a big wow factor. Pricing for this item is fairly average and after testing every day for a month, I've only used around 10% of the bottle so it may well last all year.

The film fast forwards to a point where the public seems to have forgotten about the catastrophic events surrounding the first three parks and the T-Rex stomping around San Diego, and looks like a mixture of Sea World meets Islands of Adventures on steroids. The Heartless Park Manager (HPM) believes visitors need ever bigger and badder dinosaurs to keep returning (oh, the irony) so has created some giant super dinosaur that's a composite of the terrifying features of the others. Naturally, park security wasn't high on the priority list that the HPM was working from and chaos ensues.As soon as the new dinosaurs escapes from the enclosure - and you won't believe how that happens - a variety of lazily written plot mechanisms kick into place. The new Benevolent Park Owner decides to fly his own helicopter, dangerously, for no apparently reason and that doesn't end well. Our hero, Chris Pratt, believes he can talk to the Raptors while Vincent d'Onofrio as the Evil Corporate-Slash-Military Rep tries to weaponize them. Everyone with the gun has forgotten both basic training and common sense and it becomes a massacre caused by egregious stupidity more than a poorly designed dinosaur zoo. Once we get dumped into Act 3, it quickly draws on horror sequel devices with dinosaurs fighting each other and the human either becoming food or learning not to mess with nature.The main problem with Jurassic World isn't the illogical plotting, inconsistencies with the first film, unlikable characters or lack of originality, so much that it just isn't really very entertaining. The most scary element of the movie was the half-billion box office haul, meaning we'll have to suffer through many more sequels. Compared with the original, JW replaces tension and implied terror with mediocre CG and dino-fodder characters that limp from action sequence to action sequence. I never thought I would say this about a Jurassic Park movie but frankly I was bored.

If you're new to Nespresso, these are the highly addictive and convenient pods of perfect espresso that will quickly become an expensive habit. They come in a variety of flavors and styles and there are also some off-brand versions (Bestpresso, Cafemundo, etc.) that are about half the price.There are a variety of Nespresso machines on the market and this De'Longhi represents one of the higher end non-commercial units. It's capable of producing a complete cappuccino in about 45 seconds from start-up. Operating the unit is very easy - simply fill up the tank in the back, drop the pod in the top and select the size of the cup. Adding frothed, steamed milk is just another button press with the cup staying in exactly the same place.De'Longhi couldn't have done a better job in terms of aesthetics and simplicity, and even the cleaning functions are mindlessly easy. The only downside is the cost - unless you really need an integrated frothing device, you can buy the two units separately for much less. That aside, it's the perfect simple for medium usage in the home or office.

If you're looking for an example of how to take an impeccable cast, best-selling novel and high-level concept and forge a muddy, depressing, overlong death-march, this is it. Like some post cold-war throwback, this is the sort of film that constantly reminds you that you're lucky to live on the 'right side' of the iron curtain while wondering why Russians talk with such funny accents.With a plot looser than many first-draft scripts, the most exciting and colorful action sequence happens right at the start while the finale is a whimper. The main character (Hardy) has no motivation to endlessly pursue the killer. destroy his career and kill his family. Rapace is unlikable throughout the entire flick and Kinneman is wasted as a monotone, two-dimension villain bested by even the tritest of TV cop shows. By the time the audience works out the main thrust of the narrative, it's too late to care and while editing is one of the many problems here, it's the relentlessly bleak, over-long and unfocused nature of the picture that kills it for the viewer.Overall, it's a thrill-less thriller that has pretensions of investigating the importance of finding a child killer in a society that denies the existence of murder. The story is uneven, simultaneously introducing too many distracting subplots while failing to follow the key ones thoroughly enough. While some of the lame plotting would be forgiven with more interesting characters, the combination of silly plot developments, expository dialog and confusing direction neuter any attempt by a skilled cast to save it. Add a thick serving of laughably fake Russian accents and this would be better suited as a made-for-TV movie or a drinking game where you take a shot every time something unbelievable happens.

It's not that Z For Zachariah is bad for any particular stand-out reason - it's more than it's an amalgamation of things that don't work together. As such, it comes across as some sort of Lifetime drama you might watch in a hospital where pain-relieving drugs might fix the problems of the third act. It's a gentle snooze, pregnant with promise to explode into violence, but instead is satisfied with turning a church into a hydro-electric generator somewhere towards the end.It needed some external force to nudge the main characters into action - either the threat of zombies (The Walking Dead), the end of the world's food supply (Interstellar) or the ticking timebomb of death (and watching Arnie trying to act) in Maggie. Instead, the cast is happy to eat, drink, farm, walking around slowly in radiation suits, and chat. And for readers of the original book who didn't see the trailer, Chris Pine's late arrival creates what is adventurously described as a "love triangle" which lets the movie coast into a finale that doesn't really resolve anything.Ultimately the movie conversion removes the themes of the book and replaces them with Chris Pine and a waterwheel. It's so spectacularly uncinematic that you have to wonder how it got through the production process. In all fairness, the acting is fine and Margot Robbie is good, but there is less tension in the whole movie than in the opening credits of The Walking Dead. It's a little like ordering a pizza and the car shows up with a pack of cereal - it's probably better for you but you can't escape the disappointment.

The Aroma kettles are good appliances to own for 2-4 years before replacing. This model is aesthetically pleasing, easy to fill and clean and clicks onto the base without plugging directly into cables. It's possible to control the temperature with the digital keypad but in reality you're probably only ever going to use the "on" button. As a functional, fairly stylish device that fits into most modern kitchens, it's a good choice.

This is probably the best kettle I've ever used. Apart from being visually attractive with good ergonomics and fast on the boil, it also has a metal tea infuser installed, making it a two-in-one kettle and tea-pot.As a kettle, the blue LED a glass container is visually fun to watch. I haven't had any issues with calcium deposits on the glass, which I what I initially expected from my hard-water supply. The measure on the side also makes it easier to gauge how much water you need for small brews. As a tea-kettle, the infuser seems to work best for 4 cups for black tea and up to 6 cups for white or herbal teas. It very easy to set up, take apart and clean.Overall, my only minor complaint is that it takes 3-4 seconds to react to the "On" button when it's initially connected to base. Otherwise, it functions perfectly and looks great.

Although the Dummies series can be overlooked for its seemingly jovial approach to a topic, some of the very top titles really represent best-in-class introductions to topics and Mark Layton's book can be considered one of these. Scrum is a beguilingly simply subject that's hard to write about effectively and communicate the pros and cons of the approach, and it's also even tougher to find practitioners who can talk about applications beyond IT and software.The author clearly has had considerable experience in the field and I was most impressed with his ability to talk about non-tech implementations, where increasingly I think the biggest impact can be seen. The book is concise and well-written, while also being crammed with useful examples, further resources and summaries. I'd highly recommend it for learning about Scrum or as a training tool if you want to bring Scrum or other agile techniques into a team - it's one of the best books I've read on the subject.

Since I've had a protein shake lunch every day for the last six months, I've tested out a number of brands most of which you may have seen in the supermarkets. While I put a brave face on it, the truth is that none of them really tastes like the chocolate milkshake or vanilla ice-cream that they're trying to mimic, and they tend to be fairly powdery and have trouble mixing reliably.So I wasn't expecting much from Orgain's product beyond what I had seen with Vega, which is the next best alternative. Fortunately, Orgain resets the bar in terms what's possible with these mixtures. At once healthy, plant-based, inexpensive and, dare I say, even tasty, you can actually imagine the chocolate shake. Mix it with almond milk and it's practically a treat, though I'm also perfectly happy with the cold water concoction. Either way, it blends easily and is hands down the best protein powder I've tried so far.

This is about as close as you can get to a derm-abrasion treatment at home, and creates visibly brighter, radiant and smoother skin after about 3 weeks of daily usage. The machine is easier to set up and use and the instructions are clear - the hardest part is remembering to add this 5-minute daily routine, thought it can be done while watching TV. The electrical sensation is barely noticeable if you apply a generous amount of the gel though it's more noticeable in some areas on the face than others. For my skin, I found it effectively tightens the surface and shrinks pores, which also had the effect of removing early-stage wrinkles. As home treatments go, this is about as good as it gets and although the unit seems expensive, is actually the equivalent of 3-4 visits to a professional.

This is a solid entry-level offering that packs a considerable amount of hardware into the box for the price. With an average weight and above-average overall build quality, there are many good things to be said about this Toshiba range. From the snappy keyboard to the responsive and vibrant screen, it's hard to complain about what you're getting for under $500. For media fans the screen is more than adequate for movies, and the microphone and speakers work well for everything from Skype to Pandora. The only real let-down on the hardware is the mouse-pad which can be jerky and hard to control at times.On the Windows front, while version 10 is a major leap forward from version 8, it's still questionable how much we've really gained from Windows 7. While we're celebrating the return of the Start menu and other common sense UI elements, the touch controls seem mostly unnecessary and heavy office or educational users will get frustrated with the renovated accessories (calculator, please come back), missing media programs and difficulty around tasks such as managing devices and printers. None of this is the fault of this Toshiba device, however, which more than capably runs standard Windows programs with its 6GB of RAM.The PC comes packed with bloatware with everything from eBay to Dropbox vying for attention in the expanded Start Menu. It took about 30 minutes to uninstall all the junk that Toshiba have bundled here but once it was stripped down to a non-OEM build, we got along just fine. Bloatware and mousepad aside, there's much to recommend here - it's certainly leagues ahead of the Dells offered in this price range.

There are a few things to love about Burt's Bees - the products are mostly natural (many quote 99%+ natural ingredients), they're inexpensive and - most importantly - they work just as well as pricier brands. Like many of the other items in their range, the moisturizers work over an extended period and have a tendency to make your skin springier the longer you use them. The cleaning cream is extremely mild and definitely suited to sensitive or dry skin. This kit is a great introduction to the Burt's Bees range of products and if you enjoy these I would recommend checking out their lip balms, shampoo and conditioner product - all in all, you can't go far wrong.

Healthier than drinking a soda, but definitely nowhere near as nutritionally beneficial as a freshly made fruit juice, this V8 Veggie Blend at least tastes fairly palatable and is much lower in salt than some other brands I've seen (70mg per serving, 6 servings per container).Unfortunately, most of the veggie elements come from purees and concentrates, so there's a flat, bland flavor. But if you mix it with plenty of ice cubes or drink very cold, it doesn't taste too bad. Overall, it's a reasonable shelf-stable veggie option but you can't beat the real thing.

You either like the general Axe odor or you don't - in small doses it can be less lethal, but in gym locker rooms it's a persistent cloud that won't go away. For some reason this pack contains two deodorants and one shower gel when it would have been more useful to have a shampoo, shower gel and deodorant combo.Although this is an inexpensive bundle, there's nothing about the package that screams "gift" in terms of special packaging or theme. It's really just three Axe items sold together. One of the deodorants has a clever twist lock to prevent accidental spraying when it's stored while traveling. The black plastic packaging looks somewhat dated compared with many modern bathroom products for either men or women.

I am frankly stunned at how well this works. We had a particularly destructive day last week, managing to break a porcelain vase into about 10 pieces and a fireplace Travertine tile into several awkward, jagged lumps. I was unconvinced that either could be fixed and made to look reasonably new again so tried this out fully expecting it to fail, leaving only my fingers glued together.Preparing the surfaces is the key - clean out the areas from dust and debris and then dampen the edges to be glued. Apply the glue very thinly (since it expands three times the volume in the curing process) and place the edges together. Using a clamp (or Gorilla glue tape) during the drying process helps form a solid bond but isn't essential. Wipe out any excess and then wait a few hours.After, I had to use a pocket knife to remove some excess glue that had leaked out the creaks but - truly shockingly - neither the tile nor the vase show any signs of ever being broken. I can't say enough good things about this product and with a container this large, it's going to last forever.

I've seen the infomercials and now I've tested the product - although I doubt you'll be carrying it over your shoulder in your work clothes as the pictures suggest, it's definitely perfect for throwing in the trunk for tailgating, camping or just visiting friends. The unit connects quickly to the gas tank (not included, don't forget) and it always lights within a couple of clicks.Barbecue purists will dislike the Teflon tray which prevent the flames from ever touching your food. Said purists will probably disapprove of gas too but overall the smokey flavor is maintained even if you don't get the striped griddle marks shown in the pictures. While you likely won't use this as a replacement to a full home barbecue, gas or charcoal, it's a fantastic backup that's capable of turning out a considerable volume of food.

This is a small but bright led light with three white brightness settings and one red-light mode. It's not heavy at all and the opaque casing is made of rubber so it won't crack if thrown into a bag or dropped. Under the unit there's a small plastic hanging loop to allow it be supported on a pole or hook. In my testing, battery life is consistent with the manufacturer claims and you can easily get 16 hours of light on the lowest setting. The charging cable does not include a power adapter so you must have a USB-capable port available (or a different charging cable). Overall this is a good camping unit but seems very expensive for what it is (I've seen almost identical units for half the price).

This plays Blu-ray discs adequately and I didn't experience any issues with the playback, though the lack of a display on the front makes it difficult to tell if the power is on. As a basic player, it's fine and would probably receive a 4-star rating. The unnecessary apps platform works horrendously - apart from being unneeded for most people, it's one of the worst implementations of an apps interface I've seen on any device. It really seems like Blu-ray is going the way of the CD - after testing this for a couple of weeks, I'm not sure I'll ever buy a disk ever again.

This is an interesting technology that works depending upon your use case - definitely check the manufacturer's guidelines on who this is designed for before purchasing. It's definitely more convenient than electric fences that must be trenched into the property but works with similar reliability to other wireless systems I have tested.These sorts of systems will never be as effective as an actual fence due to the inherent problems in the concept but they can work 98% of the time with a properly trained dog, an appropriate battery charging regime and the ideal layout of property. Unfortunately, I need 100% reliability since otherwise the dog will disappear fairly quickly in my neighborhood and in testing this unit for 4 weeks, it has failed on two occasions. Fortunately, I was watching the dog, but for some reason on both times the unit simply did nothing.

While there's no doubt this is a conversation piece at any party here in Texas, it's more of an infrequent toy to produce on special occasions than something you would use routinely. It's a big machine and won't fit easily under cabinets so unless you have a very big kitchen (quite possible here in Texas!) it's probably not practical for most households.It's also a beast to clean and when you start poking around the machinery, it doesn't look any more well made than a basic blender. It certainly doesn't even compare that favorably to blenders in the same product range - I'm not honestly sure what you're getting for the extra hundred dollars or so on this model when the cheapest in the range is fine.That being said, I know some margarita fans who will rave about the shaved iced and the speed with which they can be holding their favorite drink. For the rest of us, you'll likely use this once or twice a year and wonder why you didn't just buy a Vitamix blender you could use every day.

This a super-smooth blend that makes a great cup of coffee and it's half the price of the Nespresso pods. We tried this with four different people and everyone enjoyed the medium flavor. I used on a Pixie Nespresso machine and had no issues at all even though it's not the official Nespresso pod. Other reviewers have reported a bitter flavor but personally I didn't find this to be the case. Overall, I would try these again.

This lamp is ideal for the small home office. If you have limited space on your desk it can fit within a limited footprint. The light is very bright and perfect for office work such as writing or using the computer. The quality of the finish and the design is more consistent with a high end lamp that is considerably more expensive.

This is medium size pan with a heavy lid for pressing the contents down, and both items are much heavier than they look. The cast iron base distributes heat evenly so you get the same char in the middle as you do at the edges. The lid is designed for grilling paninis but can be used for any two-sided grill operation. Although the instructions indicate this is dishwasher safe, as with all cast iron skillets it's preferable to wash by hand (and it will also last longer if you let it cool down naturally after use). This is as good as any super high-end brand - after several uses, I suspect this will last for many years in my kitchen with the proper care.

I wasn't sure what to expect since its feels somewhat unnatural to put plastic or rubber in the oven but I'm pleased to say these work incredibly well. We've tested for both baking and freezing numerous times and every time it's worked like a charm. After usage, they clean easily either by hand or they can be thrown in the dishwasher. My wife loves the non-stick aspect of the design but I'm still amazed how they look brand new after a couple of weeks of fairly heavy usage. Overall, this is a great product if you bake often and a must for any kitchen.Disclosure: I received a complimentary sample in exchange for a review.

This is a light, pleasantly scented face wash with minimal lather and a long-lasting moisturizing effect. It seems to work equally well for women (although the product name indicates it's for men) - my wife and I split the double-pack and have both seen skin improvements from its usage. The containers are fairly large so one of these should last a couple of months easily if used twice a day. The product is non-drying compared with typical acne or sky medication and it works well as a pre-wash before shaving.

Oh. My. God. I knew when this opened with a 5-minute shot that c=should have been edited down to 5 seconds, I was going to need matchsticks to prop my eyelids open. I hung in there for another two hours, partly because I thought I'd end up more cultured and partly because I was trying to demonstrate my artful selection of world cinema to my wife, but it just got steadily worse. Very little happens in this two-plus hour snooze fest and what does happen isn't exactly going to brighten your day. I'm sure the art-house folk are eye-rolling me right now but if you expect any type of entertainment or normal enjoyment from a film, this is one to avoid.The best scene is in the courthouse where a judgment is read very quickly for a full 4 minutes of screentime and the captions try to keep up. In most scenes, peoples are either drinking, getting drunk or already are drunk, while most of the audience wishes they were doing the same. None of the characters are engaging so it's hard to know whether to root for them or forgive Hollywood for the endless parade of superhero films and just hope that Ironman would arrive and give us a finale.It's just so slow. So, so slow. Criticize American films all you like but at least we have pacing. There's a big whale skeleton in there too - that's the leviathan of the title that has nothing to do with the plot. What a train-wreck of a movie.

This is the ultimate adventurer's camera - it can be thrown into a backpack and taken anywhere, surviving overnight outdoor setups or shooting underwater. The photo quality is significantly crisper than any phone I've tried, and although it's a step down from an SLR, it's also more compact, rugged and ready to function. The settings aren't all menu driven (buttons are provided) so it's easy to make adjustments on-site, and with the GPS and embedded WiFi, data is captured, tagged and moved off the camera as fast as your connection will allow.The package comes with almost everything - except a memory card. This is an annoying oversight on a camera in this price range and definitely dampens the enthusiasm during setup when you realize it's missing. A typical 64GB card will yield over 5 hours of recording at the highest quality setting or around 10,000 pictures on maximum resolution. Although this camera might not be useful for many people who are accustomed to their phones, if you enjoy the outdoors at all, this is a must-have.

I tested this device when jogging and doing gardening and in both cases found the sound quality to be as good as an average set of headphones. The battery life is very reasonable (18-20 hours) and it charges in well under an hour, though the Bluetooth range is fairly weak and if your phone is more than 8-10 feet away, static and crackling become a real issue. The weight of the device is ideal for maintaining position around your neck and I didn't experience and obvious problems such as the earbuds falling out when moving. If you jog in light rain and have a hoodie, this is a good way to keep your phone protected in a pocket while still listening to music. The microphone quality isn't very clear and callers reported difficulty hearing me but for listening only, it's a good product.Disclosure: I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

I've been a Linksys customer pretty much since the dawn of wireless and had generally good experiences with all of their products. This router is no exception, though it's considerably larger and more commercial and others have seen before. The first thing I noticed is the weight, higher build quality and number of ports on the device. With only two antennae (some others in this category have 3), it provided 5-bar coverage across a 4000-square foot facility with no blackout spots anywhere.Setting it up for basic usage is very simple and there are a range of approaches from using a wizard to a configuration URL. This part takes only a few minutes and is very simple. More advanced users will love the slew of extra features and you can true make this router perform for highly customized network setups. My only slight concern is the higher cost compared to other brands - if it were $30 cheaper, I would have given all five stars.

I've used several of these Netgear devices in the past and the design and functionality just gets better and better. Brainlessly simple to set up, it's like running an Ethernet across your house. It resets itself when there are power outages or accidental disconnects and frankly you would never ever know you were using anything other than a wired router. The performance is excellent and is perfect for use-cases where hard-wiring is impractical and you don't want wireless.

This kit contains everything you need for self-lancing blackheads but be warned this is a little more tricky than it looks. Fortunately the vendor does a fantastic job of providing support and email follow ups to make up you're getting all the help you need. Watching the videos help to understand how to use all the various implements but it takes some practice and isn't suitable for every type of blemish. Still, this kit is great value and it's satisfying once you get the technique learned.Disclosure: I was asked to review this in exchange for a free sample.

This is a large, durable umbrella that packs down to a small size and is easy to open and close with the automatic push-button mechanism. It's sturdy enough to hold steady in the wind and the fabric is thick enough to feel substantial. I wish the handle were black instead of red but it's not particularly noticeable either way. I particularly like the small size and the light weight when packed away making it easy to carry around in a work or travel bag.

You can use MCT oil on salads and cold food preparations but it's not suitable for cooking with due to the low flash point and denaturization of the oil (in practice, it can also taste bad when heated up for prolonged periods). If you're on a high exercise regime, you'll notice the energy boost when taking a teaspoon about an hour before a workout but I've never witnessed any of the other "miraculous" health claims that others have reported. Personally, I don't like oil and have trouble finding recipes where I can hide this but at least this brand is flavorless and odorless making it a little easier to disguise.

I love Prime and couldn't wait to proudly boast my 10 years of membership with this baseball T-shirt. Unfortunately, by the time I got around to opening the package several weeks after ordering, I noticed a small, one-inch rip down the side of the shirt. It's a little thin and the quality overall isn't particularly great so my attempt to celebrate Prime by advertising it in public has been scaled back to houseware only.

Motorola has clearly thought through the limitations of the Smart Watch concept and produced something that is attractive, functional and practical given the restraints of the technology. Apple is setting the tone for the land-grab to own your wrist but in my test of both the Apple and Android options, I much prefer the Moto 360.First, you can't get around the tragically bad battery life that all these devices have and the Moto stands out as nearly the best at a paltry 12-16 hours of charge. You can almost hear them wheezing out battery whenever the screen is on, which means this is yet another device you'll be charging every day. It's aggravating but until somebody makes a seismic leap forward in cell technology, it's what we're stuck with.It's also important to realize that the watches have very limited onboard processing power and not only rely on the phone's nearby presence but demand it for anything useful. The watches are basically an expensive notification accessory that also double as a heart-rate monitor and pedometer but they are simply not designed to do much else. Anything beyond checking an email or text always leans on the accompanying phone for processing and functionality. You won't be watching movies on your watch anytime soon.That said, Motorola has worked around the stark limitations and created a device that looks better than most of the smart watches currently on the market. It's comfortable, blends with casual attire or suits equally well, and will easily survive showering or swimming. The touchscreen is sensitive, accurate and apparently hard to scratch, and its designed to manage Android Wear very well. The wireless charging is also a great feature that works seamlessly. I especially love the way the screen activates automatically when held at the natural angle to look at the time - it's smart and endlessly entertaining.After two weeks of Android Wear, I'm enjoying the experience in every way with the exception of daily charging. I wish the strap were designed to unclip instead of fasten together but that's a minor peeve. The notification model works flawlessly with Android Lollipop and it's a great tool for runners, though don't forget you have to carry the phone too. It's a beautifully designed piece of hardware that would receive more accolades if it weren't overshadowed by Apple's device and you might be surprised how quickly you enjoy using it. At the moment, it's also only $165 on the Google Store which makes it the best value smart watch currently out there.

I love Goji berries as an addition to cereal but the biggest drawback is the price (terrifying at Whole Foods). These berries are much cheaper than my local supermarket alternative while offering an arguably higher level of freshness. As for the taste, you'll either love or hate this type of berry but they are packed with nutrients and antioxidants and can be included in smoothies, salads and cereal mixes very easily. Overall this is a great option that cuts out the supermarket markup and as with all the Viva products I've tested, the quality is excellent. Disclosure: I received a review sample from the manufacturer.

This is a very light, fresh scent that doesn't crop-dust when you walk by, and has pleasant, feminine fragrance. It's not flowery or over-powering and probably most suited to women who enjoy extremely light perfumes or don't wear scents frequently. The gift box and bottle are attractive and a little seems to go a very long way.

This is a fine home basketball system that looks like it will withstand years of play - once you get it built. As others have commented, it's a nightmare to assemble for a product that's fundamentally not that complicated (heavy base, pole, board and hoop). It ships in a very large, heavy box that most consumers will need a partner to pull apart. There are a substantial number of pieces and the instructions aren't that great (disclaimer: I'm a pro at Ikea furniture). Talking to neighbors, it sounds like most basketball systems aren't that hard to build and this brand is an outlier. So 4.5 stars for the finished product but less than 3 for the experience of getting to your first game. They should rethink the design or at the very least include a case of beer to make it feel easier.

Without knowing this was a Black & Decker appliance, I would never have guessed from the cheap build quality and disappointing performance. This is a fairly small box that gets exceptionally hot on the exterior, yet somehow manages to both burn and undercook different parts of the same frozen pizza. It's truly strange to taste frozen tomato and blistering hot carbon simultaneously, and certainly not likely to win compliments from your children let alone any culinary awards.The plasticky and flimsy design combined with its flagrant inability to keep the heat on the inside gives it a dangerous quality that made me glad it will only be switched on for 5 minutes at a time because I'm terrified to leave the room when it's in use. I have had more confidence in some indoor candles than I have from using this electrical fire waiting to happen, and I timidly disconnect and store it in the garage every time it cools down.At best this is a below-average toaster oven with a marketing bias towards pizza instead of toast. My local Target offers similar models for $30 that also unsuccessfully cook pizza but at least you've got $100 left over to order delivery. If you have a regular oven, it will undoubtedly cook more evenly and offer better odds of not burning down your kitchen than this, and even if it takes a few more minutes I think the result will be worth it.So there's a lot to not recommend here and if I sound fearful it's only because I've been through the emotional rollercoaster of getting excited about 5-minute pizza, feeling weird about frozen parts on burned parts, and then wondering if I need to put the fire department on speed-dial. While I'm generally a fan of Black & Decker products, I'd have to suggest giving this one a miss - sadly, the lure of 5-minute pizza is not worth it.

On my 100Mbs Time Warner connection, the wireless connections never pull the maximum speed from the cheaper single-antenna cards. This triple antenna PCI card is a serious processing unit with a heat sink that rivals the graphics card, and the wireless speed was noticeably multiple times faster (the speedtest.net numbers indicated a 2-3 times improvement). If you've ever installed a card before, this is no different and Windows 8 recognises the device without any problems.

While WiB2 starts off solidly enough in the Hammer horror tradition (a collection of white, middle class people are driven to the middle of nowhere to get terrified and/or killed in creative ways), it loses its way around the mid-point and quickly descends into a disastrous mess. The 'lack of spooky' at the beginning can easily be mistaken for an attempt to build suspense but it turns out there are no horrors or plot-twists waiting - aside from a couple of CG jump scares, the once-terrifying lady of the title has been neutered into a generic ghost that can barely alarm the kids in the movie.There's nothing at all new here as the scenes veer between English wartime school drama and replaying ideas from the first film. Some of it makes absolutely no sense and you get the feeling that the director wanted the movie to end almost as much as the audience. It's a real shame since the book and stage play are really first class yet the key elements here could have been derived from any horror franchise. The actors struggle through it, probably knowing that the final product is just a wasted opportunity.

This is an elegant design that's the size of a large pepper mill and it's packaged in an attractive box for gifting. Operation is easy - just fill with beans and start the hand-crank. The grinder isn't really designed for espresso and works best for French press or filter but at this price it's to be expected (for a more consistent or finer grind, you'll definitely have to spend more money). I've been using for the last two weeks and been very happy with the results. It's definitely a change to enjoy fresher beans that are ground on demand and the clean-up isn't nearly as bad as I expected.Disclaimer: I received a complimentary sample in exchange for an honest review.

My wife and I tested this out - my skin is oily and blackhead-prone whereas she occasionally has dryness. For me, it feel like a very light mask and as long as I avoided the nose area, it didn't aggravate my skin at all; for her, she enjoyed the fresh, non-greasy feeling. I didn't personally notice any differences in wrinkles though my skin felt rejuvenated and she felt it took about two weeks but there was an impact on visible wrinkles. The fragrance wasn't strong enough to bother either of us and this is a large enough container to last 3-4 months for one person.

This is a great way for improving the comfort of existing cots or, at a pinch, using as a mattress for those occasional emergencies. It folds into a cube, making it easy to store in a closet or attic when not in use. The memory foam is much more comfortable than it looks and can transform even the most aged mattress into something quite luxurious. It's great for futons - some guests like the firmness, other wants their triple-digit sleep number  - and this gives you the option of providing both. This is also a fantastic camping (or glamping?) option since it will pack into a car or SUV without any problems.

Very strong, very long and very heavy - this is a surprisingly large two-pack that will probably last several years for the general applications I have around the house. It's substantial more heavy duty than duct tape without being much thicker and seems to be able to bond any two materials together. The pack price is extremely good value. Just be careful when you unpack since the sides are very sticky.

2015 has only just started but I'm pretty confident that I won't be premature in declaring this the worst film I'll see all year. Also by my math this  means, together with The Captive, Reynolds now owes me about $12 in unwatchable dross with his name in the last six months. Unable to decide what sort of genre to fit into, The Voices unsuccessfully veers from comedy to romance to grisly murder flick, finally ending as some sort of depressing ode to insanity, featuring hilarious scenes such as a child killing his mother and a dog telling the lead to commit suicide (in a miserable way). Jesus shows up at one point too, just for laughs.There are so many things wrong with this film that I don't know whether to rant or just create a bulleted list. At first I thought it must be Canadian given the off-kilter humor (Reynolds works at a toilet manufacturing plant where everyone has to wear pink which is probably side-splitting north of the border). Then they throw in a foodie Indian guy who has maybe 4 lines in the whole film, followed by an English girl whose main job is to get decapitated and start reeling off British cliches from the inside of a fridge. The attempts at comedy are punctuated by such violence that the entire balance is thrown off, so that it's just dark in a weirdly sinister but totally trite sort of way.On the other hand, the talking cat is really great and doesn't have nearly enough screen time.Back onto what doesn't work, it's also yet another movie where the trailer shows too many key plot points and scenes from the last 20 minutes, so there's not much point in seeing the whole thing afterwards. Or in this case maybe the reverse is true - watch the trailer instead of the movie and save $7 and 2 hours. The whole story is a wasted opportunity, the CG is bad, it has no production values and the script desperately needed a rewrite. Wasn't Reynolds in RIPD as well? If you loved that, you might enjoy this one - otherwise avoid.

Nicole Kidman cannot remember anything from the day before, psychiatrist Mark Strong is trying to figure out why, and husband Colin Firth has to explain this to her repeatedly. Or so it seems. Probably more accurately titled "After I Wake Up", it's two parts Memento to one part Groundhog Day, and has the potential to misdirect and trick the audience to keep you on the edge of your seat.Unfortunately, it does neither. The trailer manages to distil all the major events of the movie to make it appear much more intriguing, but in reality this is a snooze-fest that under-utilizes three great actors. It's a full hour into the film before anything really starts to happen and the promised twist is such a predictable disappointment that it derails the whole film.Without giving too much away, once you know the end, none of the lead-up makes any sense and the characters act unrealistically and illogically. Unlike Memento, which sidesteps logic problems in favor of fastidious plotting and expert audience manipulation, this is a banal story that you'd expect at least to explain itself at the end but instead collapses under the weight of its own absurdity. And it's a real shame since these are three people who should make a 5-star movie together.

Ideal for most small-business or retail applications, this stand will protect any 7-8" tablet from casual theft by employees or customers. It's an effective deterrent since the frame looks substantial and is much heavier than you would expect. Although a malicious user can potentially take the entire stand, if you combine with a Kensington cable lock on the base, it's practically impossible to steal the tablet in any subtle or fast way. It can also in any application at home (like a kitchen or garage) where having a tablet fixed in position is a helpful replacement to paper. Overall, this is a high quality product that is a fraction of the price of similar POS security options.

This is a simple two-step brushing process: use tube 1 for one minute, then tube 2 for another minute, without rinsing in between. Over a two-week period of twice-daily usage, it does produce noticeably whiter teeth, even if you're a coffee addict. The flavor is pleasant, the process is simple and it's really a matter of just switching out from regular toothpaste with no need for teeth guards or anything complicated. It doesn't whiten as much as targeted (and expensive) whitening products over the same time frame.At this stage, I don't know the price of this product but I can say it performs similarly to Arm & Hammer's bicarbonate of soda toothpaste, which is around $3-4 a tube in supermarkets. There is a difference in taste and I know some people cannot stand the A&H substitute but it definitely whitens very effectively. If budget is an issue (or this product is as expensive as the boxed packaging suggests), it might be a good alternative.

In terms of cost, it's comparable to humidifiers I've bought from pharmacies previously, and a little more expensive than the basic ultrasonic units available on eBay and cheaper electronics outlets. Like its counterparts, you simply fill the container with water, plug it into the pedestal and hit the power button - voila, instant cloud. If you've never seen these types of humidifiers before, you'll get plenty of entertainment from the fog produced.Where this device really shines is the sheer amount of water it can vaporize. With 1.7 cups of liquid zapped every hour, this is easily the most enthusiastic humidifier I've ever owned. Putting it next to our other one, it clearly runs at twice the pace and the gigantic water tank easily holds enough for a half-day. It also features a decent build quality, it's simple to clean and has an integrated water softener. Overall, with a feature-set this rich, it's great value and I'd highly recommend to anyone.

As business books go, this is a short, focused attempt to get what we might term "traditionalists" to jettison some long-held ideas about corporate innovation and take a leap of faith into a totally alien alternative. For anyone coming from any environment like this, I'd recommend reading Schrage's  work purely for the repetitive reinforcement of his 5x5 mantra, and that if you leave knowing this single concept and nothing else, it might yield some genuine positive benefits to you.On the other hand, if you're either an avid reader of lean methodologies and other books in this category, or you work in an industry (like software) where "fast-fail" or experimental approaches are commonplace, there's not as much new material here as you would hope for. It's interesting and passionately argued for but in terms of actionable ideas that you could introduce to colleagues and co-workers, you might be able to distil the key concepts into a 4-5 minute presentation.

If you're looking for a smaller pepper spray for a key-ring or bag, this is an excellent choice. The plastic container is a small, tough casing for the aerosol and very difficult to trigger accidentally (yet it's easy to activate when needed). The ring extension works well if you have a bulky collection of keys too.Now for the pepper spray, which jets out in a continuous stream that's about 7-8 feet away. If this contacts your skin or you're in the general vicinity, it's instantly debilitating. Fortunately, the practice canister lets you get a feel of how to disarm the aerosol and spray safely with the same liquid but with no pepper component. Overall, this is a small unit that packs a powerful punch and I'd highly recommend it for self-defense for both yourself and family members.

The shape, size and color is perfect for a keychain and visible enough to find quickly in a bag, while being easy to grasp and operate with no trouble at all. The biggest problem, and my only reason for the low rating, is that this doesn't spray a continuous liquid stream compared with SABRE's other products I've tried. It sprays a mist (more like you would expect from a deodorant aerosol) that's as likely to hit the victim as the attacker. This makes it extremely difficult to aim at a third party at a 6-8 foot distance. When we tested it outside, even 2 feet away from the mist left us coughing for minutes, so while there's no problem with the product itself, the targeting method in this device seems highly ineffective.

We ordered these beautiful napkins for a fall party. The orange color is gorgeous! A rich golden hue that mimics the falling leaves outside. The origami design is very pretty and really dressed up my table dcor. Setting them up was very easy, a simple matter of opening and giving them a fluff.  Unfolded, the napkins were a generous size and of a good quality.

My little sister had the very first Baby Alive and I'm pretty sure I have gifted someone with every version since then. Super Snacks Snackin' Sara is the latest, just in time for Christmas 2015.While there are basics to Baby Alive that seem to stay the same,( the large eyes, that odd mouth, and generic, rather nasty, cheap hair) this version does have some innovations.Gone is the wet food that makes messes and requires a supply of fresh diapers. Instead, Sara eats a play-doh facsimile that pretty much stays the same going in and coming out. You child rolls and cuts various food items with the included cutters, which just adds to the fun. The winner here is that the two diapers that accompany Sara can be reused over and over.She comes with two containers of play-doh, three cutters, a roller, a feeding bowl, a pretend juice box, two diapers and a cute outfit.Sara also speaks 30 different phrases in both English and Spanish.

My little sister had the very first Baby Alive and I'm pretty sure I have gifted someone with every version since then. Super Snacks Snackin' Sara is the latest, just in time for Christmas 2015.While there are basics to Baby Alive that seem to stay the same,( the large eyes, that odd mouth, and generic, rather nasty, cheap hair) this version does have some innovations.Gone is the wet food that makes messes and requires a supply of fresh diapers. Instead, Sara eats a play-doh facsimile that pretty much stays the same going in and coming out. You child rolls and cuts various food items with the included cutters, which just adds to the fun. The winner here is that the two diapers that accompany Sara can be reused over and over.She comes with two containers of play-doh, three cutters, a roller, a feeding bowl, a pretend juice box, two diapers and a cute outfit.

Wow. Duo Underwater MP3 player is unlike any that we have tried before. Instead of ear buds, FINIS used a "bone conduction audio transmission" that delivers audio directly through the cheekbones to the inner ear. There is a clip that secures the device to goggle straps and allows it to rest on your cheekbone.I used them with my K180 and the fit was just fine. The controls are super simple with one four buttons to maneuver, and yet you can switch between music, audio books, or podcasts. I can't imagine swimming to an audiobook, but that's just me. I like music to help move me through the water.The sound is vastly improved when the player is underwater, as it is designed to work. This creates and issue when doing the breaststroke. Because your head is in and out of the water, the sound kind of goes in and out in an annoying fashion. It should be noted that the sound is a bit off. I'm guessing it's because it never actually goes through your ear, so it just sounds different. However, I did not expect it to sound to be the same as my speakers in my living room.The company tells us that this MP3 player is waterproof to 3 meters for 30 minutes. It is combatable with iTunes and I in fact, did use iTunes to download my favorites and had no problems. It does come with an Auxiliary USB cable that allows for Universal data transfers and charging. The device offers 4GB of flash memory and a Lithium-Ion rechargeable battery life of up to 7 hours. I did not get 7 hours of play on a charge, it was more like 5 1/2 hours. I know this only because I kept track of the times between swims. I'm not the sort of person who would swim for that long! So, unless you are that sort, using it, cleaning it, and recharging may be what you do as well.In appearance this player is very trendy looking, in black and acid green. It would be well like by either male of female swimmers.

I try to avoid unitaskers in my kitchen, those items that I only use for one thing. Take for example, my aluminum roasting pan that cannot be used for anything but oven roasting. (It's also ugly)This beauty from Viking is completely different. It has weight behind it and is equally at home in the oven and on top of the stove. It roasts beautifully as the heft of the pan circulates heat evenly. The rack is sturdy and has proven to be reliable. The lid can be used as a saut pan or serving dish. Yeah, this roaster is that pretty; it positively gleams! And with the easy care of stainless steel, it will look great for years.

I own several water bottles from Contigo. The Matterhorn is one of my favorites. I like my water COLD, icy cold! And this water still had ice rattling around in it 8 hours after I filled it. I haven't tried it with coffee, as I never use a bottle for both. The lid unscrews, then there is an inner circle that unscrews and makes filling the bottle with ice much easier. I like that the inner seal makes a very nice edge to drink from. Other metal bottles have had rough or sharp edges.Unlike some others, I had no trouble getting the instruction sheet out of the bottle, I think it was clever to handle it that way, significantly reducing the amount of packaging needed.A couple of things:This bottle is heavy. On a bad fibro day, I need to make a different choice of water bottle.I sure wish it came in different colors. I wish it came in other colors.

Pie Face Game is just about as silly as you imagine. There is no finesse, no strategy, just crazy suspense of who is going to get SPLAT! You can use whipped cream or a damp sponge. Either one will cause riotous laughter and gleeful cackles. While the game is lots of fun, it is pretty thin plastic and with our rowdy crew, I don't expect it to last a long time. But while it does, the kids are having a ball with it!

Our household has begun including kale in our weekly menus. I was very interested in trying this product, the squash, bananas and kale version.First of all, we have a toddler, 14 month old, who pretty much eats everything. Happily, she really liked this too. We tried mixing it into Greek yogurt. That was a winner! Then we tried oatmeal, and she liked that as well.It's really convenient to throw into the diaper bag. I like knowing I can give her great nutrition even when we are traveling.Four stars out of five because the cost is pretty high for a continual purchase.

Our family has mad, crazy, love for Melissa and Doug toys. This wonderful tea set is a prime example of why we feel that way. The set is beautifully crafted of wood, approximately 1/4" inch thick and painted in a red, light blue, and cream palette that is perfect for either girls or boys.Included in the set is a tea pot with removable lid, sugar (or honey!) bowl with cut out lid and spoon, creamer with spout, two mugs, two additional spoons, a plate with two cookies, a menu order form, cutest of all, a box of six "tea bags" with choices ranging from Rooibos to Earl Grey. The tea caddy has a sliding plastic lid embossed with the names and descriptions of the teas. Although the photo shows a tablecloth, there is not one included. The yellow in the photo matches the bottom of the box so you could cut it out and use it if you want.It should be noted that this set is not designed to actually hold water.Our two youngest grandchildren are 18 months and 3 years, and the cups are the perfect size for them. Our older grands cannot fit their fingers in the cup handles.If it were possible to give a rating higher than 5 stars, this set would desire it!

I first purchased this game back in the 80s for my oldest daughter. This is the original 8 x 8 squares version, brought back by Winning Moves.  Basically Upwards is to Scrabble as 3D Chess is to Chess. New words are formed not only with horizontal and vertical tiles, but also in height. You can build on words, change words, and create chaos to those poor souls who love the order and method of traditional Scrabble.Play is as follows: Players draw 7 tiles. The first player forms a word that covers one of more of the center squares, and then draws more tiles to maintain 7. The next player can build words adjacent to and on top of the played word. For example, if the word "sound" were on the board, you could add an "a" and play a "r" over the "s" to make "around". You score one point for each tile in your word, plus a point for each tile UNDER your word. The board is purposely small to encourage building words up. Unlike Scrabble, there are no extra points squares on the board.Upwards is a fun family game, basically aimed at players over 10 years old. However, we do play it with our younger spellers, just with obviously simpler words. Any game that encourages kids spelling and word play gets a 5 star review!

These 36-grit 3" IIT Roloc style sanding discs are working well for metal prep on my vehicle. I've been using them with my die grinder along with a 3" IIT brand disc holder pad. I'm not sure if these will fit any other brands of disc holders though. The sanding discs spin on and off the holder easily and stay in place securely. Some of the sanding discs were mounted a little of center off their plastic hub, but it didn't seem to cause any noticeable vibration. These aluminum oxide discs are rated for 20,000 RPM's and have been doing a good job removing surface rust and old automotive paint. At 25 per bag, I think the price for these here on Amazon was very reasonable and I would buy again when needed.

This Sid Harvey 250-48 replacement cartridge was a perfect fit for the FULFLO FB4 filter canister on my oil fired boiler and included the three gaskets required for installation. These are identical to the Mitco 250-48M and Westwood F80-36 cartridges.

These are very decent pellets overall and I got them for a great price here on Amazon. They have worked perfectly in all of my five of my .177 cal CO2 pistols with no jams or other issues. All of the 7.9 grain pellets in these larger 750-count tins have been in excellent condition and I've shot hundreds and hundreds of them without any problems such as bent skirts or undersized pellets. They have also been quiet accurate with the close range target shooting that I'm using them for. Nice hollow point pellets at a reasonable price that I've been very pleased with, so will definitely purchase them again.

I recently purchased this new semi-auto P250 pellet-only pistol from Airgun Depot, since they seemed to be the only ones that had the black version in stock. This is an actual SIG Sauer product that is being manufactured in Japan and seems decently made. The pistol uses a standard 12g CO2 cartridge and is a blowback design. The package says it is rated at up to 500 FPS, but there is no mention of what ammo is used to achieve that, so I will assume it is probably with some type of lightweight alloy pellet. Accuracy seems pretty good at around 8-meters or less, as long as a proper two-hand grip is used to compensate for the hefty blowback. If you happen to already own SIG's other new all metal P226 pellet pistol, then this P250 with its polymer frame feels like it may not be in the same class as far as being a replica, but in reality, the actual P250 firearm also has the polymer frame, so is true to form. The slide on this pistol is metal, however the slide lock is not functional. Neither is the take down lever. The decocking button is functional though and also acts as a safety. The 16-round rotary clip is made of plastic and is the same one used in the P226. The front and rear sights are fixed and both have white dots.  The trigger is reasonably smooth and the pistol has both single and double action. The P250 weighs in at 1.89 lbs with a CO2 cartridge and fully loaded clip installed. This pistol does not have the nice self-piercing feature for the CO2 cartridge like the P226 does. Instead it uses a traditional piercing screw, but at least the piercing screw and knob are all metal and concealed inside the handle. I'm averaging around 45 to 50 solid rounds per cartridge. The literature recommends replacing the cartridge at 64 rounds, but so far I haven't even seen that number. SIG says the pistol is use-tested for 15,000 cycles just like the P226 and I think the overall build quality is very good for what it cost.

I purchased these Skenco Blue Arrow pellets here on Amazon for a very good price. These pointed 6.4 Grain lead free alloy pellets are actually a two-piece design using a smooth, blue plastic sleeve or sabot for a skirt. For pointed pellets, they have a short overall length and will fit into rotary type clips, so I'm using them with a collection of .177 Cal CO2 pistols for close range target shooting at 8-meters or less.  Oddly enough, the skirt of these pellets is just a little to large in diameter to allow them to fit into the clips of my Gamo PR-776 revolver, but they will fit perfectly into the clips of my Umarex S&W M&P 45, SIG Sauer P226 and P250 as well as my Crosman Vigilante 357. With my CO2 pistols, the pellets will blow clean through plastic soda bottles without issue, whereas the lead pellets I've used will just bounce off. They don't seem to compress or distort at all, even when hitting something hard, so they will penetrate nicely, at least at close range. Overall, for what I'm using them for, these pellets are working well and I would definitely purchase them again.

I occasionally use these Beeman .22 cal felt cleaning pellets as the last step when cleaning the bores of my Optimus break-barrel rifle and 2240 CO2 pistol. After cleaning, I'll put a few drops of RWS synthetic Chamber oil on some of these cleaning pellets and run them through the bore with my rod and Jag. They seem to do a decent job of distributing the oil and leaving a very thin film evenly all around the bore.
