The package says you can shoot these pellets through your gun to clean it, but I never use them that way. I prefer to just push them through the bore by hand with a Jag. I don't clean my air guns all that often, so this 80-pack of pellets will likely last me for quite a while.

These Beeman .177 cal felt cleaning pellets work pretty well for helping clean and lube the bores of my pellet pistols. I usually use them as a last step, after using a bore brush along with Hoppe's synthetic bore cleaner and cleaning patches first. I'll place a few drops of synthetic oil on a couple of pellets and run them through the bore one at a time. They seem to do a good job of spreading a thin film of oil around evenly. The package says "Clean your airgun by shooting!", but I never use these pellets that way. I prefer to just use my cleaning rod and Jag to push them through.

I purchased this Air Venturi pellet pen to speed up loading my break-barrel rifle when out in the field. It's been working great, but took a little getting used to, like anything new and different does. This pen tube is made of green tinted plastic and holds fifteen .22 cal pellets, whether they are wadcutter, domed or pointed. It has a ratcheting thumb slide to advance the pellet and insert into the breech. This model also comes with a cap that has an adjustable depth pellet seating tool. The seating tool tip resembles the end of a retractable ball point pen and can be used to seat the pellet to the desired depth after loading. This pen is so much easier than fumbling around with a pouch or tin and trying to load a pellet with your fingers, especially when wearing gloves. It's works so well that I'm thinking of getting a couple of their .177 pens to speed up loading the rotary clips for my pellet pistols.

This new SIG P226 MK-25 pellet pistol had been on backorder for weeks everywhere I looked, including here at Amazon, but I finally found it in stock at Cabela's, in both the Dark Earth and Black colors, so purchased it there. This is an actual SIG Sauer product and is being manufactured in Japan. For a CO2 pistol it's pretty powerful and the blowback is quite heavy. The package says it is rated for up to 510-FPS, but doesnt specify what ammo is used to achieve that number, so I'll just have to assume it is with alloy pellets. Accuracy seems very good at about 5 to 6-meters with the RWS Superdome, Beeman Hollow point, Gamo Rocket and Crosman Premier 10.5 Gr Domed pellets that I've used it with so far, however this pistol is kind of a beast and actually requires some getting used to in addition to a proper two-hand grip to maintain accuracy and compensate for the blowback. With a right handed shooter, if a proper two-hand grip is not used, the pistol will consistently shoot low and left due to the forward kick from the slide returning.The front and rear sights are fixed and both have white dots. Other than the grip and 16-round rotary pellet clip, which are both plastic, this pistol is all metal and weighs in at 2.8 lbs with a CO2 cartridge and loaded clip in place. The self-piercing CO2 cartridge loading system works very well. You just press the release button to open the access door on the back of the handle, slide the 12g cartridge in place and snap the cover closed. I'm averaging about 50 solid rounds per cartridge. The user instructions recommend replacing the cartridge at 64 rounds, but I haven't got near that number yet. You can either rack the slide for single action on the first round or just pull the trigger and the first round will be double action and then the slide cocks the hammer back for single action on each of the remaining seven rounds. Speaking of the trigger, it is very smooth and predictable on this pistol. SIG did a very good job of lubing all of the internal moving parts in this pistol, which is something a lot of manufactures seem to forget. The knurled metal cap on the tip of the 11.5mm X 1.0 threaded  barrel is removable. I'm guessing this is so a compensator or barrel extension can be installed, but not sure. The take-down button and slide lock buttons are not functional and the slide also does not lock back when the clip is empty. However, the decocking button is functional. It releases the hammer and also acts as the safety. Overall, the build quality on this pellet-only pistol is excellent and even more impressive when considering what it cost.

These Crosman LPH hollow point pellets have been working great in my air guns. I'm getting decent range and good accuracy with both my .22 cal. Crosman 2240 pistol and Optimus rifle. They are 14.3 grain and will hit quite hard even at distance. I havent had any issues with bent skirts or undersized pellets like I have with some other brands. Overall they seem to be very good quality pellets and I've been quite happy with them, so would definitely purchase again.

This Umarex .177 S&W M&P 45 pistol is very decently made for the price. It has mostly metal internal working parts surrounded by a black polymer plastic slide, frame and grip. At 1.7 pounds, it has a little bit of heft to it which adds to the realism factor. It came with one die cast metal 8-round rotary pellet clip along with one black plastic 8-round BB clip that will likely never get used with this pistol since it has a nice 3.1" rifled steel barrel that I don't want to risk being damaged. The 12g CO2 cartridge loads into the rear of the handle through a hinged lift up plastic back strap cover that snaps securely closed to conceal the cartridge piercing screw knob, for a nice clean look. It is a non-blowback design and has both single and double action. For having such a short barrel, the pistol is quite accurate with very good target penetration at around 6-meters. I'm averaging a good 40 solid shots per CO2 cartridge, with probably still another 10 or so usable at closer range. I purchased an extra 3-pack of the 8-round pellet clips so I can spend more time shooting and less time reloading. Overall, for what it cost, this Umarex M&P pistol is nicely made and is a lot of fun to shoot, so would definitely recommend it.

I bought two tins of these .177 Gamo Hunter pellets here on Amazon and have had mixed results. The first tin of pellets was fine with absolutely no issues at all and they shot well. The second tin however was a different story altogether. It had lots of pellets with badly bent and misshapen skirts that wouldn't even load into the Umarex rotary clips I was using. It also had many pellets that were that were so badly undersized they would either fall out of the clip when loaded or would back out of the clip when firing the pistol, causing jams. About every sixth pellet had some sort of problem that made it unusable. Very frustrating to say the least. For that reason, I don't think I will be purchasing any more of these Gamo Hunter pellets anytime soon. For me, it's just not worth the aggravation.

This sling swivel and mounting stud set was a perfect fit for my Crosman Optimus .22 air rifle with a barrel OD of .058". Installation was pretty straight forward and the instructions were easy to follow. The front barrel band mount is two pieces so it can be slipped over the rifle's barrel without having to remove the front site or disassemble anything else. Once tightened down it holds tight and stays securely in place, even with rough handling. The rear mounting stud requires drilling a counter bored hole in the stock starting with 7/32" to a depth of 1/8" and finishing with 5/32" to a depth of 7/8". The swivels included are 1" wide and are also the quick attach/detach style so the mounts can stay in place permanently even if the sling is removed. I'm using these with an Allen Endura 85 sling and it's been working out perfectly for my needs.

This Crosman Vigilante is a decently made .177 cal pellet pistol for the price. Nothing too fancy, but it is quite accurate and lots of fun to shoot. The frame is die cast zinc and the barrel assembly is made of the same black polymer plastic that many other manufactures use for their air guns. For a CO2 pistol it has pretty good muzzle velocity and target penetration at 8-meters. This pistol kit included a nylon holster along with three extra 10-round pellet clips, in addition to the stock one that comes with it. There is also one 6-round BB clip included. The two-piece black plastic handle grip is easily removed for replacing the CO2 cartridge, but the two halves seemed a little loose on the frame and would rattle slightly when in place, which I found annoying, so I added black 3/16-inch diameter stick-on foam dots at each of the corners of the handle frame on both sides and the plastic handle grip now fits snuggly with no movement. I posted a pic below showing the location of the foam dots. Overall, for what this pistol cost, I think it was a good purchase and would have no issue recommending it to anyone looking for a decent, inexpensive CO2 pellet revolver.

This Uncle Mike's MO52221 large size pistol rug is a good fit for my Crosman Vigilante 357 with the 6-inch barrel as well as my Gamo PR-776 revolver, also with a 6-inch barrel, and my Crosman Model 2240 .22 pistol with the stock 7-1/2" inch barrel. It has a full length nylon zipper that will allow it to lay completely flat when open. The rug has a woven nylon loop on the end so that can be used with a small padlock to lock the zipper closed if desired. There is also a loop to hang it up with on the opposite end. The exterior of the rug is made of black woven nylon with a soft fabric lining and a decent amount of padding, so should be able to protect my pistols from both dust and minor bumps while in storage and when transporting them in my truck. In addition to the pistols themselves, there is enough additional room available in this rug for me to carry extra pellet clips, a couple of 12g CO2 cylinders and tin of pellets, so I can use them as grab and go shooting kits. Considering what I paid for it, I think this rug was a good buy and would have no issue recommending it.

This medium size pistol rug is a nice fit for my Umarex S&W M&P 45, SIG Sauer P226 and P250. It has a full length nylon zipper that allows it to lay perfectly flat when open. There is a nylon loop on the end that can be used with a small padlock to lock the zipper closed. The rug has woven black nylon exterior with a good amount of padding and a soft black lining, so should offer decent protection for the pistols from dust and minor bumps while in storage and when transporting in my truck. In addition to the pistol, there is enough room available in this rug for me to carry a couple of 12g CO2 cylinders, some extra clips and a 250 count tin of .177 pellets to make a basic shooting kit. Considering what it cost, I'm happy with it and would buy again if needed.

This soft side case is a decent fit for my Optimus .22 air rifle with scope. It seems like it should be fine for basic, general purpose storage of my rifle to keep dust away and prevent scratches from minor scuffs and bumps when transporting it behind the seat of my truck. This case is from the Pit Bull Economy Series made in China by Bulldog. The overall exterior dimensions of my case are 48-inches long X 10-inches wide with approximately 46-inches X 9-inches of usable interior space.  My rifle is 43-inches long, so there are approximately 3-inches of additional length available inside as well as about 2-inches of additional width. The exterior of the case is made from black woven nylon and has a full length nylon zipper, so it can lay flat when opened. There are two woven nylon handles for carrying and also a plastic loop at the top for hanging the case when it's not being used to store your rifle. The interior is nicely foam padded with a soft woven black covering. There are no interior or exterior pockets, but at this price I wasn't really expecting any. The tag on it says "It Floats", but I'm assuming that just refers to the empty case, not one with a rifle in it. If I had a nicer, more expensive rifle I would probably get a more expensive case, but for my needs this economy case should be adequate.

I think this Crosman Optimus air rifle is a real honey for the money. For just over a hundred dollars it is very nicely made and the fit and finish on mine were perfect right out of the box. For an air rifle it has quite a bit of power behind it. It sent a round of Crosman .22 Ultra Mag clear through a piece of 1X pine board at a distance of about 10-feet. When fired it has a satisfying kickback and bang, at least for an air gun, so much so that I need wear hearing protection when firing it in the indoor range I have set up in my basement or my ears will be ringing, because it's at least as loud, if not louder, than my Porter Cable FR350 framing nailer is. The stock is decently made from solid wood and has a nice low-sheen satin finish. A couple of coats of Trewax clear paste wax has made it look even better. The break barrel mechanism works smoothly and really isn't that difficult to operate. The trigger takes a little getting used to though in order squeeze it smoothly without jerking the rifle because it's stiff and has a lot of travel. Thankfully though, the trigger pull is adjustable. I backed the adjustment screw out [counterclockwise] about 1-1/2 turns and along with a couple of drops of RWS Spring Oil on the triggers pivot points, it made the trigger pull much lighter and more predictable than the factory setting.The trigger safety lever is a nice design. It holds positively when set and is easy to operate with your trigger finger. The CenterPoint scope is decently made as well and was easy to install. I didn't have any issues with it other than it took a bit of fiddling to get it zeroed in. Overall, considering what I paid for it, I'm pretty impressed with this air rifle and would have no problem recommending it.

This .177 Cal. air gun cleaning kit is decent for what it costs. I think the Spring Cylinder Oil and Chamber Lube are where most of the cost is, but then the small 250 count tins of Meisterkugeln Pro Line 8.2gr and Superdome Field Line 8.3gr pellets as well as the booklet of ten 4-Inch sighting targets also adds to the total. The kits 3-piece cleaning rod has a rotating handle and is made in Italy by Stilcrin. When used with the two 9-Inch threaded extensions, it has a total usable length of just over 24-Inches, plus the length of the cleaning attachment. The nylon bristle bore brush and aluminum Jag are both about 2-1/2-Inches long overall. There is a 3-Inch long aluminum oiling needle that screws onto the plastic tips of the oil bottles. A pack of 25 felt cleaning pellets is also included. This same basic cleaning kit is available in .22 Cal. as well. Overall, I think it's a pretty decent cleaning kit and at the time I purchased it the price here on Amazon was the best I could find anywhere. One issue with the cleaning rod that comes with this kit though is going to be finding replacement bore brushes that will fit. It might be a little difficult because the rod has a 5/40 thread male end that connects to the brush. The .177 bore brushes from all the major manufactures seem to have a 5/40 thread male end, not female, which is what is needed to use this rod with the handle. I also have not been able to locate a 5/40 to 5/40 thread female/female conversion adapter, only the female/male versions.Update: I was able to have a 5/40 female to female threaded brass adapter custom made from a seller on eBay for 6.50 delivered. Now I can use the cleaning rod with any brand of .177 bore brush or jag and along with the addition of a 5/40 male to 8/32 female adapter, I can also use the same cleaning rod for .22 bore brushes and jags.

I purchased this WR25 gauge primarily to use for setting the cutter and blade height on my router table and table saw, but I'm also finding that it comes in handy for other things that need the height set or adjusted or depth measured, such as screw and dowel holes. It can straddle the cutter or blade so is a lot easier for me to use than a standard ruler. For a fairly inexpensive gauge, I've found it to be quite accurate and it saves me from a lot of extra test cutting and additional fiddling with height adjustments. The gauge has auto power-off and displays fractions in 1/32" increments with a maximum depth range of approximately 3". It seems decently made overall and even came with an extra CR2032 coin battery. The body is made of sturdy plastic with two magnets inset in the base of the legs so it can stick securely to ferrous metal tables, but of course they don't work if your tables are aluminum or MDF like mine. The mode settings on the gauge for inch/metric and incremental measurement are easy to figure out and the digital display itself is easy to read, but is not backlit. No storage case or pouch was included, but it should be easy enough to find a small zippered case at the camera store or someplace similar. For what it costs I think this height gauge is definitely worth having and would have no issue recommending it to anyone.

These 3" X 1/32" cut off wheels are decently made and have worked well for cutting steel tubing and hollow 1/8" X 27 NPS threaded rod used for light fixtures. They are made by Cal-Hawk and came in a pack of eight along with a 3/8" mandrel with a 1/4" shaft. They are rated at 20,300 RPM and seem well balanced with no noticeable vibration when running in my die grinder at high speed. Considering what they cost I think they were a good value and would purchase again when needed.

This IIT disc holder pad has been working well with the IIT branded sanding discs. It has a 1/4" shank and is rated at 20,000 RPM's. There doesn't appear to be any noticeable vibration from it even at high speed. The sanding discs will spin on and lock in it securely and also spin off easily when it's time to change them out. It was much less expensive than the actual 3M brand Roloc disc holder, so for what it cost, even if it lasts for only a couple more jobs I will still be more than happy with it.

These 2" IIT Roloc style sanding discs are working well for some metal prep I'm doing. I'm using them in my die grinder along with the 2" IIT disc holder pad, so not sure if they fit other brands of disc holders. The discs spin on and off the holder easily and seem to stay in place securely. Some of the sanding discs are a mounted a little off center of their plastic hub, but it doesn't seem to add any noticeable vibration or affect how they work. The 36-grit aluminum oxide is doing a good job removing automotive paint and surface rust in some of the areas that would be tough to get at with a larger disc sander. These discs are rated for 20,000 RPM's, but I have been using them in a 25,000 RPM die grinder since once in use and under load, the tools RPM's will drop enough that they will operate within their rated speed. I will go through quite a few of these discs at a time, but I think that is just to be expected with such a tiny disc and not really an issue. I'm only using them for smaller surface areas anyway. At 50 discs to a bag, I think the price for these here on Amazon was also very reasonable.

I purchased this rack for our 2004 RAV4 and it seems to be working out very well. The rack can hold two bikes which is great, but right away, I noticed that the lower support tube of the racks frame has no padding on it at all, so while the vehicle is driving down the road the front sprocket or pedal crank of the inner bike can bump or rub against the tube and damaged its paint, no matter how well you strap the bike down. To remedy this I put some foam pipe insulation on the tube, which worked to cushion the contact with the bike. For the price of this rack, I feel there there should have been some type of padding installed there from the factory because it seems like a pretty obvious problem. Other than that one issue, the rack seems to be well designed as well as made from good quality materials. Installation was fairly simple, but the instructions could probably be a little clearer as to which clip goes with which strap on the racks frame. With our RAV4, both the inner and outer halves of the spare tire cover had to be removed, which requires removing the spare tire from the vehicle and reinstalling it, so that adds a little more time to the install. Overall though, the rack is working well and seems like it should last for several years with regular use, so I think it was worth what I paid for it here on Amazon.

I purchased this collet cone for my Makita GD0601 1/4" die grinder to allow use of my collection of Dremel bits and accessories with it, which have 1/8" shanks. It's kind of pricey for such a small part, but it fits and works as it's supposed to and also adds versatility to my die grinder, so for my needs I feel it was worth the cost.

I just recently purchased this Dewalt DCS370 band saw and really have taken a liking to it. I've always just used a corded band saw for the majority of my smaller metal cutting work, so this cordless has already proven itself to be to be a real time saver. The Dewalt saw is single-speed design and the 32-7/8" X .020 blade runs at 570 SFPM, which is fast for a portable band saw and makes for some surprisingly quick cuts for such a small saw. In comparison, my corded Milwaukee's 44-7/8" X .020 blade runs at a maximum speed of 350 SFPM. The Dewalt only has a 2-1/2" capacity, but I find that it will actually cover many of the things I often cut like strut, allthread, PVC pipe and EMT or conduit where the extra capacity of a larger saw is not generally needed anyway. I prefer to use this saw with the Dewalt 18V Li-Ion batteries, which are quite a bit lighter than the NiCad's and makes for better balance and easier one handed cutting. The battery life has also been surprisingly good for this saw. For some reason the Lowes and HD stores in my area don't carry the 32-7/8" replacement blades for this saw, but they are easy to come by online from Amazon as well as places like eBay, Grainger and MSC Supply. The blades usually come in packs of three for around twenty dollars and in addition to Dewalt's own branded blades, these blades are also being made by MK Morse. Makita has them available as well, but their price per blade seems to be a little on the expensive side. Olson doesn't currently make band saw blades of this size and apparently has no interest in making blades this small, even though just about every electrical, HVAC and plumbing contractor around seems to use a cordless band saw on the job these days. I find myself using this saw all the time now because it is just so compact and convenient. Overall, I'm quite pleased with this saw and I think the only regret I have with it is that I waited as long as I did to get one.

I've found the GD0601 to be a very decent die grinder for the price. The grinder is a single-speed 25,000 RPM unit, not variable-speed as the technical details seem to indicate. No storage case is included either as is also incorrectly indicated. I was able to find a really nice foam lined 14-7/8" X 9-3/4" X 4-1/4" metal storage case from Coastal Tool, [Part#: CC] for around twenty-three dollars that fits the grinder well and also has a small removable metal parts bin that can hold the collet wrenches along with several bits and accessories. A side handle for this grinder is available from Makita [Part#: 192985-5], but requires sliding the rubber boot off the nose of the tool to install it. When the side handle is removed the rubber boot can be slipped back on the tool again if desired. The side handle is the same one that comes with the Makita GD0800C die grinder and I consider it to be a necessity for a straight die grinder when using it with wire end brushes and sanding discs. I had to find this out on my own though, because Makita's own Technical Support didn't even know that their die grinders could use a side handle. This grinder is fairly lightweight for its size. It's rated at 3.5A and is double insulated with an 8-foot 2-wire power cord. The power switch has a lock-on position for continuous use. The tool runs very smoothly and is also reasonably quiet for a die grinder. It can be used with many different types of bits and attachments like 3-inch cut-off wheels, grinding stones, sanding drums, wire brushes, flap wheels and burr bits as well as 2-inch and 3-inch Roloc wheels and sanding discs. I purchased a 1/8" Makita collet cone [Part#: 763626-6] for the grinder so I can use it with my Dremel bits if needed. Overall, I'm very pleased with this grinder, especially when considering that the price here on Amazon also included an additional twenty dollars off from Makita, which made the deal unbeatable anywhere else.

I've had this Dewalt DW059 impact wrench for several years and really like it a lot. I've always been impressed with how much torque it has, considering that its a cordless. This is the model that uses a detent pin to retain the socket on the shaft, not the other hog pin style that Dewalt also makes. It has a rocker switch that thankfully has no trigger lock to fiddle with, which makes it great for momentarily switching back and forth between forward and reverse to help break frozen nuts and bolts free. I use it for the usual things like lug nuts when rotating tires on my vehicles, but I've also found that it works great for RV leveling jacks. It makes the job of leveling an RV after parking a much faster and easier job than the regular method. I've run into some RV jacks that were so stiff and frozen from being exposed to salt air and beach sand all season that I doubt I could have ever gotten them to free up using a regular wrench with a breaker bar no matter how much PB blaster I soaked them with, but this impact wrench broke the jack screws loose and got them to operate freely again. For me, that alone was worth the purchase price of this bare tool. This impact wrench also works great for sinking lag bolts in ledger boards and for mounting conduit straps to poles for power and communication risers. I use it with both the Dewalt 18V NiCad and Li-Ion batteries and battery life has been pretty impressive for most jobs I've needed it for. Along with a set of SAE and Metric impact sockets, this wench is able to handle the majority of my needs for an impact wrench and is especially handy when working in remote areas with no power. I purchased a storage case for it from Dewalt [Part#: N142716] so I can carry all of the extensions and adapters I regularly use with the tool. Overall, I feel the cost of this tool was definitely money well spent.

I've had this DCD950 hammerdrill for a couple of years now and really like it. It has some heft to it and the 18V NiCad batteries definitely seem to add to that, so I tend to use it almost exclusively with the newer Dewalt 18V Li-Ion batteries. The tool feels solid in your hand with no noticeable flexing of the body at all, even when using it with larger size spade and self-feed auger bits or hole saws. I could sometimes feel the body of my older Dewalt DC988 hammerdrill flex under heavy load, so it seems Dewalt has addressed that issue. The keyless chuck on this one is a little different from the one on my older hammerdrill, but seems to hold the bits at least as securely, if not better than the old one did. Unlike my old hammerdrill, this one has a trigger activated LED light which comes in handy when working in dimly lit areas. There are three gear ranges on this tool as well as a variable speed trigger and it also has three settings on the collar for hammer drilling, straight drilling as well as a screw driver position that works along with the adjustable clutch setting to prevent overdriving fasteners. Battery life has been quite good when with the Li-Ion batteries when using it for normal drilling and screw driving, but naturally, when running something like a 7/8" X 18" nail eater ship auger through double 2X headers, they will run down more quickly. The hammerdrill itself though can handle that type of work all day without issue, just like my older model did. Overall, I'm pleased with the hammerdrill and would likely buy again when needed.

I bought this DW106 drill here on Amazon back in 2001 and still have and use it today. It doesn't get used every day, but has seen fairly regular use mainly for things like drilling holes to fish wires up into walls of older buildings with long whip type Diversibits and with small diameter cotton buffing wheels for polishing metals and plastics. It will also get used with the occasional flap disc or wire wheel for cleaning up rust and removing paint. The keyless chuck on this drill is a big help when I need to change bits frequently for a project. The motor is rated at 5.8A and has a variable speed range of 0-2500RPM. The trigger lock will only engage when the trigger is fully depressed for high speed, but is still an extremely useful feature that I use all the time. I believe Dewalt has discontinued this particular model, but you can still find this drill both new and used if you shop around. Considering how much work I've gotten out of this drill and how long I've owned it, I think it was an excellent purchase and is definitely worth getting if you're looking for a good smaller 3/8" drill.

I recently purchased this Porter Cable PN650 palm nailer to install replacement stainless steel Simpson joist hangers on all of the PT joists under our deck. The old galvanized hangers where the deck joists attach to the ledger board were very badly corroded and starting to rot away. With the deck only being a couple of feet above the ground along with the working space between joist making it difficult to get a good hammer swing from a crouching or kneeling position, I got this palm nailer to help make the job easier and faster to complete with less fatigue on my aging  body. The nailer worked great for installing the 10 X 3" nails as well as the shorter 10 X 1-1/2 stainless steel Simpson nails into the joist hangers. It was definitely much faster than trying to bang them in by hand and probably even gave more consistent results. I used it with a 1/4" polyurethane air hose and kept the compressor air pressure set to 100-PSI and the nailer worked perfectly without a single lull or reduction in impact through the whole process. The nailer seems to be well made and came as a complete kit with several attachments along with wrenches to change them out all in a nice blow-molded fitted plastic case.  Overall, I'm quite happy with it and would have no issue recommending it.

This HS1828 tamper plate is made from a fairly hefty 5-inch square piece of solid steel that weighs a little over 3-pounds. I own a Spline-Drive rotary hammer, so use it with the Bosch HS1827 shank, but it can also be used with Bosch's HS1927 SDS-Max shank. Once on the shank, it is good and tight and usually requires a couple of taps with a ball peen hammer to remove it if I want to be able to store it in my hammers carry case. It's probably a little expensive for a hunk of steel with a hole through the center of it, but it does what it's supposed to so I think it was worth the cost.

I purchased this set of Cuisinox salt and pepper mills a few months ago and they have been working out very nice. The mills give a nice even grind on the coarse kosher salt and mixed pepper corn blend we use in them. The cutters in these mills are ceramic so should stay sharp for years. The cutters themselves are adjustable via a threaded nut in the plastic base and once set, hold their setting without issue. The bottles are actually made of nice heavy glass instead of just cheap plastic. They both also have a stainless steel band around their base and nice easy to remove clear plastic push-on covers to help keep the contents fresh between uses. Overall, we are very pleased with this set of salt and pepper mills and would recommend them to anyone looking to purchase a set.

It's a little hard to tell from the product description, but this Bosch HS1827 tamper shank is the one you need if you own a Spline-Drive rotary hammer and want to use the Bosch tamper plate with it. This is the tamper shank only. You need to buy the tamper plate that it is used with separately. The overall length of this shank is 12", but it only has about 7" of useable length once installed in the hammer and inserted in the tamper plate. The shorter length doesn't seem to be an issue for me though. The shank is made in Italy from good quality steel, so seems like it should last for quite some time. I use this shank along with the Bosch HS1828 5" X 5" tamper plate for things like compacting crushed stone base for small retaining walls and it seems to do a good job with it overall.

I bought this HS1495 stubby chisel to use with my Bosch 11224VSR SDS rotary hammer. The chisel is decently made in Italy from good quality steel and has an overall length of 5-3/4", but the length is further reduced to about 4" when installed in the hammer, which makes it good for getting into tight spots where a standard SDS chisel would be too long. When used along with the Bosch right angle SDS adapter, it makes for an even more compact setup. It seems like it will hold up just as well as any other SDS chisel for concrete chipping, so I think it was a good buy.

This L-shaped adapter allows you to convert Lenox's regular PVC saw into a flush cut saw and I have found it to be a very handy accessory. When used along with Lenox's longer 18" saw blade, I can quickly cut larger diameter PVC like 3" DWV pipe perfectly flush with the floor to install a closet flange for mounting a toilet. Using it with the shorter 12" saw blade allows you to work in tight areas like inside a kitchen base cabinet to cut an 1-1/2" PVC drain line flush to a wall. The adapter sort of looks like it might be made from cheap grey plastic, but it's actually quite sturdy. I've never cracked or broken mine in all  the years I've been using it, not even in cold weather. I don't use it every day so normally won't keep the adapter permanently installed on my saw, but instead just put it on when needed. It only involves two screws so is quick and simple to install and remove. Considering how little it cost, I think this flush cut adapter was a good investment and would recommend it to anyone that regularly uses a Lennox PVC saw.

I have a set of four different sizes of these Crescent auto wrenches and this 15" wrench is one of the sizes that I seem to use the most. The jaws on this wrench open to a max of 3-3/4" compared to only 1-3/4" capacity for my regular Crescent 15" adjustable wrench, which makes it ideal for use on larger nuts and bolts.All sizes of these Crescent auto wrenches seem to be very expensive for what they are, especially considering they are now being manufactured in China, but at least they still seem to be made using decent quality steel. They all have a warning stamped into the collar of the lower jaw that says "No hammering - No extensions", but I still occasionally find myself using a hammer for initial loosening or final tightening of larger nuts. The smooth jaws on this wrench are much better than an ordinary pipe wrench for working with things like larger chrome plated brass nuts on exposed sink drain P-traps or urinal flush valves, since they won't chew them up and leave unprofessional looking teeth marks all over everything. Overall, the wrench seems reasonably well made and appears to be holding up to my use, so in general I'm happy with it.

I've had this TPI 343/C3 dual input thermometer for a few years now and it has been a good little unit. It comes as a kit with a rubber overboot and fold out tilt stand, two 48" long type-K thermocouple beaded probes, two pipe clamp probes and a nylon storage case that has enough room for extra probes. The unit is waterproof and has auto power off. It has selectable inputs for degree C or F, T1/T2 or Delta/T temperature differential, Min/Max and display hold. When needed, the unit can be field calibrated using ice water. The temperature range depends on the type of probes used, but the user manual says the thermometer has a usable range from -58F to 2462F. The GK13M beaded probes that came with my thermometer are rated for -165F to 400F, but I also frequently use it with TPI's GK12M probe [-40F to 950F] for testing ovens. The two CK21M pipe clamp probes that also came with this kit make for easier superheat and subcooling temp readings. They will fit on pipes up to about 1" in diameter and are rated for -58F to 482F. I think this is a decent unit overall, especially considering the price and features, so I would recommend it to anyone looking into buying one.

I bought this A606 case to protect and store my TPI 605 vacuum gauge in between uses. I really think it should be included with the gauge, but is not for some reason, so must be purchased separately. It's decently made of woven nylon with a Velcro closure and is a good fit for my gauge, so overall I'm happy with it.

I purchased this TPI hot-wire anemometer/air velocity meter several years ago and it seems to be holding up well. For a moderately priced unit, I think it has a lot of good features. It came with a rubber overboot and a decent nylon storage case as well as the 6 AAA batteries it uses. The unit has auto power off and reads degree C or F with temperature range from -5F to 175F as well as air velocity from 0.2 m/s to 20 m/s. It can be set to display either m/s, km/s, ft/min, knots or miles/h, but doesn't read CFM directly, so the reading must be converted using the formula in the manual. It has data recording and there is a 3.5mm serial RS232 output jack for printing and viewing the readings on a computer, but the actual RS232 cable isn't included. The remote hot-wire probe tip on this unit is approximately 3/8" in diameter and the probe is permanently attached with a cable that allows for an overall probe length of about 4-feet when fully extended, so it has plenty of reach for getting deep into plenums and ductwork. TPI recommends having the meter recalibrated once a year, so will need to be shipped to their service facility for that. Overall though, this meter seems to be well made and hasn't given me any trouble to date, so I would have no issue with recommending it.

I kept looking at the bottles people had at work and decided I needed one of those. I was able to find this on Amazon and sooo glad I did. I put in frozen strawberries and thawed blueberries. Sat it in the fridge overnight and by the next day it was delightful to drink. It is sturdy and won't break as other people have said. Cool looking bottle too. I might have to buy more as gifts.
My dog loves these!

it is my fault these do not even come close to working in my small canals. I have Samsung Ear Phones and they are huge so why would I think I could buy a smaller buds and it would fit the Samsung? Not thinking right!
Works just ok, nothing special.
I own a great dog hair pickup Dyson, but it has gotten older. While it still picks up the dog hair, it doesn't do as well as before. This Shark picks up the pace.  Happy I got it.
Nice cup of morning coffee. Smooth taste.

Where are the slots??????? Only thing that comes up for me is blackjack. When I try to download it, it tells me I already own it. I'm not the first one to comment on this problem so where in the heck are the gaming solution nerds who should fix this???????
What can be wrong with a bag of chocolate? Nothing!
It is very pretty on my counter, works great. I tossed out my older bigger Brita. This holds plenty of water for 2 people.
Very good coffee, nice body.
Tastes just like the Orangesicles we had as kids.
Kept me warm on those cold mornings. Nice texture too

Went fishing for catfish. Casting out is sooo smooth. But the problems were-1st day-After catching a nice size 2 lb. cat, threw it out again and couldn't reel it in very easily. Looked in the bail and it had a rat's nest sitting on top. Got that fixed after 5 minutes and threw it out again. About the 4th cast, everything came out of the reel, my line went out and my hook.  It took time to redo, fished some more, caught 1 more cat and the line wouldn't go out far as it did before. Checked the line and it had like little twists on it every 1/2". Back to the cabin, took all the "cajun" line that comes with the rod and put on new 12 lb Trilene. 2nd day worked well, but the screw kept loosening up from the handle. I didn't have a flathead screwdriver so I had to use my fingernail. The problem continued on the rest of the day and the next day. It loosened about every 5th cast.Pain in the butt, but I still have to give it 3 stars because of how nice it casts. Catfish-love shrimp and we didn't catch them on mackarel. Caught one on squid. Just some advice...
These work great and it's nice to have 3 colors. The little plastic fasteners are sturdy. I've used them about 4 months now and they work as good as they did the first day.
Oh my gosh these taste great. Exactly what the title says, just like you bought a caramel apple at the candy store.
So many colors of crayones, pencils and markers. Be sure to order alot of drawing paper to go with them.
One of our favorite coffees, smooth and not weak.

Wore this fishing for 3 days in the warm sun out here in California. It feels soooo comfortable and for a fair skinned older person, it kept me cool and I didn't get burned. A good brimmed hat helps for the ears too.

This is a really cool looking bag. I use it for a purse and fishing tackle box this past week. Lots of pockets. The only reason I gave it a 4 is because the zippers don't shut smoothly. Think I will put some WD40 on them next time I go fishing.
Used them to hold the fish to get the hooks out and skin the catfish. Love them!

Bought this nice looking rod and reel with great expectations. I've had many open reels before and was tired of it. Bought this, went to my friends' backyard and cast it into their pool. Very smooth. Took it fishing this past week and fished for 3 days. First day, nice catfish hit the line and reeled it in beautifully. While throwing out the second time and reeling it back in to check the bait (cats love shrimp!) and it wouldn't reel in easily. Once I got it in I gave it to my friend who has fished for say 60 years. He opened the bail and there was a rats nest in there. He got the mess out and fixed my line. I can cast out far and when I throw this out, it glides like a champ.  A few more tosses out and the hook and line gets tossed off the reel. I lose it all!! Gave it back to my friend who again fixed it for me. Caught another nice cat and noticed the handle on the reel is coming out. On the otherside of it is a big screw that had loosened. No flathead on the boat so I used my fingernail. This happened 3 more times. I shouldn't have to mess with something like that. After we got back to the cabin I had to take out all of the "cajun" line the manufacturer had put on there and put on 12 lb Trilene.  2nd day worked well with the new line, but the screw came loose again. 3rd day all went well except of course-the screw loosened again. I'm keeping it because when I go fishing with my friend, he fixes it for me. Don't know what I would do by myself. Caught only 5 catfish in 3 days, but they were good size and as they say, a bad day of fishing is better than a good day at work! I am a 64 year old female who has fished for about 30 years.
My son loves these Lemon Oreos. Thanksfully I can also find them at the store at a cheaper price.
My dog really likes these. It is her 3rd favorite treat. I feel they are probably nutritious for her too.

Went fishing and forgot my sunscreen the first day. My hands and ears were burnt! I put sunscreen on the next two days. I also poured hot coffee on my hand (had not woke up yet). When I got home I put on the Aloe Vera day and night. My hands never peeled, but my ears sure did. I use it more liberally now. Fishing next week, the aloe vera will be packed.
My work provides these pens and we all love them. I decided to buy my own box so I could use them at home, at the grocery store, anywhere.
I put these in a drawer and have used them only once in over a year. They are too tiny for much of anything.

Got this to sharpen knives and my scissors. I used the coarse setting for my scissors and found out that was not the ones to use. I couldn't cut anything. Then I put the scissors through the fine side and whala, they are sharp again,UPDATE-I had to buy new scissors because they dulled mine so they weren't useable. I might have put them in the wrong space on that little thing, but it dulled them so they couldn't even cut through paper. I bought another pr of scissors and tossed out the Edge Grip
so far so good, nice sharp knifes. I like all the colors too.
Sure glad I tried these, they are delicious. Fine medium roast, nice body.

I like the pens, but they do smear if you're not paying attention and your hand sits on the writing. They aren't as thick as Skilcraft Gel Pens meaning these are in the "fine" category. They don't flow as easily as the gel pens.
Bought these for work for very large piles of paperwork (up to 7 inches tall) and they do the job. I will buy these again.
Bought these for work. Wasn't happy when I saw how skinny they were, BUT they are very strong and working well.
No trout bites or any other bites on this product. Waste of time for me. Use Salmon Peach Powerbait. The 3 of us caught 25 trout on that.
Lots of nice size pieces and stackable too. Works for me!

My brother got me going on these and they were fine for awhile. Then I noticed every afternoon I was nauseated. I don't know if it came from the Probiotics, but I stopped taking them and the nausea went away.

It truly moisturize your skin. I bought them for my son who builds fences. It helped alot. I went fishing this last weekend and forgot to put sunscreen on the first day. Then the next morning, I ended up pouring coffee on my hand. Ouch!! I used the cream on everything and so far I am not peeling, although it still hurts.
They are so comfortable and great to wear on a day of fishing in windy cold weather.
Trout didn't seem to like it
did not catch any trout on this bait.
We just got back from fishing and this was the only bait (besides nightcrawlers) that the trout bit on. It was great
My son loves these dickies pants. Uses them for work as he builds fences. I think his belly got a little too big since he bought the last ones
Great old movie. Saw it as a kid and just wanted to see it again.
Geesh are these good.
I only gave it 4 stars because I just got it. So far it is nice and creamy and will see if it works
My favorite coffee since back in the 80s.

OMG, these cookies are so fantastic. We put a frosting on of just butter, vanilla and powdered sugar.  More fantastic. A friend at work had brought in the Pink Lemonade cookies with the Pink Lemonade frosting. To die for. I just didn't want to pay $30 for I guess a 4 pack. I would highly recommend this mix.
It is perfect for a kithcen tv. The sound is a little tinny, but it is clear. Picture is o.k.
My dog isn't thrilled with it, but she is older.When my daughter brings her 2 year old terrier over, she goes nuts. I have to hide it and she has quite the nose to find it.
It is small, but that doesn't take away from how beautiful it is.
These have a shimmer on them that really sets them off. They are of high quality and I'm glad I bought them!

I ordered these for my son who is currently 11 years old and LOVES to watch YouTube videos and listen to music.  Over time he has tried out several types and brands of headphones and has stated that this is one of his favorite pairs.  He likes that they are comfortable to wear without too much pressure or being too loose while on his head.  The sound quality for what he uses them for are great - definitely crisp and clear.  As a parent I like these because they block the noise from seeping through, so when he's enjoying things on his tablet or phone in the same room we aren't distracted or having to ask him to turn his volume down (or turn ours up!).  The best feature is that these are bluetooth capable, so should you want to go wireless you certainly can.  My son prefers to plug the wire in and use them that way because he's not one to remember to charge them.  Another amazing feature is that you can insert a MP3 card into the slot and listen to music that way as well, although we have not tested this feature so we cannot comment on that at this time. I received these headphones at a discount in exchange for testing them and providing an honest review of the product.

If you are looking for a great pair of inexpensive but very functional full-size binoculars this is a pair I would highly recommend.  These are perfect  for sight seeing, bird watching or even stadium seating at sports events.  When I used them to look out over a horizon they easily looked out with a crisp clear view and took no time at all to dial into looking out at the landscape.  They do have a bit of weight to them but are accompanied by a nice carrying case as well as a strap which both make for easy travel.  I received these in exchange to personally test and provide my honest review.

This is a nice trio of dental items that are a nice addition to your brushing routine.  My main focus for ordering this set is due to the fact I have a permanent retainer and if you have one you know that it's not the easiest to keep the plaque from building next to it.  I go to the dentist regularly for cleanings and the tartar removal tool is a must-have for me (and I will caution, it is SHARP!).  I do use it in conjunction with the mirror which works really well with the LED light so you can see exactly what you need to in order to remove any remaining food or plaque build-up.  I will be honest and say I've not used the stain remover tool since I've not found a need for it yet.  I would not recommend that these tools replace dental visits but they will help reduce the amount of plaque on your teeth and in the gum area.  This set is perfect for people with permanent retainers or for those who tend to build plaque quicker than usual.

We installed this as a replacement to our 10-year old basic builder grade shower head.  I am really impressed by this model! The shower head we removed was just a standard stationary style so I immediately felt like this was an upgrade given that this is connected to a flexible hose.  I am thrilled that giving my dogs a bath is just now that much easier, too! This installs incredibly easy (no tools required!) and sits well on the mount (ordered separately).  The jets/spray are perfectly placed for a relaxing experience; this was a welcome addition to our shower as the previous one we had lacked a decent level of water pressure.  Overall this earns five stars for ease of install, it's overall appearance, the price point and functionality.

This Purelux arm mount is a perfect pairing for the Purelux hand-held shower head.  It is very durable, made out of a solid plastic with chrome finish.The mount is supplied with a roll of teflon plumber's tape which is a bonus so it's one less item to have to make sure you have on hand.  Installation was a breeze and no tools are required! Once we had it in place it is on tight and does not leak or drip.  It fit comfortably and swivels nice and smooth, and fits the shower head arm well.  This is a great price for the arm; be sure if you are purchasing other items such as the shower head that you also purchase the hose which is sold separately.  I received this item in exchange for personally testing and providing my honest opinion of the product.

These bags are great for reducing space in your bag or suitcase while traveling, or for storing extra clothing or linens. These are great for keeping out dust and debris, bugs, water and rodents (perfect use is for places like the cabin where you leave bed linens behind). These could also work great for storing or transporting documents or document folders, storing spare clothing on places like a boat or ATV, and storing baby items such as first outfit/christening clothing/first blanket to pass on.  I like the variety of sizes and the transparent material so you can see what's inside. The plastic material is thicker than the oversized ziplock plastic bags that you can find at the local big-box stores, and the vacuum compression ensures that you can stack and store items and reduce the amount of space in your closet or storage area.  I love these and definitely will be ordering more!  I received this item at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I am a big fan of clear cases, I love their simplicity and versatility of putting a picture/drawing/decorated paper on the back. That being said, as you know not all cases are created equal. THIS clear case by Spigen is by far the top-of-the-line as far as clear cases go - I love that they kicked it up a notch with the gunmetal TPU bumper because it looks amazing! The entire case is so protective with it's thick poly material and encompasses every inch of the phone, leaving it secure in the event of an accidental drop. It feels great in my hand, and by that I am referring to I am confident it's not going to just slip right out because the material is that kind that is rather grippy. My buttons push easily, and this is no problem getting on and off my phone. If you are looking for a good, solid, well made clear case then look no further because I can assure you this is IT! I received this case at a discount in exchange for personally testing and providing my honest review of the product.

I absolutely love this keratin shampoo and conditioner by Luseta! Aside from the way my hair feels it smells amazing and I noticed that I only needed two average pumps of both the shampoo and conditioner which is nearly half of the amount of the former brand I was using! It rinses out reallly easily, cleanly (no oily residue!) and quickly - you don't feel like you need a second set of hands or stand there rinsing for what feels like an eternity. I love that this is a pump form, it makes it so much easier to use. I have tried other Luseta products and every single one has been a winner! I received these in exchange to personally test and provide my honest review of the product. I will be buying this shampoo again!

I love the way this case fits my phone like a glove! It provides a decent amount of protection without turning it into a big, bulky brick.  I chose the bright pink and grey combo which is perfect for being able to locate my phone in my purse among the sea of other stuff floating around in it.  I like the textured "grippy" grey parts of the case, it not only adds an aesthetic touch but it gives extra security to hold onto the phone.  The buttons on this case depress easily and the cutouts are done well. Overall a really great case for the price point, I would recommend if you are looking for something to keep your phone free of scratches and dings! I received this at a discount in exchange for my honest opinion of the product.

I can't say enough about this mirror and how great it is! It is perfect for makeup application and the 5x magnification is perfect for a closer look at pores, eyebrow maintenance and again, for makeup.  The LED light is soft but provides additional light that you can't get by using a standard bathroom mirror and lighting and this allows you to get up close and personal when needed.
