I experienced the same results in which the music played just fine and it was a good experience.When I got home, I tested stretching the cable out to have my phone reach from the front center infotainment system to the back side of the rear passenger area and it was able to stretch out just fine to where I could have people in the back control my phone and play any media to have audio transmission to my vehicle to listen along.  6 feet is about enough length to have someone sitting in the rear center seat of a 4 door sedan control the phone and whatever sound outputs from it to the AUX input of the vehicle.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Slim portable design2) Freely bends and moves as desired with the nylon braided design3) Easy to identify the cable based on the etched PowerAdd label on the connector heads4) Gold plated connects offers an improved performance experience5) Charcoal gray color looks niceCONS:1) The product page mentions these are tangle free cables, but I noticed with the 6 feet cables that occasionally the natural looping that it wants to retract to causes some of the loops to cross into each other in which I need to unravel out of in-between use.2) Cables naturally want to curl back up to the way they were bent from stored packaging.SUGGESTIONS:1) Offer other colored designs2) Create thicker gauge cablesUSER SCENARIOS:People who would benefit from using this cable are those who:1) Like to listen to music or podcasts2) Go on long road trips3) Have long commutes4) Do not have desirable taste in the FM radio stations5) Have an AUX input port in their vehicleOverall, these are nice cables and a fair tradeoff experience when comparing these cables from PowerAdd and the cable Ive had for a while from Anker.  I suggest users give this a try and get the 6 feet cable 2 pack because it works well in different situations and you never want to be limited with what your length of cable allows for you to do.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to give a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  I am also providing this review to help prospective buyers make smart informed decisions.I hope you like my photos.Thanks for reading my review.

Hi,This is my review of the product TT-SK05/ TaoTrinics Portable speaker:  It is listed on Amazon as:Bluetooth Speakers TaoTronics Wireless Speaker Portable Speaker (Bluetooth 4.0, High Fidelity Audio, Built-in Microphone, LED Light, A2DP Profiling, 6 Hours Playtime)-BlackI received this product last weekend and had time yesterday for a couple of hours to try it out for evaluation and review.  I have also taken a series of photos and included it in my review if anyone is interested.UNBOXING AND OBSERVATIONS:The product comes in a reasonably packaged illustrated cardboard box.  One of the confusing things about this box is that its the same one thats used for both the black and white color speakers apparently.  My box showed the black colored speaker and initially, I thought I got the wrong one, but when I opened the box lid, it was the correct white one that I ordered.The front and top of the box has a photo of the Bluetooth speaker.  The left side has the serial and model number.  The backside has North America, Europe, and Asia Pacific e-mail support information.I look at this illustration and if I was walking into a retail store, Id actually pick this up to take a look at it.  Unfortunately, there are no technical specs of the speaker around any sides of the box.  I would recommend that this is stated, at least in summary, for the user to be aware of.  As an internet company, its not a big deal, but if this company moved into retail space, this would be important.Upon opening the top box lid, I found inside the white colored Bluetooth speaker wrapped in a plastic bag inside.  When lifting that up, theres a circular cutout cardboard that tucked the speaker into the box, and underneath that was the Micro USB cable and AUX cable included with the box.The Micro USB cable is a standard type of cable for Bluetooth accessories such as the speakers.  The AUX cable is used for plugging into a phone, tablet, laptop, or desktop that does not have Bluetooth support so that you can use the speaker with limited functionality while not needing any power from the speakers internal battery.In looking all around at the Bluetooth speakerThe top side has the speaker output with a ring around it that I later found out is to change colors to indicate pairing status and ON or OFF status.  The front of the speakers has the Taotronics logo.  The right side has a Mic hole.  The backside has the ON/OFF sliding switch, DC 5V charging input port, Line IN for AUX cable, and a slider for the volume.The bottom of the speaker has a pair of U shaped rubber stoppers to provide friction against a smooth surface so that the speaker cant be slid around and knocked off of a table top easily.  I tap against the side and it rocks around briefly but doesnt really move that much.In knocking it around, I found out that based on the shape of this speaker, it can lay rested on any of the sides all around it so that the speaker doesnt necessary have to be stable and pointing up.  It could be facing you.  I liked that part of the design.What I initially considered as a suggestion is that I like a multi-function button that has separate push buttons that have rubber padding, for the volume up, down, and play/pause functionality.  In this case with this Taotronics speaker, its integrated together with a slider that rolls to the left or right, which is OK, but feels a little flimsy and feels like it can easily get mechanical failure or wear and tear over time.  Id rather have the push pads for buttons to control these functions.  Thats my personal opinion.I suggest all product owners read the users manual prior to operating this product so that they are aware of what you can and cant do with this product.Some notable information from the manual includes the following:Specifications:Bluetooth Version: 4.0Bluetooth Profile: HFP, HSP, AVRCP, A2DPOutput Power: 3WFrequency: 90Hz-20KhzInput: DC 5VBattery: 500 mAh Lithium BatteryRange: 33 feet (10m)Working Time: 6 hoursCharging Time: 2 hoursDimension: 2.48 x 2.48 x 2.95 inchesWeight: 5.94 ozSo in going through some of these specs with my perspective.Bluetooth Version 4.0 is the latest Bluetooth next to 4.1 that is available in the market for Bluetooth accessories.  I suggest all people find Bluetooth 4.0 products and not the 3.0 or lower.  The 4.0 has better stability in terms of connectivity and performance, and better battery power management.Output Power of 3W was something that I had to consider.  It didnt sound to the current level of power that Ive been looking at for Bluetooth speakers, which is around 5W.  But, at a current price of $10.99 whereas the others were selling for around $25, it was reasonable for the price.  Ill be taking close attention to how it feels by ear later on in the review.  For now, my expectations were not too high.I wouldve liked to see a higher battery capacity than 500mAh for this product.  Perhaps up to 1000mAh or 2000 mAh with an increased price for that.  6 hours of playtime is good for a portable speaker of this price range.  It may not last you the whole day, but if you use it off and on in the day, youll be good enough for about half of the day before you need to recharge the battery to full.Fortunately, the specs state the charge time is about 2 hours, which isnt too bad.  Thats a good standard charge rate.  I would like it to be down to 1 to 1.5 hours full charge time, but it may be a design or parts limitation.  2 hours is good enough to where you can charge this while heading out or having a bite to eat and watching TV or using your smartphone or tablet, then come back to see that its fully charged to use it again in the middle of the day.The dimensions of this product make it very portable.  I was looking at this and this could certainly fit into my jacket pockets.  It might even fit into some of my pants pockets, but would cause a noticeable bulge out of the shape of my pants which would look unfriendly.  But it is small and with it small, it can be stored in more possible locations for travel or placing onto crowded table top surfaces.  I like the size.The weight of it when lifted up with one hand is lightweight.  I dont see myself straining or tiring if I had to hold onto this with my hand for an extended period of time of more than 10 minutes.In the Users Manual, it talks about the LED indicator, which is the ring shape around the top of the speaker.  It will turn red when charged, turn off when fully charged, flash green when in pairing mode, flash green for every 10 seconds when paired.USAGE:The evaluation of this product will be detailed, but before doing that, you have to pair the device to your phone or tablet.  I had an iPhone 5s to test for the remainder of this review.When turning on the power button on the back of the speaker, youll hear this brush of tones, followed by another tone.  Youll see the LED flash on the top of the speaker.  By going to your Bluetooth Settings and letting it be in discover mode, it will find the product labeled as Taotronics TT-SK05.Connecting to it will cause another set of tone noises from the speaker.What I like about this Bluetooth speaker that my last two Bluetooth speakers of higher price failed to incorporate was support for the Bluetooth battery meter indicator on the smartphones like the iPhone.  This Taotronics product has that, which is handy to monitor and gauge where along the 6 hour playback battery life it currently is in to plan to when charge the product.It hurts the batterys lifespan if you charge it too often from just minimal use.  Its recommended to try to fully drain or use until its low battery before charging it all the way to full.After pairing, I tested the volume.  The disappointment that I didnt like about this product is that I found out it uses AVRCP 1.3 or older and I can tell because the volume on the speaker is separate and independent of the iPhones volume rocker meter.  So to get the full volume, Id have to crank up the speaker volume until it beeps, and also turn up my iPhone volume bar.  The same is in the case of turning down the volume, although in my tests, you can slide the volume slider held down on the speaker and it will eventually mute the volume without needing to touch the iPhone.For my test, I tried a few songs of both lyrical and instrumental and then bass.First lyrical test of the sound quality was the song that I chose, which is:Brandon Heath - The Light in MeIts a strong but calm lyrical song with mild instrumental accompaniment.As I tested it out, I noticed that I had to crank the volume on my iPhone about 50% towards the max just to have the song heard fairly well.  This was about 5-10 feet away.  To get a good audible experience, I had to crank the volume to about 75% of the maximum volume on my iPhone.  This was OK and expected for a 3W power output.  But, I didnt let it distract me too much.  I placed the speaker in the center of my home on the first floor at the kitchen table and walked around with my paired iPhone. I walked end to end the full 30 feet of experience all around and the Bluetooth connection never broke or crackled in the semi open space that I walked around with my iPhone.  I had minimal dry wood walls and exterior concrete walls that were in the way during some portions of the walk.  But, this was impressive how the connection stayed good for that long of a tested semi open spaced environment.At some points, I did crank the volume up to about 85% of the max to hear it loud and clear from near 30 feet away of semi open space.  It didnt hurt my iPhone, but this probably was draining the battery of the speaker more than tested.  But, for a small product like this, I had to crank the volume high enough to have an enjoyable experience.  And for me, I have normal hearing, but with these speakers, I did have to push my volume bar near max to hear it reasonably loud from about 20-30 feet away in a semi open space.The lyrics in the song were clearly heard and I liked how the instrumentation and lyrics were heard well and distinctive with this speaker.  Particularly the singing.  I played through the whole 3 minutes of the song without issues.My next test was the song by Nickelback - Figured You Out which has a combination of lyrics and instrumentals from a rock category.I was able to hear the voice of the singer well.  The instrumentation quality was second best.  It was heard, but meshed together with the instruments to where it felt noisier than clear and distinctive.  It was a good experience.I tried Linkin Park  Lying From You, which has a lot of yelling and hard singing with instrumentation.  The overall quality of how it sounded to my ears was OK.  I could hear it well.  It didnt feel pounding to my ears.  I heard some instruments loud and clear more than others in the song based on how it was projected through the speakers and the composition of the song.  It still had a combined mesh of a noisy experience than distinctively hearing each instrument well.My next song was a bass test.  I went on YouTube and searched up high quality bass.  I found a result that had over 1 million views and tested that song.  I had the instrumentation playing while I heard the bass very well, but I had to crank up the volume to 80-90% near max in order to hear it good.  It was noticeable with the thumping sound coming from the speakers during the bass test, which was good for this size of portable speakers.  Youll hear the sort of loud thumbs at this volume range without needing to feel the power pressure of the bass reaching your ears.  It was good for this size of a portable speaker.  It met my expectations.My next test for fun was testing out playing the 2015 best trailers video on YouTube just to test.  What I found out was that depending on the audio combination of voice and sound effects, if I heard through the speakers, I could turn up the volume to about 75-80% and hear it well in a quiet background noise setting within 5 feet away, but any further than that, and it was muffled and hard to pick up to distinguish the dialogue that was being mentioned.So from my tests, the speaker was good on clear lyrical singing in songs.  With hard instruments playing, it was loud enough to hear, but felt meshed together with noise generated instead of distinctiveness.  With bass, the bass was good as long as the volume was raised very high.  The movie watching test with these speakers didnt turn out as well, but I think its still better than not having a Bluetooth speaker and having to rely on your smartphone or tablets speaker.The final test that I did was the talking and calling test.  For this test, I used my landline speaker phone to call to my iPhone, and set the landline speaker volume up and in a different area of my house in which I had a sliding door close it from picking up my voice into the landline phone when I was talking into the Bluetooth speaker.  So initially, I heard the incoming call from the landline phone to the Bluetooth speaker playing the projected music form my iPhones ringtone music.  I was happy to say that I heard the ringtone well where it wasnt too loud or too quiet.  My previous experience with Bluetooth speakers was that it would play the ringtone music extremely loud and high to where it was harmful to the ears and ruined my experience.  But here, everything was OK.  I tested a few incoming calls and was able to take the call by pressing the multifunction button on the Bluetooth speaker.  Same with hanging up, redialing, and rejecting a call.  All of those required timing when to press into the play/pause multifunction button.The great news about the calling test was that I found out this Microphone hole built into the Taotronics Bluetooth speaker is as good as my iPhones built in microphone in terms of frequency and range.  I initially talked up close to the Bluetooth speaker and heard the audio echo through my landline speakerphone in the distance loud and clear.  Then I started to distance myself from a couple of feet away to several feet away, and at one point, being an estimated 10 feet away from the Bluetooth speaker, and when I talked in a normal tone of voice, I could hear the echo through my landline phone most of the time.  There were a few occasions where I had to repeat what I was saying to hear the echo come out word for word, but it was minimal.  This mic on the Taotronics speaker is good in sensitivity, which works out well for group settings placing it in the center around them talking to someone.One other thing to mention is the LED indicator.  Its a subtle green LED flashing light.  It looks pretty cool.  I was able to capture a photo of it in dim lighting.  It makes the product look more stylish and modern.  The light isnt bright to where it would be distracting when trying to sleep.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Small and portable enough to fit into most types of pants and jacket pockets2) Green LED ring has a stylish and nice look in a dim light setting that makes the product look more modern3) Good microphone sensitivity for picking up your voice during calls (tested up to 10 feet away)4) Reasonable sounding bass when turning the volume up about 80-90% near max5) The speaker can stand on its own or lay flat on either of its sides to face you with stability from rocking around6) The ratio of playtime versus charge time is good7) Connection testing with Bluetooth 4.0 on this product was good with semi open spacing of 30 feet all around the houseCONS:1) It uses AVRCP 1.3 or older ,which requires the user to independently control two sets of volume, one on the speaker, and one on the phone or tablet2) You have to raise the volume on your phone to about 75% to 85% to hear the music through this speaker fairly loud and clear from about 15+ feet away3) Quality for movie or TV show content listening, particularly for action movies, isnt as good as it could be.4) Music where the instrumentations are playing with the singing sound too meshed together with noise rather than distinctively hearing them separately.SUGGESTIONS:1) Rather than a sliding dial to control the volume and play/pause, it may be preferable to have a model with a push button rubber padding for each multifunction2) Provide a higher capacity battery into this product3) Provide a travel pouch or bag to carry this speaker around and protect it from wetness and dirt or debris4) Provide a lanyard extension from one part of the Bluetooth speaker to hook it onto the waist belt loop or travel bags5) Increase the power output of this speaker to what is currently standard in the market for portable speakers in the low end of competitors, which is 5W.  That way, the user does not need to raise the volume on their smartphone or tablet so high as I did with testing of at least 75% near max volume6) Make an IPX5 or greater waterproof design for this type of productUSER SCENARIOS:People who would use this product are those who:1) Are looking for a cheap budget solution that is an improvement to the speaker quality of their smartphone or tablet2) Cannot afford high end premium speakers3) Want to have calling features with music listening experience combined4) Have small group settings using this Bluetooth speaker, which allows a wide coverage of voice pickup to hear to the recipient of the call.5) Like to have stylish affordable accessories added to their gadget listOverall, this product proved to impress me than the initial expectations I had when reading the specs like the 3W power.  Although I did have to crank up the volume very high to get a reasonably loud audible experience, the small portable speaker from Taotronics will be handy on small trips to provide entertainment for myself and a small group of people that is an inexpensive risk of loss or damage.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to provide a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  This review is to also help prospective buyers make smart, informed decisions based on the information provided to them and the photos shared.Thanks for reading my review.

Hi,This is my review for the product listed on Amazon as:iClever 6ft Premium High Speed Micro USB to USB Cable, BlackI received this product last week and had time to provide a review.  Attached are a set of photos that I took of the experience.UNBOXING AND OBSERVATIONS:The product came in a small square box with the micro USB cable bolded on the top of the box with the iClever logo.  It states on the top right hand corner of that side that it contains the 6 ft. or 1.8 m Micro USB cable inside, so you know right away when you receive the package and prior to opening up the box that you got the right one.The bottom of the box has the SKU number (171-21004-19) and website.Inside the box was the USB cable tied up in a plastic bag.After removing everything and straightening the cable out, I made some quick observations.My first impression was that this cable is very thick and felt durable.  Its much thicker in diameter than other micro USB cables that Ive used from other brands.  I could pinch down on the cable and it felt pretty resistive and not bent in very easily.The micro USB connector head has the iClever branding on it so that you can use this cable among other micro USB cables to identify which brand it is compared to generic cables that have no label on them.  The ends of the cable measures as the following:The micro USB connector handle measures 5/8th inch long by 3/8th inch wide by 1/4th inch thick.The USB Type A connector handle measures 6/8th inch long by 5/8th inch wide by 5/16th inch thick.USAGE:The toughness of the material for the handles as well as the groves from the USB symbol and company name help gives it a nice grip to hold onto.  Micro USB cables have always felt pretty good to grip for me, but this one feels slightly better.  The measurements indicate that you can pinch down with your thumb and finger to give a nice secure grip to pull or push into a micro USB port or USB port, whichever direction you go.I tested using this cable on an Anker Bluetooth speaker that I had which uses a shorter Micro USB cable to see if it would charge.  The nice thing about this cable from iClever is that I am able to charge my Micro USB driven devices from my tabletop rather than leaving them on the ground to get dirty, dusty, stepped or kicked on.I plugged the USB connector into my USB charging station on the floor and had plenty of length of the iClever cable to bring it up to charge my Anker speaker on the table top with room to spare.  The LED light turned red to indicate there was current flow through the cable and supplying a charge to the speaker.  That was a quick test to show that the cable was not defective.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Thick durable material2) Comfortable sizing for connector head grip3) iClever branding etched on the micro USB connector handle helps distinguish it from other generic cables4) 6 feet of cable length allows more opportunities to rearrange where you charge your devicesCONS:1) Cable gets twisted and tangled easilySUGGESTIONS:1) Upgrade to the nylon braided material design that has less tangles2) Provide different colors for different styles and identitiesUSER SCENARIOS:This product would be useful for people who:1) Want a longer cable to not have to reach from the ground to grab or drop off devices for charging2) Want a more durable cable to handle accident prone situations3) Want a better gripped cable thats not very slippery to push and pull fromOverall, I think that this is a nice and useful cable from iClever.  Ill be able to charge from further distances away from the wall outlets and have things charged for visibility and accessibility on table tops such as my office workspace.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to give a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  I am also providing this review to help prospective buyers make smart informed decisions.I hope you like my photos.Thanks for reading my review.

Hi,This is my review for the product listed on Amazon as:TaoTronics Selfie Stick Telescopic Monopod for Android and iOS Smartphones, One Button Shutter/Remote, 3.5mm Universal Connector, No Power/Battery Required (Black)I received this product last week and had time today to evaluate it for a detailed review.  I have included a set of photos in case anyone is interested.UNBOXING AND OBSERVATIONS:The product came in a small, brown rectangular cardboard box with black printing to show the outline drawing of the monopod on the top side of the box followed by the serial number barcode on the side of the box.  The model number for this unit is TT-SH012.The bottom of the box has the address, phone, and e-mail contact for North America.  There are also e-mail addresses for Europe and Asia as well.After opening the box, I found that the selfie stick was fully exposed and wasnt wrapped on a plastic bag, which is fine I suppose, but Im used to products that are new being wrapped up, even when inside of the package.Also, I was a bit disappointed at how poorly treated the Quick Start Guide was packaged into the box.  Taotronics shippers had to force this thick multi language support quick guide into the box and in doing so, had to roll it up so that it could fit since leaving it flattened out would not fix the dimensions of the cardboard box.  Also, several of the pages got bent and folded in permanently from the top right hand corner of the Quick Start Guide which sort of bothered me because I couldnt reverse or correct this Quick Start Guide to flatten it out anymore.  So I received a new product with a new Quick Start Guide that looks like it had been sat on by someone sitting in a seat and caused it to wrinkle up and crumple on the corners and edges.  I suggest Taotronics does a better job at how they handle packaging these types of printouts.Before using the product, I read the manual to become familiar with the naming convention for all of the parts and how to use the selfie stick.  Ive had about 4 brands of selfie stick that requires charging the lithium ion battery inside of them with a micro USB connector.  But, with this Taotronics selfie stick, the new feature is having a 3.5mm connector built into the selfie stick supply the power for the capture button by connecting to the smartphones headphone jack.  That was one of the things that distinguishes this selfie stick from others.  Quite often with other brands of selfie sticks is that they dont design a Bluetooth battery level indicator for the smartphones, so while those selfie sticks are rated to last 20 hours under one charge, you dont know when those 20 hours will be up before charging from full depletion.  And on the other hand, you dont want to overcharge too often after using it for a couple of hours worth because the batteries have a tested and rated number of charge cycles that you can put it through.  But here, this Taotronics selfie stick doesnt need any of that.  But it will draw some battery from your smartphone when you use it, but it should be minimal.In looking at the selfie stick, when Taotronics said that they designed the lightest and smallest retractable selfie stick on the market, they were not kidding.  This thing is very small and thin.  The handle can be held with a full grip end to end in a babys hand.  I have sort of big long fingered hands so this was easy to clench with one hand.  But what I didnt like about it was that the handle, being that it was thin, didnt offer much of a cushion when holding and gripping the rubber handle.  It feels pretty hard and slightly uncomfortable when gripping it to a pinch and as my later tests showed when using it, my hand and wrist got a tired after holding it fully extended taking several shots after a while.  Nonetheless, the handle has a nice gloss to it and feels smooth to handle.  I would suggest Taotronics designs some grooves that help curve and fit better into a handled grip and provide some friction.In also looking at the camera button, its a dark orange colored button thats circular.  It has a nice mechanical sound when you press on it to know that its triggered the action that youre trying to make to take a photo, which is also good for troubleshooting purposes if your selfie stick isnt responding.  Again with the comfort issue, this camera button doesnt feel as nice as other selfie sticks.  For example, Taotronics made a selfie stick called the TaoTronics iFly Bluetooth Selfie Stick Extendable Monopod.  Model# TT-SH10.  You can look it up on Amazon.  From those photos, you can see the camera button design is different than the one pictured for this selfie stick.  That button design on the iFly actually feels nicer on the thumb, is more smooth, and comfortable than this one that Im currently reviewing.  Other newer brands of selfie stick have adopted to that design as well.  This orange button in the current design form of the selfie stick TT-SH012 is smaller to accompany the smaller cylinder shape of the monopod, but is not the most comfortable among Taotronics series of selfie sticks.  I suggest Taotronics reconsiders an improved design for the camera button for long term use of comfort when taking several photos, possibly 100, in a day.The wrist wrap feels nice and comfortable with the soft nylon material.  However, whats missing is that theres no fastener on this wrap, so you can fit your hand in this and have it wrap around your wrist, depending on different hand and wrist sizes of people, youd have twice the wrist size left as an opening in which youd have to require holding onto the handle of the selfie stick the whole time.  So this current design doesnt necessarily cling onto your wrist snug.  I suggest Taotronics improve on this feature by adding a fastener to adjust different wrist sizes for a more secure fit.The Phone Holder was interesting.  It moves pretty easily.  It has a rubberized groove pattern on the thin sides of the holder where you can expand it to fit the phone.  Theres a knob on the side where you can twist to loosen up the holder and then tighten it up so that the angle locks in without being able to move around easily for a secure lock with the weight of the phone.  What I didnt like was that Taotronics advertises that this phone holder can rotate 270 degrees.  There is a picture of that on the Amazon Product Page.  However, based on my testing, even though I loosened the adjusting knob, I was unable to get a complete 270 degree rotation towards having a 90 degree bent of the phone holder facing me while placing the handle straight on a table top or held in my hand.  In the pictures that I attached to the review, youll see that its off by 20-30 degrees and even with a lot of effort trying to bend it, I was unable to get the full 270 degree rotation.  It could be that my unit is defective.  Ive contacted Taotronics about it.  I suggest Taotronics does a quality check of this feature that it advertises before shipping out units.The last feature to talk about is the 3.5mm connector.  When I first opened the box, I found this was dangling around.  There is a spot for it to be securely closed loop on the side of the phone holder where there is a Wire Collector, which essentially is a hold to plug the connector head into.  In looking at the wire, it looks pretty frail.  I had to be extra careful handling it and avoid getting it jammed by rotating the phone holder in one direction or the other.  I wish the coating of the wire had more thickness and toughness.  But the design of the monopod was to be small and thin, so this is what happens.  The cable coils out from the back of the top of the handle and leans towards the side.  Initially I didnt find much of a problem with this cable dangling around, but as I started to test and use the monopod, I frequently ran into the issue where when I rotated the phone holder back and forth, a part of the cable would get caught and jammed against the phone holder when trying to collapse it to a close and that got me concerned with damaging the internal wire of the cable.  It happened quite often when rotating the phone holder back and forth.  Same problem occurred, or got worse, when I did a closed loop to tuck the dangling 3.5mm connector into the wire collector.  It just easily gets in the way.  I suggest Taotronics improves on this feature by redesigning the location of where the cable comes out and where it settles when not used with the perspective of the rotation of the phone holder.MEASUREMENTS:3.55 mm connector stretches out to about 7 inches with of cable length based on my measurements.Shortest capture length from base of selfie stick is 6 inches.  Furthest capture length from fully expanded pole from base of selfie stick is about 23 inches.USAGE:Since this selfie stick didnt have any Bluetooth pairing involved, the setup process to get ready to use it was pretty easy.  The phone holder expands out to fit your phone in a landscape position.  For my test, I used an iPhone 5s that had a fully protective case installed on it already.  It fit into the phone holder just fine and the rubber grip of the phone holder allowed me to make adjustments to slide around the iPhone to get the right placement of it.  Next, I opened up the headphone jack cover of my case and plugged in the 3.5mm connector from the selfie stick into the headphone jack and tested pressing the capture button while in the Camera app.  It started to take pictures right away without any issues.Next, I tested changing the length of the pole and taking different selfies at different angles and heres where I ran into a minor problem.  When I had the pole not extended out and be fully collapsed, or when the selfie stick was extended out to about one level of extension, when I turned the selfie stick a little too much one side or another, the pole over rotated due to the weight of the smartphone and tiled more to the side than what I had wanted it to.  That happened quite frequently and my iPhone 5s is an older model of the iPhone series.  Just moving it one way or the other just dropped more weight and rotation of the pole to the same side with more movement than what I had wanted, which got a bit annoying.  It seemed like a defect.  I contacted Taotronics about it with some recorded videos.  I suggest Taotronics look into this to see if this is a design or assembly flaw with their units.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Small, lightweight, and thin2) Users no internal battery and is self-powered by your smartphone3) Easy to setup and get ready to capture photos4) Can be shared with multiple users with ease and not have to worry about repairing to other devices5) Smooth handle with a comfortable wrist wrapCONS:1) Handle of selfie stick is not comfortable for long term use and causes hand and wrist fatigue after a few minutes of taking photos2) Camera button has a stiffness feeling to it thats not as comfortable to press on as the older model TT-SH10.3) No fastener for the wrist wrap4) 3.5mm connector gets caught and jammed easily when rotating back and forth the phone holder5) Phone holder when tested doesnt provide a full 270 degree rotation6) Connector wire seems frail or sensitive to accidental damage like from jamming7) Found a defective issue with my unit where turning the selfie stick with the phone installed side to side caused the weight of the phone to cause the pole to over rotate beyond the stopping point of the turn8) Quick Start Guide got damaged from the current form of packagingSUGGESTIONS:1) Reprint the Quick Start Guide or increase the dimensions of the product box so that the guide doesnt have to be curved and bent up to fit the current dimensions of the box2) Add some grooves to the handles for a more ergonomic handheld grip to better fit the shape of the hand and fingers3) Adopt the current camera button design of the TT-SH10 or improve the current design on the TT-SH012 to have a better comfort and groove of the camera button4) Add a fastener to the wrist wrap to have a tight snug fit around the wrist when worn5) Redesign the selfie stick so that it can actually rotate a full 270 degrees and not come up shorter than that based on the Amazon product page product description6) Change the location of the 3.5mm connector, where it comes out, and where it settles when left unused to avoid getting jammed by the phone holder rotation7) Create a tighter lock of the extension pole with the base handle so that rotation of the stick with the phone installed does not cause the pole to move on its ownUSER SCENARIOS:This product would be useful for people who:1) Take lots of photos of their life2) Go on trips frequently3) Take selfie videos for Video Blogging4) Want to take photos with a wider angled shot of whats around themOverall, it did feel good taking several selfies without worry about battery life of the monopod.  If theres anything to be careful about, its that since this is designed to be small, thin, and compact, the full extension of the monopod may not be as good as other brands of selfie sticks.  So with a shorter extension, theres not as much of a wide coverage that your selfie captures will be able to take for group or scenic photos if youre looking for the capability of a wider depth shot.  But for other people, who may just want to take a picture of themselves or with a couple of friends, this selfie stick is tolerable.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to give a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  I am also providing this review to help prospective buyers make smart informed decisions.I hope you like my photos.Thanks for reading my review.

Hi,This is my review for the product listed on Amazon as:iPhone 5S Screen Protector, iPhone 5 Screen Protector - Maxboost iPhone 5S 5 5C Glass Screen Protector - [Tempered Glass] Worlds Thinnest Ballistics Glass, 99% Touch-screen Accurate, Round Edge [0.2mm] Ultra-clear Casings Glass Screen Protector Perfect Fit for Apple iPhone 5 / 5S / 5C Case Maximum Screen Protection from Bumps, Drops, Scrapes, and Marks (Lifetime No-Hassle Warranty)I received this product recently and had time to evaluate it today for a review.  I have also included a set of photos of the contents in case anyone is interested.UNBOXING AND OBSERVATIONS:Whats nice that Maxboost did was that it planned out the packaging well for a screen protector that can be bent, crushed, or mishandled by the shipper and handlers.  Not only did this product come in a padded envelope, when you open it up, then it has another additional layer of bubble wrap pouch that tucks a hard plastic shell case inside of it that unveils the screen protector contents.  So theres almost 3 layers of protection to the screen protector and contents there.In opening up the package, inside had the following:- Instruction and installation manual- Screen protector wrapped in a foam like pouch- Guided Stickers with dust sticker- One dry wipe and one wet wipeOne of the disappointing things about these contents is that there was no micro fiber cloth.  That was clearly stated in the video installation guide, as well as the printed install manual inside the package.  I later found out from contacting Maxboost customer service that their old package had the micro fiber cloth and they received customer complaints about it for some reason, so they decided to change it to these wet and dry wipes.  Im not sure why someone would complain over micro fiber cloths.  Those tend to be very useful and helpful.  Also, they are reusable and easy to wash, whereas these dry and wet wipes are onetime use.  I think Maxboost should update their printouts, videos, and product page to let users know about this.The installation video is very helpful and Im glad that Maxboost made one that clearly shows you how to install the screen protector for people who are new to the process like me.  I suggest Maxboost also provides a video to show to users how to cleanly uninstall, remove, and detach the screen protector if it was not applied correctly or got damaged to where it needs to be removed for replacement.Speaking of which, whats great about Maxboost is that they offer a lifetime warranty on their screen protectors.  What this means, as mentioned and clarified by consulting with Maxboost customer service, is that once you buy one of their screen protectors for a phone model, you just have to go on their website to fill out a warranty form with your Amazon order number, and then whenever your screen protector gets damaged from drops or accidents, you just have to contact them, take a picture of it, and theyll look you up to process a replacement.  Seeing how iPhones tend to be kept or held in value for at least 4 years for each model, that means that a $8 screen protector for the first initial cost will end up repaying for itself for however reckless you are with your phone for drops or damages to the screen.  I think that is great that Maxboost offers this.  I dont hear about other brands that sells screen protectors that offer a lifetime warranty like this with no fine line conditions to them.  You can replace them as many times as you want.  Good policy Maxboost.USAGE:Installing was straight forward given the printed and video instructions.  I used to have to rely on asking the Apple store to have their employees do these screen protectors installs so that I wouldnt mess them up myself, but seeing how theres a lifetime warranty on these from Maxboost and an easy to follow video, I felt more confident in installing this myself at home.First, you use the wet wipe to clean around the surface of your iPhone.  Then you use the dry wipe.  The dust sticker is then helpful to dab around for any remaining dust around.  I suggest to all users to try to find a room that doesnt have too much activity or motion going on.  And have the windows closed shut to avoid any dust or debris flying around in the air while this install is taking place.  After that, then you put the screen protector faced down with the peeler facing the phones screen.  Using the guided stickers, you line the screen protector up with the phones screen so that theres little to no difference to tape it down on one side.  After that, then you lift the other side of the screen protector, peel of the adhesive, and flatten back down the screen protector onto the phone case.  After that, Id leave it settled and use a credit card to swipe around to get rid of air bubbles before removing the guided stickers.  Quick polish and youre good to go.The benefit of having this screen protector is that theres a lot of iPhone cases out there which do not have raised edges in the front or its very minimal and exposes the iPhones screen to a direct face plants or angled impacts to risk damaging the screen.  Before this screen protector, I resorted to using a case with a built in screen protector plate as a 2-in-1 solution, but the case isnt attractive, and if I wanted a pretty case, I needed a screen protector or risk exposing the front screen to any scratches or damages.  Now with this Maxboost screen protector, I can buy pretty or attractive looking case designs to walk around with and have a front facing solution that provides a complete all around solution.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Install video is very helpful2) Lifetime warranty with unlimited replacements3) Guided stickers for easier matching and mirroring of the screen protector with the iPhone.CONS:1) No micro fiber cloth that was expected to be in the contents based on the printed guide and video install guide showing it in the package2) Dry and Wet wipe packages are hard to tear and remove.  Very resistant.SUGGESTIONS:1) Provide an uninstall and removal video for users who damage their screen protector or install it incorrectly.  This video would be useful for replacement processes.2) Update the printed manual, install video, and product page to state that new packages do not have the microfiber cloth and that it has been replaced with a dry wipe.USER SCENARIOS:People who would be interested in using this product are those who:1) Currently have no screen protection for their phone2) Dont want to keep having to repurchase screen protectors from brands that dont offer a long term warranty3) Dont currently own a case that has front facing protection for their phoneOverall, this screen protector and its contents are a useful solution for protecting the investment and value of the phone.  For an item that costs less than $10 and has lifetime warranty, youll get your $10 worth of damages and replacements overtime.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to give a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  I am also providing this review to help prospective buyers make smart informed decisions.I hope you like my photos.Thanks for reading my review.

Hi,This is my review for the product listed on Amazon as:Tablet Stand, TROND A1 Multi-Angle Portable Stand Holder for 3.5"-10" Tablets, Smartphones and E-Readers, Compatible with Apple iPad Air / Air 2, iPad Mini Retina 2, 3; iPhone 6 Plus 5s 5c 5 4S; Samsung Galaxy Tab 2, 3, 4, Note 3, 4, 8.0 10.1, S5 S4 S3; Google Nexus 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10; ASUS EeePad Transformer, Lenovo Tab, Kindle Voyage Paperwhite / Fire HD HDX (Black)I received this a while back and had time today to evaluate it for a detailed review.  I have also taken a series of photos if anyone is interested.  This product was tested using my iPhone 5s.UNBOXING AND OBSERVATIONS:This TROND product came in a simple boxed packaging where the label for the product wrapped over the opening lid of the box to create a seal to show that it is brand new.  The TROND brand name and model number is on the top of the box.  Certifications and approvals are on the front of the box.  Serial barcode is at the bottom.Opening the box reveals the stand wrapped in a plastic bag followed by the Welcome Guide underneath it.Although the stand seems pretty straight forward to use, I suggest all users to read through the Welcome Guide first prior to using it.Some important information in the Welcome Guide includes:Technical Specifications:Model: TROND A1Material: Aluminum & ABSCompatibility: 3.5 to 10 inch smartphones, e-readers & TabletsDimensions: 4.72 x 3.94 x 1.18 inchesNet Weight: 4.59 oz.In looking at the stand, all areas where the device rests on the stand has a layer of ABS rubber.  This is important when it comes to bare bone smartphones or tablets with no cases installed on them to avoid scratches to the device when resting and adjusting the device on the stand.The TROND logo is on the rubber padding that the device rests on.  Its pretty thick.  It is recommended to not pull the rubber padding off of the stand.  The way it feels on my fingers does not indicate that the side of the phone or tablet resting and moving on this pad can cause any scratches or damage to that device.The top of the stand has a rubber padding for the rotated angle that you can adjust for the stand to protect the top part of the phone or tablet resting on this.There are a pair of rubber stoppers on the bottom of the stand, but its fairly minimal and based on my tests dragging or pushing the stand back and forth on the tabletop, it didnt do much use to where youd notice immediately the benefits of those rubber stoppers.The Aluminum body of the stand has a tough and glossy look to it, which some may find desirable.  I just noticed that while handling the stand, that my finger prints causes grease like stains on the stand that is easily captured when handling the stand normally.The back of the stand has a circular cutout portion of the back support of the stand that serves the purpose of being able to charge your phone or tablet while using the stand, which can happen to drain easily while using the stand to do FaceTime or Video Chat.One of the things that I felt fortunate about was that based on the cutout designs of this stand, nothing felt sharp or abrasive while rubbing around and holding anywhere on this stand.  Everything is rounded and smoothened out, which is a plus.USAGE:One of the things I knew was a limitation before getting the stand was that theres a limit of 60 degrees that this thing can tilt back on.  To some people who eventually use the stand with their camera, thats not too big of a deal.  However, I do know some brands who have stands like this that offer 325 degrees of free rotation, which can be handy for situations depending on what youre recording or taking a picture of.  I hope TROND updates this product with a more flexible range of adjustment with the angles.But with the limitation, I was able to adjust the stand so that I could rest my phone or tablet closer to vertical while still having the tablet stand stand up on its own, however, there was some sensitive stability issues.  But if you left everything alone and just played the video or took the photo with a tap on the screen, then it holds up just fine.Adjustments while the phone or tablet is settled on the stand should be with both hands, one to hold the phone or tablet, and the other to pull the back support leg of the stand.Moving the rotator was very easy and did not cause much resistance.  I was also able to readjust the rotation many times without seeing any obvious wear or tear of the rotator.The angle from near vertical to 60 degrees and how it should be used is user specific.  For me, I was sitting at the dinner table with this a couple of feet away from my body and near vertical captured my jacket and not my face.  However, the maximum extension of 60 degrees captured my face, but aimed too high and capture much of the unnecessary background.  It also shot up towards my nostril as well which was not welcomed.  But trying it on more elevated surfaces ended up being a better experience.  The angle will vary on the tabletop height that you have the stand on in comparison to whether youre standing or sitting.I used my FaceTime to record myself while having the phone on landscape resting on the rubber pad and having it at the maximum angle of 60 degrees.  Overall, it worked out quite nicely and is a definite improvement to what I was using before to capture myself, which was a selfie stick.  This is much different from a selfie stick because I can free up my hand that normally holds the stick to do more with myself in the video.  Also, this tablet stand can be placed far away in the background to catch a group or social moment going on within range without having to hold onto it.  For indoor use or outdoor use that doesnt require travel or movement, then this tablet stand is definitely preferable choice for photos and recording.  If youre walking around, then a selfie stick would make sense.I tested out poking through the charging cable from connecting it to my iPhone to pulling the cable through the hole on the back leg support of the stand to plug in.  That worked with little to no issues.  The charging cable has to bend and curve backwards and is something that would make sense for a phone thats in portrait position.  Otherwise, if youre going to do a wide shot on a landscape, you dont need to feed the cable through the hole because the cable will have free access and movement from the side of the stand.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Rubber padding allows unprotected devices to get comfort being rested on the stand without risk of damage2) Hole in the back leg support of the stand provides a solution for some who like to charge their devices while using the stand3) Stand holds up on its own without falling when angled near vertical thanks to the bottom supportCONS:1) Side edges of the aluminum portion of the stand can feel a bit roughSUGGESTIONS:1) Increase the angled ability for the rotation of the stand to match competitive brands that allow up to 325 degrees of rotatable ability2) Increase the thickness and placement of the rubber stopper on the front leg support of the standUSER SCENARIOS:This product would be useful for people who:1) Like to take photos2) Like to take videos3) Like to FaceTime or Video Chat4) Are holding a special social event that theyd like to capture a memory ofOverall, this product is a good starter for tablet stands to model behind.  I find this to be very helpful and useful for those who are confident in themselves to capture themselves, their family, or their friends in the moment to hold memories of on their phone or tablet.  But Id like to see TROND upgrade this stand so that it can support a larger angle that makes it competitive with other brands of tablet stands.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to give a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  I am also providing this review to help prospective buyers make smart informed decisions.I hope you like my photos.Thanks for reading my review.

Hi,This is my review for the Taotronics TT- SH13 Bicycle Mount Holder.  It is listed on Amazon as:TaoTronics Bicycle Mount Holder Cradle for Smartphone, GPS and other Devices (One-button Release, 360 Rotatable, Rubber Strap)I received this product last week and had time today to evaluate it on a bike for review.  I have also taken a set of photos of how the product looks like out of the box and when installed on a bike for anyone who is interested.UNBOXING AND OBSERVATIONS:The product box itself is very simple and Taotronics wasted no time trying to make a flashy presentation.  After all, its whats inside that matters.  Still, I wouldve liked to see more around the box to make it more appealing.  The front of the box has a sketched drawing of the product with the Taotronics brand name and model number TT-SH013.  The side has the serial number barcode.  The back of the box has e-mail and phone contact information for North America, Europe, and Asia.Inside the box were a few items which included a cradle, clamp and rubber grip.  The clamp already had preinstalled the orange colored rubber grip.  Taotronics was nice enough to provide a black colored rubber grip for users preferences, but to swap that out requires a Philips screwdriver and some steps that the User Manual doesnt state.Since this was a totally new product to me, I went ahead and read the Users Manual to become familiar with the item prior to installing it.  The Users Manual doesnt describe everything in detail, so its best to consult with other users experiences within the Amazon product page community as well.So first looking at the cradle.  This cradle is interesting because it has a few features.  Theres the release button which will take the side holders and slowly expand them with a mechanical movement to fully open it wide so that it can fit certain smartphones and tablets in a portrait position.  It doesnt require any battery power to do so.  Its all mechanical.  You can collapse the side holders by pinching both sides that will create a cranking sound in doing so.  One of the things I didnt like about the release button is that it made a squealing sound whenever I pressed it and it was repetitive.  To most people it wouldnt be an issue and only noticed in a quiet environment, but for a product coming out of the box, I was expecting to have no defective issues.  I suggest Taotronics be careful about the assembly of their products to avoid this squealing.Whats neat about the cradle is that theres a bottom piece that folds out if you flick it out that serves as a bottom tray to hold the phone.  So now you have three sides that hug the phone together which gives a nice tighter fit from being shaken around and falling out of the cradle.Theres a lot of rubberized padding and designs to grip the phone thats on the cradle.  On the backside is a circular piece of rubber with a design pattern for grip onto the backside of the phone.  On both sides of the holder are teeth like rubberized patterns that help grip it like clenching the phone with your fingers.  They are safe on the phone and give a secure but massaging like feeling when rubbing them against your fingers.Taotronics has its logo on the bottom tray flap that closes up.On the back of the cradle are 4 key like patterns for inserting the clamp onto the cradle.The clamp itself comes preinstalled with the rubber grip and is loosened up already.  Theres a lock knob thats below the jaw of the clamp that can be spun in one direction to open up the mouth of the clamp more, while the other direction is to close the clamp shut when it is on the handlebar of the bike.  The lock knob can be folded up as well if need be.Inside the clamp has a rubberized padding with grooves in it to match the shape of the bikes handlebar while not causing any friction that could scratch up the handlebar.Clearly, Taotronics did a good job so far in this observation of how it placed rubberized patterns in places on the mount to provide a secure fit and traction against the devices or parts while avoiding it to cause any scratches on those as well.USAGE:Before directly applying the mount to the bike handle, I tested assembling and disassembling it a few times to get used to it and so that I can show it to others how to get it done since the visuals in the Users Manual are not fully clear.I tested installing a Samsung Galaxy S4 smartphone to the cradle.  To insert it, I pressed the release button to fully expand it and then flicked open the bottom tray to have it rest into the cradle while pinking the sides mechanically shut to squeeze along all 3 sides of the phone.  What I found out from this method was that when I have the phone sit into the bottom tray, that raises the height of where the top rubber grip corners could stretch to wrap over the corners while making the bottom corners with the longer grip too loose.  I think the bottom tray serves the purpose of certain types of cell phones and smartphones, but it was not compatible with the Samsung Galaxy smartphone because if I used the bottom tray, it was not possible to stretch the rubber grip corners at the top without possibly damaging it past elasticity.  That was how the top felt and I tried hard to wrap it over but couldnt do it.So instead, I took out the phone, flicked the bottom tray to close and then reinserted the phone into the cradle and centered it before pinking the sides of the holder shut to give a secure fit.  When I did this, then the rubber grip on the top and bottom corners were able to wrap over and give a secrete fit.I tried to shake the cradle around with the phone mounted back and forth, rocking it back and forth and moving it in different motions.  It was secure in place without any budge, which is great because if theres ever an impact or collision with the bike having this mount on, I wouldnt want the phone to be sailing off in the air and having a bad drop impact.After I installed the phone to the cradle, I looked at the clamp and saw how the 4 keys lined up to the holes behind the cradle.  You first push it in and then once all 4 keys are in, then you push up to secure it in the design to tentatively lock it in place so that it doesnt move around.  To detach the cradle, then you just reverse the motion by pushing down and then pulling out to separate the two pieces apart.Next up was the clamp.  The clamp was straight forward because it was already twisted mostly to have the jaws open.  I just twisted the bottom some more to loosen it up and then I took out a bike and tried it on the front center handle bar, which fit just fine.  Then while holding it still, I turned the bottom lock knob several circles until I couldnt turn it anymore.  The lock knob can fold inwards, but I found that if I do that, I had to loosen the screw some more to fold it in, and in doing so, that caused the clamp to slip from grip of the handle bar and move around, which isnt what I wanted to do, so I left it flipped outwards and tightened it all the way.Once it was secure, everything felt pretty good.  I tested with someone messaging on the phone and navigation while on the bike.  It did not slip off or have any issues.  It felt like a good mount that locked up tight.Whats a neat feature about this mount is that the 360 rotation allows the user to be able to put their phone in landscape or portrait display depending on what they do with their phone.  Or you can have it at a slanted angle if thats what youd like to do.  Its pretty free form and moves clockwise or counterclockwise without much effort.  But I found that the rotation worked only once the cradle was connected to the clamp.I decided to leave it on that way and leave the bike in the garage so that I wouldnt have to loosen it and reapply it.  It became part of the accessory thats permanently on the bike and will be good for most year around trips, with the exception of the rainy days that will be coming up in which will not protect the phone from water damage.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Rubberized design with the intent for secure protection and prevention of damage onto surfaces2) Neat mechanical design for having a single push button for slowly expanding the holder with a simple compression spring to pinch it tight for a snug fit of the device3) Comes with a spare color change rubber grip for different styles for bikes4) Secure grip to the bikes handlebar with the clamp5) Simple rotation to change orientation of the app or video that is being watched while on the bikeCONS:1) Lock knob does not fold in when securing a tight twist and requires to loosen it up to fold it correctly, but in doing so, causes a weak and slippery grip to the handlebar of the bike.2) Bottom tray usage doesnt allow the compatibility of the rubber grips to fit up and over the corners of the smartphone used for testing because it becomes off center in the placement of the phone with respect to the locations of the rubber grips3) Squealing noise can be heard whenever the release button is usedSUGGESTIONS:1) A redesign may be needed for the bottom tray or stating what devices are compatible to use it so that the rubber grips fit all along the corners2) Provide instructions for the use of the release button, 360 rotations, and replacing the rubber grip with the one provided in the boxUSER SCENARIOS:People who could use this product are those who:1) Ride a bike (obviously)2) Are bikers who need navigation or entertainment while riding around using their phone3) Are bikers who need access to their phone without stopping to reach from their pockets4) Are bikers with little to no pocket access on their clothes for phones or mobile devicesOverall, this is a neat product for a new category from Taotronics.  They did a pretty good job with their first design of this product, but as I suggested, more improvements can be made to make it an even better experience.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to give a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  I am also providing this review to help prospective buyers make smart informed decisions.I hope you like my photos.Thanks for reading my review.

Hi,This is my review for the product listed on Amazon as:EasyAcc Monster 20000mAh Power Bank (4A Input 4.8A Smart Output) External Battery Portable Charger for Android Phone Samsung - Black and OrangeI received this product a couple of weeks ago and have used it a few times to provide a detailed review.  I have included a set of photos that I have taken in case anyone is interested.UNBOXING AND OBSERVATIONS:The product comes in a very simple cardboard box that has no graphical designs on it.  If it was in a retail store, I wouldve passed by it.  But the presentation on the Amazon product page is what sells and when receiving this product box, the intention in my opinion is to use this product out of the box and discard the box.The top of the box has the brand name and model number of the power bank.  The right side had the serial number barcode.  The bottom of the box has some feature summary and example of compatible products for this power bank.  Basically, any mobile device that uses a USB Type A connector to charge the product can be used with this power bank.Upon opening the box, I found the power bank was wrapped in a plastic bag to protect it from dust and fingerprints by the factory or shipper.  In taking that out, I found the User Manual underneath with 2 micro USB cables that were in a hidden compartment that had to be lifted out of the layer of cardboard in the interior.  Everything was tightly snug when packaged.The first thing I recommend on doing is reading the users manual to be aware of how to use the product and what it can and cant do.  Some notable information includes:Smart Technology is built into this power bank.  What that means is that while the total output is capable of 4.8A max based on the technical specifications, plugging in devices that have less output will charge at their optimal rates based on the power banks chip detecting what type of device youve plugged into it.  So if I have an iPhone 5s and plug this in, it will charge at about 1A.The input is 4A with the use of two USB charging ports.  That is quite impressive as Ive used other power banks of heavy capacity thats 8000mAh and up from other brands like RavPower and HisGadget and they only provide a 1A to 2A port to charge at best and because of that, it can take easily 8-12 hours to fully charge from empty.  That means that if you have to go do something the next day and want one of those charged and ready for use at full capacity, rather than waiting until you go to sleep to start charging it like how you would with your phone or tablet, youd have to start charging it during your dinner time or well before that, and thats not something most people would think of doing during their busy lives.  So I was disappointed in those specs for other power banks from other brands, but here with the EasyAcc power bank model, it is stated that it will fully charge in 6 hours, which for 20000mAh, this is much more reasonable and bearable to deal with for overnight charging.There are a total of 4 Smart Output ports with a total output of 4.8A max.  That seems reasonable because anything more than that will just cause the power bank to get sensitive to getting too hot and deplete too quickly.  With 4.8A, that means that it is possible to charge 4 smartphones like 4 iPhones or Android phones since those usually charge at 1A each.  But with 4.8A, it is also possible to charge 2 tablets as well, but Its likely that you will not be able to fully charge two tablets to full, but more of giving an increased partial charge for both devices.A cool feature that will be tested later is the LED light thats built in as an additional feature for emergency lighting with this power bank.  I found power banks with an LED lighting can come in handy as an integrated feature for emergency situations, like power outages or doing something simple like looking for something in your car, or looking at a lock.Although its possible to charge the power bank at 4A max with 2 USB ports charging at 2A each, it is possible if youre limited with your settings or environment to just use one of the two ports and charge at 1A or 2A depending on if youve plugged it into the wall with a wall charger or own a charging station.  I would not charge this with the USB port from a laptop or computer because that will be a very slow charge that would drive you nuts.Technical Specifications for this product include:Capacity: 20000Mah/74WhBattery Type: Lithium ionInput: DC 5V 4A(max)Output: DC 5V 4.8(max)Size: 6.57 x 3.15 x 0.86inWeight: 454g/16 oz.There is a map in the User Manual that describes the 4 LED dotted indicators on the power bank and what they represent in terms of battery life remaining.  Each dot represents within a 25% range.The Power Bank will cut the energy output within 30 seconds once the devices have been fully disconnected from the power bank or fully charged.The product comes with a 12-month warranty, which should be sufficient time for anyone to use this product about once a week and see if theres any unexpected issues that may arise to report it and get the power bank replaced or fixed.Now in looking at the power bankI chose the Orange and Black color combination for this product because Ive had so many of my electronic products be a black or gray solid color that I wasnt something that could stand out and look fairly attractive.  This model does come in a Black and Gray colored combination, but I didnt opt in for that one.With the Black and Orange combination, the top and bottom of the power bank is in black while the mid layer lining is in orange, which includes that being the color surrounding the power button and USB ports.The top of the power bank has the EasyAcc logo engraved and the 4 dotted LEDS are in the opposite corner.Below the LED area is the power button ON/OFF on the side of the power bank.  You can press it on/off with a single press or double press to turn on or off the LED flashlight.On the opposite side of the power button are the 2 USB ports for charging, which is labeled as IN.  They use Micro USB connectors as inputs, so you can use the two provided by EasyAcc in the package, which are short in length for packaging and convenience, or you can get your own 3 to 10 feet micro USB cables and charge the power bank that way.There are 4 USB ports and the flashlight lens on the narrower side.  The output ports are labeled as SMART.  I wouldve liked to see the LED flashlight lens be dipped in more than it currently is by design.  That way, if you drop the power bank and it lands on the floor on that side, it doesnt end up chipping or cracking the lens.  The way it looks like now, I can glaze my finger over the surface of the power bank and hit the bulge of the lens.  I wouldve liked to see the lens be more protective by dipping it into the grove more by about  of an inch.  I offer that as a suggestion for improvement.If you were to lose the users manual, the bottom of the power bank has some etching of the technical specs for the power bank which may come in handy one day.The power bank can stand on any of its side that you put it in, but in this case, since the power bank is fairly heavy and is rectangular shaped, it would make since for it to lie flat down on the fat sides rather than have it stand on the thin sides.The overall look of the power bank under lighting has a slight shine to it under the reflection of the light.  It has a nice smooth feeling, not necessarily a slick polished feeling, but it is smooth and feels nice.  You can get a little friction on it with rubbing your thumb and fingers on it back and forth while holding it in one hand.  Because of how wide the power bank is, I cant clench my fingers together to create a closed grip, but the grip side to side is good enough to hold in your hand and walk around with you for a minimal amount of time.  It stands out quite nicely on my desktop to quickly identify it over my other mobile accessories, which is a plus.USAGE:My power bank unit came fully charged, so I tested it under a full load by plugging in a variety of mobile accessories.  In my photos, youll see that I plugged in two Bluetooth speakers, a selfie stick, and a Bluetooth headphone.  Immediately when I plugged them in, they started to charge and I could tell with the charge light.  I left them there while heading out for a couple of hours and when I came back, they were all fully charged and the lights were all turned off.  I tested the charged products and they were good to go.  The power bank still had 4 LED dotted lights on it due to these devices having little battery capacities compared to an iPhone or iPad, which would drain it more.  But overall testing showed that all 4 ports were functioning normally as expected and charging sufficiently.The next thing that I did was try the LED flashlight.  I turned off the lights in my area to see the deep contrast in the lighting from a dark place.  I double pressed the power button and turned on the LED light.  Id have to say that my first impressions were that this is a good lighting source when needed for looking around the house.  The light from far away hitting the wall about 20 feet from my spot showed the light was dim but helped me visibly identify surroundings and objects about 10 feet in diameter.  On the other hand, I could bring it to hone in on something just within 6 inches from the source that I wanted to focus on and the light is bright as an ordinary standalone flashlight.  Its pretty impressive for a power bank.  Ive used power banks from other brands that have had LED flashlights built into them and theyre nowhere near as strong or useful as this EasyAcc model.  Now, I wouldnt use this as a primary flashlight as there are better ones out there, but for a convenient access to a source of lighting for emergency situations, this products flashlight will do.IN SUMMARY:PROS:1) Meets the need for a large family2) High battery capacity can charge a tablet to full with room to spare for charging smartphones3) Useful built in flashlight that can provide adequate lighting for emergency situations4) Shorter charging rate compared to other brandsCONS:1) Flashlight lens curves out too close to the surface of the side of the power bank, making it likely to absorb some impact damage if dropped from a tall height and landing on different hard surfaces.SUGGESTIONS:1) Provide a travel carrying pouch for this power bank2) Dip the flashlight lens further by about a quarter of an inch to provide the curvature of the lens to have greater protection from drop testing impact when landing on that side with the ground3) Add a digital display of battery remaining rather than using LED dot indicatorsUSER SCENARIOS:This product would be useful for people who:1) Live with a family or roommates2) Plan to go on a road trip or outdoor trip with friends or family3) Own power hungry devices such as a tablet4) Have many different mobile products that are USB based for charging5) Dont have available access to wall outlet sockets or a power stripOverall, this is a major improvement in the power banks category for EasyAcc, a company of which I did not like originally when I first tried their 6400mAh model.  There have been much better improvements since then in their product line of power banks and chargers.  This one easily beats out at least two other brands of power banks that Ive tried of near the same range of battery capacity.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer to give a detailed review of the user experience and how to improve the product.  I am also providing this review to help prospective buyers make smart informed decisions.I hope you like my photos.Thanks for reading my review.
